entry.title: Peking University Lecture: How Does NetEase Design Social Systems for its MMO Games? (Media Article)
entry.content:
Note: This article is a reprint from the WeChat public account “手游那些事” (shouyou naxie shi - “Those Things About Mobile Games”). The content is compiled from a collaborative course between NetEase Leihuo Games and Peking University, with Leihuo User Experience Center participating in the user research part of the sharing.

It is well known that NetEase’s MMO products have always performed very well, with many products firmly ranking at the top of the grossing charts. For example, one of its flagship products, A Chinese Ghost Story mobile game, has been online for two years and still ranks in the top 10 of the Chinese App Store’s top-grossing games.

The secret of A Chinese Ghost Story, as a two-year-old “old game”, is still able to capture users lies in its social system. On the Internet, A Chinese Ghost Story mobile game is jokingly referred to by some players as a large-scale social dating mobile game—this to some extent reflects the weight of the social system in this game. In the industry, A Chinese Ghost Story mobile game has also been known for its excellent social design.

In the recent collaborative course between NetEase Leihuo Games and Peking University, Yao Yuan, the lead planner of A Chinese Ghost Story, shared her views on “the essence of game user experience” and the methods and principles of game social gameplay design; Liu Yongcheng, head of Leihuo UX User Experience Center, shared how UX business provides scientific data support for user experience design.

The following is a compilation of the content of the class:

I. “Only Attracting Players is the Only Criterion for Judging the Excellence of a Game”

The user experience we usually talk about is about the user’s personal feelings, mainly emphasizing the user’s emotions and feelings. In a broad sense, user experience includes everything that players feel in the game, including visual experience, story experience, social experience, combat experience, growth experience, and so on.

There used to be a saying in game development: fun is the only criterion for testing a game. In Yao Yuan’s view, this statement is no longer suitable for current games. Attracting players is the only criterion for judging the excellence of a game.

How can we attract players? That is to meet the needs of users.

Yao Yuan led the audience to review the history of Richard Bartle, Nick Yee and others in the study of player needs and motivations. Based on the theory of evolution, she discussed the essence of games from a unique perspective—games are actually simulations of reality, and players are actually conducting preparedness environmental adaptation training. Starting from the essence of the game, Yao Yuan summarized the universal player needs into three points: competence, relatedness, and autonomy.

II. How to Conduct User Experience Design from a Product Perspective?

Among the three player needs, relatedness is the most basic one. Relatedness is generated by social interaction, and in game design, social interaction is a very important part of user experience design.

So how does A Chinese Ghost Story design its social system? Yao Yuan mainly shared the following three points.

  1. Social Interaction is Based on Player Identity Recognition, and Name is an Important Expression Tool

It can be said that the social relationships of current domestic games are very complicated. Friends, mentors and apprentices, sworn brothers, couples, teams, groups… a wide variety, like a deluxe family bucket. However, in all current MMO games, these are already standard.

Everyone is doing social networking and wants to integrate all relationships into the game. But few people consider from the very beginning of game social interaction why social interaction is generated.

Yao Yuan first explained the essence of social interaction from a biological perspective: “When I was doing my Ph.D., I studied a kind of woodpecker. They are polygamous and live together without shame. During our research, we came up with a hypothesis that if this species has a highly socialized society, each of its individuals should be identifiable. Because only when individuals are identified can all their subsequent relationships, or strategies based on individuals, be possible. Therefore, the beginning of social interaction is the identification of identity. Identity is very important.”

Social interaction is based on identity recognition, so how is it reflected in the game? Yao Yuan took Chen Xinghan’s new work “Sky: Children of the Light” as an example to explain the importance of names for game player identity recognition.

In “Sky: Children of the Light”, everyone’s character looks the same. But when the player’s friendship with a character increases, the player can give the other party a name. “At this time, this person has a completely different meaning to you. You can see him from a long distance, and you can see him among a group of people, knowing that you have soared in the clouds together. For players in the game world, compared to the more versatile appearance, the name is a particularly good tool to express personal identity.”

In addition, Yao Yuan also shared an idea about setting the length of the name: “The space of mobile games is limited. If the name is too long, it will definitely affect the length of the information displayed later, and if it is too short, it will not be enough to express personal characteristics. But seven characters is a seven-character poem length for Chinese people, which is a very good format for players to name and express their inner feelings. Therefore, the name length of our A Chinese Ghost Story mobile game is finally set to seven characters, which is a little less than the PC version.”

  1. Social Immersion is More Important than Visual and Narrative Immersion

In the game, making social connections is like the process of “establishing connections” described in “The Little Prince”. This process requires a certain social space, that is, it is necessary to give players a chance to settle their social relationships. “In the game, we need to let two people see each other and understand each other’s characteristics at the same time or in the same space, which can already provide them with a very good social space.”

How to use elements in the game to create a social space for players? Yao Yuan used the chat channel of A Chinese Ghost Story as an example.

Due to the space limitations of the mobile game interface, most of the real-time games on the market will shrink the chat channel to a button on the main interface, and players will only see the chat channel when they click the button. But A Chinese Ghost Story places the chat channel at the bottom of the game’s main interface in order to enhance the player’s social immersion.

“Maybe the information displayed here is not enough, but for players, they can find that there are always active players talking in the world.” Usually, most games emphasize the immersion of game plots and visuals, but Yao Yuan believes that for MMORPG games, social immersion is much more important than immersion in visuals and stories.

  1. Design Social Gameplay by Considering Players’ Emotional Needs and “Labeling”

A Chinese Ghost Story mobile game also has unique “tips” when designing social gameplay.

First of all, when making game content, it is necessary to consider its positioning and what kind of emotions and needs the players involved will have.

In class, Yao Yuan threw out a question: “If you design a wedding system in an online game, what content do you think should be put in?” As soon as the question came out, the students below spoke up. Some said that there should be a wedding parade, some said that there should be invitations and dresses—these are common elements of wedding systems in MMO games already on the market.

“Actually, we have implemented all the above functions in the game, but we have specially made a function in the wedding, that is, players can kill people in this scene.” Yao Yuan said an interesting setting in the wedding gameplay of A Chinese Ghost Story mobile game. This answer is something most people did not expect.

“Actually, this is a strong interaction between players: to kill him. This is also the experience we have gained from playing games before: single players who come to watch the ceremony, out of the spirit of the FFF group, will especially want to kill the newlyweds; on the other hand, the newlyweds may also want to show ‘the couple work together, and their strength can break gold’—therefore, the wedding scene is often also a scene of tragedy, and all players have a very happy melee together.” This experience is to a certain extent similar to the process of guests making trouble in the bridal chamber in reality, achieving the same effect by “killing people”, so this seemingly strange gameplay can be recognized by players.

Secondly, when making social gameplay, it is necessary to add an emotional or experience label to the gameplay at the beginning of the design, as the basic purpose and principle of making this type of gameplay.

Regarding this method, Yao Yuan used the “Monk System” in A Chinese Ghost Story mobile game as an example. From the PC version to the mobile version, A Chinese Ghost Story will set up a “strange” “Monk System”: once the player feels that he has seen through the world of mortals, he can go to the abbot of Bao’en Temple to apply for monkhood. After becoming a monk, you can only sweep the floor, chant scriptures, and ring the bell in the temple. Most of the time, you cannot leave the scene, cannot complete daily tasks, cannot marry, cannot become sworn brothers, and cannot kill people.

In many cases, when players have the idea of churning in the game, they may not necessarily want to leave the game, but just need a way to vent their emotions, and to get some attention and comfort. Therefore, “becoming a monk” is actually a process for players to act like a spoiled child to their friends, and a way to meet the player’s need to “be valued”. This is reflected in the friend interaction in the “Monk System”: for example, when player A becomes a monk, the system will push this message to his friends, and friends can redeem the monk player by donating incense money. This system sounds completely “anti-social”. Apart from gaining an immersive experience of “becoming a monk”, this system is negative for social interaction and even for game experience. So why design such a system? What kind of emotional label is given to it? The answer is something that many people can’t think of—Tsundere.

In addition, Yao Yuan also used the question-answering system in A Chinese Ghost Story mobile game with “recognition” and “topic” as labels, the imperial examination system with “timeliness” as a label, and the guild flower battle gameplay with “noise” as a label to illustrate the importance of labeling when designing social gameplay.

When all the labels are integrated, it will eventually create a A Chinese Ghost Story social system formed by real players, with its unique game temperament. Compared to a sophisticated and luxurious but indifferent metropolis, it is more like a small town full of human touch—you often meet acquaintances on the street, and you can chat about gossip when you meet. In the real world, this feeling may only be rooted in the memories of our parents or when we were young. But in the world of A Chinese Ghost Story, it belongs to the young people’s world, rooted in Chinese culture, and has a lively and bustling atmosphere.

In the end, Yao Yuan summarized how to start to improve the player’s game experience:

First, we need to analyze the needs of players and recognize the needs of players.

Second, we ourselves must also actively practice and invest in experiencing the game, and iterate the game based on the feedback of the gameplay.

Third, any design we make must be based on rational analysis, including emotional experience factors are also part of our rational analysis.

Finally, please remember, “The player is always your best friend.” Stand with the users, understand their needs, and put people first, this is the foundation of all user experience design.

III. UX Business Provides Scientific Data for User Experience Design

After Yao Yuan talked about game user experience and the design of social gameplay in A Chinese Ghost Story from the product direction, Liu Yongcheng, head of Leihuo User Research Center, explained how UX business systematically forms user experience support from the perspective of the work of the user experience department. “The product is a decision-maker, and the user experience is a supporter. User experience is also the last specialized game profession to enter the game industry in the entire game industry.”

The work goal of the user experience department is to use scientific methods to form qualitative and quantitative data to provide decision support, thereby connecting players and game development groups.

Liu Yongcheng said that during the testing period of A Chinese Ghost Story mobile game, the user experience department conducted several tests, continuously analyzing the causes of player churn, public opinion, player behavior in the game, game problems, and the highlights of alternative competing products, and visualized them through the data platform. These have played a very important role in the design of the game’s social gameplay and the improvement of the product.

From the content of Yao Yuan and Liu Yongcheng’s lectures, the reasons for the success of A Chinese Ghost Story mobile game in game social interaction can ultimately be attributed to two major aspects—people-oriented social design concepts and scientific user experience data.

entry.title: Talking About Design Questioning - IXDC 2018 Summary Sharing (Part 1)
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

The IXDC International Experience Design Conference is one of the most prestigious design conferences in the industry. Every year, it invites many industry leaders and experts to share cutting-edge design achievements and the latest design cases through keynote speeches and workshops. As a newbie in the design industry, I have long been yearning for this conference. Last year, I finally had the honor to participate for the first time. During the 4-day conference, I gained a lot. Below I will share some of my gains from this conference.

Talking About Design Questioning

The first workshop I attended was presented by Li Yue, a senior user experience designer at Didi Chuxing’s CDX, titled “Making Good Use of the [Experience + Data Dual-Drive Model] to Derive Good Design”. It mainly used two cases to illustrate how to combine one’s own work and experience preferences to build a design thinking model suitable for oneself, and how to use the design model to guide the design and derive more effective design solutions. I think the biggest gain from this is not the design model itself, but the thinking about the essence of design and the most important and easily overlooked point in the design process: design questioning.

At the beginning, Mr. Li introduced the Double Diamond design model proposed by the British Industrial Design Association, as shown in the figure. In this course, we mainly involved the two parts in the red box.

 

A Little Story

Let’s start with a little story. A bird is flying and is very thirsty. At this time, it finds a bottle on the ground, and there is water in the bottle. How can the bird drink the water in the bottle? At that time, everyone put forward their own solutions, and almost everyone’s solutions focused on how to solve the problem of the contact point between the bird and the bottle. But if we look closely at this question, is it essentially the bird’s need?

 

As shown in the figure, through design questioning, we find that the bird’s idea of drinking water from the bottle is essentially the bird’s thirst need. Then, only by solving this essential need can the bird be most satisfied, so the path to solving the problem is broader.

 

Let’s interpret it in detail with cases.

Case 1

 

Xiaoju Flash Report is Didi’s internal reimbursement software, but recently their product team is not very happy, because colleagues in the company are complaining: “It’s so difficult to use!”

 

In response to this problem, Didi’s design team also used the 5 Whys method to ask the root cause.

 

From the questioning process, we found a very interesting point. The new functions added by the product side to improve product satisfaction have reduced the user experience of the product. Then everyone should think carefully, what is the design purpose of this product?

Improve employee reimbursement efficiency

After determining the design goal, the next step is to determine the users. The main users of reimbursement apps include three groups:

 

The specific design part is not closely related to the theme of this sharing, so it will not be repeated.

Case 2

 

Jushi Recorder is a car video recorder launched by Didi, but recently their product side is also not very happy, because too few videos are successfully extracted from the recorder.

 

In response to this problem, the Didi design team also used the 5 Whys method to ask the root cause.

 

Through this questioning, we established the goal of the product:

Improve the success rate of uploading appeal videos

But why do we need to achieve this goal? We need to continue to ask.

 

In this way, we will gain a more comprehensive understanding of the problem and know exactly what aspects need to be optimized in the design.

 

Summary

In fact, in everyone’s daily life, they often directly receive the needs of the product or planning side and start designing directly. This can easily lead to the later discovery that the content carefully designed by oneself is not what the demander wants, and then fall into the situation of constantly changing. In fact, this is also due to insufficient requirement mining and failure to discover the real essential needs of the demander. When encountering problems, we must ask more questions. It is not only to help the demander diagnose whether it is a pseudo-requirement, but also to understand the problem more comprehensively in this process, so as to determine the design goal and complete the design that satisfies both parties.

entry.title: Observations from Overseas Testing in Japan
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

In April, Hangzhou was already warm and blossoming, starting to move towards summer. I boarded a plane to Tokyo wearing clothes for the approaching summer. However, upon landing, I was greeted by cold rain and wind.

The next day, the street intercept test in Tokyo officially began. Walking out of the place where I was staying, I felt the chill of winter, a cold that even a suit jacket couldn’t block. Tokyo seemed to want to hinder our testing in this way. But would we be choked like this?

No.

The original plan for street intercept testing on the ordinary streets of Akihabara was changed by us, because most of the passers-by were in a hurry and were completely unwilling to stay on the road for even a second.

I began to look for positions at the station that could block some of the wind, waiting for an opportunity to find pedestrians who seemed to be idle. At the same time, as opportunities became fewer, the cafes next to the station also became places I tried.

In addition, in order to increase the success rate and sample size, I asked classmates to conduct intercepts at their alma mater’s campus in Tokyo and at the entrances of stations around the campus.

With three approaches, the subsequent intercept tests became relatively smooth.

Although there were difficulties in the next two days of interceptions, we successfully overcame them and exceeded the established goals.

In summary:

  1. When there are uncertain factors interfering with the test, different strategies should be considered, even changing the tactical direction, to ensure the completion of the established goals.

  2. To increase the effective sample size, hiring part-time students and conducting very strict training before they start intercepting is also a good compensation method.

  3. Overseas testing is very different from domestic testing. For example, Japanese people attach great importance to privacy, so when it becomes increasingly apparent that this is an issue during the testing process, it is also very important to promptly revise questions involving privacy, which can increase the probability of success.

  4. Street intercepts may encounter various types of players. Maintain a good attitude, stay calm and deal with it, and strive to complete the test goals.

entry.title: Observations from Overseas Testing in the United States
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Last time we shared our observations from player testing in Japan. This time, we want to share some observations from testing in the United States. For this test, we chose Los Angeles as the location, and the testing requirements were to conduct a novice test and a UI interface test for a game.

Test Preparation

Upon receiving the request, I felt a bit nervous. Testing novices? Does that mean we need to find a good coffee shop and prepare some ‘Fat Otaku Happy Water’ (soda, a common term for sugary drinks in some gaming communities.) so that foreigners can sit comfortably and play games? Wouldn’t that mean we have to start making appointments with players in China?

After some intense brainstorming, we finally decided to conduct the test in the form of lab testing plus street interviews. There are strictly controlled lab tests, as well as random interviews as a supplement to the results.

Test Execution

Domestic testing is like this:

 

US testing is like this:

 

Where are the people? Where are the people? Where are the people????

There are many crowded places in China: on the streets, in the dining areas of KFC and McDonald’s, at the entrance of milk tea shops, schools, shopping malls, movie theater entrances…

The United States is really sparsely populated.

In addition, some players indeed didn’t show up at the lab. So I started the long journey of finding people. But we were well prepared. We went to this place:

 

This place:

 

And this place:

 

Do you think we went to Universal Studios, Santa Monica Beach to eat, drink, have fun, and watch bikini beauties? No~~~ I only saw potential subjects all over the place.

 

For overseas street interviews, large tourist attractions and beaches are excellent places for testing, because these places not only have a large flow of people, but also provide a large number of resting places (the experience of sitting down to test will be better), not to mention people of all colors and countries from all over the world.

 

When you find tourists who have been queuing for half an hour and have nothing to do, don’t hesitate, these are the target players we can recruit.

 

Of course, there are also men, women, and children eating in restaurants.

 

Player Characteristics

So after the test, what is the difference between Americans and Japanese?

Japanese people are like this, I call them “superficial brothers” - polite and courteous in conversation, generous in scoring, but when it comes to verbal feedback and game behavior, they start to show “split personality”.

 

Americans, on the other hand, are very straightforward and have a sense of American humor. During the testing process, they will be generally more enthusiastic and willing to provide various opinions and suggestions. The completion rate of other columns and suggestion columns in the questionnaire is higher than that in China.

This is our lady who is writing hard to record player opinions.

 

And young men

 

So what should we pay attention to when receiving such enthusiastic Americans?

The answer is: no fruit, no snacks, but please prepare enough Fat Otaku Happy Water (soda) and potato chips!

entry.title: Application of Goal-Oriented Thinking in Requirement Analysis
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

This article shares the content of last year’s new campus recruitment training course in Guangzhou. The course includes: Game Understanding, Design Thinking - Requirements and Goals, Design Expression - Creativity, Design Expression - Information Operation Process. Each lesson has been very rewarding. Today, I will share the content about design thinking and use the design of a sign-in interface as a case to introduce my thinking process.

As a designer, when starting work, one often gets stuck in a cliché process. Faced with a requirement, you try to understand what the details of the requirement are, see what the planner needs, look for competing products, learn from what can be applied, and then produce your own design plan. Faced with such a plan, you always cannot pinpoint the good and bad, and will feel mediocre. The cause of this is a lack of a reasonable design goal.

Often in the early stages of design, we would set a very broad design goal, such as:

  • I want to design a very interesting interface;
  • I want to design a very useful interface;
  • I want to design a very novel interface;
  • …

In fact, such goals are not instructive and do not help the design at all, and in the end, they are easily ignored by ourselves.

So how do you get your design goals? As an interaction designer, you need to meet the needs of the planner, you need to understand what the planner’s goals are, and at the same time analyze what the user’s goals will be, so as to obtain the design goals.

 

Planner goals are often related to the potential value of the game, such as increasing game retention, increasing conversion rates, ensuring core experience…

For example, planner requirements: players log in daily and receive 5000 game coins and a random item. Log in for 7 days in a week, and you will get 1 piece of a quarterly limited skin fragment. Each quarter requires 10 fragments to exchange for the limited skin.

I try to analyze as follows:

 

By constantly questioning every detail in the requirement to dig out the purpose behind each requirement, and then thinking about what game value the planner wants to reflect by designing these functional points. It is not difficult to find that through layers of thinking, the planner’s ultimate goal is to achieve the effect of “increasing retention” in the sign-in interface.

 

User goals need to pay attention to what are the characteristics of the target users? What content does the user need to pay attention to in this interface, and what operations will the user perform?

First of all, characteristics, through means to find the target user’s age characteristics, gender characteristics, hobby trends, etc., to help us cater to their preferences.

Secondly, what will users look at? What to do? Still use the above sign-in requirements to analyze.

 

By exhausting the user’s behavior path, we can get what information the user will pay attention to in this interface, and the attention to information will also become clear.

After clarifying the planner’s goals and user goals, we also need other dimensions of thinking to supplement our design goals.

For example, the positioning of the sign-in interface, often in the game, the sign-in interface is after selecting the server and before the game starts. This determines that the sign-in interface is first of all an important interface: it determines the player’s first impression; it determines the tone of the game. At the same time, it is also an unimportant interface, it emphasizes use-and-go; do not divert the user’s attention, avoid overshadowing the main content with excessive design.

 

After the above analysis, it is easy to get a very detailed design goal, and the subsequent work will be very easy, just design according to the following content one by one.

 

Finally, as a designer, we are often not satisfied with meeting the design requirements. We all hope that our design is both functional and artistic. This requires designers to deeply explore the core and world view of the game. From this, get any content that can help the design, so as to design works that both yourself and players love.

entry.title: Service Innovation Design: Iteration Risks and Interaction Prototypes
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Do you want to know?

How to do interaction iteration?

How to make interaction prototypes?

How to rely on prototypes to increase the persuasiveness of solutions?

What are the tools for interactive prototyping?

What can usability testing at the prototype stage test?

On May 13th, the eighth lecture of the joint course “Service Innovation Design” by NetEase Leihuo User Experience Center and Zhejiang University (ZJU) gave a detailed lecture on iteration risks and interaction prototypes.

This course is mainly divided into three parts: UI iteration risks, introduction and case sharing of interaction prototypes, and tool introduction. It is taught by the interaction design manager of Leihuo UX.

The following are part of the course content:

UI Iteration Risks

  1. Major experience problems are discovered only after launch.
  2. An important function has always had experience problems, but it has not been solved.
  3. Insufficient innovation in the interaction scheme of core functions.

How to Avoid Iteration Risks

Iteration is the norm in the process of game development.

Avoid it by making prototypes for testing.

Who is the Prototype for?

Decision makers - Decision-making

Experiencers - Testing

Designers themselves - Self-testing

Good interface, “looks good” or “smooth” is not the ultimate goal, the ultimate goal is to make players feel that their experience is under control, and the prototype is a means to advance the experience.

Introduction to Interaction Prototype Tools

 

Flash Flinto Protopie

Simple interface prototyping tools

Ordinary clicks and other operations can be performed

Used in combination with drawing software to create prototypes

Unity

 

Utilize 3D advantages, control the camera, and interact with the game scene

Can generate mobile packages, computer packages, and web pages

Service Design Tools Introduction

01. Customer Journey Map

 

At the heart of most customer experience research, journey maps track user-facing interactions with services and represent them as structured visualizations. Typical journey maps are multi-channel and time-based. Creating it requires researchers to identify the touchpoints where users interact with the service, connect these touchpoints as part of the overall experience, and depict the various stages of the experience for further analysis.

02. Service Blueprint

 

As a key tool for service design, blueprints depict each component of the service, including users and service providers, their touchpoints, and behind-the-scenes processes. Unlike customer journey maps, these blueprints capture the work of the provider and the key processes of service delivery. Because they run through the user experience, service blueprints can reveal where silos exist in the organization. According to Dana Chisnell, co-founder of the Center for Civic Design, the gaps between these silos often correspond to low points in customer service. Service blueprints are designed to be co-generated and can be a tool to bring together different teams responsible for the discontinuous parts of the service. The process of creating a blueprint itself can foster collaboration and can also reveal areas of overlap and teamwork. Pollaine further suggests creating Journey Summaries, tracking a particular user’s journey through the main stages of the service in order to select touchpoints to focus on.

03. Stakeholder Map

 

Stakeholder maps identify important internal and external stakeholders and key users, and often describe the relationships between stakeholders and their relative importance. In addition to service design, stakeholder mapping is also used in strategy analysis, project management, and other fields. It helps the team assess how the interests of each stakeholder affect the project and how to address these issues.

04. Expectation Map

Expectation maps build on customer journey maps as a way to visualize customer emotions and desires during the journey. They are usually created during the discovery phase and are designed to represent the dynamically changing expectations of the service, expressing the best experience users can imagine. The map captures expectations in four aspects: seeing, hearing, saying, and doing, as well as thinking and feeling. The map can take a deep look at specific channels or aspects of the service to define where more details are needed. It can be used as a diagnostic tool to pinpoint areas of service that need attention.

05. Customer Lifecycle Map

 

By providing a comprehensive understanding of the customer’s relationship with the service provider, customer lifecycle maps are often used to highlight points where people may abandon the service. It takes into account the customer’s motivation and momentum overtime and can be described as a series of service journeys.

06. Design Scenario

This tool can combine several other techniques to integrate storyboards or characters into a hypothetical story. Driven by user research conducted by the team, the scenario can be particularly helpful in examining potential problems that a new service concept may encounter, or in constructing negative scenarios, exploring what might get worse to highlight what works well in practice. Design scenarios can also help teams build around a clear vision.

07. Organizational Impact Analysis

This additional tool is provided to establish a direct link between the customer experience and the delivery mechanism. It identifies the impact of customer stages or channels on different departments. This analysis is designed to help teams plan collaboration with internal stakeholders and pave the way for change.

08. Business Model Canvas

 

The canvas replaces the traditional business plan to identify the elements of a sustainable service product. Although the canvas is usually applied to private sector services, public sector organizations can use this tool to help departments see themselves as service-centric businesses, including how their key activities support a value proposition that serves specific customer relationships. The business model canvas contains nine sectors that can be filled in collaboratively to help service providers simulate various aspects of their service offerings.

NetEase Leihuo UX User Experience Center will also launch relevant information about the ZJU series of courses, so stay tuned!

entry.title: Introduction to User Research Lab Testing
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Lab testing is a common method of interacting with players in user experience research, and the feedback from player testing is more real and direct, which can facilitate product iteration and optimization. So today, let’s briefly introduce our lab testing.

 

Figure 1: Qingzhiwu Lab

We currently use two labs, the Qingzhiwu Lab and the in-house lab. The Qingzhiwu Lab is located near the Yuquan Campus of Zhejiang University, in the urban area, making it convenient for players to participate in testing.

 

Figure 2: Qingzhiwu Lab

The key point of lab testing is to invite specific players (players with certain gaming experience, demographic indicators, and game experience depth) to the lab for a longer game experience, generally limited to 2 hours, observe their game experience behavior, pay attention to players’ attitudes and feedback, and use various methods to evaluate players’ experience.

 

Figure 3: In-house Eye-Tracking Lab

Lab testing will test and iterate on the core experience of the game, the novice process experience, the interaction of key interfaces in the game, new game activities or gameplay versions, etc. It can be said that it runs through the entire process of game development to online operation.

 

Before the test, we will conduct a mock test. One person plays the role of the participant experiencing the game, and multiple people play the role of the tester to observe and use the corresponding observation sheet to fill in. After the mock execution is completed, there will be a review to optimize the testing process and the documents used for testing. Make the subsequent formal testing smoother and more professional.

 

Before the test starts, we need to ensure that the players arrive on time. We will contact the players in advance by text message and phone. The test equipment will be debugged and can be used normally during the test for the game experience, reducing interruptions and facilitating the smooth progress of our test.

 

Figure 4: Qingzhiwu Justice Online Lab Test

After the test is over, we will review the test with the product on the spot, summarize and discuss key issues. An agile feedback report will be submitted on the same day. Within three days after the end, we will also submit our detailed analysis report.

entry.title: Mobile Game Social System - Detailed Explanation of Friends Interface Interaction Design
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

The social system has always been an indispensable part of many games. Although it is not directly related to the core gameplay, it is a key system to increase player immersion and improve retention. Especially for MMO products with strong social interaction, the social system plays a key role. For example, our A Chinese Ghost Story mobile game is known for its excellent social design.

From the perspective of planning, when designing a social system, we usually consider how to meet the needs of players, how to promote the establishment of a player network, how to use the elements in the game to create a social space for players, and so on. As interaction designers, when we are involved in social system design, we need to consider more about how to improve system usability, reduce interruptions, and satisfy the rational layout of all functions.

Here, we focus on the main operating system in the mobile game social system - the friends interface, and sort out the interaction design elements of the friends interface.

I. Functional Block Breakdown

Divided by functional blocks, friends can be divided into these three parts:

  • Existing Friends
  • Find Friends
  • Message Notifications

The existing mobile game friends interfaces basically include these three parts. Depending on whether a certain game focuses on social interaction, the specific functions within each part will be different. Games that focus on social interaction often have more expanded functions, such as moments, message boards, social relationship recommendations, etc.

Block Description
Existing Friends Displays a list of current friends, allowing players to interact with them (e.g., chat, gift-giving, team up).
Find Friends Provides methods to search for and add new friends (e.g., by username, nearby players, recommended players).
Message Notifications Displays friend requests, system messages related to social interactions, and potentially mail (though mail is sometimes a separate system entirely).

The diagram above (not included here, as it requires a visual representation) shows the specific functions usually included in the friends block. It can be seen that there are quite a lot of function items included. Therefore, sorting and merging these function items is a prerequisite for rationally arranging the layout of the friends interface and making the overall hierarchy simple and clear.

1. First-Level Tab Division

Usually, the three major functional blocks are used as the three first-level tabs of the friends section. If there are more expanded functions, then second-level tabs are added. The message notification part is special. Mail notification is a relatively independent part. Some games will put it together with the friends block as an independent tab, and some games will separate it. This can be determined according to the specific planning direction of the game, and it has little impact on the friends block itself.

 

2. Friend Request List Entry

Although friend requests are message notifications, they are usually placed on the friends list page. This is because after a friend request is accepted, the friend will enter the friends list, which is logically related in terms of operation. Therefore, it is easier for players to understand that the request information is placed on the friends list page. And the importance of friend requests is relatively low, only requiring a prompt when there is request information. Usually, a button can be placed as an entry or used as a second-level tab.

 

3. Find Friends Functional Block Merging

In the “Find Friends” section, it can be seen that the search results, recommended friends, nearby people, and recent contacts all contain player lists and add friend operations, only differing in the specific information of the players.

 

Therefore, we can usually combine two of the blocks for display. For example, the recommended friends list is displayed in the default state, and after a search, this area displays the search results list.

Using this method of switching display content in the same area can more effectively utilize interface space and simplify the interface hierarchy. If there are multiple functional blocks at the same time, tabs can be added to clarify the logic.

 

II. Prompt Detail Design

In order to make the player’s operation smooth, in interaction design, it is necessary to exhaustively list all possible operation situations that the player may encounter, otherwise some details may be overlooked. There are also some design details that need attention in the friends section.

1. Nickname Display

The nickname is the beginning of the player’s establishment of social relationships and identification of identity in the game. Therefore, the player’s nickname needs to be clearly displayed first in the friends list. Due to limited space in mobile games, the length of the nickname is usually limited. However, when designing the layout of list information, we still need to consider long nicknames and multiple languages. Simple icons or levels can be placed before the nickname, but free space needs to be reserved after the nickname. Usually, the nickname is on a separate line, and other information is on a new line. In this way, when the nicknames of various players are of different lengths, it will not affect the display of subsequent information and keep the layout clean.

 

2. Prompt Information

Clear prompt information is the guarantee of smooth use by players, and there are also a series of prompt information that needs attention in the friends section.

For example, for nearby people, when the player turns off the positioning function, the list of nearby people is blank, and it needs to be prompted that the current positioning function is not turned on. In this case, we usually use positive guidance prompts such as “Turn on the positioning function to discover more players” with corresponding icons to guide players to use this function.

For another example, when the request list and search results are empty, it is necessary to pay attention to displaying corresponding prompt information such as “No friend requests” and “No corresponding friends found”. Without these prompts, a blank interface will make players wonder if it is stuck or if there is no content.

 

Clear interface hierarchy, functional block division, and detailed design details are aspects that we must consider when doing interaction design. This is the basic guarantee for satisfying usability and the premise for producing more innovative designs.

entry.title: Introduction to Public Opinion Research
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

In previous work, we introduced lab testing. This issue mainly introduces another qualitative research that we often encounter in our daily work: public opinion research.

Academically speaking, public opinion is the sum of beliefs, attitudes, opinions, and emotions expressed by a large number of people about various phenomena and problems in society. The large amount of information we encounter every day, such as Weibo, WeChat public accounts, and Tieba posts, all belong to public opinion. When these comments are related to our games, they are the objects of our research.

Compared with other research methods, public opinion can quickly and agilely obtain player feedback, and has great advantages in timeliness and cost.

Game public opinion generally focuses on hot spots, problem points, and spreading points, and will be emphasized according to the different stages of the game. The game testing period, launch period, and major update period are the risk periods of public opinion. The public opinion research work at this stage will mainly monitor channel ratings, monitor negative comments, monitor spread content, and mine highlights, etc. The purpose is to assist in maintaining the game’s reputation and subsequent product improvements. During daily operations, public opinion is relatively stable. Research focuses on monitoring game popularity, collecting activity feedback, and conducting UGC content analysis. The purpose is to help evaluate the effectiveness of activities and supplement data research in the game.

In actual work, the first step is to find the right channels. The channels we generally contact include forums (such as Tieba), distribution channels (such as the App Store), social platforms (such as Weibo), and video websites (Bilibili), etc. These channels have their own strengths in terms of group typicality, content relevance, external influence, and communication power, and can generally be screened according to the focus of public opinion research. For example, as an official channel, forums are an important channel for players to feedback game experience problems, and the game relevance is high, so you can mainly pay attention to forums when monitoring gameplay experience feedback on a daily basis.

The subsequent public opinion collation work is relatively simple and has a low threshold for getting started, but making a public opinion report that is useful to the product still requires in-depth understanding of the product and advanced training in public opinion analysis skills.

entry.title: Service Innovation Design: Agile Concepts and Planning
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

The “Service Innovation Design” course is jointly organized by NetEase Leihuo User Experience Center and the Department of Industrial Design of Zhejiang University. This course will last for three months and will be taught in 20 sessions. The course focuses on how to combine game products, offline game scenarios, and game users through service design, and cultivates students’ service design capabilities through theoretical explanations and case analysis. The final results will be exhibited at Zhejiang University.

On the morning of May 22, the eleventh lecture of “Service Innovation Design”: Agile Concepts and Planning, was held as scheduled in the Department of Industrial Design of Zhejiang University. This course was taught by a PM from the Leihuo User Experience Center, mainly explaining in detail from three parts: basic concepts of agile development, how to build an “agile” team, and thinking and planning.

At the beginning of the course, the teacher used “Deadline is the primary productive force” and “Game of Thrones’ anti-climatic ending” as examples to introduce the need for reasonable planning: Waterfall Development and Agile Development, which brought bursts of laughter from the students present. The course unfolded in a pleasant and relaxed atmosphere.

The teacher first explained the basic concepts of Waterfall Development and Agile Development.

Waterfall Development, like a waterfall, has strict hierarchical steps. It is the most typical predictive method, strictly following the pre-planned steps of requirements analysis, design, coding, integration, testing, and maintenance. The advantages are clear and visualized progress, and simple progress management. The disadvantage is the extremely high cost of rework or change.

The teacher gave intuitive examples of industrial assembly lines and house construction to help students understand Waterfall Development.

One day, a pig and a chicken were walking down the road. The chicken said to the pig, “Hey, how about we start a restaurant together?” The pig looked back at the chicken and said, “Good idea, what do you want to name the restaurant?” The chicken thought for a moment and said, “How about ‘Ham and Eggs’?” “No way,” said the pig, “I’d be committed, but you’d only be involved.”

Then, the teacher used this joke to introduce Agile Development (Scrum). The pig team members are equivalent to the developers, and the chicken team members are equivalent to the users and stakeholders.

Agile development takes the evolution of user needs as the core, and adopts an iterative and gradual method for software development.

In order to help students more intuitively understand the difference between Waterfall Development and Agile Development, the teacher used “arranged marriage by parents” to describe the rigid and strict procedures of Waterfall Development, and “free love” to describe the flexible and free nature of Agile Development. Laughter of agreement came from the students again.

Advantages of Agile Development:

  • Rapid response to change: Prioritize what to do first, adapt to unexpected needs.
  • Shorter delivery cycle: Continuously optimize and improve the product.
  • Project transparency: Members and stakeholders can see the progress and problems of the project.
  • Low trial and error cost: Even if a sprint has problems, the manpower and material resources wasted will not be much.
  • High return on investment: Fast output and low cost.

“2334, please remember these four numbers.” The teacher said to the students when explaining how to build an “agile” team.

2 Tools:

A Kanban board is generally a physical whiteboard, the purpose of which is to visualize and track iteration progress and collaborate. The Kanban board needs to display everyone’s tasks in the corresponding status (To Do/Not checked out, Doing/Checked out, Done), generally using sticky notes.

A burndown chart is a visual representation of the work that needs to be completed before the project is finished. A burndown chart has a Y-axis (work) and an X-axis (time). Ideally, the chart is a downward curve, and as the remaining work is completed, it “burns down” to zero.

3 Roles:

PO: Product Owner, generally a product manager, responsible for requirements analysis and organization, decomposition and acceptance of stories, maintenance of the Product Backlog, etc.

Scrum Master: Plays the role of a facilitator, responsible for hosting meetings, assisting team members in solving difficulties, resolving external interference with the team, and communicating with the outside world. The Master can be a dedicated person, or it can be a member of the team. In many teams, the PO also serves as the Master.

Dev Team: The entire development and testing team, including UI designers and all other relevant personnel.

3 Artifacts:

  • Product Backlog: Product requirement pool
  • Sprint Backlog: The set of requirements to be developed this time
  • Potentially Shippable Product Increment: Deliverable results

4 Meetings:

  • Sprint Planning: Requirements review meeting and iteration kickoff meeting. In this meeting, the following conclusions need to be reached:
    • All members have a clear and concise iteration goal.
    • Clarify all requirements and technical implementation risks.
    • Evaluate the workload required and the personnel to be invested.
    • Determine all the final features and workload to be released. The Story needs to be broken down into Tasks, in units of hours.
  • Daily Scrum Planning: Daily stand-up meeting. As the name suggests, it is a meeting held standing up. Everyone forms a circle or a semicircle. There are two purposes for doing this, one is efficiency, and the other is to make it easier for all team members to see each other.
  • Sprint Review: Iteration review meeting. The main content of this meeting is for stakeholders and team members to show the functional increments of this iteration. It should be noted that unfinished functions are not displayed, and PPT is not needed. Record relevant feedback after the demonstration.
  • Sprint Retrospective: Iteration review meeting. The main purpose of the meeting is to review the overall situation of this iteration. All members must participate, review the good things done in this iteration and the areas that need improvement, and propose improvement measures for these areas that need improvement.

In the last part of thinking and planning, the teacher mainly explained the Mandala thinking method, mind mapping, and how to plan, and practiced the Mandala thinking method with the classification of The 36 Stratagems.

The Mandala thinking method is also known as the nine-square grid thinking method. After listening carefully to the teacher’s explanation, the students discussed in groups and showed their classification of the thirty-six stratagems.

At the end of the course, the teacher once again emphasized to the students the core of Agile Development: “Embrace change!” The students responded with enthusiastic applause.

entry.title: How to Make Data Processing More Efficient
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Single-Machine ETL Optimization

I. ETL is the Core Part of BI

What is ETL: Extract, Transform, Load. Faced with large amounts of data, how to load it efficiently?

Core: The process from JSON in logs to the data warehouse should be as efficient as possible, and it is best not to rely on any irrelevant tool frameworks. Ideally, shorten the time from raw logs to the database as much as possible, and make it accurate.

What is BI: Visualizing the data in the backend database? Making it look better?

Core: Data visualization is an art. A good visualization solution can analyze data more conveniently and comprehensively; and it can also monitor exceptions.

Main Process of ETL:

  • Log Files: Raw player behavior logs.
  • Data Extraction: Parse raw logs through regular expression matching, etc.
  • Generate Intermediate Files, Format Conversion: Parse raw logs to generate intermediate files, perform format conversion for easy subsequent processing.
  • Scheduled Data Loading: Taking Hive as an example, usually partition by day, load the data of the previous day into Hive every day. It can also be processed by hour, depending on the needs.
  • Usually, ETL takes at least 1/3 of the time in the entire project. The quality of ETL determines the quality of the entire BI project.
  • The ETL process must be pure, otherwise the automation process will be interfered with by other factors. If ETL is not smooth, there is no need to look at the rest.
  • Data file storage should avoid a lot of copying and moving as much as possible. Moving calculations is cheap, moving data is expensive.
  • ETL code must also be modular and easy to expand. Adding a new requirement does not require changing the core code, only adding the corresponding functional requirements.
  • For log processing, it is necessary to make full use of computing resources and parallelize it because this process itself is a mutually independent process.
  • Data processing code must be rigorously tested and can be automatically monitored (including partition missing, field updates, and the addition of new logs).

II. Single-Machine Log Processing

If you only have one machine, how can you achieve efficient ETL when processing log data? The processor of a computer system is often idle, especially since many current computer systems have good computing power, and most personal PCs are also multi-core processors. At the code level, we must let the computer exert its maximum computing power and keep the processor in a “busy state” at all times.

Usually, multiple processes are used for processing:

  1. Python uses the Global Interpreter Lock (GIL), which serializes the threads in the process. That is, multi-core CPUs cannot actually achieve the purpose of parallel speedup. The use of multiple processes is not limited. In practical applications, multiple processes are recommended.
  2. If the time required for each child process to execute is very short (execute +1 operation, etc.), there is no need to use multiple processes, because the startup and shutdown of processes will also consume resources.
  3. Multi-processing is often used to handle CPU-intensive (scientific computing) requirements. If it is IO-intensive (file reading, web crawling, etc.), multi-threading can be used.

Simple code example:

#Psuedo-code representing the principles, not actual code
Write_process(Data_Queue):
For Entry in Data_Source:
Formatted_entry = format(Entry)
Data_Queue.put(Formatted_entry)
Data_Queue.put(None)

Read_process(Data_Queue):
While True:
Entry = Data_Queue.get()
If Entry == None:
Break
process(Entry)

Data_Queue = Queue()
Write_p = Process(Write_process, Data_Queue)
Read_p = Process(Read_process, Data_Queue)

Write_p.start()
Read_p.start()
Write_p.join()
Read_p.join()
The write process writes to the queue, and the read process reads from the queue.

Global Interpreter Lock (GIL): The execution of Python code is performed by the Python virtual machine, and access to the Python virtual machine is controlled by the Global Interpreter Lock (GIL). This lock ensures that only one thread is running at a time.

Important Modules:

  1. Process module: Used to create child processes, which can realize the creation, startup, and shutdown of multiple processes.
  2. Queue module: Used to control process safety, the same as the Queue in threads.
  3. Pool module: Used to create and manage a process pool. This module can be used when there are many child processes and the number of child processes needs to be controlled.
  4. Lock module: When multiple processes need to access shared resources, Lock can be used to avoid access conflicts.

Note:

On UNIX platforms, when a process terminates, the process needs to be waited on by its parent process, otherwise the process becomes a zombie process. Therefore, it is necessary to call the join() method for each Process object (actually equivalent to wait). For multi-threading, since there is only one process, this necessity does not exist.

Single-Machine Multi-Process ETL Summary:

  1. Data logs are usually placed on HDFS, and single-machine processing and copying to the local machine takes a lot of time. Avoid moving large amounts of data.
  2. The number of processes needs to be dynamically set, and the appropriate number of processes should be set according to the size of the task.
  3. In the face of large amounts of data, single-machine operations may become a bottleneck in efficiency. Increasing processes may not be very effective, and each step needs to be peeled off layer by layer.
  4. Output of error logs and performance monitoring, which is convenient for efficiency optimization.
  5. Of course, the biggest advantage of single-price processing of log data is stability and ease of debugging.
  6. Configuration of database connection pool: Better utilize network resources, minimize the overhead of connection establishment and disconnection, and improve ETL performance.
  7. Database grouping and sorting are better than ETL grouping and sorting. Hand over sorting and grouping problems to the database.

Core:

For projects with a relatively small amount of data, single-machine processing of logs is completely sufficient. It is necessary to pay attention to the efficiency of data copying. The most important thing is stability and ease of debugging.

entry.title: Design and Specification of Basic Functional Interaction Motion Effects for Mobile Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

Nowadays, various apps and mobile games are increasingly pursuing an immersive interactive experience, and are no longer satisfied with the design of traditional static interfaces. At the same time, they are paying more and more attention to the design of motion effects in the interface. Many companies currently have their own interaction design specifications, such as Ant Design, etc., which have even packaged interaction and programs together for easy development and use. However, the design specifications for motion effects are relatively lacking. Designers often need to constantly adjust with technical colleagues to achieve the desired motion effect design. In the UX department, interaction prototyping engineers help interaction designers achieve the desired interaction design effects to complete rapid iterative output, making it easier to choose better solutions for in-depth advancement. Here, I will share some experience about the cooperation of interaction motion effect design.

The main function of motion effect design is to make the scene move through the movement of elements, so as to reduce user fatigue, increase information acquisition, increase the sense of ceremony, and trigger emotions. From a functional perspective, they can be divided into functional motion effects and expressive motion effects.

Functional motion effects are mainly used to express state changes, prompt users to pay attention, guide user operations, highlight information display, provide user feedback, and connect different information.

Expressive motion effects are mainly used to create experiences, such as obtaining achievements, specific transition effects, and creating a certain atmosphere. Expressive motion effects are often more complex, closer to animation or video, and generally appear less frequently, mainly in situations such as achieving achievements and obtaining special items. The rendering of the atmosphere is often greater than the embodiment of the function. The following mainly focuses on functional motion effects.

Functional motion effects often have these characteristics:

  1. Short

    How short? The unit of measurement for functional motion effects is generally milliseconds (ms). The duration of general functional motion effects will be controlled within 1s, and some agile feedback motion effects may only be about 300ms.

  2. Concise

    The purpose of functional motion effects is very clear. At the same time, because of the short duration, the motion effects need to be concise, coherent, and without too many effects.

  3. Natural

    The motion effect should conform to the physical laws of the real world. It assists users in cognition and understanding of the interface, so it cannot increase the cost of understanding and cognition.

By analogy, in fact, functional motion effects are very similar to elements such as line spacing and font in the interface to a certain extent. We use different font sizes and line spacing to distinguish different information levels, so that users can understand the structure and content of the article faster and easier. Functional motion effects also establish a cognitive connection between users and products through actions, making the operation and use of products more fluent and natural.

In interaction design, we have strict specifications for font size, line spacing, and alignment to improve the uniformity of the product. Similarly, motion effect design also needs a set of specifications. Imagine that when users click different buttons to open pop-up windows, the duration and motion curve of each motion effect are different. Users will be confused by this difference. When the number of such confusions increases, they will feel that the product is not smooth to use and have negative emotions. Basic functional motion effects often exist in every operation of the user, which will affect the experience of the entire product.

Based on this consideration, specifying a set of common basic motion effect specifications in the early stage of the product can lay a solid foundation for the product. The design process of motion effect specifications is as follows:

First, determine the personality of the product. Different games or apps have different personality characteristics. For example, Anipop will be more lively and cheerful, while Identity V will be darker and more terrifying. The corresponding feeling of motion effects is also different. If all the motion effects in a horror game are lively and exaggerated “DUANG DUANG” effects, it will destroy the carefully rendered horror atmosphere of the game, causing detachment and interrupting the user’s experience.

Secondly, find out the needs. The basic functional motion effect needs of a game are basically the same, such as click feedback, the appearance and closing of pop-up windows, the appearance and closing of tips, page switching, etc. The needs can be extracted by checking the game and reviewing the recordings to reduce errors and omissions. For example, different games will use different list presentation methods. The motion effects of strip lists and modular array lists will be different; and for array lists, sliding left and right to turn pages and sliding up and down to turn pages will also have different motion effects for the appearance of the list. This can better guide players to understand the page turning operation.

After that, design the requirements. At this stage, the designer cooperates with the interaction prototyping engineer to directly make the final motion effect with engineering software, and output code or engineering files to reduce the inability to fully restore the design expectations during development after only producing design documents and videos. At the same time, it can also greatly reduce the workload and burden of development. In the process of cooperation between designers and prototyping engineers, in order to further improve efficiency, designers can use visualization tools to independently design and iterate motion effects, and then connect with engineers to improve overall work efficiency and reduce the awkward situation of one person directing and one person operating. For example, when designing a motion curve, in order to make the motion effect more natural, the curve of each movement should be a easing curve. These curves can be adjusted by visually adjusting the anchor points (https://cubic-bezier.com/). The code can then be directly exported to the prototype engineer.

Finally, output the design specification document. Although the engineering file has been output through the prototyping engineer, the design specification document is still necessary in practical application. On the one hand, it can guide designers and engineers to reuse it in the application. On the other hand, the design specification should also be iterated with the advancement of the product. The specification document can be updated in real time to respond to all changes with a constant. The design specification document generally includes several aspects:

  • Application scenario of motion effect
  • Action decomposition (change value and time)
  • Basic code
  • Effect display (animation/gif/video)
  • Prototype engineering file

entry.title: Introduction to Qualitative Research in Game Projects
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Qualitative research is one of the commonly used methods in user research. Although, in games, we have a large amount of game logs to conduct various data analyses and obtain more accurate results, data is often only a result and an appearance. We are more interested in knowing the underlying reasons behind the data, that is, why such data results are produced.

Telephone interviews, in-depth interviews, street intercepts, and focus groups are the four qualitative research methods we commonly use.

Telephone Interviews

(Image from the Internet)

Generally, for products that already have a certain user base, such as products that have been launched or are being tested, the telephone interview method can be used for some special research topics. The advantage of this method is that there is no venue restriction, and the cost of acquiring players is relatively low. However, the disadvantage is that it is impossible to observe the players’ real game experience, and it is necessary to carefully distinguish the authenticity of the players’ feedback.

In-depth Interviews

In-depth interviews are generally combined with laboratory tests or other tests. Generally, we invite players to participate in designated venues and pay a certain amount of compensation. This type of interview, first of all, has certain requirements for the players themselves, such as game experience, occupation and other demographic information; secondly, it has high requirements for time and venue, because the test not only needs to provide players with a comfortable environment, but may also involve the participation of multiple parties such as products, user researchers, and players, so coordination is required. Because in-depth interviews provide players with compensation, players are more willing to cooperate, but relatively, the feedback will be more positive. Therefore, when conducting in-depth interviews, do not over-interpret players’ ratings of products.

Street Intercepts

Suitable for product evaluation in the demo period. Generally, according to certain game experience, occupation and other demographic information, players are directly invited on the street to watch game videos or try them out, and give certain feedback. Unlike in-depth interviews, this street research method generally does not provide players with compensation, or players do not know in advance that they can receive compensation. Therefore, players’ behavior is more real and closer to market performance. However, because there are many uncontrollable factors in external testing, this method also has disadvantages: the experience interview time is generally short, and it is difficult to find target players, like finding a needle in a haystack.

Focus Groups

Generally, a small-scale symposium is used to select a group of relatively “similar” players, and the host conducts interviews in an unstructured or semi-structured manner. It is generally used to understand the attitude of a specific group of players towards a certain gameplay or concept. Through interaction and discussion with each other, players can often stimulate more new ideas and viewpoints. However, it should be noted that there may be “opinion leaders” or relatively introverted players among the players, so there are higher requirements for the host’s ability to control the scene.

The above is a brief introduction to the four qualitative research methods we commonly use in the user research process. Each method has its own advantages and disadvantages. In the actual work process, it is also necessary to choose the appropriate method according to specific needs.
