entry.title: Pandas: 'Using SQL' in Python
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

What is pandas?

 

pandas Concept Introduction

Let’s briefly introduce pandas. pandas is a tool based on NumPy (which can be used to store and process large matrices), providing high-performance, easy-to-use data structures and data analysis tools for the Python programming language. As the official documentation states, many potential pandas users have some knowledge of SQL, so this article aims to compare pandas with common SQL usage methods.

The official documentation states that new features in pandas will only support Python 3 after January of this year, so this article will use Python 3 for examples. The usage in Python 2 is basically the same.

pandas Structured Data Classification

Before we start, let’s briefly understand the data structures of pandas. pandas mainly has three types of data structures:

  • Series: A 1-dimensional sequence, which can be regarded as a DataFrame without column names and with only one column.
  • DataFrame: Multi-column 2-dimensional structured data, which can be regarded as a container for Series.
  • Panel: 3-dimensional structured data, which can be regarded as a container for DataFrame.

Among them, DataFrame is more common and can be imagined as the form of an Excel table. It can be generated by reading multiple types of text such as .csv, .xlsx, and JSON data, or it can be generated through objects. This article will focus on the use of DataFrame.

Using pandas to Implement Basic SQL Functions

We use the pandas test database tips and import it into a DataFrame. The data format is as follows:

 

SELECT

pandas is more flexible in data selection. To select the first two columns of data, the corresponding SQL is:
sql
select total_bill, tip from tips;

Using pandas, you can filter data based on rows and columns. The simplest way to select rows/columns is:

 

Note that there are two square brackets here. pandas also supports row selection:

 

Note that the row numbers here start from 0 by default, and the usage here is similar to list slicing. Can we locate certain rows and columns? Of course, we can. Here we need to use the loc or iloc methods, as shown below:

 

All four methods can achieve the results in the figure. Of course, there is a more convenient method, which is to use the ix method. However, the official documentation does not recommend using this method now. loc and iloc are based on index and position, respectively, which can be distinguished by the representation of columns in the figure. One uses the column name, and the other uses the position of the column. This fully reflects the flexibility and convenience of pandas, which can use multiple methods to retrieve data by row and column. There are also at and iat methods to locate the value of a certain row and column.

WHERE

The main filtering method in pandas is based on df[df[column] boolean expr], such as:

 

The corresponding SQL is select * from tips where sex='Male' limit 5. If there are conditions such as and and or in the where filtering condition, you can use & and | to add conditions. As shown in the figure, add filtering conditions and select two columns:

 

There are also methods such as notna() and isna() to assist in judgment, to determine whether it is empty. At the same time, you can also determine how many rows of data meet the conditions:

 

GROUP BY

In pandas, group is generally used with aggregation functions, such as avg(), count(), etc. There are not many supported methods in this area, but they can basically meet daily needs.

The corresponding SQL is select sex, count(*) from tips group by sex. Here we need to look at the corresponding data volume according to gender. Using pandas will be very concise:

 

Note that there is another method called count() method. The count() method cannot be used here because the count() method counts the columns. For the calculation of multiple aggregated values, such as the SQL:
sql
select sex, max(tip), max(size) from tips group by sex

In pandas, you can use the agg() function with a dictionary configuration to achieve the goal:

 

If there is a count, there is a distinct count. Here you can use a similar method to obtain the gender situation contained in each tip according to the tip:

 

DISTINCT

We mentioned distinct count above, so let’s take a look at distinct, which is also a very frequently used function in SQL. In pandas, we can also find a corresponding method, drop_duplicates().

For example, to remove duplicates from tip, you can use it like this:

 

You can see the row numbers in front, 0 and 56. This is the role of keep in the method. keep can be set to first, last, and False, which means to keep the first, last, and delete all duplicates, respectively. The effect is as follows:

 

inplace can be True or False, default is False, which means to return a new DataFrame or return the original DataFrame after removing duplicates.

JOIN

Speaking of SQL, we have to mention join. When performing data association, join can play a huge role. I won’t go into the difference between various types of join here. There are many vivid examples online. So what is the corresponding method in pandas? Is there a join method? Yes, there is, but this method is based on the index, which is the row number, so we generally use the second method, the merge method.

 

You can see that the usage is very close to the join in our SQL. You only need to use a list to represent the columns to be joined, and you can use multiple dimensions as association items.

ORDER

The last more commonly used one is sorting. Similarly, the usage is also very flexible and very similar to SQL. As shown in the figure, it is to sort sex and size, where sex is in descending order and size is in ascending order. Here, you only need to use the list method to sort multiple columns.

 

Summary

We have learned about the flexibility and power of pandas by corresponding to the high-frequency keywords of SQL. Of course, the capabilities of pandas are definitely not limited to this. When processing medium-sized data, if you can skillfully optimize the use of pandas, it will be very helpful to our work. After all, this is using a script. In addition to what SQL can do, there are more abundant means to process and obtain the data we want.

entry.title: Let's Talk About Design Communication - IXDC 2018 Summary Sharing (Part 2)
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

In the last sharing session, I introduced the sharing by Li Yue, a senior user experience designer at Didi CDX, “Making Good Use of the [Experience + Data Dual-Drive Model] to Deduce Good Design”, which mainly elaborated on the important role of the 5 Whys method of design inquiry in excavating the essential needs of the product or planning party at the initial stage of design. In this sharing, I will talk about how design communication should be carried out in the design process based on another IXDC workshop.

Let’s Talk About Design Communication

This design communication workshop was prepared by Dhaval Joshi, a senior product manager at Tencent, and Suxi Chen, an interaction designer. It mainly derives content about design communication through the problems encountered in their VR live broadcast design process. I think the main gain is how to carry out work in unknown field design, and secondly, to learn how to organize feedback from different states in the design process.

Dhaval Joshi started with V+ live broadcast. V Society is one of the earlier companies to use VR and other technologies to do game e-sports, and it performed well in the Dota2 international competition. Inspired by this, Tencent also hopes to provide a new immersive experience for its LOL fans and users through the mobile VR e-sports live broadcast experience, to create new ways to reach fans and provide new channels to attract users.

As shown in the figure below, in the traditional development process, design, development, and testing cooperate with each other through a linear process to complete the requirements.

 

However, when targeting VR, a new form of interaction, they suddenly found that everyone did not know how to achieve the best performance of this new media, and their design performance and communication were not easily understood by others, because product managers and programmers did not have a unified understanding of VR performance.

Faced with VR, a new medium, they first started by positioning the characteristics of VR itself. We know that in real life, everyone watches games on the sidelines of the stadium (as shown in the figure below), facing a large space. What VR virtual reality can bring us is to reconstruct this space, so that everyone can be immersed in the scene without leaving home.

 

Then, since mobile VR on mobile platforms generally adopts a head-mounted technology form, the operation will not adopt the form of touch screen. Therefore, there are two key points in VR design.

 

Therefore, for this kind of three-dimensional space design, they creatively adopted a new way of expression to facilitate communication. as the picture shows.

 

Then, use low-fidelity to directly let the program quickly implement an interactive version for testing.

 

Through this case, we can clearly see how important simulation is in design communication. Only when the participants understand and synchronize the information between each other can they get what the designer wants in the design implementation process.

 

Translation Model

Another gain for me is about the translation model. Tencent’s designers use it to translate the interaction form and scene they set into a language that the program can easily understand. But I personally think that this is actually very suitable for complex systems like games to sort out various states and feedback. As shown in the figure below, the translation model is to number each element after completing the basic interaction framework, and then sort out the feedback of all other elements after triggering one of them.

 

Through this operation, it can ensure that the designer does not miss the state when outputting content to the greatest extent, and can enrich the performance of the interface and think of ideas that were not thought of during previous designs. Of course, this method also has disadvantages. If the interface is particularly complex, the efficiency will be greatly reduced. Therefore, the number of compressed element numbers should also be considered.

Summary

To review, design communication is an indispensable and important part of design communication. In the design process, how to make product managers, developers and other relevant personnel understand the design content and clarify the design goals is the key problem to be solved by design communication. Simulation is a good way. Through simulation, developers and product managers can actually participate in and experience the design, and then it is easier to understand the design ideas and unify ideas.

Designers, especially interaction designers, often pay more attention to the various states of design. Through the translation model, it is more convenient for designers to sort out feedback and states in the later stage to prevent omissions.

entry.title: [UE Sharing] How to Become an Interview Master (Part 1)
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

In previous articles, we introduced many qualitative research methods. So, do you know what we spend 50% of our time doing in these qualitative studies?

Yes, that’s right, half of our time is actually spent interviewing (chatting) with players.

Many people may think that interviewing is actually just chatting. As long as you establish a good relationship with the player at the beginning and communicate with them in a sincere and friendly manner, the player will open up and give you all their feelings and opinions. Or maybe, it’s thought that being outgoing, cheerful, and talkative are the conditions for a successful interview.

But in our actual work, interviews are far from being successful based solely on creating a good atmosphere or the interviewer’s personal social skills. Everyone needs to understand that sometimes interviewees don’t express themselves much, not because they are unwilling to express themselves, but because the interviewee’s own ability to express themselves is actually limited. Sometimes, the interviewee may not even know where the problem lies. For example, we often ask players, “Why don’t you play this game anymore?” We may hope that players can make a comprehensive analysis from aspects such as graphics, gameplay, and monetization. But ask yourself, if you suddenly receive such an interview call one day, can you really figure out why you don’t want to play this game? Therefore, when we conduct interviews, we actually rely heavily on the interviewer’s own interview skills to dig out the player’s problems, help the player figure out the problems, and express them clearly.

The player you imagine:

[Image of a detailed and expressive individual]

The actual player, doing the Buddhist “three”:

[Image of a person saying “I don’t know,” “It’s okay,” and “Whatever”]

So how can you become an interview master?

[Image of a person meditating]

To become an interview master, we need to break through 3 levels of mastery

The First Level of Cultivation: Be a Good Mouthpiece for Players

Although we have always emphasized that user researchers are not just mouthpieces for players, in the initial stage of becoming an interview master, you must first learn how to be a good mouthpiece.

So how do you become a good mouthpiece for players? There is a keyword here, which is “disassemble” (拆 - chāi)

[Image of拆]

First of all, we need to clarify our purpose. A large part of the content of our interviews is actually to understand what problems players have encountered. The problems here, of course, refer to the problems of the product itself. So what we really need to get is feedback from players on what problems the product itself has.

Here, many beginner interviewers are often easily fooled by players, that is, they confuse the product’s problems with the player’s experience problems. Many times, players seem to be talking about the product’s problems, but they are actually just expressing their own feelings and not talking about the problems of the product itself.

Let’s look at the following question: “I feel that the… emmm… hit feedback of this game is not very good”

[Image showing concern and confusion at a screen]

What is hit feedback? In games, hit feedback refers to a kind of simulated real fighting feeling composed of attack feedback and hit feedback during the character’s fighting process. This defines whether a game’s combat feels impactful. Here, hit feedback is actually a player’s feeling.

[Image of hand with a lightbulb]

But just knowing that the hit feedback is not good, we still don’t know where the product’s problem lies. Why? Because hit feedback is actually composed of many parts. Hit feedback can first be divided into two aspects: attack process and hit performance. The attack process includes attack actions, attack special effects, hit confirmation, combo design, etc. Hit actions also include hit special effects, hit actions, etc. So the question is, the player says the hit feedback is not good. Is it because the attack action design is not real enough, or the hit action performance is not obvious? Which part should the designer modify to improve the hit feedback of this game? We cannot get the answer from the feedback of the above player.

[Image of a chart breaking down a character action’s components]

So if you encounter a player who says “the hit feedback is not good”, our interview on this issue is not over. The “depth” of in-depth interviews lies in “specificity” and “follow-up questions”

How to achieve “specificity”? Here we need a standard. A complete question should include these parts, 5W2H. Summarized, it can also be called a three-part answer: “problem” + “attitude” + “expectation”. The best feedback on a question should include these 3 parts. You can use this standard to check whether the player’s feedback on this issue is complete.

[Image of 5W2H Framework]

The second point, “follow-up questions”. As mentioned earlier, the player’s ability to express and their understanding of the problem are not as good as we think. Sometimes, no matter how we follow up (pressure), the player can only say that the hit feedback is not good, but they can’t say why. At this time, the interviewer needs to have the above table (framework) in mind. The interviewer can gradually locate the specific problem point with the player within this framework.

[Image of gears working together]

For example, for the problem of poor hit feedback, we can first confirm with the player whether it is some action performance of the attack process that is not obvious, or the performance of the other party being hit is not obvious. If the player says that the performance of being hit is not obvious, then we will confirm whether the hit action is not real enough, the special effects performance is not strong enough, or the sound effects are not good enough. Follow this framework to determine the location of the problem step by step. This is a common method of gradually restoring the player’s feedback attitude to the game design.

[Image of a funnel going from high level view, to specifics]

The essence of this method is to think about the player’s problems within a framework. So for a professional interview master, what is needed is a framework for disassembling various game problems. This requires us to often do some game disassembly summaries and accumulations at ordinary times. For example, when a gameplay is not fun, how can we disassemble it into the game’s design? When a game’s art is reported as not good, how can we disassemble it into various details?

Let’s review. Today we talked about the first level of becoming an interview master, which is to be a good mouthpiece for players

So how do you become a good mouthpiece for players? The keyword is “disassemble”

Why do we need to disassemble? Because the player’s ability to express and analyze problems is not as good as we think

We need to guide the player step by step to discover the location of the problem within a framework, and gradually restore the player’s feedback attitude to the game design

How can we accumulate these frameworks? We need to play games more often, or when we find problems, we should do more game disassembly summaries and accumulations

So, as I just said, there are three levels to becoming an interview master. What about the other two?

To be continued, so stay tuned…

entry.title: Thoughts on Game Interaction Design in the "Hook Model"
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Do you often say to your friends in daily games, “Just 20 more minutes” or “Just one more round”? This kind of scenario where it’s hard to let go in the game is actually a common manifestation of our investment in the game, and even indicates that we may be “addicted” to the game. So today, let’s talk about the “Hook Model” theory that makes us addicted to games from the perspective of game interaction designers.

The “Hook Model” is a product design method proposed by Nir Eyal in Hooked that can engage users and gradually make them dependent. It mainly includes four steps: trigger, action, reward, and investment.

 

These four steps are a cyclical process. The more users are immersed in this cycle, the stronger the attraction of your product design. Conversely, when users stop this cycle, as a designer, you need to consider at which stage the user encountered a problem, why it did not meet the user’s expectations, and how to make the product design closely connected with the user’s behavior habits and emotional state.

Trigger

Everything is difficult at the beginning. The first step is to trigger the user to be motivated to use your product, which is called a trigger. As the first step in habit formation, triggers need to use pain points and needs to make users have expectations and attention. Therefore, as a designer, you need to clearly convey the user’s needs and desired goals to the user, arouse the user’s sense of participation. When designing, you not only need to display the user’s short-term goals, but also the display of long-term goals is extremely important.

 

In Shenmu (神都夜行录), the sign-in interface displays the special reward for the 10th day of sign-in - Jade Bi - independently. While giving users a higher goal, it also reminds users and stimulates them to log in again every time they sign in.

 

When the goal is too long-term to be achieved quickly, the user will not see the goal feedback at the beginning, so after a long time, they will become bored, which reduces the motivation to open the product. The sign-in goal in Onmyoji is relatively long-term, but when designing, the long-term goal is broken down into multiple more achievable phased small goals, which can better stimulate user motivation.

Action

After the previous stage triggered the user, in this stage we need the user to take effective action. The difficulty of taking action will directly affect the possibility of the user continuing the game. Therefore, it is necessary to meet the user’s psychological expectations, ensure that the core behavior entry is obvious, and high-frequency behavior operations are easy to implement. This stage requires us to sort out the user’s usage path, delete unnecessary operations, reduce the user’s action cost, and make the product design efficient and easy to use.

 

The main task prompt of Idol Company (拜托了经纪人) is permanently displayed on the main interface in a differentiated and prominent form. When you click to open the task details, you can click to directly jump to the corresponding function interface for operation. For example, you can directly enter a certain story chapter, or you can jump to the card development interface, etc., greatly reducing the user’s operation path and improving the user’s operation efficiency.

 

Dungeon-type games are usually repetitive and mechanical gameplay, mainly reflected in the scene, tasks, and operations. When designing, it is necessary to provide automated functions to reduce repetitive interfaces and save user operation time. For example, in Samurai Shodown, when the dungeon ends, in the area that is easy to operate on the horizontal screen, the function of challenging again is provided, reducing the threshold of action to improve the efficiency of clearing dungeons.

Reward

In addition to the ease of use of the product, the product must also be able to provide a variety of potential incentives to maintain the user’s interest, so that the user’s behavioral motivation can be satisfied, and the user’s desire to continue using it can be increased. When designing, it is necessary to grasp the user’s behavioral needs, give timely prompts and feedback, and let the user’s behavior have rewards.

 

In the ranking settlement of QQ Speed, the change in rank points is used to bring a sense of achievement to the user, and it also shows the change in the ranking of the user’s current rank points among the national users, which can further stimulate the user’s comparison psychology, so as to continuously carry out the ranking gameplay to surpass others.

 

Social showing off is also one of the driving user behavior methods in rewards. In the settlement interface of Peacekeeper Elite, in addition to strengthening the display of MVP user information, it also shows the achievements of the team users in the current game, so that users can use the achievements obtained as a capital to show off to other users and gain recognition, regardless of whether their performance is the most prominent in this game.

Investment

Investment refers to the time, energy, money, etc. that users invest in the product. In order to make users have psychological expectations and take action, it is necessary to strengthen the user’s cognition that the more investment, the better the service, and cultivate users to become loyal users. When designing, it is necessary to guide users to use the product again, and encourage users to continue to invest in the product to improve stickiness.

 

Whether it is a mobile game or an end game, the in-game mall and coupons are just needs of users. When Honor of Kings induces consumption and recharge, it insights into the user’s consumption tendency psychology and shows the difference in the recharge stage, so that users can clearly continue to recharge. It can bring about changes in the noble level and have more game privileges.

 

Users tend to overestimate the results of their labor input, so the more input, the more it can increase the user’s sense of exclusivity and self-identity. When Lovebrush Chronicles (lit. “Meeting Nishuihan”) ends the travel function, it prompts the rewards that can be obtained and the rewards that have not yet been obtained, accurately showing the gap brought about by different investments, and encouraging users to increase investment time to bring more rewards.

Conclusion

The “Hook Model” guides users to participate through goals, reduces user payment behavior, and gives feedback after each payment, and finally improves product stickiness through user payment. When designing, it is necessary to grasp the user’s pain points, plan the user’s behavior path, give users a sense of psychological satisfaction, and then continue to stimulate users to cycle investment, so that users are addicted to it will naturally be a matter of course.

Note: Cover material source: UI China Ellicia

entry.title: Introduction to UE Research Methods - Questionnaire Survey
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Last time we introduced the interview method in qualitative research. This time we will introduce the questionnaire survey in quantitative research.

 

(Image from the internet)

What is a questionnaire and what kind of information can it provide?

A questionnaire is a common quantitative research tool in social science research. It is highly self-reported and supports the rapid collection of large-sample data. Questionnaires can provide feedback on some of the respondents’ behavioral patterns (e.g., player type/daily game frequency), subjective feelings and attitudes (satisfaction with the game/willingness to recommend), and the scale/extent of feedback problems (e.g., the main problem reported by players is XXX, accounting for XX%). However, questionnaires can do little to understand the reasons behind the respondents’ behaviors and attitudes, and need to be combined with further qualitative research methods.

What are the advantages and disadvantages of the questionnaire method?

Advantages: It can quickly collect large-sample data at a lower cost, and the results can be quantitatively compared.

For example, by placing a game satisfaction questionnaire in the game, at least thousands of sample feedback can be collected in a short time to obtain satisfaction scores for longitudinal and horizontal comparison; while if interviews, intercepts, and other forms are used, it will consume a lot of manpower and time.

Disadvantages: The quality of questionnaire data will be affected by various factors such as the way of questioning, the attitude of the respondents, and the sensitivity of the questions, and the authenticity of the answers will be compromised. Moreover, the feedback content is often not deep enough, and is more biased towards phenomenon description.

Taking game satisfaction as an example again, the questionnaire can give us a general understanding of the satisfaction of large-sample players, but there are also the following problems: 1. Some players fill in the questionnaire sloppily and directly check the first option, without actually providing feedback on their true satisfaction. 2. We only get the players’ satisfaction scores, and do not know the reasons why high/low-scoring players gave the scores.

Application scenarios of questionnaire method in game user research

Questionnaires are widely used and basically run through all stages of game research. Here are a few examples.

  • Need to understand the game type preferences of a specific group of people (such as players of a certain game/fans of a certain IP): Distribute questionnaires in QQ groups, forums and other places where the target population gathers.
  • During the game testing period, it is necessary to introduce players with specific attributes: Use online questionnaires/telephone questionnaires on the reservation website to collect game experience and demographic information, and then screen out the required players.
  • During the game testing period, it is necessary to understand the players’ satisfaction with the game, pain points, etc.: Distribute questionnaires in the game, and use single-choice, multiple-choice, free-form and other forms of questions to collect player feedback.

 

Reservation screening questionnaire, surveying players’ game behavior habits and preferred game types

 

Example of an in-game questionnaire, investigating players’ satisfaction with a certain gameplay

General steps of questionnaire research

 

Tips for questionnaire research

1. Questionnaire design should be carried out around the research purpose to ensure that the data comes from the target population.

Before designing, it is necessary to communicate the needs well and clarify the purpose of the questionnaire to ensure that the results of the questionnaire meet the research needs. This also helps to control the number of questions. In addition, the first draft of the questionnaire can be written in the form of Excel, Xmind, etc., which is convenient for quick modification and clarification of ideas, and does not need to directly produce a fillable electronic questionnaire. In addition, there are certain risks in distributing questionnaires in the name of the company, and it is necessary to check repeatedly and from multiple parties when distributing.

2. In scenarios with a large sample size, use closed-ended questions (single-choice, multiple-choice, scale) instead of open-ended free-form questions.

Free-form questions with large samples often mean collecting a long string of text data that is difficult to quantify uniformly and has a huge workload of coding. For the convenience of data analysis and the vertical and horizontal comparison of results, closed-ended questions should be used as much as possible. The options for closed-ended questions can be determined through runs, public opinion, feedback from previous versions, and communication with planners.

 

(Free-form results are often bizarre…)

3. In terms of question design, it is necessary to make the questions easy to understand and answer.

  • Keep the questionnaire logically smooth and reduce the cognitive burden on players. Put questions from the same module together, or directly use matrix questions.
  • Avoid using jargon, and make questions and options easy to understand or add annotations:
    • Counter-example: What kind of fun do you value more in the process of experiencing ARPG games? [Players may not understand what an ARPG game is, or it may be different from UE’s understanding of ARPG]
  • A single question should only examine one issue, and should not involve multiple contents:
    • Counter-example: What do you think of the art style and art quality of the XXX game? [Art style and art quality are two different questions]
  • Avoid leading questions: Due to the existence of acquiescence bias, players’ answers will be affected by the way of questioning.
    • Counter-example: Is the operation of combining rough stones too cumbersome? [Player’s inner thoughts: Is it cumbersome? I didn’t pay attention, so it’s cumbersome]
  • Pay attention to the randomization of options for some questions (completely random, ascending/descending order) to eliminate the influence of positive statements (such as choosing the first answer)

entry.title: Introduction to Brand Advertising Click-Through Rate Prediction Models and Algorithms
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

What is Ad Click-Through Rate Prediction?

To understand what ad click-through rate prediction is, we first need to understand the basic components of a general advertising business. A general advertising business can be divided into three main components: advertisers, advertising media, and advertising traffic.

Advertisers are the parties with advertising needs, hoping to increase the awareness of their brand products by exposing advertisements on various media; advertising traffic is the group reached by advertisements, that is, the audience of advertisements. For different types of advertisements, the groups they hope to reach are also different; the advertising medium is the intermediate platform connecting advertisers and advertising traffic. Advertising traffic obtains information from the advertising medium, and the advertising medium will provide the advertising content required by the advertiser to the advertising traffic.

In the past, the main carriers of advertising were billboards, print media, and television, and other traditional media. In the era of mobile Internet, brand advertising exposure based on various applications and portal websites has become a new way of advertising display. Different from traditional media advertising, this type of advertising has the characteristics of large advertising traffic, large amounts of data, and real-time push. Since such advertisements can be directly clicked, many advertising platforms will charge based on the click-through rate of advertisements.

So, how to measure the effectiveness of advertising on such media? Based on this, the concept of ad click-through rate came into being, which is expressed as the ratio of ad clicks to ad impressions over a period of time.

Since an ad click is a sign that an ad audience is attracted to the ad, ad platforms and advertisers always want to maximize the click-through rate of ads. Different users are attracted to different ads to different degrees. Therefore, as an intermediary, the advertising platform always hopes to push the most attractive ads to each user, so as to maximize the click-through rate of various ads.

To achieve this great goal, the intermediary begins to rack their brains to predict the click-through rate of each advertisement among different groups of people, hoping to know the attractiveness of each advertisement among different groups of people before the advertisement is displayed, so that it is easier to push the advertisement. This process of wanting to achieve the function of predicting the future is called ad click-through rate prediction.

Problems Encountered in Ad Click-Through Rate Prediction

In the previous section, we mentioned that in order to improve the effectiveness of ad display, the ad platform hopes to predict in advance which ad is most likely to be clicked by the same user. Therefore, the ad platform needs to build a model based on data from multiple perspectives such as ad content and ad audience, so as to achieve ad click-through rate prediction. However, some problems encountered in this process may discount the prediction effect, which can be roughly classified into three points:

(1) The advertising platform obtains fewer data fields and has more categorical features. As an intermediary, due to legal factors such as user protection regulations, it is generally difficult for advertising platforms to obtain detailed information about the advertising audience. Even the information obtained is often categorical features such as “whether the mobile phone brand is Huawei”, which makes it difficult to build a model;

(2) Compared with single feature factors, feature interaction factors are more important for click-through rate prediction. For example, middle-aged men from Boston, USA are more likely to click on sports product advertisements. The click of an advertisement is often the result of a combination of multiple feature factors. However, due to the large number of feature interaction items, it is easy to cause feature dimension explosion by constructing interaction features through traversal;

(3) Cold start problem. When a new advertisement is connected to the platform, since it has little sample data, or even no record of the advertisement being clicked, it will be very difficult to predict the click-through rate of the advertisement through a model built based on data.

How to Achieve Ad Click-Through Rate Prediction

In order to achieve ad click-through rate prediction and overcome the three difficulties mentioned in the previous section, some advertising systems often use feature engineering + machine learning model + Bayesian smoothing to achieve this. This article mainly focuses on the machine learning model and Bayesian smoothing.

Logistic Regression Model:

Basic principle: The logistic regression model is a model used earlier in click-through rate prediction. It combines the relationship between features in a linear form and then maps it to a range between 0 and 1, so as to provide the model user with the probability of a user clicking on an advertisement.

What problems are solved:

  1. As shown in the formula, the logistic regression model has a relatively simple form and can still be trained quickly under large-scale feature dimensions;

  2. Logistic regression performs well on data based on categorical features, and the data required by the model is more in line with the basic data characteristics of ad click-through rate prediction;

  3. The model is highly interpretable. For an advertising flow, it is easy to know what features of the flow make it more likely to click on the advertisement based on the weight of each feature of the model, which facilitates further optimization of feature engineering.

What are the shortcomings:

  1. It does not solve the problem of the large dimension of feature interaction factors well. Although the logistic regression form is relatively simple and easy to train, based on the construction of interaction items from actual data features, the model still has huge parameters to deal with;

  2. Logistic regression performs poorly on continuous variables (such as age, online time, etc.), so continuous variables cannot be well used for modeling in click-through rate prediction.

Factorization Machine Model:

Basic principle: In view of the fact that data interaction items are important in ad click-through rate prediction and have a large dimension, the Factorization Machine (FM) model has made targeted processing of interaction item information. Because in actual business, data is often sparse, that is, advertising traffic has no value or meaningless value on most features, the FM model predefines a certain number of derived dimensions, and compresses the huge sparse features to this derived dimension, and only considers the interaction of this part of the derived dimension. This reduces the number of model parameters and takes into account the interaction between features.

What problems are solved:

  1. Transform sparse dimensional data into dense dimensional data to improve model generalization ability;

  2. Take interaction items into account and control the number of model parameters.

What are the shortcomings:

  1. The model only considers the interaction between two features, and does not consider the interaction between more features;

  2. Since the features are compressed, the interpretability of the model is not as strong as that of the logistic regression model.

Ensemble Learning Models:

Basic principle: For example, the Xgboost model, GBDT model, and Lightgbm model organize decision trees or regression tree models in a regular manner to improve the generalization ability of the model. Ensemble learning models also consider multi-dimensional interaction factors between features.

What problems are solved:

  1. Multi-dimensional feature interaction information can be automatically discovered according to the tree model;

  2. Determine the importance of features according to the weight of different features in the decision tree to make splitting decisions;

What are the shortcomings:

  1. Since the tree model is limited by depth, the model is still unable to extract higher-dimensional interactions. Generally, it is necessary to use the high-dimensional interaction obtained by the neural network model as a feature to assist decision-making;

  2. The model structure is relatively complex, and its training iteration period is longer than other models. This shortcoming causes difficulties for ad click-through rate prediction businesses that require rapid iteration.

In view of the advantages and disadvantages of different models, different models are often used in combination in practice, and each plays its advantages in different links.

Bayesian Smoothing:

Bayes, a probability theory expert who has tortured the majority of mathematics students, believes that everything has a probability distribution. For example, the probability of the sun rising from the west tomorrow is 0%, and the probability of rising from the east is 100%. We can give the probability of many things on various values before they happen. The click-through rate of advertisements is no exception. Perhaps because this pre-given probability distribution is not accurate enough to be convincing, we always hope to correct this experience (prior) that we have pre-determined through the results observed during the actual occurrence. After this correction, our new experience (posterior) will be more credible.

Therefore, in order to solve the problem that the model fails due to insufficient samples of new advertisements, Bayesian smoothing abstracts the ad click-through rate into a probability distribution from the perspective of probability statistics. This probability distribution shows the possibility of the click-through rate of an advertisement in different sections.

For the problem that new advertisements do not have enough data to support their probability distribution, the click-through rate probability distribution of other advertisements can be used as the click-through rate distribution of new advertisements. Then, based on the experience of certain data accumulated by the new advertisement during the continuous exposure, this ad click-through rate distribution is corrected. Finally, based on the posterior click-through rate distribution, we take the most likely point of this ad click-through rate as the estimate of the click-through rate of this advertisement.

In this way, not only can the estimated value of the click-through rate of new advertisements be effectively obtained, but also the click-through rate of the model can be corrected each time. For example, a certain model judges that the probability of a user clicking on the advertisement is 10%, but Bayesian smoothing believes that the probability of the click-through rate taking this value is very low and needs to be corrected, so it is adjusted based on the click-through rate distribution. Finally, the adjusted estimated click-through rate will be more accurate.

entry.title: Let's Talk About Interaction Design in Game Settlements
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

This is a reflection on game interaction design, and I want to take this opportunity to talk about the positioning of interaction designers and their core competitiveness.

Everyone should be familiar with the settlement interface. Almost every game has its own settlement interface. As game interaction designers, when faced with such a mature and numerous reference interface requirements, how to make our designs stand out among many competing products has become a problem that needs to be considered. When faced with such a demand, I first chose to see how competing products do it. So I searched for relevant content on Baidu, but the results were very disappointing.

 

The search results are roughly as above. A closer analysis reveals that these settlement interfaces have several commonalities. The basic elements included in the interface can be summarized into the following categories: ribbons, wings, trumpets, stars, etc. These are basic GUI elements. This means that, aside from visual elements, the above settlements have little difference from an interaction perspective.

However, there are many beautifully designed settlements on the market. The following are excellent cases in my mind:

 

First of all, the settlement of Overwatch is different from the usual ideas. Overwatch first displays the best shots of the game before the settlement values. Even if you are the losing side, you may appear here. This design idea will weaken the performance of the battle’s win or loss, allowing players to focus more on making wonderful operations themselves.

 

Secondly, the settlement of Extraordinary Ones also has a new design before the numerical settlement. As a MOBA game, the relationship between winning and losing will greatly affect the player’s emotions. Therefore, as the losing side, a link of blaming teammates is designed before the numerical settlement, which cleverly transforms the original negative emotions of failure into a situation of teasing teammates, greatly reducing the unpleasant experience of failure.

 

The settlement of Kung Fu Panda uses the story bridges in the movie IP, combining the settlement rewards with the movie plot, which is full of situational immersion. This design will make players feel familiar with the game, and it is also more in line with the players’ psychological expectations.

 

Then there is the settlement of Heroes of the Storm. Winning or losing is not what the designer wants to express most. Compared with winning or losing itself, the designer hopes that the game itself will bring fun to the players. In Heroes of the Storm, the performance of each player is what the designer wants to express more, so it will highlight the display of data such as MVP, most kills, and most siege damage.

Try to analyze what role interaction designers might play in these excellent cases, or what we as interaction designers can do.

 

It is not difficult to find that in these excellent design cases, designers are no longer only focusing on layout and the expression of visual elements. Designers have begun to think about the core of the game from the gameplay itself, and then apply it to the design.

——This is the core competitiveness of game interaction designers.

Game interaction, as a branch of Internet interaction, is not feasible to completely copy the design thinking of the Internet. Games, as one of the branches of art products, should also be full of artistic features in their design. This also requires us as game interaction designers to think deeper, so sometimes we need to regard ourselves as “half a planner”, to think about the game play itself, and to immerse ourselves in the worldview, only with heart can we make interesting things.

entry.title: Chengdu Internet Cafe Research Insights
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

The previous two articles shared insights from player testing in Japan and the United States. This time, we want to share some insights from the Internet cafe research conducted by the Leihuo UX department in March 2019. One of our research locations was in Chengdu, and the research content was to understand players’ expectations for new games and new gameplay. The research method combined qualitative interviews and quantitative questionnaires.

Research Preparation

Before the research, both the product team and Leihuo UX were full of curiosity about the front-line market – what games are our users playing? What kind of games are they looking forward to? In addition to in-game questionnaires and in-game player behavior, we should communicate with players face-to-face to understand their real thoughts. This is the motivation for this research.

[Receiving the Demand] When the UX department received the demand for research in multiple Internet cafes across the country, the team members were eager to try – the food seemed to be a bigger part: It’s not the NetEase cafeteria’s fault, I just shouldn’t have smelled the scent of Sichuan cuisine.

 

(First, arrange all the food)

[Plan Preparation] Before departure, confirm the usability of the plan, questionnaire, interview outline, and observation record sheet. These quantitative data will play an important role in future reports.

 

(The plan went through repeated revisions and iterations)

[Departure Preparation] Before departure, based on the experience of Internet cafe research in the Hangzhou area, the Chengdu Internet cafe research team made a schedule based on the location of the Internet cafes to ensure coverage of Internet cafes in different circles. In later reports, it is also possible to observe players’ preferences for games through different circles and different player types.

 

(A detailed schedule is essential)

[Plan Preparation Summary]

  • Schedule: – Specific to the flight number, the schedule is more precise, but leaves room.
  • Internet cafe research: – Prepare alternative research Internet cafes, and strategically abandon the Internet cafe in case of emergencies
  • Map preparation: – Let members know which circle I am in
  • Interview guide: – Foolproof teaching guide, the final plan completely mastered the interview skills
  • Reimbursement expenses: – Remember to get an invoice

Research Implementation

Before the research, the marketing expert showed us the vision of this research: “Our Internet cafe player ratio is very high, and there are also many female players.”

 

(Expected Internet cafe research)

 

(Real Internet cafe research)

[First Day of Research]

None of the team members had experience in Internet cafe research. The first day of trial and error encountered a lot of obstacles. First of all, the motivation for players to come to the Internet cafe is to play games, and a large part of it is to play with friends, so it is difficult to say that they have time to accept an interview that requires a high degree of concentration. Secondly, the noisy environment in the Internet cafe also caused considerable difficulties for the interview.

 

(The first player in the Chengdu research was interviewed surrounded by 5 staff members, and the player was under great pressure)

[Second Day of Research]

On the second day of Internet cafe research, we figured out the living habits of Internet cafe players. There are actually not many players during the day, and the sample size is limited, but the peak number of Internet cafe players is from 20:00 to 23:00. At this time, the queuing phenomenon in the Internet cafe also provides us with opportunities to find interviewees who are highly willing to cooperate.

 

(Current situation of Internet cafes – PUBG and LOL)

[Third Day of Research]

After two days of research, the division of labor within the group was clearer and the cooperation efficiency was higher. According to the time and cooperation degree of the interviewees, we divided the players into two contact types: for players with low willingness, we adopted the rapid interview mode, that is, 1 person interview + 1 person record or 1 person rapid interview + recording. For players who are highly willing to cooperate, we adopt the in-depth interview mode, combining UE interviews with supplementary questions from the planners.

 

(On the third day of the research, an in-depth interview with an Internet cafe owner)

 

(Internet cafe players watching Yang Chaoyue draw lots on March 16)

Conclusion

[Experience]

  1. Understood the situation of Chengdu Internet cafe players and the current situation of the Internet cafe industry;
  2. Met and became familiar with many colleagues;
  3. The marketing planners finally mastered the interview skills and can conduct interviews independently;
  4. Members returned with a full load (both in terms of burden and weight);

 

(Some of the food during the research)

entry.title: How to Use Vim
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Vim Application Background

The full name of the Vim editor is Visual interface improved, and the specific interface is shown in the figure below.

The application scenarios of the Vim editor mainly include:

(1) Need to deploy the environment and develop code in a Linux environment. Linux often requires the use of the VIM editor for code development;

Currently, many IDEs support VIM mode, such as PyCharm/IntelliJ IDEA and other mainstream IDEs. The advantage of the Vim editor is that it does not require much mouse operation and can support all operations using the keyboard, achieving fast movement, fast input, and effective block operations. The disadvantage of the Vim editor is that it requires memorizing many operation shortcuts and command lines.

4 Modes of Vim Editor

The Vim editor has four modes. It is in normal mode by default, including normal mode, insert mode, command-line mode, and visual mode. The conversion relationship between the 4 modes is shown in the figure below.

So how are the 4 modes converted?

(1) Convert normal mode to insert mode, the specific operations are as follows:

Command Description
i Insert text before the cursor
I Insert text at the beginning of the line
a Append text after the cursor
A Append text at the end of the line
o Open a new line below the current line and enter insert mode
O Open a new line above the current line and enter insert mode
ea Append text at the end of the word

(2) Convert insert mode to normal mode, the specific operations are as follows:

Command Description
Esc Switch back to Normal mode from Insert mode.
Ctrl-[ An alternative that achieves the same as ESC.
Ctrl-C Same effect

(3) Convert normal mode to command-line mode, the specific operations are as follows:

Command Description
: Enter command-line mode. You then type a command and press Enter.
/ To search forward.
? To search backwards.

(4) Convert command-line mode to normal mode, the specific operations are as follows:

Command Description
Esc Return to Normal mode.
Enter Execute the command and return to Normal Mode.
Ctrl-[ Return to Normal Mode.
Ctrl-C Return to Normal Mode.

(5) Convert normal mode to visual mode, the specific operations are as follows:

Command Description
v Enter visual mode (characterwise). You can then move the cursor to select text.
V Enter visual line mode (linewise). Selects entire lines.
Ctrl-v Enter visual block mode (rectangular selection). Very useful for selecting columns of text.

(6) Convert visual mode to normal mode, the specific operations are as follows:

Command Description
Esc Return to normal mode
Ctrl-[ Return to Normal Mode.
Ctrl-C Return to Normal Mode.

Vim Operation: Cursor Movement

Vim editor cursor movement is all operated in normal mode.

(1) Unit level: character as the unit

Command Description
h Move left one character
j Move down one line
k Move up one line
l Move right one character

(2) Word level

Command Description
w or W Move to the beginning of the next word
e or E Move to the end of the current word
b or B Move to the beginning of the previous word

(3) Block level

Command Description
gg Go to the first line of the document
G Go to the last line of the document
0 Go to the beginning of the line (column 1)
^ Go to the first non-blank character of the line
$ Go to the end of the line
Ctrl-d Move down half a page
Ctrl-u Move up half a page
Ctrl-f Move down one page
Ctrl-b Move up one page
:<N> or <N>gg Jump to line N
:+<N> or <N>j Jump down N lines
:-<N> or <N>k Jump up N lines

It should be noted here that: all commands can be preceded by a number N, indicating that the following command is executed N times. For example, if you want to move down 3 lines, in addition to using :+3, you can also use 3j to achieve the same effect. In addition, there are actually two types of commands above: one is executed immediately after typing, such as gg; the other is to enter : first (there will also be a slash / first later). This type of command needs to be executed by pressing Enter after input, and the same is true in the following tutorial content.

Vim Operation: Open File, Find Content

Vim editor file and content operations are also performed in normal mode.

(1) Open a file in Vim

Command Description
:e <filename> Open the file named filename, if the file does not exist, create it
:Ex Open the directory tree in Vim, select with the cursor and press Enter to open the corresponding file (Tip: - enter the upper-level directory)

(2) Find within the document

Command Description
* Find the next occurrence of the word currently under the cursor.
# Find the previous occurrence of the word currently under the cursor.
/<search> Search forward for the specified string.
?<search> Search backward for the specified string.
n Continue searching for the next occurrence.
N Continue searching for the previous occurrence.

Note for the above operations: n and N are directional. If you searched by * before, n will continue to search towards the end of the document, and N will search towards the beginning of the document; conversely, if you searched by #, n will point to the beginning of the document, and N will point to the end of the document.

Vim Operation: File Modification and Saving

(1) Insert: in insert mode

Command Description
i Insert before current char
a Insert after the current character
I Insert at the beginning of the line
A Insert at the end of the line
o Insert on the next line
O Insert on the previous line

Precautions for file insertion operations: Any of the above commands will make Vim enter insert mode. After entering insert mode, the cursor will change. At this time, the text entered will appear directly in the document. Press the Esc key or Ctrl-[ or Ctrl-C to exit insert mode

(2) Delete (and save to Vim clipboard): in normal mode

Command Description
x Delete the current character, equivalent to Delete in insert mode
X Delete the previous character, equivalent to Backspace in insert mode
dd Delete the current line and save the deleted content to the Vim clipboard
d<X> Delete the specified content and save it to the Vim clipboard
c<X> Delete the specified content, save it to the Vim clipboard, and enter insert mode

Supplementary note for delete operation: The part is a description of the operation content. To delete a word, enter dw or de; to copy the content from the current position to the end of the line, enter y$; to delete the next 3 characters and insert, enter c3l, etc.

(3) Copy: in normal mode

Command Description
yy Copy the current line to the Vim clipboard
y<X> Copy the specified content to the Vim clipboard

(4) Paste: in normal mode

Command Description
p Paste after the current position
P Paste before the current position

(5) Replace: in normal mode

Command Description
r<X> Replace the current character with X
gu<X> Convert the specified text to lowercase
gU<X> Convert the specified text to uppercase

In addition to the above replacement operations in normal mode, you can use the commands in command-line mode to replace the content of the document. The specific command format is as follows:

:[range]s/search/string/[flags] [count]

Search for the search content according to the pattern regular expression, and replace it with the string replacement content. The description of the options in the specific command is shown in the table below.

Option Description
range The range of lines. % means the entire file, same as 1,$. . means current line and $ the last line.
search The text to search for
string The text to replace search with.
flags g (global) replaces all occurrences. c (confirm) requires confirmation before each replacement.
count The number of lines to apply the command to (starting from the end of range or the current line).

(6) Undo, redo: in normal mode

Command Description
u Undo
Ctrl-r Redo

(7) Save the file: in command-line mode

Command Description
:w Save the current file
:wa Save all files
:wq or ZZ Save and exit
:q! or ZQ Force quit, do not save
:saveas <newfilename> Save the file as
:w <newfilename> Save a copy of the file as and continue editing the original file

Vim Settings and Tips

(1) Vim settings

Command Description
:set number Show line numbers
:set relativenumber Show relative line numbers (this is very important, take your time to appreciate)
:set hlsearch Highlight search results
:set autoindent Automatic indentation
:set smartindent Smart indentation
:set tabstop=4 Set the width of the tab character to 4
:set softtabstop=4 Set the indent width to 4 when pressing tab
:set shiftwidth=4 Set the automatic indentation width to 4
:set expandtab Convert tab characters to spaces when indenting
:filetype on Enable file type detection
:syntax on Enable syntax highlighting

Supplementary note: The commands are listed here. You can enter them in Vim for setting, but the parameters set in this way are only effective before closing Vim this time. If you exit Vim and open it again, the previous settings will be invalid. To make it permanently effective, you need to modify an automatic configuration file of Vim, generally the file path is /home//.vimrc (Linux system) or /Users//.vimrc (MacOS system)

(2) Repeat the last command: in normal mode

Vim has a special command: .

(3) Indentation: in normal mode

Command Description
>> Indent the current line to the right
<< Indent the current line to the left

Try pressing 3>>, <<, and <G on this line.

(4) Automatic formatting: in normal mode

Command Description
== Automatically format the current line
gg=G Automatically format the entire current document
<N>== Automatically format N lines starting from the current line
=<N>j Automatically format the current line and N lines down
=<N>k Automatically format the current line and N lines up

(5) Split screen: in command-line mode

Command Description
:split (abbr: :sp) or Ctrl-w s Split horizontally
:vsplit (abbr: :vs) or Ctrl-w v Split vertically

(6) Window jump

Command Description
Ctrl-w w Activate next window
Ctrl-w j Activate window below
Ctrl-w k Activate window above
Ctrl-w h Activate window left
Ctrl-w l Activate window right

(7) Screen zoom

Command Description
Ctrl-w = Average window size
Ctrl-w + Increase height
Ctrl-w - Decrease height
Ctrl-w _ Maximum height
Ctrl-w > Increase width
Ctrl-w < Reduce width
Ctrl-w | Maximum width

entry.title: Mobile Game Social System - Detailed Explanation of Friends Interface Interaction Design (Part 2)
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

The social system has always been an indispensable part of many games. Although it is not directly related to the core gameplay, it is a key system to increase player immersion and improve retention.

In the previous sharing session (click to review), we summarized the functional blocks and detailed information items usually included in the mobile game friends interface (see the figure below), and analyzed the interaction levels and design details that usually need to be considered in the UI design of the casual mobile game friends interface with the UNO! project as an example. In the games we usually encounter, we can also find that the friends interface of common casual mobile games and battle royale mobile games are similar in design.

 

However, the design of the friends interface of heavily social MMO mobile games will be different from this, such as A Chinese Ghost Story (倩女幽魂) and Moonlight Blade Mobile (天涯明月刀). A Chinese Ghost Story is famous for its excellent social design. First of all, in terms of overall functional blocks, A Chinese Ghost Story also includes existing friends, finding friends, and message notifications. However, in the specific function point planning and interaction design, A Chinese Ghost Story will have some designs that emphasize and promote social interaction. Here, we will take A Chinese Ghost Story and UNO! as examples to compare the differences in the design of friends interfaces between heavily social MMO mobile games and casual mobile games.

Home Page Structure Difference - Friends List or Friends Chat

In the previous sharing session, we can see that the home page of the casual friends interface is usually a friends list, listing friends information and including some basic interaction operations and entrances. Friends dialogue is used as a secondary interface, which is entered through the chat entry on the friends list.

The home page of A Chinese Ghost Story‘s friends is obviously different. It directly puts the dialogue window on the home page, and the friends list corresponds to the chat window. Moreover, the default display is not the ordinary friends list, but the recent contacts. The friends list and other detailed information are hidden in the secondary interface.

Putting the chat or detailed information list on the home page, the difference between these two levels clearly reflects the different emphasis. A Chinese Ghost Story puts the recent contact chat window on the outermost layer, which greatly facilitates and encourages players to have dialogue and interaction with friends, and allows them to view new messages at the first time, which can better promote the formation of social relationships.

 

(A Chinese Ghost Story Mobile Game Friends System Home Page)

 

(UNO! Mobile Game Friends System Home Page)

Social Circle Function - Mengdao (梦岛)

In the friends interface of A Chinese Ghost Story, there is also a special system called “Mengdao”. Mengdao is similar to the function of WeChat Moments and QQ Zone. Players can publish their own status, and other players can leave comments and so on. The addition of the Mengdao system greatly enhances the atmosphere of social interaction in the game. Players can not only share content in the game, but also exchange many feelings outside the game. This makes the social system in A Chinese Ghost Story not only a necessary communication for game play, but also a social circle for players.

 

(A Chinese Ghost Story Mobile Game Friends - Mengdao Interface)

Contact Management - Friend Grouping

In A Chinese Ghost Story‘s contact system, friends can be grouped. Combined with a variety of social relationship settings in the game, such as sworn brotherhood, master-apprentice, husband-wife, teammates, etc., players can refine and manage their social relationships. Complex social relationships are the premise for building a player’s social network. However, light social mobile games like UNO! do not have a strong demand for friend grouping. Some will add some labels to the friend entries, such as recent teams.

 

(A Chinese Ghost Story Mobile Game Friend Grouping Interface)

Through these points, we can find that the friends systems of UNO! and A Chinese Ghost Story have their own emphasis, which depends on the system’s own positioning of light or heavy social interaction and functional requirements. When we do UI design, we also need to combine the needs of the planning itself to plan the interface hierarchy, consider design details, and emphasize or weaken corresponding elements, in order to better achieve the design goals.

entry.title: Musings on Consumer Psychology and Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

“Wow, everyone bought that new costume, I’m going to get one for my in-game partner!”

—— Conformity

“This weapon skin is on sale for only 99, what a bargain.”

—— Bargain Hunting

“There’s another new lottery event, I’m going to keep drawing, let’s open some boxes.”

—— Customer Loyalty

“Consumption” has unknowingly filled our lives, and games have become an indispensable part of some young people’s consumption. The “psychology” behind it has gradually been recognized by researchers and game developers. So how does consumer psychology come about? What is consumer psychology like in games?

 

Definition of Consumer Psychology

Consumer psychology is an emerging discipline that aims to study people’s psychological activities and personality traits in the process of life consumption and daily purchasing behavior.

Why is it important to study consumer psychology?

Why aren’t your players buying your costumes and appearances anymore?

Why did I spend so much money on the game this month?

It’s the game’s anniversary, what gift should I buy for my in-game partner?

 

Almost all behaviors in the game are directly or indirectly related to consumption. Only by fully understanding the player’s motivation, interests, and cognition can we possibly predict the player’s behavior.

The Origin and Development of Consumer Psychology

According to a review published by Jia, H., Zhou, S., and Allaway, A. W. (2018) in the Journal of Consumer Behavior, research related to consumer psychology appeared as early as the 19th century, when a scholar named Gale conducted an advertising effectiveness assessment based on attention and memory. Of course, when the author searched for information, he found that Fan Li in the Spring and Autumn Period had already analyzed consumer needs and managed business with “Ji Ran’s Seven Strategies”, and Xunzi proposed that production should “nurture people’s desires and satisfy people’s needs” (“Xunzi·Li Lun”), which is about meeting people’s consumption needs; in the West, Xenophon analyzed the relationship between family income and family consumption earlier. Of course, these were some early knowledge accumulation stages that were not systematic and not a discipline. It was not until 1965 that consumer psychology was first truly called a special discipline.

In their article, they mainly used the bibliometric method (simply counting the number of literature Co-citation analysis, the number of authors Co-authorship analysis, etc.) and network analysis (Networking analysis, simply counting keywords) to sort out the origin and development of consumer psychology as a whole.

 

Among them, the number of articles in the field of consumer psychology remained fairly stable between 1942 and 1992. Later, in the 1990s, as market research emphasized the importance of loyal customers to profitability (Reicheld, 1993) and the importance of branding, branding became very competitive. Since 2006, the number of published consumer psychology articles has increased dramatically, with an average of more than 70 articles published per year. Another important trigger is the popularity of online shopping. In the era of Web 2.0, more and more people are attracted to online shopping, which has triggered important research on consumers’ responses to this new shopping model. In a sense, games are also a derivative of the Web 2.0 era.

Below are two word clouds about consumer psychology in a short period of time.

 

1942-1992 Word Cloud

 

1993–2016 Word Cloud

We will talk about the content of games and consumer psychology in the next issue, and please continue to pay attention to NetEase Leihuo UX User Experience Center~

Main References

Jia, H., Zhou, S., & Allaway, A. W. (2018). Understanding the evolution of consumer psychology research: A bibliometric and network analysis. Journal of Consumer Behaviour, 17(5), 491-502.

Appendix:

The top 10 journals on consumer psychology by publication volume are as follows:

  • Journal of Consumer Psychology
  • Journal of Economic Psychology
  • Journal of Applied Psychology
  • Journal of Product and Brand Management
  • Journal of Consumer Marketing
  • Qualitative Market Research
  • European Journal of Marketing
  • Psychology and Marketing
  • Journal of Business Research
  • Journal of Advertising

entry.title: Interaction Design of Settlement Interface
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Last week, a colleague shared the interaction design in game settlement. From a macro perspective, they shared and reflected on the existing settlement design, and concluded that a good settlement should be able to weaken the sense of victory and defeat, shift emotions, and increase the fun of the game, rather than just the notification of victory and defeat and the accumulation of data. I happened to be working on the settlement part recently, so I would like to share some detailed insights on the design of the settlement interface.

First of all, before designing the settlement interface, we need to think about why our game needs settlement. Is it to determine the winner, to reward players, or to allow players to summarize the experience of this battle? The settlement interface is not a single page, but a long string of player experience. Distinguishing the primary and secondary design goals can help us effectively guide the specific design.

For example, the victory/defeat animation after a game is the first part of the settlement that players come into contact with. At this time, if you need to emphasize the result of victory or if there is very complicated settlement content later, then use exaggerated animation to display it in the design without adding other information. This often appears in relatively strong competitive games, and victory or defeat itself is also one of the core driving forces of players. However, attention should be paid to the transfer and comfort of the frustration of failure, and the situation of player loss due to the frustration of game failure should be reduced.

 

If we want to emphasize the rewarded items or the player’s score. To attract players through generous prizes and changes in ratings, we can consider reducing the proportion of wins and losses, and adding to rewards. Rewards can even be made into a separate screen of animation to enhance the joy of players, and shift their focus from winning or losing. For ratings, rising in the rankings and surpassing oneself can bring a strong sense of satisfaction to players.

 

 

 

Next, according to “why”, we design “what we want”, that is, what information we need to give to players, which is more important, which is of concern to all players, and which is what high-end players want to see. At this stage, it is necessary to sort out the structure of information in detail with the planner. Many times, the planning draft received by the interaction designer is already categorized by the planner, such as the planning case of the personal record page, the planning case of the team record, etc. They have placed the information from the perspective of the planner, but whether the player is willing to read it and whether they can understand it needs to be considered by the interaction designer. Therefore, when doing this part of the content, you must control the information as a whole, and not just design a single page.

 

In addition, many times the planner itself is also the most senior player of this game, so many times the plan given by the planner is not friendly to novice players, and novice players will get lost in the ocean of data and cannot find the key points. At this time, it is necessary to do subtraction. A more common method is to divide the information into levels, and hide the more in-depth and secondary information into other tabs or pop-up windows, which can better highlight the core data, and hardcore players can also choose to view more complex information.

Finally, there is how to display. Excel-style data will make players lose interest in viewing. Introducing some three-dimensional models or dynamic visualization data can greatly improve the readability of the data. For example, in Dota 2, players can choose different characters for data comparison, and the economic curve trend chart in Honor of Kings can give players a clearer understanding and feeling of the game.

 

 

Settlement is the final stage of a game. It is a stage for players to summarize themselves and feedback on the game experience. It is not just cold data and cutscenes, but it can also help players understand the game, improve their skills, and warm up for the next game. A large part of the player’s sense of accomplishment comes from this. Therefore, more design thinking should be invested in the design.
