entry.title: Western Fonts and Brand Design - Typeface & Brand
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

In recent years, many well-known font foundries have been commissioned by large enterprises and public organizations to create and develop thousands of custom corporate fonts. The brand image, as a concrete manifestation of the brand, is composed of many elements, such as: logo, font, brand color, packaging, IP image, etc. Each aspect affects the user’s perception of the brand.

Large enterprises have a wide variety of products under their umbrella, but their logos are diverse, making unification difficult. Using a unified brand font is a simple and effective way to improve the recognition of corporate products.

Speaking of brand font design, we have to mention Akira Kobayashi, a Western font designer who has designed brand fonts for both Alibaba and Tencent in recent years. The following introduces some basic knowledge introduced by Mr. Kobayashi in Western fonts.

1. Western Fonts

Western writing refers to all Western languages, including English, French, German, etc. Compared with Chinese and Japanese characters, Western writing does not have such a long history. Starting from Greek inscriptions, it took about 2000 years for the writing of the Roman Empire to take shape in the 1st century AD.

The classic proportions of the Trajan’s Column inscription in Rome are our best example of capital letters. Later, scribes in medieval monasteries and humanists in the 15th century created contemporary writing styles. Various fonts were born in the following centuries.

Some classic fonts commonly used now are: Helvetica, Arial, Didot, Futura, Univers, Neo Sans, Myriad, Times New Roman, etc.

2. Technical Terms

Glyph & Typeface

“Glyph” refers to the characteristic stroke direction and stroke position of a character that distinguishes it from other characters. If the glyph is compared to the skeleton, then the typeface is equivalent to the muscle attached to the skeleton. For example, SimSun and SimHei have the same glyphs, but different typefaces.

The glyphs of Microsoft YaHei are significantly different from them, mainly in the direction of the strokes.

[Image: Comparison of SimSun, SimHei, and Microsoft YaHei]

Roman Typeface (Serif Typeface)

Roman type, the more authoritative explanation for the origin of serifs is that it is a remnant of the traces of writing with a flat-headed pen when drafting inscriptions in the Roman era.

[Image: Example of Serif Typeface]

Italic

Italic is a handwriting style used in Italy. The font formed by simply tilting the outline data of the Roman typeface is called “oblique.”

[Image: Example of Italic Typeface]

Sans-serif Typeface

In French, “sans” means “without”, and sans-serif means “without serifs”. Sans-serif fonts are ubiquitous in the Internet age.

[Image: Example of Sans-Serif Typeface]

Script Typeface

[Image: Example of Script Typeface]

Blackletter Typeface

Also called Gothic, because of its high blackness, it is also called “broken letter”.

[Image: Example of Blackletter Typeface]

Stem

The main stroke of a letter, usually refers to the straight part of the stroke.

Bowl

Refers to the curved strokes of uppercase letters C or O, or lowercase letters b or o.

Counter

The internal space contained in the letter, whether closed or not, such as the area between the two vertical strokes of H or n.

Hairline

The part of the thin stroke.

[Image: Showing Stem, Bowl, Counter and Hairline]

Serif

The part with a claw-like or straight shape at the end of the stroke.

  1. Bracket Serif
  2. Hairline Serif
  3. Slab Serif

Swash

Refers to the particularly elongated strokes at the beginning and end of letters, with decorative curved parts.

[Image: Showing Swash]

Baseline

Refers to the imaginary line that the bottom of the uppercase letter H or the lowercase letter ∩ touches. The bottom of letters such as O, V, and W deliberately exceeds the baseline slightly, in order to be visually level with the baseline.

Cap Height

Cap refers to the height from the baseline to the top of straight uppercase letters such as H or E. The top line of H or E is called the capline. The top of letters such as O and A will exceed the capline slightly, in order to unify the letter size visually.

[Image: Showing Baseline and Cap Height]

x-height

[Image: Showing x-height]

Compared with the cap height of uppercase letters, in order to refer to the height of lowercase letters, x without upper and lower extensions is used as the representative of lowercase letters, and its height is named x-height.

Kerning

Designers will adjust the width of each character. In Western font design, the end of letter shape design does not mean the completion of the work, but rather that the work is only half done, because there are still hidden and important projects such as letter spacing and kerning settings.

In this UCan conference, Akira Kobayashi compared font design to the propagation of sound. For a font, its letter spacing and whitespace represent its breath and rhythm.

Apple made special style adjustments to the word “click” on the OS X El Capitan official website introduction page, making the letter spacing larger so that the letters of the word would not look like “dick” because they are too close together.

[Image: Showing adjustment to “click” on Apple Website]

For large enterprises, fonts are no longer simply “readable”. Even foreign language fonts must be used in conjunction with the brand image. Although the languages are different, from the perspective of font design, it can reduce the gap between users in various countries. Understanding the design and application of Western fonts can improve the designer’s design ability and artistic quality.

entry.title: How Game Camera Angle Affects User Experience
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

The camera angle is the perspective from which we observe the game. Different games will set different camera angle types for players to choose from. Convenient operation, not getting lost easily, and a strong sense of immersion are the basis for players to choose a camera angle type. So, what are the common camera angle types in games, and what do these types mean? If a player reports that the camera rotation is uncomfortable, how does a user researcher view and analyze this problem? Today, we will introduce two parts – the game’s operating modes (i.e., different camera angle types) and related camera parameters.

I. Diverse Game Camera Angle Classifications

1. 2D Camera Angle

 

Figure 1: Contra

 

Figure 2: Ninja Must Die 3

2D camera angle means that the game only has two dimensions of perspective – up and down, left and right. This camera angle appeared in the earliest arcade games, such as Contra, Super Mario Bros., MapleStory, etc., and also in some current parkour games, such as the Ninja Must Die series.

2. Fixed Camera Angle (2.5D Camera Angle)

 

Figure 3: New Chinese Ghost Story Mobile Game PC Version

In this camera angle type, the player’s camera angle is still fixed, similar to a god’s-eye view. At this time, clicking the left mouse button can reach the designated position, and the right mouse button has no function. WASD controls the character’s forward, backward, left, and right movement. Compared to the 2D camera angle, this fixed camera angle provides forward and backward movement of the character, but the player’s camera angle does not change with the character’s perspective. The game still looks like a plane and does not have a three-dimensional feeling, so this camera angle is between 2D and 3D, which is a 2.5D camera angle.

Currently, some PC games still retain this camera mode, such as JX3 and New Chinese Ghost Story, etc. The advantage is that it is easy to operate, and you can move by clicking the mouse. The left hand only needs to press the skill keys on the keyboard. The disadvantage is that the sense of immersion is not as strong as 3D.

3. Traditional 3D Mode

Press and hold the left mouse button to rotate the camera, and press and hold the right mouse button to rotate the camera and character orientation. WASD controls the character’s forward, left/right strafing, and backward movement. Examples include World of Warcraft.

4. Free Camera Angle

Compared to 2.5D, the traditional 3D mode provides the function of rotating the camera angle, that is, pressing and holding the right mouse button can rotate the camera and character orientation, and clicking the left mouse button can reach the designated position. At the same time, WASD controls the character’s forward, backward, left, and right movement. For example, in the New Chinese Ghost Story mobile game PC version, right-click and hold can rotate the camera and character orientation.

 

 

Figure 4: New Chinese Ghost Story Mobile Game PC Version

5. Action 3D Mode

Commonly found in current MMO and FPS games, such as Blade & Soul mode, Moonlight Blade action mode. Moving the mouse can rotate the camera and character orientation. The left and right mouse buttons can be set for skills. WASD controls the character’s forward, left/right strafing, and backward movement. In this camera angle mode, the left and right mouse buttons are freed from being used for camera angle conversion and movement, and usually have other functions that can be assigned to the left and right mouse buttons, such as some basic skills, shooting, and aiming in FPS games.

II. Some Commonly Used Camera Settings

The camera mode is a relatively general category of viewing angles. Usually, a game will set a variety of game camera parameters for players to adjust by themselves. This part will popularize and introduce these parameters.

1. Camera Rotation Sensitivity

Camera rotation sensitivity is the most commonly used camera parameter. The principle is that when the perceived amplitude or frequency of movement exceeds a certain appropriate value, the nerve center will cause discomfort, such as dizziness and nausea, to objectively achieve the purpose of preventing the current movement from continuing. This is actually a self-protection mechanism, because large-amplitude and high-frequency movements may cause damage to the human body.

When playing games, especially in action 3D mode, the camera rotation is convenient and only relies on mouse movement, which can easily lead to the camera rotation speed being too fast, causing players to experience 3D motion sickness, get lost, etc. However, if the camera rotation speed is too slow, in more intense fighting operations, the camera rotation will not be able to keep up with the enemy’s movement. For example, some players have reported: “The camera rotation after locking is really slow. If someone flashes behind you, you still have to manually turn around?”

Therefore, providing adjustable camera rotation sensitivity in the game is beneficial to improve the user experience, such as in Meteor Butterfly Sword Mobile.

 

Figure 5: Meteor Butterfly Sword Mobile

2. Perspective Angle

If the FOV (field of view) value is too large, the screen will display more scenes, but the scenes at the edges will be severely stretched. This will produce a continuous stretching effect when turning around, which is very different from the effect seen when the human eye rotates. Some FOVs are too small, like running with a telephoto lens. The characters on the screen are very large, but the image changes quickly during the movement, and the human eye will also not adapt.

3. Viewing Angle

The distance and size of the picture. The closer the distance or the larger the picture, the stronger the sense of presence, which will make the player more immersed, and thus be disturbed by the actions in the game, resulting in dizziness.

4. Frames Per Second

The FPS (frames per second) value should be stable. For example, for a head-turning action, you originally wanted to turn 90 degrees in 1 second, but the FPS is unstable and half a beat slower, causing the brain to think it is in place, but the result returned by the eyes is that it is not in place, which will cause the player to experience dizziness.

5. Depth of Field

Too much depth of field will make it difficult for the human eye to focus, and multiple focusing difficulties can easily lead to dizziness. Too little will cause image accumulation and the picture will lack a sense of layering, resulting in dizziness.

And some games use “dynamic blur” in the picture to restore the scene seen by the human eye as much as possible, that is, objects moving in the relative direction of the line of sight will appear blurred or shaken, so reduce the “dynamic blur” in the game scene (but reducing it too much will cause the picture to appear intermittent).

Therefore, if a player says that the camera angle conversion is uncomfortable and the camera rotation is a bit dizzy, as a user researcher, you need to think from multiple game aspects and find targeted points for improvement in the game, such as:

 

Figure 6: Possible problems with the camera angle

Camera angle and target locking are two inseparable game problems. Locking, that is, the selection of the attack target and the locking mechanism, includes free unlocked mechanisms, priority locking mechanisms under various conditions (such as closest distance, lowest health, most recently attacked), intelligent locking mechanisms, and various unlocking mechanisms, etc. Locking is closely related to the camera angle. For example, if a player wants to adjust the follow rate of the attack camera angle, they must first confirm that the game locking state is in unlocked attack mode, such as in Meteor Butterfly Sword Mobile.

 

Figure 7: Meteor Butterfly Sword Mobile

We will continue to introduce related locking mechanisms in the future.

entry.title: How Interaction Designers Can Quickly Get Started with New Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

As an interaction designer in a middle platform, we often need to quickly take on new games, connect with upstream and downstream as soon as possible, improve processes, and ensure the implementation of requirements. So, how can we quickly get started with this kind of new game? Based on my recent work experience, I think we should start from the following steps:

Clarify the Type

Nowadays, game types are often hybrid. What we need to do is to break it down and see what types it is composed of, so as to find competing products, and then look at the expectations of new games from the player base of competing products. For example, Apex Legends is a professional competitive + battle royale type of game. We see that before its release, there were many competing products in the market for professional competitive and battle royale types, but the combination area was still a blue ocean.

As an interaction designer, when getting started with a new game, you also need to start by clarifying the product type and familiarizing yourself with these competing games, understanding the feelings of existing players, and then bringing in this identity to experience the game feelings of the new project you joined, and conduct an initial user experience run-through.

Clarify the Progress

Games have many systems. When taking on a new project, we also need to clarify the current system completion status of the game, because the construction and optimization costs of different systems are different, and the design purposes are also different. For example, interfaces such as settlement emphasize expressiveness, while systems such as mail, chat, and settings pay more attention to unity. The picture shows a system classification form that I often refer to.

Clarify the Risks

After understanding the project type and development progress, the next step is to know what you are going to do. Clarify the risks involved.

When I first joined the project, I felt that the biggest risk was time, which included three aspects:

  1. Just arrived at the project, need time to get familiar with the team and process.
  2. Just arrived at the project, need time to learn the UGUI of the Unity engine.
  3. Testing will be conducted within a month, but many interfaces of the game have not yet been designed.

These are indeed very tricky problems, and I was once at a loss. So I still sorted out the problems and solved them one by one.

1. Determine Responsibilities and Processes

In the traditional design process, it is more like a linear process. The requirements are given to interaction, the interaction is designed and then given to visual, and then developed and implemented. But in my current project, the connections between these processes are more.

In the face of this situation, there is only one suggestion:

Take the initiative to communicate, and run more to talk face to face!

2. Learn to Use Tools

At NetEase, in order to ensure the final restoration of the system, the interface splicing is done by the interaction designer. In the process of making games with the Unity engine, I think the main points to pay attention to are the following 4 points:

Interface splicing, animation production, experience testing, resource management

  • Interface splicing: In the process of interface splicing, it is mainly necessary to pay attention to restoring the effect diagram as much as possible, ensuring that the positions of corresponding elements are accurate, the font size and color number are consistent, and there are no missing states; pay attention to the adaptation of different screens, the following of elements and the hierarchical relationship.
  • Animation production: Simple animations can help players clarify state changes. Pay attention to the corresponding relationship, position, and hierarchical relationship when making.
  • Experience testing: The engine is often the place where new game mechanics first appear. The interaction designer should experience new maps, actions, and scenes in time; then after each splicing, it must be tested! Be sure to ensure that there are no errors before handing it over to others to upload to the public storage.
  • Resource management: The UI resources and atlas packaging of the game are also maintained by the interaction designer. Remember to clean up useless resources in time; check existing resources more, find optimization points in time, and optimize.

Summary

Looking back, getting started with a new project is a process that requires rapid adaptation and integration, and requires strong communication skills with people and things. The above introduction is all my personal experience, from understanding the game to understanding people to understanding tools, and gradually getting started with the project. I hope it can serve as a starting point and bring some inspiration to everyone.

entry.title: A Quick Guide to Steam Sentiment Analysis
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

Why do we analyze Steam sentiment? Of course, it’s because we have a game recently launched on Steam, which is—Conqueror’s Blade! Interested friends can download and experience it, and show your support!

Conqueror’s Blade is a large-scale tactical action online game set in the Ming Dynasty. You will command your troops while fighting on the front lines, launching 15v15 siege battles; and in the vast Eurasian world, conquer cities and create an epic!

Now, let’s get to the point. Regarding the Steam sentiment part, how can we find the reviews we need? What indicators and content should we pay attention to? How reliable are these indicators? And how to read and use the main reviews?

First of all, how do we find the reviews we need? Currently, the reviews are located at the bottom of our product store page. There is a filter box here, sorted by result, by language, by purchase method, and by display score. Filter out the required reviews according to your own needs, and then analyze and summarize them, so that the effect is good.

Then there is the overall rating of the game by players on Steam. The current rating has some text descriptions and also the favorable rating. As shown in the figure below, the current positive rating accounts for 97%, and the text description is “Overwhelmingly Positive.”

Let me ask a small question. Are the ratings in Steam real ratings? Not necessarily. This is the same as buying things on Taobao and rating apps in the Apple Store. Everyone should have heard of the five-star praise梗 (gěng - a Chinese internet slang, referring to something funny or a meme, in this context refers to a sarcastic phrase or inside joke). (Could you provide an image of a “five-star negative review”?) Below is an example of a review from one of our players. He recommends it to other users, but in fact, the descriptions of the shortcomings are all problems of our game, and the emotion tends to be negative, so it means not recommended. So, according to this situation, we can infer the actual positive rating based on the player’s actual expression to make an overall assessment.

Next, I will give you a brief introduction to the main part of our Steam sentiment.

  1. This contains the player’s personal information, how many games he has, and what games they are. This information can be used to effectively assess the player’s type and game experience.
  2. Whether the player is a player who is keen to write reviews, and his historical reviews, you can see the points that players pay more attention to.
  3. This is the length of time the player has experienced. You can combine the length of experience with the focus of the comment content to get the short-term and long-term pain points and cool points of the game.
  4. This is the main content. The analysis points are different, but you should be familiar with the game before analyzing.
  5. Likes of user comments to discover excellent reviews.

Every day, our game will have new players joining, and new reviews will be generated, so we also need to follow up in time and iterate our views and opinions on a certain time cycle.

The above is a brief introduction to our Steam sentiment analysis. I hope everyone can apply it flexibly.

entry.title: Design Considerations for Landscape and Portrait Mobile Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Electronic games have developed for more than half a century, from arcades, consoles, handhelds, PCs to mobile games. Electronic games have gone through five generations with the update and iteration of technology.

As software running on mobile phones, mobile games have simple application scenarios and low operation thresholds, thus greatly promoting the expansion and popularization of the game market, making more and more people become mobile game players. Mobile games are divided into portrait and landscape modes, which mainly depend on usage habits and gameplay.

In Japan, players are more accepting of the portrait display of games. According to survey reports and the top-selling mobile games in Japan, a large proportion of the top 100 games are portrait games.

Image

As we all know, the pace of life and work of Japanese people is quite fast. Excluding this time, there is very little time for daily entertainment, and the fragmented time that can be controlled by themselves is concentrated when taking transportation.

Japan’s transportation system is very developed, and the subway and Shinkansen networks are all over the country, which has also become the main mode of travel for Japanese people. During the rush hour of commuting, it is not easy to hold the railing with one hand and the briefcase with the other, and to free up one hand to operate the mobile phone. The two-handed holding requirement of landscape games is obviously inappropriate.

Image

In contrast, the portrait operation that can be controlled with one hand solves this problem well. Game manufacturers will be precise to the distribution of keys, the position of option arrangement and other details on the basis of portrait display.

Considering all these limitations and opportunities, mobile game developers use the power of the mobile platform to optimize the experience brought by portrait and one-handed control methods as much as possible.

In the area map showing the comfort of the thumb, we can experience the comfort of clicking and sliding the thumb on the mobile phone screen. Here we analyze the right-handed users, and left-handed users can flip over and understand in reverse.

Due to the length limitation of the thumb, the lower right corner area is relatively easy to click, while the top and lower left corner are the most difficult areas to click. Due to the relatively weak operability in portrait mode, game manufacturers mainly focus on casual games in the game category, but of course it is not limited to this.

Image

From our existing experience, landscape games have always accounted for the majority in the domestic market, because the left and right expansion of the landscape can present a broader picture scene, and naturally contain richer elements.

Moreover, the arrangement of domestic books and printed matter is from left to right, which conforms to the reading habits of Chinese people. In landscape games, it is easy to accept the information replacement in the left and right directions due to reading habits. For example, in horizontal platformer games that constantly move to the right, the newly emerging scene elements can be noticed and information can be received at the first time.

In addition, some games also use the gravity sensor for rotation operations. Although portrait mode sometimes only requires one-handed operation, in order to maintain balance, the other hand is also needed for assistance, holding with both hands.

When holding with both hands in portrait mode, the center of gravity is not in the middle of the two hands. It takes more effort to reach a stable state than when the center of gravity is in the middle of the two hands in landscape mode. Therefore, the way of holding the mobile phone with both hands in landscape mode is more suitable for this type of game.

With the rapid development of smartphones, the size of mobile phone screens is gradually increasing, and one-handed operation has begun to become difficult, making mobile games gradually develop in the direction of landscape mode.

Image

There is no end to the pursuit of humanization and ease of use in experience design, and the same is true for game products. There is room for thinking behind every familiar operation, and every improvement in user experience is accumulated by seemingly insignificant detail changes. In the field of “games”, which inherently represents “interaction”, this should be even more so.

entry.title: [UE Sharing] Play Games with Thoughts - Let's Talk About Game Inspections
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

As a User Experience Researcher (UE), one of the enviable parts of the job is being able to legitimately play games during work hours. This is not slacking off, but an important part of UE’s work - game inspection.

What is Game Inspection?

Game inspection is actually playing games with a clear purpose, and ultimately producing a game inspection checklist. The purpose of the inspection may be to find problems in the game, or to study the characteristics of competing products.

Compared with QA testing games, UE’s game inspection not only focuses on game bugs, but also pays more attention to problems in the game experience. Novice experience, operation fluency, UI interaction, and various contents that will affect the game experience are all within the scope of the inspection, but there will be different focuses according to the purpose of the inspection.

 

What Can Game Inspection Be Used For?

Game inspection can be applied to all stages of the game:

  • Alpha Development: UX regularly inspects the version, finds and fixes problems during development; some controversial issues can also be the focus of subsequent player testing.
  • During laboratory testing: As a summary of player feedback problems in the test, it usually comes with a list of problems
  • After launch: It can be used to test new version content, and may also inspect competing games.

Among them, the focus of competing product inspection is not to find problems, but to study the design ideas of competing products and discover the highlights/features of the game

What Does the Inspection Checklist Look Like?

There is no fixed format for the inspection checklist, but it needs to clearly explain the ins and outs of the problem. Generally speaking, it should include the following elements:

 

  • Problem point: What is the problem, which system is it located in, what is the manifestation of the problem or its impact on the player

  • Problem scenario: The problem that occurs under what model and what situation can be accompanied by related pictures and texts. The problem scene can effectively help the product reproduce and locate the problem

  • Problem level: A level of the severity of the problem is determined according to the degree of obstruction of the problem, the frequency of the problem, and the scope of the problem. Conventional problem levels are divided into four levels:

    • Level 1 problems represent very serious problems, located in important modules and causing obstacles that a large number of players cannot solve by themselves.
    • Level 2 problems represent serious problems, located in relatively important modules and directly hindering many players.
    • Level 3 problems represent relatively serious problems, which hinder or cause poor experience for some players, and have a greater impact on the game progress or overall quality experience.
    • Level 4 problems represent general problems, which have hindered or caused poor experience for a small number of players, but have little overall impact on the game progress and quality.

What Else Can We Do with Game Inspection?

Game inspection does not have a narrow, rigid process requirement, and has considerable flexibility, as long as it can have a logical idea to set the inspection content and clearly present it. We can even inspect the video of the anchor playing the game, such as the strategy used by the anchor, operating habits, emotional changes, etc., which can become useful information. Play your creativity.

entry.title: Common Commands for Data Analysis
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

In data analysis work, it is often necessary to pre-process data, such as viewing data, data deduplication, and some statistics. Of course, you can choose to use Python, Java, etc. for processing, but if the same thing is handed over to instructions, it may be much more efficient. Below I will introduce some common and effective commands for work.

head

The first thing to do when processing data is to see what the data we are facing is. At this time, the head command can be used. For example, head a.txt can output the first 10 lines of the file. Of course, you can modify the number of output lines by using head -n a.txt, and adjust the value of n. At the same time, head can be used in conjunction with other commands through pipes to complete processing needs.

Commonly used methods are:

  • head -n file: Display the first n lines of the file.
  • head -c file: Display the first n bytes of the file.

wc

The wc command is used to count words. The wc command can be used to calculate the number of bytes and words in a file. If no parameters are used, the number of lines, words, and bytes of the specified file will be calculated.

Command Output
wc a.txt lines words bytes filename (The specific numbers will depend on the content of a.txt.)

The wc command can also be used on multiple files, and the information of all files will be汇总 (summarized) in the end.

For example, using wc a.txt b.txt could produce output like:

Command Output
wc a.txt b.txt lines_a words_a bytes_a a.txt
lines_b words_b bytes_b b.txt
total_lines total_words total_bytes total

Commonly used methods are:

  • wc -c: Print the number of bytes.
  • wc -l: Print the number of lines.
  • wc -w: Display the number of words.
  • wc -m: Print the number of characters.

sort & uniq

Obviously, these two commands are used for sorting and handling duplicates. Since uniq only handles duplicate adjacent lines, we often see the usage of sort a.txt | uniq. First sort the data, so that we can remove duplicate values. Of course, sort -u can achieve the same effect. Note the difference between the two when using the -k option. Regular uses can be substituted.

Regarding sort, sort treats each line of the file as a unit, compares them with each other, and the comparison principle is to compare the ASCII values from the first character backwards, and finally output them in ascending order. There are many details that can be discussed, here is a brief introduction to several usages:

First is the -t option, which can specify what symbol is used as a separator, such as sort -t "," a.txt which uses a comma as a separator;

Then there is the -k option, which can be used to specify keys, such as sort -t "," -k2 a.txt, which means to sort by the second field after comma separation.

A complex example is: sort -t "," -k1.2,1.2 -k3,3nr which means to sort by the second character of the first column, and if they are the same, sort the third column in descending order according to numerical standards.

Example Input (a.txt):

apple,banana,10
grape,orange,5
apple,cherry,20

Running sort -t "," -k1.2,1.2 -k3,3nr a.txt would produce:

grape,orange,5
apple,banana,10
apple,cherry,20

Commonly used options for sort are:

  • -c: Check if the file is already sorted. If not, it will prompt from which line the disorder starts.
  • -t: Specify the separator.
  • -n: Sort according to numerical value.
  • -r: Descending order.
  • -u: Ignore identical lines.
  • -k: Sort by which interval.

grep

The next thing to introduce is the three musketeers of Linux, grep, sed and awk. Each item can be described in a very long space. Here are some commonly used methods in work, which can help us better understand in the future.

grep is the global search for regular expressions and print, which is relatively straightforward to translate into Chinese. As the name suggests, it can search, print, and importantly, it can use regular expressions to assist in completion.

Suppose we have a file a.txt:

hello world
welcome
hello again

The simplest way to use grep is to directly search the file for the string you want to match, such as:

grep 'hello' a.txt

As you can see, it prints all lines in the file that contain hello.

hello world
hello again

When using grep, we have many parameters to choose from to assist in completing the requirements, such as:

  • grep -i: Case-insensitive.
  • grep -v: Match lines not containing a pattern. grep -v 'hello' a.txt would match the welcome line.
  • grep -n: Display the line number of matching lines.
  • grep -E: Allows the use of extended regular expressions (equivalent to using egrep).
  • grep -c: Print the number of matching lines.
  • grep -l: Can search in multiple files and print the file where it is located. grep -L indicates files not containing the pattern.
  • grep -A n, grep -B n, grep -C n: These three options display n lines after, before, or around (context) each matching line, respectively.

The above are some options that are often used in work. Of course, there are also some very useful ones such as -r, etc. A very important condition is that you need to have more knowledge of regular expressions to maximize the power of grep. Regular expressions are not described in detail here.

sed

sed is a stream editor, a very important text processing tool, mainly used in conjunction with regular expressions, and is good at replacing. During processing, the currently processed line is stored in a temporary buffer, and then the content in the buffer is processed with sed. After completion, the content of the buffer is printed to the screen, and then the processing of the next line continues until the end of the file.

The most basic command is in the form of s/old/new/g, that is, search for old and replace new globally. Without g, it will terminate when old first appears. Similarly, when we replace content in vim, we also use a similar form.

Here’s an example to introduce some commonly used methods, mainly involving regular expressions. Let’s say we have a file with the following content:

1,234,567 JJ
9,876,543 KK

First, we need to remove the commas from the numbers. Use the following command. As you can see, for the matched content, we can use \1 and \2 to represent the matched content. Pay attention to the content in the parentheses in the regular expression, which is what we often call grouping, that is, the matching item:
bash
cat a.txt | sed -r ‘s/([0-9]),([0-9])/\1\2/g’

This will result in:

1234567 JJ
9876543 KK

Using the -r option with sed allows us to use extended regular expressions; otherwise, we need to pay attention to many details, such as escaping parentheses.

At the same time, we can use & to replace the matched string, such as using cat a.txt | sed 's/\w\+/[&]/g'. (Assuming the output of the previous command has been redirected to a.txt).

This would result in (note, without -r you might need sed 's/\w\+/\[&\]/g'):

[1234567] [JJ]
[9876543] [KK]
Similarly, you can use sed for filtering, or you can call it deletion. We can also do this using grep -v mentioned earlier. Using cat a.txt | sed '/JJ/d', we can successfully remove the line containing JJ.

In addition, sed has many more interesting functions. There are special books on sed and awk, and you can also see that the knowledge in them is very deep. This is just a brief introduction that can make daily work convenient.

Other commonly used options are:

  • sed -i: Edit the file content directly, which means that using replace will change the file content.
  • sed -e: Implement multi-point editing. sed -e ... -e ... The result of the previous one will affect the following ones.

awk

This command is really hardcore, and it can actually be regarded as a programming language.

awk is a programming language tool for processing text. It reads input files, sorts data, processes data, performs calculations on input, and generates reports, and there are countless other functions.

The main idea is to scan the data in the text file or text stream line by line, perform pattern matching on the current line of text, and if the match is successful, continue to execute the content of the data processing module, otherwise continue to process the next line of data.

Let’s take an example. When processing logs, a simple scenario of using awk. The following is a simulated login log, and the data are all simulated. Only two of them are put here, and there are multiple items in the file. We need to count the types of app_channel after deduplication.

2019-07-24 10:00:00,user1,login,app_channel=”channel_a”,other_data
2019-07-24 10:01:00,user2,login,app_channel=”channel_b”,other_data

First of all, we need to get the corresponding content of app_channel, and we need to extract it. Of course, we can also use regular expressions here, but I want to introduce the awk -F command, which can specify the input separator. The separator can be a string or a regular expression. We can use this command repeatedly here to finally get the corresponding content.

First, we separate according to "app_channel":
bash
cat log.txt | awk -F ‘app_channel=”‘

{print $2} after that means that we want to print the second part after separation. The result is as follows:

channel_a”,other_data
channel_b”,other_data
We can see we need another separation. We can clearly use the quotation mark as a delimiter to get the channels:
bash
cat log.txt | awk -F ‘app_channel=”‘ ‘{print $2}’ | awk -F ‘“‘ ‘{print $1}’

This gives us the channel names. The next steps involve sort and uniq, as shown above.

To count each channel, you can use awk’s associative arrays (similar to Python dictionaries):
bash
cat log.txt | awk -F ‘app_channel=”‘ ‘{print $2}’ | awk -F ‘“‘ ‘{print $1}’ | awk ‘{channels[$1]++} END {for (channel in channels) print channel, channels[channel]}’
This takes the extracted channel name ($1) and increments a count in the channels array. The END block prints out the counts for each channel after processing all lines.

You can see that if we put the data into the database and use SQL to complete the requirements every time we encounter such a situation, it is certainly possible, but as I mentioned at the beginning of this article, instructions often bring efficiency. If it involves the association with other data to complete the requirements, then it still needs to be processed in the database with SQL.

Of course, the function of awk is far more powerful than this small requirement. It is really unrealistic to expand on it. You can add a little difficulty to think about it. For example, to count each channel, you can use the array usage of awk. The array of awk can be characters or strings, similar to the assignment and value retrieval methods of dictionaries in Python. Then here we can use the data of the previously extracted channels for further processing.

Here is the basic structure of awk:

awk ‘BEGIN{ commands } pattern{ commands } END{ commands }’

  • The first step is to execute the statements in BEGIN{ commands }.
  • The second step is to read a line from the file or standard input, and then execute the pattern{ commands } statement block. It scans the file line by line and repeats this process from the first line to the last line until the file is completely read.
  • The third step is to execute the content of END{ commands } when the end is reached.

You can compare it with the command we processed channel counts above, and the basic structure is consistent.

So far, I have briefly introduced six commonly used commands for data analysis. These are all good helpers for data analysis work, because analysis is inseparable from the support of data. How to process it efficiently will also help us complete the analysis tasks more reasonably and accurately. Of course, there are many other useful commands, such as cut, tr, join, etc., all of which can well assist us in completing the requirements. Each command also has many functions worth our in-depth understanding. When they are used in combination, they are even more powerful. And my introduction above is just very basic and daily functions. You can do more discussions and explorations.

entry.title: UI Sharing: Situational Design in Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

July, the scorching airflow roasts the road surface, and the young people on the street seem to be sizzling squids, constantly sweating. The sun seems to have no intention of “stopping for today” and continues to thrust its passion into this somewhat weary world. I lie on an IKEA beach chair that cost 100 yuan, gulping down ice-cold fresh watermelon juice while fantasizing about the sunset beach of Swansea.

Situationalization

Situational design is about letting you feel the temperature of the sun through the screen. The design itself does not emphasize allowing players to achieve their goals as quickly as possible, but rather allowing players to incorporate emotional changes during the operation process, ultimately leaving a deep impression.

Successful emotional design can help games stand out in homogeneous competition, improve user loyalty and recognition, and allow users to spontaneously participate in the dissemination of the game.

Situationalization can be said to be an add-on to interaction design. On the basis of interactive usability and ease of use, it allows players to obtain a richer and higher-quality process experience. The so-called flow state is that wonderful moment!

Situationalization is More Than Just Games

The concept of situationalization does not only exist in games, but often appears in life. As mentioned in “Designers Need to Understand Psychology,” people are more willing to listen to stories than to resumes. The description of story scenarios can better help people understand the content you want to express, and it is also more immersive, containing more emotional expression.

In fact, we have all been exposed to situationalization since we were very young. If you still remember the inspirational stories you wrote in the examination room, and the dark clouds and heavy rain in the stories. In fact, this is the most natural situational design. Through various strange weather environments, it expresses and renders the tragic experience and mood of the protagonist, guides the reader to resonate, and promotes the plot. In games, it’s like this.

Players will not improve their clearance rate or experience better operation because of this design, but the immersion of the environment will enhance their emotional experience during the game, and even push it to a climax in the game!

Situationalization and Interactive Experience in Games

Here I recommend two situational design games that are worth playing. If you are interested, you can download and experience them.

Return of the Obra Dinn

Players will explore the East India Company merchant ship “Obra Dinn,” which was missing and drifting outside in 1808 and was finally discovered, from a first-person perspective.

In 1802, the merchant ship “Obra Dinn” left the port in London, fully loaded with more than 200 tons of trade goods and headed for the Far East. But six months later, it did not appear at the loading and unloading stop in the Cape of Good Hope, Africa, and was declared missing at sea.

Until the early morning of October 14, 1808, the merchant ship “Obra Dinn” slowly drifted into the port, with the sails severely damaged and no crew members visible. As an insurance estimator from the London office of the East India Company, the protagonist boarded the ship to assess the insurance, find a way to restore the crew roster, and further discover what happened on the ship.

When the player first boards the ship, the boatman cannot carry the box and needs the player to take out the things in the box. You will find that in addition to the magical pocket watch, there is also a booklet. This booklet has hundreds of pages and contains not only the previous roster, but also all the important content needed to play this game. As the game progresses and the player explores, this content will gradually become richer.

There are many interactions with the scene in the game, as well as many wonderful props; and they are handed over to the player to discover through some inadvertent moments.

Donut County

With “a (growing) hole that devours everything” as the core gameplay, coupled with a fresh and lovely art style, even without the background bonus of publisher Annapurna and developer Ben Esposito, Donut County is enough to whet players’ appetites. The six-year development process and the plagiarism storm that occurred near the release are certainly regrettable, but the final Donut County that appears in front of us has too much irreplaceability beyond the gameplay.

Around the design of the hole, Donut County tells an allegorical adult fairy tale in a form similar to a fireside chat. Every line of dialogue seems to be carefully written, and in this process, the shaping of the group portrait is extremely successful. Of course, the most popular character is the philosophical raccoon. The game’s bestiary is like his poetry collection.

There are almost no fixed UI elements in the game screen, and all interactions are guided by the player during the game. This makes the game experience itself smooth and unstoppable.

In my opinion, the purpose of situationalization itself can be divided into two types. One is to create an atmosphere to make the player’s emotional experience richer; the other is to integrate the functional interaction itself into the game’s plot. At this time, the player will probably think, “Oh, can I click this?” or “Ah, it seems that I need to open this door?”; when the player really triggers the interaction, they will exclaim WOW, Awesome.

So on such a hot day, when you see a glass of iced watermelon juice, you will definitely want to pick it up and imagine your sunset beach.

entry.title: How to Become an Interview Master (Part Two)
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Last time we talked about the first level of becoming an interview master:

Being a Good Voice for the Players

Let’s review some key points of the first level of being an interview master.

The keyword for being a good voice for the players in the first level of interviewing is “deconstruction”.

How to deconstruct? Because players don’t have the professional ability to break down problems, we need to guide them step by step within a framework to discover the root of the issues, gradually mapping the players’ feedback to the game design.

Accumulating these frameworks requires playing games regularly and doing more game deconstruction thinking when problems are discovered.

Besides understanding basic interview question deconstruction, what other abilities are needed to conduct a good interview? Today, let’s talk about the second level of interviewing:

Understanding Your Players

First, let’s look at an example. In a test, two players had completely different feedback on the same content of the same game:

Player 1 Player 2
“This game is way too easy!” “This game is way too hard!”

So, with this kind of test result, should we suggest the developers make it easier or harder?

Don’t rush to a conclusion. Let’s first find out who these two players are.

It turns out that the player who said the game was easy is a veteran player with T2 level game operation ability, while the player who said the game was too difficult is a casual player.

It can be seen that players with different backgrounds will bring completely different feedback.

In our interviews, to understand why someone gives specific feedback, we need to further understand what kind of player they are, including their gaming background, educational background, and even their lifestyle.

A person’s past cognition, experience, needs, and attitudes often determine some of their present and future behaviors. The behavior shown by the player and the feedback expressed are just the tip of the iceberg. We need to dig out the underlying needs and motivations under the iceberg.

So, when understanding a player, what information do we usually collect?

This can be divided into two categories: one is demographic characteristics, and the other is game characteristics.

(1) Demographic Characteristics: Demographic information, income level, time characteristics, gaming environment, cultural environment, etc.

(2) Game Characteristics: Previous game experience, game interests, social habits, operational ability, etc.

Here are some common player characteristics:

a. Time Characteristics:

This mainly refers to the player’s occupation. Generally, we will divide players into working professionals, students, and freelancers. The free time characteristics of these three types of players are very obvious. Office workers generally work during the day and play games at night, while students are more active on weekends and holidays, and freelancers are often the “time warriors” in the game. When players report that there are too many or too few activities, it’s helpful to understand their occupation.

b. Income Level:

Generally speaking, high-spending players don’t care about how much money they spend. They are more concerned about how long it will take to fill the “pit”. Many high-spending players are impatient and want to max out their gems and pets in one day. Casual players and low- to mid-spending players are more sensitive to prices, especially for newly opened numerical sinks, and price increases of some items can be expected to receive a large amount of complaints the next day. Therefore, what needs to be noted here is that it is necessary to understand which player segment an activity or some cultivation content is targeting.

c. Game Interests:

In the same game, different players have very different interests. Some players like to find people to PK and fight everywhere in the game, while others like to roam the map and enjoy the scenery in a more relaxed way. Different gameplay activities also have their own labels. If the label of a gameplay does not match the label of a certain player, then this gameplay may not be well received by the player even if there is no problem in design. Therefore, research on a certain gameplay also needs to find the core players of this gameplay to do some interviews. For example, for a PK-type gameplay, more feedback on combat experience can be obtained from PK-type players, and they can even help you analyze the balance of professions. But if you encounter a casual player, you may get feedback that this gameplay is not interesting and the rewards are not rich enough.

d. Different Operational Abilities:

This should have been deeply understood in the example at the beginning. Before the game test, we generally use questionnaires to measure the player’s operational ability, and then look at their feedback in combination with their operational ability. So if you encounter the two opposite types of feedback mentioned above, whether the game should be made more difficult or easier depends on what kind of players the core target audience of this game is. If you want to cover those ordinary players with not very high operational ability, then the game will inevitably need to reduce the difficulty; if the game itself has a difficulty threshold and is known for its difficulty, then it needs to stick to itself. After all, a game does not have to meet the needs of everyone. Just strive to give players who like this type of game the best gaming experience.

The above is the content of the second level of being an interview master.

To review, the second level of becoming an interview master is:

Understanding Your Players

Why do you need to understand your players? Because every game, every game content has its preset core target group, and collecting feedback from the corresponding core players can better help improve the game or the game content.

When understanding a player, we generally start with their demographic characteristics and game characteristics. In detail, it will also include demographic information, income level, time characteristics, game environment, cultural environment, previous game experience, game interests, social habits, operational ability, etc. As for when you need to understand which characteristics of the player, it depends on the characteristics of the core target group mentioned earlier.

So, in summary, we have already finished talking about the two levels of becoming an interview master. Some people may ask, what is the third level? The place to practice the third level is here:

entry.title: Introduction to Feature Engineering Methods Using TensorFlow API
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

This US (User Study) sharing introduces a practical feature construction tool for feature engineering in data mining model building - tensorflow.feature_column, which is the feature column interface of TensorFlow.

The TensorFlow framework is widely used in building deep learning models. Its feature column interface (feature_column) can be used to implement the construction and processing of various features. This interface provides a wealth of feature tools.

In TensorFlow version 1.14, the TensorFlow feature column interface provides the following tools:

  1. bucketized_column: Discretization of continuous features by bucketing.
  2. categorical_column_with_identity: One-hot encoding of categorical ID features.
  3. crossed_column: Feature crossing of categorical features.
  4. embedding_column: Embedding feature compression of sparse categorical feature matrices.
  5. sequence_categorical_column_with_identity: Categorical encoding of sequence features.
    …

The feature column interface tools provided by the official TensorFlow documentation.

 

(1) bucketized_column

This display method more intuitively reflects the bin interval in which each value is located.

(2) categorical_column_with_identity

Three input parameters are required in tf.feature_column.categorical_column_with_identity:

 

The key part inputs the corresponding feature name, and the num_buckets part indicates how many ID categories there are, corresponding to the range [0, num_buckets-1]. If in the actual feature, the ID value is greater than the upper bound of num_buckets, the program will report an error. After determining num_buckets, tf implements one-hot encoding.

In addition, default_value specifies the situation of extra features appearing in the feature column, that is, the ID value is greater than the upper bound of the ID value range. If default_value is set, these extra ID values will be classified as default_value, but note that the value of default_value also needs to fall within the ID value range.

(3) categorical_column_with_hash_bucket

Three input parameters are required in tf.feature_column.categorical_column_with_hash_bucket:

 

It solves the classification problem when there are too many categories in practical problems. If there is no good manual classification index, the hash classification method is used to divide different fine-grained values into a coarse hash bucket. It uses the method of hashing and modulo operation on the same feature with different values to obtain the binning result of different values, so as to realize binning. It can be found that this will classify some irrelevant values into one bucket. Therefore, the number of buckets specified by this bucketing method should be large, as a preliminary bucketing of feature data.

entry.title: Four Principles of Game Interface Design
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Although game interfaces are more free and lively than internet APP product interfaces, the layout design of game interfaces still needs to follow certain principles. This article shares four principles of design: contrast, proximity, unity, and alignment.

To better understand, the following uses the X game interface as a carrier for explanation.

 

Its interface GUI design was not ugly at the time, but the entire interface gave a strong sense of clutter. This is because it did not follow the principles of proximity, contrast, and unity in the four design principles.

Contrast Principle

The principle of contrast means highlighting what should be highlighted and weakening what should be weakened. When designing the interface, the planner will often give a lot of information that needs to be put up, but the designer cannot just pile it up. It is necessary to sort out the information first, place the key information in the visual core position, and emphasize it, such as more refined GUI beautification, larger and more gorgeous fonts, and so on. Other less important information needs to be relatively weaker.

The information content in the screen, each wants to highlight itself, and the content is scattered throughout the interface, making people not know where to look, and it is easy to miss important information.

Proximity Principle

The principle of proximity is to integrate similar information together. For example, the primary buttons on the screen, refining, lineup, learning, illustrations, etc., need to be placed in a connected position. Player information, the name on the screen, intimacy, technical travel and combat power also need to be integrated together.

Unity Principle

The principle of unity, that is, in an interface, its colors and elements need to be repeated to make it a whole. In this interface, the colors have been well unified, mainly yellow and black, so looking at the color distribution alone, without looking at the information, will not give people a too chaotic feeling. But the elements have not been repeated. There are too many elements distributed in the picture, including various sizes of fonts, flat and retro style collisions and overlaps, which increases the chaos of the interface.

Around the problems of the above three principles, the interaction designer iterated the interface. The following figure is the effect after the designer’s iteration. Although the overall is not as cool as before, it achieves the effect of information integration and a clear interface. Each piece of information is organized and presented, important information is placed in the visual center, the buttons are easy to operate, and the elements are also flattened as a whole. After iterating according to the four principles of design, the original chaotic interface layout was optimized into a new interface with clear information at a glance.

 

Alignment Principle

Finally, let’s look at the significance of the alignment principle for game interface design. Alignment is the basis of interface design. The above three points may require a certain amount of accumulation by the designer to achieve, but alignment can be said to be a kind of consciousness without technical content, and it is the minimum requirement that designers need to follow. The design interface in the figure below does not follow the principle of alignment. It gives a very cheap and low-quality visual feeling.

 

The interface in the figure below follows the principle of alignment. It appears very neat and clear in terms of information layout. The comparison between the two is immediately apparent.

 

Of course, following the principle of alignment does not mean that every interface needs to rigidly layout information. In the main interface of the game, some misaligned layout styles do not affect the overall interface, but will add a little agility. The alignment principle is more used in interfaces that aim to present the content of the information itself.

The above four principles are summarized by game designers after years of practice, and do not represent the industry’s standards. As a designer, after a long period of accumulation, more or less, you will summarize some of your own experience and methodology. As a design beginner, learning from the experience left by predecessors can help you avoid many detours, and these four principles are the same.

Learn, apply, expand, but don’t be rigid.

entry.title: Game Interaction Design and Psychology - Interpreting Susan Weinschenk's "100 Things Every Designer Needs to Know About People"
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Susan Weinschenk, from the psychological perspectives of how people observe, read, remember, think, perceive, make decisions, concentrate, and the source of human motivation and sociality, analyzes and summarizes how to apply this psychological knowledge in design. For interaction design that emphasizes user experience, it can be regarded as a must-read book.

The brain receives about 40 million sensory inputs per second and tries to fully parse their meaning. It will guess what we see based on past experience - heuristics.

Reasonable use of shapes and colors can affect what people see.

What others see on your website may not be what you intended. Their personal background, cultural level, familiarity with the things in front of them, and what they expect to see will all affect their observation results.

Peripheral vision is more likely to attract attention

People use peripheral vision when looking at a computer screen, and often judge the content of the entire page by just glancing at the peripheral vision area.

Although the center of the screen is an important central vision area, don’t ignore the peripheral vision area. Be sure to ensure that the peripheral content clearly shows the purpose of the webpage.

If you want users to focus on a certain part of the screen, don’t place animations and flashing elements in the peripheral vision area.

 

In The Last of Us, in order not to interrupt the player’s immersion in the plot, the interface elements are cleverly hidden.

People look for patterns when recognizing objects

Since people will involuntarily look for patterns, use patterns as much as possible, and use grouping and spacing to create patterns.

To make an object (such as an icon) easy to recognize, draw it with simple geometric shapes. This will make the geometric ions that make up the object more obvious, thereby making it faster and easier for people to recognize the object.

Use two-dimensional elements more and three-dimensional elements less. The brain receives the information observed by the human eye in a two-dimensional form, so three-dimensional graphics on the screen may slow down the speed of recognition and understanding.

 

At the beginning of designing a character, the geometric relationship of the character’s silhouette should be considered. In fast-paced competitive games, different characters need to have clear geometric differences, which can prevent players from cognitive difficulties in intense battles.

The brain has a special area for recognizing faces

When people look at a webpage, they first recognize and react to faces (at least people without autism do).

On a web page, a face looking directly at the user is the most contagious, perhaps because the eyes are the most important part of the face.

If the eyes of a person on a webpage are looking at a nearby location or product, people tend to look at the same place, but not necessarily pay attention, just look.

9% of men and 0.5% of women are color blind

When designing pictures and websites, use www.vischeck.com or colorfilter.wickline.org to check and see the effect of color blindness.

If you use color to represent a specific meaning (such as green for things that need urgent processing), you should also use another distinguishing scheme (things that need urgent processing should not only be set to green, but also have a box around them).

When designing a color scheme, consider using colors that everyone can recognize normally, such as different shades of brown and yellow. Avoid using red, blue, and green.

The mystery of the difficulty of reading uppercase words (a point of view based on English design)

People think that all caps are a loud and emphatic tone, and they are not used to reading them, so use them as little as possible.

Use all caps only when writing headlines or when you need to get the user’s attention, such as a prompt to the user before they delete an important file.

Reading on a screen is harder than reading on paper

Use larger fonts on the screen to reduce eye fatigue.

You should divide the text into several blocks and use bullet points, short paragraphs, and pictures.

Increase the contrast between the text and the background. Black text on a white background is the easiest to read.

Make sure the content is worth reading. The reading problem ultimately depends on whether the article itself interests the reader.

Short-term memory is limited (Example: Remember a phone number without pen and paper)

Don’t let people’s memory be in different places, such as reading text or numbers on one page and then entering them on another page. If you do this, they are likely to forget the information and their confidence will suffer.

If you want people to use working memory to remember things, don’t let them do other things before completing the task. Working memory is easily disturbed, and too much sensory input will prevent them from concentrating.

Psychologist Alan Baddeley questioned the 7 plus or minus 2 rule. Baddeley (1986) conducted a lot of research on human memory and information processing. In addition, researchers such as Nelson Cowan (2001) have followed in his footsteps. Research now shows that the “magic number” is actually 4.

 

It is good to limit the information presented to users to 4 items, but it is not necessary. You can use classification or grouping to display more information.

Display no more than 4 pieces of information per group.

Note that users like to use auxiliary memory aids, such as notes, lists, calendars, and schedules, to reduce their dependence on brain memory.

People are better at processing small chunks of information

Progressive disclosure requires multiple clicks. You may have heard that website design should minimize the number of clicks required for users to get detailed information. But the number of clicks is not important, and people are very willing to click multiple times. In fact, if users can get the right amount of information with each click and are willing to continue to browse the website along the design idea, they will not notice the clicking operation at all.

If you have to choose between making users click and making users think, click more and think less.

Before you use progressive disclosure, be sure to do enough research to figure out what information most users need and when they need it.

How difficult is it to get people’s attention? It depends on how focused they are

As long as you give clear instructions and the task is not too time-consuming, people can concentrate and immerse themselves in it, ignoring other distractions.

People’s subconscious will constantly scan the surrounding environment to see if there is any information that interests them, such as their own name, food, sex, and danger.

The closer people are to the goal, the more motivated they are

The closer people are to the goal, the more motivated they are to complete it, especially when success is in sight.

After achieving the goal, motivation and purchasing power will decrease sharply. This is called the post-reward reset phenomenon. Usually, people have little patience to complete another task.

The risk of losing customers is highest when rewards are achieved.

Human sociality: The upper limit of the number of people in the “strong relationship circle” is 150

When designing a product that focuses on community relations, consider whether the interaction is designed for strong relationships or weak relationships.

If you are designing for strong relationships, you need to design some features that allow users to get close to each other, so that they can connect and get to know each other in the circle.

If you are designing for weak relationships, don’t make it the main purpose for users in the social network to directly contact or get close to each other.

Human sensory system: Everyone has seven emotions and six desires

 

The seven emotions of happiness, sadness, contempt, fear, disgust, surprise, and anger are universal and are expressed through facial expressions and body postures.

If you want to communicate with pictures (such as pictures of people on a website), using pictures that express one of the seven emotions is the most effective way to communicate.

People are good at reading these seven basic emotions from photos. People can often tell which emotions are fake, so try to use pictures that look real.

Find out which emotions can infect the target users. In addition to the basic information of users, it is also necessary to clarify and record their psychological conditions, such as which emotions are most infectious or most likely to stimulate various psychological activities of target users.

People always make mistakes, there is no completely fault-tolerant product

To design a product or game that persuades people to take specific actions, you need to understand the subconscious motivations of the target group.

When people tell you the reasons for their specific actions, you should be skeptical. Because decisions are made in the subconscious, they may not know the real reason for their decisions.

Although people make decisions based on certain subconscious factors, they also want to find a reasonable reason for the decision. So you still need to provide users with some reasonable reasons, even if they are not the real reasons that make them make the decision.

When designing game interactions, we often hope that players will act according to our own designs from the perspective of designers. We give players some abilities and hope that they will follow suit. In fact, it is more important to understand the psychology of players, analyze and use the mental model of players, so that the game can become what we want it to be, and players will listen to the “suggestions” of the designer and feel that this is exactly what they want.

entry.title: Things About Novice Guidance Testing
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

For a game, the novice guidance is the first door that players open to the game. Whether the novice guidance is good or not is crucial. Complex and difficult novice guidance can easily “dissuade” newbies, while boring and repetitive novice guidance will make “veterans” feel bored. Both results may lead to player churn during the novice guidance stage, thereby reducing the game’s retention rate.

Therefore, testing the novice guidance is very important. The intuitive feedback from the test can optimize the novice guidance, thereby improving the game’s retention.

 

(Justice Online Novice Guidance)

The novice guidance of the game mainly bears two “missions”:

The first mission is to enable players to master the main functional gameplay and successfully “get on the road.”

For the mastery of functional gameplay, we need to do a lot of dismantling work before testing, that is, to organize and dismantle all the functional points involved in the current novice guidance.

 

(A Chinese Ghost Story Mobile Novice Guidance)

Novice guidance testing does not end after the player has experienced the novice guidance and asks “Did you learn it?”. For the dismantling of functional points, we need to refine every detail, such as “move”, “dodge”, “skill release”, etc. During the test, we need to carefully confirm whether the player has learned these basic functional points. Not every content that appears for the first time in the game is very important. Basic functional points must be problems that will get stuck if they are not learned, resulting in the inability to continue the game.

Therefore, we also need to distinguish which ones are worthy of attention and which ones are not so important. For current games, most of the novice guidance is linear, that is, only one point is taught at a time, and the next point is taught after this point is taught, instead of presenting a tree shape. Because if there are too many teaching points at the same time, players will not know what they should learn. Therefore, for linear novice guidance, the order in which various functional points are taught may also be very important. These are all contents that need to be paid attention to in the test.

The dismantling of functional gameplay plays a great role not only in the testing of novice guidance, but also in the analysis of novice node retention. After dismantling the various guidance points in the novice period, we can bury points for these contents in advance. When the game is tested, we can see which node has a higher churn rate through data, so that we can get a more objective result.

Another “mission” of novice guidance is to attract players through high-quality plots, animations, and other content, create a sense of substitution, and thus retain players.

 

(Meteor Butterfly Sword Novice Guidance)

So when testing, it is not just about whether the player has learned, but also about the attractiveness of the content in the novice stage. Generally speaking, novice guidance mainly makes players feel “bright” through the plot and art quality. Therefore, when conducting tests, we will pay attention to the player’s acceptance of the world view and their evaluation of the art.

If further subdivided, the plot can be broken down into background story, character settings, plot lines, etc., and the art can be broken down into scenes, characters, animations, special effects, etc. However, the breakdown of content is relatively subjective and not as specific as the breakdown of functional gameplay, so it can be carried out according to your own needs.

Novice guidance testing is not necessarily before the game is launched. After the game is launched, we also need to test the novice process. For example, for a major promotion, we hope to introduce a large number of game newbies. For these newbies, is there any problem with our guidance? Or, after the game is launched, some content of the game has actually become a benchmark. In the novice guidance test, do we still need to test these contents? These all need to be adjusted according to specific needs.

entry.title: [US Sharing] A First Look at Flink
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Flink is a stream processing framework. In stream processing, data can usually be regarded as an infinite-capacity pipeline. Every time a message comes in, it is processed. This is a different concept from batch processing. Batch processing usually stores data in a file system and then processes the data.

From this, it can be seen that compared to the batch processing method, the stream processing calculation approach has lower latency and is more suitable for scenarios such as real-time calculation.

So how do we count data in this stream processing framework? In Flink, a variety of windows are provided to help us implement the calculation and statistics of stream data. This article will briefly introduce the concept of windows in Flink.

Consider the following scenario: cars are constantly passing through a checkpoint from the same direction. We want to count the total number of cars passing through this checkpoint within a period of time. Since the cars are constantly coming, we cannot wait for all the cars to pass through this checkpoint before counting and summing.

So we need to change our thinking and try an accumulation strategy.

Every time a piece of data comes in, we add it to the previous result. In this way, for each input time, an updated record will be obtained:

 

But this cumulative sum may not be what we ultimately want, because it may lose some data during the continuous updating of data. Then we may need to re-describe the problem:

Count the number of cars passing through the checkpoint every minute.

Then we need to count the vehicle data every 60 seconds. This is called a Tumbling window in Flink, as shown in the figure:

 

As can be seen in the figure, each Tumbling window does not overlap. In some scenarios, we may need a smoother transition method, such as counting the data of the previous 1 minute every 30 seconds. This is a Sliding window, as shown in the figure:
