Sublime Text is a code editor with a beautiful user interface and powerful features, such as code thumbnails, Python plugins, code snippets, etc. Key bindings, menus, and toolbars are also customizable. Sublime Text’s main features include spell check, bookmarks, a complete Python API, Goto functionality, instant project switching, multiple selections, multiple windows, and more. Sublime Text is a cross-platform editor that supports Windows, Linux, Mac OS X, and other operating systems.

Case Demonstration

Sublime was once the mainstream front-end editor (although it has gradually been replaced by VSCode now), and its powerful text functions are also commendable for the efficiency of big data development. Next, an example will be introduced to help everyone appreciate the brilliance of Sublime:

Sublime supports the syntax of most mainstream programming languages. When we open a piece of text, we only need to set it to the corresponding syntax format in the View –> Syntax of the main menu to highlight the keywords:

 

One of the highlights of Sublime Text is that it supports multiple selections - selecting multiple areas at the same time, and then editing them at the same time.

Ctrl + D selects the word where the cursor is currently located and highlights all occurrences of the word. Ctrl + D again selects the next occurrence of the word. During the multiple word selection process, use Ctrl + K to skip, Ctrl + U to go back, and Esc to exit multiple editing.

A major application scenario of multiple word selection is renaming - to make the code cleaner. Although Sublime Text cannot automatically rename like an IDE (such as Eclipse), we can use multiple selection + multiple editing for intuitive and convenient renaming:

 

In programming languages that use semicolons as statement terminators, the mixed use of special characters seems to have little effect on the compilation and operation of the code, but in languages like Python that use indentation as syntax, mixing tabs and spaces will cause errors when the code is executed. Sublime’s lower right corner can set Tab Size: how many spaces a Tab key is converted into, and then select Convert Indentation To Spaces to convert all Tab keys to space keys.

As shown in the figure, when the code is selected, a long horizontal line represents a tab, and a small dot represents a space:

 

Finding & Replacing

Sublime Text provides powerful find (and replace) functions. The basis of replace is find, so the replace function is introduced here. Use Ctrl + H (Command + option + F on Mac) to bring up the standard find & replace module. The first button on the left of the first row is the regular expression switch, which means whether the searched content is a regular expression or an ordinary string. The following demonstrates calling up the standard find & replace module, then turning off the regular expression switch, and replacing the string UBB with ux_b:

 

After the code is modified, Ctrl + J can merge the currently selected area into one line (in actual development, it is recommended to have one variable per line, aligned with the letter at the beginning):

 

Summary

In addition to the built-in functions of the editor, Sublime can also be used as a simple compiler (the compiler call path needs to be configured by yourself). You can install the package control console (Package Control), use Ctrl+Shift+P (Command+Shift+P on Mac) to call it up, and then you can install and use various extension plugins on Sublime.

entry.title: Is the Goal of Game Interaction Design Always "Convenience"?
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

When we talk about interaction design, it naturally connects to user experience. Interaction is designed to improve user experience. Designers gradually summarize their own methodologies in their work to make the user’s gaming experience smoother and give the game product the attribute of “convenience”. No matter what kind of game, most of the time, this is the purpose of interaction design.

Convenience can be divided into visual, auditory, tactile (operational), etc.

Visual Convenience

Visual convenience can be further divided into UI layout, UI size, etc.

Generally speaking, the player’s visual center will be concentrated in the middle area of the screen. We can divide the screen into a nine-square grid. The player’s visual center will be concentrated in the middle area and its surroundings. When laying out the UI, most games will also concentrate important information in this area, allowing players to obtain the important information that the interface wants to present to players more quickly and conveniently.

 

You can observe the games on mobile phones. Although many interfaces are not directly centered, they may have a left-right/up-down layout style. However, if you draw a frame around the important information as a whole, you can see that the overall is still concentrated towards the middle. If the important information of a game is scattered around, with pieces here and there, the player’s reading efficiency will be much lower, and such a design is relatively unsuccessful.

 

(The character interface of Meteor Butterfly Sword is distributed left and right, but the characters and information are still centered overall)

UI size refers to the proportion of fonts, icons, and various pop-up windows and other UIs in the interface. Designing UIs of reasonable size is one of the basic qualities that game interaction design should have. UI size can help players distinguish important information from secondary information. A comfortable UI ratio is also the foundation for players to play games for a long time. If a game’s UI cannot even be seen clearly, let alone the gameplay.

Due to the popularity of mobile games, the most common problem when many PC games are converted to mobile games is the UI size allocation. PC games display a lot of content. Directly reducing the proportion to the mobile game interface will make it appear very crowded and small. Game designers mostly design on large screens. Looking directly at the large screen, it is easy to feel that the current proportion is already very suitable or even too large. This is very dangerous.

The best way is to often put the interface on the mobile phone to see the effect when making the interface. If time is tight, you can also take screenshots of mature mobile game interfaces, extract the font, icon and other sizes from its interface as a standard, and do it on this basis, which can get twice the result with half the effort.

Operational Convenience

In contrast to vision, the area where players are convenient to operate when holding the device comfortably is often around the screen. Fortunately, these two areas do not focus on one piece, which is convenient for us to better design mobile games. For games with heavy operations, in core combat, we often design the joystick and skills on the left and right sides. Initially, it was designed for the purpose of operational convenience, but now this design has gradually become a barrier.

The design barrier means that new designers do not need to think too much to come up with the design of the left joystick and right attack. If there is a new game whose interaction is left attack and right joystick, it will be much more difficult for players to get started. When a function develops to the point where it is unnecessary and unsuitable to design a brand new operation, a design barrier is created.

 

In addition to the operational convenience design of a single interface, the transition between interfaces also needs to consider the convenience of operation. Generally speaking, letting players achieve the goal with the fewest steps is what designers want to see. In traditional games, the entrances of various functions will be arranged in the main interface. Enter the secondary function interface through the main interface, and then filter the secondary functions. If you want to call up other functions, you need to return to the main interface from the secondary interface, and then select another function.

This is a simple page turning idea. But some games have done better, such as the rhythm game Muse Dash. Except for the core combat, you can directly click to enter various functional entrances no matter what interface you are in.

 

 

(In MUSE DASH, the display of tabs in different interfaces can directly point to the function to be entered regardless of the interface)

However, this design is not universal, and it is more suitable for use in games with fewer total functions, otherwise it may also lead to confusion in player memory and other adverse consequences.

However, is the purpose of game interaction design always “convenience”? The answer is no. The word “convenience” comes from “Xunzi·Jundao”: “Its response to changes is also quick and convenient without confusion.” It means to be convenient and straightforward, convenient and light. In some game designs, it is not enough to just consider convenience.

Guided Design

The purpose of the game’s novice guidance design is not “convenience” from the beginning. Normally, after downloading a game, clicking to open it and you can experience the game content, is the fastest and most “convenient” process. However, the novice guide breaks this process. Most games’ novice guides do not allow skipping. Players must experience the novice before they can enter the game.

Now many players have more or less game experience. For them, downloading the same type of game and going through the cumbersome novice guide is likely to cause disgust. However, in the era when the game market was not so prosperous, the novice guidance of many games was missing or even non-existent. For example, a new 3D game, even if new players know that WASD can control the movement of up, down, left, and right, they don’t know what they should do, where they should go, where to pick up tasks, and so on.

Novice guidance is necessary for players, but its form of expression and detail can be distinguished. For example, Onmyoji and Onmyoji Arena can choose whether they are novices or veterans before starting, and choose the corresponding guidance design according to their own needs.

Emotional Interaction Design

Emotional design, which we often talk about, uses interactive operations to influence the player’s flow and enable the player to have a better gaming experience. The purpose of this type of design is also not “convenience”.

For example, the card draw system common in card games. The most convenient interaction is undoubtedly to click the button to enter the card draw, enter the card draw interface, and click to draw the card. However, more and more card games have set up card draw interactions, typically Onmyoji‘s drawing symbols to draw cards, Love Nikki-Dress UP Queen‘s male protagonist interactive card draw, and so on. These operations that can be given emotional design often have some characteristics: the realization of the function itself is simple, it requires a certain price or the benefits are large, and it is easy to trigger players’ emotional resonance through interactions other than hard-core operations.

The purpose of game interaction design is not necessarily “convenience”. In different situations and for different purposes, the purpose of interaction design will change. Since most of the time interaction is designed around convenience, beginners may fall into the misunderstanding of “convenience” supremacy when summarizing methodologies, and miss some interesting designs. More seriously, sometimes the operation design that is considered convenient may make it difficult for players to understand. Therefore, no matter when, we must return to the perspective of user experience. First, think clearly about the purpose of the function you are responsible for, what it can bring to users, what users will expect… You cannot be preconceived and put on your own methodology. The purpose of interaction design is not absolute at any time.

entry.title: You've Learned So Many Techniques, But the Requester Says They Don't Need User Research
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

User research, as a new role, still faces many doubts and objections during its promotion. Because for a long time in the past, there was no such role as user research, and products were still made successfully. Today, I will introduce to you what doubts user research may face and how to deal with these doubts.

1. We Have Never Had a User Research Role, So We Don’t Need User Research.

Source: Many old-fashioned people will have this feeling. We have never had this role, and isn’t our product also very good?

Response: Not having this role does not mean that user research has not been done. Every product must have researched its target users, understood the preferences of target users, and peeked at the evaluations left by users on the Internet. And these are all doing user research work. There were no professionals to do it before, now is the time to let professionals do it!

2. We Are Very Busy, the Schedule is Very Full, and There is No Time for User Research

Source: The product schedule is very full, and the understanding of user research is not enough, which may cause the above-mentioned troubles for the requester. We are already very busy and have no time to do user research.

Response: Doing user research with a small amount of time now may save a lot of time in the future. According to previous research, in the software development process alone, 60% of errors are due to incorrect user experience. User researchers can design relevant research according to the project schedule and give agile feedback in the shortest possible time. Sacrifice a small amount of time cost in exchange for future efficiency and direction, why not?

3. We Don’t Have Anything to Research Now

Source: When the project is in the initial stage, there may not be a stable build, maybe just an idea, so the requester may think that we have nothing to study now.

Response: At any stage, there is something to study. Even if it’s just some core ideas, user researchers can do some research to help the requester understand user needs. For example, concept research can be carried out even without a demo.

4. User Research Takes a Long Time, and the Information is Lagging

Source: When the version is iterating rapidly, some requesters may feel that by the time you finish the report, we have already iterated several times.

Response: Agile feedback and advance booking can avoid delays. When the product has some ideas, it should communicate with the user researcher in time and make an appointment for related research in advance so that the research can be carried out smoothly and save time. Agile feedback means that after the research is completed on the same day, the key information is quickly fed back to the requester, and it is not necessary to wait for all the research to be completed before feedback. In addition, research information is not only useful for the current version, but also valuable for the next version.

5. We Don’t Have the Money to Do User Research

Source: In the case of a limited budget, the requester may feel that my money is spent on the blade, and there is no more budget for user research.

Response: We cannot afford not to do this kind of research. For example, in the development stage, you can understand many usability problems by spending only a very small cost. In the later stage, the maintenance cost of these problems is usually more expensive. At the same time, user experience research is also an investment in future revenue. A good user experience can bring more profits.

Today, I shared with you the doubts and confusions that the requester may have in the early stage. In the future, I will continue to share with you the doubts that the requester may have in the process of doing user research. For example, is the user research method scientific? Are the conclusions reliable?

entry.title: A Discussion on Learning to Rank (LTR)
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

The problem of ranking has always been a classic and core issue in the computer field. From simple numerical data sorting like bubble sort and quick sort, to more complex, real-world business problems, such as the ranking of results retrieved from keywords in an app’s search bar, display advertising, and the ordering of items in recommendation lists, the problem is quite involved. The quality of the ranking results greatly impacts the user experience, as well as advertising revenue for search, recommendation, and advertising businesses. Unlike traditional ranking methods, Learning to Rank (LTR) can be simply understood as using machine learning methods to sort and display instances.

Evaluation Metrics for Learning to Rank:

Metric Formula
Precision and Recall (PR) -
Mean Average Precision (MAP) See details below.
nDCG See details below.
ERR Takes the reciprocal of rank as accuracy.

Precision and Recall (PR): Precision reflects the accuracy rate, and recall reflects the completeness rate.

Mean Average Precision (MAP): AP (Average Precision) can be understood as order-sensitive recall. MAP then averages this. The higher the position of the relevant documents retrieved by the system, the higher the MAP value. It is calculated for a single query as the mean of the average precision scores for each relevant document retrieved.

AP = Summation from(k=1,n)[P(k) * rel(k)] / Number of Relevant Documents

  • Where k is the rank in the sequence of retrieved documents.
  • n is the number of retrieved documents.
  • P(k) is the precision at cut-off k in the list.
  • rel(k) is an indicator function equaling 1 if the item at rank k is a relevant document, zero otherwise.
    MAP is the mean of the AP scores across multiple queries.

normalized Discounted Cumulative Gain (nDCG): Cumulatively calculates the overall gain value. In MAP, the four documents are either relevant or irrelevant to the query, that is, the relevance is either 0 or 1. nDCG improves this by dividing the relevance into r+1 levels from 0 to r. The formula in the figure above is the DCG calculation formula, but the comparability of DCG between lists of different lengths is not high. nDCG adds normalization processing.

DCG_p = rel_1 + summation from(i=2,p) [ rel_i / log2(i) ]

  • p is a particular rank position.
  • rel_i is the graded relevance of the result at position i.

nDCG_p = DCG_p / IDCG

  • IDCG is the ideal DCG, the DCG value for a perfect ranking.

Expected Reciprocal Rank (ERR): Takes the reciprocal of the ranking of the correct answer in the results given by the evaluated system as its accuracy, and then averages it for all questions.

Model Classification for Learning to Rank:

Learning to rank models are usually divided into pointwise methods, pairwise methods, and listwise methods. The three different design ideas are mainly reflected in the annotation methods and loss functions.

Pointwise Methods:

This is the simplest and easiest to understand solution. It transforms the ranking problem into a common classification or regression problem in machine learning. If the final prediction target is a real value, it is a regression problem. If it is a probability problem, it is a classification problem, such as CTR (Click-Through Rate) prediction. First, each processing object is manually labeled with training samples. Machine learning models such as support vector machines and logistic regression are used to adjust parameters. Finally, new instances use the model’s scoring function to get a new ranking score. This type of method has an obvious disadvantage: it does not consider the relative relationship between instances.

Pairwise Methods:

This approach gives the relative ranking between each instance. According to the relative ranking, the final ranking of all instances can also be given. This is mainly because it is easy to calculate the gradient of the loss function, but it is difficult to directly calculate the value of the loss function. Representative methods are the Lambda series, such as LambdaRank and LambdaMART, RankNet.

Listwise Methods:

This approach directly gives the overall ranking of all instances, directly optimizing evaluation indicators such as nDCG and ERR. However, it is more complicated during training because all training instances need to be labeled with their rankings.

Major Challenges in Ranking:

  1. Serious imbalance in the ratio of positive and negative samples: How to sample reasonably. For example, in CTR, there are many impressions, but very few click behaviors. In recommendations, there are many browsing behaviors, but very few purchase behaviors.
  2. Sparse target data: Accuracy is not high enough.
  3. High real-time requirements: For example, being able to change the recommendation list in real time based on the latest click behavior.
  4. The importance of multiple different objectives cannot be quantified: Advertising may aim to increase the CTR click-through rate, but in games, it is sometimes retention, purchase rate, repurchase rate, etc. How to measure the importance of recommended list instances for different objectives is also very complex.

Common LTR Ranking Models in Industry:

The evolution of algorithms in the industry:

Artificial Rules -> Linear Models -> Tree Models (GBDT) -> Deep Learning

Here are several ranking models widely used in the industry:

  1. LR + GBDT (Semi-automated Feature Combination): This combined model has been widely used in CTR prediction, and of course, the ranking part of many companies’ recommendation systems also deploys this combined model. The LR model has good interpretability, but it requires good feature engineering and cannot effectively extract combined features. Therefore, the GBDT model can be used first to extract combined features and enhance the generalization performance of the model, and the new feature vector is input into LR.

  2. FM Model (Automated Second-Order Feature Combination): That is, the Factorization Machine model. On the basis of linear features, second-order feature combinations are directly introduced, and the inner product of corresponding feature vectors is used to represent them. In essence, these features are embedded.

  3. Wide & Deep Model (Automated Higher-Order Feature Combination): First used by Google in Google Play for app recommendation ranking. The wide part is a linear model, and the deep part embeds the combined high-dimensional sparse features into low-dimensional dense feature vectors using a neural network. Joint training of the two parts can complement each other’s shortcomings in complex feature engineering and insufficient interpretability.

Application Scenarios of Learning to Rank in Recommendations:

  1. Multi-channel Recall Fusion Ranking:

    A recommendation system’s recall phase may use a variety of different recall strategies, such as content-based recall, collaborative filtering-based recall, popular item-based recall, interest tag-based recall, and so on. It is impossible to definitively determine which recall strategy is more important for items recalled by different recall strategies. Therefore, a learning-to-rank model is needed to rank the items recalled by multiple channels based on user behavior feedback, which is also a major function of the ranking module. Each recall channel can use A/B testing to select the appropriate number. Users have different levels of interest in each channel of content, so the top-k parameter k for recall can also be personalized.

  2. Multi-objective Fusion Ranking:

    Not only to improve CTR and CVR (Conversion Rate), but also retention, add-to-cart, and other multiple objectives. Different parameters are trained for different objectives, and the parameters of different objective models need to be manually adjusted. In addition, different objective models have different levels of importance, and there needs to be a personalized weight for each type of person. We can construct pairs of items generated by multiple objectives, and train the order of different items during training. Another method is to adopt multi-task learning, share parameters, and fuse the learned scores. Typical algorithms include Google’s MMOE (Multi-gate Mixture-of-Experts) and Alibaba’s ESMM (Entire Space Multi-Task Model).

entry.title: Some Differences Between Game Interaction and Product Interaction
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

When it comes to interaction design, people most often think of website interaction design and app interaction design, while game interaction design seems relatively niche. Even in the interaction design courses of many universities, students are mostly exposed to the design of conventional products, and there is very little content on game interaction design.

As types of interaction design, game interaction and product interaction have many things in common. Their purpose is to improve usability and user experience. So what are the special features of game interaction that are different from product interaction?

Landscape Orientation

The first and most obvious difference is that many games adopt a landscape orientation. The natural difference between the horizontal and vertical holding postures determines the different hot zones for finger touch, and thus the layout of the interface functions will be adjusted accordingly.

The main holding method of a vertical screen is one-handed, and the touch hot zone is mainly concentrated in the lower left. Of course, with the increase in the size of mobile phone screens, the holding method and the touch hot zone have also changed accordingly, which will not be discussed in this article. In contrast, landscape screens are often held with two hands, and the natural activity areas of the left and right thumbs are the most convenient places for users to touch. Therefore, the main operation area of ​​the game is usually placed on the lower left and lower right, and the auxiliary function area is placed on the upper left and upper right. The top and bottom of the screen are more inclined to place some display information that does not require operation, as these areas are less accessible.
Vertical Touch Hot Zone
Landscape Touch Hot Zone

Information Hierarchy

In conventional app product design, the information density of each interface is usually controlled within a certain range, such as line spacing and font size, to ensure that users can easily identify and read under normal circumstances. Content of different information levels usually uses screen transitions. For example, the list page is one interface, and clicking to view details is another interface. The situation in games is very different, especially in core battle scenarios. Frequent screen transitions will not only put huge pressure on scene loading, but also greatly disrupt the user’s gaming experience.

Therefore, there are very few interface transitions in games, which requires interaction designers to pack a large amount of information into one interface. Game interaction needs to consider the size and layout of information more, use non-full-screen information windows more, and carefully sort out the transition levels of information and the impact of transitions on user experience.

Operation Guidance

The complexity of game operations also determines the importance of novice guidance in games. Product apps often only have brief guides when new features are added or revisions are made, while games will have a longer and carefully designed novice guidance process at the beginning. Game designers spend a lot of effort on the process, content, and form of novice guidance, in order to make it easier for users to get started and more willing to stay.

In addition to straightforward click prompts, explanatory text, etc., some implicit guides are also worth considering. For example, for the page turning method of a list, using arrow guidance or text description is too deliberate. We usually use the form of exposing a section of a row at the edge to remind users that there is more content. In fact, if you add some more details to the animation effect of the list, the list items appear from top to bottom in sequence, and the user can more naturally receive that the list is arranged vertically and should be turned up and down.

For example, we can attract users’ attention through light and dark contrast, dynamic and static contrast, etc., and guide users’ visual focus shift in a natural way. The way to choose a profession at the beginning of Justice Online is through a small bird. The bird takes off in a relatively static scene, and the user’s sight naturally focuses on the bird. When the bird flies to one of the professional characters, the user’s sight is also naturally taken to that character. This natural form of guidance can enhance the user’s sense of immersion more than directly using highlight effects.

Emotion and Atmosphere

How to render emotion and atmosphere is a key difference between game interaction and product interaction. Conventional products are more like a tool for users, assisting users’ lives in all aspects. Games are more like an escape from life for users. How to build a smooth user experience and reduce interruptions to enhance immersion is something that game interaction needs to consider. The integration of the interface atmosphere with the game world view, the cognitive consistency between the interaction method and the actual operation method, etc., can help enhance the user’s sense of immersion.

As game interaction designers, how to flexibly apply these methods to the design and enhance the immersion of the game through interaction still requires us to slowly explore through continuous attempts.

entry.title: The Setup and Effects of Tournaments in MMO Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

In the recently concluded Dota 2 “TI9 International Invitational Tournament”, the OG team from Europe defended their title, breaking the curse of no same player or same team winning twice in years. It was also these same five young men who, for the first time, shattered the myth that Chinese teams won every even-numbered year at the TI8 arena last year, crushing the dreams of countless Chinese Dota fans. In addition to endless glory, they also brought in more than $10 million in championship bonuses each year (TI9’s total prize pool exceeded $30 million, with the champion team receiving 45.5% of it, more than $14 million, which also broke the prize record set by TI itself last year) and hundreds of millions of viewers per day.

Dota 2, which was dubbed “Dead Game” by “Principal” Wang Sicong several years ago, has maintained many world records precisely because of its relatively complete tournament system. It cannot but be said to be one of the miracles in the history of e-sports.

However, unlike games such as DotA and CSGO, which test skills, tournaments cannot be used as a core eye-catching and money-making method in MMO games. The main reasons include the following:

  1. Compared with MOBA, shooting and other operational games, MMO game players are more diverse. In addition to the battle power players who pursue the thrill of PK, there are also a large number of players who pursue social interaction, exploration, appearance and other gameplays. Therefore, tournaments cannot be an eye-catching method for all players.

  2. As a battle power development game, the core method of improving battle power in MMO games is still氪金 (kèjīn - pay to win) and 肝 (gān - grinding), and relatively speaking, the player’s operation and skills have a relatively slight impact on the results. Therefore, for traditional MMO games, tournaments will not be used as the main means of attracting traffic.

However, this does not mean that there is no place for tournaments in MMO games at all. In fact, there are still a considerable number of players who are willing to watch the “fairies fight” of various masters in the game. And in recent years, watching live broadcasts has become more and more a trend. For most players, they can satisfy their desire to “experience” the fun of master players through live broadcasts of tournaments. In addition, they can also learn the operation techniques and detail control of master players in tournaments.

Taking A Chinese Ghost Story Mobile (倩女幽魂手游 - Qiànnǚ Yōuhún Shǒuyóu) as an example, a variety of tournament types have been launched, including the “Cross-Server Star Tournament” series specially created for big R players and the “National Championship” where all players compete fairly and test the players’ details and operations more.

For the “Cross-Server Star Tournament”, stricter restrictions are imposed on the registration conditions: only players with VIP level 18 or above can form a team to register. But this also ensures the luxurious level of the contestants’ equipment and improves the watchability of the tournament.

Compared with the “Cross-Server Star Tournament” where money is king, the “National Championship” pays more attention to the players’ control of details and the level of operation. The “National Championship” has almost no entry restrictions. All registered players can create accounts according to their profession on the exclusive tournament server, and all created accounts have the same level and equipment with the same or similar ratings for players to freely adjust and replace, and they can freely form teams to register. In the tournament, in addition to pursuing the ultimate equality, all accounts are equipped with “nuclear weapon-level” equipment, which can make players truly experience the top enjoyment of master players.

In MMO game tournaments, if the participating teams win the top four, they will receive cash rewards of up to tens of thousands or even hundreds of thousands of yuan, as well as exclusive in-game props, titles and other rewards. Other players can interact by watching live broadcasts and participating in quizzes.

In addition, the finals of the “National Championship” are held offline together with the “A Chinese Ghost Story Carnival”. Players can purchase tickets in the game to meet the master players face-to-face, and players who cannot arrive at the scene can also watch the live broadcast in the game to cheer for their favorite teams.

Therefore, although tournaments are not a core means of attracting traffic for MMO games, through reasonable tournament settings and player interaction methods, they can still greatly enhance the player’s experience in the game.

entry.title: Battle Pass System Design in Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

What is a Battle Pass? It’s a fantastic payment design from Fortnite that has swept across various games, such as the Honor Pass system in Honor of Kings, the season pass in PUBG Mobile, the Battle Pass in Apex Legends, and so on. It can be said that the design of the Battle Pass is another revolution in the game payment model after the design of loot boxes.

 

 

Looking at the major payment models of games, such as Monument Valley, a single-player game, the revenue mainly relies on “tickets”; such as A Chinese Ghost Story, an MMORPG game, the revenue mainly relies on a small number of big spenders; such as casual games like Candy Crush, the revenue is mainly the transaction of consumables; such as Onmyoji, a card game, the revenue is mainly from gacha, similarly Overwatch‘s loot boxes and Hearthstone‘s card packs; there are also ways to earn revenue such as skin sales.

Each payment model has its advantages and limitations. For example, the skin itself has very low appeal to many players who focus on practicality. The method of gacha loot boxes has the same drawbacks as the skin payment method on the one hand, and the gacha of pure card games has greater limitations on the core of the game itself. So how does the Battle Pass work?

 

 

This mechanism is divided into two modes: free version and paid version.

Free-to-play players can earn experience by completing tasks and other methods in the game, and accumulate levels to obtain corresponding level rewards; at the same time, they can also purchase the paid version to unlock more rewards at the corresponding experience level; of course, they can also directly purchase experience to obtain rewards.

It can be found that under this mechanism, the more players play, the more rewards they get, and the greater the temptation to purchase the paid version. At the same time, once the paid version is purchased, players will be very eager to reach the final grand prize, so they will stay in the game for a longer time, or directly spend money to “buy time”.

At the same time, this mechanism has a very big advantage. Its payment is separated from the core of the game itself, which means that payment will not impact the game balance, which is very friendly to players with low spending. In addition, this method of getting on the bus first and then buying a ticket is far more likely to give players the urge to pay than the method of buying a ticket first and then getting on the bus. At its root, this is a model that accumulates rewards for players.

 

 

From the theory of game design, our core is to hope that players can be “addicted” to our games, that is, to improve players’ interactivity and stickiness, so that users develop usage habits. The HOOKED model explains and illustrates the operating mechanism of “addiction”.

The hooked model mainly includes four stages: trigger, action, variable rewards, and investment. Trigger refers to the inducement that prompts users to take action. For example, the level 1 reward of the Battle Pass is often very generous and attractive. At the same time, as players continue to play the game, they will always be prompted to receive corresponding level rewards for free, and at the same time, they will be prompted that the paid rewards are more generous.

 

In action, as players continue to play the game, they will get closer and closer to completing the stage goal (next level/final level). At this time, the motivation to complete the task will be stronger. Through the design of Battle Pass level rewards, a more attractive reward is set every few levels, and a higher attractive reward is set at level 1 and the highest level. Of course, in this process, players constantly receive rewards. Variable rewards can meet the needs of users and stimulate users’ desire to use; and constantly invest time, money, etc., investment will form user preferences, because users tend to overestimate their labor results, and try to be consistent with their past behavior to produce psychological associations and automatically take action, these are all converted into sunk costs that affect the player’s judgment, and promote the player to continuously enter such a cycle of addiction.

 

In the design of the Battle Pass, the most core and important thing is, first of all, the display of the next “small goal”, which is the direct driving force to attract players. Secondly, for players who have not upgraded, the overall comparison of rewards in the two modes is also an important driving force to promote players to pay. As the level increases, players will feel that they have missed more rewards, attracting players to pay. In addition, the arrangement and level distribution of sub-tabs such as tasks and exchanges in the system also need to be simplified to reduce the difficulty of understanding and operation for players.

The Battle Pass payment model has gradually matured after more than a year, and there is also more commercial potential to be tapped.

entry.title: What is the Core Experience of a Game
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

A few years ago, a game advertisement swept the country and became a popular online phrase:

“This is a brand new version you haven’t played before. Just experience it for three minutes, and you will be like me, loving this game…”

Undoubtedly, this was a successful brainwashing campaign. Many netizens imitated the accent of the spokesperson. Besides the popular catchphrase, there is one point worth pondering: Why would someone fall in love with this game after just 3 minutes of experience? What do players experience in these 3 minutes?

This is the topic of our discussion today: the core experience of a game.

The core experience carries the core fun of the game. Take A Chinese Ghost Story Online (New Ghost) as an example, an MMO game that has been operating for 8 years. When many people talk about this game, they will mention social interaction. There are many players who like to make friends, find partners, decorate their homes, and chat in the game, rather than discussing PK skills.

So, is social interaction the core experience of New Ghost? No. At low levels, players are almost always playing solo, running through storylines and tasks. Guilds are something that come after level 25. Then is growth the core experience? No, either. Why do players want to grow? Ultimately, it is because they want to improve their strength so that they can defeat bosses and PK with other players, which is – combat. The reason why players continue to play is that the combat is exciting, defeating monsters is exciting, and “killing” is exciting.

When we want to extract the core of a game, the simplest method is subtraction.

New Ghost can be without the guild system, without the marriage system, and even without the chat box, but it cannot be without combat.

From this point of view, the core experience of New Ghost and Honor of Kings is the same: kill, defeat the opponent, and achieve combat victory.

In other words, the core experience must be repeatable and expandable. A player can repeatedly experience it from entering the game to leaving the game.

The core experience determines the type of game. Obviously, Shining Nikki and Knives Out are two different types of games. The former is a dress-up and nurturing game, while the latter is a tactical competition game. Different core experiences attract different types of players. In 2018, the average number of active users in the Chinese game market reached 280 million (MobData Research Institute, 2018). In the segmented market, MOBA and shooting games are evenly matched, and puzzle and parkour games also occupy a large market share.

The most important thing for game developers at the beginning of game design is to determine the core experience of their game. This affects what kind of players will become the target players, whether they can accept the game, whether they are willing to try and continue to experience it, and it is also an important way to find a blue ocean.

A breakthrough and innovative core experience design can often help the game gain a leading position in the industry and reap unexpected rewards.

So, the core experience of the game is so important, what kind of support can we provide as user experience researchers?

If the game has not been officially launched or is still in a state of flux, congratulations, you are likely to find a way to success for the game at this time. For example, through concept testing, the product can understand what players are interested in and what they want at an early stage.

If the game has taken shape, a complete novice test can test the ease of getting started with the game and understand whether players can enjoy the core of the game as quickly as possible.

Of course, there are thousands of methods. Grasping the core experience of the game is grasping the soul of the game.

entry.title: Overseas Player "Scream-degree" Testing
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

As a very important category in game user experience testing, “scream-degree” testing has always been a powerful tool for evaluating the quality of gameplay during the project initiation period.

Many companies are also using this system for project rating and filtering. The many indicators in this system are crucial and are highly correlated with the market performance of the project after its launch.

Starting from 2013, known as the first year of mobile games, major manufacturers began to comprehensively deploy in the mobile game market, accelerating their speed to seize the opportunity. This scene of competing powers also led to the explosion of the mobile game market in 2014.

Consequently, this market situation also raised the production cost of mobile games to an unprecedented level. The result is that the competition to create a high-quality mobile game product that is acceptable to the market has become very fierce.

On the other hand, the strategy of major manufacturers to fully deploy in mobile games and the rising overall development costs have created a situation that runs counter to each other. If you want to blossom everywhere and save costs to increase profits, the risk is too great for every company.

Full-scale deployment is a good thing, but not every product will be successful. So you need to “use good steel on the blade.” Within the limited annual development budget, how to develop mobile game products that are most likely to be accepted by the market is a question that every manufacturer wants to try to figure out.

In this process, “scream-degree testing” emerged and began to establish a stable and convincing mechanism for project evaluation.

The so-called “scream-degree test” is to use a minimized version of the Demo containing the most core experience and gameplay of the product before the product is officially launched and starts to be developed vigorously. It collects indicators that can reflect the quality of the product’s core gameplay and future market potential, as well as player expectations, in the form of street interviews, and uses them for project rating and filtering.

Through this filtering, we can more effectively invest more manpower, capital, etc., into products that are more likely to succeed in the future, and focus on deploying in core strategic markets.

Everyone may have a question, why is this system called “scream-degree test” instead of “satisfaction test” or “fun test”?

The answer is simple. Based on the above, the purpose of this test is to select products that can thrive in the future market as much as possible during the project’s infancy. Compared with the “satisfaction” survey of players’ satisfaction with the game (which itself may have an evaluation standard), the “scream-degree” tests the players’ “excitement” for the game, whether the game is beyond the players’ expectations, and whether it can make the players scream “OMG, buy it”. This is what we need to achieve in the test.

If 2013 was a year of explosion for mobile games, then by 2018 and 2019, the red ocean market for domestic mobile games had also arrived. Without the demographic dividend, without the device dividend, and even without the policy dividend, the difficulty of obtaining game licenses is also increasing.

So, what are the major game manufacturers considering now? Going global. Using their own R&D strength and their vision and research on overseas markets, many domestic manufacturers have begun to continuously develop or directly distribute to overseas markets. In the process of this strategic adjustment, “scream-degree testing” is also an indispensable part. Because no one will think that the competition in foreign markets is much smaller than that in the domestic market.

You know, although the cost of acquiring users for Chinese mobile games is higher than that in Southeast Asia and other places, it is still much lower than that in relatively developed and mature countries in Europe, America, or East Asia. This also means that the cost of user acquisition after the game goes overseas is still a major barrier to entry. In terms of core gameplay, to win the favor of users, we also need to understand what they think about the game.

We recently had a new casual game project, planning to go overseas for distribution. Accordingly, according to the company’s internal project initiation process, we also planned this “scream-degree test for foreign players” together.

In order to improve the efficiency of the test and provide quick review and decision-making support for the decision-making level, we chose to conduct street intercepts of foreign players in Hangzhou.

The main locations considered include the bar streets where foreigners in Hangzhou mainly hang out, the international student teaching buildings and dormitories of various university campuses, the office buildings where foreign working people hang out, the major business districts in the city center, some famous scenic spots along the West Lake, and some personal resources, such as the game night that the user researcher participates in.

We combined the time when foreigners appear and tactically carried out “surprise attacks” at various locations. For example, in office buildings, we tried to conduct street intercepts at noon or dusk, which can effectively improve the efficiency of intercepts and the hit rate of players; for example, on university campuses, we mainly conducted intercepts in the afternoon when international students were leaving class, etc.

Of course, we will strictly control the demographic ratio, such as male and female players, working people and students, in the execution of the test in combination with the product positioning. In this way, the information we collect will be more convincing. The specific implementation method we adopted was to record with a mobile app and manually record the players’ specific verbal feedback and operational problems.

Overall, the scream-degree test for foreign players is much more difficult than for domestic players. In the later stage, we will also gradually develop scream-degree tests for foreigners in other cities, including some overseas cities. North America, Japan, and some countries in Southeast Asia are important markets for games to go overseas. Conducting tests in these local areas and collecting the most authentic feedback from players is also one of the strategies we will continue to implement.

entry.title: The Intertwined Relationships of Various Tools in Data Analysis
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

I. SQL

SQL is probably the most used tool in data analysis. It is easy to learn and widely applicable, making it a favorite among “SQL boys” and “SQL girls.” If there’s an anomaly in a certain metric, an “SQL baby” can handle it. Not only can SQL be used to obtain the change in metric data, but it can also analyze the reasons for the change. All of this relies on SQL. The following uses Hive SQL as an example to discuss the level of SQL proficiency required to meet basic business needs.

1. Basic Common Syntax is a Must

What are the basic common syntaxes? For example, various join types in query statements (inner join, left join, right join, full join, etc.), equality and inequality joins (on, where), group by, order by, count, sum, common window functions, etc.; as well as table creation (create table), table deletion statements (delete, drop), etc. These will not be elaborated on here.

2. Time Functions

(1) datediff: A function that calculates the interval between two dates

(2) from_unixtime() and unix_timestamp(): Conversion between 10-digit timestamps and time formats

from_unixtime()

unix_timestamp()

Note: 10-digit timestamps and 13-digit timestamps are different. The former is in seconds, the latter in milliseconds.

(3) to_date(): Extracts only the year, month, and day

(4) In addition, there are many other time functions, such as date_add, pmod, etc.

3. Functions for Secondary Processing of Fields

(1) concat: Connects multiple strings into one string.

Note: There are also related functions like concat_ws() (concat with separator), group_concat() (concatenates values from multiple rows into one string), etc.

(2) split: Splits a field

The above splits into a list. Marking the list index can select the corresponding field.

In addition, size, length, and explode are often used in conjunction with split. Among them, explode is commonly used for converting rows to columns after character splitting.

4. Regular Expressions

SQL statements can also be used with regular expressions as query conditions, which is very useful. This part is relatively detailed, so just look it up when you need it.

II. Python

Sometimes SQL is not enough to support the entire data analysis process. For example, when you need to compare and analyze samples, Python comes into play.

You need to master the use of common libraries in Python, such as NumPy, pandas, and SciPy. It is best to familiarize yourself with them by implementing basic statistical methods. In addition, learning to use lists, dictionaries, functions, and classes well will be very helpful for the flexible use of Python in daily life. For example, when the amount of data is very large and you need to iterate through row data, lists or dictionaries are much faster than pandas in processing data.

Based on different needs and scenarios, the use of Python varies. The following only shows the basic operation flow:

1. Data Reading and Character Processing

Flexible use of multiple reading methods

Method 1:

Method 2:

And using the to_csv function in the pandas library, etc.

Of course, everyone has their own habits, and good methods are those that are easy to use!

III. Collaboration Between Python and SQL

Hive’s custom functions support Transform and UDF. UDF is to package and upload Java code. If you don’t want to write Java code, you can use Transform, write a script, and process it through the script.

Among them, transform(field1, field2, field3) contains the three columns of data that need to be processed, which are the results directly queried by select. The above results are processed through the test.py file, and two columns of data, namely field4 and field5, are output. The python script test.py will receive the input data on stdin, process each row, and output the result to stdout.

IV. Others

1. Data Visualization: R, Excel

Most data visualizations can be completed using Excel charting. However, if you want to be more sophisticated and create violin plots, box plots, etc., you need to use R. You can learn about this on your own.

2. Linux, Bash, Hadoop

Many data analysis tasks now use big data platforms. If you still have energy after learning the above, you might as well take a look at Linux, Bash, and Hadoop. You don’t need to learn in depth at the beginning, but you can familiarize yourself with the basic operation statements, which will be more handy in future work.

entry.title: Introduction to Data Mining and Modeling in Data Analysis
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

This sharing focuses on data mining and modeling in data analysis:

After data exploration and data preprocessing, we obtain data that can be directly modeled. According to the mining objectives and data format, we can establish models such as classification and prediction, cluster analysis, association rules, time series patterns, and deviation detection.

Classification and Prediction

Classification and prediction are two main types of prediction problems. Classification mainly predicts class labels (discrete attributes), while prediction mainly establishes continuous value function models to predict the value of the dependent variable corresponding to a given independent variable.

1.1 Implementation Process

(1) Classification is to construct a classification model, input the attribute values of the sample, and output the corresponding category, mapping each sample to a predefined category.

The classification model is also established on the existing labeled data set, and the accuracy of the model on the existing samples can be easily calculated, which belongs to supervised learning.

(2) Prediction refers to establishing a functional model of interdependence between two or more variables, and then making predictions or controls.

(3) Implementation process

The first step of classification is the learning step, which establishes a classification model to obtain classification rules through inductive analysis of the training sample set. The second step is the classification step, which first uses a known test sample set to evaluate the accuracy of the classification rules and make predictions.

The first step of prediction is to establish a functional model of predictive attributes through the training set. The second step is to perform prediction or control after the model has passed the test.

1.2 Common Classification and Prediction Algorithms

① Regression analysis: Regression analysis is the most common statistical method to determine the quantitative relationship between predictive attributes (numerical) and other variables. It includes linear and nonlinear regression, Logistic regression, ridge regression, principal component regression, partial least squares regression, etc.

② Decision tree: Adopts a top-down recursive method, compares attribute values at internal nodes, and branches down from the node according to different attribute values. The leaf node finally obtained is the class of learning division.

③ Artificial neural network: An artificial neural network is an information processing system established by imitating the structure and function of the brain’s neural network. It is a model that represents the relationship between the input and output variables of the neural network.

④ Bayesian network: Bayesian network, also known as belief network, is an extension of the Bayes method and is currently one of the most effective theoretical models in the field of uncertain knowledge representation and reasoning.

⑤ Support vector machine: Support vector machine is an algorithm that converts low-dimensional nonlinear separability into high-dimensional linear separability through a certain nonlinear mapping, and performs linear analysis in high-dimensional space.

1.3 Regression Analysis

(1) Research scope of regression analysis

Problem Type Description Example
Simple Linear Regression Relationship between one independent variable and one dependent variable. Predicting sales based on advertising spending.
Multiple Linear Regression Relationship between multiple independent variables and one dependent variable. Predicting house prices based on size, location, and number of bedrooms.
Nonlinear Regression Relationship where the dependent variable is not a linear function of the independent variables. Predicting population growth based on time.
Logistic Regression Predicting the probability of a binary outcome (0 or 1). Predicting whether a customer will click on an ad (yes/no).

(2) Commonly Used Models for Regression Analysis

Model Formula Description
Linear Regression Y = β0 + β1X + ε Predicts a continuous dependent variable Y based on a single independent variable X.
Multiple Linear Regression Y = β0 + β1X1 + β2X2 + ... + βnXn + ε Predicts a continuous dependent variable Y based on multiple independent variables X1, X2, ... Xn.
Logistic Regression log(p/(1-p)) = β0 + β1X Predicts the probability p of a binary outcome (0 or 1) based on a single independent variable X.

Note: Linear regression models are usually relatively simple regression models, but the independent and dependent variables can have some form of curved relationship, requiring the creation of a nonlinear regression model.

① Logistic Regression Analysis Introduction

Logistic function: In the logistic regression model, the dependent variable has only two values, 0 and 1. The logarithm is taken after taking the event ratio, and the function is obtained:

log(p/(1-p)) = β0 + β1X1 + β2X2 +...+ βpXp

② Modeling Steps: First, set indicator variables according to the analysis objectives, then collect data and screen features; list the regression equation and estimate the regression coefficients in the model; perform model testing, including accuracy, confusion matrix, ROC curve, and KS value; model application, input the value of the independent variable, you can get the value of the predicted variable, or control the value of the independent variable according to the value of the predicted variable.

For example: Logistic regression modeling based on the data of a certain bank in reducing loan delinquency rate.

Use scikit-learn to perform logistic regression analysis on the data. First, perform feature selection. For example, simply use the F-test value to give the F value and P value of each feature, and select the one with a larger F value or a smaller P value. Secondly, there are recursive feature elimination and stability selection. Here, the random logistic regression in the stability selection method is used. First, feature selection, and then use the selected features to establish a logistic regression model and output the average accuracy rate.

The example code is as follows:

After running, the results are as follows:

Effective features are: salary, address, debt ratio, credit card debt

From the results, it can be seen that the random logistic regression is used to eliminate variables, and x2, x8, x1, and x5 are eliminated respectively. The final model has four columns left, where the random threshold is 0.25, and this program uses 0.5.

Logistic regression is essentially a linear model. The model validity test here is essentially a linear test, that is, the selected variables have a strong linear correlation with the result, and the selected ones are not necessarily irrelevant, and may be non-linearly related.

For the selection of non-linearly related variables, there are decision trees, neural networks, etc., which is another field of knowledge.

entry.title: A New Beginning for Motion-Sensing Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

The Beginning of Motion-Sensing Games

Motion-sensing games are not a new thing. As early as the beginning of video games, arcade games were the biggest promoters of motion-sensing games. Experiencing games with your body, the meaning of motion-sensing games is as literal as it sounds.

If you were to ask what the first well-known motion-sensing game was, Nintendo’s “Duck Hunt” on the NES sold 30 million copies. In that era of scarce game performance, without exquisite graphics and a vivid virtual world, motion-sensing elements could be said to be the most obvious way to enhance the gaming experience.

Motion-sensing games rely heavily on specialized, unique input devices. This requires players who want to experience motion-sensing games to purchase expensive equipment to play, and these devices cannot support other games. From the very beginning of motion-sensing games, its advantages and disadvantages have been exposed. People cannot play motion-sensing games for a long time, nor can they play them lying in bed. The interaction form of motion-sensing games brings fun to players, but also brings experience problems: inaccurate recognition, discomfort caused by physical exertion, and space limitations.

The history of motion-sensing games is a game of trade-offs, how to make the interactive experience more interesting, and also make the input hardware more versatile. Or rather, the key problem that motion-sensing games need to solve is to find the best input device for controlling body movements. Personal computers require a mouse and keyboard, TV consoles cannot do without gamepads, and mobile phone interaction is based on touch screens. So what should the interactive device for motion-sensing games be?

Expectation and Disappointment

Then, time came to 2006, and Nintendo, which once used a laser gun to hunt ducks, came with its “big baby” again. Nintendo’s internal code name was “The Revolution”, and the TV console Wii, based on the concept of motion sensing and home entertainment mode, was released, with sales of 20 million units in the first year. As of December 2018, the cumulative global sales of Wii reached 101.63 million units, and 920.66 million copies of games.

This console was conceived after the launch of GAMECUBE in 2001.

Nintendo game designer Shigeru Miyamoto said in an interview that the plan at the time focused on a new way of interaction between the game console and the player.

The consensus at the time was that hardware capabilities were not the entirety of a game console. The market cannot allow too many high-performance consoles to coexist at the same time. Just like if there were only ferocious carnivorous dinosaurs on the earth, they might kill each other, eventually leading to their own extinction.”

Wii was very successful in that era, and it was from Wii that motion-sensing games entered a climax. Microsoft and Sony have successively launched their own motion-sensing kits. It seems that consoles without motion-sensing functions cannot be called good consoles. But each company also has its own views on how motion sensing should be implemented.

Is the Motion Controller the Future?

The motion-sensing interaction mode proposed by Nintendo relies on its motion-sensing controller. This is also a major interactive mode of motion sensing in the following ten years. The main difference of the motion-sensing controller lies in the use of gravity sensing and accelerometer sensors, so that the controller can sense the player’s waving action, as well as the approximate position and movement direction.

The advantage of the motion controller is that it is less affected by the environment. As long as the player holds it in his hand, he can operate freely. Secondly, with different device extensions, the shape and holding posture can be switched according to different game types, simulating the player’s physical touch in the game to a greater extent. But its disadvantages are also obvious. It cannot capture the player’s complete motion information. For example, in the “Just Dance” game, although the game requires corresponding actions to score, many times you can get a high score as long as you wave the controller according to the rhythm. At the same time, the gamepad also limits the number of operation inputs. In the simulated driving game, players can only control the direction, and the speed control can only be controlled by the computer. This greatly affects the original gameplay of the game. Because of this, there has never been a truly hardcore work in motion-sensing games.

Motion Capture and Gesture Interaction

In 2010, in order to catch up with the sales of Nintendo’s Wii console, Microsoft finally brought their motion-sensing device-Kinect. Kinect adopts a completely different interactive approach. It does not rely on any physical devices. Players only need to stand in front of the camera to capture the player’s complete body movements. Even on Kinect 2.0, the accuracy and effect of this capture are very good. In addition to motion capture, Kinect’s dot-matrix microphone also supports voice control. The high-tech Kinect created a world record for sales at the time, and even now it still is.

On Kinect, players control the cursor by the position of their hands, and holding is a click operation. They can also wave to do page turning and return operations. Gesture operation has always been considered a very cool interactive method by players, but many interactive studies show that the learning cost of gesture interaction is very high, and everyone’s understanding of gestures lacks basic consensus and habits. Secondly, gesture interaction itself cannot be precise, and it will also bring fatigue to players.

In the end, there were only a handful of successful games on Kinect. The relatively complete “Star Wars” can be said to be a work that was more recognized and accepted by players in terms of motion-sensing game operation at that time, and the game was no longer just a casual game. When the characters in the game make corresponding actions according to the player’s gestures, the player’s “scream level” is still very high.

The biggest difference from the Wii motion controller is that players can use their hands and feet together in the game and make more coherent and complex actions, such as kicking and jumping in fighting games. When designing these interactive actions, Microsoft also tried to minimize the physical exertion of players. For example, when controlling the character to move left and right, players do not need to actually make these actions, just slightly shifting their body can trigger it.

However, the biggest problem with motion interaction is also revealed, misoperation. This is also another drawback of gesture interaction. Users are no longer just operating in a single dimension, but in three-dimensional space, which makes the trigger conditions of actions themselves difficult to define and control. For example, now there is an operation called waving your arm. It seems like a simple command, but the actions that everyone may make are different; the distance, amplitude, and direction of the wave are uncontrollable. This makes the trigger conditions for gesture interaction very difficult to define, and the probability of misoperation and operation failure is very high.

Players’ Coolness

Therefore, after experiencing the wave of motion-sensing games in 2010, the still immature motion-sensing interaction gradually faded out of the vision of the console platform. The lack of motion-sensing game content, insufficient hardware capabilities, and the difficulty of sustaining interactive methods. When players have a taste, they are more disappointed.

New Exploration

Of course, motion-sensing games were not abandoned after failure. On the contrary, it has always been the direction of future games. In the process of the gradual development of VR and AR, motion-sensing interaction has become a part of virtual reality technology, and even the only feasible form of interaction. On mobile games, motion-sensing technology will also be used as an auxiliary operation method, such as the “gravity-sensing aiming method” in PUBG Mobile. But motion-sensing games, as an independent and complete game system, are rarely mentioned again, until Nintendo brings its “big baby” again.

Nintendo Labo

Nintendo has never given up on the exploration of motion-sensing games from beginning to end. At the beginning of the design of the new generation of mobile handheld Switch, the controller was designed as a motion-sensing controller, and an IR infrared camera was added. Although I don’t know the purpose of adding the infrared camera, in the later design of Labo, this camera can be said to provide new ideas for the entire motion-sensing game interaction.

The Labo project is Nintendo’s another exploration of motion-sensing games. Although in the first version of Labo, the switch becomes a toy like a fishing rod, piano, etc., it seems that it cannot well reflect the concept of “motion-sensing games” (still lacking the necessary gameplay), but its working principle and design ideas have provided an interactive prototype for future series of products.

Separate Controllers Work Simultaneously

The Switch has two independent game controllers. This design is to make it easier for you to operate with friends in multiplayer games. At the beginning of the design of Labo, the producer always hoped to make a breakthrough in operation, so that this set of interactions can give full play to the advantages of the Switch controller, instead of making settings similar to others.

Therefore, I have been thinking about the controller and its special features, and finally I realized that it is the sensor-there are sensors in both the left and right controllers. If we create while connecting two Joy-Cons at the same time, we can use the differences between their sensors to do various new things… This is the real beginning. ——Mr. Sakaguchi (Head of Labo Software)

This design concept runs through the entire Labo product, and also provides new possibilities for the design of motion-sensing devices. Usually, what people understand most easily is that two controllers are used separately, such as my right hand holding a “sword” and my left hand holding a “shield”, then they are a superimposed control relationship. But in the design of the “fishing rod”, by fixing the right Joy-Con to the handle of the fishing rod, and then fixing the left Joy-Con to the fishing reel, you can use the position of the handle to measure the rotation of the fishing reel. Or to put it another way, if you only use the Joy-Con on the left, you will not be able to distinguish the movement of the fishing rod from the movement of the fishing reel. However, if you then add the Joy-Con on the right and compare its sensor with the difference of the Joy-Con on the left, you can make it work normally. As they delved deeper into all the experiments, the Labo production team began to regard Joy-Con as a sensor bundle, which gave them a real opportunity to release the consideration of various possibilities.

Infrared Camera in a Cardboard Box

In addition to the collaborative work of the controller bundle, another interesting mechanism is the use of an infrared camera. In traditional motion-sensing games, infrared depth sensors are placed in space to capture the player’s movements. In the Labo project, this infrared camera is used in a closed box. The infrared camera no longer directly captures the player’s motion information, but captures the position and size changes of the “reflective strip” in the box due to the player’s operation.

The picture above shows the design of the control device of the Labo No. 2 project robot. Players only need to insert the controller with the infrared camera into the hole in the box, and the camera will capture the position changes of the four reflective strips in the box in the game. And the player ties the four ropes linked to the reflective strip to the feet and hands, and can control the movement of the robot in the game by pulling the rope during exercise.

This design brings many benefits. First, the amount of input information has increased, and it is no longer limited by hardware. The camera can collect multiple different position variables at the same time, and each variable corresponds to the player’s different gesture operations. Second, gesture input information becomes controllable; as mentioned above, the problem with interactions like Kinect that rely on motion capture is that players can make many unpredictable gestures, which can lead to misoperation and operation failure; while the movement of the “reflective strip” in the box is very fixed and controllable, they can correspond very well to the fixed actions in the game, and are accurate enough. For example, in this robot game, there are only a few attack actions. Capturing the player’s extra actions (such as twisting the waist) will only increase the complexity of the trigger of the motion interaction. Converting the player’s effective actions into predictable input parameters and inputting them into the game control is the core highlight of Labo’s motion-sensing design.

Of course, the use of this camera also brings another benefit, which is to reduce electronification. In addition to the original Joy-con controller, the Labo controller no longer has other electronic sensors, which solves the cost problem well. This problem may be a难题 that has existed since the beginning of motion-sensing games, high cost and low versatility.

Labo Series and Ring Fit Adventure

The Labo series launched the third game of the series in the first half of this year. The biggest difference between the third part and the previous ones is that it is no longer a series of mini-games. This time it is a complete exploration game, and even added online and battle parts. At the same time, Labo’s motion-sensing design concept is also constantly exerting its advantages. The controller is like the key switch of the device, and players can quickly and freely switch between various motion-sensing devices; motion-sensing operations are no longer vague and inefficient, and players can very accurately control complex motion-sensing devices, and experience the fun of control at the same time.



Not only that, the recently released “Ring Fit Adventure“ has once again made motion-sensing games a big hit. The biggest change of “Ring Fit Adventure“ compared with traditional fitness games is the leap in its gameplay. Secondly, the interaction mode based on the fitness ring is also very interesting.

It seems that the second spring of motion-sensing games is coming.

Epilogue

Nintendo has always been a game company that I admire very much. When motion-sensing games are not favored by the market, they still insist on constantly trying motion-sensing creative elements in their own games. From Nintendo games such as The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild, Super Mario Odyssey, and Mario Party, we can experience those wonderful experiences that have disappeared. Of course, until now we dare not say whether motion-sensing games can really try to impact hardcore games, but it must be able to become the interactive mode of future immersive games. At the same time, we have also seen a clearer direction from the development of motion-sensing technology.

Motion-sensing games do not necessarily have to completely simulate human movement. Players can interact with the game through motion-sensing devices to complete more exciting operations. This is the goal of motion sensing. In addition, motion-sensing devices also need to have stronger scalability and be able to freely adapt to input information in different operating modes. Just like the hardware product structure designed by engineers in the past, the motion-sensing device is the “button” that guides the player to make interactive actions. In future motion-sensing games, whether this device is virtual or concrete, it will carry a more real and rich experience for players.

A new beginning for motion-sensing games, a new world.

entry.title: Game Community Research (1): TapTap
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

A game community is an online community composed of a group of game-loving netizens who specifically discuss and interact with games and game-related content.

Similar to other online communities, game communities have the following characteristics:

  • Certain entry barriers: These game communities must be entered by players who have a certain understanding of the game and can accept specific interaction rules.
  • Specific communication and interaction spaces: Unlike more comprehensive content platforms (such as Weibo and Tieba), these communities often have their own dedicated apps, forums, and other interaction spaces.
  • Content production around specific themes: Game communities focus on games for content production and operation, and the content produced is highly specialized.
