For us game practitioners, the game community is a very important platform for game marketing and interaction with players, because it allows us to better understand the game content preferences and game experience ideas of higher-level players. In this series of studies, we will introduce several typical game communities and their differentiated user characteristics and service positioning characteristics.

First up: TapTap

TapTap is a game community and third-party game download application platform developed by ewan (Shanghai) Network Technology Co., Ltd. On this platform, users can easily discover games, purchase and install games, and can also publish game reviews and discuss games with other enthusiasts.

As a game community, TapTap has the following service features:

  • Clear access mechanism: By setting up an “Etiquette Exam” in the user registration process, TapTap clarifies a relatively clear user access mechanism - users need to understand and recognize certain community interaction rules, and master basic game common sense to enter the TapTap community.

  • Emphasis on shaping the interactive atmosphere of community members: By setting up interactive review replies, likes, and thematic forums, TapTap emphasizes creating an atmosphere of communication between players and players, and between players and game developers.

  • Featuring high-quality game review content: Compared with game reviews in mobile app stores, game reviews on TapTap are generally of higher quality. Even if players give a low-star rating, they will give detailed reasons. These quality-guaranteed game reviews provide game developers with many suggestions for game optimization.

The above are the service features of TapTap as a professional game community.

User Portrait

Some people may ask, what are the characteristics of TapTap users? Do they have preferences for specific game categories and gameplay? By querying Baidu Index (time window: September 29, 2019 - October 28, 2019) and referring to other industry reports, we have obtained the following TapTap user portrait information:

(1) User gender distribution: TapTap has significantly more male users than female users.

(2) User age distribution: Among TapTap users, users aged 24 and below account for 78.6%.

(3) User geographical distribution: Mostly distributed in coastal areas, but also covers some central and western provinces. If calculated according to the frequency of users searching for TapTap in various places, users in coastal provinces (such as Guangdong and Jiangsu) rank higher, but it can be seen that the search popularity of TapTap is higher in some central and western provinces (such as Henan, Sichuan, Hubei, etc.).

(4) User game preference: Relatively prefer independent games. Compared with popular game categories, users have higher evaluations of games with innovative gameplay. Based on a study of the Top 50 games on the TapTap reputation list in the first half of 2019 conducted by 36Kr website in May 2019, we can find that most of the games with good reputation (rating 8.0 and above) on TapTap are independent games, including independent studios and independent projects released by major manufacturers.

Based on this list, we can also find the following trends: popular categories in the mobile game market, such as MOBA, MMO, and battle royale, have been somewhat snubbed on the TapTap platform due to the large number of similar competing products and the convergence of gameplay. Games in categories such as puzzle, story, casual, and hardcore action are more likely to be praised by TapTap users because their audience is relatively small and there is more room for gameplay innovation.

Summary

From the above analysis, we make the following summary:

  • TapTap as a game community: has certain entry barriers, is highly specialized, and maintains a relatively neutral image among players and game manufacturers;
  • As a member of such a game community: young, with rich game experience, and relatively niche game preferences.

So do other game communities have similar user and service characteristics to TapTap?

Reference Sources:

  1. TapTap Product Experience Analysis Report (March 8, 2019)

    https://www.jianshu.com/p/6d005f656446

  2. We sorted out 50 high-scoring games on TapTap in 2019 and found some new trends (May 17, 2019)

    https://36kr.com/p/5205474

  3. Baidu Index: TapTap related pages

    http://index.baidu.com/v2/main/index.html#/trend/taptap?words=taptap

entry.title: [UI Sharing] Three Basic Design Principles for Gesture Interaction in Mobile Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Gesture interaction generally appears on the touch screens of various mobile devices. Mobile devices have become one of the important terminals for people to participate in entertainment games, and gesture interaction design for touch screens has become an important design topic in the field of game design.

How to design gesture interaction with higher usability? In practice, we have summarized three important design principles for gesture interaction.

  1. Gesture interaction needs to be simple and direct. Simple gesture operation design allows players of different ages to learn at a glance, thereby stimulating players’ game fun. For example, Fruit Ninja (2010) and Angry Birds (2011) can be completely controlled with just one finger throughout the entire game process.

 

 

  1. Gesture interaction needs to conform to common sense in life. The gesture design of the game should be as simple as possible and conform to the player’s habits in the same context in real life, and the metaphorical gestures should follow the universally recognized principles.

The interactive design of gestures in the Florence game fully reflects the respect for the cognition and experience gained by players in real life when designing gesture interactions, and uses them in gesture interaction design to reduce the cost of guiding players to learn interactive behaviors.

 

The method of turning off the alarm clock is to press the alarm clock; the method of brushing teeth is to drag the toothbrush left and right, up and down; liking and refreshing social software are the same as in daily life. In Florence, players can complete these interactive behaviors by instinct without any strong guidance or text introduction.

Combined gesture interaction requires effective guidance

Different from touch interaction, gestures such as dragging, pinching, long-pressing, or wiping belong to combined gesture interaction. Combined gesture interaction can often bring a more immersive interactive experience than a mouse or controller, that is closer to real life. For example, in the Apple system, operations such as switching screens and returning to the desktop use gestures with the touchpad.

 

 

Players and users will feel that their fingers can control the screen as they wish. However, a user who has never been exposed to these interactive behaviors needs to read these gesture tutorials in detail to understand and use these interactive behaviors.

Combined gestures in games also require detailed teaching and guidance, otherwise some players will not be able to discover these interactions we provide to players, or after accidentally discovering these operations, they will not be able to use these interactive operations correctly again.

Gesture interaction requires precise control

Touch gestures are less accurate than a mouse in terms of operation. It is difficult for players to click very small buttons or drag controls to areas with pixel-level accuracy. Therefore, when designing gesture operations, we need to pay attention to the position, size, and number of buttons, as well as confirmation and undo operations.

 

Epilogue

After completing an interaction design draft containing gesture interaction, we must verify its usability. The commonly used method is to implement a prototype based on the minimum viable solution of the design on a mobile terminal, and verify the rationality of the design through practice, research, and walkthroughs.

entry.title: Introduction to the KANO Model for Requirement Analysis
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

KANO is a method commonly used in the early stages of product development. I feel it is still worth taking some time to understand. Today, I will briefly introduce this method.

Background of KANO

Inspired by the two-factor theory of behavioral scientist Herzberg, Professor Noriaki Kano of the Tokyo University of Science, and his colleagues, first introduced the criteria of satisfaction and dissatisfaction into the field of quality management in the 1970s. They used a two-dimensional model to understand quality and proposed the famous Kano model. It is a tool for classifying and prioritizing user needs, based on analyzing the impact of user needs on user satisfaction, reflecting the non-linear relationship between product performance and user satisfaction.

Supplementary Knowledge Card: Two-Factor Theory

Also known as the motivation-hygiene theory, it was proposed by American psychologist Herzberg in 1959. It mainly divides enterprises into two key factors, namely: motivating factors and hygiene factors. Motivating factors are factors that can make people feel satisfied and motivated (achievement, appreciation, challenge, responsibility…), and hygiene factors are factors that are prone to opinions and negative behaviors (salary, working conditions, company policies, management…).

When is KANO Suitable for Game User Research?

The product development cycle can be simply divided into these 5 periods. After the concept is confirmed and before the core gameplay MVP is completed, the product will go through a period of exploration. During this period, the product will sort out the main functions of the game and design the highlights and features of the game. At this time, some products will have a question: What do my users really want? Which functions/features are more appealing to them?

When the product meets the first two conditions, the KANO requirement analysis can be used to help them solve this problem:

  1. The product has a relatively clear target user (who I want to research).
  2. The product has a preliminary design direction, brainstorming many special features or basic functional systems (what kind of game I want to make).
  3. The product is a bit distant from their target users (non-essential condition: I don’t quite know what my users want).

The first two are actually easy to understand. Why do I mention the third? Because the main design team of some products is deeply rooted in the soil of their target users, and the information they know can represent the views of most of their users.

At this time, this kind of conceptual function research is not so significant for product reference. It is more necessary to focus on understanding the implementation standards of this feature, that is, how to express it and how it will better resonate with users. This is more common in some art material research, or combat method research.

Introduction to the KANO Model

KANO divides needs into 5 types through the user’s attitude towards two situations – “having this function” and “not having this function”:

  • Attractive Needs: Needs that surprise users. If this need is not provided, it will not reduce user satisfaction. Once the attractive need is provided, user satisfaction will increase significantly.
  • Expected Needs (One-Dimensional Needs): If this function is provided, customer satisfaction increases. If this function is not provided, customer satisfaction will decrease.
  • Must-be Needs (Basic Needs): These are the basic requirements of the product. If this need is not met, user satisfaction will decrease significantly. However, no matter how much the must-be needs are improved, customer satisfaction will have an upper limit.
  • Indifferent Needs: Whether this function is provided or not, user satisfaction will not change. Users do not care whether this function exists or not. This kind of thankless need should be avoided as much as possible.
  • Reverse Needs: Users do not have this need at all. After providing it, user satisfaction will decrease. Improvement can greatly reduce dissatisfaction.

One important function of KANO is to help products prioritize players’ needs:

KANO’s ranking of requirements: Must-be > Expected > Attractive > Indifferent

Games are not a very functional product. Users are unlikely to choose you because your basic functions are good, “for example, your game is particularly smooth”. They are more likely to choose you because of some differentiated features. In this case, letting the product know which content can be differentiated will be particularly important.

Use of the KANO Questionnaire

The original KANO questionnaire is mainly divided into two parts, requiring players to express their attitude from “very positive - neutral - very negative”.

KANO’s intention is to summarize the significance of the need for a single user by classifying the user’s attitude.

Note: The initial score is that one sample has a need classification for one function.

(A-Attractive needs, O-Expected needs, M-Must-be needs, Q-Questionable, R-Reverse needs, I-Indifferent needs)

The corresponding attractive, expected, must-be, reverse, and indifferent here are those that appeared in the previous quadrant diagram, so I won’t repeat them. What you need to pay attention to is your Q. If a need appears as Q, it is likely that there is a problem with this sample data, it may be an input error, or it may be a random fill-in. You need to consider deleting all the results of the sample. If there are many Qs, you should carefully review the question stem to see if there is an error in your question stem.

At this point, everyone will find that the results obtained by using KANO are based on the summary of the attitude of a single sample. Because each sample may have a different attitude towards the same function, coefficients/algorithms need to be introduced for comprehensive evaluation.

In the Better and Worse system, R and Q are not included, so reverse needs need to be counted separately.

PS: When a need is rated as a reverse need a lot, this need needs to be excluded.

PPS: Under normal circumstances, reverse needs in games rarely appear. If they do appear, you need to pay attention to whether there is a problem with the description of the need.

Through score conversion, you will finally get a scatter plot.

No matter which method you use, you will eventually get a scatter plot. The KANO model does not give a fixed quadrant division standard. You need to set a dividing line to help you classify needs. This indicator line is the horizontal and vertical axes of the quadrant diagram.

Here are two division methods that I have used or seen:

Method 1: Divide according to the distribution of current demand scores

This method has a stronger directivity for the ranking of needs (internal relative value); the directivity for the category attribution of need classification will be weaker.

Method 2: Divide according to the meaning of the attitude represented by the score

① 0.5 Better/Worse coefficient – at least 50% of people think it would be better to have this/would be disappointed not to have this

② Average attitude score of 2 points – it would be okay to have this function (hope to have it, but it won’t add points)/reluctantly accept not having this function (hope to have it, but not having it won’t deduct points)

This method has a clearer attitude towards the category attribution of need classification; but it is relatively strict. In non-essential products such as game products, because players have large differences in the fun they pursue in the game, the attitude will not be very concentrated. This method is still applicable when the differences within the group are small during the research, such as all of them being the same type of players (such as strong PVP players in a strong operation MMO).

Practical Operation Process of KANO Questionnaire

As a questionnaire, KANO can be used for research alone, or it can be combined with in-depth interviews or focus groups. There are various ways to use it. The questionnaire itself has roughly these steps:

  1. Requirement pool collection & item confirmation.
  2. Questionnaire design (determining question items and options, and confirming the presentation format)
  3. Questionnaire testing
  4. Data collection (distribution + recycling)
  5. Data cleaning (exclusion of invalid questionnaires)
  6. Data analysis.

There are several points that must be paid attention to in actual operation:

① As a questionnaire, the text carries most of the product’s intentions, so it is necessary to ensure that the question stem can be understood by users, and the content understood by users is consistent with the original intention of the product. It is recommended to do at least two rounds of text material testing (testing to find problems to modification is one round).

② The filling method of KANO is relatively complicated, and users with different abilities have different understanding abilities. It is best to administer the test in person (the tester needs to understand the original intention of the product for the description of each item in the document), which can better explain the logic of the questionnaire and provide immediate interpretation help.

This article ends here. Thank you for reading. I hope it can be helpful to everyone in using the KANO tool~

entry.title: Seven Recommendations for Creating Game UI
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

The game user interface is the space where the user interacts with the machine.

The game user interface not only includes the GUI (graphical user interface) on the screen, but also includes touch controls on mobile phones, for instance - all controls that interact with the user in one or more ways. This is what we call interaction.

In the following text, we will discuss a lot about the graphical interface, but please keep in mind that it is part of a larger scope: the GUI is always affected by the interaction method, and it also affects the interaction.

1. Designing UI is About Space and White Space

Controls bring structure, hierarchy, and clarity, giving the GUI a sense of breathing room.

The main task of design is to deal with screen space: when and where should players master what information on the interface?

We can use two design methods:

  1. Carefully add the information you think is necessary on the interface until the interface is almost arranged.
  2. Put all the information you think may need to be placed on the interface, and then remove some information you think is not important until the white space of the interface reaches a comfortable value, and leaves enough important information for the user.

Space is not just the blank part between two main elements, but also includes the white space between letters, the pixels between images… When it comes to space, everything is important.

Which of the above two design methods is used depends on the project, intention, and designer. When designing, keep an open mind and try new methods. (One note: Due to the prevalence of minimalism, many UI designers are now starting to work in this direction, but over-focusing on minimalism may lead to a lack of important game information. Minimalism is not as easy as it seems. In many cases, planners want to express a lot of information. Minimalism is not about deleting information, but about presenting more information with less content, which increases the requirements for designers.)

2. Art Style and Immersion

The UI style being consistent with the game’s art direction will greatly enhance the overall immersion of the game. However, if you don’t have enough resources or ability, please don’t try to make a very special GUI to fit your art style. Designing a mature flat UI is better than a strange “I think this GUI is very suitable for my art style”.

Flat design is like “black”, it is easy to get results.

 

Dishonored, stylized user interface

 

Besiege, more flattened design

3. Form Follows Function

When designing, consider using color, shape, and other attributes to illustrate how to use elements. This design method is called “affordances”.

1. Shape

The shape, color, and size of UI elements really illustrate their position and purpose here.

 

As shown above, the shadow of each button provides a lot of information to the user. The light comes from the top, and the shadow will cause depth and possible movement when pressed.

2. Size

We can use “Fitts’s Law” to scale the button to a degree proportional to its use.

But making information/space huge is not the solution to everything. Too large is often ugly and feels inappropriate. Aesthetics are also very important. The more beautiful the appearance, the more it can bring players satisfaction and pleasure. We believe that this will also affect key performance indicators.

The proportion between elements is also very important. The following figure is a design sketch of a binary options game. The proportion of its interface elements is very poorly designed, which is why its bottom button appears completely unsuitable for the interface.

 

3. Color

Compared to shape, color should better illustrate “what this space should do”. You can ask yourself, what do you want to convey to the player with this control, is it good or bad? This should influence your color choices.

Color also depends on culture. For example, in foreign countries, red will be used for health-related content, as well as negative, warning, and feedback. But in China, red is mostly a very positive color, which means good luck and joy.

When designing international games, you need to consider this, but we don’t need to be too careful. In a globalized environment, the meaning of color is not so clearly demarcated. For example, many games in China now also use red as a warning, such as a strong red feedback when the health is low. The influence of culture on color will only slightly affect some special feedback and UI elements.

In addition, when designing, we should try to design in black and white as much as possible. This is a good technique to help you quickly obtain prominent information and identify key issues. In addition, about 10% of people can only see a limited range of colors, so we should also pay attention to how to match colors so that these people will not be confused because they cannot see the color difference.

4. Consistency

The UI needs to be consistent with player operating behavior, and so do color and space.

This is a rule of thumb to help you easily know how many colors should be in the UI palette:

 

  1. Choose a dark/black and a slightly lighter color
  2. Choose a bright/white and a slightly darker color
  3. Choose a red color as a warning and negative feedback color
  4. Choose green as the verification and positive feedback color
  5. You can choose another “key” color as the color of all other content. This color needs to be neutral and not particularly positive or negative.

Of course, you can choose more or fewer colors according to the specific situation of the project. Choosing the right color is another matter. Trying to make the colors match well is also important.

If you need to use the same color to make changes, I suggest you only change the “saturation” and “brightness” of the color, as shown above.

We also need to pay attention to the number of fonts and font sizes used. We will only add fonts or sizes when it makes sense, and combine them with the creation of interactive levels for a purpose.

5. Usability, Efficiency and Satisfaction

The player is never wrong.

Repeat, the player is never wrong.

If someone misuses your design, it means that your design is misleading, and the problem lies with the designer. Users don’t really misuse it, they just use it according to what they think is the correct understanding.

Of course, we can’t meet everyone’s needs, so we need to focus more on the core audience. Sometimes making a tutorial can greatly help us improve usability.

In general, this is a very ideal point of view, and we should always strive for an experience without explanation and friction.

6. The Art of Animation

Movement should be natural.

Animation is a bonus item for the interface, which can make our design change from “very good” to “wow”. Slight animation transitions can convey a lot of information and feelings in a very intuitive way.

It can also help the player’s brain transition from one state to another, and make the whole experience smoother. We believe that the best animation is one that players are not aware of, but is still useful to them.

Just like level design: the best designers are invisible, and players are unaware.

Sadly, this makes it very difficult to test animations and truly define whether they are correct.

The movement should last between 200 milliseconds and 400 milliseconds. Any animation over 500 milliseconds may be felt to be too slow.

Below we use Robert Penner’s easing animation example to explore the real skills:

 

Most of the time, we will want to use cubic motion to make the animation feel natural. Depending on the game world, we will generally use “elastic”, “bounce” or “back” to get a cartoon-like feeling.

(Another indication about motion: elements moving within the screen range should accelerate and decelerate, elements moving out of the screen should only accelerate, and elements entering the screen should only decelerate.)

7. Frictionless

 

Google’s undo button, designed with user fault tolerance in mind.

All of the above can be summarized in one word: frictionless - the user interface should provide players with the information they need at the right time and allow them to control it in the way they like.

This is largely ideological, but perhaps an AI-driven future can better achieve this. For now, our design goal is “fewer errors”. We can’t make a completely correct UI interface, which contains too many factors.

In the final analysis, UI design will be designed according to its purpose and according to what the player’s brain is familiar with.

References:

UI design sharing of IronEqual independent game studio

entry.title: How User Researchers and UEs Respond to Stakeholder Questions (1)
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

In the previous issue, we shared the questions and concerns that stakeholders might have in the early stages. This issue mainly shares the questions that stakeholders may have during the user research process.

PS: There is a link to the previous issue’s content at the end of the
date: Not present in provided HTML).
categories:
- NetEase UX
- 

Image source: pexels

Q1: Why are there so few users? Will the test results be inaccurate?

According to Nielsen’s classic theory on usability testing, 5 users can find more than 80% of usability problems. The differences between individuals are not as big as we think. For example, core usability problems can often be tested by just a few people. We invite more users to the lab, and we can indeed find more problems. But the more problems found are generally minor problems. The core problems will be repeatedly mentioned by different users.

Q2：Don’t you already have a lot of channel feedback and experience in this area?

We are not trying to replace your existing experience and information, but to supplement, improve, and iterate on this experiential information. The market and users are constantly changing, and we will adopt more methods to collect different information. For example, post-00s are now receiving market attention, and what post-00s think is definitely different from post-90s.

Q3: Will you promise players/users anything?

We will not make any promises in the process of contacting users. Moreover, when collecting player suggestions, we will also follow standard procedures to tell players that we will truthfully convey the player’s suggestions, but whether to implement them requires comprehensive consideration. User researchers have undergone rigorous standardized process training and are very cautious in contacting users.

Q4: I’m worried that the content will be leaked. What are your measures?

We will have users sign a confidentiality agreement and screen users. First, the test part will have detailed communication with the stakeholders. If the IP is confidential, then we will avoid mentioning IP-related issues during the testing process. Second, every user who participates in the test needs to sign a confidentiality agreement. We have a very standardized confidentiality agreement. In addition, user researchers will actively screen some users to avoid testing industry practitioners or media personnel. Finally, when user researchers deal with confidential projects, they will not handle them publicly, but by authorized members.

entry.title: Python Learning Guide - Iterables, Iterators, and Generators
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Generators and iterators are unavoidable topics in Python learning, and they are also frequently used in actual coding.

First, let’s clarify the relationship between several key concepts:

Iterable Iterator Generator
Object implementing __iter__ and __next__ A special type of iterator
Can traverse elements Can traverse elements using next() or for
Implemented using generator functions or expressions

Iterable (iterable)

Objects that can be directly used in a for loop are collectively called iterables (Iterable), or in other words, objects that implement the __iter__ method. An iterator must be an iterable.

You can directly use the isinstance() function to check if an object is iterable.

Lists, tuples, etc., are all iterables. You can call the __iter__ method of the iterable using the iter() function to obtain the corresponding iterator, and then use next() to iterate through it.

List Comprehension (List Comprehension)

List comprehension, or list generation, are different terms for the same concept. Essentially, they create a new list directly using [].

It’s important to distinguish between generator expressions and list comprehensions:

List comprehensions also leverage Python’s iteration features, using [] to enclose a for clause. They are primarily used for creating new lists, and are efficient and highly readable. However, the returned data is entirely stored in memory.

Relationship between Generators and Iterators:

An iterator is a broader concept. A generator is a special type of iterator, but the reverse is not true.

Generators and iterators are similar in that they can both be used to access elements through a for loop and are both iterables.

Iterator (iterator)

An iterator is an object that implements both the __iter__ and __next__ methods, capable of remembering the position of each traversal.

Iterators can be traversed using the next() method or a general for loop. Iteration terminates by raising a StopIteration exception, which is also part of the iterator protocol.

Custom iterator implementation:

Generators are characterized by lazy evaluation, calculating only when used, saving memory space. This is why print(g) in the example above doesn’t directly return the values, but instead returns a generator object.

Generators are single-iterator objects. They produce only one value at a time, and each value can only be retrieved once. Attempting to retrieve a value more than once will raise an error.

Design of Iterables and Iterators:

Finally, let’s address why we need iterables if iterators alone can fulfill our needs for traversing collection elements. Iterables typically also need to call the __iter__ method to return an iterator for element traversal.

The book “Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software” describes the design of the iterator pattern very well:

  1. Access the contents of an aggregate object without exposing its internal representation.
  2. Support multiple traversals of an aggregate object.
  3. Provide a uniform interface for traversing different aggregate structures.

Summary

If an object implements the __iter__ method, it is an iterable. If an iterable implements the __next__ method, which provides iteration traversal, it is an iterator. Calling the __iter__ method returns an instance of the current object’s iterator class.

    https://www.runoob.com/python3/python3-iterator-generator.html

entry.title: Game Product Design: Player's Sense of Achievement
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Introduction

Game producer Jenova Chen mentioned in his GDC talk about Journey (the designer of Journey sharing the team’s process of developing the game) that movies are already very mature and have precipitated different emotions, but the sense of achievement provided by most games cannot be provided by movies. Only the feedback obtained after one’s own efforts will give you a sense of achievement. This feeling can only be achieved through interactive experience. Perhaps because of this, this is also the most explored emotional direction in games.

Goals in Games

The charm of games, or the reason why they attract players and make them unable to stop, is precisely this. There are many goals in games that can satisfy people with different needs. Those who like collecting have full collection achievements, and those who like cultivation have various cultivation elements. In the game, players are always in a state of striving to achieve a certain goal, from completing single-game goals to phased milestone goals, and then to completing the ultimate goal. In this way, players feel that they have something to do, and experience a strong sense of participation and immersion in the process of doing things. When the goal is completed, there is also a strong sense of achievement.

During design, player goals and design goals can be achieved simultaneously. “Visible progress” in the game is a very important advantage compared to various learning and exercise goals in real life. Many times in real life, when we learn a piece of knowledge or a skill, we practice for a long time without seeing “visible” progress, and we even don’t know whether we are practicing in the right direction. But in the game, we can clearly see the “experience increase”, “current progress”, etc., so that we have more motivation to continue.

User’s Sense of Control

Sense of control is a person’s belief in their ability to control the surrounding environment. In the context of user experience design, sense of control can be used to describe the user’s confidence or frustration in using the product, and can also be used to describe the usability of the product itself. If users have a high sense of control when using the product or completing tasks, their attitude will be more positive, they will be more willing to accept setbacks and make mistakes, and they will also have a greater sense of security. In the process of experience design, we should ensure the user’s sense of control to enhance the user’s participation and willingness to explore.

Especially for racing games, you can experience a higher need for control - bypassing different corners, flying out, and most importantly, grasping your own direction, otherwise you will lose control. The sense of control and challenge it possesses is very fascinating. This fascination is very easy to enter a “flow state”, which is also the effect that game designers hope to achieve.

Feedback and Satisfaction

When skills are improved or levels are raised, there is a certain sense of proficiency. At this time, players should have a feeling of encouragement. This kind of positive and rapid encouragement helps users form a positive attitude towards the use process. For example, when you are playing a game, the initial operational requirements make you feel a little uncomfortable, such as selecting minions and switching between heroes’ attacks. But when your level improves, you can easily control your operations, and the operation effects are fed back in real time, quickly informing you of the results, to obtain great satisfaction.

The game feedback system clearly tells players the current situation and shows how far they are from achieving their goals. It is reflected in the form of points, levels, scores, progress bars, equipment backpacks, etc. The feedback system is the most basic and simplest form. For players, real-time feedback is a promise: the goal can definitely be achieved, which gives people confidence to continue playing.

Coda

Games make players feel happy. We must constantly create happy things in the game to satisfy players’ corrections to real-life dissatisfaction. Players will have a good impression of such games, and their psychology will be satisfied.

entry.title: 2019 TGA Game of the Year "Sekiro" and Its Players
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

What is dark? But an excuse for light.

What is rot? But an excuse for ripe.

Without darkness, would stars be admired?

Without a burn, would man discover fire?

Without shadow, could you find the light source?

Without hunger could you serve a main course?

What is dark? But an excuse for light.

What is death? But an excuse for life.

Introduction

Souls-like games are known for their “difficulty.” To beat a Souls-like game, players often have to die hundreds or even thousands of times. What kind of magic can make players enjoy “death,” a form of negative feedback? Defeated again and again, and picking up the controller again and again to embark on the journey. This poem can be said to be the best annotation of the Souls-like series.

When a general goes to war, he should consider it an honor to die in battle, and a disgrace to survive.

— The Art of War by Wu Qi, Chapter 4: On Generals

Although the Souls series has gradually been recognized and received attention among players, it has never been able to win the “Oscar” of the game industry - the TGA Game of the Year. In 2014, Dark Souls 3 failed to win the TGA in a year with few major game releases. In 2015, Bloodborne also lost to another masterpiece, The Witcher 3. In 2019, Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice embarked on the journey again, and this time Hidetaka Miyazaki finally got his wish.

On December 13, 2019, Beijing time, Miyazaki finally ascended to the altar and won the TGA Game of the Year award. This process, just like the games he created, never gives up, never surrenders.

 

Sekiro’s 2019 keywords are not just limited to TGA Game of the Year. It can be said that Sekiro was a phenomenal game in 2019. The editor has summarized several key words about Sekiro players in 2019.

Keyword 1: “Hesitation is Defeat” (“Hesitate and you lose”)

“Hesitation is defeat” is a combat technique taught by Isshin Ashina, the Sword Saint, to “Wolf” in the game, just like Sekiro’s parrying gameplay. Players can no longer wait for the best time to attack like playing other action games. Hesitation is defeat. All players can do is pick up the sword in their hands, find the rhythm of the BOSS’s attack, and use offense to resolve the opponent’s attack. This novel action game play is nicknamed “clashing iron.” Playing Sekiro has also been nicknamed “going to clash iron.” Asking if someone has played Sekiro has become “Have you heard the sound of clashing iron in Ashina Castle at 4 am?”

The rise of live streaming platforms has fueled the popularity of Sekiro. Even if you haven’t played Sekiro, or even if you haven’t heard of Sekiro, you will definitely see “Hesitation is Defeat” frequently from March to June 2019, as well as various memes of this phrase. Sekiro made this phrase a popular online buzzword in 2019.

Keyword 2: “Noob” (“Cai”)

Players failed again and again in Sekiro, and the word “死” (death) appeared on the screen again and again. Gradually, everyone found that the word “死” seemed to be less and less familiar, and they began to feel strange to it, not knowing how to write “死” - in 1960, psychologists Lambert and Jakobovits named this phenomenon “semantic satiation” (I won’t go into details here, if you are interested, please comment and forward, if there is high demand, the editor will publish a special article to explain this phenomenon).

Enthusiastic players began to make their own MODs on PC, replacing the word “死” with “菜” (noob/vegetable), to encourage and mock themselves. As a result, everyone gradually found that they didn’t know how to write “菜” either.

Keyword 3: Speedrun and “Cheesing”

In the early days of Sekiro’s release, the two most popular (most viewed and commented) content about Sekiro on video websites were “speedrun” and “cheesing”. Within a week of the game’s release, expert action game players reduced the world record for Sekiro speedrun to 50 minutes and 52 seconds (from Russian player Darflesh). This means that you can buy Sekiro on Steam, beat the game, and then apply for a refund. It’s a legitimate way to “get” the game for free.

More interestingly, videos on video websites about “cheesing” and “copying homework” were also very popular, which can be said to be another extreme. Players are eager to defeat Genichiro Ashina, to defeat Owl, to defeat the Sword Saint. However, they are not skilled enough and their reaction is not fast enough. Therefore, this kind of cheesing video is extremely popular among players. Expert players upload some high-fault-tolerance gameplay for other players to learn, so that they can quickly beat the game.

I even think that this year’s “copying homework” trend on Double Eleven (Singles’ Day) is a continuation of the “copying homework” trend of Sekiro at the beginning of the year. It can be said to be a classic case of the influence of popular games on trend culture.

Keyword 4: Sekiro Lore

Hidetaka Miyazaki’s consistent style in the Souls series is that the game’s narrative is always fragmented and incoherent. Players need to speculate on the structure of the world and the direction of the plot from the item descriptions, NPC dialogues, and even the arrangement and changes of items in the scene. Sekiro is no exception. Players often cannot grasp the whole story of the game in a single playthrough, or even have no idea what happened. As a result, videos on “Sekiro Lore Studies” have also received a certain amount of attention on video websites. The video authors will analyze the text and pictures in the game to analyze what happened in the world of Sekiro, and to speculate on what kind of story Miyazaki wants to tell the players. The editor strongly recommends the “Sekiro Lore Researcher” series by Bilibili user 龙崎棒棒糖 (Long Qi Bang Bang Tang), which is the best Sekiro plot analysis video I have ever seen.

Epilogue

In 2019, Sekiro brought countless joy to players. I hope that the cooperation between Miyazaki and another old thief, George R.R. Martin, can go smoothly, and that players can continue to experience pain and happiness. Let’s look forward to Elden Ring together.

entry.title: Randomness, Pseudo-Randomness, and Pseudo-Pseudo-Randomness in Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

Introduction

Randomness is an important characteristic that contributes to the fun of games. Every game incorporates randomness in its numerical design. Whether it’s opening loot boxes, drawing gacha, or experiencing critical hits and item drops during combat, these random probability events often leave the majority of players lamenting their bad luck, while a small minority rejoice in their good fortune. It is precisely because of this uncertainty that players have more anticipation and hope during their gaming experience. Each random outcome brings players a fresh experience.

 

A Lucky Gacha Draw

Pseudo-Randomness and Philosophy

Just like the principle of moderation in philosophy, too little randomness reduces player enjoyment, while too much randomness affects the balance of the game. Different types of games require different degrees of randomness in different aspects. At appropriate times, it is necessary to manually intervene in randomness to ensure the game experience.

In computer language, 0 is 0 and 1 is 1. There is no data in a program that can be both 0 and 1. A quantum superposition state like Schrödinger’s cat cannot exist within a game program. To satisfy people’s need for randomness, programmers need to write a specific program to achieve random numerical changes within the game. In this sense, all so-called “randomness” in games is actually “pseudo-randomness” that has been manually intervened. Of course, whether all random events in nature should also be regarded as “pseudo-random” events belongs to the realm of philosophy, and we will not take up too much space to discuss it here.

 

Schrödinger’s Cat

Pseudo-Pseudo-Randomness

To prevent the random settings in the game from having a significant impact on game balance, and to protect the rights of players, most game manufacturers add some manual adjustments to the “pseudo-random” settings, namely “pseudo-pseudo-randomness”. This ensures that players with less-than-ideal luck obtain a basic gaming experience. Examples include pity systems in gacha mechanics, and making the frequency of some random skills, such as critical hits, constant during battles.

Let’s take the hero Axe from the game Dota 2 as an example. One of Axe’s skills, “Counter Helix,” is described as follows: When taking basic attacks from the enemy, Axe has a chance to perform a helix counterattack, attacking all nearby enemies. In older versions, this probability followed a “random distribution,” meaning that every time Axe was attacked, there was a 17%-20% chance (which increased with level) to trigger Counter Helix. This led to situations where a lucky player using this hero might spin like a fan, achieving kills, while an unlucky player might be killed without triggering the skill even once, causing frustration.

In a later version, Valve adjusted all skills with “random distribution” in Dota 2 to use “pseudo-random distribution.” This means that the actual probability of a skill triggering is different each time. Each attack that does not trigger the event increases the probability of the event occurring on the next attack. This ensures that the event will occur at least once within a fixed number of attacks/casts. In simple terms, through manual intervention in “random events,” Valve ensured that Axe’s Counter Helix skill, at a 20% probability at max level, would trigger at least once every 5 attacks.

 

“Axe’s” skill, “Counter-Helix”

Of course, after such adjustments in the game, some skilled players playing heroes like Phantom Assassin (whose ultimate has a 15% chance of triggering a high-multiplier critical hit) will often attack creeps before “fighting” to “accumulate critical hit rate.” For example, if they attack creeps 3-4 times in a row without triggering a critical hit, they can choose to attack the enemy hero, thereby increasing the chance of a critical hit on the enemy hero.

Conclusion

In summary, randomness is important for enhancing the actual experience during the game. Adding appropriate random event gameplay in the game can effectively improve the player’s experience. Too high or too low a probability will have a negative impact. Choosing the appropriate type of randomness, pseudo-randomness, or pseudo-pseudo-randomness in the game is a decision that game designers need to make based on the game’s own gameplay attributes.

entry.title: Randomness and Positive Feedback Presentation in Auto Chess
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Analysis of Auto Chess Characteristics

Last year, Dota 2’s Auto Chess mod suddenly became popular. After its launch, Dota Auto Chess became the number one map in the DOTA 2 Workshop, with an average daily online presence of 300,000. With the launch of other auto chess games in the future, I believe there is still a lot of room for optimization in auto chess.

Auto chess incorporates and optimizes the gameplay of mahjong, with automatic battles, a low learning curve, high randomness, and points for comebacks. There are many points where you can get happiness in random confrontations, rather than only the first place being able to get happiness.

So how do the auto chess games on the market show their randomness in the game interface, and provide real-time positive feedback to players?

Randomness

Randomness is mainly concentrated in the interface for selecting pieces. In Auto Chess (Drodo) / Dota Auto Chess, this is mainly reflected in the pop-up window for displaying pieces during the battle interlude. It only pops up automatically during the battle interlude, and is not a permanent window. To call it up, you need to click the gold button or the chess piece button.

 

Auto Chess (Drodo) Piece Pool

 

Dota Auto Chess Piece Pool

Here, in order to emphasize its randomness, owned pieces or recommended pieces will have special effects around them, and there will also be upgrade prompts. Arena of Evolution: Red Tides even has a “luck rating”.

 

Arena of Evolution: Red Tides

Teamfight Tactics has it as a permanent page at the bottom. (Permanent menus are more friendly on the PC side. Justice Online‘s Fight for Freedom made it into a switchable piece pool.)

 

Teamfight Tactics Permanent Pieces

 

Justice Online’s Fight For Freedom

Positive Feedback

The probability of each round of pieces appearing itself will bring certain positive feedback to the player, especially when there are two one-star pieces and the third one-star piece is drawn, when the key lineup card is drawn, and when the opponent of this round is defeated, there is a feeling of being the chosen one. (In contrast, the negative feedback content such as not drawing the card is not so strong.)

In addition, after the end of each game, there is a settlement interface. Some have a settlement interface that tells the player the income of each round (including losing streak income) and the skill gold bonus in some game mechanisms; others have the income display appearing in the battle interface. Teamfight Tactics will accumulate 10 gold coins into a golden shell on one side.

 

Arena of Evolution: Red Tides

 

Teamfight Tactics Golden Shell

But there is a problem with auto chess, that is, the length of time for each group of players to finish the current round is different. While waiting for other players to finish the game, some players may upgrade their pieces, etc. If you need to constantly switch perspectives to get this information, it is easy to miss your own chess selection time.

How to solve the problem of switching between rounds?

Some star-up information or victory information, etc., are realized by some auto chess games through bullet comments (danmu - 弹幕).

 

Dota Auto Chess Bullet Comments

Round Division

In order to clearly divide the rounds, Teamfight Tactics and Dota Auto Chess both use scene switching to distinguish.

Teamfight Tactics realizes scene switching through the shuttle of different spaces, while Dota Auto Chess switches through the illumination of day and night.

 

《Teamfight Tactics》 Scene Switching

 

Dota Auto Chess Scene Switching

entry.title: Game Community Research (2): Haoyou Kuaibao (AppChina)
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

A game community refers to an online community composed of a group of game-loving netizens who specifically discuss and interact with games and game-related content. It has the following characteristics:

(1) It has a certain entry threshold;

(2) It has a specific space for communication and interaction;

(3) It produces content around specific topics.

For us game practitioners, the game community is a very important platform for interacting with players and conducting game marketing activities, because it allows us to better understand the preferences of players with rich game experience and high game skills for game mechanics and content. In the first
date: November 29, 2019), we introduced TapTap, a professional game community with a clear access mechanism, a strong interactive atmosphere among community members, and a commitment to high-quality game reviews. In this article, we will introduce another well-known game community platform - Haoyou Kuaibao (AppChina). Although it has some similarities with TapTap in terms of service content and member profiles, Haoyou Kuaibao also has its own unique positioning, which also affects the game marketing and operation strategies of game practitioners to a large extent.
categories:
- NetEase UX
-## Part Two: Haoyou Kuaibao (AppChina)

Haoyou Kuaibao is a game enthusiast community developed by Xiamen Chunyou Interactive Technology Co., Ltd. In Haoyou Kuaibao, users can follow the real-time trends of the mobile game market through the rankings, and they can also experience beta versions of new games first and publish game reviews to communicate with millions of game enthusiasts and game developers. Compared with TapTap, Haoyou Kuaibao has the following two unique service positions:

  1. Focusing on the “Game Guides + Toolbox” integrated module as the main content feature: Compared with TapTap, which focuses on user social interaction and community operation, Haoyou Kuaibao is more practical - it focuses on meeting the specific needs of players to “play”. The main content feature of Haoyou Kuaibao is the integrated module of “Game Guides + Toolbox”, that is, players can not only share game guides in game reviews, but also launch self-created auxiliary tools for high-traffic games with a certain learning threshold, such as network accelerators, Clash Royale deck builders, Arena of Valor rune simulators, etc. In the main page of the Haoyou Kuaibao App, there are many entrances to game guides/toolboxes, and they are all in a prominent position on the page.

 

Haoyou Kuaibao’s Toolbox Page

 

Different Toolbox/Guide Entrances on the Haoyou Kuaibao Page

  1. Focusing on letting players recommend games independently: In the introduction of the previous article, we can know that TapTap values the cultivation of high-quality game review content, which requires TapTap to take the “high-end, elegant, and classy” “elite” route in user group cultivation and game review screening, that is, the reviews and guides written by players with rich game experience and high game skills are more credible and more likely to be recommended by TapTap editors, becoming an important force affecting the game experience and evaluation of other ordinary players. Different from TapTap, by setting up a distinctive player self-recommendation game list function, Haoyou Kuaibao gives more ordinary players the opportunity to independently recommend and review games. In the “Novelty - Game List” module on the App’s homepage, players can search for or create popular game lists. The games included in the list reflect more of the players’ personal preferences, rather than professionally evaluated and more popular games.

 

 

Haoyou Kuaibao’s User-Created Game List Page, with a page style similar to NetEase Cloud Music’s Song List.

Why are there these significant differences between Haoyou Kuaibao and TapTap in service positioning and content features? This is related to the differences in user groups between the two. Compared with TapTap, what are the profile characteristics of Haoyou Kuaibao users? Do they have preferences for specific game categories and mechanics? By querying the Baidu Index (time window: September 29, 2019 - October 28, 2019) and referring to other industry reports, we obtained the following user profile information of Haoyou Kuaibao:

(1) User gender distribution: Compared with TapTap, Haoyou Kuaibao users have a relatively balanced gender distribution, with slightly more males than females.

 

(2) User age distribution: Compared with TapTap, Haoyou Kuaibao users are older on average, with the highest proportion of users aged 30-39, exceeding 50%.

 

(3) User geographic distribution: Compared with TapTap users who are mostly distributed in coastal areas, a considerable number of Haoyou Kuaibao users are distributed in central provinces. If calculated according to the frequency of users searching for Haoyou Kuaibao in various places, Henan, Hebei and other central provinces rank prominently, surpassing coastal provinces such as Shandong, Jiangsu, and Zhejiang.

 

TapTap user geographic distribution, it can be seen that its users are mostly distributed in coastal provinces such as Guangdong and Shandong

 

Haoyou Kuaibao user geographic distribution, it can be seen that a considerable number of users are distributed in Henan and Hebei.

(4) User game preference: According to the introduction of the previous article, we can conclude that TapTap users relatively prefer indie games, and they rate games with innovative gameplay higher than popular game categories. In contrast, based on the research on the shortlist of Haoyou Kuaibao’s 2018 Best Game and Most Popular Game, we found that Haoyou Kuaibao users have a higher acceptance of popular games from major manufacturers. PUBG Mobile even won the Most Popular Game of the Year award. At the same time, compared with TapTap users, Haoyou Kuaibao users also prefer a more diverse range of game types, covering the popular battle royale, FPS, RPG, MOBA and the relatively niche sandbox and survival genres.

 

The red circles in the table indicate the games nominated for the 2018 Haoyou Kuaibao Best/Most Popular Game by two major domestic game manufacturers - Tencent and NetEase. It can be seen that Haoyou Kuaibao users have a high acceptance of games produced by domestic major manufacturers

 

From the nomination of Haoyou Kuaibao’s 2018 Best/Most Popular Game, it can be seen that its users prefer a more diverse range of game categories. Compared with TapTap users, Haoyou Kuaibao users have a higher acceptance of popular game categories

Conclusion: From the above analysis, we draw the following conclusions:

(1) As a game community, Haoyou Kuaibao: Compared with TapTap, it has a lower entry threshold, a more diverse user group, and focuses on meeting players’ practical needs for “playing”.

(2) As a member of such a game community: They may be relatively older and have a preference for popular game categories and gameplay.

entry.title: A Brief Discussion of Game Fun Theory - A Case Study of UNO
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Why does entering UNO feel like entering a black hole of happy time? Fun is a very complex word, with more dimensions than pleasure. There are many theories that explain the fun of games. Today, we will start with two perspectives: reinforcement theory and flow theory.

 

Official UNO mobile game “UNO!”

Reinforcement Theory (Skinner’s Reinforcement Theory)

Reinforcement theory was proposed by Skinner, also known as the operant conditioning theory. Positive reinforcement is more commonly used in games. Positive reinforcement, also known as positive reinforcement, simply means that by adding a certain stimulus, the probability of a certain behavior increases. For example, Xiao You completes her homework on time every day and gets 30 minutes of UNO time. In order to get 30 minutes of UNO time, Xiao You completes her homework on time every day. Thus, a connection is established: completing homework on time will be rewarded, and the reward brings happiness.

 

Skinner’s Operant Conditioning

So how is reinforcement theory applied to games? By rationally utilizing the reinforcement formula, linking rewards to certain behaviors, and increasing the individual’s sense of gain and achievement, players can experience more fun.

Application of reinforcement theory: In the game “UNO!”, winning a game will earn coins. This is a kind of positive reinforcement. I win, I can get rewards, and thus get more satisfaction. Moreover, in order to expand the impact of this positive reinforcement, very rich special effects are usually used. This feeling of coins flying all over the sky, doesn’t it give a great sense of gain and achievement?

 

Players win a lot of coins in the high-stakes arena of “UNO!”

Reinforcement theory is more biased towards the behavioral level. Players are reinforced by this, feel happy, and will invest more frequently in the game. But players don’t always win. Sometimes, due to the increased difficulty of the game, they will lose ten times in a row or be punished with 16 cards. So why are players still enjoying it?

 

Players experience a ten-game losing streak in “UNO!”

Flow Theory (Mental Flow)

Flow theory was proposed by psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi. He defined flow as a feeling of complete focus of one’s mental energy on a certain activity; when flow occurs, there is also a high degree of excitement and fulfillment. The generation of flow needs to consider five dimensions: challenge and skill, anxiety and boredom, and difficulty balance. In the figure below, A is our player. He will have different states due to the level of challenge difficulty and his own ability level. For example, if a high-difficulty challenge is matched with a low skill level, the player will be very anxious; if a low-difficulty challenge is matched with a high skill level, the player will be very bored. Only when the appropriate difficulty challenge is matched with the appropriate skill level will the player be in a state of flow.

 

Flow Channel (from Jesse Schell’s “The Art of Game Design”)

The purpose of game design is to adjust the appropriate difficulty so that players are always in a state of flow and get a very satisfying feeling. In the figure below, players reach the first stage (world1) with only a relatively low skill level, while reaching the last stage requires a very high skill level. This stage is the player’s growth process. In games, for example, in the “UNO!” novice tutorial, various gameplays are opened in sequence. Players need to learn how to play the classic mode first, and only after upgrading to level xx will other gameplays such as competitive events be unlocked. This kind of teaching conforms to the growth process of flow and is more likely to make players feel excited and satisfied.

 

Fractal Flow Channel, Expanded from Wave Flow Channel

Case Study of Applying Flow Theory: “UNO!” Ranked Mode

 

Ranked Mode in “UNO!”

In the current ranked match of “UNO!”, players can be matched with players one level above or below their own rank. In other words, players will always be matched with players of similar skill levels, so players are always challenging “appropriate difficulty” and are more likely to be in a state of flow. So why do players still want to continue playing even if they lose? From the perspective of flow, the flow state that players have experienced before gives them a foundation of skills and a psychological state of satisfaction and confidence, and they are more convinced that they can challenge this difficulty. Think about it, if you lose a ranked match, you always feel that “my skills should be fine, I was just unlucky, I will definitely win the next one.”

 

The UNO China Streamer Open held by “UNO!”

The fun of games is still a relatively complex topic. In addition to reinforcement theory and flow theory, some scholars explain the fun of games from the perspective of evolutionary psychology and behavioral economics. So here’s a small question for everyone to think about. Why do people especially like to participate in game competitions?

References

http://indiedevstories.com/2011/08/10/game-theory-applied-the-flow-channel/

https://wiki.mbalib.com/wiki/%E6%96%AF%E9%87%91%E7%BA%B3%E7%9A%84%E5%BC%BA%E5%8C%96%E7%90%86%E8%AE%BA

https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E8%A1%8C%E4%B8%BA%E4%B8%BB%E4%B9%89

entry.title: Applying the Hook Model to UNO!: How Do Players Get 'Addicted'?
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

As an UNO! enthusiast, I often claim that “I’m addicted to playing UNO!”, but why am I addicted? Where does the “addiction” come from? In fact, it can be explained by a very specific model, namely the famous “Hook Model”.

The Hook Model was proposed by Nir Eyal and Ryan Hoover, authors of Hooked: How to Build Habit-Forming Products. They attribute addiction to “behaviors done with little or no conscious thought.” And how to become “addicted” requires the four product elements of the Hook Model:

  • Trigger
  • Action
  • Variable Reward
  • Investment

Trigger

“Trigger” is the first step of the Hook Model. If this step cannot arouse the user’s interest, the follow-up is out of the question. There are two forms of triggers: “external triggers” and “internal triggers”.

External triggers are external information that induces users to take action and enter the system. The external triggers after the launch of UNO! include: recommendations from app stores (including TapTap), information pushes on platforms such as Weibo and WeChat official accounts, and friend invitations among UNO players. It is worth mentioning that KOL (Key Opinion Leader) promotion is also an extremely effective external trigger. Many UNO! players said that they were hooked after watching the live broadcast of the famous up-host “Xiaoyao Sanren”.

Internal triggers are user self-directed triggers driven by their own emotions. Studies have shown that negative emotions, such as loneliness, fear, frustration, and confusion, can even affect our behavior more than positive emotions. The initial launch of UNO! coincided with the period of domestic epidemic, many users were isolated at home and felt bored and lonely, eager to communicate with others, and were very likely to get into new games.

Action

After the trigger, it is to make the user take action. The Hook Model is built on the Behavior Model of Stanford professor Bijou, that is, behavior = motivation + ability + trigger. In life, no matter what we do, we have various motivations, and UNO! satisfies the following needs of users in terms of motivation:

  • Sociality: The two-player mode and room mode with limited free room cards in UNO! allow players to play with friends, especially former board game players, who can experience UNO cards online.
  • Sense of Achievement: The ranking system, World Cup, various leaderboards, and rankings among friends can stimulate players to continuously challenge.
  • Ability: that is, the user’s ability to complete the desired action. In terms of ability, the threshold of UNO! is low, and the low cost of user input makes it easy to get started:

  1. The game time is short, basically 3 minutes per round.
  2. The operation mode is simple, which is to draw cards and play cards, and occasionally there will be functional card options such as challenges and stacking.
  3. The game rules are simple, and there are only two situations to win: play all the cards or have the lowest score when the time is up.

With a sufficiently low threshold, the addition of the ranking system and custom rooms allows players of the same level to match each other, retaining high-level players.

Variable Reward

After the behavior is triggered, it is necessary to give users some rewards for continuous stimulation in order to cultivate their usage habits. But rewards alone are not enough, and Variable Rewards can make users truly “addicted”. Behavioral research shows that people’s satisfaction with products will gradually decrease over time. Maintaining variability can ensure the mystery and attractiveness of products, and maintain users’ long-term interest, which is also the reason why all games need to be updated regularly. The rewards in the Hook Model include three aspects:

  • Social Rewards: That is, cooperation and competition, sense of identity, and interpersonal rewards generated by interacting with others. The two-player mode of UNO! can freely match unfamiliar teammates. In the game, you can give flowers and rotten eggs to your teammates. “Not knowing what kind of teammates you will encounter” is an unknown expectation. The daily exchange of gold coins between game friends, the leaderboard, and the ability to open a room to customize the rules of the game, all give players the motivation to participate in cooperation and competition in the game.

  • Hunt Rewards: That is, the specific resources or exclusive information obtained. UNO! has high-multiplier mode such as 40x and 80x. Once you win, you can get a lot of money. This kind of high-intensity reward stimulation will give players the desire to continuously challenge. In fact, all gold coins and prop rewards in the game belong to the category of hunt rewards.

  • Self Rewards: That is, the sense of control, achievement, and other self-emotional rewards experienced from the product. UNO! has set different ranks, and self-recognition can be obtained through promotion. The World Cup “representing China” also gives players a sense of honor and achievement.

Investment

Psychological research shows that the time and energy a user invests in something is directly proportional to the degree of dependence, just like you won’t cherish free things, but you will recharge more and more in paid games. Therefore, the last step of “addiction” is to invest.

The simplest investment is time and money. When a person has played 200 rounds of UNO or recharged 200 yuan of gold coins, no matter how many gold coins he has left or whether he is bankrupt, he will want to get more or even multiple times more gold coins, and will further invest in the game.

As mentioned earlier, UNO! is a game with a low entry barrier, but it is not easy to become a master. It requires a process of learning and continuous practice, which is also an investment in self-improvement. When you become a master of a game, it will be more difficult for you to leave the game.

In addition, the accumulated appearance and ranking in the game are also an investment in “content” and “data”.

References

Bijou S. Behavior analysis of childdevelopment[M]. New Harbinger Publications, 1993.

Eyal N. Hooked: How to build habit-formingproducts[M]. Penguin, 2014.

entry.title: [User Research] From UNO to the Street Vendor Economy - Anchoring and Reciprocity Principles in Consumer Psychology
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Recently, the street vendor economy has become very popular. While surfing the internet, I found that everyone is setting up stalls, and there is a lively atmosphere everywhere. As a game developer, I am not to be outdone. I want to discuss with everyone how to use the experience of making games to become the king of street vendors, and introduce how consumer psychology effects can be applied from games to street vending. This sharing uses the official UNO mobile game UNO!™ as a case study.

Anchoring Effect

The anchoring effect is a cognitive bias that refers to the tendency for individuals to rely too heavily on an initial piece of information (the “anchor”) when making estimates or decisions, even if that information is irrelevant. When making decisions, people unconsciously give too much weight to the information they first obtain. For example, when a salesperson wants to visit a customer, they will specifically propose a time to visit, such as “Are you free at two o’clock on Saturday?” If the customer is not available, they will generally look for another suitable time based on this time, rather than setting aside the “two o’clock on Saturday” time anchor and expressing that they do not need to meet the salesperson.

In the UNO!™ game, you will see some discounted items. Discounted items are often marked with the original price and the discounted price. Since the discounted price already provides the information, why mark the original price? The original price is the “anchor”, which affects your estimated value of this item. When you estimate the value of this item to be 10 diamonds, but now you can buy it for 8 diamonds or even 5 diamonds, wouldn’t you think “it’s a steal, buy!”

Then when we go to set up a street stall, we can use this experience. Whether we want to sell clothes or snacks, don’t forget to give customers an “anchor” first, quietly lock the value of the goods, and then give customers a discount, so that customers have a feeling of “getting a bargain”. Of course, it should also be noted that if this “anchor” deviates too far from the value of the goods, it will not be effective.

Reciprocity Principle

The reciprocity principle suggests that we should try to repay, in kind, what another person has provided us. In summary, it is a behavior that should be reciprocated with a similar behavior. For example, on your birthday, someone gave you a birthday present. Then you must be thinking about giving him a birthday present on his birthday, or giving him some gifts at other suitable times.

In the UNO!™ game, players can give each other coins. If a friend gives you ten coins, then you must be thinking about giving them back. If your daily coin gifting limit is used up, and you play a game with him, you may also want to give him a small gift in the game to give back.

So how can the reciprocity principle be applied to street vending? Suppose we go to set up a stall to sell fruit and occupy a high-traffic area of the street. We pull in passers-by for free tastings. People who have eaten the fruit will want to reciprocate with some behavior, and may choose to buy some fruit, or of course they may say thank you. Stalls selling clothes don’t have tastings, but don’t worry, put two buckets of low-cost flowers at the door, and give one to everyone who passes by. Someone holding a flower will always want to give back to you, and by the way, take a look at the clothes and buy some clothes.

I have to say, psychology is really everywhere in daily life and games. Using game experience to become the king of street vendors, we game people never give up. Leave a small question, what is going on with the queuing to enter the server in the game and the “shills” at the entrance of the milk tea shop?

References

https://wiki.mbalib.com/wiki/%E9%94%9A%E5%AE%9A%E6%95%88%E5%BA%94

entry.title: Introduction to Flat Illustration Design
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Introduction

Illustration, as an art form, with its intuitive imagery and profound appeal, can attract the attention of a wide range of consumers in commercial applications, and also has strong communication power.

Therefore, illustrations are widely used in advertising, posters, product packaging, web pages and other platforms, such as Monument Valley, the packaging of Cha Pi (茶π), and Ziroom’s splash screen. Against this background, flat illustration emerged as a relatively popular illustration style.

Next, we will understand the principles and production of flat illustration, roughly learn and grasp the main points, and create our own flat illustrations.

What is Flat Illustration?

Flat illustration is a non-realistic illustration technique that summarizes the outline of an object, extracts its features, and retains the original recognizability of the object. It is generally drawn by combining and changing basic geometric shapes (ellipses, circles, triangles, rectangles, etc.).

Flat illustration has the advantages of high versatility (wide application), easy to get started, short production time, and good effect, and the picture is simple, the subject is clear, and the “information” to be displayed can be highlighted. Therefore, it is highly praised by illustrators and designers.

For example, in the mobile game UNO!, the map part of the “World Tour” mode is a typical example of the application of flat illustration.

Because the overall game style is relatively clean and simple, it is not suitable for realistic depictions with too many details. In this case, simply flattening the photo (landmark building) can achieve the effect of retaining regional characteristics and perfectly integrating with the game, and the picture can also be appropriately beautified according to needs.

 

 

UNO! “World Tour” mode in-game application effect

Flat Illustration Deconstruction

Since flat illustration is basically composed of simple geometric shapes, complex illustrations can be deconstructed into combinations of multiple geometries.

The following uses a few simple icon examples to illustrate the basic expression forms of flat illustration.

① Solid Color Blocks

The basic shape is obtained through Boolean operations, and simple color blocks are laid flat.

 

 

② Lines

Use lines to shape the outline

 

③ Gradient

Also on the basis of color blocks and lines, gradient processing is performed on the color blocks to increase details.

 

④ Color Overlay

Use methods such as reducing opacity to achieve a rich picture effect through color overlay contrast.

 

⑤ Texture

Flat texture is a very popular style.

It aims to use grain effects, textures, etc. to enhance the texture of the illustration and increase the durability of the picture.

Grain texture effects can be used to add a sense of space to the foreground and background, or to add shadows and highlights.

 

Author: Bárbara Malagoli

Getting Started

Recommended tools for beginners here include AI, PS, drawing tablets, etc.

The steps for beginners can be divided into copying, semi-original, and original.

 

① Copying

Copying is the simplest.

What we have to do is find a picture we like and copy a picture as similar as possible next to it.

This can familiarize you with the operation of the software, such as shortcut keys, some small skills, etc.; on the other hand, by copying, you can roughly understand the completion process of a picture and the expression of professional illustrators.

② Semi-original

The semi-original here refers to taking a photo and performing simple artistic processing on it.

It should be noted that if the final image is to be used commercially, then you must pay attention to copyright issues. Therefore, the photos we choose should meet the following two conditions:

One is that the subject of the photo has no copyright, such as a roadside rose;

The second is that the photo is preferably taken by yourself. If it is someone else’s photograph, be sure not to pick those photos with special shooting angles, as this type of photo also belongs to the author’s creation.

In addition, for the selection of photos for secondary creation, it is recommended that beginners choose front or full-side views as much as possible. In this way, there is less interference from perspective when drawing, and try to choose things with clean outlines to reduce the difficulty of outline extraction.
