Next, we will use a brief process demonstration to talk about how to create flat illustrations. If you are interested, come and try it out~

Step 1. Take a photo you are interested in and analyze it

 

The entire Christmas decoration actually has a lot of details. Keep in mind the suggestions just now, choose the front + outline feel, so you must first crop the photo content.

 

Step 2. Create a new artboard in AI and reduce the opacity of the photo

Create a new A4 size file in AI, drag the picture in and adjust the opacity.

This can be adjusted according to your own comfort, to ensure that you can see the structure without affecting the next step.

 

Step 3. Extract the outline

Note that you don’t have to restore the photo one-to-one, try to summarize it with complete geometry

(Note: For specific operations on AI, you can search for relevant tutorials online~)

 

Step 4. Fill in the color

Use different colors to distinguish different hierarchical relationships.

 

Step 5. Repeat steps 3 and 4 to draw the required parts

Then adjust some of the sizes and positions, and you can get the following picture that is roughly close to completion.

(Note: This part requires a lot of patience, and you may feel bored when drawing)

 

The following steps are slightly difficult, and beginners can choose to learn:

Step 6. Enrich the picture

You can add some scene content around it to fill it~

At this point, a simple pure flat illustration is almost complete.

 

Step 7. Add texture

In order to make the picture richer and more beautiful, we can add a layer of texture in PS.

Remember what I said in the previous introduction? Graininess can be used to express the dark or highlight of an object.

So when drawing texture, you can choose different colors to draw in the dark or highlight positions, remember to check the entire picture content~

Add some missing details, and you can also adjust the color scheme if you don’t think it looks good before,锵锵锵~ (onomatopoeia)

(Note: The grain effect can be achieved with Dissolve + Airbrush in PS. For detailed tutorials, you can search for it yourself.)

 

Step 8. Try to make the windmill in the picture move!

 

③ Original

After mastering the operation of copying and semi-original, it is very simple to create original works~

Just find a few more photo materials for reference, and then choose different content for combination and creativity, and it will be your own original work~

Conclusion

The above is the idea process of getting started with flat illustration.

First of all, you must have a certain understanding of flat illustration, including understanding what flat illustration is and what its expression techniques are.

Then it is to deconstruct the object information and summarize it with geometry as much as possible.

It is strongly recommended that beginners must copy a lot when getting started, and summarize the rules of extracting object outlines, that is, how to better express object characteristics with geometry.

In the process of copying, you must proceed step by step, starting with simple icons, and then to complete illustrations; when you have accumulated a certain amount, you can start to try semi-original or original.

By then, you have accumulated a lot of materials in your mind, and it will be easier to draw.

I hope everyone can draw beautiful illustrations~

entry.title: Gestalt Principles - Making Design Easier (Part 1)
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

Introduction

Gestalt principles are a fundamental theory in design, widely used in many aspects of visual design and interaction design.

Let’s take a look at Gestalt principles to make design easier.

What are Gestalt Principles?

Gestalt is the transliteration of the German word “Gestalt”, which means form, shape, or structure.

Gestalt principles are actually a psychological concept, also known as Gestalt psychology.

Gestalt psychology mainly studies the visual and sensory fields, advocating the integrity of perception.

The human vision has a tendency to generalize and simplify graphics.

In other words, when we look at things, the eyes and brain work together.

It is not to distinguish the individual components of an image at the beginning, but to combine the various parts into a more easily understood unity.

Gestalt principles include multiple principles. Here we mainly share four of them: similarity, proximity, closure, and continuity.

 

① Principle of Similarity

The meaning of the principle of similarity is very simple, that is, elements that are similar in a certain aspect tend to form a whole.

For example, in the figure below, people’s first impression of this picture is 2 kinds of circles, not 15 circles.

This is because our eyes and brains automatically group the solid circles into one group and the hollow circles into another group.

 

People usually think of it as 2 kinds of circles instead of 15 circles

When elements are similar in shape, size, or color, the principle of similarity can work.

For example, in the figure below, we can easily distinguish between similar and different, and group similar ones together.

 

Group similar graphics together

② Principle of Proximity

The principle of proximity means that elements that are close in distance or position tend to form a whole.

As shown in the figure below, we will naturally think that these are 3 groups of circles, not 6 independent circles.

 

We will naturally think that these are 3 groups of circles, not 6 independent circles

Proximity is actually the primary principle of Gestalt, and its influence is so great that it can offset other principles.

As shown in the figure below, even if the shapes are not similar or the colors are not similar, as long as the distance between the elements is close enough, we will be more inclined to regard them as a group.

 

When the distance between elements is close enough, they tend to be regarded as a whole even if they are not similar

Generally speaking, proximity > color similarity > shape similarity. The arrangement of the three groups of patterns in the figure below can well reflect this point.

Therefore, in interface design, we often use the principle of proximity to distinguish large functional modules, and then use color similarity to distinguish states (such as selected states, etc.).

 

Proximity > Color Similarity > Shape Similarity

Application of Similarity Principle and Proximity Principle

In practical applications, similarity and proximity are usually used together.

The simplest principles are often the most powerful and useful. Similarity and proximity are widely used in various UI designs.

① Control Layout

The navigation bar, which is used by almost all apps, contains the principles of similarity and proximity.

Take the navigation bar of the “NetEase OA” app as an example.

The form and size of each group of tabs are similar, and users can easily identify that they belong to the same functional module.

At the same time, the color of the selected tab is different, highlighting its different state (this is also the reason why we often use color to represent special states such as selected states).

And when we analyze these, we actually default that these are five groups of elements.

Although the similarity between the icon and the text is very low, because they are close enough, we will default that they are a whole.

 

The control layout of the navigation bar cleverly uses Gestalt principles

② Functional Partitioning

In game interface design, proximity and similarity are also very important.

Because a game interface often contains multiple functional modules, proximity can help us perform functional partitioning.

For example, the deployment interface of Conqueror’s Blade.

We will separate different functional modules, so that the functional division of the entire interface is very obvious.

The most important deploy button is separated from other functional blocks, and the prominent size and color are used to make it easier for players to notice the button.

In the same functional module, such as the densely arranged information area on the left, the distance between rows is also separated to clarify that each row is the information of the same player.

At the same time, the similar icon forms and arrangement positions make it easier for players to identify similar information and compare information.

 

Gestalt principles help with functional partitioning within the game interface

③ Information Clustering

The principles of proximity and similarity can also help us cluster information and show the differences and connections between large amounts of information.

For example, the Soul interface of Conqueror’s Blade contains a lot of grid and icon information, which uses the distance between different grids for clustering.

At the same time, size similarity is used to enhance the distinction. The larger ones in the middle are the installation slots, and the two sides are the Soul libraries.

The principle of symmetry is also implied here. The symmetrical form will make people feel more comfortable and holistic.

In addition, the background pattern of the installed Soul and the background pattern of the slot are the same, which builds a connection between them through shape similarity.

 

Using Gestalt principles can show the differences and connections between large amounts of information

④ Use Containers

Sometimes there is too much information in the same interface, and there is no space to separate them.

In this case, in addition to using distance for clustering, we can also use “containers” to frame the same group of information in one area.

The container can be a background or a line.

For example, the tournament interface of UNO! needs to accommodate a large amount of information. In order to be able to clearly classify and display this information, we use different backgrounds.

In addition, the score panel here uses the principle of proximity to separate “Classic Single Player” and “Fun Single Player”.

Color similarity is used to distinguish between positive and negative score levels.

 

Gestalt principles can clearly classify and display large amounts of information

entry.title: Gestalt Principles - Making Design Easier (Part 2)
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Introduction

Gestalt principles are a fundamental theory in design and have been widely used in many aspects of visual design and interaction design.

Let’s take a look at Gestalt theory and how it can make design easier.

Gestalt principles include several principles. Here we mainly share four of them: similarity, proximity, closure, and continuity.

Principle Description
Similarity Elements with similar visual appearance are perceived as a group.
Proximity Elements that are close to each other are perceived as a group.
Closure Elements that form a closed shape tend to be grouped together.
Continuity Elements that have continuous or common movement direction tend to be grouped together.

The previous article has introduced the principles of similarity and proximity. This article will continue to explain the principles of closure and continuity.

Principle of Closure and Its Application

① What is the Principle of Closure?

Closure means that elements that constitute a closed shape tend to form a whole.

As shown in the figure below, we usually think there is 1 circle and 1 point, not 9 points.

 

We usually think there is 1 circle and 1 point in the picture, not 9 points.

There are three types of closure: shape closure, negative space closure, and experiential closure.

 

Three Types of Closure

A very classic example can illustrate both shape closure and negative shape closure.

In the figure below, we can identify two triangles.

 

Two triangles can be seen in the figure

Connecting the black borders, the resulting triangle is shape closure.

Connecting the outlines of the three black circle depressions, the resulting white triangle is negative shape closure.

Experiential closure, to a certain extent, relies on people’s existing experience, as detailed below.

② Application of the Principle of Closure

The principle of closure is often used in visual design to increase the sense of variety.

Applying the principle of closure in interaction design can express more information with fewer elements, making the interface content simple and not redundant.

  1. Truncation Design

Truncation design, which is very frequently used in UI design, is based on the principle of closure.

How can we let users know that a list is scrollable?

For example, the list interface of “UNO!” adopts two methods - truncation and paging controls.

At the end of the list, a part is truncated. Because of closure, we will naturally imagine a complete whole below through the remaining part, so we know that we can slide down to view.

In many cases, this method can reduce the use of controls and reduce the burden of interface layout.

And the three-level tabs here, because of their small area, using controls can better attract users’ attention.

 

The list interface of “UNO!” uses truncation and paging controls

  1. Whitespace Implication

Closure can also help us with cognition in some cases.

Clever use of whitespace will not affect our cognition, but can add more possibilities to the design.

For example, the game Sky: Children of the Light uses only a very small part of the arc to represent an entire planet, reducing the burden of the picture while having a sense of mystery waiting to be explored.

 

Clever whitespace can add more possibilities to the design

  1. Experiential Closure

The common tab design is a form of experiential closure.

The older tab design used a very realistic and complete closure form, similar to the tabs of a notebook.

 

The old tab design adopted a realistic and complete closure form

With the evolution of the visual style of the Internet, people have experience in using the Internet, so simplifying it to the form of only one line can also make users understand the selected state.

People will naturally regard the tab and the corresponding content below as a closed whole through their own experience.

 

Experiential closure allows people to easily identify the simplified tab style

Principle of Continuity and Its Application

① What is the Principle of Continuity?

Continuity means that elements with continuous or common movement directions tend to form a whole.

Human vision tends to perceive continuous forms in order to connect elements together, rather than scattered fragments.

For example, the dots in the figure below will be seen as lines bending in two directions.

 

We will see the dots in the picture as lines bending in two directions

Compared with the principle of closure, continuity emphasizes the guidance of direction, rather than beginning and end.

If some parts of a graphic can be seen as connected together, it is also easy to be seen as a whole.

By finding very small commonalities, we can connect two different elements into a whole.

For example, the letter H and the leaf in the figure below are two completely different graphics.

But even so, it can still be connected into a whole through curves and leaf veins.

 

By finding very small commonalities, two different elements can be connected into a whole

② Application of the Principle of Continuity

  1. Visual Guidance

The Around the World mode of “UNO!” is a basic application case of the principle of continuity.

The icons of each chapter are arranged continuously. It is obvious that they are extending backwards and can be slid backwards.

Without the arrangement of these icons, we might just think it is a static landscape picture.

 

The arrangement of icons in the Around the World mode in “UNO!” adopts the principle of continuity

  1. Establish Connections

Continuity can also help us establish connections to different UI elements.

For example, the personal goal interface of “UNO!”.

When we complete the task on the right, there will be an animation of a badge flying to the progress bar on the left.

This form can very clearly let users know that the increase in the progress bar on the left is composed of completing the tasks on the right. Clarify the connection between them.

 

Continuity helps different UI elements establish connections

  1. Form a Whole

Continuity can also help us form a whole.

Take McDonald’s two coffee posters as an example.

The coffees on the left are arranged continuously one after another, which will guide our sight to look down one by one.

And it also integrates the principle of closure, making them look like a cup of coffee as a whole.

The picture on the right is an arc-shaped arrangement, forming a feeling of C, which is the first letter C of coffee.

 

 

Both coffee posters adopt the principle of continuity

  1. Space Construction

Sometimes continuity can also construct some invisible lines, and these invisible lines can help us create a sense of space.

For example, the poster of “Call of Juarez: The Cartel”.

The guns of these people are pointing at others in a staggered manner, which will give us a feeling of lines crossing in space.

This can very well increase the sense of space and dramatic conflict of this static poster.

 

The principle of continuity constructs “invisible lines” and creates a sense of space

Sometimes in UI design, we can also use the orderly arrangement between elements to construct some invisible lines.

For example, the figure below is a concept design drawing of “Anthem”.

No borders or backplanes are used here.

Instead, it relies only on the alignment and continuous arrangement of text elements to form invisible lines.

This outlines the effect of 3D UI, which is very spatial and futuristic.

It also helps us focus our sight on the image in the middle.

 

The principle of continuity increases the futuristic sense of the picture and helps focus the sight

Conclusion

In addition to the four principles shared above, Gestalt principles also include simplicity, symmetry, common fate, experience principles, etc., and also have a wide range of applications.

As a basic design theory, Gestalt’s principles are actually very simple, and have been applied in many designs.

So why do we still need to understand these?

In many cases, we judge what kind of design is reasonable based on our own experience, but we cannot say the reason for this design.

Gestalt theory can provide a basis and guidance for our design, and give us a thinking framework;

On the other hand, it also provides a basis for us to elaborate and explain our own solutions, making our solutions appear more reasonable.

entry.title: Consistency Principle and Game Design (Part 1)
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Introduction

The direction of escalators in shopping malls is always consistent. It will not be the case that the escalator on the first floor is up on the left and down on the right, while on the second floor it is up on the right and down on the left.

Imagine how much inconvenience it would cause people if the escalators going up from the first floor to the fourth floor were all on the left, while the one on the fifth floor was on the right?

This reflects the consistency principle.

The Consistency Principle and Its Importance

1. What is the Consistency Principle?

Within the same product, the navigation methods, naming methods for the same functions, visual presentation of similar elements, and interaction rules for operational behaviors should be consistent.

At the same time, the product should also be consistent with common industry standards.

The consistency principle is ubiquitous in life and is also widely used in the field of game design.

2. The Importance of the Consistency Principle

For players, the consistency of interfaces and functions can greatly reduce the learning cost for players.

When players are familiar with the basic operations, they can quickly learn other systems and gameplay, reducing the sense of interruption for players in the game, thereby improving the player’s operational efficiency.

There are many games where we can “blindly operate” after our operational proficiency improves, and even form muscle memory, allowing us to enjoy the exciting battles in the game.

For developers, the consistency of the interface allows many art resources to be reused.

For example, the consistent style of buttons in the game allows designers to quickly reuse them without having to redesign them for each interface.

The same is true for programmers. The same functions can also be directly reused, reducing development costs.

In addition, consistency can help the game maintain a consistent style and form the game’s unique style and impression.

Moreover, for newcomers, they can quickly get started with the project according to development or design specifications, reducing learning costs.

The consistency principle is reflected in many aspects of design.

This article mainly divides it into four parts for introduction: visual consistency, text consistency, functional consistency, and special effects consistency.

Application of the Consistency Principle

1. Visual Consistency

Visual consistency is mainly reflected in the consistency of visual style and visual elements.

Here’s a concise example:

The following two games have a strong difference in visual style.

The cold gray atmosphere of Conqueror’s Blade is embellished with bright red, rendering a strong sense of war epic and history.

The high-purity colors of UNO! are cheerful, lively, and bright.

Each game has its own unique visual style, and when designing, it is also necessary to comply with the style attributes of the project itself.

Different games have different visual styles

Consistency also needs to be considered in the details of visual presentation.

For example, we often use red and blue colors in games to represent conflicting sides.

Sometimes blue represents the friendly side and red represents the enemy side; sometimes blue represents defense and red represents attack.

In the design of Conqueror’s Blade, there is a gameplay where two sides duel in the world, and other players can also join the battle. When joining, they need to choose a faction.

At this time, it is natural to think of using the red and blue colors of the duel to represent the two factions in the battle.

So the question is, what should the semantics of red and blue be?

The simplest solution is that red represents attack, but is it really appropriate?

In the Conqueror’s Blade World Pursuit Battle participation interface, red and blue represent enemy and friend, not attack and defense

To solve this problem, after re-examining the game, it was found that in the core battles of Conqueror’s Blade, red and blue always represent the friendly side and the enemy side, and have nothing to do with attack and defense.

Therefore, it was finally decided to maintain the consistency of color semantics, with blue representing the friendly side and red representing the enemy side.

So how do you determine the enemy and friend?

We have specially designed a set of calculation methods, which compare the initiator of the two sides of the battle with the player based on elements such as family relationships.

The relatively friendly side is placed on the left as the blue side, and the other side is on the right.

If the degree of friendship is the same, the blue side on the left is the defending side. After all, the pursued side should be more protected and supported.

In game design, it is necessary to maintain the consistency of color semantics

In addition, the font size, spacing, and positional relationship of the text in the game also need to be consistent.

We often set several font sizes for the game at the beginning of the design, which are used for titles, subtitles, and body text, respectively.

In most cases, the default font size and spacing will be used to ensure visual consistency, making it easier for players to quickly locate the information they want to know.

Font size, spacing, and positional relationships need to be consistent

In addition, the size relationship of elements also needs to be consistent.

This is mainly reflected in the use of icons and some materials in the game.

For example, at the beginning of the design, the size and style of the “unit cards” of Conqueror’s Blade lacked consistency. The position and proportion of the characters in the cards were different, and other elements were not kept in the same position and relative size.

After the later optimization, the size of the cards was clustered, and the overall visual feeling was more consistent, making it easier for players to form image memory and improve the player experience.

Conqueror’s Blade “unit card” iteration, element consistency optimization

2. Text Consistency

The style and semantic expression of the text also need to be consistent.

For example, the feedback pop-up window for errors should use the same language and structure when describing the same thing, otherwise it will cause players to pay higher reading comprehension costs.

For example, the text on the confirmation button cannot be called “OK” at one time, “Confirm” at another time, and “Got it” at another time, otherwise the player will have to react to the meaning of the button every time, causing a pause in the experience.

This unnecessary burden and pause are very unnecessary.

However, because this kind of pop-up window is spread all over the game, omissions and occasional inconsistencies often occur. More care and attention must be paid during the design.

Text needs to be consistent in style and semantic expression

entry.title: The Consistency Principle and Game Design (Part 2)
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

Introduction

Within the same product, the navigation methods, the naming of identical functions, the visual presentation of similar elements, and the interaction principles of operational behaviors should maintain consistency.

Simultaneously, the product should also maintain consistency with common industry standards.

This is the Consistency Principle.

Application of the Consistency Principle

The Consistency Principle is ubiquitous in daily life and is also widely applied in the field of game design.

This article mainly divides it into four parts for introduction: visual consistency, text consistency, functional consistency, and special effects consistency.

The previous article has already introduced visual consistency and text consistency. This article will continue to explain functional consistency and special effects consistency.

1. Functional Consistency

(1) Position

In games, key bindings are the premise of all operations.

Therefore, key prompts are crucial for novice players, helping them quickly get through the novice period.

The figure below shows two key prompts in Conqueror’s Blade.

The prompt order for skill releases of “QERT” is exactly the same as the key bindings, which players can quickly learn;

However, the prompt for the unit operation keys of “XCV” is a bit “awkward”.

Not only are the horizontal keys not displayed horizontally, but the order is also reversed.

Players need to repeatedly confirm the operation and the position of the keys during learning, which increases the learning cost.

In addition to the correspondence of key bindings, the position of identical elements in different interfaces should also be as consistent as possible.

Let’s take the position of the simplest and most basic “close button” as an example:

Generally, the position of the close button in the same game is the same. If one of them suddenly changes position, it will be difficult for the player to find this close button.

The figure below shows the deployment interface and the unit formation interface of Conqueror’s Blade.

One is to select soldiers to deploy for battle, and the other is to preset the combination of soldiers to deploy in advance, which is a bit like a deck-building system.

In the design, considering the user’s habits, try to unify the operation area for selecting soldiers in the same position.

In this way, players only need to learn one system and they will be “familiar at first sight” with the other system, making it easier to get started without additional learning costs.

The soldier selection operation positions of the deployment and unit formation interfaces in “Conqueror’s Blade” are consistent

(2) Interaction Method

Taking PC games as an example, mouse operations mainly include left-click, double-click, drag, right-click, and middle scroll.

These operations should also be kept as consistent as possible in the selection.

For example, in the armory (warehouse) interface of Conqueror’s Blade, players mainly use right-click and left-click drag to transfer items.

Therefore, the operation of disassembling and assembling the abilities of the unit’s soul also follows the operation of right-click and left-click drag, ensuring the consistency of operation, so that players do not need to repeatedly memorize two sets of operating logic.

The armory interface and the unit soul installation interface of “Conqueror’s Blade” use similar operating methods

2. Special Effects Consistency

It is often said that Apple phones seem to be smoother than Android phones, and Android phones always lag.

This is because the animation design of each app on Android is different, which gives people a feeling of fluctuating speed.

In contrast, slower animations seem to have slower loading speeds.

The iOS system is relatively more unified, so users will feel more comfortable and smooth.

Similarly, in the design of the game, for common animations, we should also establish a general animation library and animation specifications to ensure the unity and consistency of sound, animation, and special effects.

The figure below is the basic animation document of UNO!, which is convenient for quick search and reuse during design.

Basic animation document of “UNO!”

3. Inconsistency

The Consistency Principle does not always bring positive effects and a comfortable experience in all situations.

Therefore, at the end of this article, let’s talk about “inconsistency”.

Inconsistency is actually a dialectical way of using consistency.

Simply put, we make the same thing as consistent as possible, but two different things or similar things are made very “inconsistent” to help players distinguish and prompt.

For example, when buying items in the store, buying for yourself and buying for others seem to be the same purchase behavior, but they are actually different.

At this time, it is necessary to deliberately make the two “purchase” buttons very different to remind players that these two choices are different.

By making similar but different elements inconsistent in design, the consistency of the design is further highlighted.

《Conqueror’s Blade》 store purchase and gifting pop-up window

In addition, we can also create surprises for players through inconsistency.

For example, in Conqueror’s Blade, most of the system interfaces are in shades of gray and black.

Then, in the optimized design of the unit soul system, which is the main feature of the latest season, a very bright color representing the unit’s quality is used as the background, giving players a refreshing feeling;

At the same time, colors are also used to help players classify the categories and qualities of units.

The “ingenious” design of the unit soul details page in “Conqueror’s Blade”

Conclusion

Consistency is a very basic principle and method in design, and it is also a way of classifying and recognizing the world and processing complex information. It is very important for every designer and needs to be implemented throughout.

But it is a tool, not a shackle. It should not be followed rigidly during use, but the Consistency Principle should be viewed with a progressive eye, and it should be balanced and updated.

For example, design specifications should also be updated simultaneously as the design progresses, otherwise the guiding significance of the specifications will be lost.

At the same time, it is also possible to appropriately jump out of the norms and make certain innovations and breakthroughs, otherwise it is easy to make players feel boring and monotonous.

Under the condition of local unity, seek common ground while reserving differences, and make continuous progress.

entry.title: Interest Curves and Game Novice Guides (Part 1)
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

The interest curve was proposed by Jesse Schell in The Art of Game Design: A Book of Lenses.

In games, movies, or performances, interest curves are often used to record the changes in audience or player interest over time.

The novice guide of a game, in addition to letting players understand the basic rules of the game, is also the “face” of a game to attract new players’ interest.

Therefore, we can start from the perspective of the interest curve to analyze how to make the game novice guide quickly capture the player’s heart in a short time.

01 The Concept of the Interest Curve

We use the horizontal axis of the coordinate system to represent time and the vertical axis to represent the degree of interest.

According to Jesse’s theory, a good interest curve template will show the following form:

 

Example of a good interest curve in “The Art of Game Design: A Book of Lenses”

The degree of interest at point A represents people’s first impression of a segment, which is often influenced by rumors, advertisements, and other pre-promotion.

It quickly reaches point B.

Point B, as an exciting “hook” for the audience, gives the audience a happy signal and makes the audience look forward to the next paragraph.

After point B, the audience’s emotions gradually stabilize, and at point C, it reaches the peak of a paragraph.

The stability of point D then sets the stage for the next peak at point E.

At point F, it enters a gentle transition period again.

Finally, it reaches point G, reaching the climax of the entire segment, and ends the entire segment at point H.

As shown below, Jesse also mentioned two examples of interest curves that need to be improved.

 

Two examples of less-than-ideal interest curves

In Figure A, the highest point of interest does not appear at the end of the segment, which will give the audience a feeling of anticlimax.

In Figure B, there is a long period of dullness between two points of interest, which may easily cause the loss of audience or players during this process.

02 Examples of the Application of Interest Curves

Similar application cases of interest curves can be found in many works of art.

Let’s take the performance of “Big Bowl Thick Noodle” in the variety show “Sisters Who Make Waves” as an example:

There are 4 sections of opera singing in the whole performance, all of which are highlights.

If we arrange them according to the timeline, we can get the following interest curve:

 

The distribution of opera singing and the interest curve of “Big Bowl Thick Noodle (Sister Lang Version)”

At the beginning of the performance, Yu Kewei’s opera singing opening suddenly raised the audience’s expectations.

Then the two sections of opera singing by Zhang Hanyun are also the focus of everyone.

Finally, it is still Yu Kewei’s singing, accompanied by the chorus of other sisters, pushing the entire performance to the highest climax.

Similarly, this curve is also applied in many three-act movies, such as “The Shawshank Redemption”.

In the cause, process, and result stages of the movie, we can all see several plots that can stimulate the audience’s strong interest.

It is under the continuous advancement of “foreshadowing-climax-foreshadowing-climax-…” that the audience’s attention can closely follow the fate of the protagonist.

 

The plot interest curve of the movie “The Shawshank Redemption”

03 The Composition of Interest

Since we want to arouse interest, we must understand what constitutes interest.

In “The Art of Game Design: A Book of Lenses”, three main components of interest are mentioned:

(1) Inherent interest

Adventure, fantasy, specials, and reward mechanisms are inherently interesting.

(2) Artistic expression

That is, aesthetics in the game.

(3) Immersion

When players have a strong empathy for the tasks in the game, interest also arises.

Next, let’s talk about these three constituent points in detail with specific examples in the game.

1. Inherent Interest

In “Uncharted: The Lost Legacy”, the protagonist needs to go through a series of level challenges.

For example, jumping with the help of billboards, lurking with the help of cover, sliding on tall buildings, etc.

A certain degree of difficulty and thrilling pictures are already interesting enough for players.

In addition, there will be some calm and soothing passages between several levels, such as the dialogue between two characters, to avoid the appearance of interest points being too dense.

 

In “Uncharted: The Lost Legacy”, the protagonist jumps between billboards

 

In “Uncharted: The Lost Legacy”, the protagonist jumps onto the high wall and slides on the electric wire

In “Luigi’s Mansion”, a series of fright events and novel and fun interactive methods also give players a very strong interest.

While the player thinks the game is fun, they also memorize the game operation of using the flashlight to shine around.

 

In “Luigi’s Mansion”, Luigi opens the closet and is scared by the bouncing toy

 

In “Luigi’s Mansion”, the combination of vacuum cleaner and flashlight can pull objects closer or push them away

In the novice tutorial of “UNO Together”, the player narrowly defeats the system opponent with the advantage of one card.

This arrangement greatly stimulates the player’s interest in the game and gives the player a deeper impression of the game.

 

The opponent has also called UNO, but the player still wins

Artistic expression, immersion, and analysis of the application of interest curves in novice guidance will be detailed in the next article.

entry.title: Interest Curves and Game Tutorials (Part 2)
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

The Interest Curve was proposed by Jesse Schell in his book The Art of Game Design: A Book of Lenses.

In games, movies, or performances, interest curves are often used to record how the audience’s or player’s interest changes over time.

And the game’s novice tutorial, in addition to allowing players to understand the basic rules of the game, is also the “face” of a game to attract new players’ interest.

Therefore, we can analyze how to make the game novice guide quickly capture the player’s heart in a short time from the perspective of the interest curve.

01. The Composition of Interest

In The Art of Game Design: A Book of Lenses, three main parts that make up interest are mentioned:

(1) Inherent Interest

Adventure, fantasy, uniqueness, and the reward mechanism itself are all interests.

(2) Artistic Expression

That is, the aesthetics in the game.

(3) Sense of Immersion

When players have a strong empathy for the tasks in the game, interest also arises.

In the previous article, we have already understood “Inherent Interest”;

Below we will continue to introduce the other two main components of interest - artistic expression and the sense of immersion.

1. Artistic Expression

The aesthetics in the game are usually reflected in exquisite graphics, eye-catching special effects, excellent camera language, beautiful music, and cute little details.

These aesthetic enjoyments can also bring certain spiritual stimulation to players.

Taking the game Ori and the Blind Forest as an example, it firmly grasps the player’s heart in the early stage of the plot with its highly recognizable art style and excellent camera narrative method.

Cute Animation

At the beginning, Ori, the child of the Spirit Tree, falls into the forest and is picked up and adopted by the mother beast Naru.

The scene where Naru gently holds Ori in her arms is particularly warm in a dark storm.

In this way, the audience is brought to the first emotional high point.

 

Naru found Ori and held Ori in her arms

Ingenious Details

Naru takes Ori out to find food and makes a mark on the tree that has been picked.

This kind of small and clever detail, which is relatively secondary to the plot but can give the audience a knowing blow, is often very moving.

 

Naru takes Ori out for food and draws a small cross on the tree that has been picked

Excellent Camera Language

In the next paragraph, the Spirit Tree is severely damaged, and the entire picture darkens.

In the process of Ori going out to find food for the exhausted Naru, the shadows of the past reappear one by one at the location at that time.

This scene further intensifies the player’s emotions.

 

Ori goes out to find food for the exhausted Naru, and the past emerges

It should be noted here that low emotion does not mean low interest.

When the player’s emotions follow the game’s sadness or anger, it is often the peak of interest.

The Use of Light, Shadow and Tone

In the above scenes, we can clearly feel the changes in tone, light, and shadow in the three clips.

The quiet blue, the bright yellow-green, and the terrible dark red make the scene atmosphere very prominent.

In addition, Ori and Naru are always the brightest presence in the picture, allowing the audience to clearly focus their vision.

2. Sense of Immersion

When players empathize with the protagonist of the game, they will naturally have a strong interest in the fate of the protagonist.

Jesse mentioned that when players first come into contact with the game, the protagonist is a stranger to them;

If a good sense of immersion can be achieved later, the player will treat the protagonist as their friend, and even eventually bring it into themselves and empathize.

The game Florence does a very good job in terms of “sense of immersion”.

First of all, the game uses a plot that is highly consistent with the real life of most players.

Such a plot itself will give players a feeling of “you have me, I have you”.

 

 

Florence’s growth process

At the same time, immersive interaction can also make players empathize.

When Florence has problems with her boyfriend’s relationship, the player wants to put together puzzles and photos from Florence’s perspective.

When starting to put the puzzle together, the player will think that the two protagonists should sleep facing each other;

But after putting it together, it is found that the two are not only back to back, but also have irreparable cracks in the middle.

Similarly, when the player tries to put the photo together, the photo keeps drifting away, which can evoke the player’s inner melancholy.

 

 

Players can no longer repair the relationship between Florence and her boyfriend

02. The Embodiment of Interest Curve in Novice Tutorials

We can use the above three key points that make up interest to analyze the interest curve of a novice tutorial.

Super Mario Odyssey is a game that does a very good job in novice tutorials.

We measure its interest points from the three perspectives of inherent interest, sense of immersion, and aesthetics, and we can get the following curve:

 

The interest curve of “Super Mario: Odyssey” in the novice tutorial stage

The first peak point appears in the plot animation - Mario’s hat is trampled and torn by the boss.

The player’s interest is composed of the smoothness of the animation and the plot itself.

At the second peak - the hat ghost becomes Mario’s red hat, and the player shakes the switch handle to throw the hat forward.

The cute and immediate feedback and the near-real physical interaction make the game very interesting.

After the operation practice of Mario possessing the frog, it finally comes to the climax of the novice level - fighting the small boss.

The funny animation and challenging level design also push the player’s interest to the highest point.

Similarly, we can also see a similar curve in UNO.

Animation, preliminary rule guidance, and the final stage of actual combat drills constitute the nodes in the novice tutorial.

 

The interest curve of “UNO” in the novice tutorial stage

03. The Inspiration of Interest Curve to Game Novice Tutorials

Through the analysis of the above content, we can summarize that the interest curve provides the following three new thinking directions for analyzing the rationality of novice tutorials:

① Designers can analyze whether the setting of interest points of the novice tutorial on the timeline is reasonable from the time point, whether there is a long dull period that is likely to cause churn, or whether the setting time of the peak of interest is reasonable.

② We need to think about more directions that can be tried from the three constituent elements of inherent interest points, artistry, and sense of immersion, so as to make the interest curve better.

③ Understanding the composition of interest is also of reference significance to interaction designers:

Novel and fun interactions can touch players;

At the same time, immersive interaction can allow players to improve their understanding of the game and game characters in the process of interacting with each other.

entry.title: A Brief Discussion on Mechanical Elements in Game Design
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Introduction

There are many kinds of mechanical elements in games, such as mechanical characters, mechanical equipment, vehicle games, construction games, etc. This article will discuss them from two dimensions: the creation of a sense of mechanics and the enhancement of immersion.

“Sense of mechanics” refers to the player’s subjective feeling about the characters, items, scenes and other elements in the game, whether they feel that these elements are like machines. “Sense of immersion” is whether the player is easy to enter the “flow” state during the game, and whether there is an experience of “I have become a mechanical element”.

Game Category Strong Sense of Mechanics High Sense of Immersion
Strong World of Tanks Vehicles, Besiege Mechanical Structures World of Tanks, Titanfall 2
Weak Nier: Automata Protagonist, UNO Cartoon Wheel Nier: Automata, UNO

  • The vehicles of World of Tanks and the mechanical structures of Besiege have a stronger sense of mechanics than the protagonist of NieR:Automata and the cartoon wheel of UNO.

  • The wheel of UNO is only used as a lottery prop, and the construction of Besiege uses a God’s perspective. The sense of immersion is not as good as the other two games that directly let players control characters and tanks.

Creating a Sense of Mechanics

01 Following the Worldview Setting

The character above uses sheet metal structure and metal materials to reflect the sense of mechanics. From a realistic point of view, its design is not reasonable, and it is suspected of showing off force. But this design is in line with the worldview in the game, that is, a technologically advanced centralized society.

02 Detail Obsession

The same rich details, Warframe focuses on decoration; Frostpunk depicts the steel frame. These functional structures have stronger credibility.

03 Reasonable Structure

Form follows function. It can be seen from the appearance alone that the weapons and engines can rotate (“circle” and “sphere” shapes, meaning “rotation”). The internal structure explains the reason for this design from a rational point of view.

04 Obeying the Laws of Physics

In reality, it takes about 30 minutes for a warship to reach full speed. In the PC game, it is adjusted to about 30 seconds, which can still reflect the sense of cumbersomeness. In the mobile game, the ship turns while it is stationary, and it can even move, which is not realistic.

The pointer rebound of the wheel in UNO! is well handled, simulating the effect of a ratchet.

05 Interface Design and UI Design

Putting on the mech, the appearance and skills of the character change, and borders and hexagons appear on the edge of the screen. Changing or strengthening the mech will change the color and style. Although it is a simple design, it is “rough but reasonable”.

The difference between the pilot view and the Titan view is: In the Titan view, the skill bar in the lower left corner of the screen has changed, and at the same time, elements of the cockpit have been added to the screen. In addition, the shaking, footsteps and mechanical sounds when walking have been adjusted, and the Titan’s weapon interface has been added.

Gameplay and Sense of Immersion

Next, take “ship” as an example to discuss the sense of immersion in the game from the perspective of gameplay.

The coordinate axis below reflects the difference in immersion between these 3 games. Their core gameplay can be simply summarized as “displacement” and “action”.

World of Warships

Compared with the other 2 games, the gameplay is the simplest, only operating the warship.

  • Displacement - the forward, backward and turning of the warship;

  • Action - artillery, fish, consumables.

The object of the player’s operation is always the warship, directly creating the feeling of “I am driving a ship”.

Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flag

An RPG game with a naval battle mode. Players can switch between controlling the character or operating the ship (the character walks into or leaves the helm).

  • Displacement - the movement of the protagonist and the movement of the ship;

  • Action - the attack, dodge, etc. of the character, and the firing, collision, etc. of the ship.

During the stage of driving the ship, the object actually operated by the player is the ship, but the game uses camera movement and adds character animation to “deceive” the player.

In the animation, the perspective is close to the third person of the protagonist, and the animation of the protagonist turning the helm can be seen; when firing, the perspective needs to be adjusted to the side of the ship, and the player can see the animation of the protagonist steering (left) and the sailor firing (lower right) at the same time.

After introducing the element of “person”, it will make players feel that “I am operating the character, and the character is driving the ship”.

Fortnite

Similar to Assassin’s Creed, there is a switch between characters and vehicles.

  • Displacement - the walking and jumping of the character and the movement and acceleration of the ship;

  • Action - the attack, construction, and use of consumables of the character, and the attack and use of consumables while sitting on the ship.

Assassin’s Creed has a novice tutorial, and the two gameplays are slightly different in operation, while Fortnite directly uses the keys and perspectives when operating the character. One player can only choose to drive the boat (mainly considering displacement) or sit on the boat (mainly considering action, using weapons to attack), and the learning cost is low.

In the vehicle mode, the camera is the same as the normal mode, which further reduces the feeling of switching between the character and the ship. It is the game that is most like “I am operating the character” among the 3 games.

Methods of Designing a Sense of Immersion

01 The object actually controlled by the player is a machine

The previous article analyzed this point from the perspective of gameplay. If the control object is a character, but still needs to operate the machine, what will happen?

Players need to turn on the engine, light up the radar, and operate the rudder. This gameplay is suitable for business simulation games. The ship is not like a whole, but a combination of parts; The player’s attention is not on the ship, but on the character.

02 The player’s psychological feelings can be realized through guidance

The camera movement and character animation in Assassin’s Creed are examples of excellent use of this method.

  • We can also use the switch between pilots and Titans in Titanfall to illustrate:

In the first picture, players will feel that the Titan belongs to the pilot’s equipment;

In the second picture, the pilot and Titan seem to have become two independent characters in the game, and players can choose one to control.

The guidance method can adjust the sense of immersion in the game.

03 Switching control objects cannot bring cognitive burden

Assassin’s Creed and Fortnite, switching from controlling the character to controlling the ship is a positive case.

Metal Slug 1 is a counterexample:

In other levels, the shooting direction is the same as the moving direction, but in this level, it is opposite. If you want to shoot from right to left, the player needs to press the right direction key.

Because it uses the action of the gun (shooting), but matches the displacement of the character (opposite to the shooting direction), it may be a mechanism to increase the difficulty, but it does destroy the sense of immersion during the game.

How to design the mechanical elements in the game well is a huge topic. This article only makes some thoughts on the mentioned games from some angles. “Sense of mechanics” and “sense of immersion” are both ways to construct the game experience. I hope this sharing can bring you some inspiration.

entry.title: Sure: Server Opening Strategies for Multiplayer Online Games from a Big Data Perspective
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

What is GDC?

GDC (Game Developers Conference) is the world’s most influential game developer conference, held annually in San Francisco, and has a history of 35 years. Although tickets for the week-long conference cost up to $2,000, as many as 27,000 industry professionals attend in person, demonstrating its value and authority. The highlight of GDC is the non-sponsored keynote speeches. Each year, the organizers invite less than 300 presentations on average, divided into two categories: Core and Summit. These speakers are carefully selected and invited by the organizers and their global advisory committee. They are highly recognized by the industry for their high quality and innovation, and to some extent represent the current highest level and development trend of the game industry.

Since 2020, due to COVID-19, it has been changed to an online format. The 2021 GDC conference was held from July 19th to 23rd.

A presentation titled “Queuing: Let Data Guide Your Server Opening Strategy” was selected for this year’s GDC Online Game Technology Summit. This is the second time that NetEase Games Leihuo UX User Experience Center’s data mining team has been selected since its first participation in GDC in 2020. The presentation mainly discusses how to analyze the queuing mechanism from the perspective of game big data to assist games in flexibly adjusting server opening strategies and their application technologies. Two flexible server opening strategies are proposed in the presentation: “diversion” and “redirection”. The former avoids the risk of high server load by real-time monitoring and calculation of game queues and server logs, and opens servers in time to divert queues. The latter strategy is suitable for planned operational activity plans, combining player game portraits and players’ autonomous choices to direct players to designated servers in the plan, thereby bringing a better gaming experience.

The speaker is Sure from the data mining team of NetEase Games Leihuo UX User Experience Center. Today, Leihuo UX official website will give you an introduction.

As a senior data mining engineer, he joined the Leihuo UX data mining team as an intern in 2017 during his graduate studies at Zhejiang University, and took on the data mining work for the third test of Justice. His love for games and excellent data mining skills enabled him to grow rapidly during his internship and join the Leihuo UX data team. The first game he was independently responsible for data mining as a full-time employee was Lovebrush Chronicles. During the launch period of the game’s national server, with his data mining foundation, he took the initiative to undertake the game’s full-process data mining work, and helped the game launch smoothly. He then took on the data work for the game’s overseas version throughout its entire life cycle. Half a year later, he began to follow up on the PC version of A Chinese Ghost Story, during which he greatly optimized the PC game’s log processing process and established PC game log specifications, further ensuring data quality. The PC and mobile game work experience accumulated during his work was summarized into processes and specifications and widely used within the team.

Following the growth and expansion of Leihuo and the Leihuo UX team, in early 2019, he began to serve as one of the leaders of the data mining team, leading team members to be responsible for more game product data services, including A Chinese Ghost Story, Lovebrush Chronicles, Hyper Scape, Naraka: Bladepoint, UNO!, Revelation Online, MARVEL Duel, and more. “Data creates more game value” has always been the team’s goal. With the team’s unremitting efforts, the test and launch data work of game products has been successfully completed time and time again, and the player’s game experience has been continuously improved, helping game products achieve success.

 

Game: Naraka: Bladepoint

In addition to providing high-quality and agile basic data work, as the leader of the data mining team, he began to think about and upgrade existing businesses and expand new businesses. At the end of 2019, he participated in and led the data-side development of the new Tianyan BI data platform, which was officially launched. The platform launched a general BI module, integrated general logic, greatly reduced the development manpower of key indicators, provided richer visualization controls, and brought a standard data BI development model, which was well received by product owners after launch. Subsequently, he led the team to develop Leihuo UX’s self-developed recommendation system in stages, successively launching an AB test platform and algorithm services, which were applied to UNO!.

 

Game: UNO!

At the beginning of this year, he was successfully promoted to Data Mining Supervisor, and he is also one of the youngest supervisors to be promoted in NetEase in the same period. Let us look forward to his more achievements in the field of data mining and more active presence on the GDC stage!

entry.title: The Invisible Hand: Game Worldview and World Narrative
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Introduction

Literary works use words to express ideas, film and television works use images and sounds to convey themes, while games can both carry the content that words want to express and borrow the techniques of movies to create an immersive feeling. Games also have an irreplaceable advantage - players can participate in interactions and write the direction of the story themselves. As a game designer, how do you build this grand “virtual world”?

What Does Worldview Mean?

Games are the inner expression of the creators. Whether it is an independent game, a single-player game, or a commercial game, the design of the worldview is a crucial part. Its existence will set the tone for the game framework and will also guide most of the text creation and element design in the game. A successful game must have an excellent worldview to support it - like the “iceberg theory”, what we can see is only a part of the game creator showing to the players, and a larger part of the world is hidden in a deeper level, unknown to people.

Consistency of Worldview

A well-structured game worldview needs to be composed of various connections and meanings. When such a worldview is running, every part of this world will abide by its operating rules, and these parts can coexist reasonably. An excellent worldview, because the internal logic of its composition is too large, although it has a grand story background that can be tapped, it is almost never presented to players in a straightforward manner.

If a game designer wants to build a consistent worldview, the challenge they need to face is to “understand the internal connections of the world”. Just like the real world, the virtual world also has backgrounds in physics, history, politics, culture, and other levels. At the same time, it can also incorporate virtual elements such as science fiction and gods to add novelty to the game settings.

 

In The Elder Scrolls, the structure of the world has reached a very high degree of completeness. When players complete the main line, they have actually only explored a small part of the world. If you are a warrior, you can experience the faith of the Companions; if you want to become an Arch-Mage, you can go to the College of Winterhold to challenge yourself; you can also experience the arduous and exciting life of a thief, or enter the romantic world of a bard… In addition, there are many tasks unrelated to careers waiting for players to experience. Therefore, players will feel that this is a real world, there seem to be endless stories to experience, and it seems that they can always adventure.

 

It is not only plot games that need to construct a complete worldview. Naraka: Bladepoint, as a battle royale game, also insists on building a worldview IP during design. In the process of players experiencing the game, the background stories of different characters are different, and players can start to explore the world gradually from different branches of the story. By talking to different heroes, you can get fragments related to the background story. This makes players, after experiencing the exciting battles of the game, still have the enthusiasm to explore the game world.

Internal Logic of Worldview

In Europe, which has many mountains, few plains, and blocked land transportation, a maritime civilization that loves freedom and adventure has developed; in the two river basins with vast plains and a suitable climate, an agricultural civilization that is attached to the land has been nurtured. There is always a causal relationship between the development of time and space in the world, and the construction of the virtual world must also follow the rationality of logic.

When creating a virtual world, it is best to have the subconscious of cognitive principles and perceptual principles, rather than being too radical and subversive, challenging the player’s cognition, because it is very difficult to challenge the existing cognitive system to reconstruct logic. If you are not careful, the game will collapse in the player’s mind.

 

In Detroit: Become Human, the game company created a world where androids and humans coexist, allowing androids to have self-awareness, simulate humanity, obey human control, but also have the impulse to resist and escape. All settings are fantasies that are divorced from the real world, but they secretly follow the logic of the world line.

In the movie-like plot advancement, Detroit: Become Human prompts players to think about the balance between technology and ethics, as well as deeper social issues, racial issues, and political topics.

World Narrative

Everything in the game world tells a story, and players can learn about the history of the virtual world by exploring the space. The way of telling stories through buildings, scenes, sound effects, and things in them is world narrative.

The information that makes up the worldview is like pieces of a puzzle, each piece showing a small part of the world. Players collect pieces of information through continuous exploration. When the information obtained reaches a certain amount, they will build a basic understanding of the virtual time and space.

 

World narrative is not limited to the statements of words and characters, it is more about creating an “atmosphere” to allow players in it to get deep resonance. A devastated city can tell players that there was a war here; magnificent buildings can be associated with the prosperity of empires, royal families, and countries; secret underground organizations indicate that the local customs are strict, but there are still villains lurking in the dark.

Non-linear Storytelling

The narration of a world narrative does not have to follow a linear narrative method, that is, players do not need to follow a designated route to explore the plot during the game. This means that in the process of exploring the world, players have the freedom to explore the game according to their own behavioral logic. For example, during the game, players need to solve a mystery, and two clues are needed to solve the mystery. In the narration of the world story, no matter which clue the player finds first, it can guide the story to the final answer. In the process of exploration, other clues in other environments will also be used to learn about other information about the world.

In contrast, scripted stories rely on pre-made events to control the key process of the game. Scripted stories sometimes block all interactive behaviors, so too many scripted stories will destroy the game experience, but appropriate addition can allow players to better understand the main plot that the developer wants to convey and relax the player’s mood appropriately.

 

 

《Tomb Raider》 combines scripted stories with world stories; the sorting ceremony in 《Harry Potter》 is a scripted story

Therefore, the content of the world narrative allows players to experience it multiple times. Like the player’s cognition of the real world, in the process of multiple experiences, from rough to specific, slowly discover all the details of the event and improve the plot of the story.

Recording Stories Through Carriers

When we tell stories in an open world, since players can freely control the actions of the characters, they may make various behaviors that deviate from the expectations of the game designers. Therefore, in game design, various methods need to be used to restrict the player’s behavior, which makes game design more tricky and also increases the development cost. But world narratives are often events that have already happened, and no matter what choices the player makes, they are already established facts that cannot be changed.

With this advantage, world narrative has become an important tool for storytelling in game design, used to solve a large number of key problems caused by interaction. It can be described in words, for example, through various character dialogues and letters, postings, to convey information, it can also use sound instead of words, or be placed in some video carriers - news broadcasts, video tapes, street screens, etc.

 

Conclusion

The game industry is paying more and more attention to the design of worldview and story. To make a game that allows players to have an in-depth experience, the needs of functions alone are not enough. Game developers create a game world that is both real and illusory in various ways, creating flesh and blood beyond cold data, so that they can create works that touch people’s hearts again and again.

entry.title: When Players Say "I Don't Like the Game's Art Style," What Do They Really Mean?
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

In sentiment analysis, user researchers often encounter players giving vague, subjective feedback, especially in areas such as game art and story, such as: “I don’t really like the art style of your game”, “I feel the world-building is not good, not interested” … What’s more troublesome is that these feedbacks seem to be mostly “emotional output”, and cannot clearly point to problems that the product can perceive and ultimately form落地 (luò dì, meaning ‘grounded’ or ‘practical’) improvement measures.

Do players dislike the overall style? Or do they dislike the specific art or story design? Why don’t they like it? What targeted adjustments can the product make to reverse the player’s evaluation? If we want to understand these deep-seated needs behind players’ “emotional output”, user researchers need certain research methods to dig into their real thoughts, such as more detailed 1v1 interviews. How to do it specifically? This sharing will take the player’s evaluation of the game’s art style as an example to show you how to deeply understand the real thoughts of players by splitting and detailing the “art style” in the design and actual use of interview questions.

Deconstruction: Which Details in the Game Will Affect Players’ Perception of the Overall “Art Style”?

To understand what specific factors prompted players to give negative reviews of the game’s art style, the first thing to do is to deconstruct the relatively general term “art style”: when players evaluate the game’s art style, what modules and details will they think of? Based on past experience in art style research, we have compiled the following detailed elements:

Module Details
Overall Atmosphere Overall color, lighting, saturation, brightness, whether the elements are in harmony, etc.
Character Design Character modeling, clothing, accessories, body proportions, etc.
Scene Design Building modeling, special effects, color matching, etc.
UI Design Interface fonts, frame design, color matching, etc.
Animation and Special Effects Action fluency, special effects presentation, etc.
Other Whether it conforms to the world view, whether it matches the gameplay, etc.

With the deconstruction of all the module details that may affect the player’s evaluation of the game’s “art style”, in the questionnaire and interview question settings of the 1v1 art style test, we can design specific questions for these detailed points. For example, in a test on players’ art style evaluation, we carried out some detailed digging for product needs and some feedback points that players might have in the pre-test:

Question:

“Do you think the overall art style is acceptable?”

  • “Completely Unacceptable”
  • “Unacceptable”
  • “Acceptable”
  • “Can fully accept”

Follow up:

  • “What are the reasons for your previous choice?”

  • “What do you like about the art design of this game?”

  • “What do you not like about the art design of this game?”

Not only in questionnaire and interview design, but also in the final presentation of player feedback, user researchers also need to explore and summarize the details of different aspects, and strive to provide a complete blueprint for the product’s art improvement strategy. For example, in one test, overall, players were not satisfied with the game’s art style, but when analyzing player feedback, we found that players’ specific dissatisfaction with the game’s art could be roughly categorized into three aspects: in-game art, appearance art, and interface art.

Main Dissatisfaction Aspect Specific Issues
Combat Scene Art Scenes are monotonous, lacking atmosphere, character models and actions are stiff, special effects are not gorgeous
Character/Item Appearance Art Character models are not good-looking, clothing lacks characteristics, wings are too large
UI Interface Art Fonts are not beautiful, icons are not exquisite

Therefore, when providing suggestions for modification, we will also look for details of relevant competing products for reference according to the players’ art needs at different levels. For example, in terms of in-game art, we referred to some designs of Onmyoji and provided some more practical suggestions, including:

  • Adding scene interactions with the environment (Grass interactions, environment destruction)
  • Add Weather Effects, and have them tied into environment interactions (Rain effects)

Mining: Beyond Art Design, Factors That May Also Affect Players’ Style Evaluation

Some may think that as long as all the elements in the game that may affect the player’s art style evaluation are listed, the player’s one or several specific deep-seated needs can always be found. In fact, this is not the case. When evaluating some special styles, the influence of art design itself may not be as great as imagined. Instead, there are other things outside the game that may affect the player’s “first impression”. For example, in a research on the art style of a game with a Western fantasy background, a player said:

“I don’t really like the art style of this game… I can’t say exactly, I just don’t like it. I usually prefer to play games like Onmyoji.”

Although the player did not give specific art feedback suggestions, his words actually hid the reason why he did not accept the art style of the research game - the influence of other games. Obviously, the player’s game experience will shape his game art preferences to a large extent.

  • Players will have their own preferences that have been shaped by their prior experiences.
  • Different types of games will tend to have distinct styles.
  • If you are attempting to deviate, expect resistance from players who prefer a certain style.

The art preferences of players of different game genres are largely influenced by popular games of that genre. How to attract players of different genres into the game as much as possible and meet their art-related needs has become the focus of many game development teams.

In addition, other media or pop culture product experiences also affect some players’ art evaluation of some specific style games to a considerable extent. Still in this research on the Western fantasy background game, some players gave feedback like this:

“I don’t really like the art style of this game, I just think it’s very ordinary… I have actually seen the Lord of the Rings and the Hobbit series before, and I feel that some of the elements inside are too familiar…”

Obviously, the player buried a pitfall in this feedback. Does he accept the Western fantasy art style? If you only look at the first half of the feedback, the answer may be yes. But later, when he mentioned the Lord of the Rings and the Hobbit, a new question arose: if he can accept movies of this style, why didn’t he accept games of similar styles and elements? Obviously, behind this answer, there are still some deeper art needs waiting for us to explore.

In Conclusion

Whether it is the product or the user researcher, when facing players’ evaluations such as “I don’t like the art style” and “I don’t like the world view and story style”, they may be somewhat confused - where are their points of dissatisfaction? Do we really have such a problem? If so, what improvements should we make? In fact, we can deconstruct these general feedback points through forms such as 1v1 player interviews or research, and finally dig out the needs behind these dissatisfaction emotions. Here, the spirit of “getting to the bottom of things” is very important.

entry.title: Is Beauty Objective or Subjective? - Characters and Appearances in Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

In the 1999 International Varsity Debate final, the University of Malaya and Xi’an Jiaotong University brought a wonderful battle of wits to debate enthusiasts. Relying on “solid argumentation, quick thinking, and beautiful imagery”, the four swordsmen of Xi’an Jiaotong University were invincible, easily winning the national debate, and the topic of “Is beauty objective or subjective” also triggered reflection.

But let’s be a little more down-to-earth, take “beauty” down from the crown of philosophy, and put it in the more approachable game, will the conclusion change? This is also a question that many game products are concerned about: what kind of characters and appearances will be favored by players?

There is no harm without comparison

In Naraka: Bladepoint, female character appearances are more popular than male character appearances. Kurumi, with her rambling voice pack, is already half-way out of the circle. The phrase “Can you come and help Kurumi?” has penetrated deeply into the hearts of players. However, the popularity of female character appearances is not only related to the design of female characters, but more importantly, people’s aesthetics of men have changed.

 

Figure 1: Male and female characters in Justice Online

We may wish to list some of the characters of martial arts MMORPGs, it is not difficult to find that all the male characters in the game have long been out of the traditional martial arts image of the strong man, and move towards the direction of the celestial being. Just like the popular animated film Ne Zha, the image of the dragon prince is exactly like this (including Ne Zha after transformation). If the dragon prince is replaced by an image with a more martial arts flavor like Li Kui or Lu Zhishen, it is estimated that no one will ship them anymore.

As for the female image, foreign game manufacturers have begun to try to make a lot of changes. For example, Rob Gallerani, the game design director of the recent Diablo II: Resurrected, also said that the female Amazon warrior will be greatly modified in the remake. The new Amazon warrior looks stronger and more sturdy. The reason for this design is to make the Amazon female warrior look more like a warrior.

 

Figure 2: The original and remastered Amazon warriors

The same situation also appears in Horizon Zero Dawn, “Only for PlayStation”. Aloy goes from an unrecognized marginal character to a hero with a mission. Her agility and wisdom are no less than any male. The game strongly downplays the sense of gender in the tribe. Perhaps the development team hopes that players will feel the charm of the character itself, not her gender or appearance.

 

Figure 3: Horizon heroine Aloy

Such examples are becoming more and more common in overseas masterpieces, and these situations have indeed been resisted by some players. At this time, bring the topic back. The male characters of Naraka: Bladepoint did not take the route of the celestial beings in the previous domestic online games and single-player RPGs, but chose a more tough guy route, which is determined by the project team’s positioning of each character. But the result is that no matter how the style of fashion is designed, it will not be as acceptable as the female characters when placed on the tough guy role. This is a choice.

Unified Aesthetics, but Not Completely Unified

The above-mentioned is indeed the change of all the major trends, but people’s aesthetic preferences must be different. For example, men and women have different aesthetics for specific skins. For example, a costume called “Butterfly Dream” in Naraka: Bladepoint has reached the highest quality - red. As a red skin, whether compared with the red skin of the same level or with other appearances of Kurumi, the popularity of this appearance has not reached the expected level. Because as the highest quality skin, the developer certainly believes that this skin’s design sense, special effects and gorgeousness have reached the highest level.
