In order to reduce the load on the server, over time, the [Yume100] forum has the default rule of “no water posts, replies must be more than XX words.” Therefore, [Yume100] has gathered the most sincere and persistent standalone game players, where they conduct sincere game discussions, and through discussions and exchanges, the most core players are retained.

 

The Yume100 forum has strict requirements for the number of words in members’ posts.

 

In the Yume100 forum, you can often see members writing small essays to discuss female-oriented game related topics.

After the emergence of new social platforms such as Weibo, players of buy-to-play games also moved some of their discussions and social activities to Weibo and communities. On Weibo, you can buy and sell second-hand game cartridges, purchase in groups, or make friends with like-minded people in super topics with tags. In the search list of communities, by searching for specific words such as “otome game” and “standalone game”, you can also find many active groups of hundreds of people.

 

The homepage that is only responsible for the trading of standalone otome games has 36,000 fans, and the super topic of the same name is also quite active.

 

Specific word search, you can see many active standalone otome game groups.

 

Players introduce their game attributes on Weibo and make friends with like-minded people.

Players will make friends spontaneously through Weibo or communities. Only by playing the game will they have a common topic and maintain a relationship. Therefore, under the influence of this small circle culture, players will buy the game itself, complete the game, and communicate and interact with like-minded people.

6. Smooth Reading Experience Brought by Buy-to-Play

Unlike free mobile games, buy-to-play otome games often do not charge players any fees after paying the amount of the game itself. The phenomenon of script reading stalls caused by level-up and level-stuck in mobile games is uncommon in buy-to-play games. Players can reasonably arrange their time and read the plot content they like in one go. Many players often mind the reading stall caused by the bundling of plot and level in mobile games. On the way to wait for the upgrade, players may have forgotten the plot content of the previous chapter, thus interfering with the player’s immersive experience. The smoother reading experience is also the reason why players will choose buy-to-play otome games.

entry.title: Exploring Arabic Games: From Market to Development
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

In recent years, with the domestic game market approaching saturation, a large number of domestic manufacturers have turned their attention to overseas markets. Data from the “China Game Industry Report” shows that the overseas sales of domestic games have shown an upward trend in the past three years, and the growth rate is relatively stable. On the other hand, the goal of domestic games going overseas is no longer limited to the traditional East Asian market and the American market. Data shows that the proportion of the United States, Japan and South Korea in the overseas sales of domestic games has declined in the past three years, replaced by the Middle East, Central Asia, Eastern Europe and other previously neglected regions.

1. The Current Situation of the Middle East Game Market

The Middle East, also known as the main Arabic-speaking region. This area has always maintained a mysterious impression in the hearts of most people in China. The strong religious atmosphere and the very different language and characters have made domestic game producers discouraged.

But in fact, the game industry has considerable prospects in the Middle East. Soccer games represented by “FIFA” have good revenue in the Middle East, and the popular e-sports has become a competitive growth point supported by the Saudi government.

In terms of gaming equipment, console games are more mainstream in the Middle East, and PC games are also more common. The mobile game industry has only developed in recent years with the rise of smart phones. Currently, the mobile game market in the Middle East is still in the development stage.

In terms of game types, game players in the Middle East prefer European and American style RPG games, such as “The Witcher”, “Resident Evil” and “Assassin’s Creed” series, all of which have a considerable audience in the Middle East; while MMORPG and JRPG, which are more mature in the East Asian market, have not received good response in the Middle East market. However, this situation may improve with the rise of mobile games. Overall, the game preferences of Middle Eastern players are more similar to those of European and American players, but compared with European and American players, their acceptance of East Asian game culture is lower.

2. The Potential of the Game Market in the Middle East

Overall, the game market in the Middle East is still in a rising period. In this region, nearly half of young people are “digital natives”. They are accustomed to the use of electronic devices and smart software, which also gives them more opportunities to contact and understand various new software, including video games. In foreign video websites such as Youtube, there are many Arabic game review videos with millions of views, which is enough to prove the potential of the entire Arabic-speaking region in the game industry.

Another major factor contributing to the development of the game market in the Middle East is its payment model. In the Middle East, most game players have a relatively high level of education and are more proficient in English, and can directly experience the English version of the game, which also leads to the fact that the users of the entire game market have a strong ability to pay and do not lack the willingness to pay. The result is that the main way of game revenue in the Middle East comes from the high consumption of individual players.

Finally, the game industry and video game industry in the Middle East have also been licensed by the government, especially Saudi Arabia and the UAE, both of which have introduced policies to promote the development of the video game industry in their own countries.

3. Precautions for Game Development in the Middle East

Of course, there are still certain requirements for a game to enter the Middle East market. Compared with other games commonly seen in the domestic market, the design of games in the Middle East needs to consider two aspects: cultural environment and language environment. Only by approaching the usage habits and trend of the Arabic language ecology from two aspects can it be possible to break the cultural barriers and achieve success in the Middle East market.

Cultural Factors

When it comes to cultural factors, the differences in geographical environment are unavoidable: the climate in the Middle East is very dry, and there are basically no large rivers except the Nile. The landform is mainly desert, so there are rarely forest landforms in this area; at the same time, there are no high mountains in the Middle East, which makes the area often windy. In this case, traditional houses in the Middle East are mainly made of stone and are low in shape. At the same time, there are few crops such as rice and tea that require sufficient water in the Middle East. In Arab culture, the most common plant image is the date palm, and the most common animal images are camels and horses.

Therefore, in the more successful mobile game “Revenge of Sultans” in the Middle East, the appearance of the main SLG city has been changed. The traditional palace-shaped main city has been changed to a low shape similar to a mosque, and minarets and other buildings with Arabic characteristics have been added on both sides of the building. In terms of the general environment, “Revenge of Sultans” also adopts standard desert terrain, with vegetation such as date palm trees to show the characteristic features of the Middle East.

Another very important factor in the Middle East is the religious foundation. The entire Arab region and the Arabic language itself have been indelibly influenced by Islam. Religion has penetrated every aspect of Arab life. The crescent pattern has become a major symbol of Arab civilization, and the Islamic god “Allah” has become a unique existence in the Arab mythological system. Islam has only one god, which is reflected in the localization process of the game, that is, the conveyance of the concept of “god”.

In polytheistic mythological systems (such as Greek mythology, Roman mythology, and Japanese mythology), the number of “gods” is more than one, and different gods have their own duties. But in Arabic, there is only one word used to describe “god”, and this word can only be used to refer to Allah. Therefore, games often need to convert “god” to a certain extent during the Arabic localization process. For example, in “God of War 4”, in the game guide video made by Arabs, “God of War” is translated as “سيد الحرب” (meaning Lord of War). This translation is obviously to avoid religious problems.

Linguistic Factors—Arabic Player Interface Reading Habits

In terms of game design, the right-to-left writing order of Arabic often becomes the first threshold for game UI design. The right-to-left writing brings not only simple changes in text layout, but more changes in reading order. In the Arabic environment, readers are more accustomed to paying attention to the right side of the interface first, and then to the left side of the interface. Therefore, the interface design of Arabic websites is generally developed from right to left.

Take Al Arabiya, a Saudi news website, as an example. It can be seen that the headlines of the Arabic version of the website are placed on the right side of the screen, while the news with relatively low attention is placed on the left side. In addition, the magnifying glass icon of the search function is also opposite to other languages. Even for pop-up windows, the option buttons are arranged on the left side of the entire pop-up window.

In contrast, in the English version of the website, the headlines are adjusted to the left side of the screen, and all tabs are arranged in left alignment, including the top function interface, which also adopts a left-to-right layout, which is also the same as the interface layout of most languages that read from left to right.

In terms of English websites, the Arabic interface of YouTube has also made directional adjustments. Different from other websites, YouTube has also adjusted the direction of the pop-up of the functional interface to maximize the website experience of Arabic users.


Case Study of Game Experience Design Adapted to Arabic

In games, many manufacturers have also noticed the special features of Arabic and have taken special measures for the Arabic interface. Of course, these measures are often “compromises” made for this special language in localization to minimize the impact of the characteristics of this language on the overall game experience. In view of the right-to-left reading habit of Arabic, Arabic players tend to pay attention to the right side of the screen first, and then to the left. Therefore, some games designed in English or other left-to-right languages will avoid designing the interface according to the habits of their own language.

In the Arabic interface of “Resident Evil 7”, text prompts such as news reports and diaries are adjusted to right-to-left layout and centered on the screen, which is also the most common way to handle the Arabic interface in games.


《Resident Evil》 uses right-aligned text format for Arabic

But sometimes, simply adjusting the direction of the text cannot fully make the interface fit the usage habits of Arabs, especially when the text involves Arabic numerals. Although Arabic is written from right to left, numbers are an exception, and they still maintain the order from left to right. For example, in “Horizon Zero Dawn”, the item type number in the backpack interface is handled incorrectly. According to Arabic habits, the number 3 should be placed to the right of the quantifier عناصر.

Also in this game, in the column displaying the number of items, 20/20 is placed to the right of the quantifier مورد. This layout design is relatively more in line with Arabic reading habits.


《Horizon Zero Dawn》 Arabic backpack interface

Of course, some games did not consider the particularity of this language when localizing into Arabic, and directly used the previous UI, resulting in the interface not being aesthetically pleasing in Arabic. For example, the dialogue options in “The Witcher 3”, the option text of the English interface and the Arabic interface are left-aligned, causing the Arabic interface to deviate from normal reading habits.

The dialogue options in “The Witcher” remain left-aligned, making the Arabic UI look unaesthetic

4. Summary

Overall, the Arab game market, represented by the Middle East, is still in the initial and rising stage, with greater potential to be tapped; but in view of the particularity of the Arabic language itself and the cultural particularity of the Middle East, domestic game products still need to make certain adjustments in content when trying to enter the Arab market, so as to facilitate the promotion of products in the Arab region, especially in UI design, it is necessary to consider the right-to-left writing characteristics of Arabic.

entry.title: Where Did All the Mothers in Video Games Go?
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

There are countless classic characters in video games, but we rarely see profound mother figures in games, and we rarely see gameplay themed around mothers. Where did the “mothers” in video games go? This requires us to think and inquire from multiple perspectives such as psychology, the game market, and the industry.

1. Where Did Mom Go?

May 8, 2022 (today), happens to be Mother’s Day.

A few days ago, when I was preparing this article, I actually intended to write about the glorious mother figures in games. Maternal love is always touching, and I thought it would be the same in games.

It’s just that when I racked my brains to search for the games I’ve played, the impressive game characters were often fathers. Whether it’s Joel in The Last of Us series, Atreus and his God of War father Kratos, the good dad Ethan in Resident Evil Village, or Kiryu Kazuma and Arakawa Masumi in the Yakuza series, players either act as good dads to take care of children, or have a good dad to lead them to grow.

So where did the mothers in the game go? The conclusion is: they either exist only in the game’s database and text records, or they exit the player’s adventure early. The better ones may still be at home waiting for you to come back (like mom in Pokémon), or send you a letter or some small specialties from time to time (like in Animal Crossing & Story of Seasons); the worse ones may die in childbirth at the beginning, or die soon after as a plot device (Tomb Raider, God of War).

 

In Animal Crossing, Mom will periodically send letters to the player.

Game developers seem to be finding ways to eliminate the role of mother from the game, as if mom is the biggest BOSS in the game. It makes me ask:

Why do we rarely see the image of “mother” in video games?

2. Archetype Theory in Psychology and Player Experience

People’s perception of the image of “father” and “mother” is often influenced by “stereotypical” images in dramas, legends, and literary works. This subconscious perception of “father” and “mother” is a common phenomenon in different social cultures. The psychology giant Carl Jung defined such a collective subconscious or unconscious cognition of human beings as an “archetype”.

The “archetype” of the father represents an authority figure, strict and powerful; while the “archetype” of the “mother” represents love, care, enthusiasm, compassion, and tolerance. In layman’s terms, when we mention or see “mother” in works, we can often associate it with a gentle, amiable, hardworking, and understanding mother figure wearing an apron. When we think of “father”, we are more likely to portray a serious, unsmiling, tall, and powerful middle-aged man. This is the influence of “archetypes” on us.

In the field of games, most 3A masterpieces tend to bring players exciting adventures or adrenaline-pumping excitement, creating a sense of “insecurity” for players in terms of plot or gameplay. In the design of companion characters, if the player is always accompanied by a mother during the adventure, this sense of insecurity will be largely eliminated—it is difficult for us to imagine that when we are fighting with monsters, there is a mother next to us who keeps nagging “This is too dangerous, come home with me” or the mother steps forward to block in front of you and help you deal with all the problems. I’m afraid the game experience will not be very good.

In the design of the player’s own character image, the “father” image is often more favored by game producers than the “mother” image. Because the image of “father” often symbolizes a guide and strength, which is very consistent with the character image that game producers hope players can experience, and also conforms to the main line of the game that allows players to become stronger in RPG and other games. For example, in The Witcher we play as Geralt, relative to Ciri; in God of War, we play as Kratos, relative to Atreus; Lee in The Walking Dead, relative to Clementine, all are “carrying the burden of tradition, shouldering the dark gate, letting them go to the wide and bright place”.

Therefore, the comfort and coziness brought by the mother image is incompatible with the rebellious and adventurous spirit advocated by most video games, just like a 13-year-old rebellious teenager and his mother.

Of course, not all games use the father’s role as the protagonist. UNDYING for example. Under the ravages of zombies, you, as the protagonist Anling, resist the virus while taking care of your young child Cody in a difficult environment. What the game wants to express is not the common survival and adventure, but the greatness of maternal love. Therefore, it is reasonable to use the mother as the protagonist.

 

The Game UNDYING

3. Target Audience and Game Types

Another very intuitive but very important factor is the target audience of the game.

In the traditional video game market, male players are often the mainstream. Therefore, for most game manufacturers, it is a very natural thing to target male players and launch male protagonists.

Furthermore, many of the internet-addicted youths who used to be in arcades or using NES, Windows 95 or Windows 98 are now fathers. NGA, the main base of World of Warcraft players, has also gradually opened up a parenting section in the past few years. The former guild leaders are asking around in the section what kind of milk powder is best for their children. The former 24-hour online internet cafe teenagers complain about their less than one hour of game time every day. These players are still an important audience for games, so we can often see classic game works of “male mothers”.

Conversely, in those purely female-oriented games, or games with a large number of female players, and games that pay more attention to the female game market, the mother element is often more profound. This is more common in many social MMO games or simulation games that focus on life simulation. For example, in Justice Online, there is a baby-raising gameplay, where female characters can be pregnant for ten months and finally give birth to their own baby, becoming a veritable “mother”. Players not only need to pay attention to their physical condition during pregnancy, but also need to help them grow even after the child grows up.

 

The baby-raising gameplay added in the “Wulin Mengzhu” expansion of Justice Online

In simulation games, it is even more straightforward. Be My Mom on Steam brings you a one-stop experience of being a mother from pregnancy, childbirth, preparing milk powder and diapers, cleaning poop, and creating a baby room. In addition, there will also be some games that are not “mothers” in name but are almost the same as playing mothers, such as the popular casual game Travel Frog a few years ago. Players prepare the frog’s travel backpack, and the frog sets off on its own. You don’t know when it will come back, and you’re not sure what it will bring back to you, which gives people a feeling of “before leaving, the dense stitches, worrying about the late return”.

 

The game Be My Mom

4. The Perspective and “Selfishness” of Game Practitioners and Producers

The last point that has to be admitted is that many games are also largely influenced by game practitioners or producers in the choice of mother or father roles.

The Yakuza series has many classic good dad-type characters, such as the classic protagonist Kiryu Kazuma. But if we want to find a memorable mother figure in the game, you will suspect that the worldview of Yakuza is that men have children. For the reason for this phenomenon, when we see the photo of the producers of the Yakuza studio, we will generally understand.

 

Group photo of the new Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio

A domestic report disclosed by Gamma Data in 2017 also showed that the number of male game practitioners is about three times that of female game practitioners. The male-dominated game industry naturally cannot avoid the trend of male perspectives dominating game production. It is difficult for these rough men to tell a story about mothers, unless the company’s leader is Patrick Star.

Of course, the gender bias of game practitioners themselves is one reason, and the “selfishness” of individual producers often also affects the amount of mother or father elements.

Neil Druckman, one of the producers of The Last of Us, became a father during the game’s production. He also frankly stated that his daughter gave him great inspiration in portraying the “father-daughter” relationship between Ellie and Joel. He realized the importance of family and was “willing to do anything for his daughter”, which also affected the development of the game’s related plot.

Cory Barlog, the producer of God of War, also said in an interview that he projected his own image onto the protagonist Kratos. He is usually busy with work and cannot be with his children. Any parent will feel confused about how to educate their children and is always looking for changes, just like Kratos and Atreus in the game. In addition to the father, the image of the mother will also be affected by “selfishness”. On Mother’s Day in 2020, Paradox uploaded a promotional video for its upcoming game Empire of Sin on its YouTube channel. The reason for choosing Mother’s Day for promotion is that one of the female mafia godmothers in the game is based on the great-grandmother of the game producer Romero couple - they want to commemorate their great-grandmother in this special way and express their respect for Mother’s Day.

5. Conclusion

All in all, the reasons why we rarely see the existence of mother figures in games are: on the one hand, many games themselves are not suitable for the existence of “mothers”. The sense of security and attachment that “mothers” bring to players is incompatible with the adventurous and rebellious spirit of video games; on the other hand, it is also the choice of the game market. The male-dominated game market also determines that the “mother” element is difficult to resonate with and be substituted by players; finally, the gender differences of game practitioners themselves and some selfishness of game producers also inevitably affect the overall design of the game.

However, in recent years, as the gender ratio of the game industry and the game market has gradually become balanced, more rich and diverse game types and themes have emerged. The high wall that keeps “mothers” away from games is constantly collapsing. We have indeed seen more and more “mothers” shine in games, and more and more games have begun to design gameplay with a mother’s perspective. Whether it’s Ana in Overwatch or Mad Maggie in Apex Legends, game producers are also practicing such a truth:

Video games themselves do not exclude the existence of “mothers”. Whether the image in the game is “mother” or “father” is determined by what kind of experience the player wants to have.

 

Character in Overwatch: Ana

 

Character in APEX: Mad Maggie

If one day we want to experience a warm and comfortable journey in the game, it is not impossible to join a nagging mother to accompany you.

Finally, I would like to dedicate this article to all mothers in the world, Happy Mother’s Day!

entry.title: Online Intimate Relationships and In-Game Purchases
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

We have a lot of interpersonal relationships in real life. Besides ourselves, we have parents, siblings, relatives, partners, children, friends, and other relationship chains. If we compare ourselves to a small stone, throwing this stone into the water, the ripples that spread out are people with varying degrees of intimacy with us.

In academic research, there are two types of intimate relationships: broad intimate relationships and narrow intimate relationships. Broad intimate relationships include parent-child relationships, kinship, friendships, partner relationships, and so on. Narrow intimate relationships in academia refer more to partner relationships, that is, the two parties in the relationship are lovers.

This article mainly focuses on narrow intimate relationships, introducing how online intimate relationships are formed, consumption affected by intimate relationships, and its inspiration for user research. At the same time, for many people, partner relationships have a very strong impact on people’s lives and happiness (Berscheid and Reis, 1998) - this kind of intimate relationship with a partner can be said to be one of the most important relationships for people.

1. Online Intimate Relationships and Intimate Relationships in Games

With the Internet now deeply penetrating thousands of households, communication through the Internet has become very common. And this communication is not limited to the traditional sending and receiving of messages, but extends to the sharing and display of personal unique messages and the establishment of online interpersonal relationships with others. People on the Internet may be a replica of their real life, or they may be very different from themselves in real life. Some people are even more “socially phobic” in real life, but they are like fish in water on the Internet and can find friends more easily.

In this case, online intimate relationships have also emerged. Perhaps, this phenomenon can be crudely explained as “online dating.” Online intimate relationships are different from intimate relationships in reality. On the Internet, the two parties in an intimate relationship may not have met, but the Internet provides them with a place and scene for communication.

How do online intimate relationships form? Some studies have shown that online intimate relationships reflect a spiritual intimacy. They are willing to reveal themselves to each other and share their worldview (Merkle and Richardson, 2000). On the Internet, due to the existence of anonymity, people tend to reveal themselves more when they meet strangers than in real life, and feel more comfortable expressing themselves to others than in real life. More self-disclosure lays the foundation for the development of online intimate relationships. When the two parties get to know each other in constant self-disclosure and establish a sense of trust, it will make their feelings more intimate. In general, the Internet provides channels and scenarios for both parties to show themselves to each other. People can show what they are like to each other according to their own ideas, which on the one hand pleases themselves, and on the other hand also promotes the budding of the relationship between the two parties.

The formation process of online intimate relationships also has obvious drawbacks. What both parties reveal to each other is what they want the other party to see, that is, there is some beautification behavior. Under the beautification behavior, both parties will form a more positive impression of each other. In addition to the information sent may be beautified, the person receiving the information may also beautify this information, constructing a perfect image in their mind.

The intimate relationship in the game is a typical online intimate relationship. Games provide players with a stage to show each other. Players complete various tasks in the game. They will clear a certain dungeon together, fight a small/large battle together, explore the entire game world together, and take photos at beautiful scenic spots together. Games not only provide players with the opportunity to reveal themselves, but also create some content for self-disclosure that other online intimate relationships do not have. That is, game players can show what kind of people they are through the game, and the game itself is also the content they display - PVE commander, gang leader, puzzle solver, etc. The game enriches the connotation that people can reveal.

 

In addition, many games, especially MMOs, also provide “official endorsement” for online intimate relationships. Players can form couples or even marry in the game, making the intimate relationship in the game more solemn.

2. Intimate Relationships and In-Game Purchases

Intimate relationships can influence users’ purchases to a certain extent. For example, we often see couples buying couple outfits, couple accessories (such as couple rings, mobile phone cases), and using couple avatars to show their partner relationship with their significant other. In psychology, we use the consistency pursued by both partners to explain this phenomenon, that is, the two parties in an intimate relationship use consistent things to show their intimacy. The same is true in games. Many “couples” in games will show their couple relationship by purchasing men’s/women’s fashion of the same series, purchasing the same accessories and pendants, and using couple names that are antithetical.

In this case, the game will also set up corresponding content to meet the consistency pursued by both parties in the intimate relationship. For example, Justice Online will release matching couple outfits for men and women on Valentine’s Day, Qixi Festival, 520, and other important lover’s festivals, which has been well received by players.

 

 

Justice Online’s 2021 Qixi Festival Outfits

 

Justice Online’s 2021 ‘520’ Outfits

But do both parties in an intimate relationship always pursue this consistency? Not necessarily. When the two parties in an intimate relationship become more and more intimate, they will regard each other as part of their self-awareness, that is, the two people are one. In this case, they will involuntarily complement each other when making purchases. For example, in the game, one party already owns pet A. In the eyes of the other party, they, as a whole, both own pet A. Therefore, in the following choices, they will tend to buy pet B or other things. Because in the eyes of the other party, he/she already owns pet A, so he/she will not spend resources on repeated purchases, but will buy others to enrich the items they all have.

Here is an example of a friend’s intimate relationship, not a couple’s relationship, to illustrate. For example, Justice Online launched seven clothes with the same style but different color schemes on Double Eleven in 2021. Many “sisters” in the game each own one. The “Seven Fairies” standing together include all color schemes, which is very eye-catching. Each member psychologically believes that they have more than one, and the ownership of friends satisfies the player’s psychology to a certain extent.

 

So when we as user researchers study this situation, we must pay attention not to look at the problem with a single eye, but to combine the factors that affect the behavior of intimate relationships, such as the intimacy between partners, the characteristics of the product, etc., and consider the real needs of both parties. When they will tend to consistent consumption and when they will tend to complementary consumption, there are different answers in different scenarios.

Finally, the intimate relationship that this article focuses on and discusses is a narrow intimate relationship. From a broad perspective, parent-child, kinship, friends, etc. are all within the scope of intimate relationships. They are also affected by intimacy and other factors to a certain extent. Will affect the behavior of users/players. These interpersonal relationships can more or less find a correspondence in current online games - such as sworn brothers, fixed teams, gangs, etc. commonly seen in major games. Therefore, broad intimate relationships are also worthy of attention for user researchers, especially game user experience researchers.

entry.title: Automation in Practice - Procedural Content Generation
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

GDC 2022

From March 21st to March 25th this year, GDC 2022, the world’s largest, most authoritative, and most influential professional summit in the global game industry, was grandly held at the Moscone Center in San Francisco. In this year’s GDC, Leihuo UX was invited to give 17 presentations, distributed in 9 core presentations and 8 summit presentations, once again breaking the record of the Chinese game industry and leading the world.

This article introduces the presentation “Automation in Practice: A Guide to Procedural Content Generation” by Zhou Yi, Senior Data Analyst at Leihuo UX, and Tianpeng, Data Mining Engineer at Leihuo UX.

Problems We Encountered in Game Development

When generating content and terrain for games, we encounter multiple problems, and these problems are likely to exist in many game design processes. For example, players always complain that the map design is unfair, the spawn points are unreasonable, the resources are unbalanced, and so on. For another example, given two maps, how to compare which map is better and fairer to both sides? Under a specific map, is it still fair if the two teams have different numbers of players? Is it easy to obtain items at the beginning? What size of the map can ensure fairness? Which random generation algorithm to choose? These are all likely to exist.

The above summarizes the problems encountered in the generation of random content (such as maps). Next, we will explain how we use mathematical methods to achieve automated content generation from the perspectives of practice and simulation programs.

In practice, from spawn point settings to map item placement, it will greatly affect the initial growth of players. The growth of players in the middle and late stages of the game mainly depends on the players’ own skills. Therefore, in order to reduce the interference of irrelevant factors (such as the operation and skills of different players), we will compare the effectiveness and fairness of the map in the early stage of the game. Comprehensive simulation experiments are an effective way to test these hypotheses, and the method of controlling variables is the key to simulation experiments.

The Simulation Experiment We Designed

In order to conduct simulation experiments, we designed a program. The background of the program is that two teams (red team and blue team) mine gold mines on the edge of a snow mountain, and both the gold mines and the snow mountain are algorithm-generated. The red team randomly spawns in the west (i.e., the left half), and the blue team randomly spawns in the east (i.e., the right half). Each team member uses the same pathfinding strategy. The game ends if the two teams meet (i.e., early stage) or the gold mine resources are exhausted. When the two teams meet for the first time, they may fight or share gold mine information, which will bring the game into the middle and late stages.

Why do we use data from the early stages for experiments? First, these data are relatively easy to interpret, and the experimental results can be better applied to the application. In addition, the time-consuming of a single experiment is also a factor we consider. The faster a single experiment is, the more experiments we can do.

 

The Mathematical Model We Designed

 

In our mathematical model, the difference in gold coins obtained by two teams in a single game can reflect the difference in spawn points and resource locations, because they all use the same pathfinding method. The variance of the gold coin difference caused by thousands of games can reflect the stability of the map; the expectation of multiple experiments can reflect the fairness of the map; the variance of different maps can compare the quality of the map; the variance of different random generation algorithms can compare the effectiveness of the map.

Let’s look at the following two maps, one with snow mountain piles and gold coin piles, and the other with only scattered gold coins. Can you directly see which map is more beneficial to the red team (born in the left half area)? Through our mathematical model, we do 3,000 experiments on each map, and we can now get the density map of the gold coin difference between the red team and the blue team.

 

After our model analysis, Map 2 is symmetrical about the zero point, and it is more stable because the curve is narrow and high. Map 1 is not symmetrical, although its peak is zero. In addition, Map 1 has multiple peaks, and we can roughly see that Map 1 is more beneficial to the blue team. Now, we can do a Z-Test to verify this hypothesis: Map 1 is more beneficial to the blue team.

 

After the significance test, we know that the hypothesis is correct, that is, Map 1 is indeed more beneficial to the blue team.

Ways to Make the Map Fair

We did a few things. First, we tried to determine the map size and team size. Generally, the larger the map, the smoother the curve, that is, the smaller the variance of the gold coin difference between the two teams, indicating that the stability of the map is higher.

 

On the other hand, as the number of red team members increases, the result is more beneficial to the red team; and as the number of blue team members increases, the result is more beneficial to the blue team. It can be seen that the number of people can indeed change the fairness of the map. This also answers the questions we raised earlier. The following table shows the μ values under different team sizes, where rows represent the blue team and columns represent the red team. It can be seen that most of the values in the table are negative, indicating that in most cases, the map is beneficial to the blue team.

 

In addition, we also designed a pathfinding algorithm, specifically referring to the strategy by which each person in the team finds gold coins, because the coefficient indicators of pathfinding may affect the final result of the experimental model. For the reliability of simulation experiments, when considering pathfinding strategy coefficients, at least 5 principles should be referred to: Everyone (AI) is always greedy for obtaining gold coins; they do not always follow a fixed route, but the randomness is limited; everyone uses the same pathfinding algorithm; they have a certain ability to escape traps; and they conform to human behavior characteristics. The following is a pathfinding strategy coefficient we designed. You can also design your own algorithm, but you need to consider these 5 principles when designing.

 

And, we designed a random generation algorithm. The function of the random content generator is to generate obstacles, reward items, and so on. The mainstream algorithms are uniform distribution selection, Perlin noise, Fractal noise, etc. Here, we take uniform distribution as an example to illustrate how the random content generator works. The first step is to generate a matrix of the same size as the map, and each value is sampled according to a uniform distribution between 0.0 and 1.0. The second step is to traverse all elements of the matrix and get the positions with the largest k values. The third step is to display gold coins (or snow mountains) at these k positions.

The figure below shows the gold coins generated by the uniform distribution selection algorithm. The left side is the value of the matrix, and the right side is the position of the gold coins.

 

The figure below shows the snow mountain generated by Perlin noise.

 

The figure below shows the snow mountain generated by Fractal noise.

 

Summary

Now that we have the mathematical tools, how can we automate the content generation process?

First, design the map scale, reward quantity, obstacle quantity, and player quantity according to expert knowledge. Step two, set our indicator baseline, for example, sigma cannot exceed 30. Step three, define the “early stage”. Step four, choose the appropriate random generation algorithm. Step five, generate multiple simplified maps. Step six, conduct thousands of simulations on these simplified maps. Step seven, calculate the indicators. Finally, accept maps that meet the baseline.

entry.title: Leihuo UX | GDC 2022 Presentation Transcript: The Art of Hair in Games - Aesthetics and Production for Eastern and Western Players
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

GDC 2022

From March 21st to 25th this year, GDC 2022, the world’s largest, most authoritative, and most influential professional summit in the game industry, was grandly held at the Moscone Center in San Francisco. In this GDC, Leihuo UX was invited to give 17 presentations, distributed in 9 core presentations and 8 summit presentations, once again breaking the record of the Chinese game industry and leading the world.

 

This article introduces the presentation “The Art of Hair in Games: Aesthetics and Production for Eastern and Western Players” by Leihuo art expert Nora & Leihuo UX game user researcher Alex. The following is the transcript of the presentation.

 

Foreword

When we make next-generation games, we often pay great attention to the effect of character presentation, and hair is a very important part of it. Interestingly, many games with Eastern themes and games with Western themes have many aesthetic similarities and differences. We have compiled some interesting feelings and experiences to share with you. There are many interesting points, and this presentation will focus on the aspect of hair.

Similarities in Eastern and Western Hairstyle Aesthetics and Design

From the perspective of art design, hairstyle design is implementable. Whether it is Eastern or Western, the design of hairstyles will be extracted from the elements of actual hairstyles in life for secondary creation. For example, braids and short hair. In Justice Online, some design elements are also extracted from daily life styles. Everyone can feel that, whether it is Eastern games or Western games, the design and aesthetics of hairstyles are not fabricated out of thin air, but are created using elements from reality. In terms of technology application, the mainstream is also to use hair card technology to make hairstyles. With the improvement of hardware, some games also use dynamic hair simulation technology to show better effects. These technologies are based on the workflow of hair strands, so that the created hairstyles are displayed with real-time simulation effects.

 

 

Differences in Eastern and Western Hairstyle Aesthetics

If you have visited ancient Chinese and Western classical paintings in museums, you will find that the two are completely different systems. Relatively speaking, Western classical painting focuses on light and shadow, perspective, and anatomical structure, expressing the material world and entities. It can be said that Western aesthetics mainly lies in reproduction, and it attaches great importance to the beauty of realism.

 

Relatively speaking, ancient Eastern paintings are more of an expression of personal feelings than a depiction of the real world. For example, the Chinese national treasure “A Thousand Li of Rivers and Mountains”, we can feel the beauty of mountains and rivers from the paintings, but it does not completely conform to light and shadow, perspective, and structure, which is the expression of lines and feelings that Chinese painting emphasizes. Due to this difference between Eastern and Western aesthetics - the reproduction of reality and the expression of emotion, it has caused differences in the aesthetics of hairstyle design in Eastern and Western themed games, and also the differences in the acceptance of hairstyle aesthetics by players. Therefore, Western-themed games pay more attention to the rationality of hairstyles during the protagonist’s fighting process. Many Eastern-themed games will pay more attention to the silhouette, contour, and beauty of the shape.

 

Four Key Considerations in Game Hairstyle Art Design

After talking about some discussions on aesthetics, we will now enter another major module of our presentation, which is also the four key considerations of our team in game hairstyle art design, that is, how can we better implement interesting and beautiful hairstyles in games.

Part 1: History - Experience

Hair has completely different manifestations in different historical stages, becoming more and more refined and diverse. Hairstyles can symbolize personal identity, status, culture, etc. In game design, we can make full use of hairstyles with characteristics of the times and history to better tell stories.

The design of hairstyles that conform to the background of the character’s era in the game can give players a good immersive experience when they first enter the game, and they will not feel out of place. This historical immersion is not only well represented in games with Eastern themes, but also in many other cultural themes. For example, the hairstyles in Assassin’s Creed Origins show that players know that the story background of this game is in ancient Egypt without any text introduction. Similarly, the hairstyles of the characters in God of War can intuitively reflect the background of the ancient Greek era in which they are located.

 

Part 2: Diversity - Individuality

From the perspective of personalization, the specific clothing and hairstyles of certain game characters are highly personalized, which helps to show the characteristics of the characters. For example, the protagonist of Judgment, Takayuki Yagami, has a unique hairstyle that is memorable. This is the strong memory point that the “personality” of the hairstyle brings to players.

In some other games, by providing a large number of hairstyle customization options, game players are provided with more diverse different customized appearances and unique hairstyles, which can give players a better user experience. On the basis of hairstyle diversification, personality customization can also be provided through adjustments such as hair color decoration.

NetEase Leihuo Games also attaches great importance to diversified and personalized design. For example, there are many interesting hairstyles in Naraka: Bladepoint. This is a hairstyle that combines a very masculine basic style, the mohawk, with very feminine long curly hair. The designer combines two completely opposite temperament hairstyles together, and the designed style matches the male face, which has a strong personality and characteristics, and can also make players have a strong memory point.

 

In short, diversification and personalization are two sides of the same coin. Whether it is personalized design or diversified choices, it is to better provide players with memory points and immersion, and bring a better gaming experience.

Part 3: Contrast - Memory

In most cases, the design of various hairstyles and dresses for characters in games is mainly for aesthetic purposes. But sometimes, the hairstyle itself carries strong character and temperament characteristics. For example, long curly hair will naturally make people think of a gentle female character; but if this hairstyle is matched with a male face full of beard, it will produce a strong sense of conflict, which will also give players a relatively strong memory point. Even if you haven’t entered a certain scene with this character/role, you already want to find out if something interesting has happened to him.

This is a Boss from Justice Online. The hairstyle design of bald head + braid has a strong memory point, and it is also very in line with the evil personality that the boss should have. This hairstyle can be obtained when the player defeats the boss. In this game, if the player’s face is more delicate and soft, with such an evil hairstyle, the evil temperament is completely absent, and it is even a little funny and impressive, and it is successfully remembered in the guild or player community. This is the effect brought by the hairstyle design with a huge contrast.

 

Part 4: Breaking Labels - Universal Values

Game planners or designers, film directors/producers, often use specific hairstyles to directly define the personality characteristics of a character. However, sometimes such designs can have some undesirable effects. Why? Because using specific hairstyles to define a character will make games or film and television works lack diversity. In addition to hairstyles, the character’s personality can also be highlighted through other aspects of design.

Let’s look at some other examples of labeling. For example, the slicked-back hair in the picture is easy to associate with the mafia when you first see it. This is actually adding a natural label to this type of character. However, this hairstyle is used on some people, and it reflects more of a cool form and personality characteristics, and has nothing to do with his profession. This label should not be pinned on a person so quickly.

 

If we can break this inherent label when designing hairstyles, and add other elements to the design process of the character’s personality characteristics, and give the character richer and more complete character information from this perspective, then there will be many stories and cultural phenomena worth exploring, not just a kind of head hairstyle design art.

So, as game designers, how to transform this design that breaks traditional labels into games?

Develop and apply a diversified headdress system

Game designers are prone to some labeling processing when designing character roles. For example, expensive hairpins, warrior helmets. However, if you have a rich and diverse hair decoration system, you can reduce the presence of labels a lot.

In Justice Online, we have designed and applied a diversified hair decoration system. Various hair accessories allow players to have many different collocations, and other players also have more desire to explore the story behind the character and socialize with the player behind the character.

 

Design a creative hair shape customization system

We don’t want warriors in a game to only have bald heads, buzz cuts, or short hair. They can all have very different collocations in the hands of players. This attempt can also make players more tolerant and accepting of the character’s own hairstyle and appearance.

Hair dyeing system design based on diversity and high aesthetics

This can also be called our efforts in breaking the label of game character hairstyle design. For example, in Naraka: Bladepoint, this dyeing system can also be used for any hair color matching, allowing players to create freely and be remembered by other players. We have no conventions, no fixed labels. The dyeing system gives this label a harsher soil for survival.

Multi-faceted display of the integration of different cultures

When designing games, based on the premise of conforming to the background of the times, strive to do cultural integration and multi-faceted display of different cultures. This point is of far-reaching significance, and we will continue to do so.

entry.title: How "Zen" Game Experiences Capture the Hearts of Players
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Unpacking is a healing, zen-like puzzle game developed by Witch Beam, released in November 2021. The main content of the game revolves around a familiar experience – moving. While creating a comfortable living space, you will gradually learn about the life of the baggage owner. The game combines elements of block puzzles and home decoration. There is no timer, no meter, or score. All you can do is pack, organize, and place items where you think they belong.

The game developer used “zen” to describe their game, which describes a game mode that “imposes as few restrictions as possible on the player.” This type of game mode has also appeared in other games, such as the “Zen Garden” in Plants vs. Zombies, which often presents different forms depending on the type of game, but they don’t seem to have caused much of a stir.

Its “free and unrestricted” feature seems to contradict the concept of mainstream games, which leads to “zen” games almost always having low interactivity and overly simple game mechanics. You can complete the entire Unpacking without any tutorials. All you can do in the game is place the items taken out of the box, which is very simple for a game. But such a “simple” game is loved by players and has been nominated for multiple awards. Does it rely solely on its so-called “free, unrestricted, leisurely, and never-failing” features? How do “zen” games capture the hearts of players?

1. “Zen” and Aesthetic Experience

Let’s trace back to the origin of “Zen”. “Zen” comes from the “Chan” of Zen Buddhism, which is familiar to Chinese people. When this word was introduced to European and American countries, the word even deviated from its original meaning in Zen Buddhism,凝聚了西方人对于神秘的东方智慧的向往与好奇，becoming a pronoun for its subjective impression of Eastern philosophy and even Far Eastern style. For example, the “Zen” mentioned in some games often just borrows the name of “Zen”, but in fact there is no “Zen” reality, only superficiality.

As a design culture with a strong subjective experience, the “Zen” style represents the essence of traditional Chinese culture. The philosophical basis of the “Zen” style is composed of Confucianism, Buddhism and Taoism, and incorporates the wisdom of traditional humanities and philosophy. For example, the “natural” and “free” thinking in Taoist theory, through meditation to perceive the purity and perfection that already exists in one’s heart. It requires to perceive Zen from green mountains and green water, to experience Zen joy from one’s own daily life, and to realize the transcendence of life and spiritual freedom in the flowing and impermanent life.

If we apply this Nirvana thought to real life, it will make people feel satisfied, happy, and excited, and add to the情趣of life. This kind of emotion is a spontaneous expression of following nature, which will make people obtain a special pleasant experience, that is, aesthetic experience, from the perceptual intuition of nature and all things in the universe, thereby greatly improving people’s life. “Zen” games can bring players a relaxing and immersive spiritual experience. In this state of “spiritual tranquility”, the audience abandons the external world and inner distractions, concentrates their thoughts, and returns to their nature. It is like an energy that ignites people’s inner feelings and potential memories, forming more emotional works, naturally presenting the inner world of the audience. Zen games attract players through their aesthetic experience that is different from other games. Next, we will talk about how to gain aesthetic experience from games.

2. Aesthetic Experience in Games

The famous psychologist Maslow once said that there are five basic needs in a person’s life, and these needs are like a ladder, gradually upgrading and accompanying a person’s life. People’s aesthetic needs actually exist in people’s subconscious, but they are rarely discovered. Such aesthetic needs also exist in video games. Early video games attracted us mainly by human primal impulses. With the development of electronic technology, the experience that games bring to people has begun to “evolve” from the primal impulses of survival and plunder to more delicate and subtle empathy and nourishment mechanisms. The design of video games has gradually begun to pay attention to the aesthetic experience of games.

Designing game works with deep connotations and artistic value is inseparable from game mechanics. For example, traditional artworks, on the one hand, fully display the “appearance” carefully designed by the artist, that is, the sensory experience, and on the other hand, contain deeper connotations that need to be gradually explored, that is, “connotation”. For video game works, “connotation” is its internal mechanism, which is the inner, deep, and indispensable element of the game. It reflects modern people’s pursuit of aesthetics and cultural values, and affects the gameplay of the game. While emphasizing the interactivity of the game, showing the deeper aesthetic experience of the game can enable the majority of game players to have a better gaming experience.

Early games on Nintendo’s 8-bit and 16-bit consoles were action games, and the operability reflected in front of players through these game mechanics became the main gameplay of these games. With the continuous development of video games and the enrichment of game types, different game types have incorporated different game elements. For example, RTS games pay more attention to the gameplay that emphasizes strategy and micromanagement, while FPS games focus on mazes, tasks, and tactical coordination. Different mechanisms reflect different game experiences, but no matter what kind of game experience, their design starting point reflects human civilization and social culture, and expresses the designer’s cultural values, aesthetic tastes, etc. Therefore, the game mechanism can also be said to be an important aesthetic feature of game art.

The aesthetic experience is based on the aesthetic characteristics of the game and human-computer interaction, and is a dynamic process. It is a subtle exchange between the player’s various psychological elements such as perception, imagination, emotion, and understanding and the game in the process of interacting with the game world.

In 2004, American scholar LeBlanc et al. proposed the “MDA model” of video games, pointing out that in game design, it is often the internal mechanism (Mechanics) of the game that determines the dynamic interaction (Dynamics) of the game, and then conveys the core emotion (Aesthetics) of the game to the player. He believes that the “fun” of the game is actually the aesthetics of the game. Players feel the experience that the designer hopes to bring through the mechanism through the dynamic interaction part. This interaction is not only the player’s operation, but also includes visual and auditory language, including the experience that players get from the game environment, game art, and game music. We use the following table for intuitive explanation.

From this table, we can see that the aesthetic experience of the game is a dynamic process carried out in stages. Players first come into contact with the interaction layer, that is, external effects (pictures, music, special effects, etc.). The external effect is passively accepted by the player, but the operability of the game gives the player the initiative to practice, and the player obtains a sensory experience at this level. But more important is the core layer of the game, where players will gain a psychological and emotional experience. The sublimation from psychological “pleasure” to philosophical “pleasure” depends on the emotions and cultural values in the game, and relies on the player’s understanding, judgment, and comprehension of the game mechanism.

With the continuous development of graphics and image technology, the graphics of video games have evolved from pixel-level to today’s next-generation quality in order to continuously improve the immersion of the game. However, any art form is not deeply rooted in people’s hearts only by the sensory surface feelings, but more by its cultural connotations. To create an aesthetic experience for players is to transform complex game rules into an experience process, so that players can rise from emotional identification to the deep “understanding” of the soul.

3. When We Design Games with a “Zen” Style

Abandoning Complex Core Mechanism Choices

Zhuangzi believed that “heaven and man were originally one, but the moral norms and典章制度(diǎn zhāng zhì dù - rules and regulations) designated in the human world make people lose their original nature, and become incompatible with nature. Only by ‘abandoning the sage and discarding wisdom’ can human nature be liberated, return to nature, enter into the ‘sitting and forgetting’ of emptiness and clarity, and then elevate to the spiritual realm of ‘all things and I are one’.”

As early as the 17th century, Schiller proposed the famous “game theory”, the purpose of which is simple, that is, to illustrate that “free games” have the characteristics of non-utilitarianism. Zen games abandon complex mechanisms, there are no settings such as stamina bar, ability bar, item bar, etc., starting from emotions, emphasizing their aesthetics and freedom, and bringing players into a “flow” state. The creation of Zen games often stems from this concept of purifying people’s hearts, establishing a virtual world that can be immersed in “pure emotion” interaction without any disputes. Here we can feel another new field outside of other games that pursue excitement and a sense of accomplishment - a journey of the soul. This “journey” allows our body and mind to be completely immersed in the “tranquility” and “Zen” aesthetic experience far away from the hustle and bustle of the city.

So, in addition to abandoning complexity, what exactly does it do? We have already explained that, in order to obtain what kind of aesthetic experience, in addition to the cultural connotation of the game itself, the game mechanism is very important. And the design of the core mechanism of Zen games is very different.

In this core design model, in the middle is the core mechanism, and outwards are the secondary mechanism, progression, story, or “hero myth”. The core mechanism is a behavior pattern in which players need to frequently use this element to interact with the game. It works with the other three layers on the player’s brain, and then conveys a specific experience to the player. We take the classic Zen game Flower as an example to analyze the core mechanism design of Zen games.

We can see that “flying” as the core mechanism of the game has a free and romantic color, and the behavior patterns of the secondary mechanism have an inherent interaction and connection with the natural world. Players play the role of invisible wind and use petals to revive flowers, which makes players imagine themselves as the power to awaken natural life in the game, reflecting the connotation of natural “symbiosis”. “Flying”, as the core mechanism, not only brings players a sense of freedom, but also makes players feel that they are integrated with nature, allowing players to have zero-distance contact with nature. When the player’s emotions are integrated with natural emotions, the player realizes that reviving nature is the mission of people in this game world. This is how Zen games bring players into a “flow” state - through their unique core mechanisms.

Let’s look at Unpacking. Although its ideological connotation may not be so profound, you can still feel the role of its Zen core mechanism in the entire game. For most people, moving may be a very troublesome thing, but in the game, the developer made it a casual and decompressing game. Moving can have many connotations. It can be the pursuit of a desired goal, or it can be an escape from a past. No matter which one, they all mean that you will face a new stage in your life.

In the design of the core mechanism, the game selectively abandons the “packing” part and only shows the “unpacking” part. “Packing” means letting go and preparing for the next stage, while “unpacking” means introspection. When we open the sealed box and take out the items, we are actually decompressing our hearts. When we examine the items and consider their placement, we are actually examining ourselves, examining the past, and planning for the future. The game gradually brings players into a “flow” state with the core mechanism of “unpacking and placing” corresponding to the psychological process of “decompression and introspection”. The player’s emotions gradually merge with the emotions of the game protagonist. While immersed in the game experience, it also allows players to internalize some emotional experiences into their own growth through introspection. Zen games bring players a fresh emotional experience through creative core mechanism design. Such a mechanism itself is full of humanism, satisfying the emotional demands of players and allowing players to always be in a state of “flow”.

Metaphorical Narrative Design and Emotional Creation in Levels

The “Zen” style emphasizes “imagery”, which can be understood as the original concept of Chinese art aesthetics, fully integrating the dual levels of rational and perceptual understanding. Introducing the “Zen” style in the design of video games, making full use of the aesthetic symbols with “hint” functions in it, players can also get a more emotional deep aesthetic experience from it, stimulating each player’s exclusive emotions, and incorporating more deep connotations into the game.

In Unpacking, the game narrates through the design of metaphorical mechanisms. For example, the game introduces a new concept in the third stage – some items in the room cannot be moved, which forces players to negotiate their items with others and fill in the empty spaces. You will realize that the protagonist at this time is sharing a house with others, which can easily remind you of your life in a shared space when you were young. In the fourth stage, you can move the items already in the room at the beginning of the level, which represents a compromise in a romantic relationship. There are also specific placement rules that certain items must follow. These game mechanisms that are not explicitly expressed contain the “connotation” of each stage, symbolizing the protagonist’s growth stage and life trajectory. Local metaphors strengthen the overall emotional intensity of the game, making the game have deeper ideological depth and poetic connotation.

If these implicit mechanisms have a strong emotional mapping and depict the character itself and the emotional interaction between the player and the character from a microscopic perspective. Then the level design brings players into a journey of emotional ups and downs from a macroscopic perspective. Players experience 7 changes in their life trajectory through 7 moves in the game, and at the same time feel the experience of each life stage in the level. The different details of the same item in each level and the different placement mechanisms perfectly imply the changes in different stages, thereby promoting the development of emotions, identifying with and resonating with the protagonist’s state of mind reflected in different details each time, and completing a journey of life.

4. Conclusion

The experience that video games bring to players has become more diverse with the development of technology. It is no longer limited to the relatively primitive impulses such as survival or the desire for victory at the beginning. It is slowly evolving towards higher-level and more delicate emotional needs. People hope to create a spiritual pure land in the hustle and bustle of life, where they can release more emotions and liberate their minds.

Traditional games often attract players through wonderful plot settings or operating mechanisms full of a sense of accomplishment and excitement, bringing players emotional ups and downs. In Zen games, there is almost no specific plot and victory or defeat. The game touches players through the interactive experience created by the mechanism. The designer integrates his own life experience and values into the game mechanism, and promotes the emotional interaction between the player and the game world from a microscopic perspective. This is the aesthetic experience that Zen games bring to players.

entry.title: Disco Elysium: Unique Craftsmanship Needs Specialized Tools
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Introduction to Disco Elysium

Disco Elysium is a role-playing game developed and published by ZA/UM, a game studio from Estonia. It is also their first game. Disco Elysium won Best Role-Playing Game, Best Independent Game, Best Narrative, and Best New Independent Game Developer at TGA2019. The basic gameplay of this game is similar to the dice-rolling gameplay of DND (Dungeons & Dragons), but the points required for successful judgment can be affected by skills, the Thought Cabinet system, and the plot. This game has a large amount of text and boldly abandons the combat part completely. The only bit of combat plot is also determined by plot choices. It can be said that this is a game where text is supreme.

Localization is a crucial part of the game’s dissemination. Especially for a role-playing game like Disco Elysium, which is similar to a visual novel, localization is indispensable.

1. The Significance and Difficulties of Localization for Disco Elysium

In this game, almost all information is conveyed through text and voice. Players obtain information through text and interact with the game plot through text dialogue options. If players cannot understand the text, then this game is almost impossible to play. The original text of Disco Elysium is not only English, but also mixed with French, Spanish, and even Finnish dialects. Not only that, words from various fields such as astronomy, geography, politics, history, philosophy, and economics may even appear on the same page, including words created by the author. The original text is so “unfriendly” to non-native speakers that the members of the Chinese localization team “Whisper Studio” sighed “What is this?” when they first read the original text.

Therefore, localization is crucial to the dissemination and sales of Disco Elysium. Conversely, Chinese localization is indispensable for Chinese players to access Disco Elysium. However, it is obvious that the localization of this game is not an easy task. The localization staff is faced with not only the problems of multiple minority languages, mixed use of created words, but also the two major difficulties of a huge text volume of 1.3 million English words, a large number of obscure metaphors, and abstract sentences. The depth of its plot text can be seen from the first two scenes of the opening, and you can also see the puns and flexible combinations of self-made words in the text. It can be seen how arduous the localization work will be.

“Nemesis is in the mirror at home; that is their address. Even the clearest water in the world, if it is deep enough, can drown people. - R.S. Thomas”

 

Figure 1. The opening quote of “Disco Elysium”

 

Figure 2. The first dialogue in the opening of “Disco Elysium”

In an interview with the localization team “Whisper Studio”, they mentioned: “Starting from the official localization of the official version of the game in September 2019, we spent nearly 4 months completing the initial translation at the end of 2019. We spent another month localizing the updates and new texts. It is equivalent to completing the initial translation in December, and the internal test officially started in late January and early February.” As of August 28, 2020, the update announcement of Disco Elysium on this day mentioned that the text of the game is still being continuously revised, polished, and supplemented after its release. “According to the latest statistics, Disco Elysium has a total of about 1.3 million English words and 1.8 million Chinese characters.” At that time, it was only a year after the Chinese localization of Disco Elysium began. The localization team initially localized more than one million words in just 4 months, and it was the difficult-to-localize text as mentioned above. This is already a very rare thing.

2. Communication Between the Localization Team and the Developer is Indispensable

Nowadays, problems such as isolated translation and stiff transliteration in the localization of overseas games are common. There are many reasons for this, such as the game production team cannot allow localization personnel to fully understand the entire game or the scene of the text due to confidentiality and other reasons; or the game text is translated for the second time, and is not directly localized from the original text; or the game production team does not understand the market situation and finds an unprofessional and irresponsible localization team.

For example, in the classic game The Witcher 3, traveling merchants all became “female travelers”, merchants were all translated as “perfume merchants”, and the word “cat” was replaced with “cat’s eye” globally, and so on. A large number of such stiff and strange translations have added many difficulties for Chinese players to understand the game world, and are also likely to lead to misunderstandings of the plot, and also destroy the player’s immersion. It is also obvious that the localization team did not fully access the game content before translating.

For another example, recently, careful players have found that the localized text of multiple items in Elden Ring even has exaggerated, nonsensical, and deliberate use of rare words but incorrect use. For example, in the item description of the item “Death Prince’s Malignant Pustule”, the sentence “those who have concerns (from the Buddhist Heart Sutra, meaning: obstacles)” has no source at all in the Japanese version (it is suspected to be derived from the original text meaning “cannot die completely”), let alone whether the use of Buddhist terms here is in line with the atmosphere. Netizens speculate that this kind of translation is because the localization staff cannot access the entire game to understand the overall meaning, and they do not know how to localize this original text in isolation, so they deliberately mystify it.

 

Figure 3. The item “Death Prince’s Malignant Pustule” in “Elden Ring”

For Disco Elysium, the Chinese version was not released simultaneously with the game, but after the game was released, so the localization team was able to experience the specific scene of the text in the game. R, a member of the localization team, mentioned in the interview that “most of the people in the team played the game”.

Moreover, the localization team can also communicate with the original author about the text content to ensure the accuracy of difficult points.

R said a story in the interview: “We constantly understand the details in the process of work, and even help the original author to correct mistakes”…”For example, a Chinese text says ‘I am very tired of XX’, and it feels that something is not right when connected with the context. After repeated comparisons, we proposed to ZA/UM: ‘Is it that tried was typed as tired here?’ They checked and found that it was indeed a typo.” It can be seen that it is indispensable for the localization team to communicate with the original author about the text content.

Not only that, ZA/UM also observed the effect of the initial Chinese sample in the Chinese player community. Kaur Kender and Danis H, two executive producers of ZA/UM, participated in the “Guangzhou Nuclear Fusion” game exhibition. They observed the performance of players playing the sample at their booth. They said “players really understood our game”: players would smile where there were humorous elements, and corresponding emotions would also be conveyed where there were dramatic conflicts, which shows that the translated text can indeed express the creative intention. The game company is responsible for its own works, and also observes and researches the effect of the translated samples. Such careful localization work is worthy of praise from players. It can also be seen that they do not simply want players to be able to read the game text, but pursue that players can understand the game connotation. This should be the effect that localization should pursue. Even if they are native speakers of different languages, they can also understand the same game connotation.

But with such a large amount of text, the Chinese localization of Disco Elysium still has a long way to go. Even now, after multiple patches, there are still errors. For example, in the figure below, “broke” is incorrectly translated as “broken”, and the correct translation should be “the billboard prevented the car from falling into the canal.”

 

Figure 4. There are still translation errors in “Disco Elysium” today

3. One-key Language Switching, Letting Players “Localize Themselves”

What makes Disco Elysium different is that it has made a very practical feature in terms of localization - one-key language switching, that is, players can specify two languages and a key on the keyboard, and pressing the key can quickly switch the language of the entire game between the two on the spot.

For people who cannot understand English, this function is almost meaningless, but if players have a certain English foundation, combined with today’s convenient word search software, players can independently understand some sentences that they feel they have not understood. On the one hand, this is a kind of compromise, that is, a compromise to the profound and difficult-to-localize text, allowing players to combine dictionaries to independently translate and understand some difficult points; but on the other hand, this greatly facilitates players to deeply understand the original meaning of the game. It is impossible to localize English, which is very different from Chinese, without information loss. This function allows players to read the original text to make up for the inevitable information loss in the localization process. For a game that takes text reading as almost all content, this function can be said to be a perfect fit.

Disco Elysium needs this system very much. This game has a lot of hints and puns. For example, the original text of the first dialogue at the beginning has a sentence “no ex-wives contains in it” (see Figure 2). “ex-wives” is a homophone of “ex-wife”.
