This almost explicit pun, even if it is translated into “no old love”, players may not be able to associate it with “ex-wife”. I believe that players who have a certain foundation in English have played the first week. When they return to this first dialogue during replay, they use one-key language switching to view the original text. When they see these hints and puns, they will definitely be able to understand different content from them and get a new sense of novelty as if they were seeing this game for the first time.

4. Careful Production Creates a Successful “Disco Elysium”

In general, Disco Elysium has become the closest one to a novel in the game, but it has the flexibility that novels cannot have, flexible and complex plot dialogues that change with choices, a unique Thought Cabinet system, and a smart one-key language switching function. In addition, players can also be immersed in the shocking soundtrack and beautiful pictures with tension when playing, as if they are Harry, immersed in the scene.

The production company ZA/UM once dabbled in creating music, painting, publishing poetry and novel collections, but they all fell silent. But they combined them and created this Disco Elysium, which found a carrier for their thoughts that had been precipitated for many years. They boldly wrote the text obscurely and difficult to understand, boldly deleted the combat elements in the “DND” game mode, but flexibly added many interesting elements to increase the fun, and smartly added a one-key language switching system that increases the possibility of players interpreting the deep meaning of the game. They have well integrated all this, so that even we who are far away on the other side of the Eurasian continent can also happily immerse ourselves in it and play Harry Du Bois to explore the world of Disco Elysium.

entry.title: 'He's a Good Guy Now, But Maybe Not Later' - The Appeal of 'Social Deception' Games During the Pandemic
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

In 2017, the social deduction game Werewolf, based on the Werewolf culture, became one of the keywords of the game industry in the first half of 2017 due to its explosive development, and was even considered a new trend in the industry. Four or five years later, under the multiple impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, when Werewolf is mentioned again, it no longer has the excitement and glory of the past, or rather, it has “transformed” and appeared in the public eye in a new form.

In 2018, a social survival game called Among Us was released, but it received little attention until 2020 when it became popular due to many Twitch streamers and YouTubers playing it. In early 2022, following the popularity of Among Us, a game called Dread Hunger, or “Werewolf at Sea” as players call it, was launched on Steam. In the first week of its release, the number of online players of the game quickly soared from less than 3,000 to 12,000. Today, the number of online players of the game is still increasing. According to SteamDB data (data at 0:00 on May 1, 2022), the game ranks in the TOP 10 of the Steam popularity list.

As a cooperative survival game with a not-so-novel gameplay, incorporating elements of Werewolf that are not well-regarded today, why can it continue to attract players’ attention months after its release?

1. Survival RPG in Werewolf Mode

“We’re almost through the passage. Storms are battering the keel and the crew are whispering of blood and dark magic.” - Captain’s Log, April 1847

Dread Hunger is a multiplayer cooperative survival Werewolf-like game with the theme of social deception, survival in adversity, and escape and confrontation. The game is set in the snowy Canadian Arctic Circle. What comes into view in the game is the vast snowfield and rolling snow mountains. Players will play eight crew members with different identities on a 19th-century warship assigned by the British Royal Family, sailing through the cruel Arctic. Among them, two players will be “thralls” who will hinder other players.

The goal of victory is also very simple. First of all, players must ensure their own survival. The “good” side needs to get the ship out of trouble, while the “thralls” need to prevent it at all costs. Like common survival games, players need to eat, keep warm, and arm themselves. In addition, the ship needs fuel to move forward, so everyone needs to collect coal, and at the same time, the ship must avoid icebergs on the route.

For this game, “survival” and “Werewolf” are like the keel and sails of this ocean-going ship. “Survival” is the keel of the game, which determines whether the players can continue, and “Werewolf” is the sail, which determines where the ship goes.

2. Why It? What’s Different?

In fact, this gameplay is not the first of its kind in Dread Hunger. As early as 2019, Project Winter had a similar design. It was also a cold winter, also with 8 players, also with 2 “traitors”, and also all about “surviving”.

Multiple Character Classes

On the gameplay mechanism of Project Winter, Dread Hunger adopts the multi-class setting of RPG. For example, players can play the roles of captain, chef, engineer, doctor, etc. Different roles also have different weapons and abilities. And some survival construction gameplay is retained, such as going to the wild to collect resources to build various props and items.

This kind of construction gameplay not only provides richer playability, but also deeply penetrates the two conditions for the game’s victory: survival and reaching the destination. The setting of multiple classes creates multiple dimensions for the player’s game experience: due to the different performance of various classes, in the middle of a game, each player can exert the characteristics of their class. Even if you are tired of one of them, there are others to choose from. For players, the rich diversity in the game process creates long-term playability.

Each Performing Their Duties, Direct Confrontation

In addition, compared with games like Among Us that listen more to speeches, Dread Hunger completely abandons the meeting, taking turns to speak, and voting环节 (huán jié - sessions/segments), and emphasizes direct confrontation between different camps. Being eloquent is not a necessary skill for the “thrall” camp, and the “good guys” do not have to organize language to “explain themselves”. Except for communicating necessary information with each other, players can focus on their own work, which greatly reduces the psychological burden between casual players and makes the game rhythm more refreshing. Through this mechanism, players can cooperate with each other and move towards the goal, or they can trust each other and eliminate the traitors.

Operation and Strategy

The game also retains the fun of identities in traditional Werewolf from the mechanism setting. The ship, as the base camp of everyone, often gathers on the ship after nightfall in order to hand in supplies and avoid the severe cold. This has become a natural venue. Everyone exchanges information while doing their work: who might be a traitor, and the traitors will also be mixed in, spreading rumors and secretly sabotaging.

The game enters the later stage, and the game also changes from a scheming Werewolf to a positive asymmetrical confrontation. In order to develop better, the “thralls” will leave the main group and act alone, while the surviving good players also change from mutual suspicion to huddling together to resist the threat from the thralls and the weather. In a short game of more than 20 minutes, it includes the early game strategy, the mid-term suspicion, and the late-stage positive confrontation. With the changes in the weather and the development of the thralls, the pace of the battle is accelerating step by step, keeping the players’ nerves in a state of high tension.

The most important thing about the game is that it completely gives the choice to the players themselves. It tells you the ultimate goal of victory, but it will not deliberately guide players on what to do and what not to do. Players can give full play to their imagination to achieve the desired effect. As long as you can achieve the goal, the developer doesn’t care what happened in the middle, which also leads to the game’s operational ceiling being very high. Therefore, whether it is at the level of strategic gaming or in operational details, there is a lot of room for learning and improvement. So it is not difficult to understand why everyone is happy to continue playing.

3. Social Deception Carnival Under the Pandemic

Under the pandemic, in addition to satisfying the sociality between friends, the game has also released the “little devil” deep in the player’s soul.

For such games, the core attraction is never the rule-based competition of other games, let alone the competition of reaction and operation. The fun is often dependent on details, the player’s observation, or various subtle clues are crucial. The reasoning process is also full of drama, and the surprise and sting that erupts the moment the mystery is revealed, the pleasure brought by acting in the dark corner under the eyes of everyone, all this together creates the fun of deception and the joy of cooperation, which is what this type of game ultimately brings us. The game seems to be saying to the player: Hey, it’s safe now, why not give it a try? The most important thing is that this “dark” impulse is currently only in the game and will not have any serious impact on real life.

The game’s own mechanism has also created a strong sociality. This new online social “Werewolf” has broken through the restrictions of the pandemic. Players are forced to communicate, cooperate, or compete with each other, neutralizing a certain degree of isolation in the pandemic environment. There are now many games with social interaction or interpersonal relationships as the theme, but the gameplay is often single and lacks stamina. At least for now, Dread Hunger does not have this concern.

For players, deceiving each other among friends is the real entry into the game. The questioning and lies of close friends face to face create multi-layered fear and excitement. Imagine a backstab from a friend, suspicion in a treacherous environment, or being wronged. Finally, the game is over, and back in real life, everything returns to normal. You will still continue to trust him/her. After all, you are friends, how could he/she possibly lie to you?

entry.title: Incorporating Gamification into Experience Design
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

What is gamification? Generally speaking, gamification is a method of enriching educational content and marketing or business processes through game mechanics. Gamification design is a powerful tool to enhance user engagement and transform products from function-centered design to human-centered design. For example, gamification in education can significantly improve learner engagement and knowledge retention, and help users complete tedious tasks or training. Gamification is also incorporated into some marketing strategies to attract customers and inspire loyalty.

In interaction design, gamification can motivate users to perform expected actions and provide a meaningful user experience. Inserting interesting features such as leaderboards and badges into existing systems will also stimulate users’ intrinsic motivation and drive user participation.

Gamification is not about turning the user interface into a game. Instead, it injects fun elements into applications and systems, motivating users by introducing gamification into existing systems. There are many ways to gamify a system, such as countdowns and encouraging completed tasks, etc. People like to interact with the system and satisfy their curiosity.

1. The Dynamic Model of Games

In the player motivation model collated by Quantic Foundry, the pleasure brought by action, social behavior, the challenge and practice of thinking, creativity, the immersion of the virtual world, and the experience of achievement have become the main motivations of current game players.

 

Action and Social

 

The needs related to action and social interaction are based on immediacy and adrenaline surges. People who score high on these motivations are more likely to want a sense of excitement (commonly known as “thrill”), such as instant destructive behavior, social interaction with other players, etc.

 

The game “Knives Out” satisfies both the thrill of attack and social needs

Training and Achievement

 

This item addresses the user’s need for progress, skill development, and overcoming challenges. Some players want to acquire more powerful skills and deeper thinking, which gives rise to this type of game that requires players to be calmer and spend a longer time playing. It seeks progressive and cumulative mechanics. StarCraft is a series of games that require more strategy and high cognitive load.

 

Players gain better results in StarCraft through training and accumulating experience

Creation and Immersion

 

This item involves providing users with a platform that promotes exploration and creative expression. Users can try new options or combinations at any time and create unique content, and see the results of their creativity, receive instant feedback, and be rewarded for it. Users who value this point will seek a broad and expressive style of play, they are curious and always testing the boundaries of the game. A deeper sense of immersion can be created through a profound and sophisticated game style and a complete story narrative. Personalized design and providing a sufficiently open world and gameplay can also meet the user’s creative needs.

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Personalized Face Customization Interface

From the dynamic model of the game itself, we can gain insight into the three main needs of modern people in the game. By grasping such needs, we can help the user experience design of the product have a more systematic thinking and a more complete dynamic mechanism.

2. Design Principles of Gamification

The basic gamification elements are: points, levels, tasks, leaderboards, badges, progress bars, avatars, teammates, etc. The design principles of gamification come from the relevant mechanisms of the game itself, including five basic mechanisms and two design principles, through which the playability of the game is guaranteed:

  1. Goals: The game must have clear overall goals: Why are you here? What is the point of the mission? Therefore, when users achieve them, they will feel a sense of accomplishment when they win, which is a basic game element to enjoy.

  2. Rules: There is no game without rules. The most effective rules are usually easy to understand and execute, requiring little or no learning from the user. From a user experience perspective, rules will determine the various touchpoints in the user’s journey.

  3. Feedback: Feedback is the basis of every interactive system. Users want to see their progress and how they can improve. Feedback can be displayed in the form of progress bars, new levels, encouraging messages, greetings at each level, or animations.

  4. Rewards: Users have invested time and effort according to the rules of the game, so the game needs to provide some rewards! Rewards can be virtual badges, points, trophies, coins, leaderboards, stickers, avatars, or cash, and so on.

  5. Motivation: User engagement is at the heart of any design philosophy. To inspire this engagement, designers must be aware of two types of motivation – intrinsic and extrinsic. Intrinsic motivation comes from curiosity, pride, or a sense of accomplishment. Extrinsic motivation comes from tangible things we want to achieve, such as money, good grades, or praise. In mobile applications that prioritize engagement, intrinsic motivation is much stronger. The sense of pleasure that users experience after winning something is considered the ultimate intrinsic motivation.

  6. Freedom of Choice: When users voluntarily participate and abide by the rules to achieve their goals, the system/product will be interesting to them. But when they are forced to do so, the fun is greatly reduced.

  7. Freedom of Failure: As long as users can fail without fear of punishment, the possibility of failure brings a sense of excitement, which will keep players coming back to try again. Therefore, we can find a way to inject enough risk to ensure that users stay engaged but not frustrated.

Based on the design principles of gamification, we can better analyze how games and applications design functional mechanisms and the visual specifications of interactive interfaces according to user psychology.

Next comes the application link. We will explore the application of gamification mechanisms in product experience through specific examples of games and Internet products.

3. Commonly Used Gamification Designs

Starting from the different elements of the game, there are the following commonly used gamification designs:

Badges and Stickers

Combine badges and stickers to reward users for completing set challenges or collecting points. Small rewards can not only give users positive feedback and enhance their enthusiasm, but also give users a sense of accomplishment.

 

Personalized Avatar Collection in the Game

In the design of the game Onmyoji, users can unlock multiple avatar frames through activity achievements, satisfying personalization while giving users a further sense of accomplishment, and can also play a function of showing identity in social interaction within the game.

In the gamification of products, we can also see a variety of user avatar frames, or personalized input method skins. The game elements of badges and stickers not only fundamentally satisfy users’ enthusiasm for stamp collecting, but are also an important part of showing personal identity. Taking the language learning software Duolingo as an example, reaching new levels, spending lingots, and following friends can all earn related user badges, promoting user participation in a different way.

 

Duolingo App Badge Design

Leaderboards

It is a huge incentive for players to see their names on the leaderboard. After all, it is human nature to desire some healthy competition to win some sweet rewards. However, designers must be careful when applying this game element. Leaderboards can have a negative impact on some users: they may feel frustrated when the competition is fierce.

Specifically, the system prompt when failing can use “try again” to imply that players reduce their worries about punishment and provide positive psychological guidance. The ranking display is also more gentle with the text information “top n%”. At the same time, the interaction design does not overemphasize failure. The contrast in the interaction design between the winning and losing sides is small. Compared with punishment, it focuses more on highlighting the progress of individual growth levels, which can give the losing party less frustration.

 

Ubiquitous Leaderboards in Games

In the efficiency tool product Forest, users can be motivated by seeing their concentration time ranking among friends. This design is also used in WeChat Sports to mobilize users’ enthusiasm. At the same time, users can also set not to display their rankings, avoiding a lot of embarrassment. From the interaction with friends, the enthusiasm of users is mobilized through social needs, and the initiative is generated from the comparison with users in the entire platform. Leaderboards are elements that can well stimulate user motivation.

 

Leaderboard Design in Applications

Challenges

From daily task check-ins, ranked match upgrades to various dungeon challenges, this gamification technique turns boring tasks into exciting activities. Challenges can push users out of their comfort zone and allow them to reach new heights.

 

《Revelation M》 Task Illustration

This technique is also often applied to various learning products, maintaining user retention by setting various task challenges. In the popular word memorization software, the number of words that can be memorized is used as a reward prop. Through continuous check-in as a challenge for users to obtain rewards, and check-in stamping as a random reward, it fully mobilizes users’ motivation to pursue rewards and their expectation of random surprises.

 

 

Continuous Check-in Rewards for Word Memorization Software

Points

Many games use a points system to measure the success of players in conquering challenges to motivate them to complete specific tasks.

 

Obtaining Points Through Operations in the Game

In the ballroom game of Harry Potter: Magic Awakened, the dance score of two players is calculated by averaging the scores of the two players. While motivating players to hit more full combos, it also cultivates the tacit understanding and friendship between players, and at the same time satisfies the user’s motivational needs for challenge and making friends.

The game mechanism of points is also often used in Internet applications, such as language learning, productivity, time management, task managers, and education. For example, Starbucks’ “Star Rewards” mechanism transforms the consumption process into a journey of “becoming a Gold Star member” - users become higher-level members by consuming and accumulating stars, giving the traditional consumption behavior more meaning of “gain”, and giving the “star collection” a romanticized experience with an integrated brand art image. Similarly, takeaway software such as Ele.me and Meituan give feedback and redeem red envelopes based on consumption volume, which also diverts users’ attention and improves user experience with gentle gamification design.

 

Obtaining Points Through Operations in the Game

Journey

This game mechanism makes people feel like real players in the adventure. In product design, designers can apply a branched approach, introducing new features as users gain experience.

 

New journeys unlocked according to level/task can make players more involved in the growth of the game

In Alipay’s “Ant Forest”, sustainable environmental tasks give users a sense of mission when playing games. At the same time, the types of trees and map chapters that are continuously unlocked according to the accumulation of user experience ensure the motivation for users to continue to participate. In the experience process, there will also be a series of branch line unlocking linkages such as Ant Manor, Baba Farm, and Protected Area Patrol, which ensures the user’s turnover and retention.

 

Achievement Unlocking and Branch Line Linkage in Applications

Constraints

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》’s Dark Tide Mode sets a limited time range and number of revives

Constraints, restrictions, and deadlines don’t sound fun, however, adding a countdown or life limit, allowing users to complete a task within a given time or with limited life energy, can increase people’s excitement and stimulate productivity. With the dynamic effects of the game interface and sound prompts, it can further promote the player’s tension and improve the level of concentration. Such constraints are also often used in promotional activities of shopping software and personalized functions of memory software.

 

Shopping software activates users’ excitement and stickiness by limiting the number of times and time limit for red envelope collection

4. Summary

Gamification design not only comes from the various mechanisms of the game, but also an experience design born based on the deep logic of user psychology and experience. Based on the common ideas and principles of gamification design, we can better improve the product service experience, use game ideas to drive users’ enthusiasm and participation, and can also use this to create more new and fun functional modules.

entry.title: How to Make Players Become a "Good Father" in Games?
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

Players are often asked to play other roles in games, and these roles may be far from our real life, such as a stern “old father.” Those classic father figures on the screen seem to be questioning us: Why, even if we don’t have relevant life experience, can we still immerse ourselves in the role of the “old father” in the game?

1. Becoming a “Good Father” in the Game?

20 years ago, when I was receiving corporal punishment from my dad, I probably wouldn’t have thought that many years later, I would be playing a stern old father in a game, worrying about how to get along with my rebellious son.

The father-son relationship has always been a relatively unfamiliar topic to me. When I was in college, I basically maintained a one-sentence-per-month, three-words-per-sentence relationship with my dad. The impact of this kind of father-son relationship on me is that since I started playing games, I have been strongly skeptical about whether I can empathize with the “father” role in the game. After all, for most gamers, a generally accepted truth is:

Empathy often comes from each person’s differentiated life experience. We are more likely to resonate with plots that are similar to our experiences, and it is difficult to empathize with characters with different personalities.

However, this view gradually became less convincing as some players came into contact with more and more games with fathers as the protagonists. In fact, whether it is Kratos in the new God of War or Joel in The Last of Us, I can feel the strong sense of immersion brought to me by the game characters - I hope Atreus will not follow the same path as “me” and become a revenge machine; I also don’t want Ellie to be taken away for research and become the dawn of sacrificing herself to save mankind. These emotional fluctuations seem to imply to me: You have become a “good father” in the game, whether I really have a child or am a homebody gamer who never leaves home.


Kratos and Atreus in God of War


Joel and Ellie in The Last of Us

In the DLC “A Father’s Promise” of This War of Mine, the father “Adam” played by the player did his best but failed to save his daughter, bringing sadness and tears to countless players. Even if none of us players may have experienced war, and few players really have a lovely daughter, these do not affect the player’s empathy and immersion with “Adam”.


Steam comments from players of the DLC “A Father’s Promise” of This War of Mine

I believe that players’ immersion in the “father” role is not grandstanding on social platforms or game comments. So we can’t help but wonder, what is the magic of these video games with “fathers” as the protagonists, that can make some players who have no relevant life experience become a qualified “good father”? This article will interpret this issue from three aspects: character image, gameplay, and narrative.

2. A Projection of the Ideal Father?

The first aspect of creating a strong sense of immersion is to create a character setting that meets the player’s psychological expectations. The game character controlled by the player is the main medium for the player to interact with the game. In the virtual world, they are the player’s avatar and spokesperson. The first success of many games is that the father image in the game perfectly matches the player’s imagination, or projection, of the ideal father image.

Projection is a concept in psychology, which roughly means that individuals will subconsciously reflect their own thoughts, emotions, feelings, and cognition on others or external things. In games, the protagonist often becomes the object of our projection. We will project our understanding of the role and behavior of this character in life onto the identity and behavior of the character in the game. Images that conform to the projection are more likely to make players empathize and understand, while images that do not conform to the projection will blur the identity of the character and even create a sense of incongruity.

From this perspective, we can better understand why fathers in games tend to be taciturn, tall and majestic, fatherly love is like a mountain, because this represents the image of the ideal father in the hearts of most players - not that they want to have such a father, but that they think fathers should be like this.

Of course, there are far more than just old father images of fathers in reality, but if there is such a game where players need to play a meticulous, powerless old dad, I believe the sense of immersion will not be very good. In many cases, we don’t even need to go that far. As long as there are some atypical fathers, it is enough to make us question the character image in the game. For example, Ethan in Resident Evil: Village, apart from his love for his daughter, Ethan does not show much of the side of being an old father, so that many times I would think, even if Ethan is replaced by Mia (Ethan’s wife), the feeling the game brings to me does not seem to change much, especially in recent years when there are more and more female protagonists. If the father in the game is not “typical” enough, then this “neutral” parental image does not necessarily need to be undertaken by the father. You can replace him with any family member, it can be a mother, or a brother or sister.


In Plague Tale: Innocence, the older sister is the representative of the family image

3. Gameplay that Better Matches the Behavior of the Father Character

The behavior of a character is largely reflected in the specific gameplay of the game, and players often have their own expectations for the behavior of a character. If the gameplay does not match the character image and personality, it will be difficult for players to immerse themselves in the game image.

The reason why switching the gender of the protagonist in Resident Evil is relatively less incongruous for some players is largely because they are already used to operating female characters to struggle for survival in zombies. There are enough female protagonists in the Resident Evil series. But if the player is asked to play a feminized Kratos, Kratos, no, “Krat-Mom” stretches out her arms and tears the monster in half like tearing a chicken, I believe the sense of incongruity has already exploded. This sense of incongruity may not be brought about by the image. Even if we design Krat-Mom into the classic mother image, gentle and amiable, understanding, tearing monsters by hand will still make us instantly detach from the role. The source of this sense of incongruity is actually that the game did not achieve such a content very well, that is: the matching of character image and gameplay.

Let’s make another assumption. If Krat-Mom doesn’t fight by tearing chickens by hand, but takes out a staff and releases cool magic, it seems much more reasonable.

If the new God of War was all about puzzles and no longer had combat elements, it wouldn’t matter whether Kratos was a Krat-Mom - puzzle, leisure and other gameplay generally do not have a particularly obvious character tendency. These neutral gameplays generally do not encounter the problem of matching gameplay and characters, but some gameplays will have relatively strong character implications: such as bloody action gameplay, parenting, war, military simulation, and so on.

From a macro perspective, games with fathers as the protagonists are more suitable for action, FPS and other combat-oriented gameplays. These gameplays that focus on strength will be more in line with our expectations of character behavior. Conversely, gameplay focused on parenting and leisure is often not found in games that emphasize the father-son or father-daughter relationship. Because many times, sweeping the floor, cooking, washing clothes and mopping the floor are often not in line with most players’ expectations of their father’s behavior. This is why we often play action games with dads, but not moms.

From the perspective of more detailed gameplay design, the interaction between father and son can also often increase the player’s sense of immersion as a father. For example, in God of War, players can call Atreus to shoot arrows, or let Atreus be a puzzle-solving tool. In these simple gameplay designs, players can also feel the unquestionable, cold-on-the-outside-but-warm-on-the-inside father-son relationship between Kratos and his son.


In the game, you can use specific keys to command Atreus to shoot arrows

4. Empathy Brought by Delicate Emotional Narrative

Good game narrative is crucial, otherwise even if the character image conforms to the player’s projection and the gameplay perfectly matches the character, what we may be playing is an enhanced version of Contra. To this day, some players still lack a sufficient impression of the characters in Contra. They don’t know who “I” am, where “I” came from, or why “I” killed so many strange enemies. What Contra lacks, in fact, is: empathy between the player and the character.

From the perspective of pure plot production, empathy is not particularly difficult. There are causes and consequences in script creation, and creators can have ample space and ink to foreshadow a character so that the character’s behavior is logical. But in games, it is often difficult for us to make players have a strong sense of empathy, because game narrative is often limited by the design and volume of the game itself (unless it is a text adventure game).

If some inherent logic in the plot cannot be expressed in the game through delicate narrative and effective design, the audience will be detached from the character and feel that “he is not me, because I don’t know why he does this.”

The first DLC “Legacy of the First Blade” of Assassin’s Creed: Odyssey is actually a relatively typical negative example. The protagonist played by the player will quickly experience a series of “turbulent” plots such as meeting NPCs, marrying NPCs, having children, and then having their family destroyed and sending their children away in less than 10 hours of plot. The plot content does not match the story rhythm. Marriage and childbirth itself is a major event in a character’s life, but there is no foreshadowing, and the character does not have enough inner monologue to support a series of behavioral logic. This series of narrative problems makes players feel as if they are operating a completely unrelated character, and the DLC with the lowest score in history was born.


In the DLC, the character played by the player will conceive new life. This segment, which should have evoked strong empathy, has been criticized by players.

In terms of game narrative to make players empathize, God of War and The Last of Us do much better. In explaining the changes in the father-son (father-daughter) relationship, they use a slow pace to tell a not very complicated emotional entanglement, which is enough for players. Of course, this does not mean that there are no narrative problems at all. For example, from my personal experience, the source of the father-son conflict in God of War comes from the foreshadowing of the previous work (Kratos himself is a god, but his son does not know). Without playing the first three parts, it is actually difficult for players to understand the畸形 (jī xíng - abnormal, deformed) father-son relationship between them in the early stage. Fortunately, Kratos opens up to Atreus in the middle of the game, which also makes players understand the cause and effect of Kratos’ behavior logic.

5. Conclusion

Back to our original question: how do video games make players become “good fathers”? It requires the guidance of character image, gameplay, and narrative. Although most players agree that the player’s sense of immersion comes from each person’s differentiated life experience, this is not a false proposition, but it is also not a necessary condition for players to have a sense of immersion.

If the game can shape its character image that conforms to the player’s projection, build relevant gameplay that matches the character, and design a game narrative with smooth internal logic, it is not an impossible task for a player who has never been a father to become a qualified father in the game.

Games, as the ninth art, come from life and give back to life. Our thoughts, sights, and ideas in life are projected onto our game characters, and the plots we experience through game characters will become catalysts for us to understand the world and our families. Countless players commented under the God of War game that Kratos’ story reminded them of their own fathers, and I am one of them. After finishing God of War, I called my dad after a long time. My dad hadn’t received my call for a long time and was slightly flustered, very worried that I was sick or encountered some problems. I suddenly realized that fathers are probably the same. They may not be as powerful as Kratos, but they will definitely love you like Kratos, silently but powerfully.

Player comment in the God of War section of Reddit: I don’t usually post things like this, but I have to do it in the face of this game. If the game is out of 10, I would rate it 11. I have a deep understanding of this story because my mother recently passed away, leaving only me and my father whom I have never been close to. Thank you, God of War.

Finally, I would like to dedicate this article to all the fathers in the world and wish them a happy Father’s Day. The prose poems written by fathers are still circulating, don’t let them dissipate in the wind.

entry.title: Helping Chinese Games Ride the Wave of Globalization - An Analysis of the Localization Practice of *Naraka: Bladepoint*
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Game design itself exists to realize people’s dreams. In games, people can get a highly realistic experience of flying a plane to defend their homeland, or play famous figures to interpret the joys and sorrows of different destinies. This characteristic of the game destined it to be a global product from the day it was born. Language is just an obstacle to the realization of dreams in games.

Today, with globalization and highly developed technology, almost all game products cannot be satisfied with the success of a single market. How to acquire more players and occupy more game markets in more countries is a question that all game manufacturers must consider.

This article will take Naraka: Bladepoint as an example to explore the choices and challenges faced by Chinese games in the process of going global and localization, to help more Chinese games ride the wave in the global game market.

1. Language Selection: Localization VS Internationalization

Internationalization refers to the modification or porting of a product or service so that it obtains the widest acceptance in different language countries and regions around the world. In practice, English is generally used as the internationalization language, and corresponding universal symbols are used.

Localization refers to the modification or porting of a product or service to make it more suitable for the needs of audiences in a specific language or country. In practice, the most frequently selected languages are Spanish, German, French, Simplified Chinese, Japanese, Brazilian Portuguese, Italian, Korean, Russian, and Polish. At the same time, Indonesian, Thai, Hindi, and Vietnamese are also rapidly gaining popularity. Given the growth prospects of the game market in South Asia and the Pacific region, it is expected that these languages will become popular languages in the next few years.

Obviously, localization is a higher stage of development of internationalization. If a game wants to achieve greater success worldwide, localization is a must.

NetEase’s 24 Entertainment’s Naraka: Bladepoint shoulders the important task of promoting traditional Chinese culture. From the beginning of its launch, it chose the path of global localization, hoping to provide players around the world with the ultimate user experience. Naraka: Bladepoint launched its global open beta on August 12, 2021. Initially, 11 language versions were launched simultaneously for players around the world, and then Vietnamese and Thai versions were added. At the same time, it has Chinese, English, Japanese, and Korean voiceovers, covering game players in more than 200 countries and regions around the world.

 

When choosing the localization language, the first factor considered by Naraka: Bladepoint was which countries/regions would be most popular for a Chinese-style martial arts multiplayer competitive game. Obviously, Naraka: Bladepoint‘s unique gameplay is widely popular around the world. The weapon system that combines melee + ranged weapons, the unique grappling hook design, and the unique hero skills, coupled with the blessing of Chinese martial arts elements, make it stand out among many games of the same type.

Secondly, Naraka: Bladepoint needs to consider how to enter the world’s mainstream game market and acquire a wider game audience. Therefore, countries and regions that rank among the top in global game revenue are taken into consideration. According to Newzoo data, the top ten countries and regions in global game revenue in 2021 are: China, the United States, Japan, South Korea, Germany, the United Kingdom, France, Canada, Italy, and Brazil. This ranking has been very stable. Therefore, similar to the localization choices of many Western companies, 24 Entertainment chose French, German, Spanish, and Portuguese, as well as Japanese and Korean, as the localization languages.

 

In addition, Traditional Chinese (used in Hong Kong, China and Taiwan, China) is also worth considering, because game players in Taiwan, China and Hong Kong, China have high purchasing power: Taiwan, China ranks 16th and Hong Kong, China ranks 20th in the list of countries and regions with global game revenue.

Third, as a computer game, the main purchase channels for Naraka: Bladepoint are the official website, Steam, and Epic. As one of the world’s largest comprehensive digital distribution platforms, the five most popular languages on Steam other than English are Simplified Chinese, Russian, Spanish, German, and Brazilian Portuguese.

But at the same time, the more popular the language and market, the more intense the market competition. The US market is known for being difficult to penetrate; while the Japanese market is lucrative, it is not the best target market in terms of specific game graphics or types. Therefore, while focusing on mature markets, Naraka: Bladepoint also focuses on emerging markets with huge development potential, such as: Thailand, Vietnam, and Turkey. These markets lack games in their native language and have less competition, so it is easier to achieve success.

2. Narrative Brushstrokes: Sinicization VS Westernization

As an action-adventure multiplayer competitive game, the text in Naraka: Bladepoint is mainly divided into two categories: one is related to the setting of the game’s worldview and character background stories, and the other is related to the setting of the game’s gameplay itself. Its overall narrative style is a typical oriental style, including a large number of Chinese elements, such as: Longmen Grottoes, Bruce Lee, nunchucks, Sunwing, koi, dragon boat racing, zongzi, etc.

In the choice of game narrative style, the first thing is to ensure that players correctly understand the gameplay of the game, to ensure that they can quickly get started and have an immersive experience of the oriental martial arts style. Therefore, most of the texts related to the gameplay of the game adopt a straightforward narrative style.

Secondly, it is necessary to ensure that the correct cultural symbols are conveyed. The spread of culture is a subtle process. The clothing, weapons, props, and event settings in Naraka: Bladepoint all reveal a mysterious oriental charm.

For cultural symbols that are well-known and accepted worldwide, the established expressions are generally used. For example: Bruce Lee, the Longmen Grottoes. On the one hand, these mature cultural symbols can help the game attract more potential players, and on the other hand, they promote the further spread of Chinese culture among the existing players of the game.

 

 

However, for cultural symbols that are relatively less well-known and accepted, and have no fixed expression, the method of free translation is adopted, careful consideration and repeated deliberation are made, and efforts are made to express the cultural meaning behind the text while increasing the understandability and acceptability of the text.

For example: Naraka: Bladepoint has carried out a series of development plans called “Sunwing” based on the traditional cultural symbol “Golden Crow” (金乌 - Jīn Wū). The Golden Crow is a Chinese cultural symbol with an origin concept, originating from the sun bird of the Shang and Zhou Dynasties. It is a symbol of Chinese cultural heritage. In the game, the Golden Crow is also the god of Naraka: Bladepoint. The development plan of “Sunwing” shows that 24 Entertainment will systematically and continuously carry out the inheritance of Chinese culture in the name of the Golden Crow. In this regard, the Thunder Fire UX global localization team carefully considered and chose “Sunwing Relics” as the translation of “金乌纪” (Jīn Wū Jì). “Sunwing” reflects the origin of the Golden Crow as the sun bird, perfectly matching the image of the “Golden Crow” in the game, and “Relics” reveals the connotation of the “Sunwing” project to inherit traditional Chinese culture.

 

Third, the localization narrative of Naraka: Bladepoint must ensure the readability and spreadability of the game text. For the oriental style worldview and character background story settings in the game, a set of parallel and corresponding Westernized worldview and character backgrounds have been constructed separately.

 

The concise and straightforward narrative style of the gameplay is to ensure that players quickly understand the game and ensure the basic game needs of players; the Sinicized narrative style of Chinese cultural symbols is to reflect the unique oriental style of Naraka: Bladepoint, give the gameplay additional cultural meaning, and increase the stickiness of players; the Westernized narrative of the worldview and character settings is to facilitate communication among Western players and improve the spread and acceptance of the game. As a successful overseas product, Naraka: Bladepoint adopts different narrative styles as needed to present foreign players with a game product that perfectly combines Eastern and Western narrative styles.

3. Common UI Issues: Text Overflow

One of the most common problems in localization practice is text overflow, that is, the target language length exceeds the length of the UI reserved text box in the game, resulting in incomplete text display or text overlap. The main reason for text overflow is that Chinese text is generally compact. When the text content is translated from Chinese to other languages, the number of characters in the target language is often much larger than that of the original text.

In the localization practice of Naraka: Bladepoint, the number of characters in the full-language text and the number of characters in the Chinese text were pulled and compared. The ratio of the length of different languages relative to Chinese was obtained by using the number of characters in the target language/corresponding Chinese characters. Some interesting phenomena were found:

(Note: If the ratio is less than 1, it means that the number of characters in the target language is less than the number of Chinese characters, and there is no risk of text overflow; if the ratio is greater than 1, it means that the number of characters in the target language is greater than the number of Chinese characters. The larger the value, the more serious the risk of text overflow)

  1. The risk of text overflow in Korean is the lowest, at 61%; while the risk of text overflow in Thai is the highest, at 81%, and only 19% of the Thai character length does not exceed the corresponding Chinese character length;

 

  1. Among Western languages, the character length distribution of German, French, Spanish, Portuguese, and Russian tends to be consistent, which is related to the fact that these languages belong to the Indo-European language family, and there are certain similarities in word origin and grammatical structure; among them, the risk of text overflow in German, French, and Spanish is the same, and they are all relatively high, at 79%, and the risk of text overflow in Russian is slightly lower than other languages, at 73%;

 

  1. Among Eastern languages, the character length distribution of Korean and Japanese is relatively similar, and the distribution of Thai and Vietnamese is relatively similar.

Although Korean and Japanese belong to different language families, their grammatical structures are similar. In simple terms, the similarities between the two: the grammatical structure is subject-object-verb, and they are both “agglutinative languages”, which express grammatical forms through changes in the final ending. In addition, honorifics are developed, and the honorifics used are completely different when facing people of different generations, ages, and social status.

There are also many similarities in the composition and origin of Japanese and Korean vocabulary. They are mainly divided into three categories: Sino-Korean words, native words, and loanwords. Among them, native words are the most important in sentences and can express the core meaning of sentences. Sino-Korean words account for a considerable part of Japanese and Korean, both of which were once deeply influenced by Chinese culture, so Sino-Korean words come from China. In addition, in modern Korean, some Japanese-translated Chinese characters were absorbed to express new concepts. In terms of loanwords, both Korean and Japanese use a large number of transliterated words borrowed from Western languages such as English.

 

Another interesting phenomenon is that the character length distribution of Thai and Vietnamese, which also belong to Southeast Asian languages, is also very similar. Although Thai uses Thai letters, Vietnamese uses Latin letters. However, in terms of grammar, both Thai and Vietnamese are similar to Chinese, and they are both isolating languages. Verbs have no morphological changes, nouns have no grammatical gender and number forms, and there are no grammatical case changes. Adjectives do not need to maintain grammatical gender, number, and case consistency with the nouns they modify. The basic word order is the same as Chinese, which is the “subject-verb-object” structure.

 

In short, the risk of text overflow in various languages generally exists. In response to this situation, the problem can be solved from the following three perspectives:

  • During the development stage, front-end personnel can indicate the recommended character length and the maximum allowed character length of the field in the localized resource configuration file;
  • When the number of characters in the target language is 1-2 times that of Chinese, focus on the accuracy of the language and the conciseness of the language during the localization translation stage. If necessary, abbreviations or manual line breaks can be used;
  • When the number of characters in the target language is more than 2 times that of Chinese, in the localization testing stage, cooperate closely with the UI team, adjust the length, width, and height of the reserved text box or table, the size of the font, or solve the text display problem through UI design (adding scroll bars), so that the text is displayed completely and the interface layout is reasonable.

Thunder Fire UX’s global localization team undertook the localization of Naraka: Bladepoint in 13 languages. In this process, the global localization team and the interactive experience design team cooperated closely and complemented each other, and promptly solved the display problems in the language packs of various languages, providing a template for the game to go overseas and the efficient localization process.

4. Conclusion

As the first game of 24 Entertainment to operate simultaneously in 13 languages, Naraka: Bladepoint has been online globally for 10 months, and the peak online on Steam and other platforms is among the top, and it continues to receive praise from players around the world. During this period, Thunder Fire UX’s global localization team has been with us all the way and provided strong support, and constantly searched for the best solution for Chinese games to go overseas in localization practice.

entry.title: Those Fashion Sets that "Broke Through" Over the Years
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

Everyone has a love for beauty. This is no exception in games. If you want to become more beautiful in the game, in addition to face sculpting and makeup, fashion is essential.

In addition to meeting the needs of players for aesthetics and personalized display, fashion also plays a very important role in the revenue of many games. Especially in fair competition games such as MOBA and Battle Royale, fashion and skins are an important part of the revenue. Even in MMO games that emphasize stats, many games have begun to adopt a dual-path operation model of “stats + fashion”. In some games, fashion appearances are also rewarded as gameplay rewards, becoming another long-term goal in addition to stat rewards, providing players with motivation for daily activities. The importance of fashion to the game is self-evident.

1. Do Beautiful Fashion Sets Always Sell Well?

“What kind of fashion sells well?” is a question often asked at the beginning of many games.

When studying this issue, we often use another concept to replace this question, “What style and design of fashion do players prefer?” Generally, we would think that players buy a fashion set because the design is beautiful and attractive to them.

However, do beautiful fashion sets always sell well?

The answer is, not necessarily. Beautiful fashion sets do sell relatively better, but it is not a perfect positive correlation.

Beautiful Fashion Sets Do Sell Relatively Better, But It’s Not a Perfect Positive Correlation

When evaluating a fashion set, we often introduce two indicators, one is sales, which represents the objective income brought by the fashion; the other is the approval rating, which represents the player’s subjective evaluation of the fashion’s aesthetics.

Approval rating = Number of people who rated it as beautiful / (Number of people who rated it as beautiful + Number of people who rated it as not beautiful)

 

Game A fashion sales and approval rating chart

 

Game B fashion sales and approval rating chart

From the two figures above, we can see that, first of all, beautiful fashion sets do sell well, and this is the general trend. However, sales and approval ratings are not perfectly positively correlated. In particular, the approval ratings of several top-selling fashion sets are not much different from the following fashion sets, but the sales are far apart. (The fashion sets in the charts have similar prices, the same sales methods, and no additional special effects, so they are not affected by these factors)

The “Breakthrough” of High-Sales Fashion

To explain this data, we can start with the players who buy fashion. Through player contact, we can divide players who buy fashion into two categories: one is the fashionista who will steadily buy fashion and almost never miss any fashion sets. They use exclusion factors when making fashion purchase decisions. As long as the fashion is not particularly ugly, they will generally buy it.

“It doesn’t have to be beautiful, but my wardrobe can’t be without it,” is a phrase often uttered by a fashionista friend of mine, which also explains to some extent why the sales of mid-ranked fashion are relatively close.

The other group of non-stable audiences do not have a strong need for “fashion collection” or “changing new clothes”. They will only buy when they really like it or really need it. Therefore, if there is a significant change in sales, the reason is mainly that it has hit that large group of non-stable audiences.

 

So, what kind of fashion can cause a ripple among this group of non-stable audiences? After carefully studying the players’ discussions on fashion, we found some answers.

2. Those Fashion Sets that “Broke Through” Over the Years

For these breakout fashion sets, we can divide them into two categories according to the way they broke out. One is the breakout brought by self-propagation, and the other is the audience of the fashion itself.

Breakout Brought by Self-Propagation - Mainly Social Factors

When studying breakout fashion, we found that some breakout fashion sets are accompanied by a very high level of discussion in the game. Generally, after a new fashion set is released, the number of related keywords in the game will increase briefly, and players will express some opinions on the new fashion. However, most of the time, the discussion heat of different fashion sets is relatively close, while the discussion heat of some breakout fashion sets can reach 2-3 times that of ordinary fashion.

For example, the following fashion set. In addition to more people participating in the discussion of new fashion, we also saw comments in the game such as: “Male characters, please consciously put on new fashion, don’t make me kneel down and beg you”, “Are there any handsome guys wearing new fashion, give me a location, let me see the abs”. The first male fashion set with exposed abs in an ancient style game became a carnival for female players in the game. Many male players who are not usually interested in fashion will also “reluctantly” put on new clothes for this social currency, making this fashion set an annual breakout fashion.

 

Annual Breakout Fashion Set

There are also some series of fashion sets, which are also very suitable for group building scenes among female friends and guilds in the game. In the game, players don’t like to wear the same clothes, but wearing clothes of different colors and standing in a row has a very strong visual effect. “Family, let’s wear swimsuits and take a group photo together”, “We are the seven swimsuit fairies” are comments that players often mention when discussing these fashion sets. In order to wear sister outfits with their female friends, to show the relationship of the small group; to participate in the group photo of guild members; or even a shout out on the public screen for a photo, can become the purchase motivation of this group of non-stable fashion audiences.

 

Seven Swimsuit Fairies

In addition, Qixi Festival and Valentine’s Day are also excellent times for buy-one-get-one-free self-propagation and “bundled” sales.

The Audience of the Fashion Itself - Fashion with a High-Class Temperament is Easier to Attract More Players

In addition to the above-mentioned fashion with social attributes, we also found that fashion sets described by players as “immortal”, “luxurious”, and “noble” often have significantly higher sales. We speculate that this phenomenon is mainly affected by the following two reasons.

It’s hard not to like the fashion temperament + “Value” > “Price”

① Fashion temperament that everyone can hardly dislike. When players evaluate fashion, they evaluate the temperament presented by the character after putting on the fashion, rather than the style of the fashion itself. For example, “cute”, “sexy”, “lady-like”, “elegant”. Each temperament will have its own audience, and it is relatively stable, and rejection is also obvious. For example, some people just don’t like to dress cutely and cutely, and prefer a tough and capable temperament. The audience size of this temperament also determines the sales of fashion sets corresponding to this type of temperament. In a survey of fashion temperament preferences in a certain game, we also found that most of the temperaments correspond to an audience of no more than 30%, that is, to each his own; temperaments such as toughness and competence are relatively niche preferences among female players, so the sales of fashion sets with such temperaments will also be relatively low; while temperaments such as cuteness, immortality, and nobility have a relatively prominent audience among female players, exceeding 40%, so it is not surprising that the sales of fashion sets with such temperaments are high.

② “Value” > “Price”. When players make fashion purchase decisions, price is inevitably a necessary consideration. When prices are similar, whether it is “worth it” becomes the main criterion. Under the influence of various ancient costume dramas and Xianxia dramas in China, we subconsciously feel that clothes with the temperament of “immortal” and “noble and luxurious” are worn by people of higher status, and the clothes worn by these people of high status are all exquisitely tailored and made of exquisite materials, and the prices are not cheap. Therefore, when a cute fashion set and a noble and gorgeous fashion set are placed in front of the player, the player will naturally feel that the noble and gorgeous clothes are more expensive. When the “value” increases, “value” > “price”, it is easier to make a purchase decision.

(But it is worth noting that the results of fashion temperament here all come from MMO games with oriental themes. Games with different themes and art styles, and players from different cultural circles will have great differences. For example, in the Japanese server, the niche “dark” temperament in China has become the favorite of Japanese server players. Temperament is a relatively good dimension for fashion preference research. The results in the text cannot be generalized and are only used as examples)

 

3. Summary

In general, in addition to the aesthetics of the fashion itself (the approval rating of the fashion is also relatively high), the self-propagation brought by social attributes and the character temperament perceived by the player after putting on the fashion (rather than the style of the fashion itself) are all powerful drivers behind these breakout fashion sets.

In multiplayer online games, fashion is not just an appearance. For players, fashion is sometimes a symbol of the relationship between female friends, sometimes a prop for group building among friends, and sometimes an expectation and sustenance for an image that cannot be realized in reality. In the study of fashion, starting from the player side and analyzing and understanding the player’s fashion needs and purchase motivations can also bring us many interesting answers.

entry.title: A Powerful Tool to Mobilize Players' Emotions - Quick Time Events (QTE)
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Recently, Sony released the final version of the PlayStation popular game related terminology list - “Game Dictionary”. This list contains more than 100 words and phrases frequently used in the game world, including game types, various gameplay terms, and slang among players. The “QTE” to be introduced next is also among them. It is a gameplay system with rich forms that can be well applied in various games, and it can even be said to be ubiquitous. When you see this term, what game scene comes to your mind first?

1. Introduction to QTE

QTE, namely Quick-time event. Sony’s game dictionary explains it as a game scene in which players need to respond to multiple screen prompts and enter the correct buttons to trigger specific screen actions.

Players can obtain buffs, advance the game process, or avoid damage by completing QTEs. After decades of development, QTE has become an indispensable gameplay in many games and is widely known.

The history of QTE dates back to video games in the 1980s. Due to technical limitations, some early interactive movie games - such as Dragon’s Lair - pre-recorded established storylines in the form of animation or live-action movies, and then required players to perform specific operations at a fixed time period to facilitate the continued playback of subsequent game content. If the player does not follow the instructions, it will lead to the end of the game or a BAD END. This is one of the sources of QTE.

 

《Dragon’s Lair》 prompts the player to press the left button to enter the next animation

But the true QTE in the modern sense comes from the milestone masterpiece Shenmue on the Sega Saturn console in 1999. At that time, the game producer Yu Suzuki first proposed the concept of Quick Timer Events. Compared with previous works, Shenmue integrated QTEs into cutscenes and various aspects of the game. There are many chase and fight real-time rendered CGs in the game. During this period, players need to press the correct buttons within a certain period of time according to the prompts on the screen to avoid obstacles or block enemy attacks. If the player presses the wrong button or presses it too slowly, the player may bump into pedestrians or get punched in the face.

 

《Shenmue》 QTE prompt in the center of the screen

Since then, QTE operations have begun to be widely used in games, especially action games and interactive movie games. The increasingly rich forms of expression of QTE and its more diverse integration with games have brought unique interactive experiences to players.

2. Interaction Design of QTE

Currently, mainstream QTEs can be divided into two types. The first is a system that tests the player’s instant reaction. In the actual game process, the player must quickly respond to the buttons that appear on the game screen and press the buttons corresponding to the screen. With the development of technology, button operations have also evolved from the initial single button to combination buttons, joystick operations, and so on. The second is a specific or random symbol that moves back and forth quickly within a length. The player needs to press the corresponding button when the symbol moves to the valid area.

QTE relies on screen prompts, which will inevitably involve interaction design. Observing the constituent elements of QTE, the screen prompt includes two parts: “quick time” and “event”.

Relatively speaking, the design of “event”, that is, the button, is relatively simple, mainly to make it clear for players to see and not to conflict with the game style. In mobile games, you can draw a schematic diagram of the finger and cooperate with pressing and sliding dynamic effects to prompt the player to operate.

 

QTE prompt in the mobile game 《Guardian Tales》

The design of the “quick time” part, that is, the visual representation of the reaction time left for the player, has a richer design expression. The two QTE forms mentioned above are also distinguished by the different design of the player’s response form.

For example, in Tomb Raider, buttons appear on the screen to prepare the player, and at the same time, “bullet time” appears to “stretch” the emergency moment for the player to react. When the circle shrinks to the correct size, the player presses the corresponding button to complete the QTE operation. While retaining the “quick” element, it also makes obvious prompts from both the picture and the button dynamic effects, effectively utilizing the player’s reaction time, thereby reducing the player’s cognitive load and improving the player’s QTE experience.

 

QTE prompt in 《Tomb Raider》

The calibration operation when repairing generators in Identity V is a typical second type of QTE form. A completion judgment area is set on the arc-shaped track, and there is also a perfect judgment area. In the game, a sound prompt appears first, and the right finger area flashes, prompting the player to prepare to tap. Then the judgment area and the red pointer that sweeps across appear, and the player taps the screen to complete the QTE operation. With the help of the length of the track, a richer design of the QTE operation can be carried out that is closer to the game form, such as the length and number of judgment areas. In Identity V, different characters may have different judgment difficulties (different lengths of judgment areas), which also enriches the character mechanism to a certain extent.

 

QTE screen of 《Identity V》

3. Use of QTE in Different Games

Music games are a game genre that can be regarded as purely QTE-driven. Precisely because they are so closely integrated with QTE, they don’t immediately come to mind. Combining the judgment method of QTE with the rhythm of music has slowly developed into a separate game category. The difference in buttons and judgment methods has also created various game forms in music games. This natural QTE form is very easy to accept and even becomes a memory of a generation.

 

《Audition》 This mode combines two QTE methods at the same time

In action games, there are many ways to bring players the excitement and impact of the picture while simplifying the action. But the most direct way is to work hard on visual expressiveness. The most typical is to increase the effect of animation performance and make sufficiently rich QTE effects.

In the God of War series, QTEs are used to show cinematic plots. They convert various directions of pushing, pulling, and struggling into buttons on the controller, simulating a series of operations. This game hopes that when Kratos is fighting the big boss, players can also participate in this thrilling battle. At the same time, the picture can also retain the cinematic scenes and sense of lens. The first half is handed over to the traditional action mode, and the second half is supplemented by QTE expression.

 

《God of War》 combines QTE with character actions

Another type of game that makes extensive use of QTE gameplay is interactive movie games. As a plot-driven game genre, it is usually criticized for its lack of gameplay. On the one hand, letting players make various choices and independently decide the direction of the plot greatly deepens the player’s sense of substitution and control; on the other hand, using the tension and sense of operation of QTE, to a certain extent, makes up for the lack of gameplay with a low threshold. Compared with earlier games of the same type, today’s interactive movie games have more interesting designs for the consequences of judgment failure. Whether the QTE is successful or not sometimes determines the direction of different endings. This may be a passive result of the player or an active choice. At the same time, like action games, the position of the UI is no longer fixed in the center or on the left and right sides of the screen, but is combined with the character’s actions to minimize the impact of the inserted QTE operation on the plot immersion.

 

《Detroit: Become Human》 QTE prompt on the enemy’s knee

It can be seen that QTE has rich applications in various games. “Quick time” is a good way to mobilize players’ emotions. Whether it is to enhance the plot and action of the game, or as a small game form alone, it has good performance. But at the same time, it is also necessary to avoid its abuse, and to reasonably combine it with the game when using it, otherwise it will only interrupt the player’s game experience. Too much is as bad as too little.

entry.title: When Players Say "Drop Rate is Low," What Should You Think About?
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

The “drop rate” is the probability that a player will get a “pleasant surprise” in the game. With the continuous development of game categories and gameplay, the “drop rate” in the player’s mouth has also expanded from the most basic monster drops to card draws, loot boxes, and all “low probability” events. In all player feedback, “drop rate” has always been a hot topic, existing extensively in various public opinions, and game industry personnel cannot avoid responding to it.

Why has “drop rate” received so much attention? How should we understand the “low drop rate” that players talk about? As a game user researcher, how should we dig out the “real problem” behind this feedback?

1. Know Yourself and Your Enemy: Why Do Games Set a “Drop Rate”?

Compared with the “functionality” emphasized by commonly used apps, games, as a form of entertainment design, pay more attention to the player’s “flow experience.”

The game experience pursues a process that makes players “excited and happy”. When a low-probability event like a “low drop rate” occurs, the pleasure feedback generated by the player will be greater. If doing something can get a reward, it will drive people to repeat it to get the reward multiple times. In games, this reward feedback is more immediate and obvious. Remember when you first came into contact with Fantasy Westward Journey, how many players wandered around in the wild just for a mutated monster, a precious bubble.

 

Have you ever wandered around the East Sea Cave for a mutated Sea Slug?

2. Put Yourself in Their Shoes: How to Understand the “Low Drop Rate” Players Talk About?

As mentioned in the previous article “What Does it Mean When Players Say a Game is ‘Grindy’?”, the “grind” mentioned by players does not necessarily equal the actual time spent in the game, but rather “I feel” that it takes a long time. The same is true for “low drop rate,” which does not necessarily reflect that the game’s numerical settings are really unreasonable, but may just be “I feel” that the drop rate is low.

We can break down the problem behind this as follows:

What Exactly is the “Drop Rate” that Players are Talking About?

“Low drop rate” is not just a “mathematical problem,” but also a game experience problem. And it will produce different situations when it corresponds to different games and different gameplay. To analyze this problem, we need to identify the context in which players mention “drop rate.”

For example, after a card game is launched, it often receives feedback of “low drop rate” in the early stage. Our first reaction might be: to confirm the drop rate… to think about whether the drop rate is very low…

 

Wait a minute!

Don’t fall into the “number trap” so quickly. Think about it first, is the “drop rate” that the player said consistent with what you understand now? “Low drop rate” does not necessarily mean “the value set by the game is low,” but the gap between the player’s psychological expectations and the current situation.

 

On the game’s official website and card draw page, developers have disclosed the probability of high-level items appearing. At this time, it is not necessarily the “item” itself that is the problem, but that there are items and characters in this pool. The guaranteed minimum that players want is a “character”, but what they may draw is an “item”. Therefore, even if they draw a guaranteed item, some players will think that the “experience is not good”. They didn’t get what they wanted, and they may even feel unhappy because they “wasted a guaranteed opportunity”.

So in this scenario, the “low drop rate” that players are talking about should actually be interpreted as “low probability of dropping characters”. Knowing the player’s needs makes it easier for us to take the next step. In subsequent updates, the product also improves the player’s experience in drawing cards through more detailed card pools, designated guaranteed directions, and exchange of specific cards after a certain number of draws. These are specific adjustments made based on specific issues.

Why Do Players Think the “Drop Rate” is Low?

So why do players frequently report “low drop rate” problems?

The first common reason: “Unscientific experimental attempts” and “Survivorship Bias”

Since 2016, domestic online games are required to disclose the probability of drawing or synthesizing, but although the probability has been disclosed, “misunderstandings” still exist.

Example: The success probability of strengthening in a certain game is announced as 25%. Players may subconsciously think that this means “as long as I strengthen 4 times, it is a 100% probability”. This is definitely unreasonable from a statistical point of view. Probability cannot be accumulated. Each strengthening is a separate event. “25%” is an expected value, not a guaranteed result. But it is easy to be subjective in player feedback.

In addition, players who are particularly lucky are also more willing to show their results on public platforms, that is, “Survivorship Bias”, which makes other players who browse the posts more unbalanced: “Why are they all so lucky? Is this game targeting me?”

Here we also recommend a previous article “Demystifying How Random Numbers Are Generated”, which may help you more intuitively see the distribution of 10,000 people drawing 100 cards and obtaining SSRs in a purely random state.

 

The second common reason: The profound impression under the influence of the “Zeigarnik Effect”

People have a natural drive to “finish things from beginning to end”. The reason why they forget the completed work is because the motivation to complete it has been satisfied. If the work is not yet complete, this motivation makes people have a deep impression of it.

This mentality of keeping unfinished things deeply in memory is called the Zeigarnik Effect. The same is true in games. Players will have goals and tasks one by one. For example, after a new card pool comes out, players want to draw a new character. When they haven’t drawn it, they always feel uneasy and upset, and have an unfinished emotion. This emotion enhances the player’s memory of their card draw status (how many draws, what pity pulls), and keeps driving them until they draw the target card.

Therefore, even if the number of players who obtain items at normal odds is larger in the overall player group, posts complaining about “low drop rates” can always outperform in terms of the number of feedbacks.

 

Not Noticing What the “Core Problem” Is

Most of the time, “drop rate” is not the core contradiction, other problems are. The game has a complex system. In this system, dropping equipment is not the whole of the game, let alone the whole of the player experience. The feedback that players ultimately express seems to be a “drop rate” problem, but it is not actually caused by the drop rate, but other content of the game that amplifies this problem.

In a player survey, we had this conversation:

 

Here, the player thinks that the “low drop rate” is slowing down his development speed, and we should reflect on what methods we have designed to help players improve, and why these methods have not been effective. Perhaps the game provides too few channels for players to improve. In addition to direct drops, can players obtain them through trading, crafting, etc.?
