That is to say, to solve this “drop rate” problem, we actually need to look at the development design provided by the game, whether it is rich and adapted to the player’s game habits. More output channels and the conversion between discarded equipment may all be directions for optimization.

There are two perspectives that can help us think about and break down the “low drop rate” problem.

Thinking direction 1: Use “game design” to reverse engineer the drop rate problem, and trace back to the pre-drop rate link

Assuming that the operation directly related to the drop rate is an “activity”, we need to calculate the player’s “effort” in it. The more complex and difficult the activity, the different the player’s feedback will be.

Thinking direction 2: Use “user experience” to reverse engineer the drop rate problem, and what other factors have an impact

The various links in the game are interconnected. When analyzing player feedback, consider whether the problem of low drop rate raised by the player at this time can be transformed into focusing on the player’s feelings in daily gameplay, and analyzing whether the current player’s combat power level/achievement status/game goals have reached a bottleneck or far exceed the game development progress.

In summary, when we encounter feedback of “low drop rate”, we might as well ask a few more “whys”. Why do players think the drop rate is low? And why do players think that the low drop rate is the most important factor affecting their gaming experience?

3. Countermeasures: How to Adjust in the Face of “Low Drop Rate”?

Will Increasing the Drop Rate Solve the Problem?

In response to the “low drop rate” problem, directly “adjusting the drop rate” is certainly not the best choice. In all user experience optimization, we must refuse the behavior of “treating the symptoms but not the root cause”. In the cases mentioned above, we have seen the different root causes that can be derived from the same feedback of “low drop rate”: “what is dropped is not what is wanted”, “there are few channels for development”, “the pre-activity is too boring/too difficult” and so on.

Let’s imagine what would happen if the drop rate were increased?

① Games focus on the state of flow. The reason why “dropping top-quality equipment” can make players think it is interesting and interesting is precisely because of its scarcity. If a prop with a 10% drop rate is changed to a 90% drop, what excitement will players have?

② What if it’s just a fine-tuning? For example, adjust the probability of 10% to 20%, which maintains the rarity and does increase the drop rate. If this is the case, it cannot eradicate the player’s perception of probability. Under a large sample, this adjustment of the drop rate may be diluted, and there will still be some players who will achieve it in a way that far exceeds the actual probability - they will still receive a lot of feedback about the low drop rate.

③ What about adding a guaranteed mechanism? The guaranteed mechanism is indeed the current mainstream operating model. At least players can get a reward after a certain number of times. But there is also a problem with this. What kind of guarantee is “conscientious”? When the game is directly linked to payment, this matter becomes even more difficult to please everyone.

 

After Breaking Down the “Drop Rate” Problem, What’s Next?

User research is not a “one-shot deal”. Players may raise the problem of low drop rate at different stages of the game version. We need to keep tracking and constantly analyzing: Perhaps the solution we designed in the previous time did not achieve the desired effect.

For example, unlike the “guaranteed” method used in the card draw gameplay, the common method in cultivation games is to produce a substitute material A. Even if the player cannot obtain the equipment by directly farming, they can also obtain material A with a certain probability. After accumulating a certain amount, they can use A to make the desired props. If the player mentions “low drop rate” again under this condition, we can further analyze the effect and usage of material A: whether the drop also involves probability, which lengthens the timeline? Is the threshold too high, and players are caught in a cycle of wanting to get material A to improve their equipment, but their equipment needs to be made with material A.

entry.title: Analysis of the Thai Game Market and Game Localization Process
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

1. Game Localization Process

What is “Localization”?

Actually, “localization” is not simply having the target language in a foreign game. The premise of localization is whether the game is open to the target region. Secondly, it is to modify and adjust the content in the game appropriately according to regional differences. Of course, the main content of localization work is to unify things that are well known abroad but little known domestically into popular domestic terms. This article will introduce what game localization is from several directions: process, cases, and market.

The usual game localization process

  • Step 1: Integration and analysis of game content. Combining the core gameplay and market conditions, the localization team obtains a player profile through a comprehensive assessment, and completes the rating of the game product at the same time. Regional differences breed different cultures. Usually, the localization team needs to integrate specific content in the game, such as text, audio, and some specific elements, and continue to follow up on subsequent translation and optimization after systematic analysis. According to the resources required for the localization project, overall analysis can not only clarify the project direction, but also help the project manager formulate project plans and promote budget execution.

  • Step 2: Sorting and packaging of original game materials. Game materials related to localization needs usually include game code, audio, text, and even the introduction of the game background. In addition, a corpus is also essential, including Translation Memory, Term Bases, and Style Guide. Sorting and packaging the original materials can better provide them to the staff of the localization project and corresponding suppliers.

  • Step 3: Localization of game code. After confirming the code text that needs to be localized, extract the relevant strings in the game code and transfer them to the Translation Management System. In this process, if the code is not suitable for localization, or is not efficient enough and requires repeated work, thereby increasing labor costs, the code should also be iterated and optimized.

  • Step 4: Integration of the translation management system. After the strings in the game code are entered into the translation management system, it is necessary to intervene in the translation platform or Computer Aided Translation tools to support translators in translation. In this process, if the translation management system has already integrated related auxiliary tools, then only need to add the translator to the system, and assign tasks to promote translation work.

  • Step 5: Translator translation. The progress of translation can be detected from the translation management system.

  • Step 6: Localization of other non-text elements. According to the player profile, target market culture, and needs, some elements of the game need to be adjusted and modified to suit the target audience. In this process, cultural taboo issues need special attention.

  • Step 7: Quality inspection. The quality inspection of translation includes grammar, spelling, semantics, and whether the terminology translation is consistent. After the translation is imported into the game and the integration is completed, it is also necessary to screen for functional bugs, etc.

  • Step 8: Integration and adaptation adjustment of localized content. Integrate the reviewed translated text with the completed localized game content. If functional bugs are found after screening, they need to be repaired and the adaptability of the UI user interface needs to be adjusted to ensure that the text can be displayed in the appropriate position.

In game design, the earlier the localization needs are considered, the easier the subsequent localization work will be. In addition to the above steps, Thai localization also has some issues that require special attention, such as overlapping diacritic marks.

2. Common Localization and UI Problems

Incomplete display of diacritic marks, a common problem in Thai games

90% of Thai games have the problem of incomplete display of diacritic marks. Incomplete display of diacritic marks means that when vowels and tones are typed in the same position, they will often overlap in the same position, or the spacing is too far.

 

From the picture above, we can see that the word in the rightmost part has overlapping diacritic marks, making it impossible to read the word normally.

This problem has long existed in many Thai games. Naraka: Bladepoint also had this problem during the Thai localization development stage. In order to successfully complete the localization of the Thai version of Naraka: Bladepoint, the global localization team, the interaction experience design team, and the product program team worked together to provide a model for game globalization and efficient localization process. In fact, most Thai players know about this problem, but players don’t pay much attention to it unless it causes the original meaning of the word to change. For example, in the picture above, one of the diacritic marks of หมาป่าขนทอง (Rong Jin Wolf) disappears, resulting in the meaning becoming “dog throws golden Rong”. Once this type of problem is seen by players, it may be ridiculed. However, this problem was well solved during the localization process of Naraka: Bladepoint, making the localization quality of Naraka: Bladepoint in Thai receive more praise from players than other games. Therefore, players have a huge sense of intimacy with the game during the game experience, which has become one of the reasons why many Thai players choose Naraka: Bladepoint.

Other examples of game localization errors

 

《Sword Art Online: Hollow Fragment》

Sword Art Online is a popular cross-media game, covering comics, animation, and video games, and it has gained a considerable number of fans in the West. Sword Art Online: Hollow Realization was listed as one of the best anime series games in 2017.

But its second part, Sword Art Online: Hollow Fragment, has many problems in the Western market, and localization is one of them. From the picture, we can see that the customer said: Hey, is that black man sexually harassing the maid?

But in fact, the black man the customer said refers to the male protagonist Kirito in black, not a black man. In this scene, Kirito did not make any sexual harassment behavior. Such localization errors will seriously affect the player’s experience of the game.

3. Thailand’s Gaming Industry Continues to Expand

Thailand’s 32 million gamers have helped the Thai game market generate more than approximately 6.8 billion RMB in revenue, making it one of the most watched game markets in Southeast Asia.

The normal growth rate of the Thai game market is an average of 10% per year. Due to the impact of the epidemic in 2020, the growth rate of the Thai game market has increased to 34.89%. According to the current situation where people are still staying at home, the growth rate of the Thai game market in 2021 should continue to increase to 15%. Therefore, the Thai game industry is constantly developing talent and building an ecosystem in the industry.

  • 2018 growth rate 13.78%
  • 2019 growth rate 15.96%
  • 2020 growth rate 34.89%, about 6.86 billion RMB

However, the popularity of games in Thailand mainly started from mobile devices such as smartphones, and then spread to other platforms such as PCs or consoles. Mobile games have the highest share, at 4.203 billion RMB (divided into Android 2.215 billion RMB and iOS 1.988 billion RMB), followed by PC games at 1.646 billion RMB and console games at 957 million RMB.

4. Thai Players’ Game Platform Choice Trend

Undoubtedly, the preferred platform for Thai players is smartphones, and 95% of Thai players use mobile phones to play games. Mobile phones are the most popular platform in Thailand. According to Consumer Insights, most players also play games on consoles and PCs:

Among Thailand’s Internet users,

  • 95% of players play games on mobile phones
  • 84% of players play games on PC
  • 69% of players play games on consoles

According to the data, female players prefer to play mobile games, while male players prefer to play games on other platforms:

 

In the past 6 months, the vast majority of paying players (95%) will spend money on game props or virtual goods. The most frequently purchased props by men are playable characters (42%), and the most frequently purchased props by women are game currency (46%). Among all players, in-game currency is the prop with the highest purchase rate.

5. Popular Games in the Thai Market

Multiplayer competitive games, especially MOBA, Battle Royale, MMORPG, ARPG, and strategy games, are the most profitable in Thailand. Works based on popular game IPs also perform well. These top-ranked games increase user engagement and revenue by increasingly frequent game updates and in-game activities for Thai users. In addition, many of these games have an Asian-style art style due to the influence of the northern Asian market.

  • 45% of players in Thailand have played Coin Master in the past 6 months
  • About 44% of players have played FIFA
  • FIFA is more popular among men
  • Coin Master is more popular among women

 

Popular Android mobile games in Thailand in April 2022

 

 

Popular PC games in the Thai market in 2022

It can be seen that 24Entertainment’s Naraka: Bladepoint ranks 6th, which proves that Naraka: Bladepoint is very popular in the Thai market.

According to Newzoo research, the favorite game type of Thai players is shooting games:

  • 38% of players play shooting games on mobile phones
  • 35% of players play shooting games on consoles
  • 34% of players play shooting games on PC

This makes sense, because in the past 6 months, more than one-third of Thai players have played GTA or Call of Duty (35% for each game). Considering the huge consumption potential of Thai players, it makes great sense to localize games for this emerging market.

6. Conclusion

As it stands, the development trend of Thai games will continue to rise, and the proportion of player growth will also increase correspondingly. From the player growth rate of only 13.78% in 2018 to the instant increase to 34.89% in 2020, it is not difficult to see that Thai games still have a lot of room for development. Text is one of the parts that players have the most contact with. No matter how fun the game is, if players can’t understand the text, the game experience will be worse. Game localization is often misunderstood as simply copying and pasting with translation tools, but it actually involves many professional skills. In addition to being proficient in the corresponding language, localization staff also need to be very familiar with the product and the market. It is necessary to consider what kind of expression is most suitable for the target audience and avoid cultural conflicts and other problems.

Many game developers regard localization as the final link in the game development cycle. For them, this is like an extra step. But in fact, this approach is not wise, but will make the game miss the opportunity of overseas markets. When a product has not been localized and entered the local market, it may face a large number of copycat products in the local market, and thus return without success. If localization is carried out after similar situations occur, it will lead to the need to rewrite the source code and create translation materials. When players choose to experience new games, localization will also be one of the factors that players consider. Excellent localization is more like a reassurance. In addition to giving players a better gaming experience, it can also make players feel that the developers are making games with their hearts, so that players can feel more at ease when experiencing the game.

entry.title: The Evolution of Game Subtitle Design
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Movie subtitles, as frequent visitors to the big screen, have a profound impact on the film and television industry. But when we turn our attention to game subtitles, the situation seems a bit subtle. Players immersed in the audio-visual feast may often not notice the small subtitles, and sometimes even think that subtitles are obstacles that hinder them from taking screenshots and enjoying the game. In some games that do not pay much attention to UI design, game subtitles may be routinely delisted. You may ask: Is it wrong to look for subtitles in the game world? But perhaps, there are far more design points in game subtitles than you think.

1. The Past and Present of Game Subtitles

1940s: The Era of Title Cards

Have you ever thought about this question: In the past when computer technology and digital photography were underdeveloped, in the era of film and even silent films, how did subtitles appear?

Before the subtitles we are familiar with now were born, filmmakers printed important subtitles on the bottom plate to make “title cards”, which were photographed and inserted into the movie sequence frames to express key plot content. The era when “title cards” flourished was the golden age of silent films. The unique advantage of title cards is that the translation of movies becomes very easy. Filmmakers only need to remove and replace the title cards to complete the translation of the movie. Behind the small title cards is the export of a large number of films and the spread and penetration of culture.

 

Title card in a Chaplin film

Technology brings development, and demand brings progress. Sound films, a rich form, soon appeared, and title cards gradually withdrew from the public eye. But before the producers had time to celebrate the innovation of film technology, the difficulty of film translation followed. If you want to export your own movies, whether it is remake or dubbing, the cost is extremely high. It can be said that demand forces progress. Less than two years after the advent of sound films, subtitle technology was born and has been continuously iterated and evolved in the following years.

1980s: CC Subtitles and Accessibility Design

As mentioned above, the emergence of subtitles was originally to make movies easier to watch and more efficient to spread. It is foreseeable that the emergence of subtitles will not only erase cultural boundaries, but also break the shackles of disability.

In the 1980s, a more detailed subtitle form with auxiliary functions, “Closed Captioning”, was born, which was later known as “CC subtitles”. In this kind of subtitles, not only the dialogue of the characters will be presented, but also the key music, sound effects, and the name and even the corresponding position of the speaker in the scene will be marked, so that people with hearing impairment can also enjoy the program content. Apple’s products and promotional videos have provided good support for CC subtitles, and bilibili in China also provides CC subtitle options.

 

Comparison of CC subtitles and regular subtitles

1990s: The Emergence of Game Subtitles

It is also the progress brought about by demand. At the end of the 20th century, with the rapid improvement of the game industry in technology and thought, subtitles, a very functional component, and some established usage rules were also extended to game products.

 

Game “Half-Life”

This is also an important node in the history of games. The famous id Software developed and shared the Quake engine, and Valve created its first game “Half-Life” based on it. “Half-Life” is a brand new type of game with cinematic narrative, coherent level design, a lot of dialogue and descriptive text. Because of this, many unexpected problems also appeared, including the embarrassing situation that the experience was affected because the dialogue could not be heard clearly. Early games did not have a lot of plots and descriptions, and did not rely on text for assistance, so naturally there was no such problem. Fortunately, there were experts among the people. Due to the convenience of the Quake engine, excellent subtitle mods and other mods continued to emerge, which improved the game experience and added fuel to the development of game subtitles.

Today: From Subtitles Default Off to Subtitles Default On

For players of the millennial generation, subtitles in games seem to be there by nature. They are like air. You often hardly notice their existence. Only when you are “short of breath” (can’t see the subtitles clearly) will you curse the game interaction designer. But we can see from the above that game subtitles did not exist at the beginning, and there has been a lot of experience from the default off of game subtitles to the default on of game subtitles.

At the beginning of Red Dead Redemption, the protagonist John, sitting on the train, listens to the chatter of men, women and children in the carriage, thus introducing the entire game world. However, if you are a player who is not good at listening, this group dialogue is more like a lullaby, so that you have to turn on the subtitles and watch it again. This situation was not uncommon at that time, because many games maintained the habit of “subtitles default off”. Today, many games, including Red Dead Redemption 2, default game subtitles on. This change in status also reflects that the status of subtitles is gradually improving, and developers are becoming more and more user-friendly.

For normal users, their hearing is sufficient to support them to understand the content without turning on subtitles. But in special cases, such as when the surrounding environment is very noisy and the player has difficulty concentrating on listening, subtitles will be very valuable.

At the same time, we can also conclude from the history of subtitle development that there are four scenarios suitable for game subtitles: for games with localization needs, for players with hearing impairments to play games, for intense and exciting games where users cannot concentrate on listening, and for playing games in noisy environments.

2. Common Problems in Game Subtitle Design

Font Size

The first is the choice of text size. If the font is too large, it will block the line of sight; if the font is too small, it will be difficult for players to distinguish the dialogue content of the game. For developers, the most important thing to consider is that for different players and different game devices, the suitable font size is not the same. For example, some players may have high-performance hosts and a super-large curved screen in front of them when playing games; while some players may only be able to let their small and thin laptops bear the burden. Therefore, the best solution is that the developers have considered these factors during testing, and tested the game effects under different game devices and playing distances, and ensured the readability of the text in most cases. Of course, you can also add custom options for users so that they can choose the text size themselves. But I personally think that the best solution is to let the developers complete the 99 steps of the design, such as making highly versatile designs or self-adaptive designs, and players do not need to make too many choices or changes for comfort.

We can also learn from the established norms of other industries. Amazon’s UI guidelines stipulate that 1080p, UI text uses a minimum of 28px. Channel 4 in the UK requires that all high-definition subtitle specifications should be 46px, and standard definition should be 26px.

Contrast

In subtitle design, it is very important that the text needs to have a high contrast with the background to ensure that the text is easy to read. Sometimes, as the game background changes, the text will be blurred because it is too close to the background color. The general and most economical solution is to add a dialog box. The translucent dialog box can ensure the high contrast between the text and the background without destroying the game screen. Some games also use the text color to change with the background to improve the contrast. For example, the game What Remains of Edith Finch, which will be discussed later, its text will change in real time with the different colors of the scene to ensure that the text is readable throughout the process.

Designers need to pay special attention to the use of red, because for most color-blind players, red will appear dark brown.

Too Much Text

When arranging text content, you should avoid presenting too much text at one time, which will not only affect the game experience, but also cause reading difficulties. Line-by-line typesetting and reasonable sentence breaks can greatly improve readability. Line-by-line typesetting needs to control a single subtitle to about two lines; reasonable sentence breaks are based on natural pauses, plus the punctuation marks of the sentence.

Game subtitles can also learn from the standards of the television industry in various countries or regions. If it is really necessary to present subtitles in multiple lines, the first line should be the longest, but at the same time, the length of each line should be roughly the same.

Automatic Mode

I believe that everyone has had the experience of turning on the automatic playback mode because they had to free their hands to eat snacks when going through the plot, and the playback speed here is also something that developers need to consider. Different players have different reading speeds. For example, for children, they need more time to read the same text. The reading speed needs to consider most players, and relevant literature or established UI design specifications can be referred to. The most ideal state is to set multiple speeds for players to choose.

3. Advanced Usage Guide for Game Subtitles

After talking about the basic part of subtitle design, let’s take a look at the advanced application tutorial examples of subtitle design - What Remains of Edith Finch. From the purpose and effect of subtitles, I divide them into three categories: assisting immersive experience, guiding players’ vision, and enhancing the sense of game interaction.

Auxiliary Immersion Experience

(1) Floating Subtitles

The most intuitive way in the game is to present the main plot of the game with a large number of floating subtitles. These floating subtitles appear on the player’s travel route, allowing the player to experience the feeling of deepening in time and space with the plot. At the same time, these subtitles will also take into account the player’s current perspective. For example, in Molly’s story, the Molly played by the player finally becomes a snake. At this time, the arrangement of subtitles is based on the snake’s perspective.

 

 

 

Floating Subtitles

(2) Text Reading

The large background narration and story description in the game are presented in the form of letters. The player seems to have really become a person in the game, reading the text that can be flipped through and written in the game, rather than reading the subtitles at a fixed position on the screen. For example, at the beginning of the game, the protagonist played by the player opens the diary left by his mother on the boat and learns about the past stories of the family; in Barbara’s story, the player reads Barbara’s story by reading the comics. The design of the text is also the style of comic-style dialog boxes, or exaggerated onomatopoeia. Every time the player experiences the story of a family member, he will open the diary he carries with him and draw a portrait of this person on the family tree, and this interface is also our menu interface.

 

 

 

(3) Text Transition

The way players enter or exit the story of a family member is by reading the letters or reports left by him or his relatives and friends found in his room. The text transition is very smooth and easy to make people feel that they are not finished.

 

For example, Walter, goes outside after 30 years. He sees the light, but at the same instance, is taken by a train.

 

 

Text Transition

Visual Guidance

(1) Guiding Items

The most commonly used method in the game is to place relevant plot subtitles around related items, plus a certain forced perspective conversion, to achieve the role of emphasizing and pointing to specific items. At the same time, this method is also used to guide interaction.

 

 

 

The position of the subtitles guides the player to the tent in the corner, so that the player unknowingly completes the content of blowing over the tent in the plot. The player’s surprise when the effect is triggered unconsciously is exactly what the designer hopes the player will empathize with the protagonist in the game.

(2) Text Disappearing Effect

The special effect of text disappearing can also be used to make a big fuss. For example, in order to guide the player to make the action of “lying on the peephole and looking into the room”, the designer makes the disappearing effect of the relevant plot text be sucked in by the peephole, naturally guiding the player to the peephole. And the entrance to the underground cave is in a very remote place in the player’s initial perspective, and the game also guides the player to find the entrance through the text disappearing effect.

 

 

 

Text disappearing effect

(3) Enhancing Game Interaction

The interactivity of subtitles is also a unique part of this game. Some interactive texts can greatly enhance the player’s gaming experience. For example, as the player pushes open the fence, the text is scattered on the ground, giving the player feedback and bringing a different kind of small surprise. The player manipulates the kite to return the plot text to its place, so that the player can empathize with the character who is flying the kite while thinking richly. The text plays the perspective of the rock, and as the Walter played by the player smashes the underground cave, it rises and falls and is finally smashed.

 

 

 

Game interaction

4. The Future of Game Subtitles: How to Design VR Subtitles

When talking about the development history of subtitles earlier, it is easy for us to find that demand drives progress. The emergence of VR games and the demand for VR subtitles naturally also require designers to master certain VR subtitle design points. From the most basic readability and comfort, designers need to consider not only the text itself, but also the presentation of text by VR hardware and the space where the player is located is no longer a comfortable sofa and a super large display, but a heavy head-mounted device and a dizzying panoramic space.

 

Subtitles in the VR game “Half-Life: Alyx”

From the perspective of readability, the first thing to pay attention to is the distortion of the space in VR. Designers cannot simply place two-dimensional UI information directly, but need to redesign the interaction method and interaction range according to the VR operation characteristics and habits. At the same time, different from flat two-dimensional design, the unique property of VR is the depth of field (Z axis). The Z axis expands the possibility of interaction forms, but it is also necessary to pay attention to the physiological characteristics of players having difficulty focusing when the Z axis distance is too far. Secondly, there is the problem of resolution. Since the current VR standards for various platforms are not uniform, the resolution of elements in some platforms is extremely low, and thin lines are prone to serious jagged problems. Therefore, interactive designers should avoid line-shaped icons and fonts that are too small and too thin. Finally, there is the design of dynamic effects, which should not only avoid competing for the attention of the theme information, but also pay attention to the fact that excessive dynamic effects in the VR environment are more likely to make users dizzy.

 

Interactive Guidance in “Half-Life: Alyx”

From the perspective of comfort, thousands of words can be summed up in one sentence: reduce head movement to reduce dizziness. Since the VR screen has no edges, designers need to place elements and interactions within the field of view as much as possible, so that users do not need to turn their heads hard. In places with frequent interaction, try to reduce the amplitude of dynamic effects, avoid narrowness or excessive brightness, and reduce users’ dizziness and visual fatigue. At the same time, for moving street scenes or objects, try to adopt a constant speed to avoid users suffering from motion sickness.

 

Depth of field (Z-axis)

 

Designers should try to place content within the field of view

entry.title: Why Do Player Surveys Need to Talk to Players About Their Lives?
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

1. What Do Player Surveys Usually Survey?

Long-time followers of NetEase ThunderFire UX should already be familiar with various user research methods from previous articles. Common user research methods include questionnaire surveys, user interviews, lab tests, focus groups, street intercept tests, etc. Research methods always revolve around the problems encountered in each stage of game development. We try to help solve various problems encountered by the product through player research. In the early stages of the game, we will investigate the current market situation and the needs of players for specific types of games; in rapid development, we will investigate whether the current core gameplay of the game is sufficiently competitive in the market, and whether the game’s novice guidance is smooth; after the game is launched, we will also investigate the opinions and needs of various players on the game.

All player research can be said to be goal-oriented. We need to draw clear and effective conclusions to better optimize the game. Because of this, we are so focused on any small problem in the game, and hope to improve the game’s new additions, payment, and retention by changing it. However, playing a game is a dynamic interaction process between the player and the game. Each player’s game behavior is not only affected by game factors, but also by the complex factor of “himself”. Before becoming a player, a player is already a living person, a complex individual who has already formed his own preferences and attitudes, and a social role with various social identities. It can be said that what kind of person a player is predicts what kind of behavior he will have. If you cannot jump out of the game itself to sensually understand the player, you cannot rationally understand the player’s various incredible behaviors in the game. However, this part of player research is often ignored, and is considered to be of little help in solving actual game problems.

2. Why Talk to Players About Life in Player Research?

As the years of doing user research work increase, we are increasingly “off-topic” when doing player research. We no longer only talk to players about games, but also start to talk to players about life. This seemingly inexplicable operation is due to the fact that all human behavior is determined by their own needs, and humans are social animals. To understand player needs, you must understand the player’s life.

 

When doing MMO player research, we once came into contact with a player. His way of playing MMOs was very different from that of ordinary MMO players. He neither cultivated combat power nor participated in activities, but he was online for a very long time every day. Why is he so loyal to this game?

We tried to dig out some of his views on the game, but found that his evaluations of all the game systems were mediocre, just saying that the game atmosphere was very good. He just hangs up in the game every day, mainly to see if anyone is looking for him to chat, and then to see what everyone is saying in the guild channel. Such a game experience seems to be no fun at all in the eyes of ordinary people, but he has been playing like this for several years. Until we asked about his life status, he said that he is now the main source of income for the family and has great pressure at work, but this negative energy cannot be told to family and friends. Society does not seem to allow middle-aged men to admit their vulnerability, so he chose to talk to netizens in the game. “I can talk to friends in the game, purely to find someone to chat and talk to. We are friends when we are online, and we have our own lives when we are offline. We can comfort and tease each other.”

In this way, it is not difficult to understand that for him, the game is more of a place to relieve real-world pressure, and the quality of the gameplay is irrelevant to him, so he can play an MMO like a chat app. He is not attracted to other new games on the market with more diverse gameplay, so he can stay loyal.

3. What Factors Influence Players’ Game Motivation?

Many researchers have explored how players’ game motivation affects their game behavior, and have divided players into different types based on their behavior. The most famous of these is probably Bartle’s player model, which divides players into Killers, Achievers, Explorers, and Socializers along four dimensions.

 

The X-axis is the object in the game, and the Y-axis is the method in the game. Simply put, killer players like to take action against players, and they are keen to defeat others; achiever players like to take action against the world, and they are happy to complete various tasks and goals in the game; social players like to interact with players, and they are even more interested in game players than in the game itself; explorer players like to interact with the game world, and they are happy to explore various contents in the game.

Quantic Foundry’s model extracts 12 player game motivations through cluster analysis, and divides players into 6 categories: “Action, Social, Mastery, Achievement, Immersion, and Creativity”. It will not be elaborated here.

 

These models effectively help us understand players from the perspective of needs. We can know from them what specific needs in the game affect players’ behavior of playing games, that is, what players really want to do in the game.

In actual research, we found that players’ needs are not only affected by in-game factors, but also by out-of-game factors. If we go one step further and regard games as a kind of ordinary entertainment activity, and think about why players play games, we will find some interesting things. For example, players who choose to play games are not necessarily real gamers. Some out-of-game factors that we often ignore are also affecting players’ game motivation, including the player’s life status, and the player’s attitude and concept of the game.

We found that some players choose to play games out of real love. They believe that games give meaning to their lives and are the best way to mobilize energy. Correspondingly, they often have their own clear preferences and attitudes in game selection, and their behavior is relatively consistent. We can easily classify these players into one of the above player models.

Another part of players, when talking about games, regard games as a regulator of daily life. For them, games are not much different from other entertainment activities such as watching movies, and are mainly for relaxing themselves. These popcorn-type players often pay more attention to the visuals and excitement of the game, but may not have high requirements for gameplay. They are also relatively more susceptible to changes in life. For example, they may suddenly churn if they are busy recently, and may return without reason after being idle.

 

There are also some players whose gaming experience looks very complicated, and their gaming time seems to be very heavy. But once you ask carefully, you will feel that they do not have clear game preferences, and even their understanding of gameplay is not like that of a game player. Their words and deeds are always contradictory, so that it is difficult for you to classify them as any type of player in the above player model. These players are likely to regard games as social activities. They play games mainly influenced by friends around them, in order not to be out of touch with people around them. What they value is being able to play with friends around them, not the game itself. It is not difficult to understand why the games they choose are often very different; if you delve too much into their evaluation of a certain game, you will fall into a trap.

The MMO player exemplified above represents a large group of game players, that is, those who desire to escape from daily life. They may have the need to relieve pressure, and interesting game environments and low game thresholds are easy to attract them; they may also have unique emotional needs, wanting to find social connections in the game, or find their lost selves, so they pay more attention to whether the game is humane, rather than the quality of the game.

 

4. How to Talk to Players About Life

In the research, we found that the life status of players is a very difficult topic to talk about. Many players are reluctant to expose too much of their personal information in the research. In the actual operation process, the tips we use include the following:

  • Give players an opportunity to introduce themselves. A player who is willing to communicate with you about daily life will inadvertently reveal more of himself, and then you can follow his words to ask more potential information.
  • Ask about the player’s life status at the right time instead of asking directly. For example, when talking about the player’s views on daily activities, you can take the opportunity to understand whether the player’s life status is busy, and how much weight the game has in his life.
  • Communicate with players like a friend and give appropriate self-disclosure. Qualified user researchers should not express their own attitudes too much, as this may induce players, but there is no need to be a robot. Appropriate reactions will make players feel that they have met a game enthusiast and are more willing to communicate with you. More content will not be repeated here, and we will expand on it in the next article.

In short, all human behavior is motivated. We cannot talk about a player’s game behavior without his daily life, and we cannot talk about what is wrong with the game without the player himself. Player research itself is a big topic. Perhaps only by truly understanding the player’s life status and attitude towards life can we see the living players through the fog.

entry.title: It's Just Simple Elimination, Why Is It So Addictive?
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

1. Match-3 Games and Their Brief History

Elimination games are a type of puzzle game where players mainly win by matching and eliminating a certain number of identical game elements, such as fruits, gems, animal heads, building blocks, mahjong tiles, etc., so that they are adjacent to each other. Usually, three identical elements are matched and eliminated, so this type is also called “match-3 games”. Some match-3 games will add a development/story, or management line on top of the elimination gameplay. Players obtain items through winning the elimination gameplay, and use them to upgrade buildings, improve character stats, etc.

Tetris should be the earliest ancestor of elimination games, and Dr. Mario, later released by Nintendo after Tetris, can be said to be the prototype of match-3 type games.

 

After that, games like Bejeweled and Zuma were released one after another. Richer elimination rules, gorgeous elimination feedback, and realistic elimination sound effects made the two games successful worldwide, pushing the match-3 game genre to the world.

 

To this day, match-3 games have occupied a stable position in both domestic and foreign markets. In the “2021 China Game Industry Report” released by the China Game Industry Research Institute, elimination games accounted for about 4% of the market share of the top 100 mobile games by revenue.

 

Overseas, elimination games have always occupied an important position in the mobile game best-selling list. According to DoF data, the global puzzle game market reached US$5.1 billion in 2020, of which elimination games accounted for US$3.76 billion (excluding China, Japan, and South Korea). Especially in the United States, elimination games are the largest segment of its mobile game market, and they are also an important region for domestic elimination game manufacturers to go overseas. According to GameRefinery data, elimination games accounted for 21% and 16% of the revenue of the US iOS game market in 2020 and May 2021, respectively. Among the Top 100 games on the US iOS best-selling list, elimination games account for about 15 games, among which King, Playrix, and Zynga, several major elimination game manufacturers, have occupied the main positions all year round.

 

King’s series of elimination/casual games

The core gameplay of match-3 games is actually not complicated, but the love of people all over the world for them can span decades. It seems that it will continue to be popular for decades to come. Why is it so attractive? We try to find some answers from the perspective of psychological mechanisms.

2. Elimination Gameplay Unit: Easy-to-Obtain Instant Reinforcement

No matter how old the elimination game is, it always has several steps: “gathering the same color through operation (filling the same row in Tetris)”, “eliminating the same color blocks (the same row)”, and “increasing the score/scoring numbers”, forming the smallest gameplay unit of the elimination game, and the process of the game is to constantly repeat this action. Every time you complete a gameplay unit, the game will give audio and visual prompts, such as the elimination animation and score display in the picture. Visually, the stacking of the same color naturally conforms to human perceptual fluency preferences, which will bring a sense of neatness and comfort.

 

While the elimination action is in progress, the game system will generate sound effects such as “great”, characters, and scores. In human culture, these all represent praise and are very direct positive feedback. In the current popular elimination games, there are even combo settings (the more you repeat the elimination action, the higher the score brought by the combo), and there are various functional blocks, which are more gorgeous and exaggerated in the effect of elimination, and can bring more attractive visual feedback. Even the remaining steps after each elimination round will have a fancy score settlement performance. All of them have increased the feedback after the elimination action, doubling the player’s pleasure.

 

From the perspective of psychological mechanisms, each elimination gameplay unit is a positive reinforcement - you make an action, and then immediately get a pleasant experience. Theoretical research on positive reinforcement has found that when people take a certain action, they can get a certain pleasant result from others, and this result in turn becomes a force to promote people to tend to or repeat this action. This is the basic principle of the core gameplay of elimination, which seems simple, but you always want to continue.

3. Randomness: The Joy Written in the Genes

Most elimination games, on top of the pleasant unit of elimination, have superimposed a layer of human’s joyful addiction written in the genes - randomness. In elimination games, the block matrix given to you at the beginning of each round is random, and the sequence of blocks that fall from above after elimination is also random. When you are lucky, you can randomly get some functional blocks at the beginning. For example, colored candies that can eliminate all blocks of the same color, striped blocks that can eliminate the entire row/column, and coloring candies that can collectively change the color of blocks of a certain color. These props will reduce the difficulty of passing the level to varying degrees. When you are lucky, you can encounter a king-bomb opening - two adjacent colored candies. After they move each other, there will be a full-screen elimination effect, and you can even pass the level with full stars in one step.

 

This kind of random and unfixed experience is more addictive than fixed feedback. This effect is called intermittent reinforcement in psychology. Psychologist Skinner conducted a reinforcement experiment on rats. He designed a lever. As long as the rat stepped on the lever, food would fall. In the experimental group with constant food delivery, when the experimenter no longer delivered food and the rat did not get food by pressing the button, the rat’s established behavior habit would quickly disappear. In another control experiment, the experimenter changed the appearance mechanism of food to random dropping, and the rat also learned to keep pressing the button. Even if it takes dozens of uncertain presses to drop a piece of food, the rat will still maintain this behavior habit for a long time.

 

This phenomenon is related to the mechanism of action of the brain’s reward mechanism. During the evolution of mankind, the brain has evolved a set of reward mechanisms that can associate certain situations with pleasure. In this way, we tend to try situations that may produce this experience again in the future from those learnings. The important substance in this is a neurotransmitter called “dopamine”, which is related to the mechanism of finding, searching, and judging that something can bring you happiness. Simply put, the role of dopamine is to “make you want” and let you choose behaviors that can get more rewards. The amount of dopamine has little to do with the amount of happiness after actually getting the result. Its main role is to make us have desires, thereby guiding corresponding behaviors.

After people’s behavior, the pleasant result obtained strengthens people’s expectation for the next behavior, and the intensity of this expectation is controlled by dopamine. When randomness is introduced, the player’s expectation is the randomly appearing reinforcement. When the player accidentally realizes an expectation, he will then crave the next realization, and so on. In this process, our nervous system will constantly predict the relationship between the current behavior and the next moment’s reward. When this prediction deviates, the brain will secrete dopamine to let all the neurons that make predictions change their expectations. In experiments, people found that the degree of dopamine secretion caused by “almost winning/getting” is only slightly lower than that of “really winning/getting”, which shows that human expectations and motivation for the next behavior are not completely one-to-one positively correlated with the result of the current behavior. “Almost winning/getting” provides uncertain guidance for people, thereby continuously strengthening players’ behavior.

Simply put, before the result of randomness appears, people often have expectations for the result, and this expectation will accumulate with the increase of behavior. When expectations are realized, compared with certain results, uncertainty will make people secrete more dopamine, making you have a stronger desire, which will make the feedback mechanism more firmly strengthened.

Substituting into the smallest gameplay unit of elimination, after each sliding operation, we will get a block layout after elimination, but due to the randomness of the blocks falling from above, the block layout obtained after elimination is an uncertain event for us. Compared with the certain result of each sliding operation, the expectation that the next sliding operation can get powerful functional blocks will give us a stronger motivation to perform the next operation.

4. Stamina Restrictions: Avoiding Desensitization Caused by Hedonic Adaptation

Players who often play elimination games will find that most elimination games have stamina restrictions. These stamina may recover one grid every 10 minutes, or one grid every 30 minutes. Every time you fail to pass a level, one grid of stamina will be deducted. After all stamina is deducted, you can no longer continue to pass the level. Of course, you can also continue to get the opportunity to pass the level by purchasing stamina. Every time the stamina is exhausted, we always feel itchy and want to say if we can play another round. When the game occasionally releases some unlimited stamina props for a limited time of 2 hours, you often find that you are getting more and more bored, without the excitement when the stamina was limited before, and become a mechanical elimination tool person. You can’t play for 2 hours of unlimited stamina at all.

 

However, in this process, the excitement of the game has not changed, what has changed is your perception of the happiness of the game. This phenomenon is called hedonic adaptation. We can get happiness from doing something at the beginning, but as the number of times we do this thing increases, the happiness we feel each time will increase our expectations for the next time, and the next time we will need a greater intensity of experience to get the same level of happiness as before. When the elimination game brings happiness, the brain will secrete dopamine, making people look forward to continuing to eliminate the game and keeping people excited. When a stimulus is continuously input, the brain will continue to secrete dopamine. When dopamine-sending cells continuously pump out dopamine, the receiving nerve cells will cover their “ears” and reduce dopamine receptors (D2). This is the desensitization process that occurs in our brains, making people less desirous of a continuous stimulus. Of course, this is only a temporary desensitization. After a period of CD, the game will still make us feel happy. The stamina restriction in the game will interrupt people’s adaptation process to the happiness of the elimination gameplay, making the new game experience after full blood more valuable.

5. Summary

This article only attempts to analyze the smallest gameplay unit in elimination games - the elimination level, and analyze the attractiveness of this category of gameplay from a psychological mechanism perspective for readers: the elimination behavior naturally conforms to human cognitive fluency preferences, and each elimination behavior unit is an instant reinforcement feedback; the ubiquitous randomness in the level strengthens people’s motivation for experience; the setting of limiting stamina reduces the hedonic adaptation brought by repeated fun. Of course, in addition to the above designs, elimination games also have a large number of elements such as scores, stars, and even development to increase the fun of the game, making the game more playable and longer-lasting.

entry.title: From 'Raising Pets' to 'Raising Children': Analyzing the Child-Rearing Gameplay in MMO Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

In real life, we often see all kinds of complaints about “raising children” online: being too tired from working during the day and taking care of children at night, being driven to tears when tutoring children, and so on. These complaints invisibly make people feel very stressed about “raising children”.

However, in contrast to reality, “raising children in games” has been praised and favored by many players. In many MMORPG games, in order to promote player interaction, the game will solidify the emotional bond between players through the relationship (情缘 - qíng yuán) system. The child-rearing system is the “next stage” of the relationship system. It is built on in-depth player interaction and the emotional foundation of relationship players, bringing a lot of fun to the player’s game life.

Similar to reality, raising a child in the game is not a simple matter. In order to make players qualified parents, every player who wants to have a baby needs to pass an entrance exam to obtain the qualification to raise a child; during the pregnancy and raising process, players need to take care of the child every day and interact with the child; and after the child grows up , Players also need to supervise their children’s learning every day to improve various numerical dimensions.

We can see that in order to raise children, players not only need to log in to the game frequently, but also need to complete different tasks in order to take care of their children. However, even if it is so “hard”, players are still keen to “raise children” in the game. From “raising pets” to “raising children”, this kind of gameplay system with nurturing elements frequently appears in many games. Some players use them as a reflection of their inner emotions, and some will use them as an outlet for their own emotional expression. This article will further analyze the parenting gameplay in MMO games from the following aspects.

1. Simulated Nurturing

With the enrichment of game play, the design of the parenting system in MMO games is very realistic, and the entire process of pregnancy and raising can bring a strong sense of immersion. In addition to the content mentioned earlier, players need to complete daily tasks to bring experience growth to their children. Different stages of children’s growth will also have different body types and appearances.

 

For example, in Justice Online, parents can arrange for their children to complete different courses every day, such as “going to Liyun Pavilion to listen to operas”, “going to the academy to study”, “raising flowers and plants”, etc. Correspondingly, after completing the courses, players can improve attributes of charm, intelligence, character, etc.. Because the child’s energy is limited every day, the number of courses completed is also limited, so parents need to choose and arrange courses according to their own ideas. This is like in reality, parents need to choose which subjects, such as language, mathematics, English, etc., to tutor their children according to their weaknesses.

After the child grows up, the child will not only repay the parents by helping them complete tasks, but also travel, and bring back travel photos of himself in different scenes to the parents. Maybe he met a little frog by the pond, or maybe he was chased by a dog named “Wangcai” (旺财 - wàng cái: a common name for dogs, literally “Prosperous Wealth”) by the road. Imagine that when parents see the bits and pieces of their children’s journey shared with them, they will definitely have a full sense of happiness.

 

The baby’s travel album in Justice Online

In this process, players can obtain a real baby-raising experience at a lower cost, thereby obtaining the pleasure of nurturing.

2. Projecting Oneself

Compared with competitive gameplay that focuses more on operation and a sense of accomplishment, the parenting system in MMO games can provide players with a reflection of their own ideals and a proof of their emotional investment.

In reality, parents often project their expectations of their children onto their children. This is reflected in the fact that parents will expect their children to become what they want them to be through their own education methods.

In Justice Online, each baby will have exclusive personality tags (such as outgoing, introverted, naughty, etc.). Personality traits will be reflected in the daily interaction between the baby and the parents. Parents can also set personalized face customization and outfits for the baby according to their own preferences. Therefore, every baby is unique. In addition to personality, babies in the game will also have their own body types (such as burly, strong, petite, slender, etc.). In the process of “raising” children, players can raise a “baby” that meets their expectations according to their ideal settings, and can also obtain happiness and satisfaction other than upgrades.

Parents improve the baby’s values in various dimensions by giving gifts, chatting and other interactive forms, as well as taking classes, thereby projecting their expectations of the baby. And when the parents’ expectations are met, the parents’ sense of happiness and superiority will also be nourished.

 

The various attributes and appearance of the baby in Justice Online

3. Warm Companionship

In games, the use of AI is very common, including the parenting system. A powerful AI system can allow babies to give playful feedback to different chat content sent by parents, allowing players to obtain psychological comfort through the company of their children in a boring life. Many players will chat with their babies when they are free and bored. If they encounter interesting conversations, they will also take screenshots and share them on social platforms. This not only provides a sense of companionship in conversations with the child you raised yourself, but also a great outlet for emotions when sharing with game friends/real-life friends.

In various games, there are actually many players who are “socially phobic”. They will feel that socializing with other players is troublesome or stressful, but when facing their own baby, this pressure disappears. Through such companionship, “socially phobic” players can also have fun playing alone.

 

Picture: Players晒(shài - show off/share) their conversations with their children on the Tieba (贴吧 - a Chinese online forum)

After the parenting system of Justice Online was launched, many players would communicate with their “babies” in various ways, finding more companionship in this kind of casual and nurturing gameplay; many players also shared their daily baby-raising life on platforms such as Tieba and Dashen (大神 - a game community platform), communicating interesting stories experienced during the parenting process with friends, and recording the growth of their children. This is actually the same as parents in reality going crazy showing off their babies on WeChat Moments.

4. Intimate Social Interaction

The connection between the parenting system and the relationship system is very close. Although single players can also adopt children in the game, many players have children together after forming a relationship between the opposite sex. In the process of raising children with their game partner, players can also strengthen their intimate relationship. Because raising children can add more topics between partners and bring more companionship to each other.

In the game, both parents can often complete parenting tasks together, and there will be no tasks that can only be completed by the father or the mother. In this process, players need to arrange the parenting of their children according to their own daily situation, and at the same time, they also need to discuss the parenting direction of their children together. This is very important for promoting social interaction between relationship partners.

 

5. Ordinary Social Interaction

In addition to intimate social interaction between relationship partners, players can also use children as a topic to establish social relationships with other parents. Social interaction has always been an extremely important element of MMORPG games, and it plays an important role in maintaining players’ relationship networks and creating game topics. As one of the derivative gameplays of MMO games, the parenting system can establish another important social field between “parents” in addition to fixed teams, guilds, PVP arenas, etc.

In the daily tasks of the parenting system, the game will set some tasks related to social interaction with children, such as playing with other children. In order to complete these tasks, parents also need to find friends for their children, which actually promotes social interaction between players.

 

In addition, the game will also design exclusive play scenes for children (actually also for adults), such as amusement parks. These scenes generally have interactive props, such as seesaws, merry-go-rounds, etc. Players can play with their children. In these scenes, parents can not only interact with their children, but also interact with other parents, thereby establishing social relationships.

6. Conclusion

The parenting system has gradually become one of the “essential systems” of MMO games. In some games, the parenting system will be tied to numerical growth, and players will also raise children in order to improve their combat power. But for most players, raising children is to be able to obtain a real baby-raising experience in the game world. I believe that the parenting system in the game will continue to be optimized in the future, bringing players a more realistic sense of nurturing.

entry.title: Gamification Design, More Than Just Design That Looks Like a Game
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

1. Conceptual Elaboration

Gamification Definition

The common definition of gamification is the application of game elements and game design techniques in non-game contexts to change people’s inherent behavior patterns. The most popular gamification in China, for example, simply copies the game’s system, regardless of whether it is suitable for the current theme or whether it is fun. Simply adding points, badges/achievement systems, and leaderboards (i.e., the PBL system) applies the shell of the game to the themed activity. But this can only be called a game-like product that utilizes the external presentation of the game, falling into the narrow cognitive misunderstanding of gamification. In essence, gamification should not be just a simple application of the game framework to various scenarios. Gamification design should be a way of thinking, empowering non-gamified scenarios or industries through the core driving force of the game, allowing users to gain more fun and create greater value in the process of experience.

Gamification Elements

The elements that make up gamification are diverse. From the perspective of their role in the gamification system, they can be divided into three categories: dynamics, mechanics, and components. They are arranged according to the degree of abstraction to form the DMC pyramid. At the bottom of the DMC pyramid of gamification elements are basic components, such as achievements, badges, and other elements, which are the specific manifestations of dynamics and mechanics. Above the components, mechanics, including chance, competition, and cooperation, are the basic processes that drive game progress and user participation. The top layer is dynamics, which is the driving force for users to use gamified products.

Various components form complex rules under the guidance of mechanics, and a complete gamification system is formed due to the drive of dynamic elements.

 

Figure 1: DMC Pyramid of Gamification Elements

Starting from the DMC pyramid for gamification design can provide some guidance, but it is easy to fall into the design misunderstanding of completing gamification only through components such as achievement leaderboards and coins.

2. Gamification Design

How to break the simple game shell and empower gamification design? The Octalysis framework provides a core guiding framework.

Octalysis is a framework in gamification design. The core tenet is the “human-centered” design concept, not function-centered. It is composed of eight core drives. According to the different characteristics of the drives, they can be divided into: left-brain drives and right-brain drives, white hat gamification and black hat gamification. Left and right brain drives can be understood as extrinsic motivation and intrinsic motivation. Left-brain core drives often rely on extrinsic motivation, while right-brain core drives are mostly intrinsic motivation.

 

Figure 2: Octalysis Framework

Gamification in Service Design

The radiotherapy ward of the Cancer Hospital Affiliated to Chongqing University is a place that provides tumor treatment for adults and children in Southwest China. The hospital originally used standardized decoration, with pale wards, cold instruments, and the symptoms of adults’ illnesses, all bringing unknown fear to the children. After understanding the situation of the entire ward and the children’s treatment process, the designer transformed it into a “healing planet” for children.

The orange and warm white tones make the ordinary wards no longer cold, and elements of the IP world are also added to the medical area, running through the entire space. For example, after opening the glass door with 28 totems printed on it with a special bracelet, you can see the “little monsters” hidden in the plants at the entrance to greet the children.

 

Figure 3: Transformed Ward of Cancer Hospital Affiliated to Chongqing University - 1

The designer also added push-rod interactive devices and game areas to the renovation, relying on this approach to build a bridge for communication between parents and children, playing a role in mutual comfort.

 

Figure 4: Transformed Ward of Cancer Hospital Affiliated to Chongqing University - 2

 

Figure 5: Transformed Ward of Cancer Hospital Affiliated to Chongqing University - 3

From the perspective of the Octalysis framework, the transformation adds two drives, “social influence & relatedness” and “unpredictability & curiosity”, to the medical service. Under the premise of fully considering the needs of patients and their families, through the design of spatial flow, hardware and soft decoration design, and interactive device design, the fun of the medical process is increased, the curiosity of children is stimulated, and the social connection between patients and their families is strengthened.

NetEase Cloud Music Gamified Marketing

On May 26, 2021, NetEase Cloud Music and its partners launched a test. Users can test their personality color by listening to music and making choices, and can also share the test link to Moments, WeChat friends, social media, etc.

 

Figure 6: NetEase Cloud Personality Main Color Test Poster

NetEase Cloud Music’s gamified marketing utilizes multiple drives to attract users, with “scarcity & impatience” as the core and “social influence & relatedness” as the boost, achieving a surge in public opinion. In the shared pictures and texts, you can see descriptions such as “In China, one out of every xx people will like you” and “Your characteristics”. The copywriting satisfies users’ desire for the uniqueness of their personal personality color, expresses recognition and affirmation of users’ own existence, and at the same time, according to the test results, it can be used to find people who match their own color and promote social relationships.

Digital Therapeutics Prescription Drug

EndeavorRx (AKL-T01) is a video game designed to improve attention and is the first digital therapeutic device designed to improve symptoms associated with ADHD (Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder) that has received FDA (Food and Drug Administration) prescription drug approval certification. Unlike other video games played by children, the therapeutic procedures in the game are scientifically designed to challenge children’s brains during the treatment process while requiring children’s attention to be focused on multiple tasks.

 

Figure 7: EndeavorRx Promotional Poster

This game is mainly suitable for children aged 8-12 years with inattention or combined-type attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). It can improve the attention of these children. As part of the treatment, combined with other clinical, drug, and educational treatments, it will improve the related symptoms of children with ADHD.

Digital therapeutics prescription drugs are mainly guided by the two major drives of “development & accomplishment” and “empowerment of creativity & feedback”. Curiosity attracts children to play the game, and defeating challenges in the game obtains positive feedback, ultimately achieving the goal of improving attention.

However, although this will allow children to receive treatment faster than taking medicine, children with ADHD will become increasingly addicted to the game. In the trial, a few subjects even experienced side effects such as frustration, headache, dizziness, emotional reaction, nausea, or aggression. The occurrence of this side effect can be explained using the flow model.

Flow Model: Establish a coordinate system with personal skills as the X-axis and event challenges as the Y-axis to establish a flow model. When an individual’s skills are close to the challenges of the events they encounter, they will enter a state of flow. For the gaming industry, when a player’s skills are higher than the challenges presented by the game, the player will feel bored; and when the player’s skills are lower than the challenges presented by the game, the player will fall into anxiety. And the greater the gap between skills and the challenges presented by the game, the more obvious this feeling is.

 

Figure 8: Flow Experience Model

During the digital treatment process of children, if the challenges in the game are higher than the skills they can achieve, side effects such as nausea will occur. Not only EndeavorRx, but all games used as digital therapeutics prescription drugs should have a difficulty level closer to the level of the target player group, so that the recipients can stay in the flow state for as long as possible, maintain enthusiasm for the game, and achieve therapeutic effects.

 

Figure 9: EndeavorRx Game Interface

3. Summary

Gamification is one of the most widely used methods in design. The rational use of game elements can solve problems in user experience or achieve explosive marketing effects. But no matter what kind of presentation form is adopted, it is only a means of construction. The core of gamification is to promote user participation, and the fundamental purpose is always to make users feel interesting, thereby stimulating their drive.

entry.title: Designing for the Keyboard Operation Experience of Players in Different Languages
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

On a normal weekend, have those of you planning to spend the day playing games ever suddenly wondered why the keys on the keyboard are not arranged in the order of ABCD? The keyboard we commonly use, with the first six letters of the first row being Q, W, E, R, T, Y, has also become the source of its name, the QWERTY keyboard. The keyboard family has many other unusual layouts aside from QWERTY.

With the principle of learning from our questions, today we will learn some obscure facts about keyboards, and the considerations for keyboard layout when designing the user experience of games. At the end of the article, we will provide several keyboard localization experience design solutions for everyone.

1. QWERTY, a Product of the Typewriter Era

To understand why today’s keyboards look the way they do, we need to trace back to the typewriter era. That’s right, the keyboard was introduced much earlier than the first computer, which appeared in the 1940s. In the early 19th century, people had already started using keyboards, but the keyboard initially adopted a layout with 26 letters arranged in a single row.

However, this terrible design was too inefficient. Some letter combinations obviously required typists to have advanced fingering skills to reach. So, apart from the inventor himself, few people used the world’s first typewriter keyboard. Soon after, new design solutions emerged to replace the original keyboard.

The person who eventually invented the familiar QWERTY keyboard was Christopher Latham Sholes. There are two completely opposite versions of the story of his invention of QWERTY. One theory is that early typewriters would inadvertently speed up as people used them. If two adjacent letters were struck quickly, the two connecting rods would easily collide and jam. Sholes chose to separate the letters into discontinuous arrangements to reduce the typing speed of typists, thereby reducing the occurrence of failures. The other version says that Sholes observed that typists often had continuous keystrokes with one hand. When one hand was inputting frantically, the other was idle. The hand with continuous keystrokes was prone to fatigue and reduced speed. Sholes hoped to improve typing efficiency by alternating between left and right hands when typing.

 

1878 QWERTY Keyboard Design Diagram

If the two theories are combined, the design goal of the QWERTY keyboard can be seen as “increasing speed as much as possible without jamming”. Sholes deliberately separated common letter combinations such as TH, HE, AN, IN, ON, AT, ND, ST, but also designed the ER accelerator key combination, and moved the commonly used letter T to the center and the less commonly used key Q to the edge.

Regardless of what happened in the past, such a seemingly strange and incomprehensible keyboard was born and continues to this day, becoming the most commonly used keyboard in our lives with the mysterious aura of one of the world’s top 100 unsolved mysteries.

2. What Else is There Besides QWERTY?

If you look closely at our keyboard, you will find that in addition to English letters and commonly used special characters, most characters of other languages cannot be typed normally. If you want to communicate with other friends in the global village, you need to use some minor language keyboards, which are usually redesigned on the basis of the QWERTY keyboard.

In addition to QWERTY, there are also minor language keyboards such as QWERTZ, AZERTY, and new keyboards such as Dvorak.

Take the French keyboard as an example. Compared with the universal QWERTY keyboard, in addition to letting the number keys also undertake the output tasks of vowels such as é, è, ç, à, the French keyboard also swaps the positions of A and Q, W and Z, and M comes to the right of L. Such changes may be due to the frequency of use of different letters. In French, the letters Q and Z appear more frequently than A and W. Choosing this arrangement can make finger movement more convenient and faster.

 

French keyboard

Similarly, the German keyboard layout has been modified for frequency of use. Because TZ is often used as a root in German, the German keyboard swaps Y and Z.

 

German keyboard

As for some other non-Latin languages, the keyboard styles are even more varied. Relying on unique keyboards and input methods, today’s keyboards have covered the needs of most language users.

 

Russian keyboard

 

Arabic keyboard
