entry.title: Why the Love for "Annual" Games? — Starting with the *Call of Duty* Series
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

Not long ago, the new Call of Duty series released a new promotional video. The official name is Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II 2022. Casually, it can also be called Call of Duty 19. Some players may find this official name very awkward or very familiar, which is fine, because the first Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 was released in 2009, and then in 2020, Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 Remastered was released. Now, a remaster is not enough, and Activision wants to completely reboot this series to reap the last wave of nostalgia.

 

Ghost, who died as early as 2009 and died again in the 2020 remaster, will be resurrected again in 2022

So why is it that both publishers and players love annual games so much, and never get tired of it?

1. The Effect of Brand Value

When a publisher releases a hit, they will definitely try to keep the IP. This is also very common in other industries. For example, Jurassic World: Dominion, which was released some time ago, was able to reboot Jurassic World 14 years after three Jurassic Park movies were made. Does it have the flavor of Call of Duty rebooting the Modern Warfare series? In fact, the reason is the same. When an excellent work appears, the publisher will try to continue its value, which is why many excellent games and movies have sequels.

However, the quality of the sequel is also very important. It stands to reason that a AAA title like Call of Duty requires hundreds of millions of dollars in investment and several years of development. If it is released every year, it is basically impossible to guarantee the quality of the game. So Activision Blizzard thought of this early on and handed over this possibly most valuable game IP to three different studios for development, so that each studio can get 2-3 years of development time, and each generation can bring players a different feeling.

For example, IW studio’s most classic Modern Warfare trilogy, and Treyarch’s Black Ops series, which has been foreshadowed since the fifth generation of Call of Duty. Finally, there is Sledgehammer Games, which was in danger. The 11th generation, Advanced Warfare, was their debut. Although it was controversial to put the theme on future warfare for the first time, the UI design of the gun information in it impressed the players. After all, two of the studio’s founders were from Visceral Games. It is obvious that there are shadows of the UI in Dead Space. These three top studios go hand in hand to ensure the quality of the game. The games that seem to be released every year have actually been polished for 2-3 years.

 

The UI design of this generation left a deep impression

Compared to Call of Duty‘s direct competitor Battlefield, only the support of the DICE studio makes it difficult for EA’s ace FPS to become an annual game. Battlefield can barely be released every 2-3 years. The shortcomings of non-annual releases are also obvious. Battlefield 2042‘s reputation has plummeted and cannot be remedied, and it is unknown when the next generation will be released. Although Call of Duty: Vanguard, which was released at the same time, is rarely mentioned after the next new game is released, and everyone’s attention is focused on the new Call of Duty 4 months later, even if the previous generation flops, Activision Blizzard can also say “Don’t panic, everyone, look at my new game next year, it will be better”, while EA can only remedy it through one DLC after another.

In summary, Call of Duty has become a high-value brand that allows players to form a fixed memory. Some people will buy it without thinking when they hear Call of Duty. This is because the brand value of Call of Duty is much higher than other games, and their brand value is largely due to the annual nature of the game. There are many releases, the quality is good, and the competitors really can’t keep up. How can you resist not buying it?

2. Reduce Game Costs

The first is the cost of publicity and distribution. For example, when you think of FPS games, you think of Call of Duty, when you think of football games, you think of FIFA, and when you think of sports management games, you think of Football Manager. These are already inertial thinking. The marketing team no longer needs to spend a lot of money to let players know what our game is and what features our game has. Target players are already staring at the annual releases every year and are ready to buy. This kind of annual game that has formed a brand effect has a great advantage in publicity. Of course, there is another kind of brand effect, which is the producer effect. Hearing the names of Hidetaka Miyazaki and Hideo Kojima is actually a guarantee of quality in a sense, and publicity will also have a great advantage.

 

《Football Manager》is a typical example of “old wine in new bottles”

Another point is that the development cost of the game itself will be lower. For example, the Football Manager series is both loved and hated. The game mechanism is basically updated to 0 every year, but it needs to change the database of players every year. This database is the core content of the game. As a game industry practitioner, it is not difficult to imagine their development process: the basic game design process will not change, the basic gameplay and functions will be slightly optimized, and the data will be changed. It is very easy and pleasant. But this can’t be blamed too much on the manufacturers. If too many changes are made at once, it will be criticized by players. For example, Call of Duty 15 directly cut out the single-player campaign, which caused many players to refuse to buy it (Battlefield 2042 also cut out the single-player campaign, but it was not the direct reason for its poor reputation).

3. Avoid Development Risks

Another benefit of annual games is that they can “make quick money” every year. For example, Call of Duty series every year is one of the most important sources of revenue for Activision Blizzard. If this series suddenly disappears one year, the development team may not be able to withstand the pressure from shareholders. Although Rockstar can spend 200 million in costs and 5 years of development time, they are also betting that GTA5 will be a big seller in the future, and they have indeed sold more than 150 million copies.

But their parent company, Take-Two, is also very thoughtful. The NBA 2K series of its 2K studio still follows the annual series. After all, the development of GTA6 also needs funds. The annual games allow the development team to avoid some unnecessary risks. After all, if this year’s sales are not good, new games can be released next year to continue selling. It will not cause several years of development investment to be wasted due to dismal sales.

 

Rockstar’s successful development experience is very, very difficult to replicate

Following the previous point, Rockstar’s GTA5 is a successful example, and GTA6, which has been released 9 years after the previous game, is likely to be a successful example. However, there are also many examples of infinitely increasing costs due to the long development cycle, such as the development of Final Fantasy XV, which lasted for ten years. During this period, there were also situations such as temporary replacement of producers. The long-term development in the middle also almost “exhausted” the company.

The much-criticized Cyberpunk 2077 was also made for a long time. Finally, it couldn’t withstand the pressure to go online, cut a lot of game content, and pushed a semi-finished product full of bugs online. For example, the memorable black screen all the way out of Arasaka, I thought it was artistic processing at first, but later found that the processing time was a bit long, and finally realized that it was a bug. Faced with such a long-term R&D, high-cost, and high-pressure new research project, if there is an annual game with a faster development rhythm, better sales expectations, and can also reduce game costs and risks, would you be tempted? Game companies need to make a profit. As for which of these two has greater risk and how to choose, it is naturally clear at a glance.

4. Hidden Worries: How Long Can Annual Games Last?

Perhaps for manufacturers, steadily launching an annual game can continue to bring in a certain amount of revenue, but no one knows how long this rhythm will last, because the same game experience will not satisfy players. “Released every year, scolded every year, bought every year, played every year” has become the most pertinent evaluation of annual games by players. Blindly seeking stability will only make players feel tired. For example, the previously mentioned Football Manager, the gameplay system has hardly improved every year. The series is too conservative, causing the game to stagnate for several years. Even if there are no vicious bugs when the game is launched, the user experience of players has not improved.

Here we have to mention the competition between competitors. If you were to recommend a game to a classmate who likes the NBA and wants to try an NBA game, what would you recommend? After thinking about it, there seems to be no choice other than NBA 2K, and the overall quality of this game is also good, so it’s always right to recommend it.

 

The mixed reviews say it all

But for players familiar with the NBA 2K series, this game is definitely not perfect, and it is difficult to satisfy old players. The mixed Steam reviews also prove this point. Basically, each series of NBA 2K cannot achieve mostly positive reviews. However, if we don’t buy it, there will be no similar games to play this year, which also leads to the “love-hate” emotion of players.

Standing still is destined to not go far. The original absolute dominator of the NBA series, the NBA Live series, was taken away by the more realistic and better-looking NBA 2K. The lack of response from the former has since slumped and quickly disappeared from the players’ vision. The same is true for EA’s other ace FPS project, the Medal of Honor series. Call of Duty has made double breakthroughs in themes and techniques since the 4th generation, creating the Modern Warfare series. DICE studio, which started in 2002 and was subsequently acquired by EA, also leaped into modern times from Battlefield 1942; while Medal of Honor still insisted on the World War II theme setting and walked to the end. After being forced to turn to modern warfare themes in 2010, its poor game production details made the series instantly die, and no new works have been released since then.

 

The familiar Normandy landing scene is gone forever

In fact, game manufacturers have also realized this problem. In order to ensure the quality of the game, manufacturers have begun to make trade-offs in the development model: Ubisoft announced that it would slow down the launch of new works after the launch of Assassin’s Creed: Odyssey; at the same time, Activision Blizzard also revealed in an internal email in April this year that although the sales of Call of Duty: Vanguard were good, it was confirmed that the Call of Duty series would no longer be an annual game, and the game’s development model will change from “annual release” to “always on”.

In short, the existence of annual games has caused a lot of controversy, but manufacturers and players are trying to adapt to the new environment.

entry.title: Swords and Sorrows: The Acceptance of Wuxia in Vietnam
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Wuxia is a fairy tale for adults, Wuxia is the fantasy of the East, and Wuxia is a real world. Games based on Wuxia generally have rich storylines and continue to deliver the dream of wielding a sword and roaming the Jianghu with pleasure. In Vietnam, which is closely linked with China, there is still the romantic gene of Wuxia culture, and Wuxia-themed games are enduring. In the daily communication of ordinary Vietnamese people, there will also be metaphors like “as hypocritical and sinister as Yue Buqun.” It is undeniable that Vietnam has been deeply influenced by Wuxia culture.

This article hopes to analyze the Wuxia culture and Wuxia-themed games in Vietnam to answer the following two questions:

  1. What is the Vietnamese perception of Wuxia?
  2. How is the development of Wuxia-themed games in Vietnam?

1. The “Wuxia Craze” that Swept Across Generations

Wuxia culture entered Vietnam in the early 20th century, when Vietnam was becoming a French colony, and the colonists tried to transform the original Vietnamese language into pinyin. By coincidence, the Vietnamese readers of Chinese classical Wuxia novels were no longer limited to Confucian scholars who had received Chinese education, but expanded to people of all classes who mastered the national language. After the Wuxia novel craze in Vietnam, Vietnamese writers began to become self-sufficient. In 1920, Nguyễn Chánh Sắt wrote Hiệp Lữ, which was also the first Wuxia novel in Vietnamese national language literature. Hiệp Lữ was warmly welcomed by readers as soon as it was published, and under the guidance of this work, a wave of Wuxia novel creation was set off.

After that, in just over 20 years from 1954 to 1975, a large number of works by Chinese Hong Kong and Taiwan Wuxia novel writers such as Jin Yong, Gu Long, Liang Yusheng, Wolong Sheng, and Zhuge Qingyun were translated into Vietnamese, which greatly influenced the artistic taste of several generations of Vietnamese people. It has been more than 100 years since Chinese Wuxia novels were spread to Vietnam, and now the footprints and influence of Wuxia culture in Vietnam are everywhere. Works with Wuxia as the theme are very popular in Vietnam.

2. Vietnamese People’s Perception of “Wuxia”

In Vietnamese, Wuxia is usually directly translated as Võ hiệp (武侠) or kiếm hiệp (剑侠). The definition of Wuxia in the Vietnamese dictionary is an ancient warrior who is good at swordsmanship and often does good deeds and helps the weak (Võ sĩ thời xưa, giỏi đánh kiếm, thường làm nghĩa, cứu giúp bênh vực kẻ yếu). This is almost similar to the domestic understanding of “Wuxia”.

The classic Wuxia story understood by Vietnamese people is like this: the male protagonist needs to experience tragedies such as the murder of his family, go through thousands of hardships and unbearable hardships, and learn various martial arts from many masters. In this process, he will quietly dormant, hide his name, and wait for various opportunities to prove himself in front of those who look down on him. At the end of the story, the male protagonist becomes an unmatched martial arts master, he constantly refines his skills and dominates the Jianghu. The eight common Wuxia characteristics are selflessness, justice, independence, loyalty, bravery, trustworthiness, not caring about money and reputation.

Vietnamese people can also be compatible with and understand the concepts of Wuxia works, such as martial arts, weapons (knives, swords, sticks, spears, abacus, fans, pens, pipes, or various musical instruments are all kinds of weapons familiar to Vietnamese people), Qinggong, internal strength, acupuncture, etc.

 

The Vietnamese version of “The Legend of the Condor Heroes” sold at Hanoi Thang Long Bookstore

3. The History of Wuxia-Themed Games Going Overseas to Vietnam

Games with Wuxia as the background have always performed well in the Vietnamese video game market. From the earliest JX Online (Vietnamese version named “Võ Lâm Truyền Kỳ”) and Kiếm Thế, to the endless stream of Wuxia-themed games such as New Swordsman M (一梦江湖), Legend of Fire (烈火), etc., the Wuxia background is not unfamiliar to Vietnamese players.

 

On January 27, 2022, the top 4 free games in Vietnam were Wuxia-themed games

(Source: APP ANNIE)

Võ Lâm Truyền Kỳ (JX Online) can be said to be the most influential game in the history of Vietnamese video games. Võ Lâm Truyền Kỳ is a very classic MMORPG game with a sect system, task system, item enhancement/refining system, life system and large-scale PVP siege warfare.

In April 2005, Võ Lâm Truyền Kỳ became the first online role-playing game with a Wuxia theme in Vietnam, “opening the door” for the later development of this series of games. The publisher of the game at that time was VinaGame (the predecessor of VNG). Immediately, Võ Lâm Truyền Kỳ became a popular online game. According to statistics, in just about half a year, the game had 4.7 million active accounts, accounting for about 85% of the game community at that time. It is worth mentioning that in 2005, Vietnam had only 19.7 million Internet users. At its peak, it occupied 80% of the Vietnamese game market. JX Online is also the earliest online game in the Vietnamese market that is charged by time.

 

Võ Lâm Truyền Kỳ is popular in Vietnam

Võ Lâm Truyền Kỳ takes the Southern Song Dynasty of China as the game background, allowing players to seem to feel the national hatred and family hatred at that time in the game. Although the game screen can no longer be compared with today’s Wuxia online games, it makes players more immersive. In addition, Võ Lâm Truyền Kỳ achieved very high-quality offline player contact and community management in the early 2000s, and the folk also organized a lot of offline gatherings. From 2005 to 2006, Vinagame held offline Vo Lam Congresses to organize game players and established the first inter-server online game tournament in Vietnam, the First Bang Thien Ha tournament.

 

4. What do Vietnamese Players Pursue When Entering the World of Wuxia?

By observing and collecting feedback and comments on Wuxia-themed games on the market, we can get a glimpse of the goals of Vietnamese players when experiencing Wuxia games.

  • (In this game) I can talk to Dongfang Bubai and Bodhidharma! These are characters from previous novels, it’s so novel.

 

Figure 1: Players like the feeling of dialogue with Jin Yong’s novel characters, there is a sense of familiarity

  • Now there are very few games that include all the moves mentioned in Jin Yong’s novels. I think this is very well done
  • This game has very exciting siege battles, and this kind of large-scale battle is too spectacular.
  • I like the costumes and face pinching inside.

 

When “New Swordsman M” (一梦江湖) was released in Vietnam, face pinching was loved by players.

From an observational point of view, there is no obvious difference between Vietnamese players and Chinese players in the preference of Wuxia-themed games. This also explains why many Chinese Wuxia games have achieved fruitful results when they go overseas to Vietnam.

5. Conclusion

Whether it is the similarity of history or the spread of culture, Vietnamese players have a natural affinity for games with Wuxia as the background. They can understand the background and terminology in Wuxia, and their preferences for Wuxia are very similar to those of Chinese players. It can be said that Vietnam is another fertile land for Wuxia-themed culture. In the game world of galloping horses and swords, Vietnamese players are also pursuing their own Wuxia dreams.

entry.title: Perceiving and Shaping Self in the Virtual World
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

In Naraka: Bladepoint, when players are teleported into the battlefield, a loading page appears, with the difficulty of the current match displayed in the upper left corner, such as “evenly matched” in the image below. What kind of emotions will players have when they see this? Will they feel nervous when they see “quite challenging,” or will they relax when they see “easy to handle,” and bring this feeling into the match?

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Loading Page

If this reaction occurs, it can be explained by the phenomenon of “priming.” The preconceptions we have after seeing the prediction of the difficulty of the match will strongly influence our interpretation and memory of this game. In the priming phenomenon, people’s prior judgments will strongly influence the way they perceive and interpret information. For example, seeing a “quite challenging” opponent, recalling the experience of being eliminated immediately after landing, and then avoiding high-resource areas where players gather, and choosing a route to farm.

The simple words on the loading page can make players perceive their positioning in this game. “Priming” is a concept in social psychology, which belongs to the category of social thinking. This article will explain the application of social thinking in game experience design.

1. What are Social Psychology and Social Thinking?

Social psychology studies how people view each other, how they influence each other, and how they relate to each other. Its core questions are: How do we construct the world? How do social intuitions guide or mislead us? How is social behavior affected by ourselves, others, and biological factors?

This discipline is divided into three directions: social thinking, social influence, and social relations. Among them, social influence analyzes the shaping of behavior by society and personality tendencies. Social relations mainly study biological behavior, individuals’ feelings and actions towards others. The social thinking that this article focuses on includes how to perceive oneself and others, beliefs and judgments, attitudes and behaviors, etc. The research topic is how we construct social reality and how social intuition affects us.

 

《Social Psychology》

2. Why Can Social Thinking Support Game Design?

The Internet is increasingly reconstructing human “gaming” behavior and even daily interactions, such as WeChat steps and Ant Forest. In the game, especially in games with strong social attributes, the real space and the virtual space blend with each other. People communicate through the social systems built into the game platform or through communication tools and software. They not only contact each other in the game, but also participate in offline activities and rituals, making individuals, games, and society penetrate and embed each other through the integration of reality and the network.

Fortnite‘s season updates, interactive concerts, and the latest addition of KAWS exhibitions and other cross-border activities are all attempts to integrate games with reality. All players can participate in the carnival, jump into the space-time rift together, watch rocket launches and robots fighting monsters, dance and play mini-games at concerts… Fortnite is good at grasping the emotions of players. These activities have strong social attributes. Although they cannot directly communicate like in reality, players will have a tacit understanding. Everyone’s identity seems to have changed in an instant. Everyone who fights on the battlefield will become gentle and friendly when participating in activities, as if they have become friends. The reason for this phenomenon is that in a specific environment, players’ cognitive identity of themselves and others has changed. Social thinking can help us understand the essence of this phenomenon.

 

《Fortnite》 Marshmello Concert

Many social subgroups, or “interest-based groups,” have formed around games. They are becoming increasingly organized, and then constructing a certain “subculture” with the ability to influence social life. More and more games are beginning to break the circle, holding offline exhibitions, and even, like Fantasy Westward Journey, building their own theme parks. The social form in the game and the real world are complementary. Therefore, the rational use of theories related to social thinking can guide our game design.

 

Cosplayers at a Comic Convention

3. How to Combine Social Thinking with Design

Self and Others

Social thinking can help us better understand ourselves and answer the ultimate question of “who am I.” The constituent elements of self-concept are called “self-schemas,” which is the understanding of oneself, such as strong, smart, etc., which strongly affects our processing of social information. The accurate positioning of oneself needs to be completed through “social comparison,” that is, comparing with others and thinking about why oneself is different.

In the game, we can help players understand their own positioning with the help of others’ situations and construct a reasonable self-schema. Naraka: Bladepoint has designed a leaderboard for each hero, accurate to the province and city. For achievement-oriented players, this is a very effective tool. By observing the leaderboard situation of each hero, they can establish game goals and plan their career in the game, such as using relatively easy heroes to rush to the top of the leaderboard, or thinking about how to maintain their ranking on the leaderboard. Perhaps, players will imagine what level they will reach and what position they will get on the leaderboard. This is the concept of “possible selves.”

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Hero Leaderboard

Beliefs and Judgments

The priming effect at the beginning of the article is one of the ways we perceive the social world. There are some more interesting research conclusions about the priming effect. Our processing of many pieces of information is automatic and subconscious. Due to the existence of embodied cognition (there is a strong connection between physiological experience and psychological state), even physical feelings will initiate our social judgments. Therefore, changing to a set of peripherals that you like can theoretically improve the gaming experience.

Our perception of the world comes from experience and memory, as does the game world. The game will tell a complete story. Even if the game has already done foreshadowing, players will sometimes still be dissatisfied with the plot content, thinking that it is not self-consistent. They will point out problems or describe the story they think is reasonable for everyone to discuss. This phenomenon is called “belief perseverance.” People are attached to the beliefs they held before (the ideological consciousness formed by the fusion of real life and the game worldview, which is expressed here as the view on the plot), and it is difficult to change their views when they are denied.

In order to enhance the player’s gaming experience, multi-ending games, or adding selectable plot directions in the game, are common solutions that can satisfy players’ different views. Deathloop constructs a peculiar world. When players first wake up on the beach, they will continue to receive a lot of novel settings. With the progress of the game, each player will form a unique belief about this virtual world in their minds. In the final choice, no matter whether the player shoots or commits suicide, their judgment can get the most consistent ending with expectations. Judgment and belief are closely connected. Decisions and explanations based on impressions are called “heuristic judgments,” and the choices made in the game are like this.

 

《Deathloop》 The Choice of Whether to Kill Julianna

Attitudes and Behaviors

People’s attitudes and behaviors often differ. The final answer reached by social psychologists is: our attitudes and behaviors are each affected by many factors, but under certain conditions, our thoughts and feelings will be closely related to our actions. In the theory of planned behavior, a better indicator of predicting individual behavior is to understand the individual’s behavioral intentions and their perceived self-efficacy and sense of control.

Taking Death Stranding as an example, players will understand the worldview in the plot and clarify that they need to connect the node city and the relay station with the chiral network to save the world. This part can establish the player’s attitude towards behavior. The online buildings in the scene and the delivery information of other players in the menu can help players establish a self-schema, so as to have their own subjective standards. Various guidelines and encouragements in the game have strengthened players’ beliefs that they can achieve their goals, which belongs to the perceived control. The above attitudes, subjective standards, and sense of control are collectively expressed as the player’s behavioral intention to continue the game, arrange the itinerary, and set off immediately. This is the embodiment of attitude predicting behavior.

How to make players have the attitude expected by game designers depends on various systems and designs in the game. For example, through plot cutscenes, emails, and well-placed background music embedding, to tell the worldview. Leaderboards, map systems that emphasize online buildings, signs in scenes, order systems, evaluations, and achievement systems can all directly or subconsciously cultivate players’ attitudes.

 

《Death Stranding》 Sign, 3DUI form, the interaction of liking can cultivate players’ attitudes

 

《Death Stranding》 Bridges Link (player list), can understand the status of other players, help establish self-schema

 

《Death Stranding》 Map system, green highlights online buildings, giving players guidance and encouragement

 

In 《Death Stranding》, the relationship between game design, player attitude, and player behavior

Conversely, behavior may also affect attitudes. The behavior prescribed by social roles casts the attitude of the role-player. In the game, will there often be NPCs asking you for help, and these requests are one after another, becoming more and more complicated? Experiments have shown that if you want someone to do you a big favor, an effective strategy is to ask them to do a small favor first. This is the “foot-in-the-door phenomenon,” which is widely used in the design of game mission systems.

Also in Death Stranding, in the game, when you complete a commission, the NPC will thank you and give you more and more complex orders (tasks). The journey of delivering packages is becoming more and more dangerous. The main, side, or simply helping other players that players need to accept will become more and more difficult. The game also designs a corresponding system to assist players and balance the difficulty curve. For example, in the order system, the route, requirements, and possible dangers on the road are displayed in detail; if you encounter difficulties, you can also seek material assistance from other players through Bridges Link. The foot-in-the-door phenomenon coupled with proper difficulty control can keep players in a state of flow.

 

In 《Death Stranding》, NPCs will constantly ask players to accept new orders

 

《Death Stranding》 Order system, detailed information can help players plan their itinerary reasonably and complete tasks smoothly

4. Conclusion

Social thinking mainly explains scientific research related to social cognition, involving a wide range. This is a subject about “people,” and game design is also player-oriented. A virtual society that interacts with reality has also appeared in the game world. Social thinking can analyze the self-thinking of players in the game, reveal the social forces behind their behavior, and also provide theoretical support for the design of various systems. Exposure to knowledge from other disciplines is very beneficial to design. “Once the mind is expanded, the thought will never return to its original narrow field.”

entry.title: The Paradox of 'Large' and 'Small': Factors Influencing Players' Perception of In-Game Map Size
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

When analyzing game sentiment, we often find that there may be significant contradictory perceptions among players regarding the size of the in-game map: when experiencing the same map, some players will report that the map is too large, while others will report that it is too small. Why does this contradiction occur?

By analyzing various factors that affect players’ perception of map size, this article will help you understand the source of this contradictory perception and, as a game designer, how to find a balance in this contradiction.

1. What Factors Make Players Feel That the In-Game Map is Too Large?

“This game map is so big, every time I want to go to a target point, I need to run for a long time.”

“The map is too big, and I feel like I need to walk a long way to find relevant resources.”

“The map is a bit big, and I feel like I’ve been running and circling. What’s worse, I feel like I’m running very slowly, and I feel like the limited experience time is spent running.”

The above player feedback comes from a survival game we recently surveyed. Obviously, many players have reached a consistent conclusion on the issue of map size - the in-game map is too large, which affects their gaming experience to a certain extent. However, if we delve into the player feedback, we can find that the reasons why players feel that the game map is too large are significantly different. For example:

“This game map is so big, every time I want to go to a target point, I need to run for a long time.”

This is one of the important factors that affect players’ perception of map size: the arrangement of target coordinates within the map. For example, when we play battle royale games, we are accustomed to studying the coordinates of each target in the game map before choosing an airdrop point, and at the same time evaluating the possible resources around each location. If, in two maps of the same size, one map has a longer distance between targets, then the players will spend more time running and finding landmark targets, which will make them feel that the map is too large, “I feel like I can’t reach the target point no matter how I run.”

This perception of the game map being too large due to the long travel time is particularly obvious in games with significant time limits. For example, in battle royale games, players need to run out of the shrinking circle within the specified time. If the shrinking speed is too fast and the target point is too far away, players will naturally feel that “the map is so big, I can’t run to it.”

 

(Figure 2: The “Wilderness Paradise” map of Knives Out, through the yellow building indicator, players can roughly see the arrangement of buildings around each landmark block)

In addition to the distribution of the coordinates themselves in the map, the distribution of corresponding effective resources will also greatly affect the player’s perception of map size. For example, in survival games that require collecting resources, making props, and then improving survival and combat capabilities, if the resource point distribution is too scattered, it will also make players feel tired of running around in the game, just like the player feedback mentioned above:

“The map is too big, and I feel like I need to walk a long way to find relevant resources.”

Maybe the map itself is not large, but in the life-and-death atmosphere created by the game, the resource distribution is too scattered and difficult to find, which will also make players transfer the experience difficulties they encounter to the map size design itself.

 

(Figure 3: A map of the S3 Ash Plain treasure chest distribution created by LifeAfter players)

Of course, in addition to the distribution of target locations and resource points, the movement speed design of in-game characters also greatly affects players’ perception of the game map size, especially in some games without significant map instructions, where players need to constantly experience and finally “measure the map size with their feet.” The difference in spatial size perception caused by this movement speed design problem is also particularly obvious. For example, in the following player feedback, compared to the game map size itself, movement speed may be an important factor affecting their gaming experience:

“The map is a bit big, and I feel like I’ve been running and circling. What’s worse, I feel like I’m running very slowly, and I feel like the limited experience time is spent running.”

In order to reduce the impact of in-game movement speed on players’ perception of spatial size to a certain extent, many games have added many mechanisms to increase movement speed in the running design, such as in Naraka: Bladepoint, which innovatively designed a grappling hook mechanism, which can help players quickly smooth out the disadvantages caused by geographical location and increase the excitement of in-game melee combat and running.

 

(Figure 4: The grappling hook mechanism in Naraka: Bladepoint can significantly increase the movement speed of in-game characters)

2. What Factors Make Players Feel That the In-Game Map is Too Small?

The above are some of the factors that we have compiled in our daily work that will lead players to believe that the game map is too large. So, what factors might make players feel that the in-game map is too small? We believe there may be the following situations:

First, it may be that the sense of spatial closure caused by too many obstacles makes players think that the in-game map is too small. For example, in a study on the experience of Rainbow Six Siege players, we found that a considerable number of players who have experienced other FPS games will think that some scenes in Rainbow Six Siege are too small, for example:

“The real combat area is too small, and it feels often crowded.”

“The indoor structure space is small, and it is not easy to carry out offensive and defensive cooperation.”

If you carefully study the player’s feedback, you can find that the problem that players complain about is not that the overall combat map is too small, but that the combat area in the scene is small and the combat distance is too close, which may make players face frontal attacks. , The space for maneuvering and retreating is limited. One prominent design of Rainbow Six Siege is that there are many scene elements (such as obstacles) that affect combat, which may cause some players who are accustomed to long-range combat in open spaces to get stuck at the initial stage of the experience.

 

(Figure 5: Combat scene of Rainbow Six Siege)

In addition, the limited number of explorable target points and resource points in the map and their concentrated distribution, or the fast movement speed in the game, may also make some players who have the desire to explore the map think that the in-game map is too small and lacks challenge.

3. How to Seek Balance in the Face of the Perceptual Paradox of “Too Big” and “Too Small”

Whether it is a game designer or a user researcher, when we encounter contradictory sensory feedback such as the in-game map being too large, too small, and other similar sensory contradictions, how should we seek balance? Before implementing real design modifications and optimizations, we can think as follows:

First, what kind of player made a specific perception of space size?

From the above analysis, we can see that the player’s own game experience and preferences may have a significant impact on their spatial perception ability. For example, for players with strong exploration desires, they will prefer a map size design that is vast and can stimulate the desire to run and explore.

Secondly, do players have other deeper game needs besides feedback that the map is too big or too small? Compared with the feedback that the map itself is too big or too small, what we need to do more is to dig deep into the players’ deep-seated game motivations and needs, and optimize the game mechanism for these deep-seated needs. For example, reducing running time and using the limited time for exciting frontal battles and strategic play; or wanting to collect resource materials as soon as possible to achieve more game achievements.

entry.title: Gamification in Communities: Community Badges
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

1. Application of Gamification in Communities

Since the 1980s, scholars in the field of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) have continuously tried to use games to inspire exploration in non-game scenarios such as education and sociology. In research, the concept of gamification mostly focuses on the inspiration brought by game design, gameplay, and user experience. Gamification itself is an informal and inclusive explanation, usually referring to the application of game elements in non-game scenarios to improve user experience and engagement.

In online communities and social media, gamification design has also seen increasing applications: from the evaluation system of shopping websites, to restaurant and takeout reviews, to the achievement system of Q&A websites, and so on. The common feature of these websites and communities is that they rely on user output to develop and maintain the community. Therefore, how to encourage users to participate in the community has become one of the main goals of these communities.

Preece & Schneiderman, in “The Reader-to-Leader Framework”, divided community users into five levels according to their degree of participation: all users, readers, contributors, collaborators, and leaders. Two of the major factors affecting community members’ willingness to contribute are: the visibility of members’ contributions and the recognition of members’ high-quality contributions and expertise.

Just as outstanding students in school can get red stars, and students with excellent grades can occupy the top of the leaderboard, achievements and badges in games are also a recognition and reward for players’ achievements. Similarly, by using gamification methods to design some virtual rewards to stimulate community members, more people can actively participate in community building, and at the same time, it can better highlight active community members and create a good community atmosphere. As a common virtual reward in communities, the design of community badges can also be considered from multiple perspectives such as the value, meaning, and distribution management methods of the badge itself.

2. Badge Design in Communities

In the community, as one of the incentives for members to participate in the community, the design of badges is also varied. The famous online forum Discuz! once released the badge function in its Discuz! X2.5.

Various Discuz! badges used in a singer’s official forum

In overseas community forums, the developer community Stack Overflow has designed different achievement badges for different user scenarios and preferences in order to encourage users to participate in community activities. In order to encourage users to answer questions, Stack Overflow provides a variety of badges for different user levels, such as:

  • Guru badge: Guru means mentor in religion, and in Stack Overflow, this badge means that the member’s answer is accepted by the questioner and gets more than 40 points (in Stack Overflow, each time a member’s answer is liked, it gets 1 point, and each time it is disliked, it gets -1 point);
  • Self-Learner badge: Refers to the member who answered his own question, and the answer received more than 3 points;
  • Tenacious badge: Represents that the member has more than 5 answers with 0 points, and the 0-point answers account for more than 20% of their total answers.

These various badge designs cover the user scenarios of different levels, and purposefully render the atmosphere of the community encouraging users to create together - no matter what kind of questions are answered, no matter how many likes are received, it is a behavior worthy of encouragement in the community. Similar to the Tenacious badge, there are also many achievement titles in games, such as the Lucky Star and Koi achievements in Naraka: Bladepoint, which claim to be mixed into the front row.

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Koi Achievement

Facebook Group Badges

In 2017, the global social media platform Facebook launched the badge function in its group section “Facebook Group”, and in 2018 began to promote it to eligible communities (with more than 50 members). Administrators of eligible communities can manage the display configuration of badges related to the community in the Facebook Group backend panel. The Facebook Community officially explained that this function was established to “clarify the identity of administrators, reward community members who have made outstanding contributions, and enhance mutual understanding among members.”

Facebook Group backend management page related to badges: Administrators can only enable or disable a specific badge, and the distribution and rules of badges are completed by the Facebook platform and backend algorithms

In the game community research, Lei Huo UX’s user researchers evaluated the comprehensibility, information content, and distinguishability of the 6 common Facebook Group badges at that time. The research results show that Facebook Group badges play a role in emphasizing member roles and increasing member exposure, but specific badges may also cause readers and administrators to have certain biases when browsing the content of the post while prompting the identity of the post author. Since the badge distribution rules are not clear, core members of the community will have different understandings of the meaning of specific badges based on their own experience. In the eyes of users, what is more important than badges is the “poster itself” and the “content of the post”.

The 6 types of Facebook Group badges included in the study

By introducing a system similar to badge achievements in the community through gamification, for users who read posts, badges that prompt the author’s authority or the length of time the user has participated in the community (such as Admin, Moderator, New Member, Founding Member) will have a certain impact on their understanding of the content. Members believe that the speeches of administrators and old members are “more authoritative”, the content of the posts is “more trustworthy”, and will also attract more attention and discussion. Administrators themselves also said that under the extra exposure brought by the badges, they will pay more attention to restraining their behavior to create a good community atmosphere. Conversely, for the content published by new members, members will “lower their expectations” and “understand them patiently and empathetically.”

For other badges related to the frequency and content of posts, there will not be much difference in content understanding from ordinary posts. The high exposure brought by badges will relatively amplify some shortcomings and mistakes in the content. From the perspective of administrators, these posts will also be “more eye-catching”. For example, the “Conversation Starter” badge in the Facebook Group, the designer’s original intention was to commend members who put forward “meaningful discussions” in the community, but the statistical method of this badge only considered the number of replies to the original post, and the content quality of the original post was not included in the consideration of this badge, which led to some of the members who were awarded the Conversation Starter badge after the function was released being members who often provoked conflicts in the community. Users actually feel that such badges are “unrealistic”, and administrators believe that such badges will cause their “extra attention” when they appear after a period of adaptation.

  • The Top Fan badge belongs to the Facebook Page and was not originally included in this research plan, but many users still mentioned this badge during the interview.

3. Opportunities and Challenges Brought by Badge Design to Game Communities

By introducing achievement and badge systems in the community through the concept of gamification, it can encourage community members to participate in interaction to a certain extent and enhance community stickiness. However, there are many differences in the social purposes of players in the game and in the community, and community badges cannot simply copy the achievement system in the game. Easeley & Ghosh (2016) proposed. In the community, if you want to design a competitive ranking badge similar to “highest contribution”, using absolute values (such as the top 10) in the badge acquisition conditions is more helpful for community members to understand the value of the badge than using relative percentages (the top 1%).

As designers, when designing badges for game communities, they should also consider the transparency of the rules, the interpretability, sustainability, and flexibility of badges in different communities. In the design process of community badges, for the choice of badge name and the specific description of the badge, designers should find a balance between improving interpretability and simplicity, and should also consider the actual situation of the community, allowing users to participate in the customization process of badges, so that the badge achievement system can be better used by the community and create and maintain a good community atmosphere.

Note: The user names cited in the text are all pseudonyms.

entry.title: The Magic Touch to Enhance Combat Thrill: In the World of Martial Arts, Only Slowness is Unbreakable!
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

When describing a game’s combat system, we often hear words like “satisfying,” “exciting,” and “explosive.” We also often hear comments about the game’s fast-paced combat and tight level design. So, does the thrill of a combat game rely solely on speed?

Sifu, as a fighting game, has received a lot of praise since its launch. Similar to many kung fu movies, the protagonist often faces a room full of enemies, being ganged up on. The dodging, blocking, posture system, and complex combo mechanics of upper and lower attacks require players to constantly observe the enemy’s movements and react quickly and correctly. The overall fighting rhythm of the game is very fast, making your fingers sore from button mashing, but there is a very important “Focus” skill system. When used, it slows down the movements of all surrounding enemies, allowing the protagonist to unleash a powerful blow.

 

Using the Focus skill “Powerful Sweep Kick”

The sudden slowing down of the camera during combat does not give players a sluggish experience. On the contrary, it can increase the richness of the game mechanics and enhance the feeling of impact. Looking back at other games I’ve played before, this slow-motion mechanism is actually very common. Although they are all slow-motion, the experience they bring to players varies due to different trigger mechanisms and trigger scenes.

1. Ranged Attacks - Assisting Aim, Enhancing Expressiveness

In 1999, the movie The Matrix made the “bullet time” filming technique famous. The instantaneous trajectory of the bullet was clearly presented to the audience.

 

The famous bullet time scene in “The Matrix”

The airflow, smoke, flying cape, and 360-degree rotating camera position all made this bullet-dodging scene achieve the ultimate expressiveness. This slow-motion presentation method was later not only used in many gunfight movies, but also in many combat games that use ranged weapons.

In Horizon Zero Dawn, when the player draws the bow, triggering Focus or jumping will enter a slow-motion state. All scene dynamics and the player’s actions will be slowed down. In addition to helping players better aim at the opponent, the effect triggered by the arrow hitting is also more visually impactful.

Interestingly, the rhythm of the lens is not a single slow. The process of releasing the arrow is still rapid, while the explosion is slow. In the slow-motion perspective, a huge mecha creature rushes towards you, and the rocket ignites the fuel tank on its back. Steel and fire blend together in an instant, and the burning picture is frozen. The slow-fast-slow processing method expresses the “sense of impact” to the fullest.

 

《Horizon Zero Dawn》: Rocket Hitting a Mecha

In Red Dead Redemption 2, using the “Dead Eye” skill can enter the auxiliary aiming state. In this state, not only will the character’s actions slow down, but after the Dead Eye skill is upgraded, it can also mark multiple enemies during this slow-motion period to complete a burst of bullets, and view the enemy’s weak points (such as the head, heart, lungs, etc.) to achieve the purpose of one-hit kill.

 

《Red Dead Redemption 2》: Locking onto Enemies in Dead Eye Mode for 100% Throwing Accuracy

2. Melee Combat - Time Window, Special Skills, Powerful Counterattacks

The mechanism of using slow motion in melee games is different from that of ranged attacks. Melee combat does not have the problem of aiming, but it is usually fast-paced and has a low fault tolerance rate. Therefore, many games use slow motion to provide players with a certain reaction time window.

Katana ZERO is a pixel-style fighting game. The enemies move fast, and some even have bullets. The player has no health bar, only a katana in their hand. Therefore, they either kill the enemy with one slash or are instantly killed by the enemy. In addition to direct fast attacks, players can actively trigger “bullet time,” and the picture will enter slow motion. During this process, they can deflect bullets or take the opportunity to defeat the opponent.

 

Bullet Time in《Katana ZERO》

In “bullet time” mode, the screen turns black, and only the protagonist and the target are lit up, as well as the attack animation. This mechanism lowers the operating threshold for players who are not pursuing extreme speedruns. However, due to the visual impact of the before-and-after comparison, the undiminished speed of the attack effects, and the slow-motion blood splatter, the thrill of the game is not weakened.

Other games use slow motion as a transition between the player’s parry/dodge and a powerful counterattack, as a foreshadowing of the powerful counterattack, making the thrill of the counterattack stronger.

The perfect parry in Ghost of Tsushima and Link Time in The Legend of Zelda are such examples. After the player parries the enemy’s attack at a specific moment or successfully dodges the enemy’s attack, they will enter a short slow-motion phase. At this time, the player can launch a powerful counterattack against the enemy. Since this kind of bullet time is not completely actively triggered by the player at any time, it requires players to be familiar with the attack animations of different enemies in order to master the appropriate button timing. Also, because it is difficult to master and has high returns, the sense of accomplishment brought by triggering a perfect parry/perfect dodge is even stronger.

 

《Ghost of Tsushima》: Entering Slow-Motion After a Perfect Parry, Followed by a Heavy Attack

 

《The Legend of Zelda》: Entering Link Time After Successfully Dodging with a Shield Jump

3. Supporting Visual Performance - Focusing on Key Points, Enhancing Feedback

Slow motion changes more than just the rhythm of the camera. Looking at the games mentioned above, when slow motion is triggered, players often have a clear goal. Therefore, in order to highlight this goal and enhance the player’s combat thrill, games usually make some other screen processing.

Focusing on the Subject, Weakening Invalid Information

Usually, in such critical moments, the game tries to focus the player’s attention on the target they are currently focusing on. Common methods include changing the screen color/radially blurring the surrounding picture/enlarging the subject, etc.

Unifying the picture into a monochromatic tone and highlighting the current target subject with the original color or other emphasizing colors is a very useful method. Katana ZERO and Sifu, mentioned above, are such examples. Unimportant scenes are greatly weakened during the slow-motion process, and the attack effects and both the enemy and the player stand out in such scenes.

 

《Katana ZERO》 Screen Comparison

 

《Sifu》 Screen Comparison

Other games radially blur the surrounding picture, making the blurred lines converge towards the center of the picture, which is the target subject, making the picture seem to have speed lines in comics. And the direction lines of this blur also serve as a visual guide for players, making the clear target subject in the center more eye-catching.

 

《The Legend of Zelda》 Screen Comparison

 

《Cyberpunk 2077》 Screen Comparison

After the irrelevant information in the picture is weakened, if some UIs of specific skills are added at this time, they will also become more eye-catching. Just like the Focus skill option wheel attached to the enemy silhouette in Sifu and the counterattack prompt key in The Legend of Zelda, the enhanced UI will not make players feel abrupt. Instead, it can allow players to notice the most important information in a short time and focus their attention.

In Naraka: Bladepoint, the out-of-game grappling hook display system also uses bullet time. The camera stretches towards the direction of the grappling hook launch, focusing the subject of the picture on the grappling hook. Slow motion is used during the launch process, and the original speed is restored when the grappling hook is deployed. Between the contrast of fast and slow, the grappling hook, as an important functional appearance, is shown in great detail.

 

Grappling Hook Display Camera in 《Naraka: Bladepoint》

Enhancing Feedback, Strengthening Special Effects Performance

Since the player’s time is frozen, they can’t just use weak attacks, right? There must be slow and fast, forming a contrast, so that the freeze frame will be more exciting, and the strike will be more shocking. Therefore, the attack performance after the end of slow motion is often more prominent than ordinary attacks. For example, the powerful counterattacks mentioned earlier.

 

Powerful Counterattack After Triggering Link Time

4. Summary

The use of slow motion in film and television works greatly enhances the expressiveness of the picture, and it is more than that in games. As a gameplay mechanism, slow motion can assist players in aiming and highlight more important information in ranged attacks, while in melee combat, it can provide players with reaction time and provide block feedback. And its own visual expressiveness is added with the unique artistry of the game. Fast and slow, strong and weak, color and black and white, the contrast between before and after complements each other.

entry.title: Going Against the Grain: Why Do Souls-like Games Torture Players Yet Become a Global Phenomenon?
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

“Souls-like” games, a unique genre created by game producer Hidetaka Miyazaki, are almost synonymous with “torture”. Unlike most games, Souls-like games have a very high learning curve, requiring players to fight in a world full of dangers and survive countless difficult boss battles. Even a little carelessness can cause the player to die at the hands of a roadside mob. This “torturous” experience has fascinated a large number of players, who curse at repeated deaths while being inseparably pursuing the hard-won victory.

In April 2021, at the Golden Joysticks, the oldest video game award ceremony, the public voted Dark Souls as the greatest game of all time. And the latest Souls-like game, Elden Ring, sold 12 million copies worldwide in half a month, becoming another ten-million-selling IP under FromSoftware.

With many games opting to lower the learning curve to attract users, how can Souls-like games be so difficult and hardcore, yet achieve such excellent sales? One of the big reasons is that Souls-like games have a unique temperament that can give players a distinctive emotional experience, which makes them stand out among many trendy games. This article discusses how Souls-like games capture the hearts of players from the perspective of emotional experience.

1. Unique “Dark” Emotional Experience

Today’s game genres are basically divided based on the core gameplay of the game, which has created a situation where conventional games may have innovations in gameplay, but their emotional experience tends to be homogenized. The reason why Souls-like games are so successful is that they create a very strong dark, apocalyptic atmosphere, thus avoiding the homogenization of game emotions and emotional experiences, and making them stand out among many competitors.

Core Experience of Difficulty and Exploration

The special death mechanism, dark artistic expression, obscure narrative techniques, and the overall atmosphere created by the game together constitute the “Souls-like flavor” that players are fascinated by. This unique emotional experience can be summarized as “difficulty” and “exploration.”

“Difficulty” is the persistence of Hidetaka Miyazaki’s game aesthetics and the core part of the player experience. Previous “Souls” works, including the Dark Souls series, Bloodborne, and Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice, have the essence of allowing players to constantly learn in ridiculously difficult battles until they develop a suitable attack routine. The core experience is “gaining a sense of accomplishment by constantly overcoming difficulties.” Death is not just a sign of failure. When players continue to overcome difficulties in repeated deaths and finally achieve victory on their own, the previous deaths are given great meaning - constant death is for the sake of overcoming death.

“Exploration” is also an important temperament of Souls-like games. The complex, grand, and mysterious things in Souls-like games make players instinctively want to pursue them. The fragmented narrative reveals the tip of the iceberg of the grand world, and the complex, hidden, and highly explorable map immerses players in this dark land. These designs encourage players to explore the world more carefully. In order to make the game more exploratory, Hidetaka Miyazaki has made a lot of information in the game fragmented, hidden, and complex. He does not want to give players too complete and clear things, but hopes that players will build their own world through their own exploration.

Apocalyptic Aesthetic World Atmosphere

For Souls-like games, its soul figure Hidetaka Miyazaki has been committed to expressing an “apocalyptic aesthetic” in the game: depressing and vast nights, decadent and grand buildings, the ignition and extinguishing of flames, the cycle of life and death… This kind of grand, ethereal, and depressing elements frequently appear in Souls-like games, constituting a unique Souls-like world.

This apocalyptic aesthetic not only creates a very impactful emotional atmosphere for players, but also rationalizes the core experience of Souls-like games - “difficulty” and “exploration”. In a dark apocalypse, extremely difficult environments are taken for granted, and obscure information and areas awaiting exploration are also in line with the depressing and mysterious atmosphere of the apocalypse.

2. Making Overcoming Difficulties Fun

Using Negative Emotions to Enhance Positive Experiences

How to design the sense of accomplishment in the game? Souls-like games give the answer by catalyzing the unparalleled joy and satisfaction after the final victory with the negative emotions of repeated failures. In order to give players a stronger game experience, Souls-like games allow players to experience oppressive, anxious, frustrated, and other negative emotions in extremely difficult battles, and encourage players to overcome this difficulty, so as to obtain a stronger sense of accomplishment and glory. That is, by means of first suppressing and then raising, making the depression more depressing and the happiness more joyful.

Although negative emotions can be a catalyst, they are ultimately an unpleasant experience for players. In order to prevent negative emotions from being too high and discouraging players, many skills need to be paid attention to in the design of negative emotions in the game to minimize their negative impact. For example, reward players when the enemy’s weaknesses are exposed to encourage them to continue the challenge. In Sekiro, there are usually ghost fire points very close to the boss battle to avoid repeatedly experiencing the boring process of running. High-difficulty bosses are usually isolated in a spacious area for players to concentrate on the battle.

Easy Operation Threshold and High-Difficulty Enemy Design

Difficulty is an indelible feature of Souls-like games, giving Souls-like games a different kind of fun. This feeling of high difficulty does not come from complicated operations, but from enemy design.

Taking the Dark Souls series as an example, the basic operations of the game are not many. Simple four-direction movement and locking, attacks mainly use light attacks and heavy attacks, defense has blocking and parrying, dodging attacks has rolling, and switching weapons and magic. The core operations of most players are basically a combination of several common solutions, such as “slash + roll + counterattack”. Until Elden Ring, this easy-to-use operation logic is still very useful.

After the easy-to-use entry threshold, Souls-like games set extremely high-difficulty confrontations for players in the enemy design link. Souls-like games usually set a challenge with novel mechanisms and great difficulty. Usually, the game does not provide players with any clearance teaching. Players who want to overcome difficulties can only die and try repeatedly at the challenge until they master enough skills. Most of the boss enemies in Sekiro have unique fighting styles and novel attack methods. Players who face them for the first time hardly know how to defeat these bosses. Only through repeated death trials and errors can they improve their skills. This experience of learning how to fight in the death cycle is the essence of Souls-like games. Players repeatedly challenge the same difficulty, watching themselves progress step by step, producing wonderful chemical reactions emotionally, and bursting out with a surge of accomplishment when they finally overcome the challenge.

3. Letting Players Breathe in Difficulty

According to the over-limit effect in psychology, there is an upper limit to a person’s tolerance for a certain emotion. If the player is in a depressed and frustrated mood in the game for a long time, and there is no [loose] rhythm control, then the player will feel very tired. Although difficulty is the soul of Souls-like games that cannot be separated, it is also necessary to set up a breathing space for players. By designing high-degree-of-freedom coping methods, players are helped to persevere in difficulties.

In the design of the difficulty curve, Souls-like games often give many opportunities to escape in the early and mid-term in order to allow players to learn to explore the enemy’s routines more smoothly and enter the challenge mode. In Elden Ring, this progress is more obvious. Players can ride a horse to escape a failed battle. If one road is too difficult, they can choose another.

In addition, players have a variety of challenge methods when attacking bosses, and even have particularly easy countermeasures. For example, the famous newcomer killer, The Pursuer, in Dark Souls 2, can be dealt with by rolling away from most of the attacks by hiding in the position where he holds the shield, or by escaping to his birthplace and shooting with a ballista. A variety of coping methods not only further enhance the strategy of the game, but also make the player’s perception of difficulty more flexible, further reducing the possibility of players being discouraged.

4. Conclusion

Hidetaka Miyazaki, the soul figure of Souls-like games, believes that death is not meaningless. The Souls-like games he produced are always full of the propositions of “death and rebirth”, “attempt and overcoming”. He insists on apocalyptic aesthetics and insists on using extremely difficult experiences to touch the hearts of the audience. Perhaps it is this special persistence that keeps Souls-like games very strong in this era. We also need to see what efforts Hidetaka Miyazaki has made behind this persistence in order to make the player experience more complete.

entry.title: 'Can someone help Kurumi?' — Are Female Characters in Games Really Weak?
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase))

“Can someone help Kurumi?” — This is the most famous line of the hero Kurumi (Hu Tao) in the game Naraka: Bladepoint. Kurumi is always easily targeted and besieged by enemies on the battlefield, and her classic voice line is also used very frequently, becoming a well-known mantra among Naraka: Bladepoint players.

But, is Kurumi really weak?

Let’s take a look at the actual combat situation: In an impressive trio match in last autumn’s Naraka Championship, Bilibili Gaming (BKG) player Huya丶niko saved his teammates at the last critical moment. He turned the tide with Kurumi and won the title of “God of War”. In daily games, many skilled players also say that Kurumi’s solo hero ranking is the most difficult, but also the most challenging.

Perhaps it can be said that Kurumi is difficult to operate, but if played well, she can bring infinite possibilities to the team. High-level Kurumi players often become the “mastermind” of a team. It can be seen that Kurumi is not really weak.

 

Huya丶niko won the title of “God of War” in the Naraka Championship

So why do players often habitually think that these female characters are usually in a weak position in the game and need help? This article will analyze the positioning and changes of female characters in games in recent years from the following three aspects, and whether they are really “weak”.

1. The Image and Positioning of Female Characters in Early Games

In some early game works, there were indeed many female game characters who really “needed to be saved by others to survive”.

The Universal Narrative Formula of “Saving the Maiden”

Whether it’s the frequent appearance of “saving the kidnapped Peach” in the Super Mario series, or “finding the crystal and saving the princess” in the Zelda series, I believe many players are familiar with it. In fact, there are many similar plots of saving Princess Peach - Damsel in Distress is a relatively common narrative framework in early games. It comes from the French Demoiselle en Détresse, which can be simply translated as “a maiden in danger”. In such narratives, regardless of whether the female character has combat power, they are often in a helpless image of danger in the story, and are often set as the core incentive or motivation for the male protagonist to start the adventure.

 

These female characters usually appear as princesses, wives or sisters of male protagonists. When analyzing such female characters, the subject/object dichotomy is usually used, that is, the subject acts and the object is acted upon. The subject can be understood as the protagonist, the central character of the story, and generally the main playable character in the game. In the Damsel in Distress narrative, it is usually assumed that the male is the subject and the female is placed in the role of the object. In the game, she usually becomes “the reward to be won”, “the treasure to be found”, or “the goal to be achieved”.

The Gender Perspective Behind the Story Narration

The story narration of a game can usually reflect the perspective of the game maker and the worldview they want to express, and it will inevitably be reflected in the game. Grand Theft Auto (GTA)‘s gender controversy, objectification of female characters, and lack of inclusivity are often criticized: there are no female characters that can be played in the first person, no female characters that can influence the main storyline, and most female NPCs are also labeled with a single “sexy” tag. Every main poster of GTA must have a woman wearing overly revealing clothes, and the protagonist’s wife in the game is also set as a stripper.

Whether it is a game or a film and television work, if you want players to be immersed, a sense of story substitution is essential. Imagine, if female characters in the game can be arbitrarily abused, how will female players feel? Are the female game characters labeled “sexy” and “weak” a stereotype or an invisible misogynistic tendency? Nearly half of the game players in the United States are women, while women account for only 24% of the game developer group. Should the roles of women be presented by female practitioners to be more reasonable?

 

Female image in the game “GTA”

Changes in the Image of Women in Games in the Past 20 Years

In the 80s and 90s, the plot of “saving the distressed girl” once became a cliché in video games. Whether it was action fighting, role-playing, or first-person shooters, people were keen to add this old-fashioned but “effective” plot formula, and enjoyed it. And now, the old-fashioned plot of “saving the princess” and “saving the girl” has long been criticized and abandoned by the times.

In the past nearly 20 years, a significant change in female characters in games is playability. In the earliest video games, many female characters existed only to promote the plot. And now, female characters are no longer a kind of “accessory” or “catalyst”, but one of the game protagonists with combat capabilities, with maximum playability and controllability. EEDAR (Electronic Entertainment Design and Research) company counted in 2021 that 45% of 669 games, that is, 300 games, allow players to operate female characters, but there are 369 games that can only play male characters, and only 24 games can only play female characters.

 

《Apex Legends》

On the point of gender balance and diversity, Apex Legends is an excellent model, achieving a high degree of balance in the proportion of hero gender and race. Bloodhound is called “they”, is it a male or a female? There are different opinions about the gender of this mysterious hunter, and some people say that ta is actually the only non-binary gender in the game.

2. What are the Female Characters Like in Naraka: Bladepoint

Breaking Stereotypes - The Strong in the Game World

In early games, the subjective consciousness of most female characters was often ignored. After being imprisoned, kidnapped, and cursed, did they never think of resisting or breaking free from the shackles of fate? Maybe they did, but the game setting often did not allow them to “escape successfully” until the male protagonist arrived. In recent years, in games, we can not only see that the stereotype of “the princess to be rescued” is being broken, but more importantly, more and more female game characters are changing their fate through their own struggles, rather than waiting in place to be “rescued”.

 

In Naraka: Bladepoint, whether it is playability, the positioning of female characters, or the self-awareness of characters, they are completely different from the weak images in past games. Of the twelve heroes currently open in the game, female characters account for half, each with talent skills that can mutually check and balance all heroes. Another breakthrough worth noting is that Yoto Hime (Ning Hongye), as the main promotional image of the game, is a female hero, and becomes the default protagonist in the novice tutorial.

 

In the character background story of Naraka: Bladepoint, the image of the female hero portrayed is very distinct and three-dimensional, with both a sense of power and combat effectiveness. There is the unyielding, beautiful and dangerous red snake, the swordsman Yoto Hime; the ghostly assassin Viper Ning (Jia Nan) who haunts the desert; the ambitious and resourceful sea overlord Tsuchimikado Kurumi (Cui Sanniang); and the ranger Justina Gu (Gu Qinghan) who was born as an imperial princess but wanders the world to bury her enemies in blood. Whether it is the Kunlun Goddess, the Desert Blackhawk, the Flower of Heliothis, or the Dragon King of the Mist Sea, these titles given to them all imply that they are “the strong” in their respective fields.

 

“My Fate is up to Me”

If analyzed by the subject-object dichotomy, they are undoubtedly the central subject of the game. Not only that, in the description of the hero’s legend, we can see their growth line and determination to become strong. For example, in the prologue of Tsuchimikado Kurumi’s hero story, her original words are “The weak can only drift with the tide and eventually be swallowed by the sea.” “And the strong will steer their own course, ride the wind and waves, and reach the shore of victory.” In many details of Naraka: Bladepoint, from the hero story to the description of an appearance, it is not difficult to see that female characters are given more dominant positions, and their own awareness of resistance is awakened.

 

Seemingly Weak, But Can Also Be a “Savior”

Finally, back to Kurumi. After several versions of iterations, although Kurumi’s skills and positioning have been repeatedly adjusted and modified, when it comes to Kurumi, players will not easily say the word “easy”. Although she has been beaten all the time, she is also very strong, and she must always judge the situation to support her teammates, and find opportunities to help dismantle the fire when necessary.

3. Pay Attention to Female Players and Female Characters in Games

In fact, in current video games, the presence and importance of female characters are increasing. The ESA found in a survey that 48% of the surveyed players were women. Recently, a MOBA game producer also shared an interesting piece of data on Reddit, 97% of female players will only choose female characters, while the ratio of male players choosing male and female characters is 50% to 50%.

More and more players will choose female characters, which also requires game makers to set female characters from an equal perspective. Compared with the labeled masculinity and femininity, what is more important is how to define female characters - she can be a father’s daughter, a husband’s wife, a younger brother’s sister, but she should be herself more, and she can overcome difficulties, explore and conquer the world like other male characters.

4. Summary

In the setting of female game characters, many games no longer label them with stereotypes of traditional game females such as “weak”, “need to be rescued”, “accessories of the male protagonist”, etc. They are the protagonists themselves, brave, loyal, wise, powerful, and exemplary. Compared with some of the criticized Damsel in Distress settings in the early days, this is undoubtedly a forward-looking breakthrough and progress.

As the population of female game players is constantly growing, we believe that paying attention to and improving the situation of female characters in games, and then extending to exploring the needs of female players, will also be an important topic for user research. The importance of female players in today’s game market is obvious, and these newly emerging female players need respect and recognition from the game culture.
