By combining their demographic information, psycho-social environment, and the game culture they belong to, we user researchers have more directions worth studying.

entry.title: Overseas Holy Land: Analysis of the Korean Game Market and Localization Optimization Suggestions
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

In recent years, the domestic game user market in China has become saturated, and the user dividend has gradually disappeared. However, game manufacturers still regard the domestic market as the main distribution market, resulting in the incremental market gradually becoming a stock market. There are structural development opportunities in the international market, with huge potential. Many game manufacturers have begun to turn their attention overseas, seeking opportunities for games to go global.

South Korea, as a country with a top-ranking game market scale in Asia and even globally, has become one of the must-select markets for game companies from various countries due to its developed game industry, mature e-sports ecosystem, and strong player spending power. In recent years, many Chinese games have also achieved excellent results in the Korean market. In 2021, among the games released overseas by China, 33 entered the Top 100 Korean mobile games by revenue, with revenue reaching US$980 million, accounting for 22.3% of the Top 100 total revenue. In recent years, more and more overseas games and IPs have entered the Korean market, and competition has become increasingly fierce.

Going overseas has become an important strategic choice for most game companies. Before going overseas, understanding the corresponding market environment and user characteristics is an indispensable link. By familiarizing yourself with the characteristics of the market and avoiding cultural conflicts, you can avoid detours and effectively occupy market advantages. This article will analyze the Korean game market with huge potential and provide relevant localization optimization suggestions.

1. Scale and Trends of the Korean Game Market

The Korean Game Market Ranks Fourth in the World

According to the “2021 Korean Game White Paper”, the Korean game market accounts for 6.9% of the global market, and it maintains a relatively fast growth trend. In 2019, the scale of the Korean game market ranked fifth in the world, and in 2020, it surpassed the United Kingdom and became the fourth largest game market in the world, second only to the United States, China, and Japan.

 

The Scale of the Korean Game Market Continues to Grow

Although the Korean economy was generally sluggish in 2020 due to the impact of the epidemic, the market size of games has increased significantly. In 2020, the scale of the Korean game market increased by 21.3%, reaching 18.9 trillion won (approximately RMB 100 billion). The main reason for the growth of the game industry in 2020 is the increase in indoor activities due to the impact of the epidemic. (Data source: 2021 Korean Game White Paper)

The scale of the Korean game market has maintained a continuous growth trend since 2014. In 2021, it even exceeded 20 trillion won (approximately 107 billion yuan), setting a new record for the Korean game market. In 2023, it is likely to form a large-scale market of 23.46 trillion won (approximately 125.4 billion yuan).

 

2. Platform Breakdown of the Korean Game Market

Mobile Games Account for the Highest Proportion, Console Games Show a Growth Trend

From 2014 to 2020, from the perspective of the revenue share of each platform, the market share of PC games continued to decrease, while the share of mobile games increased the most every year. The share of console games was not large, but it also achieved small growth.

 

In 2020, among the revenue distribution of various platforms in the Korean game industry, mobile games accounted for the largest proportion, 63.5%, PC games accounted for 28.7%, console games accounted for 6.4%, and arcade games accounted for 1.3%.

 

In mobile game revenue, South Korea’s three major game manufacturers “3N” (NCSOFT, Nexon, Netmarble) still lead the mobile game market. NCSOFT’s Lineage IP games occupy the upstream, and Nexon’s “The Kingdom of the Winds”, “KartRider Rush+” and other games are also very impressive. However, in 2021, after the launch of Kakao’s “Odin: Valhalla Rising”, NCSOFT’s revenue decreased due to word-of-mouth and other factors; Nexon had no new blockbuster games launched, and the performance of old games was sluggish, and revenue continued to decline; although Netmarble had “Ni no Kuni: Cross Worlds” launched, the game did not bring revenue growth. In 2021, the three major Korean manufacturers failed to achieve breakthrough growth, and their influence gradually declined, while domestic game manufacturers in China are catching up.

 

The scale of the PC game market decreased slightly by 4% compared with the previous year. The main reasons are the relatively high R&D costs of PC games, the gradual shift of users to mobile games, and the reduction of new games. The report predicts that the scale of the Korean PC game market will stagnate or decline in the future. The revenue of Korean Internet cafes in 2020 was also affected by the epidemic, down 11.9%.

The sales of the console game market increased by 57.3% compared with the previous year, with a large increase. It is speculated that the explosive growth of console games was mainly affected by the popularity of Nintendo Switch and “Animal Crossing”. In addition, more and more manufacturers are porting mobile or computer games to consoles, with a focus on indie games. With the increase of Korean companies such as Pearl Abyss and Smilegate that develop console masterpieces, the Korean console game market will continue to maintain a high growth momentum in the future. It is estimated that the sales of the console game market in 2021 will increase by 17.3% compared with the previous year, reaching 1.2815 trillion won (this is predicted data, the real data has not yet been disclosed).

In the past two years, “3N” has successively announced its strategic console games. For example, NCSOFT will launch the massively multiplayer online role-playing game “Throne and Liberty”, NEXON will launch the racing game “KartRider: Drift” in the form of a console, and Netmarble launched “Seven Knights: Time Wanderer” in 2020, which ported its masterpiece “Seven Knights” to the console game platform Switch. It is not difficult to see that the reason why “3N” is tightening the reins of entering the console game is related to the stagnation of the market in its existing main areas and the huge potential of the console market.

3. User Portrait of Korean Players

According to Newzoo’s statistics on the age structure of players around the world in 2022, 46% of Korean players are 18-34 years old, and more than 50% of players are over 35 years old. The overall age of players is older. Older players have high spending power, which also determines the strong willingness of Korean players to spend on games.

PC Game Players: The Proportion of Male Players is Significantly Higher Than That of Female Players

Among Korean game players, the usage rate of PC games is 59.1%.

Among PC players, the proportion of female players is 34.7%, and the proportion of male players is 65.3%. From the perspective of age distribution, players aged 20-30 have the highest proportion, accounting for 28.4%, followed by the 30-40 and 40-50 age groups, accounting for 20.1% and 21.6% respectively.

 

● PC Game Genre Preferences:

From the perspective of the game genres that PC game players often experience, the top five game genres are RPG/MMORPG, FPS/TPS, Simulation, AOS, and Sports. Players aged 20-30 prefer to play games such as “League of Legends”, “PUBG”, “FIFA”, and “Overwatch”. The younger the players, the higher the proportion of experiencing AOS and racing genres, and they also prefer to play games with friends; from the perspective of gender, female players prefer games such as simulation, racing, and puzzle.

Mobile Game Players: The Proportion of Male and Female Players is Basically the Same

Among Korean game players, the usage rate of mobile games is 91.1%.

In the gender distribution of mobile game players, the proportion of male players is 50.7%, and the proportion of female players is 49.3%. The proportion of males and females is basically the same, each accounting for half. Compared with China, which is also an Asian country, the proportion of male and female players in South Korea is more balanced: among Chinese mobile game players, males account for 61.7% and females account for 38.3%, with males significantly higher than females.

 

Console Game Players: Male Players Account for 57%

Among Korean game players, the usage rate of console games is 20.8%. Among console players, the proportion of female players is 42.7%, and the proportion of male players is 57.3%.

 

Compared with mobile game players, there are fewer young players in console games, which is also related to spending power and family environment. The development of the Korean console market is relatively late compared with the United States and Japan. In the 1990s, Japan occupied the console market, but because of cultural restrictions in South Korea, it was also difficult to import games, and the development of the console market was relatively slow. And most Korean families have TVs in the living room. Without the consent of family members, it is impossible to enjoy console games in the living room, which also has certain restrictions on students’ experience of console games.

4. Characteristics of the Korean Mobile Game Market

Mainly MMORPG Genre

Compared with China, the Korean mobile game market has lower diversity and is mainly MMORPG. In 2021, among the Top 3 Korean mobile games by revenue, the sales of the MMORPG genre accounted for 70%. Among them, the sales of Lineage IP games accounted for more than 30%.

South Korea can be said to be the holy land of MMORPG. There is also a saying that it is “Korean-made MMORPG”. Why is this game genre so popular in South Korea? What are the reasons? What are the characteristics of Korean MMORPGs? The following points are summarized for these questions.

● The Influence of Korea’s First Generation MMORPG

When it comes to Korean MMORPG, we must mention “The Kingdom of the Winds” and “Lineage”. “The Kingdom of the Winds” is a PC game developed and published by NEXON in 1996. This year marks its 26th anniversary. It is the world’s longest-running and representative first multiplayer online game in the history of Korean games. The game also created a lot of innovative gameplay, including resurrection, purchase-type growth and other systems. After reaching the full level, you will not continue to upgrade, but you can provide continuous growth motivation by purchasing HP/MP, hunting to obtain additional experience, etc. This form is also used in current games.

 

“Lineage” is a PC game developed and published by NCSOFT in 1998. At that time, “Lineage” had two main highlights. The first was the picture quality/sound effects, and the second was the siege warfare. It induced competition among players through a relatively free PVP mode, and you could obtain props by killing other players. The unprecedented siege warfare system aroused the players’ sense of team honor, and the blood alliance system provided players with a sense of belonging. After these two games achieved great success in South Korea, MMORPG seems to have become the preferred game genre for other Korean manufacturers. After 2000, games such as “Black Desert”, “Mabinogi”, “MU Online”, and “Lineage” series were launched successively. With the explosion of the mobile game market, these PC games have successively launched mobile games with the same IP.

● Characteristics of Korean MMORPG - Highlighting of Hunting Gameplay and Convenient Operation

Compared with other overseas games of the same type, Korean MMORPGs emphasize hunting gameplay more. From the perspective of R&D, development resources can be saved. Instead of creating a brand new gameplay, adding monsters and maps can achieve hunting gameplay. Players who have experienced the “Lineage” PC game in the past have long been accustomed to Lineage-style simple operations, while complex operations and diverse skill systems, which require familiarity with precise strategies and continuous long-term operations in multiplayer battles, will not be favored by these players over 40 years old. Therefore, this simple Korean-style operation method has become a representative feature of Lineage. This very strong preference has formed a fixed model in the Korean market, and the hunting gameplay can obtain effective returns in a low-cost way, which also meets their needs.

Android Revenue Accounts for More Than 70%

The paid platforms for Korean mobile games are Google Play, App Store, and One Store, with revenue shares of 73.8%, 11.8%, and 14.8%, respectively. The proportion of the Google Play platform is relatively high, which is related to the high popularity of Android system phones. In the Korean mobile phone operating system market in 2021, the Android system accounted for 72.6%, and the IOS system accounted for 27.1%.

 

Monopoly of Top Games

In 2021, the games ranked in the top ten in sales accounted for 50% of the Top 100. Similar to the Chinese market, there is a phenomenon of monopoly of top games.

 

5. Localization Suggestions

Game Art Style and Picture Quality

Most Korean game players prefer European and American realistic, fantasy, Nordic and other styles. Many Korean players will directly give up experiencing the game because of the game style. Therefore, game manufacturers need to consider the audience of the game style when going overseas to Korea. Game picture quality has a greater impact on Korean players. In the MMORPG mobile game player game experience survey, the demand for “high-quality pictures” is much higher than other options, accounting for 30.4%, diverse gameplay accounts for 15%, and fast and simple experience accounts for 13.7%.

 

Text

Korean game players have higher requirements for the text in the game. Players will point out typos, machine translations, and system display errors in the game, and will also evaluate the character names and plot translations. If the game is released globally, there will be communication and interaction between overseas players. Character names also need to consider the communication problems of players from various countries in the game, and try to ensure consistency. At the same time, it is also necessary to consider local cultural customs, holidays, etc. If you want to succeed in the Korean game market, improving the overall translation quality is also an indispensable link.

UI Section

Compared with Chinese games, most Korean game UI interfaces are relatively simpler. Therefore, when entering the Korean market, the UI interface can be appropriately simplified and optimized, which may be more in line with the gaming habits of Korean users.

 

《Odin: Valhalla Rising》 Skill Interface

 

《Odin: Valhalla Rising》 Game Interface

Loading Interface

In Korean games, the loading interface often contains game-related teaching, guidance, tips and other explanatory content, including world view, system, partners, enhancement, skills, PVP, combat and other skills related content. Adjusting the loading interface can help players better experience the game.

 

6. Conclusion

The Korean game market has an extremely important position in the world, and it has also become one of the regions that Chinese game manufacturers must focus on when going overseas. However, it has very unique features in terms of game categories, player preferences, player portraits, and localization. Therefore, when considering going overseas to Korea and Korean localization, you can investigate the prospects of overseas game categories, player preferences, etc. in advance to lay the foundation for successful distribution in Korea.

entry.title: It's 2022, are People Still Interested in Large-Scale Guild Wars?
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

The “Territory War” in games might remind people of national warfare at first glance. In this era that increasingly values personalization, exploration, creative fun, and the rise of the ACG (Anime, Comics, and Games) subculture, this type of gameplay sounds like something popular in the last decade. So, are people still interested in this kind of gameplay that emphasizes strong organization and weak individual play?

Territory War, or what everyone calls “national warfare,” is not a fixed concept. It is a general term for large-scale multiplayer online PK activities. In the early days, most of these types of gameplay used the “nation (server)/city-state” in the game as the participating unit. Over time, “national warfare” has become synonymous with this type of gameplay.

In the current game market, such activities often appear in MMORPG games. Their manifestation is often in the form of guilds. Some games also have an alliance/faction level above the guild, and they compete for territory/land. Occupying territories of different levels will bring different rewards to their guilds and affiliated factions.

1. Characteristics of Territory War

There is a public war zone map with different areas that can be attacked.

The basic purpose of Territory War gameplay is to occupy territories/cities/attack and defense points to obtain their corresponding rewards (or points to exchange for rewards). The final reward content is generally high-value development props, or even gameplay-exclusive numerical props.

 

“Revelation M” Territory War map, the whole server competes for 3 main territories + 8 small territories

 

“Justice Online Mobile” Heaven and Earth Board Game map, 8 guilds on one map compete for 1 level 4 main city

Some games have multiple different attack and defense points in each area, and each point has offensive significance; some have only one battlefield in an area. Different games have different map designs and their corresponding point occupation rules. Relatively speaking, the fewer the battlefields, the more groups competing in a single battlefield, the higher the density of combat personnel on the same screen, and the more intense the battle.

 

In “Revelation M”, when the player’s guild attacks the Praying Temple, the attacked guild gathers and presses on the Zulong Seal platform, and nearly 300 people from both sides fight on the platform.

The guild is the smallest unit of participation.

Territory War takes the guild as the smallest unit of participation. Individuals/fixed teams and other smaller player units cannot participate. Some games also have an alliance/faction level above the guild. The degree of reward sharing and reward value within the faction are different, which will affect the loose-tight organization of different guilds within the faction, which also creates different territory war ecologies.

Taking Revelation M as an example, the smallest participating unit in the Territory War is the guild. Each guild must choose its own faction. Within the faction, they cannot attack each other or attack the territories they have occupied. The battle results between guilds in the faction are not shared. Instead, factions need to compete for faction rankings. The guild ranked first in the faction can become the alliance leader guild, and the alliance leader guild can receive an additional alliance leader guild reward (high value).

The degree of reward sharing among guilds in the same faction is not high, and there is also a competitive relationship for high-value rewards. Therefore, in Revelation M, there is often no atmosphere of sharing a common hatred within the same faction. The core of the game is still the ecology of expansion and competition with the guild as the unit. And there will not necessarily be mutual help within the same faction. In some cases, there will also be spies sent by enemy guilds within the faction (after the enemy robs the guild’s territory, the spies will plant flags. Because the territory of the same faction guild cannot be robbed, this method is used to encroach on the guild’s territory) .

 

Image source: NetEase大神-天谕手游攻略组

There is a certain tactical space, not only requiring combat skills.

Looking at the above two points alone, you may think that Territory War is to add guild units to the battlefield, or a PLUS version of the guild league with a larger map and allowing more people to participate. The difference in experience from these two is that Territory War has greater tactical space. Compared with ordinary team battles (leagues or wild team PK), it pays more attention to how to deploy troops. Due to the complex terrain and diverse mechanisms of Territory War, in addition to combat skills, it is also necessary to consider whether to choose feint attacks, lure the enemy, or other large-scale overall tactics.

Taking the Revelation M Territory War mechanism as an example, it may be easier for everyone to feel what this tactical space refers to.

[Map mechanism] There are a total of 3 large strongholds and 8 small strongholds in the gameplay. Each stronghold can accommodate up to 300 people from the same faction. After a player dies 6 times in a stronghold, he will be resurrected outside the stronghold. Specifically, each stronghold has its own running route. Different entrances, the location of the opponent’s large group, whether the Zulong Seal platform is currently stationed, predicting where the opponent may intercept our attack on the road, and how to divide the troops to outflank will also have different effects.

Take the large point of East Sea Barrier as an example. There are 4 entrances. There are 5 common attack routes, and each route has its own characteristics. For example, the back door has the shortest running distance to the platform, but from the back door to the Right Tower Square is a long slope. If the opponent charges from top to bottom, the large group here is likely to be directly killed 6 times by the opponent before gathering.

 

 

Overhead view of East Sea Barrier and the back door route of East Sea. It takes 1 minute to teleport from the back door to Zulong Seal. Successfully occupying the area means planting the guild’s Zulong Seal in the center

Due to the running map and map restrictions, in the game, who is currently occupying each stronghold, whether their main force is stationed in the stronghold, which stronghold the guild chooses to attack, whether it is a small team stealing points or a large group pressing, whether it is violent output frontal pressure or tactical flanking raid Zulong Seal, predicting the number of resurrections of the opponent’s main force during the stalemate, etc., are all variables that need to be considered.

[Dispatch mechanism] In addition, the gameplay also has a matching dispatch mechanism, which allows tactics to play more tricks:

  • Vanguard mechanism, the vanguard can transform into a mecha, and the mecha can greatly increase the damage of Zulong Seal, increasing the breakthrough power for stealing seals.
  • Unified command mechanism, unified command can use the guild-wide map summoning skill to quickly gather all guild members around the unified command (skill CD is 5 minutes)
  • Alliance leader mechanism, the guild with the highest guild contribution in the same faction will become the alliance leader guild, and the president can use the alliance leader skill to summon members of this faction to teleport to his side.

If your guild is the alliance leader guild, then you have two mechanisms: unified command summoning and alliance leader summoning. At the same time, the actual commander of the Territory War does not need to be the unified command or the president. Therefore, in actual combat, it is often the commander who contacts the scouts on a single line, and according to the intelligence given by the scouts, contacts the current person in charge of unified command and president on a single line, and asks them to hide in a certain position in the stronghold according to the situation, and pull the summoning at a critical moment to carry out a surprise attack. Here, there can be N kinds of strategy combinations.

2. What Unique Fun Does Tactical Space Bring to Territory War?

Tactical space gives players a high degree of freedom in strategic experience. This sense of game allows players to deeply understand the “pleasure of fighting with people.”

Next, I will review a Territory War that I once watched, which may make everyone feel the high degree of freedom in the Territory War.

In this battle, the UP master was at a disadvantage. The combat power level of both sides can be roughly understood as: enemy guild > our guild (the UP master’s guild is hereinafter referred to as “our side”) > enemy’s second guild. Since a guild can only occupy one large point, there are 10 minutes left before the end of the Territory War at this time. The enemy guild and the enemy’s second guild are in the same faction, each occupying a large point. Previously, our guild had launched attacks on both large points, but they were defeated by the enemy’s large group and could not be captured. Our commander speculated that the enemy should adopt a guaranteed tactic and leave a summoner in both large points. Based on this speculation, our commander started a feint in the last 10 minutes.

① Our side pretended to give up the large point and gathered a large group to attack the small point, attracting some of the opponent’s main force to interfere, deliberately receiving the summon in front of the opponent, so that the opponent found that we were going to sneak attack the Praying Temple.

② According to the terrain characteristics of the Praying Temple’s long tunnel, our commander predicted that the opponent would pull the order back to defend after being attacked. As expected, the enemy urgently pulled the summon back to defend, successfully defrauding the opponent’s summon CD here.

 

Overhead view of the Praying Temple, the tunnel is long, and it takes about 2-3 minutes to actually run to the center point

③ Our commander asked everyone to switch to the back door of East Sea Barrier, and used the advantage of the back door of East Sea Barrier to run to the location, quickly pushing to the place where Zulong Seal was located, deceiving the opponent’s large group to leave the Praying Temple.

④ At this time, there were 4 minutes left before the end of the Territory War. Our side once again pulled the summon next to the Zulong Seal of the Praying Temple. Using the time difference that the opponent’s large group needed to run through the tunnel to defend, the occupation of the Praying Temple was completed. At this time, the activity was nearing its end, and it was too late for the opponent to arrive and destroy our Zulong Seal.

 

Under the multi-layered operation of the commander, the UP master side completed the reversal of winning more with less when the overall strength was weaker than the opponent. Compared with leagues and large group battles, the unique tactical space of Territory War can provide a high degree of freedom in strategic experience. This sense of game also makes players deeply understand the “pleasure of fighting with people.” Of course, this also requires higher capabilities of the Territory War commander. If the command is not good and the tactics are not good, many players feel that they “don’t know what they are doing throughout the whole process.”

The militarized participation experience, the close cooperation of participants to complete a goal, allows players to not only experience the fun of “killing” in the gameplay, but also have a strong sense of belonging and collective honor.

In the entire Territory War participation process, the organization within the guild is relatively tight, and each member has their own tasks throughout the process. Members with special tasks contact the commander privately by voice and private messages, and members without special tasks receive unified dispatch. The premise that tactics can be implemented well and played beautifully is the cooperation between various units, which is obedience and efficient response to each player.

 

In actual Territory War, because there will always be undercover agents mixed in the group to inquire about information, the commander will hardly tell everyone the overall tactics on the microphone, nor will he reveal the analysis in his mind. He will only give clear instructions on what to do at present according to the current judgment. This kind of high-confrontation pressure situation will make all participants unconsciously and actively obey the instructions, not question the received instructions, but just try their best to execute them. In this process, players with a high degree of cooperation will automatically internalize the goals of the commander/guild management into one of their own goals for participating in the activity. In addition to relying on social interaction, common interests, and common experiences to unite team members, the guild also adds a strong buff of “common goals.”

“Everyone has their own tasks” allows players to confirm that they are part of the organization. “High obedience in confrontational pressure situations” weakens players’ self-perception. The two interact with each other, allowing players to consciously or unconsciously form “common goals” with the collective. The three together strengthen players’ sense of belonging to the collective. In this process, players strive to achieve common goals, make contributions, and even make some sacrifices (investing more time and money) also make them feel their moral emotions of fulfilling obligations, making contributions, and striving for honor for the collective, which is what we often call collective honor.

3. Will Young Players Still be Interested in this Old-fashioned Gameplay?

High strategy and militarized participation experience, these features that sound both heavy and impersonal, are indeed significantly different from the fun of self-expression, creation, and exploration that young people pursue, which is often mentioned in mainstream media. However, in actual research, we found that although the age distribution of players who like team battles is indeed older than that of players who prefer exploration/high degree of freedom, if you look at the proportion, there are still many young players who are interested in team battles.

 

In a certain survey of a certain game, the distribution of players who claimed to like large-scale team battle PK, competitive operations, and exploration.

We found something when doing related research. Many players who like Territory War are not interested in this kind of large-scale team battle at first. The less intuitive fun brought by this complex mechanism often makes them feel good after experiencing it. After experiencing intense, difficult, or reversed team battles, new players experience high-energy moments with clear goals and intense battles. In order to repeat this high-energy experience, they may gradually develop a preference for team battles. We speculate that it is very likely that the fun experience of this type of gameplay is more difficult to experience and verify in life than the fun of plots, dressing up, and puzzle solving, which are relatively easy to feel and judge whether you like them in real life.

 

4. Summary

Territory War is a form of large-scale team battle in MMORPG. Compared with regular team battles such as leagues, large-scale team battles such as Territory War have richer map mechanisms and dispatch mechanisms, bringing additional tactical space to the gameplay. It is this relatively rich tactical space that gives players differentiated fun content:

① The high degree of freedom in strategic experience allows players to deeply understand the “pleasure of fighting with people.”

② The close cooperation of each participant in the gameplay to complete a goal allows players to have a stronger sense of belonging and gives rise to a sense of collective honor.

entry.title: What Exactly Do Players Mean by "Grindy"? – An Analysis of "Grind" from the Perspective of Time Perception
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

“Grindy” is the most common complaint players have about games. Every player has a few memes in their phone complaining about how grindy a game is. Although players resonate so much with the topic of “grind”, what exactly do they mean by grind? Are they even talking about the same thing? Is grind simply referring to the length of time spent playing the game? Is it an objective time consumption or is it mixed with the influence of subjective perception? When developers receive feedback from players that “the game is too grindy”, they often fall into the dilemma of whether to modify the gameplay time. It seems that once players complain about grind, there are only two options: stick to it or shorten the time. This article will reveal the truth of “grind” from a psychological perspective.

1. Who is Fluctuating the Player’s Inner Clock?

Introduction to Time Perception and Factors Affecting Time Perception

“Grind” (肝 - gān) refers to spending a lot of time and energy playing games, and it gets its name from the fact that staying up late is bad for the liver. There is also a rumor that a certain old brother stayed up late playing games and eventually developed liver cirrhosis, and his friends in the game joked that he should pay attention to his liver. Before analyzing the problem of “grind”, we must first understand how time is perceived.

 

Time perception refers to our cognition of the duration and sequence of objective things and events. Unlike sight, hearing, touch and other senses, humans do not have specific organs to perceive time, and time perception is not a function of a single sensory channel. In other words, time perception is actually a subjective perception of people, a process of integrating fragments of the surrounding environment in an “appropriate way”.

Psychological theory believes that people judge the length of time based on two factors: external and internal. External factors include the rising and setting of the sun, the alternation of day and night, and timing tools; internal factors are the physiological and psychological activities of the human body, and the regular activities of the body can also be used as a basis for people to perceive time, such as the biological clock.

But the clock in people’s hearts is often not consistent with the real time, that is, a time illusion occurs. To give a simple example, with the same two hours, when you play a game you like, you will feel that time flies by, and you may even miss dinner; but if you watch a bad movie, you will feel that every minute is like sitting on pins and needles.

So what factors affect time perception?

Studies have shown that emotions, attention, personal interests and life experiences, and the amount of event content all affect time perception. In general, ① when people are in a relaxed and happy mood, they will estimate the time to be shorter, but when they are in a state of anxiety, anger, and pain, they will estimate the time to be longer; ② when people face things they are interested in, they will feel that time passes quickly, and when they face things they are not interested in, they will feel that time passes slowly; ③ when people are fully engaged in something, they will forget the passage of time, but if attention is focused on time information, you will feel like a day is like a year; ④ within a certain period of time, the more and richer the number of things that happen, the more complex the nature, people tend to estimate the time to be shorter; and when facing fewer things and the simpler the nature, people tend to estimate the time to be longer. In addition, vision is more susceptible to external influences than hearing, etc., and is less accurate in judging time.

2. Common Misconceptions about “Grind”

Grindy games do not equal games that take a long time

Back to the question of grind, we already know that time perception is not equal to actual physical time, and “grind” is a kind of subjective time perception of players, so when players say “the game is grindy”, it does not necessarily mean that the game actually takes a long time, but “I think” it takes a long time.

However, in the actual game development process, developers tend to equate grind with long time consumption. It seems that shortening the length of the gameplay can alleviate players’ complaints, but this is actually a mistake of “treating the symptoms but not the root cause”. For example, a certain MMORPG has been operating for many years, and its daily guaranteed tasks have always been criticized by players as being too time-consuming. At this time, how should the game user researcher conduct follow-up research? The conventional idea is that we will find players and break down which part of which gameplay players think is time-consuming, what kind of optimization players want, and what is the maximum length of time they can accept. But this plan actually ignores one point - in the past few years of the game’s operation, the daily time has not become longer, and may even have become shorter, so even if the gameplay is further shortened, the negative feedback cannot be solved from the root. The background of players’ complaints about long time consumption is that they have been playing this gameplay repeatedly for several years, and they no longer need any thinking or operation. The real problem of long time consumption does not point to time, but to the above-mentioned “simple stimulus events, decreased interest, and attention focused on time information”.

3. What Kind of Grind are Players Talking About?

How should we understand it? Analysis of several types of grind

Precisely because time perception is affected by a variety of factors, different players’ feedback on “grind” often has different reasons, so the “grind” that everyone complains about may not be the same thing at all! Players often express “grind” in these forms:

“I’ve been running back and forth, can’t there be a means of transportation? I feel like I’m wasting my time.”

“There are twenty daily tasks, and some of them are only open for a limited time. I have to keep watch at a fixed time. It’s too time-consuming.”

“Each round I have to fight five waves of the same mobs, it’s very boring. After finishing one wave, I have to wait for the next wave. Can this task be canceled?”

“There are many weapons that haven’t been collected yet, and hidden side quests that haven’t been unlocked. These really take time.”

“This game is so grindy, I keep saying ‘one more turn and then I’ll go to sleep’, and then the sun comes up.”

……

 

Some of these feedbacks need to be brought to the attention of developers, while others may not constitute a serious problem.

(1) The first kind of feedback points to the problem of repeating an operation, which is then perceived as a meaningless waste of time. This is the “grind” that players most often criticize. Studies have shown that repetition can improve people’s fluency in processing information, but when it reaches extremely fluency, people will start to get bored. The negative emotions of boredom will further stretch people’s perceived length of time. Therefore, even if the time is actually shortened due to increased proficiency, people will feel that it takes longer. Interestingly, a large number of repetitions in a short period of time will cause boredom and fatigue, but long-term repetition will not. This may explain why weekly dungeons are not often criticized by players, but repeating 30 daily loops at a time is strongly rejected by some people.

(2) It is worth noting in the second feedback that if the rules, output, or progress of the task are uncertain, and players cannot predict or control the time consumption, it is easy to feel grindy in the waiting. For example, in game matching, if only the matching is prompted, but there is no specific upper limit of the matching time, players are more likely to perceive the matching time as long. In the newly launched gameplay, if there is no clear explanation of each stage and progress of the gameplay, players are also more likely to feel that they have nothing to do, and then quit the gameplay midway.

(3) In the third feedback, “very boring” indicates that the gameplay content may not have aroused the player’s interest. When players face gameplay that they are not interested in but have to do for rewards, they are more likely to feel that the task takes a long time. When not interested, players’ attention to the task is also easily focused on time information, that is, how long the task will take and how long it will take me to complete it, rather than on the task itself, which will further lengthen the player’s time perception.

“Each round I have to fight five waves of the same mobs” suggests that the task itself is relatively simple, and the operational difficulty for players is also low. When facing a small number of simple things, people will also estimate the time to be longer, which creates the illusion of “too grindy”.

Finally, “after finishing one wave, I have to wait for the next wave” implies that players may lack other interactive content during the waiting period, and are therefore more likely to focus on the waiting time.

(4) For the fourth and fifth feedbacks, although players also feedback grind, it is more of a grind that players actively choose, which does not necessarily represent negative feedback. For example, sandbox games and simulation management games are also often said to be “grindy” by players, but players often choose to grind with a certain purpose, which can be said to be concentrating on grinding; some outstanding games can also attract players to start a second playthrough, or fight the same boss hundreds or thousands of times. Therefore, even repetitive content can avoid the problem of “grind” if it can give players a slightly different experience each time or guide players to establish different goals at different stages.

 

4. How to Alleviate Players’ Time Illusion

Some psychological inspirations

Regardless of the real grind caused by game design problems, how can we alleviate the grind caused by time illusion?

Players’ time perception is affected by both individual factors and environmental factors. Individual factors such as emotions and interests are not easy to control in actual development, and the specific situation varies, but in terms of environmental factors, we can still get some inspiration from psychology.

  1. Don’t let players wait foolishly. Appropriate distraction will be better.

Just as waiting for someone is a torment, waiting for game loading is also a torment. Providing some engaging TV programs, newspapers and other content during the waiting process can distract people from the waiting time, thereby reducing their perceived waiting time. Similarly, filling the loading, matching and other waiting interfaces of the game with some interesting content can also achieve the same effect. It should be noted that studies have shown that different fillers have different effects on the perception of waiting time. If the filler cannot attract people, it will not only fail to reduce their perceived waiting time, but will also have the opposite effect.

  1. Strengthen prompts and feedback on the status to reduce uncertainty.

Specifically, it is to give clear feedback on all status information, including waiting time, so that players can clearly know what processes are still to come and the estimated time of each process. Life experience tells us that waiting before the agreed time will not make us emotionally volatile, but every minute of being late makes people irritable. Psychologists have proposed that people feel that the uncertain waiting time is longer than the definite waiting time. If they know nothing about the relevant information of the waiting time, they will perceive the time to be longer than the actual time, and vice versa.

  1. Consider enriching the player’s psychological experience.

As mentioned above, within a certain period of time, the more and richer the number of things that happen, the more complex the nature, people tend to estimate the time to be shorter, which suggests that we need to provide players with more and richer game content. But it should be noted that these contents need to be able to enrich the player’s psychological experience rather than increase the player’s cognitive burden, that is to say, a complicated interface cannot achieve the same effect. Too much and complicated interface information may cause confusion to players, making them feel that it takes longer by reducing their sense of control; it may also directly trigger players’ negative emotions, thinking that the product looks very “grindy”.

entry.title: Behind the Highly-Rated Games with Widespread Negative Reviews - Why Can't Game Reviews Satisfy Players?
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

In the 1980s, early game media appeared in the players’ field of vision in the form of newspapers and magazines. At that time, game players had a single source of information and did not have a good opportunity to voice their opinions. Game media reviews of games largely influenced players’ game choices. With the rise of the Internet and modern social platforms, players have more information channels and can freely express their opinions on the Internet or game platforms. As a result, more and more players find that those highly-rated games often fail to bring them a good gaming experience. Where is the problem with the loss of “discourse power” in media reviews?

1. Starting with the Failure of Deathloop

On Black Friday 2021, Deathloop, which had just been released for two months, started its 50% discount, ruthlessly backstabbing the pre-order players who mocked themselves as “stupid and rich”.

For game manufacturers, it is not a good thing to start a large discount too early. Because it not only hurts the hearts of those pre-order players (they are often the core fans of the game), but also reveals a dangerous signal: game sales may have begun to weaken, and the number of active players is at stake.

Deathloop‘s current state is pretty much like this.

When the media review embargo was lifted on September 13, Deathloop was in the limelight. Metacritic media score was 88, and two major media outlets, IGN and GameSpot, gave full marks. Many media outlets were full of praise. However, after the game was officially released, many players found that the game was not as good as the media described. Frequent game crashes, endless annoying bugs, poor PC optimization, and an anti-cheat mechanism that was almost non-existent made the game’s advantages in level design and art style disappear - after all, if the game cannot even be entered, who cares how amazing your level design is?

Angry players expressed their dissatisfaction with the game with ratings and sales: Metacritic player score 4.8, mostly positive on Steam, forming a sharp contrast with previous media reviews. The game only briefly topped the Steam weekly sales chart based on initial media reviews, and then quickly “faded into obscurity”. The number of daily active players also dropped from the initial 20,000+ to less than 2,000 now.

 

As of December 1, Deathloop’s Metacritic media score was 86, and the player score was 4.8

2. Where is the Disagreement?

The problems encountered by Deathloop are not an isolated phenomenon. The divergence between media reviews and player experience has long been evident. However, in previous years, most of the hardest-hit areas were concentrated in some annual games, such as FIFA or NBA2K. What really detonated the confrontation between players and the media was a tragedy caused by a golf club. Since then, the crisis of confidence between media ratings and player experience has intensified. “Trust the media for low scores, trust yourself for high scores”, “IGN, even dogs don’t watch it”, “Famitsu? Paid-tsu!”, more and more players use such simple and crude sentences to directly express their dissatisfaction with media reviews.

The loss of credibility of game media is ultimately due to the inherent limitations of its evaluation mechanism. Long-term operation of the game, performance problems, and paid in-app purchases are often the points of divergence between media reviews and player experience.

Long-term Operation: “Five Years of Sharpening a Sword”

Media evaluates the basic quality of the game at the time of release, that is, the short-term experience, while the player’s evaluation runs through the entire life cycle, that is, it also includes the long-term operating experience.

Most of the current game ratings are based on the media review version submitted一段时间 before the game is released. However, players’ experience of the game will run through the entire life cycle of the game, especially for some long-term online games. Therefore, the later operation of the game is also an important part of the player’s game experience.

There are not a few games that have good basic qualities but are dragged down by subsequent operations, such as Battlefield 5 (meta score 81, player score 2.9), which has stopped updating. Of course, there are also games that have made a beautiful comeback with the subsequent operation of the game. The most well-known to players should be No Man’s Sky, which was full of negative reviews when it was just released, with an MC score of only 61. Highly repetitive gameplay, incomplete game completion, and deceptive marketing made this game fall to the bottom in terms of both player reviews and media reviews when it was just released. However, after five years of consistent free updates, the problems that the developer promised to solve have been solved as scheduled. Looking back at No Man’s Sky now, it may be difficult to imagine that this now “overwhelmingly positive” game was once mockingly called “No Man’s Hole” by domestic players.

 

《No Man’s Sky》 From Mostly Negative reviews in the early days to Overwhelmingly Positive reviews now

Performance Issues: 2077 Bugs

When Cyberpunk 2077 was just released in 2020, at least half of the negative reviews of the game were focused on the game’s bugs and optimization problems. And Cyberpunk 2077 was also “kindly” called “Cyberbug 2077” by players because of the numerous bugs. If the PC version only had a lot of bugs, then the console version was not like a finished game at all. A large number of frame drops, crashes, and texture problems caused a large number of players to request refunds just one week after the game was released, and it was even directly removed from the PS store. However, interestingly, such frequent and serious bugs did not significantly affect the media’s evaluation of 2077. When 2077’s media score was first lifted, it once won a high score of MC91.

Perhaps for game media, the occurrence of game bugs is understandable, but for players, a smooth game flow is obviously an important part of their game experience.

The media may not want to ignore the deeper design concept and subsequent development potential of the game because of game bugs. But as with the same problems encountered by Deathloop, no one likes to have 2077 bugs in their game, nor do they like to play a crash loop. The huge impact of these problems on the player’s game experience cannot be saved by excellent game design.

Buy-to-Play In-App Purchases: “Pay to Win”?

The media’s tolerance for buy-to-play in-app purchases is often higher than that of players.

Middle-earth: Shadow of War, published by Warner, was obviously not significantly affected by the microtransaction system in the game in terms of media ratings. However, this work, which scored 90 points on IGN and an average MC score of 75 points (the MC score was once above 85 points when it was just released), still aroused the anger of players (MC player score 4.2) due to its microtransaction system, forcing the game to remove the in-app purchase system a few months later.

The buy-to-play + in-app purchase payment model is not uncommon in recent years. Overwatch and Naraka: Bladepoint are all such payment models. For the media, the bottom line of in-app purchases is often that they do not seriously affect the game balance. Adding some in-app purchase elements to a single-player buy-to-play game cannot be an important factor in giving the game a low score. At most, a few points will be deducted to discourage this form. But for players, just not affecting the game balance cannot be a death-free gold medal for buy-to-play in-app purchases. Any in-app purchases that “pay to win” and increase the game’s grind to force purchases are likely to arouse players’ anger. Therefore, even for games like Middle-earth, which are biased towards single-player, it is difficult for players to accept paying to quickly improve their strength, let alone those games that focus on online play and can be “pay to win” to some extent (such as Star Wars: Battlefront II).

 

 

*On the game review website Metacritic, players’ criticism of the microtransaction system in Middle-earth

3. Lessons from Others

Game media is not unaware of this problem. For example, IGN will re-modify the previous evaluation after a major game update. However, if you want to truly fit the player’s game experience, future game media may need to be more “UX” oriented: listen to more feedback from test players, rather than relying solely on a few senior editors; give higher evaluation weight to player experience-oriented content, rather than just mentioning it briefly; adopt long-term tracking-style scoring research, rather than “stopping at the point” when it is released. Then perhaps the crisis of confidence between players and the media is not an unsolvable problem.

For User Research, the following points need to be achieved:

  1. While paying attention to the basic quality of the game, attach importance to the long-term operation of the game;

  2. Consider how to help the game establish a more agile and systematic performance problem early warning mechanism;

  3. Explore payment methods that players can accept.

This is also a lesson from the crisis of confidence between media and players.

entry.title: Secrets Hidden Beyond Words: Non-Textual Information Guidance Design in Puzzle Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

1. About Puzzle Games and Non-Textual Information Guidance

More than ten years ago, on a summer afternoon, in an era when smartphones were not yet popular, when I opened the 4399 webpage, ready to switch games with a large piece of watermelon, a game called the Baby Escape series came into my sight. I didn’t know that it would open the door to puzzle games.

After that, there were countless masterpieces under the label of “puzzle”, such as the Rusty Lake series with wonderful plots and hardcore puzzle elements, or Gris with a romantic and ethereal artistic atmosphere, or Her Story with novel and interesting interactive ideas. But whenever I mention puzzle games, I still can’t forget the small game I played on the webpage many years ago. In one brain hole after another, I played as a baby chasing food, going to heaven and earth, and finally came to a strange planet and became friends with a robot who loves nature. The charm of puzzle games is nothing more than this: set out with a goal, feel satisfied in solving one obstacle after another, and finally understand the meaning of this world and reach the end of the plot.

Elements of Puzzle Games

Although the definition of puzzle games is very broad, so broad that many game producers believe that as long as some puzzle-solving gameplay is forcibly inserted into the game, a “puzzle” tag can be added after the work tag, and players who prefer puzzle games will be included in the user portrait range. However, this is not the case. Although puzzle-solving is a classic and versatile seasoning in games, it is mostly a side dish to exquisite meals, bringing higher playability to the game, but it also has its own unique design points.

From the perspective of experience design, we can disassemble the elements of a puzzle game as follows.

First is the purpose of the puzzle, that is, the task set by the puzzle for the player, and the player’s motivation to complete the puzzle. For example, in the first part of the Baby Escape series, the player plays a baby who enters a variety of scenes because he is chasing a squirrel that has snatched snacks. At this time, the player’s motivation or ultimate goal to complete the puzzle is to catch up with the squirrel and get the snacks back, and the task set by the puzzle at hand is to escape the current scene. In classic puzzle games with the theme of escape rooms, even without too much plot development, escaping from a closed room is a natural task and motivation, and this setting gives the puzzle solving a natural necessity. But to make a deep impression on players and make the game full of charm, it is necessary to form the player’s internal driving force with the worldview and storyline.

Then there are the metaphors contained in the puzzle itself and the shaping of the worldview.

The game form brings a new sense of immersion and multi-sensory experience, which complements the nature of the puzzle itself as a carrier of stories and metaphors, and together constitutes the charm of puzzle games. In the third part of Baby Escape, the baby comes to outer space in order to retrieve snacks, and accidentally discovers a robot planet enslaved by the Slime King. When solving puzzles in the robot’s spaceship, you can find that there are green plants and insect drawings on the portholes of the spaceship, which shows that the robots yearn for a life full of vitality and attach great importance to the ecology and environment. But when players come to the planet where the robots live, they find that it is desolate and silent. Perhaps their former home was as green as the earth, but it became desolate and dilapidated after being plundered and mined by the Slime King.

Finally, there is the player’s puzzle-solving process, which is where interaction designers and game designers shine. How to let players of different intelligence and different game experience maximize their thinking potential in the whole puzzle-solving process without getting stuck is also what designers need to do through the ingenuity of interaction design. The process of player puzzle solving can be summarized as follows:

Non-Textual Information Guidance and Unconscious Design

When designers expect players to perform corresponding operations in the game, they often need appropriate guidance. The essence of puzzle games is “solving problems with unknown answers through known elements in the game”. This process requires players to understand the basic mechanism of the game, collect and process necessary information, and finally solve the corresponding puzzles. For a specific puzzle-solving path, different guidance methods bring completely different sense of achievement and immersion to players.

Although textual information guidance is clear and definite, when it appears in large quantities, the gameplay and immersion experience will inevitably be destroyed, and it may even give players a feeling of “you are teaching me to play games”. Non-textual information can often be well hidden in the game environment, integrated with the background setting, and allow players to naturally perform interactive behaviors. The essence of non-textual information guidance is similar to the “unconscious design” proposed by designer Naoto Fukasawa. He believes that design should pay attention to these unconscious behaviors and transform them into visible things, which can make the design more suitable for human behavior and can be operated intuitively.

2. Design Points of Non-Textual Information Guidance in Various Elements

Puzzle Purpose: Design of Big Goals and Small Goals

Here, the big goal refers to what the puzzle is ultimately for, which is related to whether the player has sufficient motivation to complete the entire puzzle-solving process, and can keep track of their puzzle-solving progress at any time. For puzzle games with long-term processes, it is very important to let players perceive their game progress at any time, which is conducive to reducing the player’s psychology of giving up halfway in the game.

In the game Gris, at the beginning of the first playthrough, the statue collapses, the world loses its color and becomes gray, and Gris also loses the ability to sing. During the whole puzzle-solving adventure, the player gradually restores the world to life through continuous exploration. As the watercolor spreads between the sky and the plaster statue, the player’s heart is also filled with color. The game uses the acquisition of color to reflect the division between large levels and to hint at the progress towards the ending. While being shocked, players are also deeply attracted and driven by the change of color rhythm of this scene art.

The small goal refers to the task set by the puzzle in the current scene. Players in puzzle games often have questions such as “Who am I”, “Where am I”, and “What should I do”. Whether the goal can be clearly presented to the player largely determines the player’s game experience. When the puzzle lacks the guidance of the presentation of a small goal, players are likely to feel confused and get stuck.

There are many large-scale puzzles in Gris. When the overall presentation of the puzzle exceeds the screen limit, with the forced zooming out of the camera, the player can see the whole picture of the entire puzzle at the first time, so as to form an estimation and thinking about the puzzle-solving purpose and puzzle-solving path of the entire scene in their minds.

The Puzzle Itself: High-Quality Metaphor of Core Gameplay

The puzzle of Gorogoa is mainly based on graphic interaction, and there are almost no readable words in the game. The Chinese translation of this game is “Picture World”, which tells the story of a little boy who discovers a beautiful and huge mysterious creature outside the window, and thus embarks on a journey to find this mysterious creature. The strongest experience that this game brings to players is different from the traditional puzzle-solving gameplay, but focuses on the interaction of picture frames and the dual meaning of the same picture, which also constitutes the basis of the game’s core gameplay and content performance.

The producer, Jason Roberts, felt the narrative tension of a single picture from the book “Fourteen Strange Pictures and Fourteen Stories”, and realized from the illustrations that multi-picture narratives can constitute a richer game world. So he set the core gameplay as the interaction of picture frames and the narrative presentation of multiple pictures.

Picture frames and multiple pictures carry very important meanings in the game.

When players first get started with this game, they will naturally superimpose, split, or splice picture frames. Each operation can bring unexpected surprises. The splicing of multiple pictures will naturally make players want to piece together different stories by adjusting their order, and the mystery brought by the picture frame will make players imagine things outside the picture frame and desire to escape from the picture frame. The dual meaning of objects, as the basis for the splicing of picture frames, fully embodies the key to “fantasy mysticism” and mobilizes players’ desire for knowledge from small objects to the big world. Under the design of this high-quality metaphor, all puzzles no longer seem to be deliberately designed by the designer, as if they are an organic part of that world.

Puzzle-Solving Process: How to Let Players Solve Puzzles Naturally

(1) Establishment of Common Sense and Rules

For puzzle games, the mechanism and methods of exploring the world and puzzles can be roughly divided into two types: special puzzle-solving rules and general puzzle-solving rules. For the former, they are generally special interaction methods designed by designers based on the story background of the game. For example, in the game Carto, the core of puzzle-solving throughout is the map mechanism similar to a jigsaw puzzle: the explorable area is a map block, and players can splice and rotate them at will, as long as the edges can be aligned. When a specific map combination is spelled out through plot hints, new maps or new plot characters will appear.

How to naturally establish the game’s puzzle-solving common sense and rules in the player’s mind is a very important part of experience design. In the opening plot animation of the game, the grandmother shows Carto how she manipulates the map to affect the actual terrain changes. While the grandmother is asleep, Carto accidentally puts the map blocks of clouds and the airship together. At this time, the wind surges, Carto is blown off the airship, and thus separates from her grandmother and begins her puzzle-solving adventure story. This plot not only explains the cause and effect of the adventure, the player’s motivation and purpose of solving puzzles (exploring the world and finding the grandmother), but also cleverly paves the way for the “rules” of this world: the map can be dragged and rotated, spliced with each other, and affect the real world.

(2) Player Inertia Guidance

For those general puzzle-solving methods in puzzle games, the learning cost of players can be reduced by adopting the rules in reality or the mental model of similar games. Just like being a frequent visitor to puzzle games, we know that those loose stones will definitely have hidden paths after being stepped on and broken, and as people who live in the three-dimensional world every day, we also know that we can jump to another platform with the help of the inertia of the rope swing. The rules of reality and the established gameplay of the game improve the rationality and predictability of the puzzles, so that the game will not have too strong a sense of fragmentation.

In the hospital level of Little Nightmares 2, there is a very clever design that fits the background of the hospital: players enter a strange room, and from the X-ray film posted on the wall, they can know that they have come to a place similar to a hospital radiology department, and the key they need to find may be in the doll’s belly. Players need to drag the dolls one by one behind the X-ray machine, press the button, take X-rays for the dolls, and then take the doll with the key to the incinerator upstairs, burn the doll, and take out the key.

For players who understand the real-life rules of these items, the whole process can be easily understood without intentional guidance. For the designer, the introduction of new puzzle-solving gameplay does not increase the player’s learning cost, nor does it require too much additional guidance design, and it is cleverly combined with the story background, which is really the best of both worlds.

(3) Trial and Error and Misdirection

The guidance of puzzle games is not all positive. Interesting misdirection will sometimes make players look back at the details, explore unexpected puzzle-solving paths, and then slap their heads: “So that’s how it’s solved!”

The overall guidance design of Little Nightmares 2 is very smooth. There are many scratches visible everywhere in the game, some are used to imply the trajectory of item movement, and some are used to prompt traps falling from the sky. Most players cannot react quickly when they encounter a trap for the first time, but after trial and error, players will find that the table in front of them has obvious scratches from the trap, and when players see similar scratches again, they will be more vigilant.

In the library area of the school level of Little Nightmares 2, the chase battle with the teacher also cleverly uses the design of misdirection. When the player plays for the first time, he will pass through the library and try to go out from the side door. However, since the companion is captured at this time, the door that needs two people to push open cannot be pushed at this time. The game uses common sense to guide players to the seemingly openable door, but when the player is stuck at the door and can only let the long-necked teacher approach little by little, this inescapable horror fills the whole body, and I believe that no player will forget this death.

When the player plays for the second time, they will realize that they need to hide beside the door first, wait for the teacher to go out, and then drag the box with the help of the scratches on the floor, climb up and push open the door handle. The designer designed the misdirection point not to “punish the player”, but to make those players who do not carefully observe the scene make mistakes, so as to learn lessons and strengthen their cognition of common sense in the game.

3. Epilogue

Puzzle games are an interactive art. It needs to have natural interactive logic, a good emotional experience, and a pleasing aesthetic feeling. These three influence and achieve each other. When they are harmoniously unified, we can say that the design of this puzzle game is excellent. Gorogoa‘s author Roberts once asked himself: “What attracts me to puzzle games? I think it has something to do with the hidden structure or meaning of the world. The seemingly ordinary things in the world, if you can arrange and combine them in the right way, you can find some hidden structures. If you look at the world and don’t find any meaning, it means that you have to accept some challenges to find meaning.” And interaction designers are the people who secretly guide players to discover challenges, complete challenges, and finally piece together the secrets and meanings of the world.

entry.title: From 20 to 380? How to Do Cross-Analysis in Game User Research?
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

Questionnaire surveys are a commonly used research method in game user research, which can quickly collect data from a large sample. Although how to set up questions and how many questions to set in a questionnaire are determined by the research purpose, in general, questionnaire designers will control the number of questions to about twenty, and no more than thirty.

So, can a questionnaire with twenty items only provide twenty pieces of information? Of course not! Cross-analysis can allow a limited questionnaire to provide more information and play a greater role. From a purely mathematical point of view, two-by-two crossing of twenty questions can produce 380 results. How to use so many crosses? How to use meaningful cross-analysis in game user research to deeply understand players?

This article will briefly introduce what cross-analysis is and its application significance, and show how to do cross-analysis in game user research.

1. What is Cross-Analysis?

Cross-analysis is a basic data analysis method used to analyze the relationship between two variables. This analysis method crosses two or more indicators to find the relationship between variables and discover more data characteristics.

The following uses an example to briefly explain what cross-analysis is.

There are two questions in the in-game questionnaire of a certain game:

① Based on your recent game experience, what is your satisfaction with the game?
a. Very dissatisfied
b. Relatively dissatisfied
c. Neutral
d. Relatively satisfied
e. Very satisfied

② What is your gender?
a. Male
b. Female

A total of 200 questionnaires were collected, and the results of data statistics for each question are as follows (non-real data, not statistically significant):

Question Option 1 Option 2 Option 3 Option 4 Option 5 Total
Satisfaction with the game Very Dissat. Relatively Dissat. Neutral Relatively Sat. Very Satisfied
Number of people who chose each option 15 25 30 65 65 200
Gender Male Female
Number of people who chose each option 95 105 200

At this time, the results we can see from the data analysis are that the ratio of men to women in the game is close to 1:1, and the overall satisfaction is more than dissatisfaction. The cross-analysis result is obtained by crossing the two variables of gender and satisfaction, which is an analysis that combines these two variables.

Very Dissat. Relatively Dissat. Neutral Relatively Sat. Very Satisfied Total
Male 15 25 25 20 10 95
Female 0 0 5 45 55 105

2. The Significance of Cross-Analysis from the Perspective of “Simpson’s Paradox”

It is not difficult to find the significance of cross-analysis from the above case. The analysis of only single variables will lead to the conclusion that players are more satisfied than dissatisfied with the game, but after cross-analysis, it will be found that male players and female players have completely different evaluations of the game. Most male players are generally dissatisfied with the game, while the positive emotions of female players have pulled up the overall satisfaction level.

The significance of cross-analysis is that through this analysis method, it is possible to more clearly understand the views of different types of players/users on the game/product, and prevent the excessive integration of data from masking and losing real data.

The so-called masking and loss of real data can be more clearly perceived through “Simpson’s Paradox”.

 

We encountered “Simpson’s Paradox” when analyzing the payment rate of a certain game’s gameplay. (The following data is not real data) In this game, the payment rate of scenery-oriented players in the overall gameplay is much higher than that of appearance-oriented players, the former is 44%, and the latter is only 28%. Before concluding that “scenery-oriented players are more willing to pay in gameplay than appearance-oriented players”, we found that the payment rate of appearance-oriented players in the two gameplays that make up the game - gameplay A and gameplay B - is higher than that of scenery-oriented players.

Gameplay A Gameplay B Overall
Scenery 53% 10% 44%
Appearance 80% 15% 28%

In gameplay A, the payment rate of appearance-oriented players is 80%, which is higher than that of scenery-oriented players, which is 53%; similarly, in gameplay B, the payment rate of appearance-oriented players, 15%, is higher than that of scenery-oriented players, 10%. However, in the overall gameplay payment of the game, the payment rate of scenery-oriented players is almost twice that of appearance-oriented players.

This is a typical “Simpson’s Paradox”, where the overall trend is completely opposite to the classified trend. Why does this happen? Because from the perspective of sub-gameplay, the payment rate of gameplay A is very high (58%) and the payment rate of gameplay B is very low (14%). In this case, a large number of scenery-oriented players participated in gameplay A, while a large number of appearance-oriented players participated in gameplay B. The overall trend that does not distinguish between gameplays loses the connotation of the data and pushes the overall explanation to the other extreme.

3. How to Do Cross-Analysis in Game User Research?

Theoretically, any two variables can be crossed, and a questionnaire can get hundreds of cross-relationships, but many cross-relationships have no practical significance. In the questionnaire analysis of game user research, if you want to conduct cross-analysis, the core is actually to classify players according to different standards, and then analyze the data of different types of players. Therefore, the core of cross-analysis in game user research is how to classify players.

Combining the characteristics of game players and data, this article divides the cross-analysis classification methods of game questionnaires into three categories.

Cross-Analysis Based on Demographics

Classifying players based on demographics is the most common way. Demographic information includes gender, age, income, occupation, region, etc.

Most questionnaires will collect demographic questions at the end, and game research questionnaires are no exception. After collecting the questionnaire, conduct data analysis, gender ratio, age segment, but demographic information provides far more than that.

 

How do we use demographic information for cross-analysis in games? Gender is the most widely used in game questionnaire cross-analysis. Male players and female players show different attitudes in the choice of game types, preferences for game art styles, and pursuit of game fun. For example, in a questionnaire analysis, after classifying players by gender, it can be seen that female players pay special attention to the picture style and the pace of the game, while male players pay more attention to the game theme and the investment of money and time (ie, the cost-effectiveness of the game).

 

When investigating the media channels that players are exposed to, through cross-analysis we found that girls prefer Weibo and Xiaohongshu, while boys relatively prefer live broadcast platforms. This discovery of media contact preference inspires us to what kind of materials our game marketing should produce and on which platforms to attract players (the data does not show all options).

 

Demographic factors such as players’ age and income are also often seen in the cross-analysis of game questionnaires, but factors such as region are not common. The reason is that factors such as region are largely related to the factor of income. Using these factors for classification may not reflect the differences caused by regional culture, but the overall economic level.

Player Classification Questions Designed in the Questionnaire

In addition to the “fixed setting” demographic questions in the questionnaire, questionnaire designers can also add meaningful player classification questions when designing the questionnaire, which is convenient for cross-analysis after collecting data. We once asked players about their gaming experience in the questionnaire as a basis for distinguishing players. By comparing the channels through which MMO mobile game players and two-dimensional mobile game players receive new game information, it can be seen that MMO mobile game players receive more customer service or pushes from game companies (the data does not show all options).

 

In addition to the game experience background, we have also used multiple indicators such as player communication ability and player game level to classify players, and further analyze the attitudes of different types of players.

Classify Players According to Their In-Game Data After Questionnaire Collection

The demographic information and pre-established player classification questions mentioned above are all based on the results of the questionnaire collection to classify players.
