Game design based on meta elements does the opposite, blurring the boundaries between games and real life by breaking the illusion of the game, thus bringing strong emotional experiences to players: ordinary games pull you into the screen, while meta-games always try to crawl out of the screen.

1. The Use of Different Types and Depths of Meta Elements

Meta means breaking the concept of traditional games at some level, such as the player being the only conscious operator in the game, the game content and out-of-game computer operations not interfering with each other, the virtual world of the game not containing concepts such as players, artists, and developers. Meta elements can generally be divided into language, trick, and interactive experience; the shallower depth can only be used as a decoration to adjust the atmosphere, and the deeper excavation can become the core of the game’s plot or even the core of gameplay.

Meta Design with Easter Egg Nature

As embellishments, meta elements often appear in the form of surprises or easter eggs, and do not have a strong challenge to the player’s cognition. In fact, the appearance of game producers who were originally hidden behind the scenes in the game and interacting with players is a very common meta design; they often make statements that are extremely inconsistent with the style of the game or give special items, allowing players to temporarily break away from the serious game plot and take a breather; some more detailed meta designs can also surprise players, such as waiting for a period of time on the start interface, and the small animal facing away from the screen suddenly turns to look at the outside of the screen, etc.

The image of the production team appears as a special NPC in “The Elder Scrolls III”

Meta Design About Character Plot

One type of meta that explores deeper and is widely used is to imply or explicitly state that the characters in the game have self-awareness that is not controlled by the player; the characters know that they are game characters, and can understand the existence of the player, and even read the player’s user folder name to address the player.

The experience of being recognized is a double-edged sword. When the character’s attitude towards recognizing the player is peaceful and friendly, and there is no very intense interaction, the player will feel that this is a novel and interesting experience, such as Anna in VA-11 Hall-A: Cyberpunk Bartender Action who knows that she is in a game and tries to escape. However, when the game character shows criticism, sarcasm, or hurt towards the player, this experience of being watched will bring a great psychological gap to the player and re-examine their game behavior.

 

In Undertale, after completing the genocide route and loading the save, you will be mocked by this cute little flower for being hypocritical.

Meta Design that Challenges the Concept of Games

Common sense about games includes: the passage of time in the game world is independent of the passage of time in the outside world, and the game can be exited and restarted at any time; the game is an independent software, the game process is independent of the player’s operation of the system, and will not affect the external system. One type of meta element breaks through this common sense of the game and replaces it with the common sense of the real world.

In the RPG horror puzzle game The Witch’s House, the player can enter a hidden ending where the character in the castle dies on their own due to being left unattended for a long time by waiting at the birth point for an hour without entering the castle; in the game Needy Streamer Overload, to achieve the hidden ending where the heroine quits the internet, the player needs to play the game offline.

 

Goodbye, Electronic Sea

Atypical Meta Design

There is also a type of meta that is not meta in the usual sense, which creates a better sense of immersion by breaking the boundary that one thought oneself was in a single-player game. For example, in the boss battle of a certain ending of NieR: Automata, players can get assistance from other players who have cleared the game; after winning the battle, players can choose to sacrifice their entire game save in exchange for help for subsequent players, just like previous players.

 

Fight alongside them

2. Psychological Effects of Meta Elements: Is This a Game?

In traditional narrative-driven games, when players control the characters on the screen, they identify themselves with the identity of the protagonist on the screen on the one hand, and clearly know their identity as players on the other hand. Being a player means that one is the only conscious character in the game, and the behavior in the game will not affect real life, and there is no need to bear any responsibility and material loss for the behavior - these unspoken common principles in the game ensure that players can safely immerse themselves in the game experience.

The excellent meta with greater depth can bring players unexpected, surprising, fearful, fooled, and even ashamed emotional experiences, often stemming from its challenge to the traditional relationship of “real-world player - virtual-world game”.

Becoming the Watched God

Meta-games often challenge this common sense: the content and characters in the game are the objects of the player’s cognition, and will not in turn recognize the player. In traditional narrative-driven games, players are often the only conscious operators in the game, and interacting with the game is essentially a kind of self-entertainment.

However, when the object in the game behaves like an independent conscious individual and can recognize the player, the player will enter a social situation from a state of solitude, falling from an omnipotent god to a height where he needs to make eye contact with the character; his behavior suddenly has an audience watching, becoming an experience of being caught off guard.

Being watched means being exposed. When people don’t want to expose themselves and feel that they are about to be exposed, they are prone to fear and anxiety. This is also why meta elements most often appear in games containing psychological horror elements.

 

In some cases it’s not that scary (like when it’s a cat looking at you)

Loss of the Mask

The fact that the player is not recognized means that his identity in the game is actually indistinguishable from other players, that is, he has anonymity. In a completely anonymous psychological state, the psychological pressure on individuals from group norms or the influence of others will be reduced, which has the effect of relaxing the mood and reducing stress, but it is also accompanied by the loss of social responsibility and the danger of inducing various horrors and venting behaviors.

The game provides players with a sense of anonymity, that is, it provides players with the opportunity to play comfortably and freely in the virtual world, and even try various behaviors that cannot be tried in the social environment without regard to the consequences.

But when the character or the game itself is linked to the player’s real life in some way and monitors the player’s actions, arousing the player’s self-awareness, the player’s anonymity is suddenly violated, and he becomes an active participant in the plot from a casual player who does not need to be responsible, and needs to be responsible for everything that happens to the character.

 

Psycho Mantis in Metal Gear Solid reads the player’s other game saves for analysis.

Out-of-Control Experience in the Safe Zone

A sense of control refers to a psychological state in which the direction of things is under one’s control; it can enhance an individual’s positive emotional experience such as optimism and self-confidence, and weaken negative emotional experiences such as depression and helplessness. In real life, people have to face all kinds of loss of control caused by force majeure; therefore, the important charm of traditional narrative-driven games is to try to interact with the corresponding worldview system, and the player’s power to decide the fate of virtual characters.

Meta elements do the opposite, subtly depriving players of their sense of control in the virtual world. When players unexpectedly find that they cannot fully control their choices, cannot anticipate the relationship between their behavior and reactions, or the reactions caused are completely beyond expectations, a sense of loss of control arises. Just like a roller coaster, the temporary eruption of negative emotions is also a benign stimulus under the condition of no real danger; the anxiety caused by loss of control on the one hand pulls the player back to reality to think, and on the other hand can become an excitement point for some players.

 

You betrayed me, yes, you in front of the screen

3. Design Ideas of Meta Elements

The most mainstream meta design forms in current narrative-driven games include interface crashes, intervention in reality, narrator intervention, and multiple playthroughs. Interface crashes guide players to pay attention to the attributes of the game itself as software, such as the start button of Pony Island is designed as <error> at the beginning, and players must repair it; intervention in reality takes it a step further on the level of “the program itself has life”, such as IMSCARED will create a new strange folder on the player’s computer desktop and put the puzzle clues in it, and players will also operate pixel computers in the game; narrator intervention is to use an independent narrator to interfere with the player’s choices, and the domestic horizontal fighting game ICEY is a typical example in recent years; multiple playthroughs are widely used in many pixel RPGs and Galgames, and are often related to save-related operations. The famous meta game OneShot has made very clever use of this technique.</error.

 

When necessary, players need to delete and modify game saves

In essence, many meta elements are designed for the player’s own meta-gaming behavior. The environment gives players some prior knowledge, such as when a warrior in a game environment sees a monster named Medusa for the first time, the player knows to instruct the warrior to take out a mirror to reflect the gaze. In ordinary games, players will unconsciously use many meta-gaming strategies, that is, resort to out-of-game elements in their minds to make decisions in the game, such as directly entering the password in the second playthrough of a puzzle game based on memory. Ordinary games have no feedback on this strategy, and recognizing the player’s own meta-gaming behavior and setting feedback for the behavior is a way to break the fourth wall.

For example, in the well-known beautiful girl (horror) game Doki Doki Literature Club!, players are often deceived by the energetic color scheme and cute character images, and substitute traditional cognitions about other games of this type in their minds: not all characters can be captured, and they may also die tragically, and game saves may disappear at any time.

 

You can load, but she’s already been deleted

4. What Can Meta Bring Us?

The existence of meta techniques actually expands the upper limit of the ideas that plot-driven games can express as a game medium. When the boundary between virtual and real becomes blurred, the content conveyed in the game is related to real life, and what is finally left to the player is inexplicable melancholy and subtle reflection.

 

In The Stanley Parable, players can only get a variety of endings if they refuse to always follow the narrator’s instructions.

Perhaps not all meta designs are good designs; many times, they also appear only as a pastime in the tense game process. However, the potential of meta elements to convey philosophical thoughts is also undeniable. Although serious meta blurs the boundary between virtual and real, its necessary step is to awaken players from the omniscient and omnipotent dream in the game. In this sense, breaking the fourth wall is actually not breaking the wall, but discovering this wall spiritually; in the face of a living game, we have to start examining our own game behavior, our relationship with the game, and perhaps our own lives.

entry.title: Mastering the World Seeing the Big Picture in Game Mini-maps
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

Game maps are simulations of real environments, with cognitive, simulation, loading, and transmission functions. Their design is to guide players to choose certain paths and trigger certain events in the game. The mini-map in the game displays a part of the area centered on the character, which can help players quickly identify the surrounding environment, terrain, and target information. It is often placed in the corner of the game screen and is a map form that helps players determine their position in the game world.

So, as a game designer, how should you make good use of this information display area to convey key information to players and present a “seeing the big picture” design effect? This article will introduce three aspects: concise and clear information expression, association with character status, and association with player needs.

1. Concise and Clear Information Expression

The mini-map function is indispensable for some games and players, but at the same time, its existence will reduce the player’s immersion in the game and distract the player’s attention to the game screen. The simplified information expression design of the mini-map is not only to pursue higher information retrieval efficiency, but also to reduce its visual interference through design, thereby enhancing the sense of substitution for the character to explore the world.

Low-Saturation Map Display, High-Saturation Marker Display

Appropriate contrast can make the foreground map elements and icon labels easier to distinguish visually from their backgrounds. Different from the simple background color in general interface design, the map uses the default base map, and the content display is more complicated, which makes the mini-map need to be more refined in the use of color. In the game mini-map design, the following points can be summarized:

  • Low-saturation map base map, markers use high-saturation theme colors to be consistent with the game’s visual style
  • Clear color levels, colors of different hues should be both contrasting and coordinated
  • Effective use of the symbolism of colors (such as the warning of red and yellow.

 

《Days Gone》: Mini-map design

Use Icon Details to Represent the Z-axis

As a two-dimensional plane, the mini-map can be used to confirm the player’s own xy-axis position, but additional instructions are needed on the z-axis, so making the target icon have multiple states is a common indication method. Some games use whether there is a height difference as the state distinction. For example, in Battlefield 1, when the character has a height difference with the target object, the marker will change from solid to hollow, which is used to roughly estimate the enemy’s position. The z-axis representation of some games includes three states: up, down, and horizontal. Use the direction of the arrow to confirm your z-axis position. For example, in Borderlands 3, use small arrows next to the target to show above or below.

 

《Battlefield 1》: Height difference marker

 

《Borderlands 3》: Up/down arrow markers

Integrated Display with Other Information

The game’s HUD is an integrated display of a “symbol list”, which needs to summarize and link similar information to form a clearer HUD layout. As a component of the HUD that occupies a large proportion, the mini-map will attract more attention from players. Displaying some information close to the mini-map allows players to always observe other information every time they check the mini-map to confirm location information, and at the same time allows the player’s visual route to be more stable and concentrated. Common examples include system information such as weather, temperature, and time. Some games also integrate character status information such as health and energy into the mini-map, but it is also necessary to pay attention to how to display this information when the mini-map UI is closed.

In The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild, special location sensing, temperature, sound, time and weather information are displayed with the mini-map in the lower right corner of the interface.

 

In Red Dead Redemption 2, health and energy and other information are combined with the mini-map in the form of small icons, and integrated information is displayed.

 

In Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor, health and focus are integrated with the mini-map in the form of edge strips. Integrated information display makes the entire HUD design clearer and simpler. But if the mini-map is closed, all important indicators on the UI will disappear with it, which is a point to pay attention to.

 

Edge Blurring Effect

Compared with the frame design with harder outlines, the edge blurring effect can make the mini-map better integrate with the game environment and reduce visual interference. At this time, the base map is mostly a wireframe effect after grayscale processing, and the logo object is more prominent. Dying Light and Diablo III both adopt this method. Compared with Darksiders II with a stroked border, the visual center of the picture is significantly different.

 

《Diablo III》: Edge-blurred mini-map

Compass-style Guidance, Only Providing Key Direction Information

Considering the player’s attention and immersion, many games have adopted a compromise approach to the mini-map, that is, only retaining the most important direction information - compass-style guidance. The form of the compass will not excessively destroy the sense of immersion. Their position is usually placed in the center of the top, and the design is not too conspicuous. Although it indicates the direction of the destination, it still cannot show the exact path that the player needs to take, which requires the player to still rely on their own exploration to reach the destination. Compass-style guidance makes pathfinding a part of the game loop and retains its core function.

 

《The Elder Scrolls》: Compass-style guidance

 

《Elden Ring》: Compass-style guidance

2. Associated with Character Status

Since the character’s status in the game is constantly changing, for example, when moving and sprinting, the player’s needs for vision will be different. When the character is attacked, the mini-map, as a HUD element, can also give feedback prompts to the player through design. Therefore, the display of the mini-map also needs to be associated with the character’s status, taking into account different usage scenarios.

Weaken the Map Display in the Moving State, and Expand the Map Field of View Display When Sprinting

In Red Dead Redemption 2, when the character is in a sprinting state, usually in the situation of looting spoils, chasing enemies, and accelerating escape, the player’s need is to obtain a farther field of view. Therefore, the mini-map in the lower left corner will shrink and present a farther range of content. When sprinting ends, the display range returns to the original normal size. In Final Fantasy XIV, when the character moves, the task mini-map will automatically become translucent, which is convenient for players to observe the game scene while finding their way, without excessively blocking the player’s sight.

 

《Red Dead Redemption 2》: Mini-map display when the character is in an accelerated state

 

《Final Fantasy XIV》: Mini-map display when the character is moving

Feedback Display of the Map in the Attacked/Combat State

In addition to displaying basic map functions, the mini-map can also carry character status information, including whether to enter the combat state, whether it is discovered by monsters, whether a collision occurs, the stamina value of the monster when riding a monster, etc., to maximize the efficiency of UI information transmission. Feedback performance is usually in the form of mini-map border color and mini-map special effects. Among them, the change of border color is more obvious, and high-saturation colors are mostly used to distinguish. The mini-map special effects are mostly to simulate the real state of being attacked, such as screen failure flickering, heartbeat scaling, etc., so that the mini-map is no longer a single UI independent of the game.

In Monster Hunter: World, the mini-map has a black border in the normal state. When a battle is about to occur or a large monster appears around, a larger black border will appear around the mini-map and keep zooming like a heart rate, simulating the effect of accelerated heartbeat; after entering the combat state, the map border turns red; if the character is hiding in the grass or wearing an invisible suit at this time, the border will turn purple to indicate that the monster has not found the character in the field of vision, but is still on alert; after leaving the battle, a thick white border appears around the mini-map and then returns to the normal state, indicating that the danger is over; when riding a monster, a large white border appears around the mini-map to show the monster’s stamina value. The lower the stamina value, the smaller the diameter of the white border, until the stamina value is exhausted.

 

In Need for Speed Heat, when the player has a car crash, the mini-map will shake like a data stream to simulate the situation of the dashboard failure after a car crash in real life, giving the player feedback prompts while creating a real immersive feeling.

 

3. Associated with Player Needs

For different types of games and players’ different growth states, even different difficult terrains, the functional requirements of the mini-map vary from person to person, from time to time, and from shape to shape. Design needs to consider the player’s needs at all times, giving the mini-map more custom options and adaptation schemes to ensure a smooth and immersive game experience for players.

Mini-maps Also Need to Be Hidden in a Timely Manner

Due to the high information density of the mini-map and the prominent visual effects of some game mini-maps, it will cause the player’s visual center to shift and lack immersion. Many games allow players to close the mini-map UI to optimize the immersive experience. By guiding in the game scene, such as NPC pathfinding/road signs/scene interaction/area prompts when changing locations + player memory and other forms to achieve the purpose of pathfinding. At the same time, for example, in scenes where fighting is the core operation, direction information becomes unnecessary information, and simplifying the UI to provide players with a more focused interface design is also particularly important.

  • In Red Dead Redemption 2, the mini-map can be switched freely. When the mini-map is closed, pressing the D-pad will briefly display the mini-map to help players quickly identify the direction.
  • In Elden Ring, when the player is fighting fiercely with the boss, because the player’s core need at this time is to fight and focus on the battle, the compass-style mini-map guidance will disappear at this time, and the absence of redundant UI also increases the epic sense of the battle.
  • In The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild, players are provided with normal mode and expert mode. The expert mode hides the mini-map, allowing players familiar with the operation to focus more on immersing themselves in the world.

Provide Special 3D Views in Complex Terrain

In The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild, due to the variability and complexity of the interior of the Divine Beast, at this time, players need not only the information of the xy axis, but also the information of the z axis. Therefore, after entering the Divine Beast, the mini-map will switch from a 2D俯视 (fǔ shì - top-down) view to a 3D three-dimensional view to help players obtain information for exploration.

 

4. Summary

The increasingly rich mini-map design forms are indeed eye-catching. Creative and rich detail expression simplifies the game’s pathfinding experience and improves the efficiency of map information retrieval. However, the setting of the mini-map will make many players dependent. Compared with focusing on exploring the in-game scene, the “God’s perspective” mini-map makes information acquisition easier, which will make players lazy and mechanical in exploring the world. Therefore, the mini-map not only needs a concise and immersive UI design, situational interaction design, and multi-state mode design, but also needs to give players appropriate space to process information independently. Providing personalized guidance experience for different players and scenes may also be a good solution.

entry.title: How to Create and Adapt Overseas Questionnaires for Global Game Releases
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

For a game released globally, understanding the needs of overseas users is crucial, whether during the development or operational phase. Especially when we need to stand from a more macro perspective, understanding the target market users’ product cognition, behavioral characteristics, gaming habits, and content preferences, the traditional research method of questionnaire surveys becomes even more important.

Questionnaire surveys can achieve understanding of all the above information in a relatively short period of time. And launching questionnaires in the game is a very effective method in the process of game development and user research, with characteristics such as “relatively low cost, relatively short time, and relatively fast conclusions.” In this article, we will tell you how to conduct the most efficient questionnaire surveys and provide some tips to avoid pitfalls when doing player research in overseas markets.

1. Multi-language Classification in Games

Multi-language classification is always essential in globally released games. However, we face a choice: which languages should we use? Let’s first look at the number of speakers of each language in the world. Besides Chinese, English (1 billion), Spanish (570 million), Hindi (540 million), Arabic (420 million), Malay (280 million), French (270 million), Bengali (270 million), Russian (270 million), and Portuguese (250 million) are the most spoken languages. Moving to games, let’s look at two examples, the enduring GTA5 and the recent masterpiece Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2, both of which are AAA-level masterpieces from world-renowned manufacturers.

 

As you can see, in these two games, the very populous languages Hindi (540 million), Malay (280 million), and Bengali (270 million) are invariably ignored. In addition, GTA5 does not have Arabic. Instead, both games have German (180 million), Japanese (130 million), Italian (100 million), Korean (80 million), and Polish (50 million). The total number of speakers of these five languages is roughly equal to the number of Hindi speakers. Therefore, the choice of languages to adopt in the game is obviously not simply based on the number of speakers.

So, is it because of the purchasing power of players? Not necessarily. Among the 18 countries in the Arabic-speaking region, the combined GDP of Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Iraq, and Qatar alone is about the same as that of Italy. Among them, Saudi Arabia’s per capita GDP has reached 24,000 US dollars, and its consumption power is not much different from that of developed countries, not to mention Qatar, a country with a per capita GDP of more than 60,000 US dollars. Despite this, Arabic still does not appear in GTA5‘s language list. However, the potential player consumption power of this country also allows us to see the demand for Arabic from GTA5 players in the Middle East on forums. Therefore, the language chosen by the game is not necessarily completely related to the purchasing power of players or specific regions.

 

Faced with the demands of so many languages, the in-game language and the language of the in-game questionnaire must have made corresponding trade-offs and balances.

2. Multi-language in Questionnaires

So, how do you determine which languages to localize for overseas questionnaires? Let’s first look at the example of Arabic. Why haven’t many successful domestic games launched overseas done Arabic localization?

From the environment outside the game, although the video game industry and game culture in Arab countries are developing rapidly and there are many national support policies, they are still in the initial stage and have not been fully rolled out. At the same time, although the Gulf countries are rich, the gap between the rich and the poor is very serious, and some countries are still in long-term war. Finally, many cultures or doctrines in Arab countries also conflict with game content or worldviews. Many manufacturers find it difficult to customize game content specifically for the Arab region in order to pursue efficiency and security.

From inside the game, students who have seen Arabic and have done game localization must know that Arabic localization is a thankless task: because of the different writing habits (from right to left) and different lengths of words and sentences, the UI design has to be almost redone for localization. The questionnaire system is no exception. Everything is read from right to left, and even the text will be “broken”. In addition, there are many religious and cultural nuances to be considered. Thus, the processing cost is huge.

 

Breaking it down further into the design of overseas questionnaires, the core is still the same: the cost issue.

For a game like Naraka: Bladepoint, which has already been launched and is operating, it currently supports 13 languages. When launching a questionnaire overseas for research, is it necessary to design corresponding 13 languages?

The answer is no. Ideally, it would be best if each language and its corresponding country or region had its own easily accessible questionnaire, but this would cause us to lose a great deal of timeliness: when considering horizontal comparisons between Chinese and foreign players, the questionnaire needs to be translated from Chinese to English after the needs are disassembled/confirmed and the questions are designed, and then English is used as a bridge language to translate into various minor languages for distribution. Such a schedule often takes at least 1-2 weeks. After the questionnaire results are collected and the data is processed, it is necessary to compare and analyze 13 questionnaires in different languages, which is very cumbersome and error-prone, and may require the intervention of suppliers at this time. In this way, a questionnaire takes nearly a month to obtain valid data and conclusions, and players and the development team have long forgotten what they wanted to verify or investigate before, which will inevitably bring great timeliness problems.

In addition, considering that the number of players in different regions may vary greatly, when the number of samples collected for a certain minor language is limited, we must also consider the reliability and validity of the entire questionnaire when processing data. Feedback from a small number of player groups is very likely to provide biased conclusions or insights in a questionnaire that requires a large sample size, which is an important issue to consider in market and user research.

Therefore, we must make some trade-offs. The first thing to consider is the number of online players in the game. To give an extreme example, if we have to choose between Japanese and Korean, and there are 1,000 players using Japanese and only 50 players using Korean, then we will undoubtedly give up including Korean in the questionnaire.

So, you might ask, what about Korean players? At this time, an English questionnaire can be used as a permanent alternative. Even if there are fewer English players, this universal language is always the “last home” for global players, and the same is true for overseas questionnaires. In the design of Naraka: Bladepoint‘s overseas questionnaires, we will, considering the schedule of the localization team, add 2-3 minor languages on the basis of Chinese and English, combined with the number of online players, translation costs, and regional characteristics, as the final questionnaire launch.

3. Differences in Question Settings between China and Foreign Countries

After arranging the multi-language questionnaire, let’s talk about the specific design of the questionnaire survey. The core point to pay attention to in this link is: Chinese players have their own unique game culture atmosphere, and other countries also have their own beliefs.

For example, when designing demographic questions, in addition to male and female genders in English questions, we also referred to the Inclusive Forms on gender proposed by UBC’s Equity & Inclusion Office, adding gender options such as “non-binary” to the questions, and in fact, some players did choose this. On the other hand, in the Japanese and Korean language questionnaires, after consulting with localizers in those countries, if options other than male and female are added to the questions, players may feel a little strange, so we still only retain the traditional three options of “male/female/prefer not to disclose”, which also reflects the difference in values between East Asia and Europe and America.

 

This difference can also be reflected in the specific options of in-game questionnaires. If the option in a certain question is “good-looking hosts and commentators”, this is a relatively common situation in China. Because whether it is the high-end CCTV Spring Festival Gala host or the live broadcast anchors who are closer to life, these people are often good-looking and have good temperament, and the audience will not have any objections. However, when the same option appears in a European or American questionnaire, players may raise some objections. After all, in current European and American games, such as the protagonist of the console game Horizon Forbidden West, or the female characters in Apex Legends, they are already more diversified and no longer follow the sexy route like Lara Croft before. This gradual “different paths leading to different destinations” in aesthetics and differences in habits between the East and the West will also affect the setting of questions and options in the questionnaire.

In addition to similar value differences, the unique attributes of domestic questionnaires also need to be noted. For example, the “H5 page” option in domestic questionnaires is not well understood by overseas players. If it is literally translated as “H5” or “H5 page”, foreign players will be confused. At this time, we must consider whether to replace the option, or directly delete the option (when it is judged that it is less used in the region), or put it in the “other” option for players to fill in by themselves.

 

Of course, some of the most basic things, such as replacing domestic social platforms and media with overseas counterparts, will not be repeated here, but one thing to consider is: it is not just a matter of replacing them with a fixed set of content, but each language questionnaire should be localized according to the usage characteristics of that country. For example, “Allah” cannot appear in Arabic, this word cannot have the Christian cross; in German localization, “SS tier” needs to be considered more carefully when expressing equipment quality because “SS” is the abbreviation of Nazi “Schutzstaffel”, and so on.

4. Summary

The above is some preliminary discussion on the design and launch of overseas questionnaires. To sum up, a very important point is the word “trade-off”. Doing overseas research is of course important, but how to conduct questionnaire research efficiently during the research process is also something we need to consider. We can make corresponding optimal decisions according to the actual situation of our own games.

entry.title: How Positive Psychology Supports Your Gaming Experience
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

Have you ever been fully immersed in a game, forgetting hunger and time?

Have you ever felt a sense of self-fulfillment and satisfaction after finishing a game?

If so, congratulations. In this play session, you successfully entered a state of flow.

 

Nothing can stop Civilization VI players from the flow of “one more turn”.

Various psychological principles and phenomena, such as “flow”, have long been closely linked to the video game industry and have rich applications in it. In this article, we will combine specific game cases to explain how the “flow” phenomenon and the positive psychology theory behind it are introduced by game designers to support the game player experience.

First, let’s understand what positive psychology is.

1. About Positive Psychology

The core of positive psychology research is what makes life valuable and meaningful. As a discipline, it examines assumptions about what can improve our lives. Its research paradigm is no different from traditional psychology, only the focus of research is different: the traditional psychology field studies “what problems have occurred in human psychology” and tries to find ways to make them less painful; but the goal of positive psychology is to make ordinary life more fulfilling. It focuses on people’s strengths and explores what makes life happier.

 

Positive psychology is an important supplement to traditional psychology, focusing on the well-being of all mankind. Through its practice, we can be more actively involved in life and find the true meaning of life.

The core question of positive psychology research is how to make people happy, and this is the common fulcrum with video games. In the process of playing video games, players actively exert their rich and diverse strengths and skills to overcome difficulties; they empathize with the characters in the game, thus creating emotional connections; video games will also give them corresponding feedback, so that they can get a wonderful sense of happiness and fulfillment. Therefore, it is crucial to understand what factors affect happiness and apply them to industry practices.

So what factors affect people’s happiness? In 2011, the father of positive psychology, Martin Seligman, proposed the very famous PERMA model in his book to explain the factors that affect happiness, and at the same time better define and explain “what is happiness”.

2. How to View the PERMA Model with Game Examples

Professor Seligman, the “father of positive psychology”, believes that happiness consists of five elements: Positive Emotions, Engagement, Relationships, Meaning, and Achievement.

 

Positive Emotion

Studies have pointed out that positive emotions greatly affect the way we view the world. When the level of positive emotions is high, the level of creativity, courage, and optimism will increase: this means that players have stronger control performance in the game. At the same time, under the influence of positive emotions, players have higher cognition and evaluation of the game, and gain more satisfaction and happiness in the game.

Therefore, it is very important to highlight the elements that can make people feel happy in the game and use them to mobilize the player’s positive emotions. For example, the Forza Horizon series produces a refreshing feeling for players during the race through the detailed depiction of the natural scenery of the United Kingdom and Mexico; the recent White Snake Legend co-branded fashion of Naraka: Bladepoint stimulates players’ sense of national cultural pride and ownership while providing players with a beautiful visual experience.

 

The natural scenery of the Forza Horizon series.

 

Naraka: Bladepoint White Snake Legend co-branded fashion

Engagement

What makes you immersed in the game and even forget the time?

It is the “flow” mentioned earlier, proposed by Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi, another founder of positive psychology. In positive psychology and PERMA theory, “flow” describes a state of immersion in the present and full engagement. When players are engaged, their energy and concentration increase at the same time. However, the state of flow is not something that can be entered casually. The game needs to meet the following three points:

  • The game itself should be rewarding, and players tend to play the game. This is the big premise.
  • The challenges in the game should take into account the player’s ability. The challenges match the ability, which makes the player more engaged.
  • Players should feel that they have control over the game during the game.

 

Sekiro and the Civilization series, which have always been regarded as industry benchmarks in the flow experience, also do well in these three points:

Sekiro provides players with a hearty gaming experience of cutting into flesh, and Civilization provides players with a gaming experience of development and growth, and overall planning;

The difficulty of Sekiro is just on the upper side of the challenge-ability line of most players, and Civilization provides players with up to 8 custom difficulties;

In Sekiro, players play the role of the ninja “Wolf” and constantly improve their combos and reactions during the game. In Civilization, players play the role of the supreme leader of a civilization and constantly optimize the best development strategy during the game.

Although Sekiro and Civilization belong to the action category and strategy category respectively, both have achieved the ultimate in their own fields, creating an immersive game experience for players.

 

Action game Sekiro (X) Rhythm game Sekiro (√).

 

The mental state of Civilization series players

Relationship

The revolutionary mentor Marx said: “Man is the sum of social relations.” Human beings are social animals and always have the need to maintain connections with others, hoping to have spiritual communication with others. At the same time, good interpersonal relationships often bring people a broader vision, stronger external support and a more stable psychological state.

The selection of game materials is rich and diverse, and naturally it will not lack the description of various social relations in various themes. Whether it is the deep emotional bond established between players and NPCs in single-player games, or the cooperative or competitive relationship established between players in online multiplayer games, it provides unique emotional experiences for players who love this type of game.

In the open-world single-player game The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim with a Western magical background, players will embark on the adventure of the Dragonborn. Among them, Lydia, the first companion encountered in Whiterun, is the partner of most players from beginning to end, accompanying the player to enter dark caves, sweep bandit strongholds, block knives and arrows for the player, share the burden of luggage for the player, share the ups and downs with the player, and accompany the player to travel all over the land of Skyrim. Because of this, Lydia has become almost one of the most talked about characters in The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim and is deeply loved by players. In community-organized polls, Lydia firmly holds the title of “Most Popular Marriage Partner in The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim”, which shows the deep emotional connection players have with her.

 

In The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, the scene where the player marries Lydia

In Battlefield 1, which focuses on large maps and large battlefields, each battle is based on the historical battles of World War I. Players are divided into camps of 32 people, representing a participating country in World War I to fight for the country. At the beginning of the game, the monologue of the soldiers from that camp will be played to unify the players’ identification with the camp. In the game, players from the same country will mainly generate social links by helping each other, cross-covering, and coordinating charges. The gunfire and the bugle will firmly unite the players’ belief in “fighting for the country”. The grandeur of the charge, the bond between comrades-in-arms, and the belief in the country are all condensed in the short 20-minute game.

 

The scene of charging together in Battlefield 1

Meaning and Purpose

When a player has a clear goal, the goal will stimulate the player’s state. When the player has a clear sense of meaning and purpose, he will actively start thinking about how to do better, thus entering the positive cycle of “player input-game feedback-player thinking-player re-input”.

In It Takes Two, the winner of the 2021 TGA Game of the Year, two players will play the role of Cody and May, a couple whose relationship is on the verge of breaking down. After another family quarrel, they are turned into dolls that their daughter cannot see by the daughter’s “Book of Love”. On the surface level, the player’s goal is to control the characters through the tasks set by the “Book of Love”, and finally return to their bodies and see their daughter; on the deeper level, the player’s goal is to let the two characters re-recognize and familiarize themselves with each other in the process of passing the levels, find the reason for loving each other, and thus save this family on the verge of breaking up. The pursuit of superficial meaning leads them on a journey of personal growth, thereby finding deeper meaning. The player’s play process is therefore tinged with a sense of mission.

 

Accomplishment

Positive psychology believes that a sense of accomplishment can better improve a person’s resilience and optimism, and make people more courageous in the face of setbacks. Similarly, in the game, appropriately giving feedback to players on small achievements and big achievements can enhance players’ acceptance of challenges and resilience, increase their sense of gain and satisfaction during the game, and at the same time strengthen their motivation to overcome difficulties.

The horizontal profile survival game This War of Mine won more than 100 international awards with its cold style, rigorous excavation of history and profound humanistic thinking. It starts from the perspective of small people in the war, takes the real event of the Siege of Sarajevo as the background, and makes players feel the pain, helplessness, and powerlessness of people in the war through a piece of microscopic cruel reality. This also makes the game have strong negative feedback on the player experience. Through the settlement of the small achievements of the player’s daily acquisition of materials and the settlement of the great achievements after the final clearance, the player can get hope for the next day’s survival and the motivation to explore the second week, reducing the risk of players giving up when facing negative emergencies.

 

The player saved the doctor on the 11th day - the memoir-like settlement form encourages players to draw a stroke of human brilliance in their own “war history”

3. Summary

Sid Meier, the master of the game industry, said at the 2010 GDC Game Developers Conference: “Games are a psychological experience”, which profoundly reveals the inseparable link between video games and psychology. The video game industry has developed to this day, and it has to be admitted that its greatest charm for game players is that it creates a rich, complex, immersive, and empathetic psychological experience for players. Although the psychological factors of the game process are not as dazzling as the game’s picture quality and action effects, its existence is the spiritual core of the interactive art of games.

entry.title: How to Create the Soul of FPS with Interaction - Gun Feel
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

FPS (First-Person Shooter), as a globally popular game genre, is deeply loved by players for its realistic battlefield atmosphere and exciting competitive confrontation. Every player has their own preferences, and when we evaluate an FPS game, gun feel is always an unavoidable aspect.

So what is gun feel? As a comprehensive feeling, it is difficult to define. It is an objective existence. How many game developers have racked their brains for it: all the feedback during the use of the gun can be included in the gun feel. It is also a subjective feeling in people’s minds: the player’s preconceived cognitive expectation of the gun’s “rules”. Only when the two match and cooperate with each other can a good gun feel be created.

For example, general FPS players perceive the AK as having a larger spread and strong recoil. If the shooting feedback fails to express this level of information, the player will feel that the gun is “weak”. It is difficult to change the player’s cognitive expectations. It is necessary to cater to the player by designing good gun use feedback, and this is the essence of improving gun feel.

All feedback is part of gun feel, but many players will first pay attention to some obvious information, such as gun model accuracy, shooting animation, sound effects, special effects, etc., but they know little about the role of interaction design in it. But it is certain that good interaction design can increase the realism and feel of the gun, and it also needs to be valued and carefully considered.

1. Recoil System and Screen Shake

When it comes to gun feel, many people will give priority to the recoil system of the gun. After all, this is the visual information that best reflects the power of the gun. But what are the manifestations of the recoil system?

Viewkick

This is the most familiar part for FPS players. It refers to the camera that is constantly raised with continuous shooting, which is普遍存在 (pǔ biàn cún zài - universally present) in all shooting games. The generally-called “recoil control” is to control the recoil of this part. This is a form of recoil expression that almost all FPS games have. In terms of design, it is generally adjusted according to the recoil value of the gun, whether it is scoped, whether it is holding breath, the gun holding action, etc.

 

Gunkick

Gunkick refers to the phenomenon that the crosshair continuously deviates from the center of the camera during continuous shooting, and the exit point of the bullet is tied to the crosshair, causing the impact point of the bullet to change accordingly. Its core lies in the constantly changing trajectory driven by the muzzle shake, which makes the entire shooting process very accurate and real, and can bring an extremely excellent shooting experience, but its implementation cost is also the highest.

 

Visual Recoil

Visual recoil is similar to Gunkick, but different. It also refers to the crosshair deviating from the center of the camera, but it will return to the center of the screen before the next bullet is fired. It has no effect on the impact point of the bullet (which is always the center of the screen). It is just a visual expression. Simply put, Visual recoil is an animated version of muzzle jump and does not change the trajectory (and the fact is that Visual recoil is indeed a random play of multiple animations). It is enough for shooting games that pursue impact but not extreme accuracy.

 

Viewroll

Viewroll refers to the phenomenon of rotating around the center of the camera during shooting. It has no effect on the position of the crosshair and the camera, so it is just a visual effect to enhance recoil. Many FPS games in recent years have adopted it. From a design point of view, Viewkick reflects the vertical stability of the gun holder, then Viewroll reflects the horizontal stability. Therefore, the design ideas of these two are not much different.

 

Spread

Spread refers to the phenomenon that bullets are randomly distributed on the diffusion circle with the aiming baseline A as the center. That is, aiming at one point, the bullet will not necessarily hit that point, but there will be an unavoidable deviation. It is achieved by directly modifying the code to displace the bullet by a small distance at a long distance. Strictly speaking, it is not part of the recoil performance system, but in design, it can be used as a supplement to Visual recoil to undertake the task of randomly distributing the trajectory.

 

Summary

Viewkick and Gunkick are the performance of recoil on the aiming baseline, which actually affects the player’s aiming; Spread is to directly modify the position of the bullet to achieve the “offset” feeling in the recoil system; Visual recoil and Viewroll are just visual expressions and have no factual impact on the player’s aiming and shooting (but may still form visual misleading).

Perhaps after talking about the above points, many readers are still confused about the interactive performance of the recoil system. Next, we will use game comparisons to illustrate how the recoil system affects the gun feel from the player’s interactive experience.

First, a horizontal comparison between Battlefield 1 and Battlefield V.

 

Comparing the above two animated pictures, which gun do you think has a stronger sense of power?

Many readers will choose Battlefield 1 on the right. The reason is that as works of the Battlefield series, the bullet exit points of both are tied to the center of the screen, but because Battlefield 1 has Visual recoil, which Battlefield V does not have, its crosshair can move additionally away from the center of the screen, and it has a stronger sense of power in the performance layer of recoil. At the same time, Battlefield 1 also has a larger Spread, which enhances the thrill of strafing.

The above two points give Battlefield 1 a better shooting experience, but also produced a problem that has been criticized by players, that is, the crosshair of Battlefield 1 is deceptive. Aiming but not hitting is the main source of frustration in Battlefield 1. Therefore, DICE studio canceled these two points in the development of Battlefield V in exchange for a “point and shoot” PVP kill experience, and at the same time adopted a larger Viewkick to make up for the shortcomings in the shooting experience.

The above comparison tells us that performance (gun feel) and operation (shooting accuracy) are difficult to balance, but the Call of Duty series (hereinafter referred to as COD) gives a better solution to this problem, that is, Gunkick.

 

First of all, COD also has the offset between the crosshair and the center of the screen, but unlike the Visual recoil of Battlefield 1, the bullet exit point of COD is tied to the crosshair, that is, Gunkick. This offset will not mislead the player’s aiming, because the player’s reference point when making fine-tuning aiming is always the crosshair. In addition, Gunkick can also replace the random effect of Spread’s trajectory, and there will be no problem of erratic trajectory like Spread, which can be described as the best of both worlds. Of course, the disadvantage of Gunkick is that it is difficult to balance cost and performance. Only FPS game industry ceilings like COD can better control it.

2. Crosshair and Sight Design

I believe that players of any FPS game will find a strange phenomenon, that is, when we watch games or live broadcasts, we always find that some players or anchors set the crosshair to some strange shapes. After logging in to the game, I also tried the same, but found that other people’s settings were not as good as my own, and the default crosshair felt better. What is going on? In fact, the design of the crosshair and the sight also includes the careful consideration of the interaction designer.

 

Convenience of Aiming is Fundamental

The form of the UI is closely related to its function. To answer this question, we must first return to the original design purpose and function of the crosshair - to assist players in aiming at the enemy. A simple sentence can actually be divided into two steps: First, find the position of your own crosshair and the enemy, and move the crosshair to the enemy; second, fine-tune the crosshair to aim at a certain part of the enemy (such as the head) and shoot. Although many FPS veterans are already proficient in shooting and are not aware of the process, they still cannot do without these two steps.

From this, it can be found that the crosshair that contains the larger area is easier to achieve the first step; and the smaller and more precise the crosshair, the easier it is to achieve the second step. This is also the reason why some professional players like to shrink the crosshair: for them, the first step no longer needs any guidance, what they need is to aim at the enemy’s weakness more accurately. In fact, the default crosshair of CS: GO takes into account the above two steps: the small point in the middle is used for precise aiming; the cross around it is used to expand the overall area for rough aiming. Therefore, most players do not need to adjust the default crosshair, and the interaction designer has already considered it thoroughly.

 

Form Follows Function

In recent years, with the development of FPS game design and technology, some strange crosshair styles have appeared in the player’s field of vision, but in the final analysis, it is still form follows function.

The crosshair has been around for the longest time. It contains a horizontal headshot line and is widely used in weapons that require precise shooting and pre-aiming; the circular crosshair is suitable for suppression. It clearly indicates the scattering range and is used in melee combat, with AOE damage, and guns that do not require precision; there are also crosshairs with parabolic scales, which are obviously used in some weapons with obvious bullet drop, such as bows and arrows, grenade launchers, etc. These crosshair styles are the most authentic feedback of the weapon, and some even borrowed from the sight of the weapon in reality. They deeply affect the first impression of a gun and also affect the player’s feeling of gun feel.

 

3. Hit Feedback

As the last step of the player’s interaction with the gun, the existence of hit feedback is a great positive incentive. The enemy’s hit action, particle effects, sound effects and other multi-sensory forms of expression constitute the current mainstream FPS hit feedback.

But due to the limitations of many competitive games, for example, in fast-paced games like Overwatch, it is impossible to show the enemy’s hit animation separately for the player, and the hit special effects are also greatly reduced; in CS: GO, in order to ensure the fairness of the competition, animation and special effects are also simplified as much as possible. At this time, interaction designers need to take action to provide certain hit feedback on the UI.

Simple but Not Simplistic “x” Cross

In the hit feedback on the UI, most of them are currently attached to the crosshair: when hitting the enemy, an “x” cross will appear on the crosshair, and different variants will present different information. These variants are the focus of the design.

The COD series uses a set of cognitive habits that players have formed for design: when your shot hits the enemy, a white “x” cross appears around the crosshair; if this hit is a kill, the “x” cross appears red; when you attack continuously, the animation of the “x” cross is flashing. Most games on the market currently use this set of UI hit feedback design. Although it is traditional, it is stable.

 

Overwatch has made certain innovations: the white “x” cross still indicates a hit, and the red “x” cross is changed to a hit on a weak point, so it is necessary to design another icon to indicate a kill. Overwatch chose the most intuitive red skull. At the same time, Overwatch has also improved the animation performance of the “x” cross under continuous attack, from monotonous “flashing” to increasing the side length of the “x” cross to express the accumulation of damage.

 

What’s more, such as Biomutant, the hit feedback is directly mounted on the enemy instead of the UI, which makes the hit feedback out of the scope of the UI interface, but more like a stylized special effect. But compared with the former with a fixed position, mounting the hit feedback on the enemy can better reflect the flexibility of the battle and has a better performance in PVE.

4. Summary

Gun feel, as the soul of FPS, is something that every game company must carefully consider and design when making this type of game. A good shooting feel can greatly enhance the coherence and interactivity of the game process and lay the foundation for a good player experience. This is a complex and arduous project. Although interaction only accounts for a small proportion of it, its role should not be underestimated. Whether it is recoil performance, crosshair, or hit feedback, it is what players pay attention to and value. It is believed that with the development of FPS games, more interaction designers will invest in these fields of work and propose more solutions for better gun feel.

entry.title: I came, I saw, I conquered Localization Strategies to Help Arabic Games Go Global
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

McDonald’s has opened chain restaurants in more than 100 countries, which is globalization. McDonald’s restaurants in Israel are closed on the Sabbath and Jewish holidays. McDonald’s in Dubai uses Arabic to transliterate McDonald’s and designs different menus to cater to Muslims who do not eat pork. This is localization.

As more and more products go global, researchers have created the acronym GILT (Globalization, Internationalization, Localization, and Translation) to refer to the activities that companies engage in when they go abroad to do business. Among these words, “translation” is the easiest to understand. Anthony Burgess once said: “Translation is not a matter of words only: it is a matter of making intelligible a whole culture.”

Arabic, as the fifth most spoken language in the world, includes more than 30 different dialects. Millennials, as the main Internet audience, have a growing demand for Arabic video games, leading to more and more game localization services focusing on Arabic. However, Arabic is also considered one of the most difficult languages to localize. Its richness, diversity, and complexity make the localization of games challenging. Compared with major languages such as English, there is a extreme lack of linguistic technology adapted to Arabic. Although all Arab countries speak the same language and believe in roughly the same religion, in fact, the complex multicultural structure makes these countries very different.

1. Adapt to the Technical Characteristics of the Target Language to Avoid Potential Technical Problems in the Localized Version

BiDi (Bi-directional): The Complexity of Text Sorting

Perhaps the most well-known textual feature of Arabic is that it is arranged from right to left. In the Pixar film Inside Out, there is a scene where the characters in the film point to a sign and read the text on it. This part of the animation content has been modified for different versions. In the Arabic version of the movie, the characters read the sign from right to left, while in the English version, the reading order is from left to right.

 

In most cases, Arabic is written and read from right to left. However, in some contexts, certain parts of a sentence are written and read from left to right. For example, when numbers and Latin text appear in a sentence, which is common in video games. This makes Arabic a bi-directional (BiDi) language, and Arabic text in any localization software should also reflect this feature. Some video games do not support BiDi, which brings difficulties to the corresponding Arabic version experience. This complexity becomes even more serious when numbers, Latin words, and certain symbols appear in a line or sentence.

The figure below shows the BiDi text display error that appeared in the Xbox One version of PUBG. When a player dies, a message pops up saying “M416 [weapon] killed you with a headshot by J*****8 [player name]”, which does not make sense in Arabic. So in fact, the internationalization stage of the GILT process includes preparing the source code of the game in advance to facilitate and support localization. It can be understood as eliminating or modifying problematic elements of the game upstream, including technical or cultural issues. The Arabic version of the game needs to support BiDi to adapt to the Arabic RTL text direction. The error that appears here is a typical example of the game code preparation or design not supporting Arabic translation/localization tasks.

 

Arabic BiDi text display error from PUBG (2017) on Xbox One

Letter Connection and Right-to-Left Layout

Arabic writing is connected. This writing style requires code or engine support in the game. Such a system will ensure that the Arabic script in the game is displayed correctly, with all letters connected and read from right to left. Some localized games from well-known developers such as Konami do not support Arabic cursive, which makes it difficult for Arabic players to read certain menu items.

In Pro Evolution Soccer, developed by Konami, some menu items do not support Arabic cursive. As shown in the figure below, “العب الان” (Play Now), which is displayed correctly, is disconnected because these letters are disconnected and displayed from left to right. However, other menu items are displayed correctly. This script problem was fixed after release, which cost Konami more money, effort, and time.

 

Disconnected letters in Pro Evolution Soccer (2018)

The problem of disconnecting Arabic letters becomes more serious and destructive when video games contain voice-over subtitles. The figure below is Maquette developed by Graceful Decay. In the game, the Arabic in the main menu and subtitles is completely disconnected.

 

Maquette main menu disconnected

–.

 

Maquette subtitles disconnected

2. Customize Localized UI Design and Terminology Unification from User Habits and Cultural Characteristics

In addition to the obvious problems of right-to-left and letter connection, carefully scrutinizing every use experience from the user’s habits is a kind of silent localization service.

Subtitles

The lack of subtitle specifications is not only a problem for Arabic video game localization, but also for other languages. However, the nature of Arabic makes this lack of standardization more serious.

Arabic does not include capital letters to indicate proper names, but occasionally uses punctuation marks to compensate. In order to distinguish between proper nouns and other words, Arabic translators usually choose parentheses or inverted commas. Many video games have adopted this practice. For example, proper nouns in The Witcher 3 are enclosed in parentheses; in FIFA 2018, proper names are retained in the source language, which is especially problematic for players who do not speak or read foreign languages; in Assassin’s Creed: Valhalla, line breaks and color-coding of proper names are used to distinguish NPC names.

 

The Witcher 3 (2015)

–.

 

FIFA 2018 (2017)

–.

 

Assassin’s Creed: Valhalla (2020)

Some localization experts believe that using punctuation marks in sentences to distinguish proper nouns from other words is awkward. However, it is difficult for players to read transliterated proper nouns and distinguish them from other words, because some transliterated words look like Arabic verbs or adjectives. Using punctuation marks to uniformly distinguish proper nouns can often improve the readability of audiovisual text and reduce confusion. In fact, it is common to use quotation marks and/or parentheses to enclose proper nouns in local TV programs or movies with Arabic subtitles. The same practice and its advantages also apply to in-game text.

 

Quotation mark annotation of the transliterated laboratory “Mirkwood” in Stranger Things

Transliteration

Another key issue in Arabic video game localization is the translation and transliteration of proper nouns (names of people or places). This problem stems from the fact that people have different ways of translating English proper nouns into Arabic. For example, in some cases, translators will replace the letters of the source word with the same letters in Arabic. In other cases, the translator replaces the pronunciation of the source word with the pronunciation in Arabic, or provides a translation of the proper noun. Due to the lack of standardized methods for translating proper nouns into Arabic, proper nouns appear less frequently in different types of translation materials, including video games, movies, TV shows, and literary works. For example, Skellige, a city in The Witcher 3, is transliterated in three different ways.

 

When players face three different transliterations at the same time on the screen: one for his/her location in the game world map; one for the list, at a specific task location; and one for the voice-over subtitles, at the bottom of the screen. However, in translation and localization projects, there is no standardized method for translating foreign names. In some localization processes, the Arabic transliteration of proper nouns needs to be managed during terminology development, which helps ensure that specific transliterations are used consistently throughout the project.

Video Game Terminology and Acronyms

When translating games into Arabic, video game developers also need to consider two other elements: the length of Arabic equivalent terms, especially video game menu terms, and the absence of acronyms in Arabic. Therefore, compared with English, translating interface items into Arabic requires more space.

The figure below shows the “Home” button in the English and Arabic versions of Captain Tsubasa: Rise of New Champions. “الصفحة الرئيسية” in Arabic requires two lines and 15 characters, while only one line and 4 characters are required in English.

 

Figure 5-A. Arabic of the Home Page Button

 

Figure 5-B. English of the Home Page Button

Video game localization has some similarities with software localization. Both involve a combination of language translation and software engineering, that is, the translated text string needs to be properly placed in the software. This requires that the string length is within the allocated space, which in turn limits the freedom of translation. The model of releasing the original product (usually the English version) together with the localized version is an accepted model in today’s localization industry, but it has important implications for translation, because translators must deal with unstable source content that may be constantly changing throughout the project. Most games released in Europe seem to follow this model, rather than the model where the localized version lags behind the original version. The latter is common among Japanese game developers/publishers.

Cultural Taboos (Haram)

Arab culture is very conservative in terms of sex, alcohol, and profanity. In addition, in most cases, topics that violate Arab and Muslim cultural and religious beliefs will be reviewed by the Arab Audiovisual Commission (GCAM) for these issues. If the material cannot be reviewed, it will be completely banned. Several games have been banned in Arab countries due to content that does not conform to Arab cultural norms and traditions. For example, some video games that have been banned in the Arab region due to violence and mention of sexual orientation include Assassin’s Creed 2, Resident Evil 6, Grand Theft Auto 5, Deadpool, and Mafia 3. There are also some other games that have been rejected or even banned by Arab players due to implicit or explicit insults to Muslims.

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 is a good example. This game caused controversy in the Arab Muslim player community. Players found that the frame pattern above the toilet in a bathroom scene in the game quoted the Quran. In Islam, it is forbidden to talk about Islam in the toilet. In response to the player community, Activision officially apologized and modified this scene in a game update.

 

Figure 6-A. Overall scene of the bathroom in Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 (2009)

–.

 

Figure 6-B. The frame pattern noticed by the player

This is not the first time that Islamic elements have appeared in the Call of Duty series of games. In the zombie mode of Call of Duty: Vanguard, players found that the Quran was thrown on the floor and stepped on by players; such a rude scene angered players in the Arab region, forcing game developers to delete it in an update. Independent game developer Rami Ismail tweeted: “Even if you think religion is nonsense, there is no reason to be disrespectful to the culture and beliefs of 2 billion people in a video game, just in exchange for a disposable asset..

 

Figure 7. Pages of the Quran scattered on the ground

When games are developing localized Arabic versions, development teams should carefully consider these issues. Development should follow the cultural norms of the Arabic-speaking region to avoid sales losses due to cultural dissonance and negative impact on the developer’s image in certain markets.

3. Conclusion

Localization is the process of making a product or information resonate with a specific target culture, in the same way that content is created locally. Several of the above-mentioned problems of Arabic localization can be reduced and avoided by adopting appropriate internationalization strategies. Game localization should also be based on Gouadec’s definition of localization, that is, adapting a product to “the specific physical, technical, linguistic, cultural, ethnic, religious, philosophical, commercial, marketing, etc. conditions and requirements of the audience or users of a specific ‘location’.”

In other words, the process of game localization should not only consider the language conversion of game resources, but also consider the cultural background of the corresponding market, including the corresponding norms to manage the acceptability of localization in overseas video game markets. These investments also depend on the level of localization that video game developers expect, the return on investment in localization based on time constraints, and considerations of the value of the target market. In general, given the huge market demand for video games from users in the Arab region, there is an urgent need for more research and experimentation in the field of Arabic game localization.

entry.title: The More Cowardly, the More Addicted - Are Horror Games Really That Appetizing
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

Horror games, a genre that has endured since the birth of gaming, remain a favorite of many game enthusiasts. While our rational minds tell us to avoid fear in pursuit of happiness, the chilling, trembling feeling we get in the dark provides a thrilling and captivating experience.

Horror games are truly a love-hate affair. When you’re not playing them, you’re intrigued by the sense of curiosity, but when you are, you’re constantly gripped by fear. From classics like Resident Evil, Silent Hill, Outlast, and Dead Space, to the rising tide of Chinese horror games like Home Sweet Home, Paper Dolls, and Paper Bride, this genre has always had titles that touch players’ nerves. Even when scared pale, players persevere to complete the entire story. What is the driving force behind players’ dedication.

 

1. What Happens in Our Bodies When We Play Horror Games?

Riding the Emotional Rollercoaster

Horror games aim to shock or frighten the audience through narrative devices such as pain and supernatural phenomena. Players experience anxiety and even disgust, accompanied by a series of physiological reactions, such as trembling, jumping, covering their eyes, and an increased heart rate, resulting in feelings of fear. When faced with terror, the sympathetic nervous system is aroused, activating the fight-or-flight response, and the level of adrenaline in the body surges. However, people usually don’t immediately flee danger. The brain assesses the surrounding environment, and after realizing there is no immediate danger, emotions relax, providing a sense of release.

In a way, it’s like a roller coaster. You experience a range of emotions, such as anticipation and tension, and then, under the stimulation of adrenaline, a series of physiological reactions occur, such as accelerated blood flow, rapid breathing, increased heart rate, dilated pupils, and focused attention on self-preservation. The brain and body prepare to react to perceived threats with greater strength and speed. After assessing that there is no real life-threatening danger, dopamine and endorphins are activated, resulting in a thrilling pleasure and mental catharsis.

Horror games take full advantage of this by manipulating and teasing the senses, scaring you, and then providing a moment of relief.

 

Excitation Transfer and Safe Rooms

Imagine you’re running for your life in the game world of Resident Evil, your health bar is almost empty, you don’t have many supplies left, and to make matters worse, there’s a猙狞 (zhēngníng - ferocious,狰狞) looking tracker who wants to kill you immediately following you. At this point, you just want to run into the nearest safe room. When you hear the beautiful melody, you breathe a sigh of relief. This safe room design and the overwhelming sense of relief are actually key elements that make horror games appealing. After experiencing an adrenaline rush and successfully escaping danger, with the release of dopamine, the player’s tension is relieved, muscles relax, and there is often an “electrified” effect after the fright.

Dolf Zillmann’s “Excitation-Transfer Theory” explains this cycle of tension and relief. Because horror games can effectively make players feel fear and unease, when they get rid of fear, the subsequent feeling of relief from excitement is amplified. This is why many games have safe room designs, not only to provide players with a safe haven from harm, but also to enhance the player’s emotions and strengthen the experience.

 

2. How to Awaken the Fear in Players’ Hearts?

So, since our bodies physiologically determine that when we face fear, a sense of excitement or fun will naturally follow the feeling of terror, how do games create horror?

In today’s horror games, even the traditional Western-style bloody and straightforward scares, which emphasize the visual horror created by zombies and mutants, are just auxiliary tools. Atmosphere and immersion are what games pursue, by finding resonance with players to achieve the purpose of engagement.

Environmental Design, Such as Music, Creates Illusions

Through modern medical scanning techniques, the brain regions involved in emotional processing, which in horror games correspond to fear recognition or processing, are most related to the amygdala and hippocampus.
