Horror games are not 100% jump scares and terrifying murders. Games like to leave you in suspense, which is where elements like suspense and sound design come into play. When eerie music enters the ears, even without directly seeing terrifying images and things, it sends a signal to our nervous system, the amygdala is activated to produce fear. At this time, we don’t have any background clues to explain what we should be afraid of, and the hippocampus will retrieve memories and fill in the blanks based on our personal fears.

 

Awakening the Nightmares Deep in Players’ Memories

So, what are we afraid of in our memories? Each cultural context has its own corresponding “nightmares”, such as the chainsaw murderers in Europe and America, Sadako in Japan, and Lady Dimitrescu in Resident Evil. These are often the design prototypes in various horror games. Or, like the ghost marriages and red candles and paper money in Chinese horror, we instinctively feel a chill and our hearts race. For example, most people are afraid of dimly lit environments, sudden ringing phones, baby cries, and other scenes, which are guaranteed to scare.

 

The most terrifying things often happen in familiar areas. When a horror game takes place in a familiar building, and the game creates a depressing atmosphere, accompanied by a slow-paced early game and a large number of puzzle-solving elements, then it gives the player a fatal blow at the climax of the plot. Although there are not so many sensory stimuli, it will make you replay it in your mind. This chilling fear is the most charming part of psychological horror, making countless players “unable to stop”.

3. Emerging Media Further Attract Players

In recent years, the resurgence of horror games, and the reboot trend, is also thanks to the rise of the streaming industry.

Horror games seem to be born for streaming, naturally suitable for creating content. Streamers have also perfectly interpreted “the more cowardly, the more addicted”. This has further promoted the prevalence of horror games in the streaming industry. After all, which streamer doesn’t like outstanding “streaming effects”? Unlike other games, narrative-based games require the entire playthrough to be watched for story appreciation, and strategy games require long-term experience to truly engage. Horror games are different. When streamers show their off-guard reactions on screen, it brings a strong sense of comedic contrast to the audience, while also driving traffic for the streamer and providing free advertising for the game, allowing horror games, which were once niche and only suitable for private experience, to reach a wider audience.

For example, popular Chinese horror games like Home Sweet Home and Paper Dolls have been played by well-known streamers like PDD, Qiezi, and even some esports players during their streams. Or, when searching for horror games on Bilibili, you will also find many videos of streamers playing or explaining the game. The rise of new media such as live streaming and video has indeed injected a boost into the horror industry.

 

As a viewer, when you have a favorite streamer who screams in terror while playing this game, you will naturally be interested in this game and take the initiative to learn about horror games. Human emotions are interconnected, and joy, anger, sorrow, and happiness can easily be spread to others through various forms. As a viewer, I might be scared to play, but I’m definitely not afraid to watch a stream. When the streamer is startled, the audience will also feel their palms sweat, which is also a kind of emotional connection.

4. Beware of Physiological Discomfort

Horror games, as a broad category, may include various gameplay forms in their core. However, in the external presentation of these games, developers need to be wary of cruel and extreme art design. Causing players physiological discomfort may detract from the visual experience. From the terrifying presentation of monsters, the basic principles of their construction, and the player’s coping methods, more in-depth design should be carried out, and early combination with player testing for corresponding adjustments can reduce the risk of negative reviews in later releases.

 

Last December, The Callisto Protocol, created by the main creators of Dead Space, was released and was considered by many players to be the spiritual successor to Dead Space. Although in terms of art design, the development team fully utilized the performance of next-generation consoles, and based on the company’s strengths (the producer is an art director), the visual effects were greatly improved, but some players experienced physiological discomfort and the singular horror and combat experience created by the game did not receive very good reviews.

5. Will Horror Continue?

For a game, repeatedly stacking horror elements does not guarantee success. As mentioned above, when players enter the feedback loop of expecting fear, sudden fright, and releasing happiness in the safe room, the fear response is constantly triggered. This feedback loop often exists in every horror game. After you face a hellhound that has scared you once, the second time you encounter a similar scene, your brain is prepared for that moment, just like a drug, you develop “tolerance.”

When we activate the fight-or-flight response, a complex neurotransmitter response is activated, producing a neurochemical cascade. Like drugs, long-term use requires more of the drug to produce the effect. Thrill-seeking players may also develop increased “fear tolerance,” thus requiring more and more fear stimulation to produce the desired response.

As most players say, a certain game has nothing new and is always “rehashing old ideas”. For horror games, if they want to endure and win the hearts of players, they also need to change the way they scare, otherwise players will only say “this plot design is the same as xxx”.

 

Currently, many horror games have attracted a lot of attention. However, the cruel fact contrary to high popularity is that most current horror games are critically acclaimed but not commercially successful. The reason is still simply “scares”. They are both afraid and curious, so instead of playing themselves, most people prefer to watch others play with the protection of bullet comments (referring to live comments that scroll across the screen on streaming platforms).

But now, with more expressive forms and gameplay attracting players to horror games, more and more players want to try them. Initially, they may be scared and develop resistance to the game, but now, after seeing new and unique horror elements and gameplay, they may develop new interest.

Perhaps horror games still cannot shake the market position of other game genres, but under the trend of the times, horror games still have great potential. We also look forward to more powerful technology, more diverse scenes and gameplay being introduced into horror games.

entry.title: How Can Interface and Interaction Help Players Quickly Get Started with a New Game
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

Besides the game’s own fun and playability, the speed at which novice players get started is also one of the major factors that determine the fate of a game. In the player’s onboarding phase, the game designer has a lot of information that needs to be communicated to the player, including the story background, game goals, basic operations, etc., which is the so-called “novice guidance”. The transmission of such information requires interaction designers to make ingenious designs to ensure its accuracy and fluency, so as to minimize the player’s memory burden, improve acceptance and onboarding efficiency, and then make the player have the willingness to continue playing.

This article will discuss several key points of interaction design that need to be paid attention to in novice guidance, and analyze them in combination with cases.

1. The Importance of Novice Guidance: Weakly Positive, Strongly Negative

First, we need to understand two related concepts. “Weakly positive” and “strongly negative”.

“Weakly positive” means that it is extremely difficult for novice guidance to gain the attention and favor of players. Although excellent novice guidance will allow players to complete the onboarding phase efficiently and smoothly, and have a willingness to continue playing the game, because it is a guide when entering a game, it does not occupy a dominant position like the game’s own plot advancement, so players do not often pay attention to this novice guidance, nor do they often pay attention to the changes in their attitude towards the game during this stage, and they do not often make positive comments such as “the novice guidance of this game is really good”.

“Strongly negative” means that if a novice guide is not done well, it is very likely to directly dissuade novice players. Novice guidance is equivalent to the gate of the whole game. If the threshold is too high, or the receptionist is too tough, leading visitors to visit hand in hand, and so on, visitors are very likely to become dissatisfied and leave. Novice guidance receives less attention, but it is particularly important.

2. Interaction Points and Guidance Method Analysis in Novice Guidance

Non-mandatory: Open Guidance

When encountering a new game, players often encounter “nanny-level” novice tutorials - the screen pauses, a conspicuous arrow appears on the interface to guide the player to click here (and only this place is interactive, unable to exit), and there are text descriptions of varying lengths. Obviously, this method is too rigid and will easily reduce the player’s favorability.

Furthermore, some players may have already learned about the game through other accounts, watching game videos, etc., so they do not need to learn the novice guidance, which designers cannot ignore.

Based on these two points, good novice guidance interaction should be non-mandatory and open. Players can freely explore in the game scene and spontaneously complete the learning of interaction methods. Of course, in some games under specific categories, or in some parts of the game’s novice guidance, mandatory guidance is more applicable, because this form can relatively effectively ensure that all players master and understand certain key mechanisms or story plots.

For example, in the game Stray, the play between kittens is used as the beginning of the story. Because it was raining at that time, the kittens’ activities were limited to the cave that could shelter from the rain, but in this space, players can freely explore and learn basic actions such as walking and interacting with other cats. Except for the necessary key prompts, there are no obvious interactions set in this scene, and players seem to have integrated into the open world of cats without human language.

 

Rainy night, players freely interact with NPCs in the cave

Learning Through Practice

Novice tutorials are not necessarily textbook-like systematic teaching. It can also break through the inherent form and integrate into actual combat, learning through practice. Therefore, what we describe as “novice tutorials” may be more appropriately referred to as “novice guidance”. Players gradually learn a variety of skills and gameplay as the plot progresses, which is very helpful for the smoothness and immersion of the game.

Necessary prompts and interactions should be integrated into the scene, which can be viewed by players at any time, and hardly affect the progress of their game.

In Human Fall Flat, there is no formed novice tutorial, but learning while playing. When players play for the first time, they will fall into one of the pre-selected maps - Mansion (of course it is the simplest of all maps), and directly start exploring the game world. During the process, players will occasionally encounter conspicuous orange items on the ground. When it is picked up, a projection screen-like floating animation appears in the scene, teaching players the relevant operations at this moment. Whether to pick it up and when to put it down is entirely up to the player, respecting and encouraging players to explore on their own.

 

Pick up the “tutorial video” to play the guidance content

In Toto Temple Deluxe, there is a very important dash action, which needs to be pressed “arrow keys + dash key” to complete. The training of this action has already begun before the game - game settings, mode selection and other preparations all need to control the villain to dash to complete the interaction.

 

Dash to complete interaction and action training

Ingenious Unconscious Design

To make the novice guidance more brilliant, it is necessary to design more hidden teaching elements and methods that players are not aware of.

Unconscious action is an action that a person can make without much thought and subconsciously. Unconscious design is an extremely simple design that captures this natural characteristic of users. It does not require a lot of artificially added interaction, and can quickly guide users to unconsciously complete a certain task. Applying it to the game novice tutorial can be roughly summarized as: using natural and ingenious implicit interaction to guide players.

In Stray, cans begin to appear on the kitten’s path, prompting the player to push them down from a height. At first, this action did not produce any feedback from the event. When the player was confused, they thought of the reality that kittens are like this, unreasonably pushing things off the table, cute and mischievous. This method not only evokes a strong resonance from the player, but also teaches the player the correct use of cans in the game. Then, a glass skylight blocked the way, and there happened to be a can on the high platform above it…

 

Itchy kitten learns to push the can down and break the glass to create an entrance

After clicking the confirm button in the Mega Man X menu, a small animation of the protagonist shooting a bullet will appear on the left side of the button. This implies that the “confirm button” represents “fire bullet”. After entering the game, the process of teaching players how to fire bullets is omitted.

 

Confirm key attack

From Surface to Core, Phased Teaching

● Player: Gradually Digest and Understand

Like the teaching of all knowledge and skills, game tutorials cannot output all the gameplay and rules of this game to novice players at once. When they first come into contact with new things, players need a process of understanding and acceptance. In this process, the game designer leads the player from easy to difficult, from simple to complex, and gradually enters the worldview of this game.

For example, one of the important contents of the ocean exploration game Dave The Diver is to go to the sea to fish. The game first teaches players the most basic left-click stab, and then long-press the right-click to shoot the harpoon, and then gradually teaches players to use various complex weapons. The number of skills mastered by players steadily increases during this period, and it is easier to obtain a sense of phased achievement.

 

① Stab

–.

 

② Harpoon

–.

 

③ Poison Harpoon

–.

 

④ Rifle

● Designer: Pay Attention to Interface Cleanliness and Logic

Phased teaching can better prompt designers to pay special attention to the conciseness and logic of information transmission.

It is conceivable that if the designer has not paid attention to this principle, it is very likely that a large amount of information will appear on the same interface at the same time in the game, making the player unable to start, not knowing which panel to read first, and what is the relationship between them.

Conversely, if the designer understands the principle of phased teaching from beginning to end, he will split, classify, and present the complicated information on this panel to novice players step by step according to a certain event logic. In this way, the process of players getting started with a new game will be more interlocked, like reading a story.

3. Summary

Game types can be subdivided almost infinitely, and there are too many to enumerate. Although many novice guidance principles are generally applicable to different games, it is not difficult to find some differences when comparing them carefully. For example, action-oriented games focus on the training of skills and combos, which may be integrated into various corners that players cannot imagine; puzzle-adventure games focus on allowing players to explore spontaneously, so as to minimize obvious guidance.

Excellent game novice tutorials need to respect the needs of players, allow players to explore on their own in a relatively free space, and naturally integrate prompts or interactions into the scene when necessary. In this way, the novice tutorial is sublimated, no longer in its inherent form, but perfectly integrated with the game itself, even reaching the level that players can hardly realize that this is a kind of teaching. Players gradually learn specific skills during the game, step by step, significantly improving the efficiency of getting started, and can more deeply experience the sense of phased achievement.

entry.title: Achievement Systems and IntrinsicExtrinsic Motivation – Do Players Really Need Trophies
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

Since Microsoft pioneered the achievement system in the early 20th century, game achievement systems have been an important part of the gaming community, but there have also been many questions. Game achievement systems were born as a tool to promote player engagement, but they have turned many players into pure “achievement hunters”. Do players really need achievement systems? From the perspective of motivation in psychology, perhaps we can get some different thoughts and inspiration.

1. Do players really need trophies?

Two months ago, Fredrik Thylander, lead game designer at Ubisoft Massive, said this on Twitter: “Unpopular opinion: achievements/trophies have been bad for gaming. It narrows games, it disrupts and diverts attention, it eats resources that could have made the game better..

 

Fredrik Thylander’s tweet on Twitter received attention from more than 200,000 players

Thylander’s speech sparked a lot of discussion among players, with both supporters and opponents. Supporters believe that achievements make players play games only for achievements. Many players don’t even enjoy the game well. They just open the guide and get one platinum trophy or achievement point after another. Some opponents believe that the existence of the game achievement system provides them with a goal to play the game, otherwise they may never challenge those high-difficulty or racing-type gameplays.

The good and bad of the achievement system is certainly not a monistic point of view. At least for many game developers and platforms, the existence of the achievement system has become an inseparable part. It can effectively extend the life of the game, guide players to experience the complete game design content, and provide players with a simple and direct game goal and positive feedback. But for players, the achievement system is not an insignificant prompt that pops up at the bottom of the game interface. As an external incentive mechanism, it profoundly affects the player’s motivation for the game. More and more players are beginning to question: Do we really need achievements?

2. Intrinsic/Extrinsic Motivation and the Overjustification Effect

The birth of the achievement system can be traced back to the 1980s Activision game Chopper Command, whose gameplay is very common flight shooting. But what’s more special is that if the player’s game score exceeds 10,000 points, the player can take a photo or video and exchange it for a special physical game badge from Activision. However, physical achievements are still a bit cumbersome, and soon achievements began to shift to the form of “electronic certificates”. The 1990 puzzle game E-Motion designed 5 “achievements” in the game. Players can get game points by completing all levels, which is the prototype of today’s achievement system.

The first cross-game achievement system was born in 2005, when Microsoft first launched the Gamerscore system on Xbox 360. Players can earn achievement points by completing game achievements on the platform, and points from different games can be accumulated. Subsequently, in 2008, Sony changed the score to a more intuitive trophy system. One achievement corresponds to one trophy. Players can unlock the platinum trophy as long as they obtain all achievements. Compared with points, trophies can more directly represent the player’s game completion and have become one of the most representative features on the PS platform.

 

(Trophy levels on PS: The player’s level is determined according to the quality and number of trophies obtained by the player)

Of course, players who play console games all year round also know that Nintendo games do not have an achievement system. In this regard, then-Nintendo director Shigeru Miyamoto said: “I don’t like to use external factors to attract people to invest time in games. I hope players play games just because they enjoy the game.”

The game concepts of Microsoft, Sony, and Nintendo correspond to the external motivation and internal motivation of players to play games.

Extrinsic motivation means that a person chooses to participate in an activity not because they like it very much, or because it can make you feel satisfied, but because this activity can bring some kind of reward or avoid some kind of punishment; Intrinsic motivation is directly related to the activity itself. Because doing something can stimulate people’s interest and make people happy, the activity itself is the goal pursued by the actor.

In recent years, many designers or players have questioned the value of the achievement system, largely because: as an external motivation provided by the manufacturer, game trophies can easily form an overjustification effect, reducing the player’s internal motivation.

The research on the overjustification effect began in the 1970s. In 1971, Edward Deci, a psychology professor at the University of Rochester, invited two groups of college students to complete intelligence tests. Experimental group subjects could get $1 reward for each problem solved, while control group subjects had no reward. Then observe whether the two groups of subjects will continue to solve problems after the test is over. The results found that although the experimental group worked very hard to solve problems, they obviously lost interest in solving problems after the test was over; while the control group would continue to solve problems after the test was over.

The overjustification effect represents the damage of external motivation to internal motivation. If too many external rewards are used to motivate individuals to do something they are willing to do, it will reduce their internal motivation. Because this will make this individual think that his motivation for behavior comes from the outside, and once the external motivation is lost, the individual will not continue to engage in this behavior.

In 2010, a speech at the Global Game Developers Conference (GDC), “Achievements Considered Harmful?”, proposed the harmful impact of the achievement system on players from this perspective. Achievements themselves exist as external incentives for the game, but with the achievement system, the game motivation of many players will gradually shift to unlocking trophies in the game. Players may gradually lose their love for the game on the way to unlocking trophies, and become pure “achievement hunters” or “platinum hunters”.

Platinum trophies provide a goal for many players, but they also limit many players to just getting trophies and showing them off on social media.

3. What kind of achievements are “good” achievements?

Since external motivation will damage the internal motivation of the game, should we completely abandon the achievement system?

In the study of the motivation system, Deci further tested the impact of “verbal rewards” on task motivation, and found that, compared with those without feedback, students who were told “you did a good job” showed an increase in intrinsic motivation on subsequent tasks.

Therefore, the overjustification effect is not inevitable. With more and more research, scholars have given clearer results on the relationship between external motivation and internal motivation:

  • Non-contingent external rewards (i.e., rewards that can only be obtained when the activity results reach a certain level) cause less damage to intrinsic motivation and produce more promotion than those contingent rewards (i.e., rewards that can be obtained as long as the activity is carried out);

    Non-contingent external rewards and contingent rewards correspond to two different types of achievements: assessment achievements and contingent achievements. Assessment achievement means that players will only be given specific rewards if they achieve a certain standard, such as our more common high-difficulty clearance achievements or level ratings. Contingent achievement is a reward that players will inevitably be given as long as they complete a certain event or process. Process rewards mostly belong to this.

    Because of their low acquisition difficulty, contingent achievements are difficult to form effective positive feedback on player behavior. At the same time, in recent years, the overall game difficulty has become more friendly, and necessary achievements are easily overused, which instead easily attracts players to focus on trophies rather than the game itself.

  • Unexpected rewards have a greater positive effect on intrinsic motivation than expected rewards;

    This division actually involves the design problem of the achievement system itself - should we hide the achievements or completely display them to the player. Aside from achievements hidden to avoid spoilers, most game achievements are still mainly explicit. Explicit achievements provide players with a relatively clear goal and a preliminary understanding of the game. Players are also more likely to simply plan their game path through game achievements. For example, in Slay the Spire, in addition to the conventional high-difficulty clearance achievements, some fancy clearance achievements will also be explicitly shown to players - the creator implies that players can choose to continuously increase the difficulty level of the game, or choose to challenge some strange clearance methods.

     

*(Fancy clearance achievements in the rogue-like card game "Slay the Spire")*

Compared with explicit achievements, hidden achievements appear less frequently in games, but they have a better promoting effect on players' internal motivation. Not letting players know the specific trophy content in advance, and giving players rewards when players accidentally trigger or curiously try some new content, can stimulate players' game fun more than directly telling players the achievement content. Because this kind of unexpected feedback is based on the player's own playing motivation, it will also encourage players to make more attempts and "unorthodox" gameplay.

  • Intangible external rewards produce more promotion and less weakening than tangible rewards;

    It is not appropriate to use intangible and tangible descriptions to evaluate the achievement system. After all, platinum trophies are not really “platinum”. For the achievement system, tangible/intangible actually lies in whether the achievement system carries other external values in addition to game incentives and self-satisfaction.

    For example, for many players, full achievements have always had a strong social significance.

    From the perspective of the game platform, the achievement system generally exists as part of the community system. You can clearly see the number of platinum trophies of this player in the PS personal profile; there is also a special “achievement showcase” on Steam for players to display their achievements. Single-player games themselves naturally lack interaction between players. For the core players of the platform, they always need something to show their “noble status”. This is also why single-player games pay more attention to the achievement system than online games. After all, online games have levels, combat power, and appearance, and single-player players want to prove that they are superior, and there is almost no other way but trophies.

     

In addition, when the platinum trophy has become a matter of "competitiveness", the nature of the matter will change differently.

There is a website called Astats, which will count the game achievements of the Steam platform in real time, as well as the number of achievements completed by players, and give rankings, providing an off-game PVP standard for steam achievement hunters. What kind of demand there is, there is what kind of product. There are many achievement-hunting games on Steam, represented by *Achievement Hunter*. Players basically only need to do nothing and hang up for two hours to unlock more than a thousand achievements in the game. These "games" themselves only serve the external value of achievements, and players no longer have any internal motivation for the game itself.

  


*(Achievement ranking on the Astats website, the highest-ranked player has completed 1.64 million achievements)*

4. Conclusion

Returning to our opening question, do players really need achievements? We might as well use a sentence from Hegel to answer this question:

“What is rational is actual and what is actual is rational.”

The gamerscore system, introduced in 2005, was intended to help boost activity among players and to get them to talk to each other more about the games. Two years later, Xbox 360 product manager Aaron Greenberg said, “And we found out that a lot of people were playing Xbox games a lot because we offered points and the other platforms didn’t.”

At least for most players now, the achievement system is still an inseparable part of the game itself. At the end of last year, Assassin’s Creed: Valhalla landed on Steam, and many negative reviews came from the fact that the game did not have an achievement system.

Of course, it’s not a big deal to have no achievements. Nintendo has always maintained an indifferent attitude towards achievements. They can add 999 “Korok Seeds” in Zelda. Whether players choose to collect them and how much they collect depends entirely on personal wishes. Therefore, for players, how to design achievements is far more important than whether there are achievements.

As an external motivation to motivate players, the achievement system itself has the risk of overjustification effect. However, adding moderate assessment achievements and hidden achievements to the game can not only avoid the overjustification effect, but also further stimulate the player’s internal motivation. Although it is difficult for us to avoid the existence of achievement PVP, most platforms now provide options to hide achievements or trophies. When we want to truly experience the game, we may also choose to turn on the options.

entry.title: How to Apply Gestalt Principles in Game Interface Design
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

1. Introduction

Although the user interface in video games is not the most shining part of the game, it carries the important function of conveying information to the player. In the process of industry development, the game content has become more and more rich, carrying more functions, and the elements on the interface are inevitably increasing. And how to organize their arrangement to clearly and intuitively convey information to players has gradually become an important proposition.

In the 1930s, three German psychologists established the Gestalt Principle based on the study of apparent motion. They applied the Gestalt Principle to aesthetics in a specific way, combined it with various psychological processes, and promoted aesthetic research with Gestalt tendencies.

And now, this principle can also well guide the design of game interfaces. This article will explain the eight principles of “Gestalt Principle” and their application in the game field one by one, to see how this nearly century-old law has insight into people’s perception of interface elements and applied it to game interface design.

 

*A game with an excellent user interface - The Division Series.

 

A game with a very stylized user interface - Persona 5

2. GESTALT: Gestalt Principles

“The whole is something else than the sum of its parts.”——Kurt Koffka

First, we need to understand what the Gestalt Principles are.

The Gestalt Principles describe how humans group similar elements, recognize patterns, and simplify complex images when perceiving shapes. It was founded by German psychologists Max Wertheimer, Wolfgang Köhler, and Kurt Koffka in the 1930s. Its name “GESTALT” is a German word, translated as “shape”. It is the principle/law of human perception. Gestalt psychologists emphasize that people perceive the overall form of graphics, not just individual elements. Therefore, if you want to summarize it in one sentence, it is Kurt Koffka’s “The whole is something else than the sum of its parts.” Interestingly, this famous saying is often mistranslated as Aristotle’s “The whole is greater than the sum of its parts,” which made Koffka himself laugh and cry.

In the long process of development and supplementation, the Gestalt Principles have also developed into a total of eight detailed principles, which describe the phenomenon of humans simplifying complex images when perceiving shapes in different situations.

 

Similarity

The definition of the principle of similarity is: when elements have the same visual characteristics, people think that these elements have a certain connection. These visual characteristics can include color, shape, size, font, texture, and so on.

It is worth noting that color is a particularly strong visual feature, and its effect on visual perception can often overwhelm other visual features and change the user’s perception of the whole. For example, in the figure below, observers tend to identify the following graphics as three rows or four columns based on the similarity of shapes.

 

However, if colors are added to the elements irregularly on the basis of the original image, observers will naturally think that the blue elements are a group and the white elements are a group. It can be seen that color has a dominant power in perception.

 

Therefore, cleverly using the similarity of visual elements in the game can greatly help players understand the functions of game elements and the connections between them without the need for extra teaching.

In the action music game HiFi RUSH, the protagonist Chai’s team will gradually welcome new partners during the adventure: the blue-clothed girl Peppermint, the green strong man Macaron, and the red-haired girl Korsica. All three have their own unique abilities to assist Chai in battle in the game and exploration outside the game. For example, the green strongman Macaron can break the green shield, and the red-haired girl Korsica can blow out the flames ejected by red enemies, and also overclock the red generator to assist exploration. Through the correspondence of colors, the correspondence between the partner color - monster color - exploration mechanism color in the game is clear at a glance, clearly and intuitively reducing the player’s cognitive load.

 

In “HiFi RUSH”, if there is no Macaron, Chai will not be able to cause damage to green enemies

Proximity

The definition of the proximity principle is: we tend to think of elements that are close together as a group or the same object, and other separated elements as another group or object.

 

In the figure above, the three stripes of the revised Logo on the left are far apart from each other, and cannot be considered as the same whole; but if the three stripes are placed very close, they obviously form a whole, forming a classic graphic with strong recognition.

Battlefield 1 is set in the battlefield of World War I. It is an FPS game that focuses on large-scale tactical competition. The battlefield can accommodate large-scale firefights of up to 32VS32. In the scoreboard page of Battlefield 1, the design of the proximity principle is well adhered to, so that the information of up to 64 people can be clearly presented, grouped, and perceived on the same page.

In the scoreboard interface of Battlefield 1, the designer first uses the vertical line + white space in the middle to divide the players into two major parts according to their camp.

For the data arrangement within each camp, in the horizontal direction, the data is divided into two major sections by proximity: off-game information and in-game information. Off-game information includes player level, player ID, etc., which are closely arranged on the left; in-game information includes captain star, troop type, KD data, score data, player delay, etc., which are closely or sparsely arranged on the right according to their relevance. In the vertical direction, the information of each player is closely arranged together, so that players can browse a certain piece of data at a glance, and convey the visual metaphor of close unity.

 

Battlefield 1

It is worth noting that since different resolutions will squeeze the white space between components to different degrees, designers need to carefully design them for application in different adaptation resolutions to maintain the correct relative proximity relationship between components under various resolutions.

Closure

The definition of the closure principle is: when people observe familiar visual images, they will perceive incomplete local images as a whole image. This perceptual ending is called closure.

For example, in the classic IBM logo in the figure below, we always perceive it as three letters at the first time, rather than several horizontally arranged rectangles and trapezoids.

 

And the following two pictures are not black pentagons and cones scattered everywhere, but a football and a spiked ball that naturally appear in your mind.

 

In video games, the principle of closure is also widely used in icon design, animation design, and other fields, subtly influencing users’ cognition behind the user interface:

Friends who have played Wo Long: Fallen Dynasty will not be unfamiliar with the following icon. It is the icon located in the lower right corner of the game loading interface, which means “loading”. The design of the icon fully utilizes the principle of closure. Although the dragon scales moving in the upper left and lower right corners are not connected into a circle, it is easy for players to imagine a majestic dragon circling around the rising sun. The giant dragon with only part of its body exposed also adds a touch of mystery, which secretly matches the psychological feeling of “Wo Long” (Crouching Dragon) hidden in the dark and蓄势待发 (poised for action).

 

*The Icon representing “loading” in “Wo Long: Fallen Dynasty”.

 

The loading interface of “Wo Long: Fallen Dynasty”, it will always accompany you in the lower right corner

Connectedness

The definition of the connectedness principle is: when elements are connected to each other, they are perceived as part of the same unit.

The connectedness principle is relatively strong, and even overwhelms the proximity principle in the example in the figure below: According to the proximity principle, we will regard 23, 45, and 67 as a whole.

 

But just by connecting a few magical lines in it, we will naturally regard 12, 34, 56, and 78 as a whol.

 

Such characteristics are often used on the tabs of the game menu bar. Kingdom Come: Deliverance is an open-world game set in medieval Europe. In the menu bar of this game, the tabs will be displayed in a darker gray color when they are not selected, and are separated from the main content list; the selected tabs will maintain the same color as the content list, and bridge the dividing line between the two, displaying as a complete parchment, so that players can clearly perceive that the current menu is the “food” menu. In order to fit the background era, the border and list of the game interface use stone brick material and parchment texture.

 

Kingdom Come: Deliverance Interface

Common Fate

The definition of the principle of common fate is: elements that move in the same direction and at the same rate are more easily identified as a whole.

The principle of common fate is the only one of the eight principles that involves movement and animation. Because of this, its influence on graphic recognition is extraordinary. For example, when cards slide, each card maintains the same direction and speed of movement, and the drop-down menu options expand vertically at the same rate, which are common designs on mobile Internet applications. By keeping the movement synchronized, designers can help users understand the relationship of grouped elements, thereby reducing the user’s cognitive burden. Similarly, when designers need to distinguish two elements, they only need to distinguish their movements to produce a great effect.

Devil May Cry V is a masterpiece of ACT games, and its scoring system is a representative part of the series. In the chapter scoring animation of Devil May Cry, the first three scoring sub-items slide out to the right at the same rate. Without other information, players can perceive the parallel relationship between the three items in a whole; while the last item, the total score, although in the same direction, slides at a relatively slow rate, effectively distinguishing it from the scoring sub-items, and arousing the player’s expectations with a longer pre-appearance, further enhancing the positive feedback after knowing the score.

 

Devil May Cry V

Continuity

The principle of continuity states that elements arranged on continuous smooth lines are more relevant than elements on straight lines or curves.

The principle of continuity mainly refers to the influence of whether the curvature change of the line is sharp on the overall perception. In the figure below, the observer’s line of sight is likely to follow two routes: a smooth curve from top left to bottom right, or a horizontal straight line from left to right. In other words: as long as the curvature changes of the intersecting lines are significantly sharp enough, the possibility of confusing the two lines will be reduced.

 

The 2016 Independent Games Festival award-winning work Mini Metro is a puzzle strategy game where players need to build an efficient rail transit network for a rapidly developing city over time. Even though the game has removed most of the redundant elements on the interface, there are still a considerable number of subway lines crossing each other in the later stages of the game. However, Mini Metro goes against the principle of continuity, designing the shapes of subway lines to be angular, and using bold colors to distinguish them, so that players will hardly spend effort in distinguishing between two lines, while keeping the arrangement of game elements elegant and clear.

 

Figure/Ground

The Figure/Ground principle states that people instinctively decompose graphics, photos, logos, websites, movie screens, and other actual life scenes into “figure” and “ground”, thereby simplifying the image, saving time, and reducing cognitive burden. The most famous and intuitive example is an interesting optical illusion art, the Rubin vase designed by Danish psychologist Edgar Rubin in 1915: whether the subject of the picture is a vase or a face depends on whether you see the graphic as white or black.

 

For designers, the most important thing is to clearly distinguish between the figure and the ground in order to guide attention to the key elements of the interface, provide visual cues, and prevent any confusion for the user, thereby keeping the user’s attention on the key information.

In Wo Long: Fallen Dynasty, players will reach the Banner of Chivalry point for rest after a battle. At this time, the game is paused, and external dangers will not affect the protagonist. Wo Long then performs grayscale and semi-transparent processing on the game screen of the big world at this time, turning it into the “background” in the visual relationship. At this time, the player’s attention is also attracted to the more critical camp rest operation that has become the “figure”.

 

Wo Long: Fallen Dynasty Game Interface

Common Region

The Common Region principle states: elements within a boundary are perceived as a group and are assumed to have a common feature or function.

The Common Region principle usually overrides weaker principles, such as the proximity principle or the similarity principle. Therefore, when designers deal with a variety of UI elements or have no space to adjust the white space, the Common Region principle will become a powerful weapon.

For example, in the table below, due to the proximity principle, the table below may be misinterpreted as classifying information by category, arranging it in columns, and dividing the three types of information of “University”, “Country”, and “Time Zone” into three groups. At this time, the proximity principle may interfere with your judgment.

 

But when the designer adds spaced zebra stripes to them, the overall relationship is very clear: each group of “University”, “Country”, and “Time Zone” information is arranged in a row relationship, expressing the country and time zone where each university is located. Even if the row spacing is much smaller than the column spacing, the observer will not misinterpret it as arranged in columns.

 

After adding zebra stripes, can you recognize which information is a group faster?

In video games, which have a richer form of information transmission, the Common Region principle has more multi-dimensional means. The game map of The Division is divided into multiple areas. When the area is irregular and there is no space for white space, the designer uses the flickering effect of the area filling and the red borders that separate each other to clearly and directly depict the current area and the dividing line between different areas, and also integrates the uneven buildings in the map into abstract areas named by humans.

 

The Division

3. Conclusion

The Gestalt Principle is already a “centenarian”. Since its introduction, it has been widely used in graphic design, product design, website design, and other fields. As a general design principle and guideline, it helps designers create more attractive, easy-to-understand, and organized designs. The idea of “the whole is not the sum of its parts” contained in it has not become outdated due to the changes of the times. Instead, it has stood firm in the long river of time and has endured for a long time.

As a new art form, games have added the dimension of interaction in addition to vision and hearing. The new characteristics and new problems in them are very worthy of scrutiny. The laws and principles that have been verified by the long river of time are the handy weapons for designers to overcome obstacles in the new era.

entry.title: How Do Socially-Inclined Korean Gamers Influence Game Localization
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

According to the “2022 Korea Game White Paper” released in January 2023 by the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism and the Korea Creative Content Agency, in 2021, the global market share of Korean games reached 7.6%, second only to the United States, China, and Japan. It is the fourth largest game market in the world, with an annual consumption of 20.9913 trillion won (about 109.6 billion yuan). This figure is expected to reach 22.7 trillion won in 2022.

As a mainstream region for games to go overseas, many domestic companies are targeting the huge potential market of South Korea and launching localized game versions. In the localization process, it is necessary to have a deeper understanding of the characteristics of local players and make corresponding adjustments. Socially, players like in-game social interaction and also value communication in the game community. An in-depth understanding of the characteristics and needs of Korean game players can provide more targeted help for game localization.

1. Social Characteristics of Korean Games

Many players like to socialize in games, and Korean games also take advantage of this, encouraging players to cooperate or compete with other players. They generally provide a variety of social functions in the game, such as chat rooms, teams, and guilds, and support players to share game experiences in the game community to meet players’ social needs. This not only enriches the game content, but also promotes communication between players, and is an important means to improve player stickiness and loyalty.

Social Methods

Many players regard games as a way of socializing, maintaining friendships and making new friends through games, expanding their social circle.

For many Korean players, games can be a way of socializing. Newzoo’s 2022 Korean player report shows that the biggest reason Korean players play games is for social interaction (18%). Playing games with friends can both kill time and enhance relationships. Therefore, most Korean games also incorporate social elements. For example, some games integrate the communication function of the social chat software Kakao, which can contact and add Kakao friends, and provide exclusive emoticon stickers for Kakao users, which is a relatively effective social marketing strategy.

 

According to the “2022 Korea Game Player Status Survey Report” (hereinafter referred to as the player survey), among PC game players, in addition to “relieving stress” and “killing time”, 30.2% of players choose “playing games with friends and family”. This ratio is higher among young players, and also shows that players in their 10s to 30s pay more attention to the social attributes of games.

 

However, this ratio is only 13.4% among mobile game players. However, in addition to the convenience of mobile phones and the fun of the game itself, the second most important element for mobile game players is social interaction.

 

In addition, for mobile game players, 28.5% of players will use direct recommendations from friends as a reference for downloading new games, which is as important as the app store (Google Play, App Store, One Store) ranking reference. It can be seen that friends’ recommendations are an important factor that cannot be ignored. Playing the social element card well is also conducive to the game gaining more new players.

 

Korean PC bangs (internet cafes) are also an important part of their game industry, and the social nature of Korean PC bang players is particularly significant. According to a player survey, 57.3% of people who go to PC bangs to play games do so to play games with friends/colleagues.

 

In fact, in the post-epidemic era, the trend of game social interaction has been reflected in players around the world. A study by Ipsos in conjunction with “Google for Games”, <2022 The Shifting Needs of Global Mobile Gamers>, shows that many players build connections with others through mobile games. Although people have gradually resumed offline social activities after the epidemic, online social habits have remained, and more and more players tend to communicate with others in games, replacing some offline social interactions. Sometimes, friends in the game even feel closer than acquaintances in life. Especially for Korean players, the game motivation of “having a common topic with others”, which is related to social purposes, has become stronger in the past year. It can be seen that players are paying more and more attention to the social attributes of games.

 

In Newzoo’s research on game driving forces, it was found that the reasons for Chinese players’ gaming behavior are also relatively obvious. Games involving competition, exploration, and strategy are more directly attractive to players, while social purposes are lower than these factors. Another Newzoo survey of Japanese players shows that the three main motivations for Japanese players to play games are “relaxation and stress relief” (50%), “filling free time” (49%), and “exploring the game storyline” (45%). Only 13% of players play for social reasons (global average 25%), and only 11% play for the sense of competition and the joy of victory. It can be seen that emphasis on competitiveness and social interaction is more obvious in Korean players.

 

Game Communities

Secondly, the development of game communities has also become a favorable booster for player communication, including game forums, offline activities, and other forms. Korean game communities have developed rapidly, providing players with game-related information, functional, and interactive services. In South Korea, the local game unofficial communities with a relatively large number of users include DCinside, inven, and ruliweb. In the April popular community ranking, two pure game communities (inven, ruliweb) occupied the top five. The top-ranked comprehensive community, DCinside, also has a dedicated game section. These communities provide players with a more free discussion space, where they can find game content that players are more concerned about, and problems encountered by players, which helps to follow up on player feedback and public opinion.

 

For example, Naraka: Bladepoint, as a high-quality martial arts battle royale game, requires team cooperation and communication. Naraka’s Korean players have spontaneously established game groups on Discord, DC, and Kakao, sharing game-related information, sharing operations, displaying drawn skins and character customization data, discussing update information, helping other players solve various problems encountered during the game, and also looking for teammates to form teams, and even participating in competitions together. These forums or communities provide a platform for players to communicate, discuss the latest event plans, observe the operations of experts, find teammates to play together, and extend the feelings in the game to outside the game. A good community atmosphere is also conducive to attracting players and improving player retention.

At the same time, the community is also a window for game developers to communicate with players. Games that listen carefully to player feedback in forums, respect player opinions, and make timely improvements can also gain player recognition. For example, Smilegate’s MMORPG LOST ARK received many negative reviews on image quality, automatic combat, balance, etc. when it was first launched, but the development team promised players that it would make improvements, and after the update, it solved more than 90% of the problems and removed the content that players did not like. After the Season 2 update, the game’s daily visits increased by 122%, new players increased by 542%, and returning players increased by 213%. The development team even received support advertisements from players. Players highly praised Smilegate’s effective communication and active community operation.

Esports Culture

Third, the booming esports culture in South Korea is also an important part of its game social interaction. Many players pay attention to esports events and enjoy the social experience brought by the game by participating, watching, and commenting on esports events.

South Korea has played a significant role in promoting the development of esports. In 1998, StarCraft changed the landscape of the Korean game industry. Under the influence of the Asian financial crisis, the esports industry attracted the attention of capital and ushered in huge development. The concept of professional players was born. After the financial crisis, the Korean esports industry also received government support. Now, Korean esports has formed a relatively mature industrial model and is also an important part of Korean game culture. Esports competitions are very popular in South Korea and have a large audience. Korean players’ love and attention to esports are also very high. Esports activities are both competition events and social activities. Players watch esports live broadcasts, comment and communicate, reflecting Korean players’ enthusiasm for game competition.

 

2. Localization Suggestions

It can be seen that the Korean game market has huge potential and is also one of the important landing points for games to go overseas. Therefore, when launching games overseas, it is also necessary to fully understand the characteristics and preferences of local players, and deeply customize them during research and development, localization, and continuous operation, so that they can be welcomed by more players in the local market.

Community Operation Outside the Game

First, it is necessary to pay attention to community operation, focus on community building and interaction, and encourage players to share game experiences and insights.

Korean game communities have diverse forms and rich content, and different types of communities have a wide range of influence among Korean game players. Players share game guides and exchange game experiences in game forums, which can not only improve their game skills, but also promote interaction and social interaction between game players. By holding various activities such as competitions and lucky draws, mobilizing players’ enthusiasm can not only enhance players’ feelings, but also deepen the connection between players and the game.

In-Game Social Gameplay

Secondly, the gameplay should also consider the social needs and habits of Korean players. StarCraft set off a wave of Korean game competition in the last century, driving the development of PC bangs and allowing players to experience the joy of competition in the game. Nowadays, the RTS, FPS, and MMORPG games that Korean players love also pay attention to the social needs of players. Strengthening players’ sense of belonging to guilds and teams, developing interesting multiplayer gameplay and team gameplay, convenient chat and friend systems, friend trading, reasonable ranking and achievement systems, etc., will give players a better experience.

In-depth research on Korean players before release and during continuous operation will help accurately capture the differences in social needs of different player groups and help the game better establish a player social network in South Korea. In the game, communicating, exploring, and cooperating with partners to complete difficult tasks and win over other opponents, so that high-quality games can build a bridge for players’ friendship, may also be an important meaning of the game itself.

3. Summary

Players in various countries have user characteristics that cannot be ignored. To do a good job in localization, it is also necessary to have a deeper understanding of players, grasp player needs, and provide corresponding services according to the game in order to better retain players and achieve common growth. Games are an important part of Korean players’ social lives. Players value in-game social interaction, friend communication, actively participate in game communities, and enjoy the fun of esports. In the process of localization, you can start from two aspects: in-game social interaction and out-of-game social marketing. Develop convenient friend and guild systems in the game, actively maintain the community outside the game, improve player stickiness, consider players’ social needs, and formulate strategies that are consistent with the characteristics of the game itself while taking into account players’ social habits.

Of course, the most core competitiveness is undoubtedly relying on high-quality content, including the core of key gameplay and the appearance of exquisite art. On this basis, targeted adjustments made for local players can be the icing on the cake.

entry.title: Naraka Bladepoint Japanese Community Research - Focusing on 5chan
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

With the spread and rise of video games in modern society, the term “game community” related to video games has gradually entered the public eye. In today’s increasingly globalized world, the overseas expansion of games has become an indispensable part of the development of the game industry. Therefore, investigating the “game communities” of players in target regions, and subsequently formulating appropriate strategies for game distribution and subsequent operations, has become increasingly important.

The “game community” is a subset of the concept of “virtual community”. “Virtual community” was first proposed by Howard Rheingold, meaning “a group of people who primarily communicate with each other through computer networks, who have a certain degree of shared cognition, share knowledge and information, and care for each other to a large extent as friends, thus forming a group”. Unlike the traditional concept of community, “virtual community” originates from computers, is built in the virtual world, and develops on the Internet. The “game community” derived from the concept of “virtual community” refers to a group that spontaneously gathers on the Internet around the common interest of games.

The Naraka: Bladepoint Japanese community in this article is a group of Japanese players who have spontaneously gathered around the game. Due to the diversity of network platforms, game communities also have various forms of expression. In Japan, mainstream game communities include Twitter, 5channel (also known as 2channel, hereinafter referred to as 5ch), Lobi, and so on. Because each platform has its own characteristics and functions, the game communities formed by players will also show different characteristics.

 

1. User Characteristics of 5chan

When accessing the Japanese Internet, especially cultural and community activities, 5chan and its user base are impossible to ignore. 5chan, formerly known as “2channel” (2ch.net, hereinafter referred to as 2ch), was founded by Hiroyuki Nishimura in 1999 and is Japan’s largest anonymous forum (now no longer completely anonymous). Its initial purpose was to serve as an alternative website to “Amezou Bulletin Board”. Amezou Bulletin Board was a comprehensive forum that aggregated multiple posts, and adopted the then-epoch-making “thread float type bulletin board” format (posts that received replies would be pushed to the top of the thread, while posts that did not receive replies would sink relatively, and posts with no response at all would sink to the bottom).

Later, Amezou Bulletin Board was closed in 2000 due to lack of functionality, server instability, and other reasons, and a large number of users poured into 2ch. In 2014, the actual management authority of 2ch (2ch.net) was transferred to James Arthur Watkins, Hiroyuki Nishimura was dismissed, and “2channel” (2ch.sc) was established. In 2017, “2channel” owned by James Arthur Watkins was renamed “5channel” (5ch.net).

5chan, which was opened in 1999, absorbed the habits of previous forums in terms of users, content, and forum terminology. The communication method of avoiding collusion among users and using unique jargon (later called 2ch terminology) was strongly influenced by electronic forums in the dawn of the Internet, namely the “dark web”.

In addition to the particularity of communication, 5chan also contains many opinions and information that cannot be seen in newspapers, television, or well-known media, and shows a critical attitude towards specific media such as Asahi Shimbun. Many people believe that “if I have to say, there is more negative information on 2ch. Because it is a vent for the negative personality of human beings, it is reasonable to degenerate into a garbage dump”.

In Tomohisa Hirai’s “Investigation of 2ch Communication: Discussion on the Internet and its Public Opinion Formation”, he summarizes the users of 2ch into the following 3 characteristics:

Desire for Self-Expression: Breaking Free from Social Constraints

Compared with face-to-face communication, Computer Mediated Communication (CMC) gives communicators (the actors themselves) more room for deliberation and choice. In face-to-face communication, communicators can express themselves through speech, body movements, clothing, etc., but it is difficult to manipulate self-expression related to physical characteristics such as gender, race, and age. In most cases, communicators themselves will also suppress self-expression behaviors that deviate from the unified values or behavioral norms of society. Communicators in CMC will be in a situation that is more free relative to norms. In addition, the “anonymity” and “ease of participation and withdrawal” that form and maintain the communication environment in which communicators are located also have a certain impact in CMC.

Personal communication on the Internet is a liberation from social constraints, and 2ch provides an environment of “anonymity” and “availability to join and leave at any time”. Because 2ch guarantees that users can be liberated from social restrictions, users can carry out communication that is rarely expressed in daily life. Some players may indeed feel dissatisfied with certain aspects of a game, but it is not appropriate to complain about it in the game’s social network or discuss its negative factors in depth. Some players will express their opinions on anonymous platforms with relatively few restrictions, thereby achieving self-expression.

Anonymous Communication: Refer to the SIDE Model

Research related to the SIDE model is based on the hypothesis that “the lack of personal cues will make participants have a higher sense of group in their personal identity and mutual behavior, and increase their trust in the group and related rules”, with the purpose of investigating “anonymous CMC situations”. The method is to observe the group set in the laboratory. The observation results can be summarized as “in the case of anonymous communication with clear group characteristics, participants are often forced to be depersonalized. The result is that personal consciousness is lower than the consciousness as a group member. From the perspective of enhancing group member consciousness, two views can be derived: ① If the “group member” consciousness is higher than the “personal consciousness”, participants tend to obey situational norms. ② When participants are aware of their group identity, they tend to favor the internal group, discriminate against the external group, and have higher hostility towards the external group. And these characteristics can be found in 2ch.

Formation of Internal Groups and Social Background: Refer to the Communication of Young People after the 1990s

In the communication of young people after the 1990s, one effective view is “valuing relationship”. In other words, compared to conveying content, communicators pay more attention to the communication itself with others, that is, “communication for the sake of communication”. In the view of sociology, young people after 1995 have little resonance with the value system of mass media, but value the relationship with friends who are close to them. Similarly, although young people are more sensitive to the nature of their relationships with friends, they often enjoy this relationship. Young people are more concerned about intimate relationships, but more indifferent to the outside of intimate relationships.

In summary, the overall user profile of 5chan can be summarized as: young people who gather together due to the same interest, have a desire for self-expression, value internal relationships, have exclusionary psychology towards external groups, have stronger cohesion within the forum, and are more active in communication.

2. Functional Features of 5chan

When studying the potential game community of 2ch, it is necessary to not only focus on the user characteristics of the entire 2ch forum, but also combine the functional characteristics of the 2ch forum itself.

Currently, 5chan has 39 main boards, and the main boards are further divided into sub-boards. Among them, there are three main boards related to games, namely games, mobile games, and online games. Under the main board, the platform will make a more detailed classification of games according to the type of game. The game board covers a wider range of games and contains more sub-boards. Users can click on the corresponding sub-board to enter the section after judging according to the type of game they want to browse.

 

After entering a sub-board, you can first see the content and theme discussed in the board. In order to prevent users from going to the wrong board and posting in the wrong place, links to connected or easily confused boards will be marked.

For example, Naraka: Bladepoint belongs to the PC Action (PC action game) section, and the content discussed is all FPS, TPS, and action games running on Windows and other computers. Please go to other sections for other types of games, such as adult-oriented Galgames, online games, etc. Like Baidu Tieba, the board rules and posting rules are located at the top for new users to use.

[Do not reply to any troublemaking, inciting, prohibited topics, hit-and-run, or useless posts >(repliers are also regarded as troublemakers)]

[Please confirm before posting]

  • This is a public place. Please do not create useless posts unrelated to PC action games.
  • Please confirm that you have not posted in the wrong section.
  • Please search the [Post Overview] again to confirm that no one has posted duplicate or similar posts.
  • Series works should be posted in a unified post. Niche games should be based on the manufacturer.

Crimes, illegal copying, software exchange, emulators, pornography, yellow jokes, attacks on fixed nicknames and individual players, and repeaters are prohibited.

 

This ensures that users who enter a certain post are first of all interested in the field where the post is located or have already understood it, and can communicate with people who have the same interest, and the speeches in the communication process follow the same forum rules and themes. Secondly, due to the secrecy of the retrieval system and the anonymity of users, 5chan is distinguished from some popular social media such as Twitter and completely open communication communities such as Discord.

In addition, due to the characteristics of the forum, the content of users’ speeches on 5chan will also be different from other communities. As mentioned above, the exclusionary psychology of 5chan users is reflected in the rules of the forum. They often prohibit new players from directly posting duplicate content without reading previous posts, or posting some content that is not worth posting separately. We believe that the rules that new users first read after entering 5chan will give them a feeling of entering an internal group from the public world, which will make them naturally abide by the rules of the internal group, otherwise they will be expelled by the internal group. The process of browsing the post history is not only a process of learning the rules of the internal group, but also a process of gradually recognizing their identity as an internal member.

In addition to the characteristics of user speeches, when searching for information on social media such as Twitter, it is usually a direct search or following some related tweeters. This will make users browse more than communicate even if they are interested in a certain field on social media. Even if they tweet to ask some content, they may not be answered. The unique Japanese habit of “FF-gai kara shitsurei shimasu” (I’m sorry to comment without following you or being followed by you) will also make the communication lengthy and complicated, and whether or not to follow will get a lot of redundant information that they don’t want. However, in a separate post of a certain game on 5chan, the desire for communication among members who belong to this internal group is greater than their desire for browsing, and the various conveniences of the forum also ensure that members can speak and discuss freely under the constraints of regulations. Therefore, the communication of users on the forum is more prosperous, and the feedback on the game will be directly posted on the forum.

 

3. Naraka: Bladepoint in 5chan

The Naraka: Bladepoint thread in 5chan was created on November 12, 2020 during the game’s internal test, which triggered players’ discussions about the initial hero strength. Since the game had not yet been released, the thread also became inactive. In April 2021, the game was tested again, and because it was possible to directly experience the game, the discussion about the game in the thread was also more active. Players’ discussions during the game test can directly reflect the players’ real views on the game, guiding the development team to further improve the content of the game.

After the game was officially released, the discussion of the game was directly focused on the essence of the game - gameplay. In Japan, the solo mode of Naraka: Bladepoint is classified as a fighting game, and the release method of the character’s ultimate, the strength of the character, and the combos of various weapons have been discussed. For the parts other than the gameplay itself, the battle pass, and the face customization function, which is one of the hot spots of the game, can only be said to be rarely discussed. In addition to the discussion focused on the gameplay itself and the exchange and discussion of game techniques, unlike other communities, this is not a platform for making friends, so there is no pure personal showing off and unprovoked insults to other players, and due to the high degree of participation and cohesion, the questions raised by players can also be answered.

 

Compared with other social media, such as Twitter and Weibo, the visible range of content posted is filtered, requiring keyword searches or following someone, and the lack of anonymity and other functions also leads to users being unlikely to get interaction. Even if they can participate in the discussion in real time, it is difficult to form a discussion atmosphere where many people express their opinions on the same issue. In addition, due to visibility, word count limits, and disagreement with others, negative impressions posted on open large-scale social media may also cause disgust and lead to disputes. In contrast, 5chan first filters the participants in the discussion - players who have a certain understanding of Naraka: Bladepoint. Secondly, the anonymity, functions, and its own cohesive characteristics of the forum make the discussion here more active and real, showing the players’ gaming experience, rather than meaningless complaints, spam, or recruitment information.

4. Conclusion

When understanding overseas game trends through research and capture of game communities, and then feeding back to game development, it is first necessary to understand the composition and characteristics of overseas communities in the target country. On the basis of further understanding user needs, apply them to the improvement of the game. The communities of each country will show different characteristics in their own culture and the evolution of Internet history, which is also a part worth paying attention to. How to use the characteristics reflected in the communities of each country to promote the game is also a topic that needs to be considered when expanding influence through communities.

entry.title: Why Do Players Turn a Blind Eye? Novice Guide Design from the Perspective of Selective Attention
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

In game research, we found a common phenomenon: when players experience new games or new gameplays, they often complain that the game’s guidance is unclear and they don’t understand how to play; on the other hand, the developers feel very confused. There is obviously a long introduction to the gameplay in the game, so why do players feel that the guidance is not enough?

Some veteran players also feel that new players are particularly “blind and unskilled” when they team up with new players to play dungeons. Even if the information is obvious, the novice will say that they did not see it.

So, how does this “blindness” of players come about? Do they really not see it, or do they not want to see it?

1. How Common is “Not Seeing”?

When players are doing novice training, they need to go through the following steps to finally master the gameplay: I see the guide, I know I need to do this, I do it, I learn it. And if any of these steps are missing, it will cause the player to fail to learn.

In the initial research expectation, we believed that players getting stuck in the novice stage might be more difficult in “completing the guide”, that is, the task settings need to be adjusted. However, subsequent eye-tracking tests showed that more players were stuck in the first two steps, that is, the players did not see the guide at all, and this was not because the players were unwilling to read the novice guide. In the test, even if players were required not to skip the guide and to follow the guide prompts, they would still miss a lot of information.

Psychological research also confirms that this “invisibility” of players is not only common, but also innate, and is related to the selective attention mechanism.

2. Why Can’t Players “See”? The Characteristics of Attention Determine That People Only See What They Want to See

If the human brain is a TV set, external information is various TV programs, and attention is the process of selecting TV programs. Only the TV programs that finally appear on the screen can be noticed by us. Although in many cases people can consciously choose which programs to watch, in many cases, this choice is subconscious. Among them, those that do not require will effort and that people can naturally pay attention to are called involuntary attention. For example, it is difficult not to hear the ringing of a mobile phone in a quiet meeting room; a red flower in a green lawn will be more conspicuous than a green flower. The act of paying attention that requires will effort and needs to be actively made is called voluntary attention, such as reviewing homework before an exam, learning some useful but boring new knowledge, etc.

It is theorized that involuntary attention is a subconscious response and does not occupy psychological resources; but voluntary attention requires the player’s resources.
