Player feedback on both mechanisms is very controversial.

 

Bundled Sales

Bundled sales include three forms:

  • Discounted purchase: When consumers purchase product A, they can purchase product B at a price lower than the market price;
  • Unified price sale: Product A and product B are not priced separately, but are sold at a bundled unified price;
  • Unified packaging sale: Product A and product B are sold in a unified package.

The binding and mandatory nature of the three forms increase in turn. An important condition for unified price sales and unified packaging bundled sales is the complementarity between products. For example, the bundling of a set of fashion, or the bundling of various props required for a certain task. The complementarity between these products is strong enough, and bundled sales are a win-win situation for game revenue and player experience. However, it is counterproductive to adopt or bundle products that are not complementary or even have no complementarity.

In our research, players often give feedback that they are not satisfied with the content of the gift pack. Even for the same gift pack, the parts that different players are not satisfied with are also different. The gift pack content that this player thinks is redundant and a waste of money may be the reason why another player buys the gift pack. And this separation also shows that the bundling of this kind of gift pack has failed. Not only is there no complementarity between the different contents of the gift pack, but the target users are also too different. It is not recommended to adopt the strong binding method of unified price sale or unified packaging sale for this kind of combination. It is more suitable for the bundling method of discounted purchase, giving consumers the freedom to choose.

 

Probability Consumption

According to expected utility theory, players’ satisfaction with probability consumption is related to their personal risk utility function. In economics and finance, the risk preferences of market participants are divided into three categories: risk averse, risk neutral, and risk appetite, and it is believed that most people are risk-averse.

The utility function of risk averters is strictly concave, as shown in the figure below, U(E(W)) > E(U(W)).

 

For example, when there are two options:

  • Get 50 yuan
  • 50% chance of getting 0 yuan, 50% chance of getting 100 yuan

Even if the average return is the same, risk averters will prefer “certain 50 yuan” rather than the risky option, that is, “the utility of 50 yuan” is greater than “the average of the utility of 0 yuan and the utility of 100 yuan”. The utility of the latter is only equivalent to “the income brought by certain CE (for example, 40 yuan)”.

According to the decision weight function of prospect theory, the decision weight of small probability events will be higher, which explains why people buy lottery tickets and are willing to draw prizes in the game for the small probability of winning the jackpot.

 

RP in the figure is the risk premium, that is, the difference between the determined income and the income from taking risks, which is the compensation required by investors for taking risks themselves. For risk averters, in the face of probability consumption such as lottery, probability enhancement, etc., in order to obtain the best or successful enhancement, the amount of probability consumption they are willing to pay will be less than their inner pricing of the target, and the difference is the risk premium.

Therefore, players will complain more during probability consumption: only when “the pricing of the drawing result” ≥ “the amount of probability consumption + risk premium” can it be possible to bring better psychological benefits than certain consumption. This also shows that the pricing of the guaranteed goods in the guarantee mechanism of probability consumption, or the expected price of consumers, needs to match “the amount of consumption + risk premium” in order to bring a satisfactory consumption experience.

3. Summary

Players’ consumption habits are different, and they are accompanied by differences in consumption timing, types of consumed props, and consumption amount. Based on this, the supply quantity and rhythm of game props need to be reconsidered to further meet consumer demand. In terms of sales strategies, although bundled sales and probability consumption have become widely used methods in games, through consumer feedback and related theoretical research, from the perspective of optimizing consumer experience, the application of the two methods still has shortcomings. Bundled sales can be improved through simple and effective improvement methods, while the optimization method of probability consumption still needs further research and investigation.

entry.title: A Psychological Perspective on Game Review Sections
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

Today, online reviews are an important channel for consumers to obtain product information, and their importance is even increasing. As the “trendsetters” of the Internet, game players are also active in major game review lists, forums, official Weibo accounts, super topics… Their comments on the game are a manifestation of the game’s reputation, and will become a reference for other players and even affect whether new players are willing to try it out.

When a player wants to see game-related news, they may go to TapTap to see the ratings, they may go to Weibo to see the hot topics, they may go to Tieba to see the guides, or they may go to the official account to see related news… What kind of impact do these TapTap ratings, comments under Weibo posts, and posts in Tieba have on viewers? This article starts from a psychological perspective, combining some psychological theories and examples to explain the interesting phenomena in the game review section.

 

1. Is a Picture Worth a Thousand Words?

Pictures and text are two main forms of reviews. People usually think that pictures are more convincing than text, the so-called “no picture, no truth”, but in the game field, are picture reviews also more effective than text reviews?

When players read reviews, it is actually a process of receiving, processing, and interpreting information. In psychology, there is a dual processing theory of widely disseminated information that can explain this process. This theory describes that in the process of information processing and decision-making, there are two independent but mutually influencing systems - the analytical system and the experiential system. The analytical system is biased towards the ideal, and requires relatively large cognitive resources to integrate information, and the process is relatively slow; while the experiential system is fast and relatively superficial.

After understanding the information processing process, let’s look at picture reviews and text reviews. For everyone, pictures are more concrete and intuitive than text. We can see the prominent content from the picture at a glance; while text can describe more essential information, but it requires a certain amount of reading and time to understand, and is more abstract than pictures.

Regardless of the specific content, under the influence of the characteristics of different types of reviews, pictures can relatively activate the players’ experiential system, while text can activate the players’ analytical system. In this case, games, as a hedonic sensory product, picture reviews can provide some specific and intuitive player feelings, matching the fast experiential system processing path. Therefore, in the game review section, picture reviews are often more likely to influence players’ emotions than text reviews, that is, they are more effective. If the game is not a hedonic and sensory product, but a practical product, then text reviews are more useful than a “fancy” picture.

 

Of course, the real review section will not be like a psychology laboratory, with only single text reviews or picture reviews. There are also many content with both pictures and text, and then there will be a superimposed effect.

2. Too Much is as Bad as Too Little? Positive Reviews vs. Negative Reviews

A review may be positive and complimentary, or it may be negative, critical, or even “flaming”. In psychology, the positive and negative and neutral aspects of a review are collectively referred to as “review valence.”

As everyone should know, positive reviews have a positive effect, and negative reviews will bring negative impressions and dissemination power, and the negative impact of negative reviews is higher than the impact of positive reviews. You can imagine whether a one-star negative review on TapTap has a much greater impact than a five-star positive review.

But for games, this special product, it is not difficult to find that in places like Tieba and forums, negative and neutral reviews are far more numerous than positive reviews, and this is mostly the case for games. In this case, the review section seems to cause a huge blow to the game. But in fact, we need to understand that behind these negative reviews are players with poor gaming experiences. Compared to players with more positive gaming experiences, they are more willing to speak out and express their “unhappiness”, on the one hand, to seek resonance, on the other hand, they also hope that the game official can improve these bad experiences in time; in addition, many psychology scholars have found through research that the effect of review valence is an inverted U-shaped curve.

 

The so-called inverted U-shaped curve describes that when people see reviews that are biased towards negative, they may have negative views on the product, but as more and more negative information appears and the degree becomes deeper, people’s trust in the reviews begins to rise and then declines. That is, compared with people’s extreme reviews, everyone is more inclined to believe in moderate review valence.

In addition to the content described by the review itself, the characteristics of the person viewing and reading the review will also have a great impact. This article briefly cites one example: the player’s own regulatory focus level. Regulatory focus level is a self-regulation process of people, divided into promotion focus and prevention focus. Promotion-focused players focus on growth, pay attention to positive results and magnify them, commonly speaking, they are more optimistic, and see more of “what can be gained”; while prevention-focused players focus on “what they will lose”, and strive to minimize their negative results.

To give a common example, a player draws a prize in the game, and the probability of winning is 80%. A promotion-focused player will feel that their probability of winning is very close to 100%, and it seems to be within easy reach, eager to try; while a prevention-focused player believes that they have a 20% chance of not getting it, and they are concerned about what they might lose.

Observing the relationship between the player’s own regulatory focus level and review valence, it is not difficult to find that for promotion-focused players, positive reviews are more useful than negative reviews, and they pay more attention to the positive gains in the reviews; while for prevention-focused players, negative reviews have a greater impact than positive reviews.

3. The Role of Official Responses

When we look at the review sections of some games, we often find a phenomenon, that is, the official “picks” or replies. In addition to the transmission of information itself, these replies actually have other effects.

Official replies have a positive effect on users. Let’s not talk about the specific content of the reply, but the behavior itself has a positive impact - research shows that in terms of the game development team directly facing the voices of players, direct interaction with everyone and collecting suggestions is a manifestation of the developer’s operation plan. A high reply rate reflects the official’s good operation planning and attitude to a certain extent. In games, the active response of the official shows that the development team attaches great importance to the suggestions of players, pays attention to everyone’s feedback and the status of the game, and also helps potential “cloud players” get to know the official and reduce the perceived negative risks. Some players even call for replies from the official in the review section.

 

So, how should game developers reply to players in order to achieve better results? This is related to the persona, the timeliness of the reply, and the specific form of the review.

First, you can consider positioning a specific persona. Why have a persona? For players, most development teams are far away from them. Even if the developers feel that they are listening to what players say most of the time and use it as a basis for changes, many players still don’t notice. When trying to communicate with players, targeted replies can indeed close this distance, but replies from the cold “xxx development team” and “xxx planner” are not obvious in closing the distance. If a clear persona can be established, especially one that is combined with the game’s own mechanics, worldview, characters, etc., it can have a better effect in closing the distance, easing the atmosphere, and operating the community. The cute loli of two-dimensional games, the female priest in the Western medieval background, the commander of FPS or military games, the injured companion of the doomsday survival game, etc., are all specific personas brewed by game developers under this strategy.

The second is the timeliness of the reply. Diagnostic theory refers to the process by which people judge the importance of a piece of information to themselves when they come into contact with it. Therefore, when information with high diagnostic value appears, people will immediately be attracted by this information and use it to help them make judgments. The official reply is diagnostic information in the entire review process, and the faster the official reply speed, the more it can grasp the player’s psychology in time, reflecting the high efficiency of the producer and the importance attached to the player. For example, the timely response of the game UNO! on TapTap reflects the players’ love for the official’s timely response.

 

How the producer replies to the player is also related to the specific form of the review. In the game’s review section, we will see some negative reviews. In response to these negative reviews, is it better to “admit mistakes” and reply “will improve”, or to analyze the reasons for the player’s negative experience with the player? This is actually related to whether the player’s evaluation is emotional or attribute-based.

Emotional evaluation refers to the player’s overall evaluation is relatively subjective, without the support of various examples, such as “so bad”, “don’t like” and other replies full of emotional words. At this time, if the official reply “admits mistakes”, apologizes and promises to improve, the player will further attribute the responsibility of the problem to the producer itself, and think that the official is perfunctory to him/her. At this time, a “defensive” reply will be more useful, such as appropriately introducing the better aspects of the game to the player, reducing the player’s bad attribution to the game itself; while attribute-based evaluation is relatively objective compared to emotional evaluation, and will describe specific problems. At this time, a reply of “admitting mistakes” is more useful, supplemented by specific improvement plans may make players feel the sincerity of the official.

4. Summary

This article mainly introduces the form of reviews, positive and negative valence, and some content of official replies, and discusses them in conjunction with relevant psychological theories. In fact, there are many more interesting phenomena in the review section, and the degree of influence of reviews on players is also different. Paying attention to the review section can help user researchers and development teams better understand players’ thoughts and needs, and explore the possibility of attracting new players.

entry.title: The Interactive Art of Loading in Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

Game loading design has undergone iterations and innovations along with the development of the game industry. It can even be cleverly designed in combination with game style and story, bringing players a better sense of immersion and a more interesting gaming experience. This article will introduce the development path of game loading, focus on the design methods of game loading, and analyze the design art of game loading from the two aspects of strong perception and weak perception of game loading.

1. The Path of Development: From Appearance to Elimination

The Original Meaning - “Reducing Anxiety”

Looking back on the time when playing Famicom games, you will find that you don’t seem to have any memory of the game loading screen. This is because the game capacity at that time was small, the storage medium was a cartridge, and the reading speed was fast. The game could basically run without loading.

In the 1980s, the storage medium for games became magnetic tape. The popular game equipment was a home computer equipped with an 8-bit microprocessor and 64k of memory. The computer read data according to the rotation of the magnetic tape. The loading time of more than ten minutes would inevitably lead to misunderstanding and anxiety about “computer crashed?” if only a black screen was displayed to the player. So the text loading prompt appeared, but this simple transition from static to dynamic form could only barely pass the boring time of loading.

 

Compared with the monotonous text prompts, many games chose to use original paintings as loading screens to help players pass the time. For the art resources that were suppressed by program restrictions at that time, this was a rare opportunity for “high-definition” display. Although the loading time was extended by 10% due to the call of art materials, this also became a rare opportunity for players to see “high-definition” pictures, so it was very popular.

 

Game Screen (left) and Loading Screen (right)

By the end of the 1980s, progress bars had already begun to be used in games. Although the first game to design a progress bar is no longer testable, this design that can intuitively reduce the player’s waiting anxiety is still not outdated.

Pioneering Design - “Game in Game”

With the upgrade of software and hardware, the game reading speed is faster. In Namco’s Ridge Racer in 1993, the game changed the previous loading form and placed the playable mini-game Galaxian in it, making the 30-second loading time pass abnormally fast, and the response in the player community was very good.

 

Loading game “Galaxian” in “Ridge Racer”

Although Namco applied for a patent for the mini-game in the loading process - “auxiliary game”, which created a shackle for its creation, the mini-game in this patent and the main game are two separate games. Later generations cleverly avoided this point and loaded part of the main game code to make it a mini-game. Part of the main game content was migrated and designed into an interactive game loading, which achieved the design of “game in game” and also made the way of game loading enter a more distinctive new stage.

Unremitting Pursuit - “Eliminate” Loading

Whether it is a static prompt, a dynamic picture, or an interactive mini-game, these are just to distract the player’s attention. However, the player knows that it is loading, and the game experience is inevitably affected. “Elimination” is the optimal solution that does not affect the game experience and concentration, and this is also the unremitting pursuit of many game loading designs.

In 2005, Tony Hawk’s American Wasteland directly used the no-loading screen as a selling point of the game, and players could experience the thrill of seamless exploration. It connects the game map through passages. When players enter the enclosed space of the passage, the map is loaded, allowing players to complete the loading unknowingly while experiencing the game.

 

2. A Thousand Producers Have a Thousand Loading Design Methods

The player experience in the game will inevitably be affected by memory reading, network speed, and response speed. Players often cannot get the feedback they want immediately after operating, and always have to wait for a while.

The Doherty Threshold theory points out that when the user’s command is executed by the system and the answer is returned within 400 milliseconds, it can keep them focused, improve productivity, and improve the negative experience of waiting. Extending the Doherty Threshold theory to the application of game loading design methods, it can be found that giving players timely feedback during game loading and the perceptibility of the waiting feedback process can maintain the player’s concentration and provide a good game experience.

The strong perception of game loading emphasizes the visualization of the feedback loading process and clarifies the waiting progress. The weak perception of the game loading process emphasizes the timeliness of feedback, so that players are unconsciously in the process of waiting.

Game Loading Design with Strong Perception

In the game loading design that players can clearly perceive, regardless of its accuracy, the visual form can well reduce their waiting anxiety. The flexible use of loading animations, progress bars, splash pages, and art resources are commonly used design methods.

● Progress Bar

Animation is a good way to attract players visually, and the progress bar is the best form of waiting time visualization. The progress bar can be designed in combination with elements that reflect acceleration, connection, etc. in the game, and with meaningful animation effects, it can give more vitality to the functional loading form. For example, in Onmyoji, the loading progress bar is displayed by the Shikigami Usagi, who has the attribute of accelerating assistance, riding a magic frog and jumping forward, which is interesting and vivid and has the meaning of the game world view.

 

● Splash Page

The splash page can not only bring a unique transition effect, but also has a fascinating guiding effect. Common forms include opening doors, closing fans, turning pages, notes, and so on. In Red Dead Redemption, the splash screen and fading animation are combined with black and white photos of the scenery, which directly brings people’s thoughts into the western world of the twentieth century.

 

Loading display of “Red Dead Redemption”

● Art Resources

Art resources are also the most commonly used content for showing off skills in game loading, which can increase players’ perceived value of the game style and establish their trust in the game. For example, the exquisite original paintings allow players to appreciate the exquisite production of game art, and also bring players a relaxed and pleasant waiting experience; the display of game models during loading, and even some free interactions, can bring players a unique experience different from the rhythm of the game.

 

Loading display of “The Elder Scrolls V”

The loading form of excellent art resources can also help the connection of the game plot. For example, the loading screen of The Witcher 3 is a plot introduction, which helps players recall the main line and also brings a movie-level look and feel.

 

Loading display of “The Witcher 3”

Game Loading Design with Weak Perception

The goal of weakly perceived loading design is to allow players to spend the game loading time unknowingly, by cleverly using “blinders” to naturally turn the loading screen into a part of the game.

● Passage

In the game’s elevators, cable cars, or winding aisles, the player’s forward speed will be limited, thus giving the game ample loading time. The design of the passage is widely used in the game loading design of weak perception. For example, there are always many elevators in Hidetaka Miyazaki’s games, and the game completes the loading of switching scene resources while the player is riding the elevator. In Souls-like games, two large scenes are usually connected by a narrow cave or an empty dungeon, hiding the loading process outside the narrow space. In God of War III, players control the characters to fly in the tunnel to avoid falling rocks, perfectly combining the passage with interactive loading.

 

● Slow Walking

Slow walking is a loading form that is more difficult for players to detect. The slowed footsteps before entering the plot, and even when the game is preloading subsequent resources, in order to prevent the player from walking too fast, there will be settings such as swamps, narrow gaps that can only be passed slowly, or deliberately tripping the character, etc. to delay time for loading. These are the means used by the production team to use actions and terrain to make the game loading and game content more naturally connected.

 

Slow walking loading of “God of War 4”

● Camera Movement

In fact, it is not difficult to perfectly hide the loading process in the game. The game only needs to limit the player’s perspective through the camera to easily hide the loading process from view. As early as the PS1 era, there were applications of using the camera to cover up loading, such as in Spyro the Dragon, as Spyro flies, the game perspective changes from the ground to the sky, hiding the loading process of ground resources. In Hellblade: Senua’s Sacrifice, the close-up shot is used to express the heroine’s inner activities and follow her perspective to complete the scene switching.

 

Close-up loading in “Hellblade: Senua’s Sacrifice”

3. Summary

Today, the design of game loading is not limited to specific routines or blindly hiding. Instead, it is constantly exploring the perfect integration of game loading with game content and worldview. More and more games are carefully designed between maps, and even no trace of loading can be seen.

Due to the technical development of memory reading speed, the current game loading process cannot be truly eliminated. While technology is sprinting forward to accelerate loading, the content design of game loading has become an art. It can be cleverly designed in combination with the game style and story narration, which can not only help the game improve the worldview, but also optimize the user experience, increase retention, and bring players a better sense of immersion and a more interesting gaming experience.

entry.title: Fault-Tolerant Design in Games How to Apply Postel's Law
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

“Just like the Roman god Janus (and many politicians), every Web application has two faces: its ‘human face’ interacts with people, and the machine face interacts with computer systems.” —— “Your Website has Two Faces” by Lyle Mullican

Human thinking is different from that of machines. Human understanding of information is fuzzy, variable, and broad, while machines can only recognize data that conforms to a specific structure. How can the two understand each other and achieve a balance between input and output? This requires certain fault-tolerant design, so that the product can use “two faces” to interact with people and machines, respectively. This article will introduce the theoretical basis behind this - Postel’s Law, and introduce its application in game fault-tolerant design with examples.

1. What is Postel’s Law?

First, let’s understand the content and origin of Postel’s Law. Postel’s Law (Robustness Principle) is also known as the robustness principle. In 1980, computer scientist Jonathan Bruce Postel released an early specification of the TCP protocol. In the specification, he proposed this law:

Be conservative in what you send, be liberal in what you accept.

“Be conservative in what you send” means that the product should abide by certain specifications when displaying content to users; “be liberal in what you accept” means that when receiving user input, non-standard input should be allowed. The core idea it expresses is: the product should have a certain fault tolerance. This has become a design guide in the computer field, and has been widely used in game interaction/user experience design.

2. Allow Diversity, Tolerate Errors and Exceptions

When designing a game system, we cannot only allow players to enter the format that the machine can recognize, but also consider the diversity of users, accept and adapt to more flexible and diverse input and operations, and design corresponding processing methods.

Allow Players to Perform Arbitrary Operations

We may have had this experience. Sometimes, when we enter incorrect text or ambiguous content in the search box, the software can still give the desired search results, as if it has “figured out” our thoughts. In this process, the program does not limit input when facing the user. Even if the content is wrong or invalid, it will not crash or report an error. Instead, it will process the input content autonomously after receiving the input, showing a high degree of tolerance. We don’t need to delve into the program implementation behind this, we just need to know that this is in line with Postel’s Law.

The nickname box in Elden Ring also handles the input of spaces in a similar way. Players can enter spaces at will without any error prompts. But when the confirm button is pressed, the program will automatically process the content, delete the spaces at the beginning and end, and the extra spaces in the middle, so that the nickname becomes a format that conforms to the rules.

 

《Elden Ring》 Character Nickname Input Self-Processing

Input Method Adaptation

Games have a variety of input methods. Taking computer games as an example, the input methods can be a controller or keyboard and mouse. Many games can recognize these different input methods and give corresponding responses, so that they can tolerate and meet the different operating needs of players.

For example, Naraka: Bladepoint has adaptively processed the input method: when no controller is connected, it will default that the player is using keyboard and mouse operations, and the interface will also display keyboard and mouse prompts; when the player connects a controller, the game will automatically recognize and switch the operation mode to controller operation, and the interface prompts will also become controller icons accordingly.

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Input Method Adaptation

Output Method Adaptation

Game products are usually not limited to running on one platform or one system. We need to adapt to screen resolutions, device types, and operating systems to reduce the impact of different device conditions on interface effects and operating experience. Taking Revelation M as an example, in addition to running on various mobile phones, it can also be played through an emulator. When we drag the interface to change to any size, we can see that the interface layout and component positions are automatically adjusted, and the interface can always maintain a reasonable and clear presentation effect.

 

《Revelation M》 Interface Adaptation

Exception Handling

Various abnormal situations such as network delay and disconnection may occur during the game running process, which is difficult to avoid. Therefore, it is also necessary to consider in advance and design the processing method when developing the game, which can prevent problems such as process loss and data damage caused by abnormal situations. Disconnect protection and reconnection, automatic saving and other functions are common exception handling methods:

If the controller is disconnected during the game process of Dead Cells, a “Controller Disconnected” prompt will pop up and the game will be automatically paused to avoid the character being out of control and affecting the game process. If the controller is reconnected, the prompt will disappear and the game will automatically resume.

 

《Dead Cells》 Controller Disconnection and Reconnection Handling

In Hogwarts Legacy, players can manually save the game, and the system also automatically saves frequently (there will be an icon prompt on the interface when saving). If you encounter a special situation during the game and don’t have time to save manually, don’t worry, you can find these automatic saves in the loading game interface, which largely avoids the loss of game progress/archive damage.

 

《Hogwarts Legacy》 Auto Save

3. Define Actionable Boundaries

Although we can use the game’s own inclusive design to accept various behaviors of players as much as possible, sometimes we still don’t want various strange operations to occur. This requires setting some boundaries to properly guide players and reduce the possibility of incorrect input.

Clear Definition Instructions

We can tell players the boundaries of operation by directly writing down the rules, so that players can autonomously filter out some wrong input situations. This method is more common in the interface for entering nicknames. The rules for nicknames are often more complicated, involving character type restrictions, character length restrictions, space processing, etc., and various input situations may occur. Different games also have different requirements for nicknames. Appropriately marking some rules will make it more convenient for players to enter content that meets the requirements.

Limited Options

We can limit the operation by reducing the freedom of input components and filtering out some options outside the boundary. For example, in the trading house of Revelation M, the value of “Purchase Quantity” requires players to enter pure numbers. When clicking on a number to enter, the system will force the numeric keyboard to pop up, avoiding the situation where players enter other characters.

 

《Revelation M》 Numeric Keyboard

Condition Constraints

Condition constraints are a commonly used design method in Metroidvania-like games. There are often some places on the map that cannot be reached in the early stage, and you need to obtain a certain ability or some props to explore. Through the gradual unlocking of various conditions, players can be guided to play according to the design expectations, enjoy the fun of constantly discovering new content, and also make the growth of the character and the rhythm of the game reach a relatively stable state.

At the exit of the novice map of Hollow Knight, this design is made. A bug is arranged to block the way. Players need to learn spell skills to pass, prompting them to return to explore other paths and improve their character abilities. It also prevents players from accidentally breaking into the late-game map in the early stage.

 

《Hollow Knight》 Using Character Abilities to Restrict Map Exploration

4. Operation Feedback and Correction

Defining boundaries can only prompt players what kind of operation is appropriate to a certain extent, but players can still perform some operations outside the boundary. Therefore, when players take incorrect or risky operations, they can also give some feedback or remedial measures to help players correct their operations autonomously.

Information Prompts

Information prompts are a commonly used feedback method. By giving prompts and guidance after players perform interactive operations, players’ operations are further corrected. The timeliness of information feedback is very important, and it needs to be pointed out immediately when an operation occurs. Hades has strict requirements on the steps of operation. For example, you must collect rewards before entering the next level. If you press the button to interact with the door without completing it, the interface will display “Collect Rewards!” information feedback, and at the same time, there will be a light spot sliding to the reward item to prompt and guide the player.

 

《Hades》 Operation Feedback and Prompts

Secondary Confirmation

Secondary confirmation is very common in games. It generally appears after some important operation steps, prompting players to the possible results of this operation, so that players can make a more cautious judgment of their operations, and prevent possible misoperation situations. For example, when clicking exit during the Devil May Cry 5 level, a secondary confirmation interface will pop up to ask, telling the player that if they exit at this time, they will continue from the last checkpoint when they restart, so that the player can confirm whether to return to the main menu.

 

《Devil May Cry 5》 Secondary Confirmation Interface When Exiting the Level

Revocable Operations

Although there is no “regret medicine” in the real world, the game world is imaginative, and anything can happen. Therefore, some games are very considerate to provide players with revocable operations, so that players can have the opportunity to make up for their mistakes after discovering them. For example, the store in Revelation Online has a repurchase function. After an item is sold, it will not disappear immediately, but will enter the repurchase list. If you accidentally sell the wrong thing, you can buy it back.

 

《Revelation Online》 Store’s Repurchase Function

Dark Souls 3 also has this design. If the player accidentally hits a friendly NPC and forms a hostile relationship, they can pray at the Statue of Velka in the game to restore the relationship with the NPC.

 

Fig 1. Example.

5. Summary

Postel’s Law tells us: the game needs to have two faces, one facing the player and the other facing the machine. The face facing the player needs to be open and inclusive, allowing the existence of diverse player operations and the input of various non-standard information; while the face facing the machine should follow the specifications and be cautious to avoid errors and confusion, so as to better convey the content to the player.

Fault-tolerant design in games is a very important part of the game experience. The application of Postel’s Law in games can help game designers design more stable systems and more user-friendly interfaces, improve the fault tolerance of game products, and thus further enhance the player’s game experience.

entry.title: Want to Visit Your Home What is the Charm of Home System Social Interaction
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

With social progress and technological iteration, the form of social interaction has undergone various evolutions. From offline to online, the roles, spaces, and scenes of social interaction are constantly being reconstructed. People’s desire for expression and sharing has not diminished, and the social battleground has gradually shifted online. On the one hand, mature social products are emerging one after another, and on the other hand, games have become the social medium for most modern people, becoming a virtual scene carrying social interaction and also a topic of conversation after dinner.

From the perspective of game production and operation, game social interaction is an old topic. According to iResearch data, among all the reasons why domestic players leave a mobile game, “weak social attributes” account for 31%, ranking first in guiding players to “abandon the game”.

So, why is social interaction so important in games?

For manufacturers, social content is different from one-time consumable content (such as new storylines). It has low production pressure and strong sustainability. Most online games rely on social interaction to maintain player investment in the later stages, and social interaction between players is also an important part of revitalizing the game ecology. For players, interacting with others in the game can bring experiences such as a sense of identity, belonging, and superiority, which is also the main pleasure in the later stages of the game.

Social interaction in games often revolves around collaboration, competition, supply and demand, etc., and combines with appropriate relationships to form an overall social structure. For example, players of the same level use warrior, mage, and priest class combinations to achieve combat division of labor. Players of different levels establish common goals for collaboration through large organizations, or achieve hard social needs through profit sharing and resource trading.

In the home system, social interaction gameplay often starts from the leisure perspective of the game, and creates more entertaining social experiences without putting pressure on players. Compared with traditional social interaction, home social interaction is more “leisurely”, “loving”, and “healing”. It allows players to interact with acquaintances or strangers without pressure, and can better help players integrate into the social ecology of the virtual world. This is the current general environment, and it is also a social scene that more players will pursue in future games. Therefore, the social interaction in the home system should not be underestimated.

In past contacts with various game players, we found that there are many types of home social gameplay. The core pleasures of players are mainly divided into the following categories: management-oriented pleasure, home construction-oriented pleasure, and pure social-oriented pleasure.

1. Home Resource Exchange

Driving social interaction with transactions is the most common way, and it is no exception in the home system. Like players in Animal Crossing exchanging specialties for cross-island trade, and players in Revelation M visiting friends’ homes to find daily flower merchants to buy rare flower seeds to exchange for home coins, this “differentiation” and “scarcity” can effectively mobilize players’ enthusiasm and motivate players to visit each other’s homes.

Specifically, taking Animal Crossing as an example, many players who enjoy collecting say that social interaction (going to other people’s islands) is a “rigid need” of the game. Because players are born in the southern or northern hemisphere, they have different (seasonal limited) insects and fish in different seasons, and these two contents account for a large proportion of the game’s collection elements. Although there are seasonal changes, due to the game’s time being synchronized with reality, in order to achieve the purpose of rapid collection, players need to travel between the two hemispheres, and visiting each other has become a necessary social link in the game.

 

《Animal Crossing》 Collection System - If you want to quickly collect all the illustrations, you need to visit other players’ islands to catch insects and fish

In addition, Animal Crossing also incorporates many random events, such as furniture, flower seeds, floor wallpapers randomly refreshed in the store, clothing sold in the clothing store unlocked with progress, and some random limited events such as carpet merchants and meteor showers (this type of event is an important way for players to obtain rare items). The random factors mean that visiting friends or strangers from time to time can discover new surprises, further stimulating players’ desire for this type of social interaction.

 

《Animal Crossing》 Carpet Merchant - Randomly appears on various players’ islands

2. Multi-person Interaction/Activities in the Home

Reciprocal (helping friends water flowers, pick vegetables, etc.) and entertaining (playing the piano, dancing, playing chess, playing cards, etc.) are common multi-person interactions in the home. Furniture interactions that can create beautiful memories together and casual mini-games where you can talk and laugh together are also social needs that players have high voices for.

 

*《Justice Online》 - Taking photos on the home swing.

 

*《For All Time》 - Multi-person Pitch-Pot Competition.

 

《Revelation Online》 - Multi-person Band Performance

In addition to small interactive props or casual gameplay, many players believe that holding party activities at home is also a great tool to promote social interaction in players’ small circles. For example, players who have participated in the Heartopia test have said that the free party is the social interaction they prefer. From preparing food and fireworks to inviting neighbors to the house, and then interacting together after the party officially starts, and finally taking a group photo, it’s a perfect ending. It is worth mentioning that the seemingly formal party gameplay has no substantial material rewards. What players can gain is the opportunity to become friends with neighbors who come to the appointment.

 

3. Co-building Multi-person Homes, Multi-person Communities

In addition to visiting each other, co-living with multiple friends, interacting and entertaining, and creating a self-world for small groups are also the home social needs of many players. Couples/roommate players in Mole’s World are quite fond of the process of building a home bit by bit.

 

《Mole’s World》 - Public storage box for furniture, both parties can move their furniture into the public storage box for management and decoration

Similarly, Justice Online‘s multi-player manor also satisfies the “cohabitation” needs of many small group players. Even if they are on different servers from their friends, they can break the barriers between servers and gather multiple friends to build a manor together, creating a team building paradise.

In the community-like design of “Qiyunji”, players can think about how to plan the area of the entire manor together with their friends and conceive the overall manor style. In addition to home construction, players can also go fishing in Bixi or cooperate in treasure hunting with their close friends, interact with their friends’ pet cats and dogs, and even transform into a chef, show off their superb cooking skills, and prepare a table of delicacies for their friends.

 

《Justice Online》 - Everyone is fishing together in the manor

In addition to such acquaintance communities, homes (or rather, communities) can also become opportunities and situations for stranger social interaction.

For example, Heartopia players also mentioned that the game’s special home social mechanism brought them unexpected surprises. Because each time you enter the game, up to 12 players will be randomly assigned to the same town, and players will meet 11 different people every day. The neighbor you passed by yesterday may be replaced the next time you log in.

The random mechanism creates distance for players who don’t like social interaction, and also brings a special social experience to the town. Every time you log in, there will be new neighbors, and new neighbors have the opportunity to become friends. From small things like watering flowers and playing with cats for neighbors, and completing a two-person action with neighbors, to big things like holding a party and inviting neighbors in the town to visit… In the end, it may precipitate a larger and more dynamic social network.

 

《Heartopia》 Map

4. Spontaneous Social Interaction Brought by Players Building Homes

The home system is often accompanied by highly free construction and decoration gameplay. In addition to creating and designing their ideal beautiful homes, players are also committed to creating various fancy things by building houses, and this kind of curiosity-seeking fancy things can usually attract a large number of players and bring active spontaneous social interaction.

Some players in Animal Crossing like to try to move real scenes into the game and record important events in their lives that are ceremonial. For example, Japanese pixel artist BAN-8KU held a virtual exhibition “Kitten Exhibition”, attracting a large number of players to visit; a Twitter player named WhimsyWool moved her canceled graduation ceremony to the game, and the 18-second video instantly received 1.5 million views and 200,000 likes; many players also held weddings in Animal Crossing during the epidemic and posted them on social media, inviting netizens to witness together…

 

《Animal Crossing》 - Holding art exhibitions, job fairs, graduation ceremonies, weddings

Similar social situations also appear in domestic mobile games. The master players of Mole’s World decorate their homes into online bathhouses, internet cafes, bars, couple cinemas, hot spring hotels, study gardens… and invite netizens to check in online. Overnight, they became internet celebrity shops, attracting many players to follow the trend and queue up to visit. Players continue to post check-in guides and experiences on Weibo, Xiaohongshu and other platforms, and Mole’s World has also frequently gone out of the circle on social media because of this.

 

What’s more, many players in Final Fantasy XIV buy houses to open RP shops (role play), providing various scenes for immersive role-playing, from small bars and teahouses, nightclubs and dance halls, schools and libraries, bathhouses and hotels, to large churches and museums, haunted houses and dungeon secret rooms, amusement parks and divination houses, photography studios, and even host clubs. Players’ brains are wide open, and they have played different tricks with the housing system.

Regarding RP shops, players can independently decorate their houses, become shop owners, hire people to play NPCs, and attract customers to consume; they can also find a favorite shop to apply for, play NPCs, and serve players who come to consume, such as providing services/item transactions according to the menu and price list, providing chat and play services, playing musical instruments or dancing; they can also just visit and consume, or chat with NPCs or other players in the shop.

 

《FF14》 - Theater RP & Audience Appreciation

In the long run, the RP shop industry chain has been derived in the game ecology. Players who want to play NPCs and players who want to contact NPCs each have their own fun, and gradually become a major feature of the game culture. In addition to promoting social interaction, RP shops have a certain stimulus for the demand for housing, furniture, and character costumes, and are also helpful to the economic cycle of the game. From this, we can also glimpse some inspiration for the commercialization of the game from the home system.

5. Summary

In summary, the social interaction carried out by players through the home system and the fun obtained during the social interaction are nothing more than three kinds. One is the social interaction derived from management-oriented pleasure (stealing vegetables/watering/feeding/special resource acquisition & exchange, etc.), the second is the social interaction derived from home construction-oriented pleasure (display & invitation to visit experience/co-building home, etc.), and the third is pure social-oriented pleasure (social interaction in the home - interactive props/social gameplay).

For the home as a social scene, most players care about whether they can simulate real life and feel the lively atmosphere of life. They regard the home as a leisure place for acquaintance social interaction, and will party, chat, dance, and hold weddings with friends in the home. At the same time, they do not exclude meeting friendly strangers through the home system and will interact. At the same time, the home is no longer limited to one person’s small home, but gradually forms a multi-person family, a community of more people, thus forming a social circle.

It is precisely this kind of non-mandatory and non-strong goal-oriented social interaction that makes players pay more attention to their social feelings of being cared for and valued, and it is precisely this kind of interaction that makes players actively deepen the connection between each other, and the home gradually evolves into a spiritual dwelling place in the virtual world.

entry.title: Why Does Music Content Customization Help Solve the Problem of Music Repetition
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

In the early days of video game development, audio experiences were often added to the game in the later stages of development, and were unlikely to fully meet the needs of game type, emotional content, background, etc. Today, in game development, it is often necessary to consider dimensions such as cost and player needs, but content consumption is always naturally faster than production, and game music still faces the problem of insufficient supply.

Game soundtracks themselves need to be adapted to the game’s level, map, and scene design. This high dependence on basic game design can lead to a problem: if the game itself does not adopt a highly differentiated and personalized design in terms of maps, scenes, characters, etc., even if the game soundtrack composers have tried to make as many changes as possible in the number of tracks and music structure design, it is still impossible to solve the problem of obvious homogeneity.

Why is this? Because if players stay on a specific map for a long time without exploring other maps, or if the overall map elements and general style of the game are relatively consistent, and unlike fantasy games that can accommodate many imaginative designs, what players hear is always music that is generally consistent in style. Even if there are subtle stylistic differences between different pieces of music, whether or not these differences can be heard depends largely on the player’s own level of musical aesthetic.

Therefore, game music often still faces the problem of high repetition, and even makes players bored and disgusted, directly muting the game.

So how can we explore potential solutions to this problem? This article will break down the problem from the aspects of players’ needs for music differentiation, factors affecting music perception, and music content customization, and discuss how to alleviate the problem of music repetition.

1. Analysis of Players’ Needs for Game Music Differentiation

Before starting the discussion, let’s briefly introduce the categories of various game music as an introduction:

  • Ambient music (including large maps, dungeons, etc.): battle music, map music
  • Functional music (instrumental performance, objects containing short musical snippets in the game, victory/defeat music)
  • Story music
  • Cutscene music
  • Songs

So, why do players need differentiated game music?

This needs to be analyzed from two levels: experience and function. From an experiential perspective, game music plays a role in creating an atmosphere, such as promoting the development of the plot climax and stimulating the player’s sense of tension in battle; in terms of functionality, game music can play a role in prompting information, such as customizing music according to the characteristics of the map, players can hear the national culture of a map from the music style, or the battle music will usually become more and more intense, thereby indicating the increase in the difficulty of the level. These are all components of immersion.

Therefore, if the game music is not differentiated, players will lack an auditory channel to grasp the information of the game, and will lose a certain degree of emotional investment, thus appearing to lack immersion.

 

2. What Factors Will Affect Your Perception of Game Music?

After understanding that players have certain needs for music differentiation, what kind of music can highlight differentiation in the perception of players? We can first look at what factors will affect players’ perception of game music.

The Existence of Music

Past psychological studies have found that the existence of music is self-evident for the creation of immersion and emotional connection in video games. However, in this regard, the existing research results present two extremes.

For some players, when the music is turned off, their emotions are detached from the game, and they believe that music is crucial for masking external noise and interference. But conversely, some people have suggested that if there is no music, they can better focus on the game experience, because music is a part of the game that players cannot actually control, which will make them feel less in control. This may be because when the music is turned off, players are more likely to hear other operation-related sound effects without being distracted by the music, so that they can be more immersed in the game.

Players’ Familiarity with the Selected Music

Generally speaking, players tend to choose familiar songs to get the emotions or emotional effects they want to enhance immersion. But in fact, the player’s prediction here is not necessarily correct. Because players lack experience in understanding the complex interaction between music and games, they may not be able to correctly choose the music they think can help achieve the desired effect. For example, when choosing battle music, players may tend to choose repetitive short songs, but in fact, repetitive short songs are easy to distract people, and they will make the atmosphere too tense, and even hinder the play of skills and battle strategies.

Lyrics

Lyrics have the risk of distracting players, especially if players like the song, they will be immersed in the lyrics rather than the game. This is because players cannot ignore the familiar lyrics in the song when playing the game, and may even hum along. In addition, they will intentionally or unintentionally try to associate the lyrics with the game, which may be because most people are accustomed to watching visual effects that match the lyrics of the song, thereby establishing a connection between the visual effects and the lyrics.

 

Differences in Music Genres

In addition, music types can also affect the gaming experience. Music that does not match the atmosphere of the corresponding scene will often increase the player’s anxiety and lead to a lack of concentration. Among them, certain music genres are more suitable for specific types of gameplay, which is also related to the historical development of the cultural connotation of music genres.

Players’ Expectations for Music Design

Soundtrack design is adjusted by several game parameters during runtime, such as switching according to the player’s game progress, etc. Experienced gamers are usually aware of the important role of music in reminding them of danger or providing other game information. Therefore, they will expect music to play a role in prompting battle status, actions, etc., and when this expectation is met, they will have a higher sense of immersion, otherwise they will be aware of the lack of this information and affect the overall game experience.

3. Solving the Problem of Music Repetition - Music Content Customization

Returning to the countermeasures for the problem of music repetition, one solution is to adopt a music content customization model. There are also many ways to customize music content, such as:

Online improvisation: In Sky: Children of the Light, players can improvise on the musical instruments in the game. This interactive mode adds more fun and more different possibilities to the game.

 

Player-composed music: The musician in Revelation M allows players to customize music scores to play. This model can not only satisfy players’ creative desires, but also generate music autonomously through a large player base, enriching the game’s music content.

 

In-game custom album series: GTA allows players to customize in-car music, so that players can not only choose the songs they want to listen to in the game, but also upload their own playlists.

 

In fact, some game companies are open to mod creation and source code release, with the aim of encouraging players to edit and share new levels or content based on the game. In order to be able to add audio to the new levels created, some players will develop mod tools and share them with other players to help them automatically write music and sound effects. For example, AudioMod in Minecraft allows users to add new music and sound effects to the game.

When Microsoft launched their Xbox 360 console in 2005, they also mandated that all games made for the Xbox 360 must allow players to customize the soundtrack, that is, when players plug in other MP3 players, the game music will be turned off and replaced by the player’s own music.

4. Music Content Customization Enhances Players’ Sense of Control over the Game

Why can the method of music content customization solve the problem of game music homogeneity to a certain extent?

First, players will subconsciously and autonomously establish a connection between music and the game. No matter what happens between the current auditory and visual environment, players will connect all the presented information together to realize their in-game experience.

Behind this phenomenon, it is not only because music will affect the player’s perception of images, but images will also affect the perception of music. Choosing and listening to music is not regarded as a peripheral experience of gameplay. On the contrary, even music external to the game and chosen by the player will be regarded as part of the game experience. It is not only used to mask background noise or provide additional entertainment, but also to enhance the emotions generated during the game.

This highlights the importance of games as Gesamtkunstwerk (total art, that is, all arts are combined under a unified ideology): the game experience is not only visual effects, gameplay, or sound, but the combination of these elements to create a better experience for players.

 

Among them, the player’s sense of control over the game is also key. Music content customization allows them to have better control over the game environment, and this control over music content also changes their relationship with game music. Player research found that when they can choose the music they want, their state anxiety level (“state anxiety” refers to a temporary state of anxiety, rather than a longer-term personality trait), heart rate/skin electrical response will decrease, indicating a lower level of emotional arousal. This effect is especially obvious in players who are less familiar with the game or the corresponding music.

But in the game, should players really be kept at a low level of anxiety? The answer is no, because the sufficient sense of anxiety provided by music can also drive players to continue to move forward in the game. For those players who pursue a more exciting sense of battle, they will prefer to experience songs that can increase anxiety. In addition, players generally expect a more dynamic emotional range when playing games, and the variability and adaptability of music play an important role in enhancing this emotional range. Therefore, the actual music design also needs to refer to the emotional experience process of players’ games and consider more.

In short, game music design needs to consider both players’ conscious tendencies and players’ unconscious cognitive habits. Only by combining the two can we design a soundtrack that matches the player’s game emotional process.

entry.title: The Magical 7 - Smooth Experience Design Under the Law of Memory
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

In 1956, American psychologist George Miller published a paper titled “The Magical Number Seven, Plus or Minus Two,” which discussed the relationship between the limits of one-dimensional absolute judgment and the limits of short-term memory. The number of alternatives for one-dimensional absolute judgment hovers around 7, which is roughly equivalent to the limit of short-term memory. That is, the memory span of young people is about 7 units (Arabic numerals, letters, words, or other units). Of course, the conclusion of “7±2” is not absolute, and it is also related to the length, complexity, and memory proficiency of the memory unit.

This is Miller’s Law, which is widely respected in design.

Miller’s Law is one of the earliest research results on the content of short-term memory, and it is still widely applicable in design. For example, designers will consciously reduce the amount and complexity of information presented to users at the same time, actively integrate information, and adopt modular methods. These are the most basic practices of Miller’s Law.

As a common scene of rapid thinking and short-term memory, game design should naturally conform to Miller’s Law. Next, this article will show you some design practices related to Miller’s Law in current games.

1. Control the Amount of Information to Reduce User Burden

People’s memory processing of information is limited. Usually, the more information there is, the harder it is for us to remember. This is a relatively easy-to-understand explanation of Miller’s Law.

Therefore, the easiest way to think of is to simply and rudely reduce the amount of information to reduce the user’s understanding burden. Facts have proved that reducing the amount of information is indeed quite effective. At present, the number of information chunks presented in people’s mobile phone software has basically not exceeded the range of “7±2”. The same is true for games.

But in fact, 20 years ago, Miller’s Law did not receive attention from designers in game design. MMORPG games in the early 21st century, such as World of Warcraft, had extremely “terrifying” skill buttons spread across the bottom of the screen. Some complex professions even had to press more than 20 skill buttons in a skill cycle! Although not all scenes need to use so many skills, the extremely complex key settings will still bring trouble to the player’s operation and memory, especially increasing the entry threshold for new players.

 

The complex skill keys in “World of Warcraft” greatly increase the difficulty of getting started

Later, with the emergence of MOBA games such as DOTA and LOL, this problem was alleviated. Take LOL as an example. Almost all heroes only have the following commonly used keys: 4 skills + 2 summoner skills + several equipment skills (basically no more than two). This falls exactly within the “7±2” range. The practice of Miller’s Law is actually one of the reasons why MOBA games are easy to get started and popular all over the world.

 

The hero skill interface of LOL is much simpler, and the number of items players need to remember is also within the “7±2” range

Of course, the conclusion of “7±2” is not only reflected in the number of skills. RTS (Real-Time Strategy) games bring Miller’s Law into full play. As a typical multi-threaded game, RTS requires players to control the overall situation and each “chunk”. According to research, in StarCraft, except for some professionally trained professional players, most ordinary players can only take care of six or seven game events at the same time, which has the same effect as Miller’s Law. These include back-end resource development, advance team reconnaissance, containment, frontal force attack, defense, etc., but no matter how the player operates, it is within the scope of Miller’s Law.

 

Not to mention other events, attack alone can be divided into single-line and multi-line, ground-to-ground and ground-to-air

In fact, when designing, designers will also consider the design of multi-threading more or less: too few threads will make the game too simple and lack depth; too many threads will greatly increase the difficulty of the game.

In addition, there are many places that reflect this “magical 7”: the number of displays in the status bar and toolbar, the menu items on the UI, the number of key NPCs in the plot… These should basically fall within the range of “7±2”, otherwise, there will be a greater risk of causing players to obtain information and memory burden.

2. Form Information Chunks to Assist User Understanding

Miller’s research is not only on the “number 7”, but also on the concept of chunks and our ability to process memory information.

I believe that everyone will encounter the problem of too many APPs when using mobile phones. Only by classifying them into groups and naming each group correctly can the mobile phone desktop look clean. In fact, this is a daily manifestation of Miller’s Law.

When the amount of information is indeed excessive and cannot be simply and rudely compressed, it is an excellent method to match related information to different information units to form chunks. At this time, the component block replaces a single APP as the memory unit. As long as the number of chunks does not exceed “7±2”, it can easily and effectively help users process and understand information, so that they can quickly identify the content of interest, and “expand” the user’s memory span to a certain extent.

In games, this method has also been widely practiced.

In the UI design of FPS games, the current gun information, the number of bullets, the backup gun, and the throwing object information belong to the same type of elements. They are often grouped together as a whole and displayed at the bottom left or bottom right of the screen at the same time, reducing the burden on the player’s brain: just glance in one direction to get all the relevant information.

 

A large amount of information does not appear individually, but is grouped into “chunks” and regarded as a unit

In addition, the character information (including health, skills, mechanism values, etc.) in ACT games also has the same characteristics, so it is often put together.

Not only the UI, but the backpack systems of many games also reflect this “classification” wisdom. Take the classic sandbox game Minecraft as an example. Its backpack has a one-click sorting function. As long as the player presses the corresponding button, the items will be automatically arranged according to the category; if you want to store, the chest interface also has a classification button with similar functions. After that, when players observe the backpack interface, they are no longer looking around like “headless flies”, but looking for the category first, and then looking for the corresponding item. The difficulty of obtaining information before and after sorting the backpack is very different, which also reflects the importance of chunks in Miller’s Law.

 

The chest classification button of “Minecraft”

3. Present Information Step by Step to Optimize User Experience

Another major method derived from Miller’s Law is: step-by-step design to reduce information density and optimize user experience. In fact, we are practicing the theory of distribution operations every day. Imagine what the user experience would be like if the food delivery APP put ordering, placing an order, filling in the address, and payment on the same interface? What if the mobile bank stuffed the key steps of transfer such as filling in information, obtaining a verification code, and identity confirmation all to the user? Step-by-step design has penetrated into all aspects of our daily life. Although it looks simple, its role cannot be underestimated.

 

Step-by-step design of ordering in food delivery APP

Game operations often encounter scenarios with particularly large amounts of information or complex business. Usually in game design, designers will first sort out the game process, and then process the corresponding information step by step, thereby reducing the impatient emotions brought to players by excessive information content in a single step, allowing players to immerse themselves in the current operation in each step.

The closest thing to step-by-step design in the game is the novice tutorial, because a large amount of information about the operation must be displayed to a person with no experience at all. At this time, how to achieve “clear explanation” while being “easy to understand” and “not discouraging” is the top priority of novice tutorial design.

At present, the novice tutorials of many games have implemented Miller’s Law.

In terms of teaching form, most novice tutorials break down the teaching content into small pieces, and only teach one content at a time, such as operation methods, game rules, task goals, etc., to avoid confusion for new players; in terms of the amount of content, although the types and focus of various game operations are different, the number of key teaching nodes in many novice tutorials falls exactly within the range of “7±2”. This is not a coincidence, but an imperceptible manifestation of Miller’s Law in design.

 

Main teaching points of the novice tutorial of “Destiny 2”

For example, in Destiny 2, although its novice tutorial lasts nearly half an hour, there are actually only a few key teaching points, many of which are already familiar to players (such as movement, jumping, use of firearms, etc.). The information density can be said to be quite low, which also reflects that Destiny 2 is not a very hardcore FPS game. At the same time, the 8 teaching points also fall within the range of Miller’s Law “7±2”, and the overall rhythm and the player’s memory burden have been fully optimized.

And Mount & Blade II: Bannerlord obviously also conforms to this rule: step-by-step teaching, and the number is limited to the range of “7±2”.

 

Main teaching points of the novice tutorial of “Mount & Blade II: Bannerlord”

In addition, inserting plots in the novice tutorial is not only an excellent way to introduce the game world view and explain the background, but also has the effect of reducing information density, allowing users to slowly absorb teaching knowledge and giving players time to remember and digest. This is also why many games like to use the perspective of the protagonist to advance the plot while killing enemies, and embed novice tutorials in the plot.

Of course, not only novice tutorials, but many puzzle game level designs also adopt step-by-step design. At this time, players will no longer advance the level linearly, but obtain information and resources in a step-by-step manner, reflecting the core of puzzle games: information acquisition and information use. And Miller’s Law solves the user experience problem during information acquisition.

For example, in the classic puzzle game Rusty Lake: Paradise, players can see many shadows of step-by-step design. From the perspective of the entire game, its plot process is divided into ten levels (that is, ten disasters), and this division optimizes the user’s plot intake experience; from the perspective of a single level, different information is placed in different small scenes, but the amount of information in each scene is very small, which is also a decrease in information density, which helps to reduce the information collection burden of players, and uses the layout of each small scene to make players form associations.

 

The smallest unit of “Rusty Lake: Paradise”

It can be seen that due to the particularity of puzzle games, the amount of information cannot be controlled within the range of “7±2”, and at this time, step-by-step design is particularly important.

4. Summary

The application of Miller’s Law in design is mainly to solve the user memory problem caused by information blocks. Reasonable information layout and information processing can greatly improve the user’s reading and memory of information. In game design, following Miller’s Law can control the complexity and difficulty of the game, improve the playability and user experience of the game; at the same time, it can also help new players better understand and master the game rules and gameplay.

Game designers can practice Miller’s Law by controlling the number and combination of game rules, interface elements, etc., designing game content step by step, and adopting interactive teaching methods, so as to create a simpler and easier-to-understand game experience, and improve the user satisfaction and reputation of the game. However, Miller’s Law should also be used flexibly, and do not misuse the “magical 7” to make unnecessary restrictions on the design. Analyzing specific situations is the best policy for design.

entry.title: How Can Non-Experts Master the Character Creation System
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

“Ten minutes to start the game, two hours to customize the face.”

This is a widely circulated saying among players in MMORPG games.

In recent years, the character customization system has gradually become a standard feature of role-playing games (RPG), and many players love it. What is the charm of character creation that makes players so obsessed? The Proteus effect mentions that when individuals are given different character traits, they tend to behave in a manner consistent with those traits.

In games with social attributes, this means that when players put on a custom game avatar, they will project their good expectations of themselves onto this avatar, and because of the beautiful appearance of the avatar, their behavior will tend to move closer to the avatar, and they will also tend to be more friendly and enthusiastic in game social interactions.

 

Nowadays, the customization function of game character images is becoming increasingly refined, allowing players to infinitely approach their ideal game image through these highly free customizations.

From the early days when you could only change the face shape, hairstyle, and body shape from a given number of templates, the character creation system has evolved to be able to adjust parameters such as size, position, and rotation through hundreds of fine dimensions. The degree of detail is so great. At the same time, in addition to improving freedom and sophistication to meet the ultimate pursuit of character creation experts, this customization system has also created a threshold for novice character creators.

On the Internet, we mostly hear the voices of “experts” and hear their needs for character creation functions, while the voices of ordinary players are often ignored. To this end, we have summarized the real feedback of ordinary players in different game character creation tests, combined with game examples, and analyzed how to improve the experience of ordinary players in a complex character creation system.

1. Increasingly Powerful Character Creation Systems

The use of game character creation functions is roughly divided into two parts: preset selection and detailed character creation.

In the preset selection, you can choose your favorite style from the given options, directly use this style to enter the game, or enter detailed character creation; in detailed character creation, you can adjust the size, position, orientation, color, brightness and other parameters of each part of the face step by step. It is no exaggeration to say that there are a thousand parameter results for a thousand players, truly achieving the so-called thousand faces for a thousand people.

The detailed character creation of most games is divided into three major sections: shaping, makeup, and hairstyle.
