Therefore, when conducting font licensing, developers need to fully communicate and negotiate with the font licensor to determine a reasonable licensing price and usage method, and scope of application.

When borrowing unlicensed fonts, it is necessary to pay attention to the deformation of the fonts to avoid violating relevant agreements. When it is necessary to use fonts similar to picture fonts in the game, fonts with very large deformations are often used to make artistic fonts to increase the aesthetics and reduce the risk of use.

5. Summary

For game players, excellent font selection and design can allow players to easily understand the text information in the game without causing doubts. Sometimes, the player’s ignorance of the text in the game can reflect the success of the text design. Developers choosing the right font not only needs to consider the coordination of the game’s worldview and the overall style of the game, but also needs to consider multi-dimensional issues such as font iteration authorization and localization to enhance the quality and user experience of the game.

entry.title: Expanding Design Principles: How Does Emotion Affect Game Experience?
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 
With the maturity of product design and manufacturers’ development capabilities, users are increasingly paying attention to the emotional experience that products bring to them. At the same time, more and more games are not only pursuing momentary excitement, pure visual and operational experience, but also fully considering and satisfying users’ emotional needs as much as possible, and are more pursuing users’ spiritual pleasure, value and emotional recognition. This article will start from the perspective of emotional design, explore its role and application methods in the field of game experience design, in order to optimize user experience through emotion.

 

1. What is Emotional Design?

Emotions are complex and changeable, but the patterns that cause emotions are general and regular; and emotional design is to use these patterns to purposefully cause people’s emotional reactions, through various shapes, colors, textures and other modeling elements, emotions are integrated into the game experience, in the process of consumers experiencing products, to stimulate people’s associations, resonate, and obtain spiritual pleasure and emotional satisfaction.

Emotion is a mandatory and oppressive experience. Converting consumers’ activities, thoughts, feelings, desires, goals, habits, and values into design will trigger positive emotional responses from users. The book “Emotional Design” clearly divides design and design goals into three levels: visceral, behavioral, and reflective, and expounds the important position and role of emotion in design. It serves as a conceptual supplement in the fields of software, interaction, and game design. Therefore, when we design any product, we need to respect emotional needs and bring a deeper level of quality experience.
 

2. The Role of Emotional Design in Experience Design

Emotion Affects Visceral Experience

The visceral level refers to the sensory stimulation that the product brings to people. The emotional response that the product looks, sounds, and feels to the user is the first step for design to generate value. Through the design of pictures, colors, layouts, sounds, textures, and tactile feedback, the product features can be visually reflected and bring specific emotional experiences to users.

For example, the beautiful pictures in the game make people feel dazzling and colorful, or red reminds people of blood, sun, and fire, giving people a feeling of excitement, jumping, and alertness, causing physiological excitement and stimulation. These are all visceral designs of the game that are acting on the visual experience of players.
 

《Fall Guys: Ultimate Knockout》 successfully attracts players’ attention with highly saturated colors and a cute interface

Emotion Affects Behavioral Experience

The behavioral level refers to the fact that users must learn and master skills, use skills to solve problems, and trigger emotions, gain a sense of accomplishment and pleasure from the experience. It is aimed at the user’s experience. For example, in the game, players need to gradually master the game rules preset by the designer, and use them to fight against other players or computer opponents to strive for victory. The experience of the behavioral layer is the core of game interaction design, which can allow users to obtain a positive emotional experience. Therefore, it is necessary to provide clear goals, instant feedback, and appropriate challenges; it is necessary to design an easy-to-understand conceptual model that conforms to the four elements of function, ease of understanding, ease of use, and physical feeling of behavioral design, so that users can use it easily, and always pay attention to the user’s experience throughout the process.
 

The core emotional experience of “achieving a sense of accomplishment by constantly overcoming difficulties” has made roguelike games and Soulslike games successful

Emotion Affects Reflective Experience

Finally, there is the reflective layer, which refers to the deeper emotions, consciousness, understanding, personal experience, cultural background and other influences that are intertwined in the user’s heart due to the effects of the first two levels, the user transforms and associates certain potential information and characteristics contained in things, and projects them into life experience. For games, the content of the game and the implied information conveyed by the storyline will stimulate players to recall and reflect, integrating out-of-game experience and in-game feelings to create a more immersive experience.
 

《Revelation M》 Guild News, Meteor Shower Treasure Chests Create an Immersive Experience

The experience brought to users by excellent reflective emotional design determines the connotation, meaning and user stickiness of the product; when the emotional experience meets the user’s long-term goals and conveys a clear and consistent personality, it is more likely that users will truly like such an experience in a meaningful way, and voluntarily and actively form a lasting and loyal connection with the brand or IP.

3. How to Use Emotional Design to Create Game Experience

Visceral Attraction Triggers Emotional Experience

At the visceral level, physical characteristics—visual, auditory, and tactile—dominate, so creating visual, auditory, and tactile appeal is an important factor in getting users’ favor and attracting users’ attention at the visceral level of the game.

So how to create multi-sensory appeal?

Designers can refine relevant characteristic elements, such as regional characteristics, character characteristics, etc., to expand the game from pure senses and aesthetics to the fields of semantics and culture, occupy users’ cognitive resources at the visceral level, guide users’ emotions, and attract users’ attention. Among them, vision, as the most basic perception channel, is the beginning of the user’s game experience. Using characteristic elements familiar to users can stimulate users’ “value resonance”, thereby affecting the generation of immersive emotional experience.

For example, in All-Star Streetball Party, the exquisite interface design incorporates a large number of street basketball elements. From the personalized graffiti-style interface to the cool and trendy sneakers and fashions, these elements contain the collective memory of basketball fans and can also attract general users who are interested in streetball culture. These elements can quickly occupy users’ cognitive resources from the visual channel, arouse associations and imagination, activate users’ sensory systems, and attract users’ attention at the visceral level.
 

《All-Star Streetball Party》 UI Interface, Sneaker Workshop

Sound evokes emotional experience

For a game, sound is also an important way for players to obtain information and emotions. Try to recall a game you like. Whether it attracts you with exciting battles, beautiful scenes, or touching plots, it is inseparable from the support and enhancement of sound: background music allows players to feel the changes in scenes and environments, skill sound effects allow players to feel the pleasure of battle, and character voices allow players to feel the personality and emotions of the characters. The sound of the game should be consistent with the style and color of the game, and be varied in different scenes or stages, so that the game’s worldview and the user’s perception are seamlessly integrated, reducing the user’s sense of alienation during the experience.

For example, in the fast-paced battle of Naraka: Bladepoint, players tend to focus on the center of the screen and it is difficult to notice changes in edge UI elements, such as the countdown to skill cooldown. At this time, sound and sound effects can play a very good feedback role: clicking on a skill in cooldown can be informed that your skill is in cooldown through the feedback sound effect of the empty state; when the skill cooldown ends, there is also a corresponding sound effect reminder of skill recovery.

In addition, the various background music in the game, and even the design of UGC instrument composition music, will also bring players a new emotional experience.
 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 The Latest Version of Naraka: Bladepoint x NieR Series Collaboration Theme Song

The gameplay of musical instruments in Naraka: Bladepoint is also diverse, making good use of music to promote interaction and communication between players.
 

Similarly, the “Crystal Prelude” of “Final Fantasy” is one of the most classic melodies in the history of games. The core melody of this prelude has become an important part of almost every “Final Fantasy”. The “Crystal Prelude” adapted by composer Masayoshi Soken for “Final Fantasy XIV” is a brisk melody that makes people look forward to the upcoming fantasy journey; while in “Final Fantasy XVI”, it uses dark music to foreshadow the suffering that Clive will endure, suggesting to players the dark and heavy plot experience on the auditory level.
 

Touch evokes emotional experience

Similarly, as part of visceral emotional design, touch can help improve the playability and fun of the game, making players more immersed in the game. The control in the game is the most direct way of contact between the player and the game. Through fine control feedback, players can feel the authenticity and tension in the game.

In the expression of touch, the greatest extent of tactile expression we can currently achieve is the delicate multi-level vibration of the game controller. For example, in the racing game Forza Horizon 5, the controller will simulate the vibration effect of car collisions and impacts, allowing players to feel the danger and tension of the car driving at high speed. In addition, in Naraka: Bladepoint, some heroes’ ultimate skills, successful parries, the second stage of bow charging, being hit by ground gas, and when the stamina is reduced to a red warning, will also trigger controller vibration.
 

Clever Use of Empathy to Enter the Experience

Enhancing the emotional connection between users and the game world through interaction can bring users a pleasant game experience at the behavioral level, thereby allowing users to further immerse themselves in it. Specifically, the immersive emotional experience at the behavioral level can enable users to more focusedly accept the information transmission in the game, cleverly stimulate users’ unconscious behaviors, and increase the playability of the game. In order to make the game more naturally guide the occurrence of user behavior at the behavioral level and complete the emotional communication between the game and the player, the technique of empathy can be used.

The so-called empathy is to use anthropomorphism, symbolism, metaphor and other methods to design the interface or emotional symbols in the game, give meaning to abstract UI controls, inject emotion into cold virtual graphics, connect the virtual world on the screen with the real world, and build psychological resonance through similar relationships, so that users can quickly adapt to the new context and integrate into the game atmosphere expected by the designer.
 

In “All-Star Streetball Party”, the card drawing is packaged as a “supply box”, which is in line with the game’s worldview and helps players understand and use it

For example, in the retro and avant-garde Internet world constructed in Hypnospace Outlaw, the game designer replaced the hand under the first-person perspective in the game with a thumbs-up gesture or a mouse arrow. By metaphor, the space in the browser is turned into something similar to the physical world, showing the contradiction between the network world and the real world, and bringing players unexpected game experience at the behavioral level with the clever design of interaction.
 

《Hypnospace Outlaw》 Thumbs-up Gesture Under First-Person Perspective

Clear Goals, Appropriate Challenges, and Immediate Feedback

The emotional design of the behavioral layer increases the player’s emotional experience by designing the player’s behavior and interaction, and the conceptual model of the behavioral layer design is inseparable from clear goals, appropriate challenges, and immediate feedback. Will Wright, the designer of “The Sims”, said: “Games can bring people different emotional experiences, which are the pride or guilt that they have never felt when watching movies.” From the perspective of interaction, in game experience design, by combining the above three game design elements, creating attractive experiences with clear strategies and skills can better improve the emotional experience of the game.

The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom does not have the clear task guidance of traditional RPG games, but players have an extremely immersive game experience. The reason is the clear exploration goals in the game. The game designs a multi-layered map system that is interconnected and independent of each other at the interaction level, so that the map expands the space for vertical exploration and is more exploratory; and, the guidance design that can be seen everywhere in the open world adds a spiral upward light vortex to the shrine, which is convenient for players to easily find even at high places. In the dark underground world, the shimmer of tree roots becomes the only visible beacon, hinting at various resources, landscapes, and enemies in the dark.
 

《The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom》 Shrine’s Spiral Upward Light Vortex

 

《The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom》 Shimmer of Tree Roots in the Underground World

For games, the difficulty setting of the game itself determines what kind of experience it can bring to players. If it is too simple, it will be boring, and if it is too complicated, it will make people feel anxious. The setting of the game should allow players to be in a challenging range in real time, and the skills required are also constantly improving. In addition to the aforementioned roguelike games and Soulslike games, the emergence of emergent interaction (涌现式交互 - yǒng xiàn shì jiāo hù) also gives the game new fun and challenges, using simple rules to emerge complex dynamic behaviors, perfectly matching the players’ emotional needs for high freedom and high playability.

The excellent game experience of Baldur’s Gate 3 inherits the emergent interaction gene of the Divinity: Original Sin series, that is, using simple rules to emerge complex dynamic behaviors. For example, in a certain dungeon, there is a chess game that requires the player to kill the black king within three steps. Even if the player does not understand the rules of chess at all, he will find that the black king is weak to electricity and can directly kill the king with electric spells. Like this, Baldur’s Gate 3 builds a world with infinite possibilities through the design of the underlying system rules. The integration of emergent interaction also greatly enhances the fun and spread of the game.
 

For emotional experience, feedback is a stabilizer and amplifier, stabilizing uneasy emotions and amplifying pleasant feelings. The game system itself is a complex system. Players input their ideas and controls, and through the processing of the game mechanism, they give feedback to the players. Players get the feedback they want and the appropriate degree, and they are more likely to continue to be in pleasure.
 

The teammate feedback mechanism in “Overwatch” extends from a single human-computer interaction feedback to human-to-human interaction feedback.

4. Summary

Emotional design focuses on influencing the user’s emotions and moods from three different levels, enhances the appeal of the design, endows the product with a deeper soul, thereby building a bridge between the user and the product to communicate with the soul, allowing people to obtain unforgettable memories and sublimating the value of design to a higher level.

Games are not only tools for entertainment and recreation, they also have the potential to evoke emotions and touch hearts, and through visceral sensory effects, empathy, game interaction mechanisms and storylines, etc., to trigger players’ emotional resonance and create a rich game experience. We have also made a more in-depth dismantling of the relationship between games and emotional design. With the continuous development of the game industry, emotional design will continue to play an important role in game experience, creating unforgettable emotional experiences for players.

entry.title: Text Overflow - The Old Problem of Game Localization
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

Localization translation and interface adaptation are indispensable parts of the process of launching a game overseas. However, some troublesome problems are often encountered in this process. One of the most common problems is that many foreign language expressions are much longer in characters than the corresponding Chinese, causing the translated text to exceed the originally designed UI, icon, or text box, resulting in incomplete display.

This situation hinders players’ understanding, and at the same time greatly reduces the sense of quality of the game in the minds of overseas players, which has a negative impact on retention and reputation. Localization translators always hope to accurately reproduce the meaning of the original language and maintain the original flavor as much as possible, achieving faithfulness, expressiveness, and elegance, but they often feel helpless because of the length of foreign language expressions.

1. Length Comparison of Different Languages

Languages of different countries have their own unique writing norms, and the same is true in the localization of games. When performing localization translation, it is necessary to comprehensively consider the fields involved to ensure the accuracy of the translation and the integrity of the semantics.

However, different languages have a general ratio of words when translated. For example, the ratio of English translated into Chinese is 1:1.6, while the ratio of Japanese and Korean translated into Chinese is about 1:1. In contrast, the text of some minor European languages is much longer. The ratio of German and French translated into Chinese is 1:1.8, and the ratio of Russian, Spanish, Italian, Portuguese, and Arabic translated into Chinese is as high as 1:2. The higher the word count ratio, the easier it is to cause the problem of translated text exceeding the box during the localization process.

 

Taking Naraka: Bladepoint, which is handled by the localization team under NetEase Leihuo UX, as an example, we analyzed the number of characters in the foreign language text and the number of characters in the Chinese text of the game, and obtained the risk of text exceeding the box in different languages in the game, as shown in the figure below.

 

It can be seen that the risk of text exceeding the box in all 11 languages in the figure is greater than 50%. Japanese and Korean have about 60% probability of seeing the text window, while European minor languages are almost “completely wiped out”, becoming the hardest hit areas for exceeding the box, with a probability close to 80%. Therefore, it can be said that how to face and solve the problem of text exceeding the box during game localization is a “long-standing” problem faced by every language.

2. How to Reduce the Risk of Exceeding the Box?

Although exceeding the box is a major problem that often occurs in the localization process of games, after years of exploration and experience accumulation, and in-depth exploration with technical team members, we can still find some potential methods to minimize the risk of exceeding the box of localized text in various languages, and even avoid this problem from the source as much as possible, so as to ensure the basic understanding and game experience of players in different countries and regions.

Game Development Stage

• Prepare for multiple languages when designing text boxes in the UI

If the game is intended to be released overseas at the beginning of its development, the UI team can comprehensively consider it in conjunction with the localization team at the beginning of the design. On the premise of ensuring interface design and interaction effects, the original text box can be appropriately expanded according to the length ratio of multiple languages to increase the text tolerance threshold of different languages.

• Design scrolling effects for text boxes

Some Chinese expressions are very concise, using multiple compound sentences in just a few sentences, or having a strong classical Chinese nature (such as poems, ancient Chinese styles, etc.). Therefore, during the translation process, the number of characters in foreign languages may be 2-3 times longer than that of Chinese. In this case, when localizing game text, it is difficult for translators to significantly reduce the translation while retaining the original meaning. If the text box in the game is limited by the interface width and cannot be further expanded, you can consider making the text scroll to avoid the problem of exceeding the box.

There are many benefits to this approach. Scrolling text can theoretically play text of any length and has strong inclusiveness; at the same time, there is no need to adjust the font and font size of the text, and the length of the text box does not need to be expanded to the maximum extent that the interface can bear; players can generally obtain and understand the information that the game wants to provide from the scrolling text.

Of course, considering the current mainstream games at home and abroad, the design of scrolling text generally appears in the game in task names, equipment introductions, etc., and is not suitable for the problem of exceeding the box in all positions and content forms. Some of the reasons include that scrolling some text technically and programmatically will lead to reduced game performance and increased overhead, and when the text that requires context understanding is too long, it is easier to increase understanding barriers and reduce the reading experience.

• Give character length suggestions

Compared with directly expanding the text box in UI design in the early stage of the project, giving text character length suggestions and finding the method of the longest character number can improve certain flexibility. Because this method can give more design space to UI and interaction, and at the same time, it can also minimize the risk of exceeding the box of the original Chinese (copywriting planners, system planners, etc. also know this character number suggestion) and localized translation.

However, there are two points to note here:

  1. The impact of resolution on text length: Text that has no problems may exceed the box and display incompletely after changing the resolution. Or, some fonts have been adjusted to the smallest font size, even if the adaptive (best fit, can adjust the font size or wrap) is turned on, the font size cannot be further reduced when the resolution is lowered.

 

Therefore, when the UI team gives suggestions on the length of text characters for text boxes, it is best to consider the various resolutions supported by the game in combination with the different platforms on which the game is launched.

  1. The impact of fonts: Even within the same language, different fonts will have a relatively obvious impact on the length of the displayed text. As shown below, the font of the first line of English is Arial, and the font of the second line of English is Times New Roman.

 

It can be clearly seen that the length of the same text will be different if it is displayed in different fonts. Therefore, if only a character limit is given, such as 4 characters, the translator uses a different font from the developer when using excel or other translation software, the length of the translation is likely to be different from the standard character length given by the development team.

Let’s give another example: the developer set a maximum of 23 characters for a button in the game, and the font from the developer’s perspective is Times New Roman. The translator set the font to Arial when performing localization in the translation system. The translator translates the text in this button as:

 

It can be seen that although the translator’s translation is exactly 23 characters, it still exceeds the box by one letter.

Even if the upstream and downstream departments unify the font, simply giving a character limit is still not necessarily the most recommended solution. Because different translators have different translation habits and commonly used words, the same sentence will have multiple translations. For example:

Buy this with gold

With gold unlock it

It can be seen that the number of characters in both translations is 18, but the following sentence exceeds the box by one letter compared to the above sentence. This problem will be more obvious in longer compound sentences.

Therefore, the UI team can give character length suggestions based on “m, n”. For example, the length of a button is “mmmmmmn”. At this time, no matter what font or expression the translator uses, they only need to compare the length with “mmmmmmn” to determine whether there is a risk of exceeding the box.

Localization Translation Stage

In addition to the early operation of reducing the risk of text exceeding the box during the development and design stage of the game, the translation during the localization process is also an important stage to ensure that the game interface finally presented to overseas players does not exceed the box.

• First of all, translators need to have enough understanding of the game content to be able to identify the possible location of the text during the translation stage and appropriately streamline the translation.

For example, “Unlock in time-limited event”, a new translator may translate it as “You can unlock this item by the time-limited event”; and a translator who knows the game well enough can immediately judge that this sentence is likely to appear in a certain prop, the unlocking method interface (button) of a certain item, usually a small text box, so it can be directly translated as “Unlock by time-limited event”.

• Use abbreviations instead of full spelling

This method is common in secondary interfaces or later in the game (players have a prior understanding of the full spelling), and can also reduce the risk of text exceeding the box with high efficiency. Common abbreviations include: damage-DMG; attack-ATK; experience-EXP, etc.

• Split sentences and reduce the use of conjunctions and prepositions during the localization process.

For example, the translation of the following sentence: 奧义状态下再造成100点伤害提升至第3级.

Dealing 100 damage by Hero’s Ultimate state and then raising to level 3.

Upgrade to Lv.3: Deal 100 more damage by Hero’s Ultimate

This translation divides the original complex expression into two sentences, avoiding the use of lengthy and difficult-to-understand compound sentences, which not only simplifies the translation, but also reduces the reading cost of players.

3. Summary

The problem of exceeding the box during the game localization translation process may be common in games on different platforms. We also found that this is a common problem in various languages, which not only affects the playability of the game and player reputation, but may also further hinder the retention of the game. Based on the experience of previous projects, we propose some solutions, aiming to avoid the problem of text exceeding the box as much as possible during the development and localization process of the game.

First of all, we recommend that the localization issues be considered jointly by various functions at the game development stage, including UI, GUI, localization, planning, programming, etc. This means that the design of the game must take into account the differences between different languages and cultures from the beginning to ensure the playability and consistency of the game in different languages. Secondly, during the translation process, we recommend using professional translation software and tools to help identify and correct the problem of exceeding the box to ensure the accuracy and quality of the translation and improve the player experience.

In short, the problem of exceeding the box is one of the challenges that must be faced in game localization. By taking appropriate measures during the development and translation process of the game, these problems can be avoided to the greatest extent, and a better game experience can be provided for players around the world.

entry.title: Layered and Engaging Visual Hierarchy Design in 3D Lobbies
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

The game lobby serves as a transportation hub in the game, mainly responsible for guiding players to different sub-functions and sub-systems (such as tasks, activities, social interactions, etc.) other than the core gameplay. In addition to the above tasks, it also includes displaying other information (such as various prompts), carrying some of the players’ social needs, and other additional functions. Therefore, the current display-type lobby format can no longer meet the needs of players in the lobby. The 3D interactive lobby format came into being. Players can familiarize themselves with and understand the game’s worldview, basic operations, and many other functions in the game in advance in this lobby space.

However, the visual hierarchy in a three-dimensional space is more complex than in a two-dimensional space. So, as game designers, how can we do a good job in the visual hierarchy design of information in the 3D lobby, provide players with a lobby experience that combines immersion and practicality, and achieve the “engaging” design effect? This article will start with the classification of game lobbies, and then introduce from the inside out from three aspects: “reasonable display of information according to priority”, “reasonable display or hiding of information”, and “visual packaging combined with worldview”.

1. Classification of Game Lobbies

Currently, the more common game lobby design directions can be roughly divided into two types: display type and exploration type, and each type can be further subdivided into 2D and 3D according to the dimensions of the space. The fundamental difference between display and exploration types is whether the character controlled by the player can move freely in the scene.

 

  • 2D-Display Type: A more general lobby type, commonly found in various mobile games. The design of the visual hierarchy of the interface also adopts a straightforward approach. The main purpose is to display functional entrances as much as possible in a limited space, and to facilitate players to enter various functions;
  • 3D-Display Type: Mainly displays character and scene models. The character models and scenes in this type of lobby choose the 3D form, which can show more model details, but the characters cannot be moved by the player in the space;
  • 2D-Exploration Type: Players can freely move on the horizontal axis, which is more similar to a horizontal scroll. In this type of lobby, more functional entrances are also bound to items in the scene;
  • 3D-Exploration Type: Compared with 2D scenes, 3D exploration type lobbies add depth. Players can control characters to walk freely in the space. In addition to binding functions to items in the scene, they can even meet other players in the scene, allowing players to have more physicalized communication.

2. Underlying Foundation: Reasonable Display of Information According to Priority

The types of information carried in the game lobby are very diverse, including clickable buttons, functional entrance panels, and some instant information, such as messages from strangers and system tips. This information is very important to players, but displaying it without distinguishing priority will reduce the player’s experience and immersion, affecting information acquisition. Therefore, dividing the priority of information is also to more freely reduce the interference of some information and enhance the player’s sense of substitution in the game world.

Important Information is Always Displayed on Top

In the space of the 3D lobby, players will be attracted by various elements in the scene, and at the same time, there will be various system information that needs to be queued to inform the user. However, some highest priority information needs to be fed back to the player in time, such as the current status and location. In conventional design, the effect of such information will be enhanced, but doing so may directly conflict with the goal of “immersion”. Therefore, for this part of the information, it is necessary to display it on top in a fixed position in the space to cultivate the player’s habits.

According to the characteristics of this type of information, in most 3D lobby designs, they will be placed in the four corners of the screen, including 2 reasons:

(1). Information residing in the corners does not affect players’ exploration and substitution of space;
(2). For information in the corner, players can quickly locate it, and the line of sight or interactive tools (mouse) do not need to be specifically searched to move to the information area. This design is also in line with “Fitts’s Law”.

 

《Star Citizen》: Player information in the 3D lobby is in the lower left corner of the screen

Give Players Necessary Help Information

In the game, the role of the lobby function is more like a product. Therefore, when designing the information hierarchy of the 3D lobby, you can learn from some product interaction concepts, such as Nielsen’s ten usability principles of “Help and documentation”.

The Help and documentation principle means that it is best if the system allows users to use it without reading the documentation, but help documentation is usually still needed. Any information should be easy to search, focus on the user’s tasks, and list specific steps to inform the user.

In the 3D lobby space scene, players may be confused about how and where to open some functions. Therefore, some games use the form of resident HUD to help players understand the shortcut keys of some operations. For example, the 3D lobby mode of Naraka: Bladepoint - Penglai Island provides shortcut key prompts for various shortcut operations.

The information of this nature is to help players better integrate into the operation of the game, so it will also be at the top of the information hierarchy, and the positioning in the plane will also refer to the location of important information, that is, at the edge of the screen and does not affect the player’s experience of the scene.

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Operation prompts on the left and top and the “Start Game” entrance in the lower right corner

–.

 

《The Division 2》 Map in the upper left corner

Properly Bury Information Clues

Although the game lobby is a role of a transportation hub, it is actually one of the links in the game. Therefore, in the presentation of information, it is still necessary to maintain a certain degree of fun to stimulate players’ interest in exploring the 3D space. In the process of exploration, it can also increase players’ understanding of the worldview and game background, and discover the small easter eggs buried by the designers. However, when choosing this information, it is necessary to pay attention to that they will not affect the player’s main operations and main process, so as to avoid negative impact on the main process.

 

《Identity V》 The reminder of the operation is combined with the item

–.

 

In 《Fallout 76》, viewing the mailbox needs to be opened in the computer in the room

3. Middle Layer Control: Reasonable “Display” or “Hiding” of Information

Players move constantly in the 3D lobby, which causes their spatial position to change. For example, when a player is attracted to an item or scene, they will move. Therefore, the prompt information in the scene is also constantly moving relative to the character. In addition, as the distance increases, the information in the space will gradually disappear. Therefore, while considering the information hierarchy, it is also necessary to comprehensively consider the player’s wishes and the impact on immersion.

Give Players the Right to Choose

When players are exposed to the new lobby design form of the 3D lobby, they naturally also hope to be able to explore the entire scene and its details. When they can generate the feeling that they have replaced the characters in it, they have largely mastered some basic game operations. At this time, some HUD information in the scene is not suitable for display. If players can choose to display or hide independently, it will be able to greatly enhance the player’s “environmental immersion”. This is also very much in line with the “User control and freedom” principle of the ten usability principles.

In The Division 2, players can turn off the HUD display in the settings to enhance the immersive experience of the game.

 

《The Division 2》 After hiding the HUD

Weaken the Visual Effect of Indicative Information

In fact, in more and more AAA masterpieces, the presentation of some visual effects will be more and more restrained. The purpose is also to allow players to better invest in the game’s worldview and plot. This purpose coincides with the 3D lobby. The linear design style can better weaken the distraction of UI on players’ attention during the experience. In some designs, it will be used: when the player approaches, it will display and prompt the specific function, and when the player is still a certain distance away, it will only provide instructions to indicate that “there is a function that can be operated in this area”.

For example, in The Division 2, when the player approaches, the interface will prompt the function of the area and click to open the operation panel. In Star Citizen, the operation of the function is bound to the items in the scene. When the player is far away, only the prompt is seen, and when approaching, the specific function can be opened.

 

《The Division 2》 Open new function

–.

 

《Star Citizen》 Open function after approaching

As for the scale of weakening information and how close the player is to pop up the prompt of the function, it depends on the game designer’s choice of scene and the map size of the 3D lobby. When the picture is at a wide angle, indicative information can be displayed when the player moves continuously for 3 units; when the picture is at close range, too much information will affect the player’s experience. However, these considerations also need to be determined according to the actual situation of the game.

Strengthen Target Information in the 3D Lobby

For the content that players need to decipher and pass in the 3D lobby, these target information can be relatively stronger. For these functions, it is more hoped that players can go to understand, and then promote players’ understanding of the game’s worldview and background. For example, in the decryption information in the lobby of Identity V, the visual intensity will be stronger than the light on the wall, which is also hoped to attract players’ attention in this way, and explore and discover secrets in this castle.

 

The presentation of sub-functions in 《Identity V》

The “Cloud Top Racing” gameplay in Naraka: Bladepoint Penglai Island is similar. This gameplay aims to enhance the fun experience of players in the lobby scene and exercise operational skills. The designer strengthened the entrance of the game by marking the wooden sign of the “Cloud Top Racing” gameplay, and attracted the attention of players.

 

Entrance of Cloud Top Racing in 《Naraka: Bladepoint》

4. Top-level Presentation: Visual Packaging Combined with Worldview

A very important part of visual hierarchy design is how to make information appear in the player’s field of vision without being obtrusive, which requires better integration with the worldview. The most common example is that science fiction games usually have a helmet or monitor for the player’s character, and some information can be displayed on the player’s screen through the form of HUD, which can also bring a stronger sense of immersion.

Display Information Based on Game Background

As visual animals, humans are easily affected by what their eyes see. When experiencing the game, the first thing we come into contact with is the visual design of the “game lobby”. If this design can be closely integrated with the game’s worldview, it can bring players a better environmental sensory experience.

And the creation of the environment is not only the work of art designers and scene designers, but as interaction designers, they also need to better integrate information with the scene, and need to distinguish between functional entrances and ordinary embellishment entrances; at the same time, they can allow players to view some important information at any time, avoiding being immersed in the environment and losing curiosity about the core gameplay. For example, in Splatoon 3, designers display the displayed information through graffiti, and make a short stay for the information of other players.

 

Graffiti information in 《Splatoon 3》

More Combination of Information Content and Scene

There will be a lot of items, buildings and other content in the 3D lobby. Designers can consider doing more scenario design in this scene. While ensuring the display of basic information, designers had better leave more space for the display of environment and scenes, and will change the background according to the changes of marketing activities. On this basis, some information can be placed in the scene, such as the name of the place, instructions for secondary operations, and so on. The purpose of doing so is also to help players in the process of exploring the lobby, gradually generate the idea of “I am the character”.

For example, the entrance to the battle in Splatoon 3 is placed in a building, and players can enter the battle mode selection by entering the building; also in this game, the newly launched function “locker”, players can customize their own lockers in a personalized way, and have more communication and interaction with other players.

 

Game start entrance and locker function in 《Splatoon 3》

5. Conclusion

Today, the design of 3D lobbies is becoming more and more abundant. Designers have added more new gameplay to the scene and space to ensure that players will not feel bored and uninteresting in the lobby. These innovations and optimizations aim to make players more immersive in the game world while gaining more fun. At the same time, the information in the scene is also becoming more and more, and the information density is also getting higher and higher. Therefore, designers need to carefully and rigorously design the visual hierarchy of information to enhance the player’s sense of substitution, environmental sensory experience and immersion in the game.

entry.title: So, it can be done like this — Recontextualization of Game Experience Design
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

1. Context

What is context?

Context refers to the environment when using language. Context can usually be divided into two types: narrow and broad. Narrowly defined, it refers to the linguistic environment formed by the context of written language or the preceding and following words of spoken language; broadly defined, it refers to the specific environment of language expression (which can refer to specific occasions or social environment).

In addition to the objective environment, context is also related to the background knowledge in the minds of each user and expresser.

What is recontextualization?

“Recontextualization” is a sociolinguistic concept summarized by Per Linell, which refers to extracting a piece of discourse from its original context and placing it in a new context, and this new context may change the meaning and understanding of the discourse. This method is often used in various media and contexts such as news reports, political discourse, and advertising. In the words of the German poet Novalis, the role of recontextualization is to “make the familiar strange and the strange familiar”.

For example, “killing the chicken to get the eggs” originally meant to literally kill the chicken in order to get the eggs; it is a metaphor for coveting immediate benefits without considering long-term interests. In “Let the Bullets Fly”, the “killing the chicken to get the eggs” in Master Huang’s context refers to getting rid of Zhang Mazi and taking back the diamonds.

For another example, the “original display” we see when visiting a museum is a “recontextualization” of the excavated/preserved cultural relics: giving new value to the cultural relics in a new time and space. Visitors re-experience the era background of the cultural relics and their possible functions and meanings through the museum’s layout and curation.

 

Beijing Satellite TV “The Palace Museum” Hall of Supreme Harmony original display

Design Context

The design context refers to the environment, background, and cultural factors of the design work, as well as the interaction between the design work and the surrounding environment, users, and society. The design context determines the actual effect and meaning of the design work.

For example, a commonly used household chopstick holder is designed with many openings for ventilation to prevent the chopsticks from being closed, damp, and deteriorating. This design in the outdoor context allows it to be used as a firewood stove. The porous structure cleverly ensures sufficient oxygen conditions for starting a fire.

 

Blogger Camping Glutton purchases a combined chopstick holder firewood stove

Game Experience Design Context

The game’s worldview is a complex that encompasses architecture, space, scenes, art style, economy, system, and social customs. It encompasses the physical environment, cultural environment, and social environment in the design context, affecting the visual effects, cultural meanings, and values of the design content.

The interaction between the game and the player means that the game and the player are symbionts under the same worldview. Factors such as the player’s game goals and needs, usage habits, operating behaviors, and psychological state during use are as important as the worldview in affecting the use effect and user satisfaction of the design content. For example, in “Minecraft”, the large amount of real-world UGC content created by players continues to inject new vitality into the game.

 

《Minecraft》 Alras Industrial - Medieval Ax City Reconstruction

Therefore, in game experience design, considering the context is very important, it can help developers better understand the usage scenarios and needs of functions, so as to better meet user needs and improve player satisfaction. At the same time, considering the context can also help developers create design works with more cultural connotations and social value, and improve the artistry and innovation of design works.

2. Recontextualization in Games

Recontextualization in games refers to the game introducing new mechanisms or informing new information, so that players can (voluntarily) experience existing content in a new way, that is, a way to revitalize existing content. Common application methods in games include the following two types:

  • Mechanical Recontextualization: Refers to the process of players experiencing familiar environments and content by using new mechanisms or props.
  • Knowledge Recontextualization: Refers to the process of players experiencing existing content from different angles/paths through the transfer of prior knowledge.

An excellent example of recontextualization in game design is Hitman 2, where developers, through the design of “identity roles” and their “scope of activities” and “mission objectives”, allow players to have multiple “recontextualization” experiences, and even bring a “lingering” game experience.

In this game, players can eliminate NPCs of different class identities and clothing to disguise themselves as characters with different identity permissions, and then enter different areas of the map with different open levels. The single game map and the number of NPCs are fixed. In order to complete various challenges on the same map, players need to repeatedly explore and replay between different roles and areas using existing knowledge to achieve all challenge goals. At the same time, with the different identity roles of the player, the tasks that the current role needs to complete, the dangers in the scene, and the boundary prompts will also change.

 

《Hitman 2》 Players can enter the smuggling cave by disguising themselves as hippies

3. How to Use Recontextualization to Do a Good Job in Game Experience Design

From a macro perspective, the game itself is a way to “recontextualize” the content it carries. Overall, there is only one core idea: “As long as I want to do it and I can do it, then I can do it”. But how to let players achieve this excellent experience of “thinking what I think, doing what I can” in experience design?

In the following content, we combine the experience design of Naraka: Bladepoint‘s Penglai Island Cloud Top Race to further explain how to use the design idea of recontextualization in the game:

Penglai Island is a three-dimensional social environment launched by Naraka: Bladepoint in its 2nd anniversary version, and Cloud Top Race is a section of architectural and stone ruins located in the southern part of Silver阙 Garden. Players can enter this area from the south of Silver阙 Garden. When players pass through this area within 360 seconds and reach the race finish line on the west side of Secret Source Island, they can get certain race rewards.

 

Cloud Top Race track map area

Broaden the Scope and Boundaries of Experience

When designing a certain gameplay or function, in addition to listing all control states and sorting out the process, it is also necessary to consider all the operating processes of the player before, during, and after use. If possible, without interfering with other content and enriching the function, multiple entry or exit experience paths can be set for the same content to meet most of the possibilities of player exploration.

 

Cloud Top Race game rules

When designing the Cloud Top Race function of Penglai Island, it was not stipulated how players would reach the finish line, or what tools they would use. Only the most commonly used fast displacement prop in the game, [Grappling Hook], was triggered to increase the time. This can be regarded as a method reminder for reaching the finish line. In the actual experience process, players can follow the game’s teaching of jumping, grappling hook, wall strike, or even various combinations to reach the finish line in the fastest way, and they are all allowed.

Find Experience Mappings in Reality

In addition to simulating various behaviors that players may have, it is also necessary to further consider the source of gameplay and functions. Whether there are similar experience contents in reality. Sort out the experience processes of the two and correspond them one by one, reduce the keyboard and mouse interaction links in the design, and make the entire experience process more natural.

When designing the interaction between the start and finish lines of Cloud Top Race, the design team did not use the common general mechanism interaction in the game (ie, press [E]), but made a regional interaction behavior trigger logic, which can be very clearly found on it analogous to the experience process of most sports competitions in reality: players can start racing from entering the game area, start timing after crossing the “start line”, and stop timing and get rewards when reaching the finish line “crossing the line”.

 

Comparison of the experience process of Cloud Top Race and sports competition athletes

Optimize the Low Emotional Feedback Content in the Experience

Although the above process mentions that it is necessary to analogy the “known” experience of players in reality to design the process of gameplay/functions, it is also necessary to pay attention to continuously providing players with positive feedback during this process. That is, on the premise of ensuring the fairness of the game content, adjust the low emotional feedback nodes in the real experience, avoid excessive frustration, and keep the player’s emotions on the basic emotional baseline of the game during the experience.

In the race, the player’s use of the grappling hook prop itself can be regarded as a way to quickly move and reduce the fair racing experience, but the designer did not impose an “irreversible penalty” on the player, such as canceling the result in sports competitions, but used the analogy between movement distance and grappling hook, and used increasing timing to complete the basic punishment method for the player. Moreover, in many players’ racing processes, using the grappling hook when accidentally making a mistake in the middle of the race can also be used as an effective strategy to “avoid restarting”. Many skilled players can complete the entire race within 50 seconds even with a single use of the grappling hook.

 

Comparison of grappling hook time increase mechanism and foul knee bending score penalty mechanism

At the same time, in order to avoid the player’s emotional depression during the race, the target point prompt will be refreshed in time within a certain range during the race to help the player find the official racing track direction and avoid the player’s emotional low tide caused by direction loss; basic reward props are set for players with different racing durations to ensure the basic acquisition experience of players.

 

Direction prompts and target point information during the race

After familiarizing yourself with “recontextualization” and this design idea, we can see that in addition to the large gameplay that can perfectly fit its design process, many small design details in the game also hide the ingenuity of “recontextualization”. For example, in the Naraka: Bladepoint maps of Griffin’s Nest and Fire Nation, a large number of small animals that conform to the characteristics of the scene and season can obtain prop rewards after being killed, and shooting down the Spring Festival targets flying in the air will also drop different rewards.

 

Small animals in different terrains in the Fire Nation map

–.

 

Spring Festival targets of different colors in the Fire Nation map

–.

 

Players shoot down the golden Spring Festival target and drop the golden soul jade

Design Considerations

The application of “recontextualization” in experience design can be regarded as a design method that can move the game four or two: it can expand the scope and possibilities of the game to infinity through limited content. However, due to the limitations of recontextualization design, this effect will only have a significant positive feedback effect in “non-linear” or “multi-map” games (that is, players do not need to complete the single-process game content according to a single timeline), such as the association design of A-side and B-side in Celeste, allowing players to enter the original level multiple times to experience new content.

 

《Celeste》 The player accidentally learned the charged super jump in the A-side content

At the same time, these “recontextualized” contents basically use more complex scene design and level connections in order to “create enough possibilities”, and often require more cost and time to develop. Some content details may not be discovered by players until the game disappears from the market.

As The Stanley Parable developer Pugh said, “The production of these contents is like shouting at the void. It may take two years before you can hear the echo from the other end of the void, because someone finally heard your silent shout from the cacophony.” However, it is precisely because these game designers continue to scrutinize and sculpt works of art that we can glimpse their state of mind at that time across time and space during the experience, and complete a spiritual adventure.

 

《The Stanley Parable》 The player continues to enter the wrong password multiple times, and the door will also open by itself

4. Conclusion

When we were children, we ran around downstairs at home, which constituted our first impression of the outside road. But when you learn to ride a bicycle, skateboard, or even drive, roads of different materials and widths have unique meanings in your eyes. From the first time you play games with a keyboard and mouse to later contacting different platforms and devices, the same game also produces new experiences in your eyes.

The powerful positive feedback brought by recontextualization design is essentially based on the player’s desire for learning and exploration and discovery, and the source of its happiness is the player’s original intention of being curious about the world. Please stay curious and continue to explore this world. Perhaps behind many of the contents you find with surprise, there is a carnival in the heart of a designer.

entry.title: Games Have Backups Too - Why Do We Need Secondary Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

1. What are Main/Secondary Games?

The concept of “main game, secondary game” has been around for quite some time, mainly because the content design of some games on the market greatly reduces the burden on players, allowing them to experience the game content flexibly, saving them worry and effort.

In this way, players who like to watch live broadcasts will also find that many game streamers open some casual games (such as Dou Dizhu) while waiting for matchmaking. On the one hand, the matchmaking waiting time is indeed too long, and they can’t just wait. On the other hand, it can also add some effect to the live broadcast and interact with fans. This is not a phenomenon unique to live broadcast rooms. Many players will also play a round of Dota Auto Chess while resting after playing DOTA.

Many players will play multiple games at the same time, and the concept of “main game” and “secondary game” has gradually become popular. Sometimes it’s even “a solid secondary game, a flowing main game”. Main games and secondary games may not be specifically distinguished at the beginning, but are divided according to the time and energy invested. For example, in Justice Online Mobile, the game is large and there is a lot of content to explore; and as the player’s level increases and gradually unlocks guilds, homes, etc., a sense of belonging will gradually develop. Over time, while playing other games, they will also subconsciously set aside a certain amount of time for this game; while in comparison, secondary games focus more on the immediate feeling.

 

So, are all “lightweight games” “secondary games”?

Obviously not. The so-called main and secondary games have nothing to do with the game category itself, but are a relative concept. For each player, they can have their own “main game” and “secondary game”. Generally speaking, secondary games often have the following relative characteristics:

  • Less time spent: On average, players spend less time and energy in this game than in other main games they play.
  • Less economic expenditure: For most players, the investment of money is often proportional to the love of the game. This is also true for buyout games. Players are willing to pay for better-made games, and they are also willing to collect different versions of games for their feelings, even if this requires repeated expenditure.
  • Less emotional investment: Players of many games will spontaneously become “volunteers” for their favorite games, giving good reviews, promoting, and vigorously promoting the game. Those who are capable will also “generate electricity with love” and create more derivative products related to the game. However, players generally do not invest in this level of effort for secondary games.
  • More single game goal: Secondary games often only meet a part of the player’s most core game experience needs, rather than meeting multiple needs at once.
  • Weaker social connections: Except for some secondary games that are only experienced for social reasons, most players invest less time, energy, and emotion in experiencing secondary games, and hardly establish complex social relationships outside of experiencing the game.

2. Why Do Players Play Secondary Games?

As mentioned in the previous section, secondary games often meet a certain part of the player’s game experience needs. Conversely, games that can simultaneously meet multiple core game experiences of players are more likely to become the main games that players invest in for a long time. This is also the fundamental reason why many games continue to expand gameplay, polish game content, and improve game experience: to attract and retain more players.

In the realm of philosophy, it is mentioned that in the process of things developing, the principal contradiction is in a dominant position, regulating or influencing other contradictions. As for game selection, when players find that one of their needs can be better matched with a certain game, they may choose to experience a secondary game.

For example, after a player experiences an extremely intense ranked match, “rest and relaxation” becomes their most urgent need; when waiting in line and not knowing when they will be called, what the player needs is a game that “starts and plays immediately, and will not be penalized for quitting”; on a train shuttling between mountains, “not afraid of lag” is the player’s most basic appeal; at a multiplayer offline party, friends enthusiastically invite, even if they don’t like this type of game, they will be willing to play with friends… At different times, players choose secondary games with different standards, but they are all closely related to the current needs. When these restrictions are no longer present, players will still return to their main game, because they have invested more energy here and can get more of the game experience they need.

This also causes the player’s main and secondary games to change or even switch over time. Students have more entertainment time and can spend more time completing daily tasks, “replacing krypton with liver”; and after entering the working state, time becomes precious, and they need to “spend money to buy time”.

3. How to Make Players Love Playing Secondary Games More?

The market for secondary games is pioneering. Everyone’s time and energy are limited, and it is unrealistic to try to make players experience multiple main games at the same time. Although secondary games mean that players invest less, but many small amounts add up. Many games have gained a good reputation for their excellent quality and precise user insights. For example, Tabi Kaeru (Travel Frog), launched in 2017, made many players keen to “raise a frog son”, and ranked first on the App Store China free game list without an official Chinese version. In many cases, the competitors of secondary games are not only other games, but also all things that will attract users’ attention.

 

How to make players more willing to experience a secondary game? We can learn a thing or two from the design of many hyper-casual games:

  • Easy to learn, simple to operate: A low game entry threshold can help the game be accessed and mastered by a wider range of players. Common gameplays of hyper-casual games such as puzzles, synthesis, stacking, racing, etc., players can almost learn at a glance and master the core gameplay in a short time. The operating frequency in the game is not high, the requirements for the player’s instantaneous response are low, or automatic pathfinding, automatic combat, and other methods are used;
  • Small levels, short process: During the game process, players are not required to have high concentration and do not need to keep staring at the screen. Make full use of fragmented time, players can open the game anytime, anywhere, and there is no strict end time point, and the experience of entering and leaving is relatively smooth.
  • Simple numerical design: The in-game cycle is relatively direct, and the acquisition and consumption paths of currency/props are clear. However, simple values do not necessarily mean that the game has no depth and is abandoned after 1 hour. Through algorithms, many games can automatically generate hundreds of levels.

In addition, there are some experiences that can provide inspiration for our design of secondary games:

  • Relevance to the main game: Dota Auto Chess uses the worldview, races, heroes, skills, and equipment system settings of DOTA, so that DOTA players can naturally get started with the game quickly and are more willing to stay in it, which plays a good supplementary role with some players’ main game DOTA;
  • Reduced burden of daily tasks: There is no need for complicated login and task systems to tie up players’ time. Players can take some time to experience the game content for a period of time at one time, and it is not mandatory to go online every day or every hour;
  • More compensation rewards, less penalty mechanisms: Even if the player is not online, they can still get growth in the game, such as offline rewards, experience compensation, etc.; and even if the player quits halfway, there will be no direct punishment, and there is no psychological burden.

4. Summary

Lowering the quality because it is positioned as a secondary game? This is not acceptable to players and the market, and becoming a “secondary game” is not an excuse for game manufacturers to slack off. Letting players “meet major needs with low investment” is the standard of a successful secondary game, even if the player only stays in this game for a few hours, has watched the plot once and cleared the level, or has experienced the first 30 levels. I hope that when players look back and think of this game, they will praise it: “At that time, it was very interesting”.

entry.title: Free if You Don't Buy: Analyzing Popular Games that Went Free-to-Play
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

1. Mainstream Game Payment Models

You’ve probably heard the saying, “Buy early, enjoy early; buy late, enjoy discounts; don’t buy, get it for free.” After a game’s initial priced release, there’s usually a relatively long period of price stability, which is the main source of revenue for new games in their early stages. After a period of stable operation, there might be limited-time discounts at certain points, such as during Steam sales, to attract hesitant players.

And for some games, the final stage is to completely remove the payment barrier after a long period of operation and switch to free-to-play. PUBG, released in 2017 with an initial price of $29.99 (98 yuan in China), became a free-to-play game in January 2022. Fall Guys, released in August 2020 with an initial price of $19.99 (58 yuan in China), became free-to-play in June 2022. Overwatch went free-to-play when its sequel, Overwatch 2, was released.

 

In summary, whether in China or abroad, there are mainly three payment models for online games: The first is buy-to-play, where you pay to purchase the experience qualification and obtain permanent access to the game after payment; examples include Rainbow Six Siege, New World, and Baldur’s Gate 3.

The second is free-to-play, where there is no barrier to entry, replaced mainly by in-game store purchases. Examples include DOTA 2 and Apex Legends.

The third is a time-based subscription model, where players purchase points to exchange for game time, paying for how much they play. Examples include World of Warcraft and Fantasy Westward Journey. This payment model will not be discussed in this article.

So, what are the advantages and disadvantages of these different payment models? Why do some developers choose to switch from paid to free, and what issues do game companies need to face when making this decision?

Buy-to-Play Games

For buy-to-play games, the main advantages are:

  • Game quality is usually relatively higher: Generally speaking, with similar investment budgets, the quality of buy-to-play games is relatively higher than that of free games. They need to attract players to overcome the payment barrier and try the game with quality. If the manufacturer does not have excellent graphics and core gameplay, it will be difficult to obtain sufficient revenue and reputation from selling the game. Compared with free games that profit from in-game stores, buy-to-play games save a lot of development and design resources on payment and long-term content. Therefore, they have enough manpower and resources to invest in game quality, concentrate on targeted design, and provide players with a better gaming experience.

  • Has a certain threshold, fewer cheaters: For players who use illegal software, they need to pay for the game again for each account they change. Increasing the cost of cheating for players by buying out also has a certain inhibitory effect on the proliferation of cheating to a certain extent.

Of course, sometimes the threshold limit is also one of its shortcomings. The mode of paying to purchase an admission ticket will also prevent some players from entering the game, especially since most AAA games are not cheap at the time of their initial release, which will become a factor hindering players from purchasing the game for players with different consumption levels.

Free Games

For free games, the biggest advantage is that there is no threshold. As long as the device can handle it, anyone can enter the game and experience it. Although everyone has different game preferences, and many players will find that they are not the target audience and lose interest in the game after trying it out, due to the large base of new players, the number of players who finally stay in the game may be more than that of some buy-to-play games.

Why do companies like Bluehole, Valve, and Activision Blizzard choose to make originally paid games free? From the data point of view, when making such a decision, the game is likely to have gone downhill for a while, and the number of retained players continues to decrease. Switching to free-to-play is also largely to attract more players who are kept out by the payment barrier. PUBG, a once-phenomenal game, has seen its DAU continue to decline since it reached its online peak in 2018 due to various reasons. By the end of 2021, the average number of online players in the game had fallen below 150,000, and the peak online was only about one-tenth of the peak. After announcing the switch to free-to-play, many free players poured in, the peak number of online players in the game almost doubled, and the average number of online players also increased significantly. Fall Guys, also a game that requires a high number of concurrent players, had very strong data in the early days of its launch, but as its popularity gradually declined, its developers were also considering how to extend the life of the game. After its decision to switch to free-to-play, the total number of players worldwide quickly exceeded 20 million, and exceeded 50 million within 2 weeks, further achieving a large-scale breakthrough in the user base.

 

PUBG experienced a peak online of more than 3.2 million in 2018, and the number of players continued to decline.

2. What Issues Should Be Paid Attention to When a Game Goes Free-to-Play?

Although the effect is good, going free-to-play is not a tool that a game can casually use to attract players. If the following problems are not properly handled, it may have the opposite effect.

Compensation for Veteran Players Needs to Be in Place

Players who purchased the game before it went free-to-play are people who spent real money to buy the game and experience it. For developers, this part of the players needs more attention and maintenance. Game manufacturers cannot only focus on attracting new players and not do their best to retain existing veteran players. If the compensation given by the manufacturer to veteran players is sincere and attractive enough, it will also attract a large number of veteran players to return; if the compensation is stingy, veteran players will not only not buy it, but may also give the game a bad review because they feel betrayed, ruining the reputation.

 

In this regard, Naraka: Bladepoint directly returned the money spent by veteran players to purchase the game in equal proportion as in-game currency when it went free-to-play, so that everyone said “misunderstanding resolved” after learning about the compensation benefits, and called it a great deal; there were even many new players who directly purchased the game at the original price after seeing the news, and then waited for the refund of gold ingots. On the day of the free-to-play launch, Naraka: Bladepoint sold another 1 million copies, once again climbing to the second place on the Steam sales list, and even the official website was overloaded by enthusiastic players.

 

Live broadcast of Naraka: Bladepoint announcing free-to-play (left) and announcing compensation rewards for veteran players (right)

Anti-Cheat Work

When a game becomes free, it means that there is no payment barrier for anyone to enter the game, and the soil of low account cost is particularly prone to breeding cheating and forming a proliferation. In a fair competitive environment, it is devastating to the game experience of normal players. When criminals can cheat at almost no cost, the gaming experience of normal players will be greatly affected. Especially for tactical competitive games, one cheating player will affect nearly 60 or even 100 normal players in the same game. One-shot headshots and ignoring control make the game experience very bad.

Before going free-to-play, PUBG has been criticized by players for cheating. After going free-to-play, it did not make effective restrictions on cheating. It only launched casual mode and competitive mode to separate paid players and free players when it switched to free. However, not all players are keen on competitive mode. In a mode where cheating is rampant and cannot be banned for a long time, any type of player will have a hard time having a good gaming experience.

Fall Guys, which also became a free-to-play game in 2022, has also been plagued by cheating, and is jokingly called “Fairy Bean Man” by players. The gameplay of Fall Guys is a casual level-breaking type, and the number of players in a single game is also large. One person cheating can make all players in this game restart directly.

 

Before going free-to-play, Naraka: Bladepoint also realized that once the game is open for free play, a large number of players will flood in, including criminals who intend to cheat. To this end, the development team made preparations in advance and banned 2,754 players who used cheats on the day of the free-to-play launch; at the same time, they also deducted the rank points of 163 players who “rode the cheat car” to warn all new and old players not to try to benefit from cheating, and to maintain a fair game environment in a timely manner.

New Player’s Novice Period Experience Issues

For new players, getting started with an old game that has been in operation for a period of time has a high cost. Veteran players have gone through a lot of training and have mastered many game skills, but new players don’t know anything when they enter the game, which can easily bring them some uncontrollable frustration. After the game goes free-to-play, on the one hand, the game needs to optimize the novice guide, teaching and other onboarding issues to lead new players to quickly master the game. Especially for some new players who have not necessarily been familiar with action games before, this group of non-core players and general players especially need strong novice guidance to teach and retain them. On the other hand, the game also needs to make more optimizations in the matching mechanism, reasonably allocate the rank difference of players in the game, and prevent the “smurfing” behavior of veteran players from leading to the direct churn of new players.

Novice guidance has always been a very important module of Naraka: Bladepoint. When it went free-to-play, the game deliberately added a lot of special training in the practice mode, including basic parry practice, charged attack followed by parry practice, jump parry practice, and higher-level operations such as dodge parry and grapple parry. Many of these operations require players to accumulate a certain amount of game time and number of games, and they can only be mastered skillfully after learning in actual combat. Putting them in the practice mode can facilitate players who are not familiar with action operations to carry out more practical exercises, accelerate the learning efficiency, and experience the joy of parrying faster.

 

Naraka: Bladepoint’s new novice special training module

3. Conclusion

Going free-to-play is not a panacea for a game to revive when its popularity declines. If the decision to go free-to-play and the compensation plan are not fully considered, it may backfire and accelerate the decline of the game. Going free-to-play needs to carefully consider the different needs of new and old players, and ensure the game experience of all types of players, so that the game can have more players to play when it goes free-to-play, and the environment in the game can develop in a more balanced and healthy direction.
